title: Syria militant group HTS forms 'reform committees' amid protests
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An authority linked to Syrian militant group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) has said it has formed community committees to implement reforms amid protests against its rule.
body:
The Salvation Government's political affairs bureau announced the measures in a statement published on 7 March via Telegram and X.

The move appeared to be an attempt to address public discontent with HTS's governance in north-western Syria, where protests against its rule have taken place since February.

The statement said that the HTS-backed authority had held meetings with local leaders, activists and journalists to listen and respond to concerns.

In response to feedback, it has set up community committees to quickly implement "genuine" reforms and expand participatory governance.

The statement said other institutions were being developed for oversight and complaint resolution.

It stressed that the group's "revolutionary project" was an ongoing experiment that required collective efforts to ensure continuous improvement.

On 5 March, the HTS Shura Council issued decrees that announced that seven committees had been formed in areas such as Idlib city, Ariha, Atmeh and Jisr al-Shughur.

The decrees said the six or seven-member committees would engage with residents to address local needs and receive complaints.

They said the committees would provide assistance and facilitate communication between residents and the Salvation Government to improve services.

The announcements come amid protests in HTS-held areas that have demanded the release of detained "revolutionaries" and accused the group of torture in its prisons.

Protestors have also called for the resignation of HTS leader Abu Muhammad al-Jawlani.

This week, HTS said it released former senior member Abu Mariya al-Qahtani, who had been detained since last summer on espionage charges.

Al-Qahtani's release was part of a broader amnesty that also saw the release of hundreds of prisoners swept up in a crackdown on alleged spies among its ranks.

See more: Briefing: HTS clears and releases senior member after months in custody

HTS-linked governing authority orders release of hundreds of prisoners

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 0800 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of Sudan TV news 2000 gmt 19 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on state-owned Sudan TV on 19 March at 19:00 GMT

2000 Main headlines
body:
2001 The authorities in Sennar State received the member of the Sovereign Council, Lt Gen  Yasser al-Atta, who visited the state to assess the preparedness of the armed forces to reclaim Gezira State from Rapid Support Force rebels. Video report.

2005 Al-Atta confirmed that all necessary arrangements have been made to eradicate the Rapid Support Force and restore order in Gezira State and Khartoum State. He reassured the Sudanese populace that the armed forces are in control of the situation as they advance towards the western states.

2007 Lt Gen  Yasser al-Atta, also met with the collective leadership of the 17th Infantry Division in Singa, alongside the Sennar Air Defense and state government officials. 

2009 Lt Gen  Yasser al-Atta, conducted an inspection of the 18th Infantry Division in White Nile state. He met with the State Security Committee, chaired by Police Brigadier Saif al-Din Ahmed, where detailed reports were reviewed to ensure effective coordination among all security agencies. The meeting yielded directives to enhance state’s security measures.

2011 Culture and information minister Graham Abdulqadir met with the acting Indian Ambassador to Sudan Mr. Joshi Jesse, Consul Anil Kumar, and the Indian delegation in Port Sudan. They discussed India's assistance in rehabilitating the Sudanese Broadcasting Corporation in Omdurman after it was recaptured from the RSF militia. They agreed to provide a detailed study on the rehabilitation needs as requested by the India.

2012 Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research, Prof. Mohamed Hassan Zahab, commended certain university administrations for their efforts in creating conducive academic environments and ensuring stability. During a meeting with university directors in Port Sudan, he reaffirmed the ministry's commitment to supporting all university programs to maintain academic stability amid ongoing activities. Zahab also expressed readiness to assist universities affected by conflict.

2014 Health Minister of Khartoum State attended the inauguration of Bar Al-Walidain Hospital in Khartoum's 21st neighborhood, alongside governor Ahmed Osman Hamza and health officials. The minister praised the hospital's opening amid wartime challenges, emphasizing its significance for the community. Governor Hamza also commended the Federal Health Ministry for its support in improving healthcare services across the region. Video report.

2019 A tour conducted by Khartoum governor Ahmed Osman Hamza and federal health minister Haitham Mohamed Ibrahim, along with their accompanying delegation, unveiled extensive vandalism at government hospitals in Omdurman locality. Video report.

2023 Governor Ahmed Osman Hamza of Khartoum State officially opened a branch of Khartoum Bank in the Seventh Revolution neighborhood, marking the resumption of banking operations in Khartoum. The Federal Health Minister, present at the event, hailed the move as a positive sign amid the armed forces' victories, underscoring the region's restored security. Video report.

2027 Governor Ahmed Osman Hamza of Khartoum State assessed the traffic police's performance in the first quarter of 2024, particularly focusing on vehicle licensing and citizen transactions with the traffic department in safe areas. This occurred during his leadership of a meeting with director of Khartoum State Traffic, Maj Gen Ahmed Ali Al-Khalifa, and director of roads and bridges authority, Mukhtar Saber. The governor instructed the authorities to streamline traffic services and deploy traffic forces in liberated areas.

2028 The sixth infantry division in El Fasher city in North Darfur commemorated the successes of the armed forces and the liberation of the Sudanese Broadcasting Corporation buildings in Omdurman from the Rapid Support Forces.

2029 The governor of Gezira State, Taher Ibrahim Al Khair, highlighted the ongoing provision of exceptional healthcare services despite the country's challenging circumstances. He made these remarks at the inauguration of the Health Insurance Center in the 24th locality of Al Qurashi, a significant addition to the state's healthcare sector. The governor, accompanied by the director of the national intelligence agency, brigadier Imad Al-Din Sayed Ahmed, emphasized the center's role in delivering essential services to its beneficiaries as part of the comprehensive health insurance coverage expansion.

2029 The acting governor of North Darfur state, Hafiz Bakheet Mohamed, presided over a meeting of the state government's cabinet ministers. The meeting included discussed reports from various service ministries. The president of the supreme council for culture and media, Khalid Yousef Abdel Rahim, emphasized the council's briefing on agricultural activities and early preparations for the upcoming season, including livestock surveys. The meeting underscored the significance of agricultural seasons and the need for timely preparations.

2031 Acting governor Mohammed Musa Abdul Rahman of Kassala State witnessed the signing of a partnership agreement between the government and the private sector. The agreement, between the Ministry of Finance and Labor of Kassala State and the United Tuteel Projects Company, aims to rehabilitate and operate the Kassala Printing and Publishing Authority. The governor emphasized the project's significance in revitalizing the printing press to accommodate various publications.

2033 The acting governor of Kassala State, Mohammed Musa Abdul Rahman, chaired a collaborative meeting with the Ministry of Production and Economic Resources and the Executive Unit for Taming the Qash River. The meeting brought together representatives from the Federal Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources, focusing on excavation and irrigation activities. Discussions centered on the progress of taming the Qash River and ensuring groundwater recharge to provide drinking water for both humans and animals.

2035 The Najashi Charitable Organization, in partnership with the Islamic Education Association of Bahrain, launched the Iftar and Ramadan food basket project at the Arous Al Ramal displacement center in El Obeid City in North Kordofan State. The initiative aims to assist those affected by the war, providing essential support to vulnerable families. Director Salah Hamdou highlighted the program's coverage of all refugee centers, praising the exceptional partnership with the Islamic Education Association of Bahrain.

2038 The acting governor of North Kordofan State, Abd Al-Khaliq Abd Al-Latif, addressed the opening session of the first training course for journalists titled "Journalists' Safety in Conflict Zones." The course, organized by the Press Committee of the High Committee for Mobilization and Preparedness, aims to enhance journalists' safety and bolster the media's role in supporting the populace, popular resistance efforts, and supporting the armed forces.

2041 End of bulletin 

Source: Sudan TV, Omdurman, in Arabic 1900 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 19 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Hamas approves new ceasefire proposal
body:
Hamas has said it accepts the latest proposal for a Gaza ceasefire.

In a brief post on Telegram yesterday, "Hamas and the Palestinian factions announced their approval of the proposal presented to them by Egyptian and Qatari mediators."

The Saudi-funded Al Arabiya TV said that Egypt and Qatar would invite US special envoy Steve Witkoff to Cairo to finalise the agreement.

Qatari Al Jazeera TV reported that Hamas's approval "may force Netanyahu to agree to what he previously refused".

Al Jazeera said the terms of the new deal include the release of 10 Israeli hostages and 18 bodies, a 60-day ceasefire, Israel's withdrawal from the north and east of Gaza and entry of aid, as well as the release of all Palestinian minors and women from Israeli prisons.

We will file a briefing.

Israel examining Hamas response

Israeli media reported this morning that officials are examining Hamas's positive response to the latest ceasefire proposal.

The liberal Haaretz daily cited unnamed Israeli sources as saying that it was still unclear how Israel would respond, quoting Netanyahu as saying that Hamas was under "atomic pressure".

The public broadcaster Kan said that Hamas was "trying to turn the tables and portray itself to Egypt, Qatar and the United States as the one which is willing to go the extra mile and bring and end to the war".

Despite what Kan described as progress in talks, it also reported that Netanyahu was still expected to hold a cabinet discussion to approve plans for occupying Gaza City on 21 August.

Egypt's Sisi, Qatari PM discuss mediation

Egyptian President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi and visiting Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani held talks yesterday in Cairo on mediation efforts for a ceasefire deal in Gaza.

"The meeting witnessed a joint emphasis on the extreme importance that Egypt and Qatar were giving to their continuing efforts, in coordination with the US, to reach a deal that would ensure an immediate ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, allow the urgent delivery of humanitarian aid without any obstacles alongside the release of hostages and captives," the Egyptian presidential spokesman said in a statement on Facebook.

The two officials also emphasised "the categorical rejection of the military reoccupation of the enclave and any attempts to displace Palestinians from their land".

Egypt and Qatar reportedly handed Hamas a new proposal to resume the Gaza ceasefire negotiations.

Israel withdrawal call splits Lebanon media

Lebanese media were divided over the US envoy Tom Barrack's call yesterday for Israel to withdraw from Lebanese territory after Beirut approved a plan to disarm Hezbollah by the end of the year.

The French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour commented that Barrack had declared himself "satisfied" with Lebanon's action, highlighting his comment, following talks in Beirut, that it was Israel's turn to comply with the November ceasefire agreement.

Meanwhile, the pro-Hezbollah Al-Akhbar daily said Barrack's visit had been "to no avail", noting that it followed the visit of the secretary of Iran's Supreme National Security Council, Ali Larijani, with both visits representing the "height of tensions" between Washington and Tehran.

The pro-Iran Al-Mayadeen TV questioned whether Barrack's comment was a "recalculation or a new manoeuvre, while ignoring Israel's violations" of the ceasefire agreement.

In related news, the UN Security Council started talks late yesterday on a French-drafted resolution to extend the mandate of the UN peace-keeping mission in Lebanon, Unifil, which expires on 31 August.

Israeli families cross into Syria

A group of Israeli families crossed into Syria yesterday, attempting to establish a new Jewish settlement there called "Neve Habashan", Israeli media reported.

According to the right-wing, pro-settlement Arutz Sheva, the families spent an "extended period of time" in Syria before being evacuated back to Israel by the army.

One of the members of the "Bashan Pioneers" movement told Arutz Sheva that the fence was "wide open" and it took 30-40 minutes before Israeli forces had noticed they had crossed the border area.

The Walla news site quoted the army as calling the crossing a "serious incident that constitutes a criminal offence and endangers the public and Israeli forces".

US forces start Iraq withdrawal

Washington has started the first phase of withdrawing forces in the US-led coalition against the Islamic State (IS) from Iraq, as the first US convoy left the Ain al-Asad airbase in the western Anbar province yesterday, heading towards Syria.

An Iraqi military spokesman described the move as an "indicator of Iraq's ability to confront terrorism and maintain security and stability without needing assistance from others", according to the official news agency INA.

The first phase is scheduled to end by late September, with US troops and equipment due to be redeployed to Iraq's semi-autonomous Kurdistan Region or to Kuwait.

By September 2026, the US will complete its military exit, reducing its troop numbers from around 2,000 to fewer than 500.

'Catastrophic' flooding hits southern Yemen

Yemeni media have reported that flooding from heavy rain overnight has brought parts of the southern city of Aden - the temporary capital of the internationally recognised government - to a standstill this morning.

Southern Yemen-focused Aden al-Ghad called the situation "catastrophic", saying floods had swept large quantities of debris on to main roads in the city's Mualla district and had submerged vehicles.

It said residents had criticised a lack of emergency response and poor drainage systems.

The leading Al-Masdar Online website said residents had been evacuated from damaged homes in the city's Crater district, and that several flights into Aden had been diverted.

Flooding across Yemen last year caused widespread devastation, with some media blaming the extent of the damage on corruption and neglect by the internationally recognised government.

Hadramawt protests - potential flashpoint?

Yemen's southeastern province of Hadramawt has become the crucible of a summer of unrest in the government-controlled south.

The Aden-based authorities have come under increasing pressure to address deteriorating economic and living conditions that have already seen months of street protests.

But weeks of protests in Hadramawt have led to fears that the province is on the brink of a military escalation that could have repercussions for the country as a whole.

The protests have also highlighted underlying tensions between the UAE and Saudi Arabia over influence in Yemen.

See our Explainer: Hadramawt emerges as focal point of southern Yemen unrest

title: Briefing: Sudan TV dedicates news bulletin to recapture of its HQ by army
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At a glance
body:
- The state-owned Sudan TV dedicated most of its 19:00 GMT news bulletin on 12 March to the recapture of its headquarters by the army from the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary group

- The TV said the army received much commendation in the country for “liberating” the state broadcaster headquarters

Full story

The state-owned Sudan TV channel dedicated most of its 19:00 GMT news bulletin on 12 March to the recapture of its headquarters by the regular army after weeks of fierce fighting with the rival Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary group.

The seizure of the Sudan Radio and Television Corporation (SRTC) headquarters by the army marked a significant setback for the RSF as the paramilitary group has been controlling the premises since its war with the army began in April 2023.

Sudan TV has been airing clips of army troops inside the television and radio headquarters in Omdurman, hours after the military announced the takeover.

The TV said in its 19:00 GMT bulletin on 12 March that the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) has received much commendation in the country for “liberating” the state broadcaster headquarters.

It said the armed forces, other security agents and volunteer fighters deserve recognition for the liberation of the TV headquarters in Omdurman.

 "This institution serves as the national voice and embodies the people's memory and historical heritage, reflecting their culture," the TV said.

Sudan TV showed the commander-in-chief of the armed forces, Lt Gen Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, arriving in Omdurman to congratulate the army for the victory. 

The TV also broadcast a statement by the chief of staff of the Sudan army, Lt Gen Mohammed Osman al-Hussein, flaunting the liberation of the TV premises and congratulating the army for the victory.

Several ministries have issued statements “emphasising the significance of this victory as a step in the ongoing efforts to free the country from the grip of RSF rebellion”, Sudan TV said.

The television prominently broadcast statements by the governors of states controlled by the army sending congratulatory messages over the recapture of the TV premises in Omdurman. These include the Northern, Kassala, Qadaref, South Kordofan, North Kordofan, West Kordofan, Blue Nile and White Nile states.

It said the residents of some of those states who spoke to Sudan TV “expressed their joy at the liberation” of the TV premises.

Sudan TV has been operating from the eastern city of Port Sudan, which has become the government base after the conflict began.

It is worth noting that RSF has not used the state broadcaster headquarters in Omdurman for broadcasting despite having controlled it for more than ten months. It instead turned the premises into "a military base" according to local media.

The group has yet to comment officially on the army's recapture of the TV building.

See: Briefing: Sudan army announces recapture of state TV and radio headquarters

Source: Sudan TV, Omdurman, in Arabic 1900 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Yemen website reports praise for newly appointed PM's walkabout in Aden
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Yemen's recently appointed Prime Minister Ahmed bin Mubarak has garnered praise for a walkabout in the interim capital Aden without a security detail, the southern-focused Aden al-Ghad news website reported on 5 March.
body:
According to the report, the prime minister undertook a tour of the Seera district of Aden on the evening of 4 March. It cited separate accounts from citizens who said that he visited two neighbourhoods, where he spent time in the local markets and ate at a restaurant.

The citizens said that they had seen the prime minister "walking around without security guards or escorts and was received with great warmth".

The report said that the walkabout was widely praised on social media.

Bin Mubarak was sworn in as prime minister in February amid reports of renewed tensions between the government and the powerful UAE-backed, separatist Southern Transitional Council, which blamed the former for poor economic and living conditions in Aden and the southern provinces. 

See: Yemen TV channel discusses challenges facing new PM

Yemen website reports separatist warning to Aden-based government

Source: Aden al-Ghad website, Aden, in Arabic 0858 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Al-Qaeda scholar condemns Algeria government for secular laws
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Qaeda's branch in North Africa (AQIM) has released the sixth episode of a religious audio series that calls for the downfall of the Algerian state.
body:
The jihadist group published the 19-minute message, which was packaged as a video, on 19 March via its channels on Telegram, Chirpwire and Element.

It was also posted on a website al-Ezza (alezza.net), which hosts material from both AQIM and al-Qaeda's Sahel-based affiliate.

The video opened with a correction that clarified the previous episode had been misnumbered as the sixth, when in fact it had been the fifth in the series.

The latest instalment criticised the Algerian government for their adoption of democracy in what it described as "practical unbelief".

It was narrated by Abu Yasir al-Jaza'iri, whose nom de guerre suggests he is Algerian, as with past segments in the long-running series that first launched in August 2022.

Despite the Algerian authorities professing to be Muslim, their acceptance of democratic principles amounted to a major deviation from Islamic teachings, al-Jaza'iri argued.

He said that enacting secular legislation, which determines what is permissible or forbidden without being grounded in Sharia law, constituted a significant breach of faith.

Democracy, by vesting legislative power in people, was tantamount to the sin of worshipping other divinities alongside God, al-Jaza'iri contended.

He cited historical and contemporary Islamic scholars such as Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, as well as the Algerian constitution to back his argument.

Jihadist groups vehemently oppose democracy, viewing it as at odds with Islamic doctrine.

The previous instalment in the series criticised the Algerian authorities for the equal treatment of Muslims and religious minorities.

See more: Al-Qaeda releases new message condemning Algeria government

Al-Qaeda justifies excommunicating Algeria rulers in new message

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 0200 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Gunmen kill five police officers in south-east Nigeria
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Gunmen have killed seven people including five police officers in an attack in Nigeria’s south-eastern Ebonyi State capital, Abakiliki, privately-owned Daily Trust website reported on 8 March.
body:
The attackers also killed two women during the attack at the popular Ebyia bridge along Hilltop road in the city. 

A resident said the assailants believed to be members of a notorious gang were allegedly returning from an operation when they opened fire on the officers.

“My dear our area has become a hit zone for hoodlums, just this morning we heard another incident that some policemen were killed by suspected armed robbers at Hill-Top road near the gas station,” the resident was quoted as saying.

State police has yet to issue a statement on the attack.

Gunmen in December 2023 killed some police officers at the same spot.

Gunmen operating in the south-east region have targeted security officers and installations in attacks.

Source: Daily Trust website, Abuja, 8 Mar 24

title: Pakistan condemns attack in Afghanistan's Kandahar
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan on 22 March strongly condemned the attack that took place at a bank in Afghanistan's Kandahar city on 21 March, The Express Tribune newspaper reported on 23 March.
body:
Pakistan Foreign Office issued a statement saying, "the Government and the people of Pakistan extend their sincere condolences to the bereaved families and pray for the early recovery of the injured."

"Pakistan reiterates its strong condemnation of terrorism in all its forms and manifestations. Terrorism is a shared concern that both countries need to address through collective efforts," the statement added.

The suicide attack that killed three and injured 12 has been claimed by the Islamic State group.

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0000 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab claims killing 10 soldiers in southern Somalia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The al-Shabab group has claimed to have killed 10 Somali soldiers and wounded six others in an ambush in Jambalul village on the outskirts of Afgoye town in the southern Lower Shabelle region, the pro-militant Calamada news website reported on 21 March.

title: Talks on changes to Somalia constitution begin in Puntland
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Talks by politicians opposed to proposed amendments to the Somalia provisional constitution officially begun on 23 March in the north-eastern Somali town of Garowe, privately-owned Radio Kulmiye reported in its 10:30GMT news bulletin.

title: Pakistan PM calls for enhanced bilateral ties with Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif expressed keenness to enhance bilateral cooperation with Russia during his meeting with Moscow's envoy to Islamabad, widely-read daily The Express Tribune reported on its website.
body:
The Pakistani premier highlighted several areas, including in energy, trade and investment during his meeting with Ambassador of the Russian Federation Albert P. Khorev, a statement from the Prime Minister's Office said.

He also urged Moscow to send a delegation to identify areas in which the existing level of trade and investment ties could be enhanced, the report added.

The Russian envoy called on the prime minister soon after US President Joe Biden's first official correspondence with a Pakistani premier in years, where he said that Washington will continue to stand with Pakistan to tackle the most "pressing global and regional challenges."

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0700 GMT 31 Mar 24

title: Somalia says 'assessing' war on al-Shabab
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Somali Information Minister Daud Aweis Jama has told a gathering of journalists in the capital Mogadishu that the government is assessing the war against the al-Shabab militant group.
body:
Privately-owned Radio Kulmiye in its 10:30 GMT news bulletin said Aweis made the remarks on 13 March while briefing the media on government activities over the past week.

“Of course the operations against al-Shabab are taking place. There is an ongoing assessment on the war and how it is conducted since there have been El Nino rains and floods. So, the operations are underway,” Aweis said.

An all-out offensive against al-Shabab was launched in 2022.

The minister did not give further details on what the assessment entails.

He also failed to comment on troops deserting their bases in the central Mudug region, the radio said.

Over the past few weeks, the Somali army has abandoned a number of bases including those in the towns and villages of Amara, Ba’adweyne, Shabellow, Qey’ad and A’ad.

Source: Radio Kulmiye, Mogadishu, in Somali 1030 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Turkey's Erdogan congratulates Putin over election victory
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Recep Tayyip Erdogan congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin over his recent election victory in a phone conversation on 18 March, the Turkish Presidential Communications Directorate said in a statement.
body:
"Erdogan congratulated Putin on his election victory and stated that he believes the positive course in Turkey-Russia relations will continue increasingly in the new period," it said.

"[He also] stated that Turkey is ready to play any facilitating role in returning to the negotiation table in Ukraine," it added.

Erdogan and Putin have developed close ties in recent years, cooperating in multiple regional arenas and deepening trade and energy relations.

However, the recent warming between Turkey and the US, following Ankara's ratification of Sweden's Nato membership and Washington's greenlight of the sale of F-16 fighter jets, has prompted some pundits to suggest Turkey-Russia ties face hurdles.

See also: Turkish commentator predicts hurdles in Ankara's ties with Russia

See also: Briefing: Major Turkish outlets overlook shortcomings in Putin's election 'win'

Source: Turkish Presidency Directorate of Communications website, Ankara, in Turkish 2300 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Unknown gunmen kill 11 civilians in Ethiopia's Oromia Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Unknown gunmen have killed 11 civilians in an area bordering Ethiopia's Oromia and Amhara regions, the private Ethiopian Satellite Television (ESAT TV) reported on 13 March.
body:
"The lives of at least 11 people were lost in an attack by gunmen in Dera District of North Shewa Zone [Oromia Region]," ESAT said.

The TV said the attackers, who had come from Amhara Region, also destroyed property.

Rebels of the Oromo Liberation Army (OLA) and the Fano militia groups in Amhara Region operate in the area as they continue fighting the army.

Source: ESAT TV, Addis Ababa, in Amharic, 13 Mar 24

title: Iran president focuses on Gaza in Nowruz messages to other leaders
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's President Ebrahim Raisi has voiced support for the "oppressed and mighty" people of Gaza in his New Year messages to the leaders of countries celebrating Nowruz.
body:
"It is our human duty to use our capabilities to make effective and serious steps to stop the Zionist regime's [Israel] attacks and deliver humanitarian aid to the oppressed people of Gaza", the Iranian government's official website quoted Raisi as writing in his letters on 20 March.

Raisi highlighted that while Iran and its surrounding countries were celebrating Nowruz, Palestinians in Gaza were under Israel's "brutal attacks" and suffering from famine as they did not have access to basic needs due to a "total blockade".

The Iranian president also sent letters to the leaders of Muslim states on 19 March, saying that the prevention of a "humanitarian disaster" in Gaza was an "immediate responsibility" of international organisations, especially the United Nations, Organisation of Islamic Cooperation and International Court of Justice.

Raisi also warned Israel against any "potential aggressive actions" in Jerusalem and Al-Aqsa Mosque against Palestinian worshippers amid the current Islamic holy month of Ramadan, the official presidential website said in a statement.

He accused Israel of committing "genocide" and "war crimes" in Gaza and creating conditions for "societal collapse in Gaza and the West Bank and forced displacement" of Palestinians.

He added that the current developments "proved" that Israel was "intentionally pursuing the policy of complete destruction of the Palestinian people and identity with the US support".

Source: Dolat.ir website, Tehran, in Persian 0408 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: N Korea minister, Mongolia president discuss strengthening ties
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korea's Vice-Foreign Minister Pak Myong-ho met Mongolian President Ukhnaagiin Khurelsukh for talks on advancing bilateral ties, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
During their meeting on 11 March, Pak and Khurelsukh discussed ways to advance bilateral ties, and strengthening exchange and cooperation, KCNA reported on 12 March. 

Pak also met with foreign ministry officials, including Mongolian Foreign Minister Battsetseg Batmunkh, to discuss ways to boost mutual support and cooperation, it added.

The visit by the North Korean delegation is the first such visit to Mongolia since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic in early 2020.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 1000 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Yemen website says bodies of African migrants found on Red Sea coast
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A leading Yemeni news website has said that fishermen found two bodies, believed to be of African migrants, on the Red Sea coast of Hudaydah (Al-Hodeidah) province on 18 March.
body:
Al-Masdar Online cited local sources as saying that the bodies were found on the coast of the Al-Khawkhah district. The sources suggested they were African migrants who had drowned in the sea due to strong winds that had swept the region in recent days.

The website said that African migrants frequently drown off the coast of Yemen as they travel there en route to Saudi Arabia to find work.

Al-Masdar reported last year that illegal smuggling operations from African countries were being carried out along the Red Sea coastal strip. It said that refugees were brought to special docks after their arrival on the Yemeni coast and were smuggled onwards in a long journey to the border with Saudi Arabia.

See also from 2023: Briefing: Yemen warring parties criticise report on migrant killings at border

Source: Al-Masdar Online website in Arabic 18 Mar 24

title: Iran police seizes smuggled guns in western province
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian police have seized 45 pistols and 90 magazines of bullets in Selseleh county in the western Lorestan Province, the official IRNA news agency reported on 29 March.
body:
According to Lorestan police chief Yahya Elahi, the officers identified and stopped a vehicle carrying the smuggled weapons on a road in the Selseleh county in an operation which was assisted by the agents of the Ministry of Intelligence.

The report added that the security forces also arrested an individual who had been previously convicted in six other criminal cases.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 0813 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Pakistan army chief says fully prepared to defend country against threats
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's Chief of the Army Staff General Asim Munir said that the armed forces were fully prepared to secure the country against the "full spectrum of threats", widely-read daily The Express Tribune reported on its website.
body:
The army chief was visiting troops engaged in an exercise in the area of Rahim Yar Khan, said a statement released by the Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR) on 9 March.

The exercise was aimed at enhancing professional expertise and "subdue the enemy’s communications capabilities and disinformation campaigns during war", added the military's media wing.

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0500 GMT 10 Mar 24

title: Ethiopia's Fano militia group reportedly kills 27 Oromo civilians
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ethiopia's Fano militia group is said to have killed 27 civilians in an area inhabited by ethnic Oromo people in the north-western Amhara region, the private Addis Standard reported on 20 march.
body:
"A total of 27 people were killed and more than 40 others have been injured in the attacks since 9 March in the Jille Dhumuga District of the zone [Oromia Special Zone], according to locals," said Addis Standard.

According to the report, residents said the Fano militia and Amhara region's security forces were carrying out "coordinated attacks" against the locals.

"The villagers alleged that the attacks are aimed at displacing ethnic Oromo residents," said Addis Standard.

On 18 March, the pro-opposition Oromia Media Network reported that the Fano militia groups had killed more than 1,000 people in the area.

There have been a series of attacks in the area on the border of the Amhara and Oromia regions in the past few years.

Source: Addis Standard website, Addis Ababa, in English, 20 Mar 24

title: Russian 'welcomes' Chinese interest in Ukraine war settlement - official
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Deputy Russian Foreign Minister Andrei Rudenko has said that Moscow welcomes China's "interest" in bringing about a settlement in the Ukraine war.
body:
Commenting on the visits to Europe and Russia by Beijing's special representative for Eurasian affairs, Liu Hui, Rudenko told TASS news agency that "we welcome China's interest and attention towards issues of settlement of the crisis in Ukraine and around it".

"You know, the proposals that China circulated in February last year are quite interesting, we support the majority of them," he said.

"Mr Li Hui's current visit to Western Europe and Russia is a confirmation that China is not standing idle but is trying to undertake all possible effort to facilitate a peaceful resolution of this issue," he said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1434 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Codeco militia frees 10 hostages in north-east DR Congo
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Cooperative for the Development of the Congo (Codeco) militia in DR Congo has released  ten hostages that were in captivity for nearly a week, the UN-sponsored Radio Okapi reported on 22 March.

title: Northern Mali residents hold protest against militant blockade
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Residents of the northern Malian town of Menaka held protests on 16 March to denounce high living cost amid a militant blockade, French public radio RFI reported on 17 March.
body:
About a thousand people gathered in the town to express their frustration at the deteriorating security situation and urge the authorities to end the embargo. 

"The town of Menaka is hungry, it's too much", "Don't come without our trucks", read some of the placards carried by protesters.

Several trucks loaded with foodstuff have been denied entry into the town leading to increased prices of food items including rice, millet and sugar as residents observe Ramadan fasting.

The situation has been worsened by an increase in the number of internally displaced persons.

Northern Mali still grapples with insecurity despite the presence in Menaka of the Malian army, Russian Wagner Group military contractors and pro-government fighters of the Movement for the Salvation of the Azawad (MSA).

Source: Radio France Internationale website, Paris, in French 17 Mar 24

title: Some 145,000 reportedly need aid after northern Mozambique flooding
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Around 145,000 people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Mocimboa da Praia District of Mozambique's Cabo Delgado Province after the Messalo River burst its banks and flooded nearby areas, state-owned broadcaster TVM reported on 11 March.
body:
Mocimboa da Praia Administratir Sergio Cipriano said hundreds of crops were lost after the flooding of numerous agricultural fields across the district. The heavy rains have also cut off access to roads linking the district to the city of Pemba, the capital of Cabo Delgado Province, leading to a rise in food prices.

"People are going hungry because there is no food in stores and warehouses and there is a shortage of fuel at local gas stations," Cipriano said, adding that the little food that can be found in stores is being sold for speculative prices.

"A 10-kilogram bag of rice is now selling for 1,500 MZN, sometimes even reaching 1,700 MZN depending on the quality," he said.

The official stressed that the entire district of Mocimboa da Praia was facing "severe hunger" and called for immediate assistance from the provincial government of Cabo Delgado.

Source: Televiso de Moambique, Maputo, in Portuguese 1800 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Belarus TV touts 'unprecedented' turnout in occupied Donbas
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Belarusian state TV broadcast a long praiseful report about the holding of the Russian presidential election in the occupied self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) in its main Sunday evening programme on 17 March.

title: Ten injured in Senegal amid celebrations of early poll results
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 10 people were seriously injured on 24 March in Senegal's central town of Mbacke as they celebrated opposition candidate Bassirou Diomaye Faye’s impressive show in the presidential vote, privately owned news website Dakaractu has reported.
body:
Faye took an early lead against his main rival Amadou Ba as counting started late on 24 March.

"Thousands of young people flooded the city centre shouting victory. An overflowing joy that also claimed a few victims," Dakaractu said. 

"In the euphoria, about 10 young people were run over by vehicles or fell off their motorcycles. They were all taken to Matlabul Fawzeini hospital and treated by Pastef."

Faye was the preferred candidate of the officially disbanded Patriots of Senegal (Pastef) party of Ousmane Sonko, who was barred from taking part in the elections. 

Ba, the ruling coalition's candidate, has said celebrations were premature and predicted the vote could go to a run-off.

Official results are expected to be released by 29 March at the latest.

Source: Dakaractu website, Dakar, in French 25 Mar 24

title: Togo validates over 2,000 candidates for 20 April election
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Togolese Constitutional Court has validated more than 2,000 candidates for the 20 April parliamentary and regional elections, French public radio RFI reported on 25 March.

title: Ruling party candidate concedes defeat in Senegal presidential election
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Former Prime Minister Amadou Ba, who ran in Senegal's 24 March presidential election as the ruling party flag bearer, has called his opposition rival Bassirou Diomaye Faye to congratulate him on his victory, privately-owned Dakaractu news website has reported.
body:
“In view of the trends in the results of the presidential election, and while we await the official proclamation, I congratulate President Bassirou Diomaye Diakhar Faye on his victory in the first round. I pray to the Almighty to grant him the energy and strength he needs to assume this high office at the head of our country. I wish him every success for the well-being of the Senegalese people,” a statement issued by Ba said

Earlier, Ba predicted a run-off because he said the opposition candidate had not reached the 50% threshold. This was after local media tallies showed Faye had a significant lead.

If confirmed, 44-year-old Faye’s victory in an election widely praised as peaceful and orderly would also be a victory for his mentor, Ousmane Sonko, who was disqualified from the polls because of criminal convictions.

Both Faye and Sonko were released from jail on 14 March following an amnesty. The two were detained in connection with sporadic political violence that has been witnessed in the country since 2021. 

Source: Dakaractu website, Dakar, in French 0000 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Iran court holds first session of controversial pop singer's trial
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian pop singer Amir-Hossein Maqsoudlou, better known as Amir Tataloo, has gone on trial before a court in Tehran, the judiciary's Mizan News Agency reported on 4 March.

title: HTS claims killing 10 Syrian soldiers in Latakia raid
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Syrian militant group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) has claimed to have killed 10 soldiers in an attack in the coastal province of Latakia on 20 March.
body:
The group's Amjad media arm issued the claim in a short statement on Telegram on the same day.

The statement said the group's Osman bin Affan Brigade had carried out a "commando raid" on a military position in the Kabina area in the province's northern Jabal al-Akrad mountains.

HTS militants killed 10 soldiers and destroyed the position, it said. 

HTS loyalists on Telegram have shared footage of fighters preparing to mount the night assault in the mountainous region, near the border with Turkey.

A war monitor reported that the attack in Kabina had killed five soldiers and wounded five others.

Meanwhile, pro-government media reported that military forces had killed 10 HTS-affiliated militants in an attack on a "terrorist base" in western Aleppo province.

Al-Watan said the military operation in the town of Kafr Amma was in response to repeated ceasefire violations by the Islamist rebels.

Domestic opposition media have reported that the clashes come after the most violent shelling in recent months between HTS fighters and government forces.

HTS controls around half of Idlib province and small parts of neighbouring Aleppo, Latakia and Hama. 

The rebel bastion has been subject to a ceasefire brokered by Russia and Turkey in 2020 that has repeatedly been violated by both Syrian forces and rebels.

See more: Analysis: Protests shake HTS's grip on Syria rebel bastion

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 0600 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Russia declares 700 foreign fighters in Ukraine 'wanted'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Investigations Committee (IC) has declared about 700 foreigners fighting as volunteers on the side of Ukraine as "wanted", state TASS news agency reported on 7 March.
body:
"In total, at this stage, about 700 foreigners have been declared wanted," the Investigations Committee said, noting some of them have already been "arrested in absentia".

Among the individuals the IC has declared wanted are citizens of the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland and Romania, the statement said.

The IC statement followed a meeting attended by its head Alexander Bastyrkin with Russian-installed heads of law-enforcement authorities in occupied part of Ukraine's Donetsk Region, which discussed the "investigation of crimes committed by Ukrainian units against the civilian population and Russian army service members on the territory of Russia and Ukraine".

The IC has opened criminal cases against three Georgian citizens, Lazha Rukhaia, Levon Ayrapetyan, and Erekle Amiranashvili for fighting alongside the Ukrainian armed forces as part of the Georgian National Legion.

Russia put the head of the Georgian Legion volunteer unit, Mamuka Mamulashvili, on its wated list in October 2023.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0416 gmt 7 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says 33 Russian strike drones destroyed
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences shot down 33 out of 37 Shahed-131/136 kamikaze drones Russia launched on the night 7-8 March, the Air Force Command has reported on Telegram.
body:
The drones were downed over Kirovohrad, Odesa, Kherson, Mykolayiv and Kharkiv regions, it said.

Russia also attacked Ukraine with one S-300 and two Kh-59 missiles, the command said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0523 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Nigerian Shia group holds protests to call for Gaza ceasefire
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A pro-Iranian Shia group in Nigeria held nationwide protests on 11 March to call for an immediate ceasefire in the Palestinian enclave of Gaza, the privately-owned newspaper Daily Trust reported.
body:
The demonstrations by the Islamic Movement in Nigeria (IMN) were held in Lagos, Kaduna, Kano, Sokoto, Zamfara, Katsina, Jos, Bauchi, Gombe, Yobe, Adamawa and the federal capital, Abuja.

According to Daily Trust, protesters in Abuja burnt UK and American flags in front of the US embassy.

“The protesters urged US President Joe Biden to withdraw all his support for Israel in order to stop the extrajudicial killing of unarmed females and children in Gaza,” the paper reported.

The IMN was founded and is lead by Sheikh Ibrahim El-Zakzaky.

It is based in the north-western city of Zaria.

The authorities banned it in 2019 following violent clashes between its members and security forces, but its supporters hold protests from time to time.

Zakzaky was arrested following the clashes.

Source: Daily Trust website, Abuja, 11 Mar 24

title: Chad 'willing' to deploy security forces to aid Haiti
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Chad's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Mahamat Saleh Annadif has expressed his country’s willingness to participate in a Kenyan-led multinational stabilisation force for Haiti, privately owned Alwihda Infos news website reported on 18 March.
body:
Annadif said Chad had been approached by the Kenyan government on the matter.

"I can confirm that the Kenyan government has contacted us and we have indicated our willingness to deploy Chadian police officers. The number and deployment arrangements will be defined at a later date," Annadif told Alwihda.

Benin has also indicated that it is prepared to send about 1,500 security forces to Haiti to help restore order. 

The deployment of the multinational force has been stalled by the collapse of Haiti’s government amid worsening gang violence in the Caribbean country.

The Kenyan government, which signed an agreement authorising the deployment of 1,000 of its forces with Haiti’s former premier, has said that it will send personnel to Haiti once a transitional authority is in place.

Source: Alwihda website in French 18 Mar 24

title: Ukraine downs 31 Russian missiles in night strike on Kyiv
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences shot down all 31 missiles Russia launched in an overnight attack on Kyiv, the Air Force Command has reported on Telegram.
body:
"The enemy attacked with two ballistic/air ballistic Iskander-M (KN-23)/Kh-47М2 Kinzhal and 29 cruise Kh-101/Kh-555 missiles" launched from 11 Tu-95MS strategic bombers, the Air Force said. 

 At least 10 people in Kyiv were injured by falling missile debris, the head of the city military administration, Serhiy Popko, reported.

Residential buildings, private vehicles and other property were damaged in three districts.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0539 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Tanzania pledges to boost access to clean cooking energy
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan has said she was committed to ensuring at least 88% of citizens use clean cooking energy by 2030, the ruling CCM party's newspaper Uhuru reported on 11 March.

title: Russian weekly TV highlights: Putin, TV point finger at Ukraine over Crocus raid
snippet:
Main themes on Russian TV weekly news review programmes on Rossiya 1, Channel One and NTV on 24 March

In unison, as if on instructions from above, the weekly news review shows on Russia’s three main TV channels on 24 March pointed a finger at Ukraine over the Crocus City Hall attack.
body:
By association, it was further suggested that broader forces wished Russia ill and would stop at nothing to that end. 

Was it Ukraine?

“All the shooters in the barbaric terrorist attack in the Moscow region have been detained. They were heading for Ukraine,” as per the night’s main headline on Rossiya 1’s Vesti Nedeli (News of the Week), with Dmitry Kiselyov (which was again brought forward by an hour to start at 1900 Moscow time (1600 gmt) rather than its usual 2000).

The suggestion that Ukraine was involved was repeated and amplified across the board, on each of the three main channels. On Rossiya 1, its Vesti Nedeli began with Russian President Vladimir Putin’s speech, in which he linked the attack with Ukraine. All four perpetrators have been found and detained, but “tried to hide and moved towards Ukraine, where, according to preliminary data, a window was prepared for them from the Ukrainian side to cross the state border”, Putin said.

“Just like the Nazis who once carried out massacres in the occupied territories, they planned to stage a show execution, a bloody act of intimidation,” he went on, but whoever directed them will be punished.

“Both the US and Europe understand that any connection between Ukraine and the attack on Crocus City Hall would be suicide for both Kyiv and the entire anti-Russian alliance; in which case, Moscow will conduct possible negotiations on completely different terms,” one of Rossiya 1’s reports remarked.

Several narratives were employed on Russian TV on the night to amplify the suggestion that Ukraine was involved, if not directly to blame it. The gamut ranged from the expression of doubt that the Islamic State group (IS/ISIS) was behind it in any of its iterations, to the propaganda refrain which frames Ukraine as a terrorist state.

Escalation? 

This, for instance, was Kiselyov: “They are already trying to throw everyone off the scent and, for example, they are talking about ISIS, while denials are coming from Kyiv, saying that it was not us. However, the irrefutable fact remains that the terrorists sought salvation in Ukraine and after their crime they headed in that direction, stopped just 100 kilometres from the border. Moreover, ISIS has a different style - terrorist attacks in the name of ISIS are carried out by suicide bombers who do not then try to escape.” “Islamic shaheds [martyrs or suicide bombers] usually commit suicide. These shooters, however, rushed to where they were presumably being expected - to Ukraine. Having failed to achieve success on the battlefield, Kyiv is increasingly turning into a terrorist country as it destroys civilians and shells cities day after day,” one of the reports on Rossiya 1 intoned.

These particular subthemes were elaborated elsewhere, including extensive editorial commentary by host Irada Zeynalova of NTV’s Itogi Nedeli (Results of the Week), to take just one of the many examples.

Here, Zeynalova, too, raised doubts about IS’s involvement. She proceeded to claim that Russia was the target of presumably far broader forces whose aim it is “to hurt us” – “and to this end they are ready to do anything”. Furthermore, she appeared to suggest that this amounted to an escalation – or, she said, “it’s simply that they now want to raise the level of tension at any price”.

“The absolutely clear understanding is that the Crocus attack could be a continuation of a chain of events in which sanctions have failed to cause us to collapse, the billions spent on weapons have been to no avail, and neither have been the propaganda campaign, the pledges of unwavering support for Kyiv or the plans for a counteroffensive, so terrorism is what is left in the arsenal,” Zeynalova posited.

This, she said, will not work either, but know, she said, that two can play this game.

Coordination?

In large measure, this was echoed on Channel One’s Voskresnoye Vremya (Sunday Time). Here, inter alia and in concert with the other two networks, it gleaned what it more or less suggested was an international conspiracy, including by media in the West, to blame IS and thus divert suspicion away from Ukraine.

As it, like the other two, chided “the position taken by the media in the West, as it promotes the version of events which holds that Ukraine and terror are two different things”, it referred to the Foreign Ministry. “Any exoneration of Kyiv by Washington before the Crocus investigation is completed should be regarded as evidence” – that is to say, with suspicion, according to the ministry.

Uniquely, even US Fox News TV and its “eternal antagonist” CNN were in agreement about the role of Islamic State in the Crocus attack, in what Channel One suggested was a coordinated fashion. Other international media were name-checked in this context, including “information planted” by Reuters with a reference to the claim of responsibility on “Islamists’ Telegram channel hitherto known to no-one”. It went on to raise similar doubts in other ways. “In the process, with incredible zeal, the US media sought to exonerate the Kyiv regime. Even though no-one had yet brought forward any accusations against the government of Ukraine, they began to make excuses in advance, one can say proactively, as if they knew something.” “All these efforts to divert attention turned out to be so coordinated that all they did was to attract it even more,” according to Channel One.

In various ways all three channels suggested there was equivalence between the Crocus attack and what they presented as Ukraine’s terror tactics – Russian propaganda’s term for cross-border attacks by Ukraine. All of them, the reports claimed, invariably target civilians, such as the shelling of Russia’s border Belgorod region. Furthermore, some of the discourse suggested a link between Ukraine and Islamic State – such as a claim contained in the Channel One report that “several dozen ISIS militants” had been deployed secretly by the US to fight on the side of the “regime”.

Putin’s comments were televised accordingly. “In the past, the West actively took advantage of various kinds of cross-border radical terrorist groups, including as it encouraged their aggression against Russia. It is natural that the neo-Nazi Kyiv regime - again with the support of the West, and often on direct orders – has switched to terrorist methods. This means the shelling of peaceful cities, assassination attempts against government officials and public figures, or attempts to recruit perpetrators of sabotage and terrorist attacks at Russia’s critical infrastructure facilities and in places where people are in large numbers,” Putin told the FSB security service’s top brass.

Putin v traitors

As usual, Putin’s comments served as the cue for much of the content on the night. A contrast was notably drawn between a nation united in grief and strong in the face of this attempt to intimidate it, on the one hand, and the “traitors” to the nation on the other.

On Rossiya 1, those against whom Putin railed as “traitors” were denounced in a dedicated piece of commentary from Kiselyov, who took his lead from what Putin had said earlier. Russia has no capital punishment, Putin said, but all those who have taken up arms to fight against their Mother Russia would be treated as enemy combatants. Each of them will be hunted down, Putin added, without statute of limitation. “We remember what the Vlasovites did on Soviet soil, and for this we will never forgive them.”

His reference to the Red Army’s defector Gen Andrei Vlasov provided the backdrop to commentary in which the word “traitors” and its apparent synonym “Vlasovites” was applied to others. They in particular included those Kiselyov branded “the new Vlasovites” – gathered together for an anti-Putin forum in Kyiv and headed by exiled anti-Kremlin figure Ilya Ponomaryov, the subject of particular opprobrium.

A long list of the Chechen separatist leaders and field commanders assassinated or otherwise neutralised followed from Kiselyov, linked by him to Putin’s a "historic" threat against "terrorists" in 1999 (“we shall wipe them out in the outhouse", although one of those on Kiselyov's list was Chechen leader Dzhokhar Dudayev, assassinated in 1996).

Implicitly, the threat could thus be taken to extend to others, like Ponomarev, not to mention the Russian Legion or the Russian Volunteer Corps, both reportedly actively involved in fighting on Ukraine’s side. "Russia and Putin do not forgive such things," Kiselyov said. “The Russian scumbag traitors thrown into meat assaults against their own motherland by the Bandera Nazi regime have two options: either perish now or a little later, but the end is predetermined in any case,” Kiselyov said.

Dissonant with this discourse, the same programme, Vesti Nedeli, asserted the putative involvement of “new Vlasovites” in the cross-border raids into Russia from Ukraine was no more than a “smokescreen”. “The Kyiv regime tried to present these attacks as an operation by traitors, as in that our positions were attacked by defectors, new Vlasovites. In fact, this was an operation by the Kyiv regime’s Main Intelligence Directorate [HUR], in which HUR’s Spetsnaz [special-forces] groups were involved along with foreign mercenaries. The Vlasovites were just a smokescreen, a billboard,” it said.

Other: Ukraine, Europe, US

As before, reports continued to refer euphemistically to Russia’s war in Ukraine as a “special military operation”. As usual, they claimed a catastrophic situation on the front line and a critical situation behind the lines in Ukraine.

“Front-line” dispatches claimed that Russian forces continued to advance towards Chasiv Yar, outside Bakhmut, as they have claimed for the past few weeks (though a distance of 10 miles between the two population centres). Each of the three channels aired reports that framed Russia’s latest series of massed attacks against Ukraine’s energy infrastructure in particular as “retribution” strikes for attacks against targets inside Russia.

In US-related reports, both Rossiya 1 and NTV sought to lend credence to allegations that Donald Trump’s life was in danger as the threat of they described as his “physical liquidation” loomed large.

NTV alone sought to promote another conspiracy theory – a “new war” apparently in the making. “Statements that China will attack Taiwan in 2027 are precisely about this, and for the sake of this new war they will wear us down so that China does not have an ally,” Zeynalova claimed. Further discourse about the sinister US followed, including about the role of its miliary-industrial complex, where “big money” mingles accordingly with big politics. 

Similarly, Rossiya 1 raised the spectre of US “hegemony” through military trade. “Increased defence spending will force nations to mercilessly cut social spending. This is something that none of the current European governments is likely to survive. The plan is totally outrageous, but they have no other choice. In fact, this is not even their plan, but that of the US. Washington is simply putting it into practice through the European elite it controls, which by its nature has the only aim - to ensure American hegemony in this part of the world,” Rossiya 1’s Europe correspondent Mikhail Antonov said, true to form. 

His and other reports continued to claim a lack of unity on support for Ukraine both in Europe and the US.

Over the studio caption "Gallic fighting cock", Kiselyov of Vesti Nedeli continued to attack French President Emanuel Macron – “bellicose” towards Russia but "increasingly ridiculous", unpopular and mocked even in France. Cue video/audio of a cockerel in a protracted cry of cock-a-doodle-do.

On all three channels, meanwhile, long reports marked the 25th anniversary of Nato’s bombing of Yugoslavia – decried by Kiselyov (despite Russia’s own track record of atrocities in Ukraine) as “a barbarity that lasted 78 days, with 1,700 civilians killed and more than 10,000 wounded”. 

Source: BBC Monitoring in English 0000 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab kills five soldiers in southern Somalia attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Shabab fighters reportedly killed five Somali soldiers and wounded nine others in a clash outside the port city of Kismayo in the southern Lower Jubba region, the group's mouthpiece, Radio Andalus, has reported.

title: One killed, two injured in attack on Russia's Belgorod Region - governor
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A woman has died and two people have been injured in an aerial attack on Russia's Belgorod Region, Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov says.
body:
In a post on Telegram on the morning of 22 March, Gladkov said the woman was walking her dogs when "a round exploded a few metres away from her".

Another woman sustained shrapnel wounds to her leg and a man sustained head injuries, he said.

He also described damage caused to private property in the city of Belgorod and the region's Belgorod District.

The post included pictures showing some of the damage caused.

There have been regular attacks on Russia's border regions in recent days.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0629 gmt 22 Mar 24

title: Iran outlet dismisses reported 'secret' talks with US over Houthis
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The government-run IRNA news agency has cited an "informed source" as saying that any recent talks between Iran and the US had been limited to the subject of "sanctions removal", a term used for talks over Iran's nuclear programme and related sanctions.
body:
Citing the informed source, the IRNA report published on 14 March dismissed recent "claims by an American newspaper" about indirect Iran-US talks regarding "the developments in the Red Sea".

The Financial Times reported on 13 March that the US held "secret talks" with Tehran in Oman in January in an effort to persuade Iran to use its influence over the Yemeni Houthi Movement to end attacks on ships in the Red Sea. 

The paper said that the January meeting was the first indirect negotiations between Iran and the US in 10 months, adding that Iran was represented by Deputy Foreign Minister Ali Baqeri Kani.

The IRNA report said the US was using "psychological operations as part of its strategy to deceive public opinion", adding that "no message has been exchanged about the developments in the Red Sea".

The report did not specifically confirm or deny that the indirect talks indeed took place in January in Oman.

In recent months, the Houthis have been targeting commercial ships, which they claim are Israeli or Israel-bound vessels, in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden in response to the Israel's war in Gaza.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 0741 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Iranian border guard killed on border with Pakistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Iranian border guard officer has been killed in the south-eastern Sistan-Baluchestan Province on the border with Pakistan, the official IRNA news agency reported on 25 March.
body:
Capt Mohammad Mehdi Nejatinia, originating from the north-eastern Golestan Province, was killed in a clash with "thugs" in the Mirjaveh border area in the late hours of 24 March, IRNA said.

Situated on the borders with Afghanistan and Pakistan, the marginalised and impoverished province of Sistan-Baluchestan is home to some Sunni militants. It is also an entry point for smuggled arms and drugs, with frequent clashes reported there between law enforcement forces and armed gangs.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 0738 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Polish protesters unblock Ukraine border checkpoint for cars, buses
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Cars and buses are now allowed to pass via the Shehyni-Medyka crossing point on the Ukrainian-Polish border in both directions, the Ukrainian State Border Service said on Telegram on the evening of 20 March.
body:
Earlier in the day, Polish protesters blocked the crossing point for cars and buses, allowing only one bus to pass every two hours.

Ukrainian Infrastructure Minister Oleksandr Kurbakov then called on Polish Interior Minister Marcin Kierwinski to react to the blocking of passenger buses at the border.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1849 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: South Sudan bans export of goods to two Sudanese regions
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The South Sudanese government has banned the export of food commodities, fuel and other goods to two regions in neighbouring war-torn Sudan to stem shortages at home and keep prices low, the Amsterdam-based broadcaster Radio Tamazuj has reported.
body:
South Sudan has prevented several lorries transporting food and fuel from crossing into Sudan's western South Darfur and East Darfur states, the station said on 22 March, citing an official.

“The directive to implement the ban order at the borderlines came from the government of South Sudan, not just Aweil North county. This is to clarify that while borders are not entirely closed, strict enforcement measures are in place,” said Garang Zachariah Lual, the information minister of South Sudan's Northern Bahr el-Ghazal state.

“The trucks currently halted at the borders are carrying food commodities, fuel and other items prohibited from being exported to Sudan."

The minister said the ban was aimed at preventing shortages of goods in South Sudan and food prices from rising.

He denied that it targeted areas controlled by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces  (RSF) group, which has been battling Sudan's army for the nation's control since April 2023.

Source: Radio Tamazuj website on 22 Mar 24

title: Governor of Russia's Belgorod reports third aerial attack on region in a day
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Vyacheslav Gladkov, governor of Russia's Belgorod Region, has reported a third aerial attack on the city of Belgorod in one day.
body:
Gladkov said in a Telegram post that air defences had shot down 11 "aerial targets on the approaches to the city", in the latest incident on 14 March,

He said that a construction depot and one other business had been hit with two people injured at the former location.

In an earlier post on the same day Gladkov said a car had been hit in a rocket attack killing the driver.

Rossiya 24 news channel's report from Belgorod, at 1442 gmt on 14 March, featured video footage of a lorry and cars damaged by shrapnel. The correspondent said that the situation in the region remained "alarming".

A now deleted video on X (formerly), purportedly from Belgorod, showed multiple vehicles on fire along what looks like a major city road.

Another video from the same account showed armoured vehicles travelling through a city, which the post identified as Kursk in another Russian region bordering Ukraine.

Three pro-Ukraine paramilitary units that claimed to have fought their way into Russian territory earlier in the week have called on civilians in Belgorod and Kursk regions to evacuate.

The Freedom of Russia Legion (FRL), Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK), and Siberian Battalion issued a joint statementon 13 March saying they were "forced to fire at military positions" in Belgorod and Kursk because Russian forces had fired on Ukraine from there.

"To avoid casualties among the civilian population we are calling on everyone to immediately leave towns," the groups said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1434 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Cyclone Gamane death toll in Madagascar rises to 11
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The death toll caused by Tropical Cyclone Gamane in Madagascar's north-eastern region of Sava has risen from six to 11, privately-owned Madagascar Tribune newspaper reported on 28 March.

title: Militia accused of killing nine in Ethiopia's Oromia region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least nine people have been killed in an attack in Ethiopia’s central Oromia Regional State, a leading local news source has reported.
body:
The private Addis Standard website reported on 9 March that the nine were killed in Dara District in North Shewa Zone by alleged Fano militia, a group that is fighting government forces in the neighbouring Amhra Regional State.

"The assault took place on the morning of 7 March 2024 in Jiru Dada, Woren Gabro, and Manketa Wario kebeles (small administrative unit) within the Dara District," the website reported.

It cited what it called informant as saying the attackers abducted children and elderly people who could not flee.

"The informant revealed that in Jiru Deda kebele, homes were razed, and more than 400 cattle were stolen."

Fano militias have been accused of committing human rights abuses in Amhara state. The group previously fought alongside the army in the Tigray conflict.

See: Briefing: Ethiopian forces, armed groups accused of extrajudicial killings

Source: Addis Standard website, Addis Ababa, in English, GMT 9 Mar 24

title: Ethiopia 'silently' informing kin of dead soldiers from Oromia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ethiopian authorities are "silently" informing families of ethnic Oromo soldiers killed in a two-year war in the north of the country, the private Addis Standard reported on 19 March.
body:
"Families of Ethiopian soldiers across the Oromia region have recently been informed about the killing of their loved ones during the two-year war in Tigray [region]," said Addis Standard.

The report said unlike in the Tigray region where a three-day official mourning period was declared, the families in Oromia were left to "endure the pain".

"Currently, families in Oromia are forced to endure the pain of their losses on their own," the report said.

The war is reported to have killed hundreds of thousands of people before ending through a peace agreement signed in South Africa in November 2022.

Source: Addis Standard website, Addis Ababa, in English 19 Mar 24

title: Pakistan says no change in trade policy with India
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan has said that its position on the suspension of trade ties with India has not changed and any proposals for resumption of trade are examined regularly, local media reported.
body:
Addressing a weekly media briefing on 28 March, Foreign Office spokesperson Mumtaz Zahra Baloch spoke about a recent statement made by Foreign Minister Ishaq Dar regarding trade with Delhi, saying he had mentioned that some members of the business community had expressed interest in a review of trade-related matters with India.

“Examination of such proposals is a regular exercise in the Government of Pakistan, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, where we continue to consider all such requests and assess our policy. At this point, there is no change in Pakistan’s position,” she said.

Baloch said Pakistan-India trade relations have been "non-existent" since 2019 when India revoked the special status of Kashmir.

She added that like any foreign policy matter, Pakistan’s relations with India are discussed and debated regularly.

"That does not mean that a policy has been changed. What the foreign minister has said, and I repeat, is that the Government of Pakistan will examine the request that has come from some members of the business community," she said.

According to a report in Dawn newspaper, Dar on 23 March said that the relevant stakeholders would "seriously examine" the trade situation with India.

See also: Briefing: Media in India, Pakistan voice caution amid call to revive trade ties

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 0739 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: China says N Korean delegation's visit to further strengthen ties
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

China's senior party leader Cai Qi has said that North Korean ruling party's delegation visit to the country will further strengthen ties, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
Cai Qi, member of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC), met the delegation, led by Kim Song-nam, director of the international department at the Workers' Party of Korea, on 22 March.

The delegation arrived in Beijing on 21 March on a three-nation tour, and will visit Vietnam and Laos after concluding the visit to China.

"Kim Song Nam stressed the need to exchange good experience in various fields, including party building and state management, and boost strategic and tactical cooperation," KCNA reported on 24 March.

"Cai Qi warmly welcomed the delegation of the WPK on a visit to China in the year of China-DPRK friendship, and said that the delegation's visit served as an important occasion in further strengthening the friendly relations between the two parties," it added.

Earlier, Kim Song-nam met Wang Huning, a senior Chinese Communist Party official on 21 March.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0400 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Kenya seeks to improve broadband access in $73.9m initiative
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kenyan plans to set aside $73.9 million to improve broadband internet access via existing state electricity firm’s infrastructure, privately owned People Daily website reported on 20 March.

title: Ukraine denies Russia downed military intelligence helicopter
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's military intelligence has denied Russian claims that one of its helicopters was shot down.
body:
In a Telegram post on 17 March, the Defence Ministry's Main Intelligence Directorate (HUR) said that its entire Black Hawk fleet was fully operational and continued to perform "combat and special missions".

"The foulmouthed propagandists and their slave owners in the Kremlin, who are spreading fakes about the downing of a helicopter belonging to Ukraine's military intelligence, should not abuse alcohol so much," HUR said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1219 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Iran-Iraq crossing reopened after temporary closure
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A border crossing between Iran and Iraq has been reopened after a one-week closure, the official IRNA news agency reported on 16 March.

title: Indian foreign minister discusses Indo-Pacific with Singapore leaders
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Indian Foreign Minister S Jaishankar has discussed the situation in the Indo-Pacific as well as the Middle-East with leaders of Singapore, The Hindu reported on its website on 25 March, citing PTI news agency.

title: Ukraine: Zelensky proposes ex-security supremo as envoy to Moldova
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Volodymyr Zelensky has said he proposed the former Secretary of the National Security and Defence Council, Oleksiy Danilov, who had been dismissed on 26 March, as ambassador to Moldova.
body:
"Oleksiy Danilov will continue his work on the diplomatic front, more specifically – I have approved his candidacy as the new Ambassador of our state to the Republic of Moldova. He discussed with me his vision for his future work for Ukraine. Moldova is an extremely important state for us – both from the point of view of security challenges in the region and our bilateral cooperation," the president said in his regular evening address to the nation on 29 March.

Earlier in March, Zelensky announced that he had proposed former army commander Valeriy Zaluzhnyy as ambassador to the UK before receiving official approval from the British side.

Danilov held the secretary post since 2019. He was replaced by Oleksandr Lytvynenko, former head of the Foreign Intelligence Service.

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1726 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Mauritania minister says lack of funding hampers green energy shift
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Mauritania's Minister of Oil, Mines and Energy Nani Ould Chrougha has told European officials that a lack of sources of funding is hindering a transition to renewable energy sources and green hydrogen, Mauritanian media reported on 20 March.
body:
The privately owned Al-Akhbar news agency reported that Ould Chrougha made the remarks at the Berlin Energy Transition Dialogue Conference, saying that industrialised nations are the main parties responsible for gas emissions that are harming the environment and that these countries must contribute to providing the required funding to ensure the transition towards greener energy.

The minister said that over the past year, Mauritania has worked to establish a legal framework to facilitate the launch by investors of green hydrogen projects and pledged that a legal code on this work would be approved before the end of this year, Al-Akhbar added.

He portrayed his country as having lucrative opportunities in this field in comparison with other states, and said that several companies have signed deals to launch green hydrogen projects with a total capacity of around 85 gigawatts to date.

See also: Mauritania, Senegal to conduct audit over delayed gas project

Russia's Lavrov lists areas for boosting cooperation with Mauritania

And from 2022: Briefing: Mauritania plans to export green energy to Europe

Source: Al-Akhbar website in Arabic 0233 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Rwanda criticises UK media outlet for 'giving platform to criminals'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring
