Rwanda has criticised UK’s Channel 4 News for giving a platform to opposition leader Victoire Ingabire and the deputy chairman of the Rwanda National Congress (RNC), Abdul Karim Ali, the privately-owned Rwandan news website Igihe reported on 21 March.

title: Kuwait opens candidacy for early election
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kuwaiti authorities started to receive applications from citizens wishing to run for the upcoming early National Assembly (parliament) election on 4 March and the process will conclude on 13 March.
body:
As many as 70 applicants, including only two women, submitted their documents on the first and second days, according to the official news agency KUNA on 5 March.

The vote will be held on 4 April, according to local media.

On 15 February, an Emiri decree dissolved the parliament, which was elected in June 2023, citing the legislature’s “violation” of the constitution by failing to “show due respect to the high office and deliberately use improper language [in addressing the country’s emir]”.

Over the past years, an insurmountable deadlock between opposition lawmakers and the government has led to the emir dissolving parliament, leading to a series of elections and government resignations.

See also: Explainer: Why Kuwait’s political scene is still in turmoil

Name in the News: Kuwait's new emir, Mishal al-Ahmed al-Sabah

Explainer: Kuwait's 6 June parliamentary election

Source: Kuna news agency website, Kuwait, in Arabic 1107 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Russia holds anti-submarine warfare drill in Arctic
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian Navy is holding an anti-submarine warfare exercise in the Arctic, the Interfax news agency reports.
body:
Interfax said a submarine, two anti-submarine warfare ships and naval aviation are involved.

It identified the ships as the Brest and the Snezhnogorsk of the Kola Flotilla.

Of the submarine, it only said that it was one of the Northern Fleet's nuclear-powered submarines.

The Il-38 aircraft belong to the Northern Fleet's mixed aviation corps, it said.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1125 GMT 27 Mar 24

title: DR Congo revokes licences of nine Russian mining companies
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The DR Congo removed nine Russian mining companies from the subcontracting market on 11 March for violation of market laws, French public broadcaster RFI reported on 12 March.

title: Al-Qaeda claims roadside bomb attack on Mali military
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Qaeda in the Sahel has claimed that it carried out a roadside bomb attack against the Malian army in the central Segou region on 29 March.

title: Russian cultural delegation visits North Korea amid deepening ties
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Russian delegation led by the country's vice culture minister has arrived in Pyongyang, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
The delegation led by Russia's Vice Culture Minister Andrei Maluishev arrived in North Korea on 18 March on the occasion of the 75th anniversary of the signing of a bilateral agreement on economic and cultural cooperation, KCNA reported on 19 March. The delegation included members of an art troupe for the Primorsky branch of the Mariinsky Theatre in Vladivostok.

In a separate report, KCNA said a delegation led by Oleg Kozhemyako, the governor of Russia's far eastern region of Primorsky Krai that borders North Korea, arrived in Pyongyang on 17 March. 

North Korea and Russia have recently deepened their ties amid a series of bilateral visits by officials of the two countries.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0400 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Pakistan, Afghanistan finalise trade agreements amid tensions
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan and Afghanistan have finalised certain agreements on bilateral trade and transit amid heightened bilateral tensions, Dawn newspaper reported on its website.
body:
The report, citing officials, said that the agreements include beginning negotiations on a revised transit trade pact and implementing a temporary admission document (TAD) for trade vehicle drivers.

This happened after talks between the visiting Pakistani delegation, led by senior Commerce Ministry official Khurram Agha, and Afghanistan’s interim Commerce Minister Nooruddin Azizi in Kabul this week.

Pakistan's Foreign Office spokesperson Mumtaz Zahra Baloch, at a press briefing on 28 March, said that Agha visited Kabul between 24 and 27 March and discussed a bilateral Preferential Trade Agreement, implementing a TAD, air transit and issues related to transit trade, with his Afghan counterpart, the report said.

“We are encouraged by the progress made on these issues and remain committed to promoting trade and people-to-people ties with Afghanistan", she said.

Talks between the two sides came against the backdrop of ongoing tensions over continued attacks in Pakistan, which Islamabad claims are carried out by militant groups based in Afghanistan.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0829 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Tajikistan's security body detains 15 'terror suspects'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Tajikistan's security bodies have arrested 15 people suspected of planning to carry out terror attacks during Nowruz (Persian New Year) festivities in the capital Dushanbe and the nearby town of Vahdat, the privately-owned Tajik news agency Asia-Plus reported on 29 March.
body:
All the 15 suspects are residents of Dushanbe and Vahdat, the report said. The agency said that a source in the State Committee on National Security (SCNS) confirmed the news. The investigation is examining whether the detainees had connections with the suspects in the shooting attack at Crocus City Hall near Moscow, where at least 143 people were killed and nearly 200 others were injured. Four Tajiks, including one from Vahdat, were charged with the attack on the concert hall.

Earlier today, an Asia-Plus source in law enforcement agencies reported the detention of nine residents of Vahdat for their links with suspects in the attack on the Crocus music hall and cooperation with the Islamic State militant group (ISIS). 

The source said that most of those arrested were residents of Vahdat, and all of them were arrested by security officers and taken to Dushanbe before the Nowruz - Persian New Year - celebration.

"The investigation will show whether the detainees were linked to the suspects. It is still unknown whether they were all part of the same chain and acted together or whether each of them wanted to commit a terror attack in Russia and Tajikistan separately. The investigation is continuing and these questions need to be answered," Asia-Plus quoted its source as saying.

Earlier, a team of Russian investigators arrived in Dushanbe to interrogate relatives of the Crocus attack suspects.

In his speech aired live on state-run Tajik TV and delivered at the festivities of Nowruz held in Dushanbe 25 March, President Emomali Rahmon urged his nation to pay serious attention to the education of their children and save them from the influence of extremist and terrorist groups and movements. "The shameful and terrible incident that happened near Moscow warns all of us, especially parents, once again to pay even more serious attention to the education of children. I repeatedly note that we should protect teenagers and young people from the influence of such destructive and terrorist groups and movements and not allow our children to harm the good name of the Tajik nation, the sovereign state of Tajiks and their parents," the president said.

Source: Asia-Plus news agency website, Dushanbe, in Russian 1347 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Ukraine army says Odesa hit by ballistic missiles fired from Crimea
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The deadly attack on Odesa on 15 March was carried out using Iskander-M ballistic missiles fired from Russia-occupied Crimea, the Ukrainian army has reported.
body:
"The enemy has insidiously struck Odesa with ballistic munitions, firing Iskander-M missiles from temporarily occupied Crimea," the Southern Defence Forces said on Telegram.

The missile strike on the city's civilian infrastructure destroyed a recreational facility, damaged at least 10 private houses, a car service station, a low-pressure gas pipeline, ambulance cars and fire-rescue vehicles, according to the report.

"Fourteen people were killed, including local residents, a doctor and a rescuer. Forty-six people were injured, including eight rescuers. Emergency services are working at the scene," the Defence Forces said.

The Odesa authorities have declared 16 March a day of mourning following the attack.

"In order to honour the memory of those killed as a result of the enemy attack on the city of Odesa, 16 March 2024 has been declared a day of mourning," the mayor's office said on Telegram.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1313 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Russian investigators want three more people remanded over Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Moscow's Basmanny District Court has said investigators have asked it to retain in pre-trial custody three more suspects linked to the 22 March attack on the Crocus City Hall.
body:
The court has already charged with committing an act of terrorism the four men accused of attacking the concert venue.

"The court has registered petitions from the investigation to select a preventive measure in the form of detention in relation to the accused Aminchon Islomov, Dilovar Islomov, as well as the suspect Isroil Islomov," the court's press service told Interfax news agency on 25 March.

The petitions will be considered by the court in the near future, Interfax added.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1443 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab 'kills 13 spy agents' in southern Somalia ambush
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Shabab has claimed to have killed 13 members of the Somali National Intelligence and Security Agency (Nisa) in an ambush near the southern Afgoye town in the Lower Shabelle region, the group’s mouthpiece Radio Andalus reported on 19 March.

title: Death toll from Moscow concert hall attack rises to 115
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 115 people have been killed in the 22 March terror attack on a concert hall outside Moscow, state news agency TASS reported on 23 March quoting the Russian Investigations Committee.
body:
The search and rescue operations continue, the Investigations Committee said on its Telegram channel.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0953 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: N Korea ruling party delegation visits Laos
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A North Korea ruling party delegation led by a senior official visited Laos and highlighted Pyongyang's policy of boosting defence capabilities, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
Kim Song-nam, director of the international department at North Korea's ruling Workers' Party of Korea, met Thongsavanh Phomvihane, head of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party's external relations committee, on 28 March, KCNA reported on 31 March. 

Laos is the last leg of Kim Song-nam's three-nation trip that also took him to China and Vietnam. Kim also paid a courtesy visit to Thongloun Sisoulith, the secretary general of the Communist Party of Laos.

During the meeting, Kim said North Korea would bolster "comrade-like and strategic" cooperation with Laos, according to the KCNA report. Kim also explained "the legitimacy of our [Korean Workers] Party's policy of strengthening national defence capabilities for self-defence and the line of struggle against the enemy".

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0500 GMT 30 Mar 24

title: At least 10 killed as DR Congo rebels attack town
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 10 people were killed in a suspected mortar explosion in Nyanzale town, Bwito chiefdom, Rutshuru territory, eastern DR Congo, privately-owned Virunga Business Radio FM reported on 4 March.
body:
The town and surrounding villages were reportedly shelled by rebels from the March 23 Movement (M23), who launched several attacks on government-held territory on 4 March.

"According to local civil society, the victims were residents who had fled the town after fighting broke out between the DR Congo army (FARDC) and M23 rebels. Our source also says that a [mortar] shell fell on the farmers, injuring several people, including women and children. As the fighting continues, local sources claim that the M23-RDF [Rwandan Defence Force] coalition has taken control of Kihondo, a village a few kilometres from the town of Nyanzale," the radio said.

According to the report, the rebels looted captured villages, but have so far failed to take Nyanzale, which is held by pro-government Wazalendo fighters.

According to local groups quoted in media reports, the renewed fighting follows the arrival of reinforcements and supplies that have boosted the M23's capacity to fight FARDC troops in the region.

Source: Virunga Business Radio (VBR-FM), Goma, in French 1600 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Ethiopian army chief claims his troops control 60% of Somalia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ethiopian Army Chief Field Marsham Birhanu Jula has claimed that his country's army was in control of 60% of Somalia, and that the Somali federal government would not be able to maintain control of the capital, Mogadishu, if Ethiopian troops were to leave Somalia.
body:
Birhanu made the remarks in an interview with the state television (ETV) on 9 March.

"It is us who control 60% of Somalia's territory. The force called Atmis [African Union Transition Mission in Somalia] is mandated to protect the whole of Somalia and we control 60% of that," said Birhanu.

"So by being in control of this 60%, it is the Ethiopian defence forces who have enabled the Somali government to be sitting in Mogadishu. I don't think the Somali federal government would continue to sit in Mogadishu if the Ethiopian defence forces were to leave Somalia tomorrow," he said.

Relations between Ethiopia and Somalia soured after Ethiopia and the self-declared Somaliland republic signed a maritime agreement last January, angering Mogadishu which considers Somaliland its sovereign land.

See Explainer: Ethiopia-Somalia row further fragments Horn of Africa region

Source: ETV News, Addis Ababa, in Amharic 1930 GMT 9 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab parades '12 defected soldiers' in south-west Somalia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Shabab has paraded 12 soldiers who allegedly defected from Somali government forces in the south-western Gedo region, the militant group’s mouthpiece Radio Andalus reported on 31 March.

title: Uzbek, Kazakh leaders offer Putin condolences over Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Uzbek and Kazakh presidents, Shavkat Mirziyoyev and Kasym-Zhomart Tokayev respectively, called their Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, on 23 March to offer their condolences over the gunmen attack on a concert hall near Moscow and discussed stepping up the joint fight against terrorism, reports said the same day.
body:
According to reports at least 137 people were killed and 150 others injured in the attack on the Crocus City Hall in Russia on 22 March.

"Shavkat Mirziyoyev expressed his deep condolences to the Russian president and people in connection with the numerous casualties as a result of the terrorist attack on the Crocus City Hall concert hall in Moscow Region," a report posted on the privately-owned Uzbek news website Gazeta.uz quoted the presidential press service as saying.

"On behalf of the people of Uzbekistan, the president [Mirziyoyev] conveyed words of support to the families of the victims and wished a speedy recovery to all those injured. He noted that he strongly condemns this crime against the innocent people," it added.

For his part, Putin thanked Mirziyoyev for "the words of support and readiness to provide necessary assistance".

"The heads of state reached an agreement to step up bilateral cooperation to fight against threats to the two countries' security and their sustainable development," Gazeta.uz said.

In a separate report, the state-run Kazakh news website Kazinform reported that President Tokayev also expressed on behalf of the Kazakh people his deepest condolences to Putin "over the numerous casualties in the terrorist attack".

"Our head of state has strongly condemned the act of violence against the innocent people and confirmed again his solidarity with Russia in the fight against terrorism," the report said.

For his part, Putin thanked the Kazakh president for his "words of support".

Earlier, all five Central Asian leaders also strongly condemned the deadly attack in their messages of condolences to Putin. (See: Briefing: Central Asian leaders condemn Moscow attack)

Source: Gazeta.uz website, Tashkent, in Russian 1042 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Russian talk shows: Putin interview, incursion from Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At a glance
body:
- Russian state TV's current affairs talk shows on 13 March provided extensive coverage of an interview with President Vladimir Putin that was broadcast earlier in the day

- Reports in the Western media casting remarks by Putin on Russia's nuclear arsenal as a threat and linking it to the previous day's reported cross-border incursion from Ukraine were dismissed as over-the-top and mendacious

- But one of the programmes itself linked his comment to the incursion

Full story

Russian TV talk shows on 13 March devoted much of their airtime to discussing an interview given by President Vladimir Putin to state TV host Dmitry Kiselyov.

But the two main programmes, state Rossiya 1's 60 Minutes and government-controlled Channel One's Vremya Pokazhet, took very different approaches.

On Vremya Pokazhet, the focus was very much on ridiculing as distorted Western media coverage that was said to have interpreted Putin's remark that Russia is militarily to use its nuclear weapons as a threat.

"People in the West like to scare themselves, maintain themselves through lies, and because of that, they are using lies and manipulating with all their might," said presenter Olesya Loseva at the top of the show.

She added that Putin's remarks were being "torn out of context", adding: "I don't know, maybe it makes them happy."

Responding, studio guest Frants Klintsevich stressed that Russia "will never be the first to use nuclear weapons, and what's most important, there are no preconditions for this right now".

He then explained that the point was that Russia's armed forces, and specifically its nuclear deterrent, were no longer in the parlous state they once were in the 1990s.

"The narrative has been let loose that seeks to prove our political inability to act to settle any issues, to prove our unpleasant aggressive Russian character, some kind of intentions on our part," he said, adding: "The main thing is not to harm oneself, one's own people. People know this."

He then turned to the camera, as if to address the viewers, and said: "So, don't worry, people, everything will be fine."

The programme was especially at pains to reject what were said to be Western media interpretations linking Putin's remarks on nuclear weapons to the previous day's claimed armed incursion from Ukraine.

Pointing to a headline on the Independent's live page - now amended to read differently - that said that "Putin is prepared for nuclear war as pro-Kyiv militias launch cross-border incursion", co-host Ruslan Ostashko said:" I never stop being surprised at so-called Western journalism."

"Where did they hear this in the interview? Nothing close to that was said," he said.

However, over on Rossiya 1, the same approach as the Independent was arguably taken by 60 Minut's presenter, Olga Skabeyeva, in linking the two developments.

"Putin for the first time commented on the attack by Ukrainian terrorists on Belgorod and Kursk regions, and said that Russia is ready for nuclear war, in an extreme case, of course, but the nuclear triad is ready," she said at the top of her programme.

Unlike 60 Minut, which did not make prominent mention of the previous day's reported incursion, 60 Minut devoted a fair chunk at the top of the programme to the official Defence Ministry line that it been stopped at the border with great losses to the attackers.

"The incursion of Ukrainian terrorists into Russian territory was a complete failure, and Russian intelligence knew about the plan to attack from three directions at once," Skabeveya said in an unattributed comment stated as fact.

The programme went on to show lengthy excerpts from Putin's speech throughout.

Putin's remarks saying that Russia was ready for negotiations on Ukraine in principle, but only on the basis of "facts that have emerged on the ground" rather than "wishful desires after the use of psychotropic substances" was especially highlighted.

The latter comment was interpreted by Skabeyeva as meaning that Putin had, in her words, "again and unambiguously hinted that [President Volodymyr] Zelensky really is a drug addict".

60 Minutes did find time to mock Western media reaction to Putin's comments as hysterical, albeit far less prominently than Vremya Pokazhet.

Putin's comments that Russia was ready to consider responding in kind if the US resumes nuclear testing had made the "Western propaganda machine literally blow up into pieces", according to Skabeyeva.

Later, she spoke of "Western lead articles about Putin having issued terrifying warnings", commenting: "Once again, we have been misunderstood."

Source: BBC Monitoring in Russian 13 Mar 24

title: At least two reportedly killed in aid airdrop in Gaza
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least two people have been killed in Gaza by an airdrop package of aid when the parachutes failed to properly deploy and parcels fell on them, the London-based Al-Quds al-Arabi newspaper's website cited Palestinian sources as saying on 8 March.
body:
Meanwhile, Israeli sources said that at least five were killed in the incident which occurred in Al-Shatti camp in northern Gaza, adding that the aid packages were dropped by a US plane.

A video posted to social media showed humanitarian aid parcels being dropped from a plane and drifting through the sky. The widely-circulated video also showed a parachute that failed to open and its parcel dropped violently. 

In recent days, the US, the UK, Jordan, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and France have airdropped aid, including medicine and food, into the Gaza Strip amid a deepening humanitarian crisis and disruptions of delivery by truck convoys. 

While aid trucks have been entering the Gaza Strip from Egypt and Israel through two crossings along Gaza's southern border, efforts to get supplies to the northern Gaza Strip, where an estimated 300,000 people remain, have been suspended amid continuing fighting and restrictions on movement.

Airdrops of humanitarian aid into the Gaza Strip have been met with criticism by social media users, including some in Gaza, who called to stop "dropping bombs" and asserted that the aid being delivered from the air is insufficient.

See also: Briefing: Social media users criticise Gaza aid drops

Source: Al-Quds al-Arabi, London, in Arabic 1300 GMT 8 Mar 24

title: Unidentified armed men abduct 30 people in northern DR Congo
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 30 people have been kidnapped in northern DR Congo's Bas Uele Province, following a raid by armed men in Digba locality, privately-owned Top Congo FM reported on 17 March.
body:
The incident took place in the chiefdom of Sasa, 45km from the urban centre of Ango territory.

"Combatants who are yet to be identified made an incursion in Sasa chiefdom, 45km from the territory’s chief town. They kidnapped 32 people: 14 boys and 16 girls," said Marcelin Mazalea, the administrator of Ango territory.

He urged the authorities to reinforce security arrangements in the area.

The incident took place two days after three people were abducted in Gwani village, which is located around 70km from Digba.

Top Congo FM reported that the DR Congo Armed Forces (FARDC) were in pursuit of the kidnappers.

Source: Top Congo, Kinshasa, in French 17 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says 35 Russian drones downed overnight
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's air defences shot down 35 Russian Shahed strike drones in the early hours of 10 March, the Ukrainian Air Force has reported on Telegram.
body:
It said that a total of 39 drones were launched from Cape Chauda in Crimea and Primorsko-Akhtarsk in southern Russia.

The drones were shot down over Kirovohrad, Mykolayiv, Dnipropetrovsk, Cherkasy, Odesa, Kherson, Khmelnytskyy, Vinnytsya, Kyiv and Zhytomyr regions.

Ukraine's Defence Forces South said on Telegram on the morning of 10 March that a building on the grounds of an industrial facility in Odesa Region and a power line in Mykolayiv Region were hit by drones during the overnight attack.

An infrastructure facility was damaged by falling debris in Vinnytsya Region, according to regional governor Serhiy Borzov.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 10 Mar 24

title: Mozambique promises to strengthen army to curb insurgency
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The government of Mozambique has unveiled plans to strengthen the army's operational capability in a bid to curb the insurgency in northern Cabo Delgado Province, state-owned broadcaster TVM reported on 14 March.
body:
The announcement was made by the prime minister, Adriano Maleiane, in a brief to parliament in Maputo on 14 March.

"We reaffirm our determination to continue strengthening the operational capabilities of the Defence and Security Forces as well as deepening bilateral and multilateral cooperation with a view to tackling this complex phenomenon," Maleiane said.

Maleiane also took the occasion to acknowledge the efforts and commitment of the army to the fight against the militants and called on local communities to continue cooperating with the authorities.

The remarks come weeks after the main opposition party, Renamo, accused the government of lacking a strategy to defeat the militants operating in Cabo Delgado Province.

Source: Televiso de Moambique, Maputo, in Portuguese 1800 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Russia jails two Ukrainians for 'spying' in occupied territory
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Moscow-installed court in the occupied part of Ukraine's Zaporizhzhya Region has jailed two Ukrainians on charges of espionage, Russia's TASS news agency reported on 22 March.
body:
Citing the Office of the Prosecutor General, the report said the two men, named as Dmytro Yevselyev and Oleh Morochkovskyi, collected information in March-June 2023 and March-July 2022 respectively about Russian troops and hardware in Zaporizhzhya Region and handed it over to the Ukrainian army and secret service.

Both were jailed for 11 years.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0828 gmt 22 Mar 24

title: Pro-Ukraine groups reportedly cross into Russia, seize village
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Fighters of the Freedom of Russia Legion (FRL), the Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK), and the Siberian Battalion, anti-Kremlin paramilitary groups fighting on Ukraine's side, have entered Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions, the news website Ukrayinska Pravda reported on 12 March.
body:
It quoted the groups as saying on social media that they had crossed the border and taken control of the village of Lozovaya Rudka in Belgorod Region, while a firefight was taking place in Tyotkino, Kursk Region.

"We are finally home. As promised, we are bringing freedom and justice to our Russian land," the Siberian Battalion said on Telegram.

"Earlier we said that it would not be possible to overthrow the criminal dictatorship in Russia peacefully. It can only be removed by force of arms. Last night we started to fulfil our promise. Fierce fighting continues on the territory of the Russian Federation," it added.

Meanwhile, the FRL posted a video of a Russian armoured personnel carrier allegedly being destroyed in Tyotkino.

The FRL said in a video on Telegram that its members had entered Russia to take part in "elections", a reference to the Russian presidential election scheduled for 15-17 March.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 0720 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Turkey officials arrive in Somalia to kickstart defence deal
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Turkey defence officials on 6 March arrived in the Somali capital Mogadishu to kickstart a 10-year defence deal signed last month, state-owned Radio Mogadishu website has reported.
body:
The defence deal enables Turkey to protect Somalia's coastline and provide training and equipment to the country's naval forces.

“Part of the aim of the officials' visit to Somalia is to build, equip Somali military and enhance the recent bilateral defence and economic cooperation deal signed by the two countries," the website said.

Radio Mogadishu released pictures from a meeting between Somali and Turkish military officials but did not disclose the identities or ranks of the visiting Turkish officials.

Turkey enjoys a closer military and economic cooperation with Somalia, and top companies from the country are in charge of the operations of both Aden Adde International Airport and Mogadishu port. 

Source: Radio Mogadishu website, Mogadishu, in Somali 6 Mar 24

title: Japan, India to enhance security, economic cooperation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Japan and India are set to enhance cooperation on national security and economy, amid talks held between Japanese Foreign Minister Kamikawa Yoko and her visiting Indian counterpart S Jaishankar in Tokyo, the NHK World website reports.
body:
Both sides agreed to boost cooperation for a "free and open Indo-Pacific region" the NHK report said.

"The ministers welcomed the holding of joint exercises by Japan's Self-Defense Forces and the Indian military. They confirmed that both countries will promote defence equipment transfers and agreed to expand the possibility of cooperation in space, cyberspace and other domains," the NHK report stated.

It added that Kamikawa said that Japan "places importance" on ties with India.

See also: India minister in Japan advises joint efforts on maritime safety

Source: NHK World website, Tokyo, in English 0548 GMT 8 Mar 24

title: Iran briefly detains son of senior Sunni cleric for 'carrying illegal arms'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Farouq Esmailzehi, son of the senior Iranian Sunni cleric Molavi Abdolhamid Esmailzehi, has been briefly detained for "carrying illegal arms" and later released on bail.
body:
Traffic police detained Esmailzehi on the Zahedan-Khash highway in the south-eastern Sistan-Baluchestan Province, the Supreme National Security Council (SNSC)-affiliated Nour News Agency reported on 4 March.

Esmailzehi was travelling in his father's convoy to visit flood-stricken areas near the province's Dashtiari city when he was detained for "carrying a gun".

Nour News said that Esmailzehi's "problem was resolved after necessary inspection".

Molavi Abdolhamid is the Sunni Friday prayer leader for the provincial capital Zahedan, and is known for his activism for Sunni rights.

He has faced anger from the establishment and a discreditation campaign in hardline media after his harsh criticism of the authorities since the nationwide protests which erupted following the death of Mahsa Amini in morality police custody in September 2022.

Sistan-Baluchestan was one of the most active provinces during the protests, especially after the "Bloody Friday of Zahedan" on 30 September that year, when dozens of people were killed.

See also (from September 2023): Explainer: The longevity of protests in Iran's restive south-east

(From January 2024): Explainer: Baluchi dissidence in Iran, Pakistan and Afghanistan

Source: Nour News website, Tehran, in Persian 0912 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Police officer killed, election candidate attacked in south-western Iran
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A police officer has been killed and another wounded in the city of Yasuj, capital of the south-western Kohgiluyeh-Boyerahmad Province, the state broadcaster's IRIB News Agency reported on 5 March.
body:
The Yasuj prosecutor, Ali Malek Hosseini, said the incident happened as an individual, who is remaining at large, opened fire at the police forces that had arrived at the place following a report on domestic violence.

Malek Hosseini added that the security, military and judiciary bodies have been following up on a recent attack attacked against a parliamentary election candidate, without providing any further details.

Moderate news outlet Khabar Online website identified the candidate as Meysam Rouzestan in a later report, saying that he was attacked by unknown individuals who used pellet guns, knives and bats to attack him on 4 March. Rouzestan is reportedly being treated for his injuries at a local hospital.

Khabar Online also cited Malek Hosseini as rejecting social media reports claiming that houses of three other candidates in the same constituency were raided by the same unknown individuals.

Iran held the parliamentary and Assembly of Experts elections on 1 March, amid calls for boycotting over the deadly crackdown on the 2022 protests and lack of competition.

Iranian media have reported several attacks on Basij members and polling station staff during the elections.

Source: IRIB News Agency, Tehran, in Persian 0525 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Putin discusses Moscow attack with Turkey, Syria leaders by phone
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Vladimir Putin has discussed the 22 March attack on the Crocus Centre Hall near Moscow in phone calls with his counterparts from Turkey and Syria, the Kremlin press service said on 23 March.
body:
The press service noted in a statement that Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had "emphasised the urgent need for closer bilateral cooperation in the fight against the terrorist threat", and that Putin had "supported the idea".

In another phone call, also on 23 March, Putin and Syrian President Bashar al-Assad agreed "to intensify contacts both in the field of anti-terrorism and in all other areas of bilateral interaction," the Kremlin said.

They also discussed the " crisis situation in the Middle East region and the current situation in Syria, which is dealing face to face with a terrorist threat"," the statement added.

It noted that both the Turkish and Syrian leaders had expressed their condolences for the loss of life in the Moscow concert hall attack.

Source: President of the Russian Federation website, Moscow, in English 1630 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Ingushetia Media 11-17 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are highlights from the website of the Ingushetia administration, the website of the Ingushetia newspaper and the Fortanga news agency for the period 11-17 March 2024:

Presidential election
body:
Refugees from Gaza holding Russian citizenship who are temporarily residing in Ingushetia have voted in the presidential election, the Ingushetia newspaper reported. Ten Gaza residents, accompanied by the republic's minister of external affairs, national policy, the press and information, Ruslan Miziyev, came to vote in Magas.

From December 2023 to January 2024, Ingushetia received four groups of Gaza refugees, totaling some 130 people, mostly children who are already studying at a school near their hotel. In November 2023, a charity auction in Ingushetia raised over 180 tonnes of humanitarian aid for Palestinians. (Ingushetia daily, 16 Mar 24)

A total of 85.21% of eligible residents of Ingushetia had cast their votes in the presidential election by two hours prior to the end of voting on 17 March, Ingushetia head Makhmud-Ali Kalimatov said, as reported by the website of the republic's government. The greatest turnout was reported in Dzheyrakh District (92.54%), the city of Magas (91.77%) and Malgobek District (86.25%). (Website of the Ingushetia government, 17 Mar 24)

Economic

Ingushetia leads Russia in the lowest loan debt load level, with the average per-capita bank debt ratio to annual wage standing at 14.9% (up un 12.2% year-on-year), the Ingushetia daily reported. Tyva and Kalmykia are Russia's most loan-burdened regions. (Website of the Ingushetia daily, 11 Mar 24)

Crime

The Southern District Military Court in Rostov-on-Don has sentenced Khavazh Derbichev, a resident of Malgobek, to 15 years and six months in maximum security penitentiary on charges of financing terrorist activities, the Fortanga news agency reported, citing the Sapa Kavkaz Telegram channel.

According to the investigators, Derbichev allowed his friend Ilyas Kartoyev to use his bank accounts for purposes of collecting donations towards a number of charity projects, such as the digging of wells in Africa. The investigators assert that of the 29.9m roubles thus collected, 13.4m was then used to fund the Islamic State terrorist organisation, and that Derbichev was aware of the fact and was paid by Kartoyev for his services.

Kartoyev and another purported accomplice, the Islamic priest Aby Umar Sasitlinsky (Israil Akhmednabiyev), are currently in Turkey. (Fortanga news agency, 13 Mar 24).

Source: BBC Monitoring 17 Mar 24

title: Rwanda receives equipment, drugs worth $13,800 from China
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Rwanda has received medical equipment and drugs worth about $13,800 through a four-decade long medical partnership with China, privately-run pro-state The New Times website reported on 4 March.
body:
The partnership has also seen Chinese medics treat patients in Masaka Hospital in the capital, Kigali and Kibungo Referral Hospital in eastern Rwanda.

"We have been doing this for 42 years. Every year we have a donation for hospitals including Kibungo referral hospital," The 24th China Medical Team chief Zhang He Ping was quoted as saying.

Some of the donated tools include theatre lights, epidural puncture package, a dental chair, an air compressor and so on, as well as medicine.

Kibungo Hospital director general Dr John Gahima said the hospital will use the equipment for treatment and in teaching medical students.

Media reports say China has donated medical equipment worth billions of francs and sent over 285 medical professionals to work in Rwanda under the programme.

Source: The New Times website, Kigali, 4 Mar 24

title: Yemen Houthi official announces further plans to reopen key roads
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An official from Yemen's Houthi movement has announced further plans to reopen roads linking rebel-controlled territory with areas governed by the internationally recognised government.
body:
Houthi-controlled Saba news agency said on 6 March that the rebel minister of public works and roads, Ghaleb Mutlaq, had revealed that arrangements were underway to open two separate roads from the capital Sanaa leading to the southern port city of Aden, the seat of the internationally recognised government.

It quoted the Houthi minister as telling the news agency that the "two important roads that serve millions of Yemenis" and linked many of the country's provinces were being reopened at the request of the rebel group's leadership.

Mutlaq stressed that the move comes ahead of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan and would have "a significant impact in alleviating the suffering of millions of citizens".

The government and the Houthis have been engaged in a war of words in recent weeks over their respective plans to reopen roads, which has been a sticking point in peace talks between the two sides.

See our additional reporting on the issue: Yemen official continues war of words with Houthis over reopening roads

Briefing: Houthis announce reopening of roads to government-held territory

Briefing: Yemen website sceptical as warring parties plan reopening of key roads

Source: Saba news agency website, Sanaa, in Arabic 6 Mar 24

title: Philippines says boats damaged, crew injured in collision with China vessels
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Authorities in the Philippines have said that China Coast Guard (CCG) ships collided with and fired water cannons at Filipino boats conducting a resupply mission in the South China Sea, causing minor damage and injuries, The Philippine Star newspaper website reported.
body:
A Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) spokesperson said the country's patrol vessels - BRP Cabra and BRP Sindangan - faced "dangerous manoeuvres and blocking" from the CCG and Chinese maritime militia during a resupply mission to troops stationed at BRP Sierra Madre in Scarbourough Shoal.

"Their reckless and illegal actions led to a collision between [BRP Sindangan] and China Coast Guard 21555 that resulted in minor structural damage to the PCG vessel," the spokesperson said on 5 March. 

Meanwhile, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr on 4 March said his country will cooperate with China in talks on the disputed South China Sea but will push back when its sovereignty and maritime rights are ignored.

Source: The Philippine Star website, Manila, in English 0800 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Islamic Resistance in Iraq claims it hit Israel's Ben Gurion airport
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI) claimed that it carried out a drone attack on Israel’s Ben Gurion airport.
body:
The Iran-backed militia said in a statement on Telegram on 12 March that the attack comes “in support of our people in Gaza and in response to the Zionist massacres against the unarmed Palestinian civilians”.

The group released a video on 12 March purportedly showing the launch of the drones used in the attack. 

Israeli media has not reported an attack on the airport, located near Tel Aviv.

On 6 March, the militia claimed a drone attack on a power station in Israel’s Haifa airport.

The IRI is an umbrella group comprising pro-Iran militias active in Iraq and Syria that seemed to have intensified their anti-US activities following the outbreak of the Gaza war.

On 3 November, it announced the expansion of its operations to targets in Israel.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 0125 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Iran's Khamenei reaffirms support for Gaza, denounces Western stance
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei​​​​​​​ has condemned the West's stance on the Gaza War, reaffirming Iran's backing for humanitarian efforts in the occupied strip.

title: N Korea's ruling party delegation meets China foreign minister in Beijing
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of a North Korean ruling party delegation has called for further strengthening ties with China during a meeting with Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Beijing, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.

title: Ethiopia struggles with cargo shipments amid Red Sea security crisis
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Ethiopian shipping company has said that it's struggling with disrupted cargo shipments amid the Red Sea security crisis, privately-owned Addis Standard website reported on 28 March.
body:
The Ethiopian Shipping and Logistics Service Enterprise said that the impediments it faced in its cargo operations due to the ongoing security crisis in the Red Sea was significantly impacting the country's import and export activities.

“In an official statement, the state-owned enterprise highlighted that major shipping companies have curtailed their visits to the region, with some ceasing operations altogether due to the precarious conditions prevailing in the Red Sea. This development has resulted in logistical challenges concerning both the time and expenses involved in shipments to and from Ethiopia,” the report said.

The company elaborated that numerous cargo vessels - previously integral to its operations through collaborative arrangements - had refrained from docking at the Djibouti port owing to the heightened risks in the Red Sea vicinity.

Consequently, the shipping company has escalated the utilisation of its own fleet to transport goods from the ports of origin for inbound shipments, ensuring the continuity of the import supply chain. 

See: Briefing: Djibouti urges Yemen's Houthis to stop Red Sea attacks

Source: Addis Standard website, Addis Ababa, in English, 28 Mar 24

title: Islamic Resistance in Iraq claims attack on Israeli base in Golan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI) has claimed a drone attack on an Israeli “drone base in the occupied Golan [Heights]” in Syria.
body:
The militia said in a Telegram post on 18 March that the attack “comes in support of our people in Gaza and in response to the Zionist massacres against the unarmed Palestinian civilians”.

IRI released a video purportedly showing the launch of the drones used in the attack.

The Israeli media has not reported on such an incident.

On 12 March, the militia claimed an attack on Israel’s Ben Gurion airport.

The IRI is an umbrella group comprising pro-Iran militias active in Iraq and Syria that seemed to have intensified their anti-US activities following the outbreak of the Gaza war.

On 3 November, it announced the expansion of its operations to targets in Israel.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 0123 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Sudanese leader congratulates Russia's Putin on poll victory
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Sudan's de facto president Lt Gen Abdel Fattah Burhan on 18 March congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin on his election victory, state-owned Sudan News Agency (Suna) reported.
body:
“It is my great pleasure to extend, in my name, and on behalf of myself and the government and people of the Republic of Sudan, my warmest congratulations to Your Excellency on your election as president of the sisterly Federal Republic of Russia,” Sunna quoted Burhan as saying in a statement.

"He stated that Sudan was looking forward to working with Russia to develop bilateral relations in various areas,” Suna added.

Sudan’s military-led government has maintained the strong relations with Russia it had during the tenure of former President Omar al-Bashir. 

In August 2022, Sudan and Russia signed 10 cooperation agreements in various fields, including energy and mining.

Russia has been seeking to build a naval base on Sudan’s eastern Red Sea coast.

Source: Suna news agency website, Khartoum, in Arabic 18 Mar 24

title: Up to five people said involved in Moscow concert hall attack - agency
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A group of up to five people was involved in the shooting attack and blast at Moscow's Crocus City Hall concert venue, Interfax news agency reports, quoting emergency services.
body:
The group is thought to consist of between two and five people in camouflage and armed with automatic weapons, the report said.

The attackers fired at the security guards at the entrance to the concert venue and then opened fire on audience members in the foyer, it said.

Graphic videos circulating on Telegram and Rossiya 24 rolling news channel show the attackers firing on audience members in what appears to be the foyer and the main auditorium of Crocus City Hall.

Another report, by state news agency TASS, said there were still people inside the building, which is on fire.

There are also reports on social media that the building's roof has collapsed and that there has been a second explosion.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1811 gmt 22 Mar 24

title: Zambia gets $150,000 grant from Japan to buy ambulance, desks
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Zambia has received a $150,000 grant from Japan to procure desks, an ambulance and build a classroom in districts in the country’s Copperbelt region, state-owned Zambian Daily Mail newspaper reported on 20 March.
body:
Japanese ambassador to Zambia Takeuchi Kazuyuki said $88,000 will be used to buy a second-hand ambulance for the Kabwe district health office, $40,000 for building a classroom block at Mutendere Secondary School in Kafue and $22,000 for furniture in eight schools in Chingola district.

“The provision of a second-hand ambulance for Kabwe district is for enhancing access to quality medical service in rural areas. The other two projects are to improve the educational environment for the overcrowded schools,” Kazuyuki was quoted as saying.

Zambia’s Minister of Education Douglas Zyakalima thanked the Japanese government for the grants, adding that the ambulance will help tackle maternal deaths in Kabwe, while the desks and the classrooms will improve learning.

Zambia has struggled with high school enrolment since the introduction of free education from early childhood to secondary school level in 2022.

Source: Zambia Daily Mail website, Lusaka, 20 Mar 24

title: Putin discusses Moscow development with mayor - Kremlin readout
snippet:
Text of report in English by Russian presidential website on 4 March

Vladimir Putin held a working meeting with Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin to discuss Moscow's socioeconomic development, including the development of transport infrastructure, improvement of production performance and investment activity.
body:
President of Russia Vladimir Putin: How are the things, Mr Sobyanin?

Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin: I must say, Mr President, despite our enemies' scheming and sanctions...

Vladimir Putin: We have more friends than we have enemies.

Sergei Sobyanin: I do not know about others, but for us, everything is going quite well.

Vladimir Putin: There is a famous saying, "It is equally honourable to be Russia's friend or enemy."

Sergei Sobyanin: Bless their hearts.

I think that Moscow's 2023 performance results are among the best in recent history. We are witnessing significant growth across the key production indicators such as pharmaceuticals, car manufacturing, and microelectronics, with growth ranging from 25% to 40%. Investment in property, both commercial and residential, as well as housing construction, are on a continuous upward trajectory. Our renovation programme is also ongoing.

The projects we have launched with you, such as Moscow Metro's Big Circle Line and the High-Speed Diameter, are operating efficiently. Currently, the Big Circle Line transports 1.3 million people daily, while the high-speed diameter accommodates 400,000 cars daily. In terms of economic impact, over a trillion roubles has been added to the federal budget and extra-budgetary funds with the start of the Big Circle Line, providing significant budgetary benefits.

Vladimir Putin: Since it started operating?

Sergei Sobyanin: No, since the construction started: while construction is in progress, the budget already benefits from VAT and taxes. The phased introduction of the Big Circle Line over several years has resulted in direct advantages.

The city budget is developing successfully, with investments showing varying trends in different years (shows a presentation). However, considering longer periods, such as from 2009 to 2011, our investment volume has surged from two trillion to 17 trillion, a 3.7-fold increase even in comparable prices. This includes investments in housing, buildings, machinery, purchased equipment, and intellectual property. The city demonstrates remarkable growth dynamics, thanks to your support, the Government, and, of course, the residents of Moscow, who are working actively and stay optimistic.

Vladimir Putin: We understand that the threats we are facing are not empty and we need to keep that in mind at all levels, the Government, federal and regional. Moscow is not just a region, it is the capital and the country's scientific, educational, and industrial centre. Therefore, it is all connected with the economy of the entire country. And we need to constantly keep that in mind. Let us discuss all this in more detail.

Sergei Sobyanin: Absolutely, Mr President.

Source: President of the Russian Federation website in English 1400 gmt 4 Mar 24

title: Japan says foreign ministry staff to accompany soccer team to N Korea
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Japanese government has said foreign ministry staff will accompany the country's national soccer team to North Korea for a World Cup qualifier next week, the website of national broadcaster NHK World reported.
body:
Japan will play North Korea for a 2026 World Cup Asian qualifier match in Pyongyang on 26 March.

The Japanese government has also urged its nationals to refrain from traveling to North Korea as part of its sanctions against the country over its nuclear weapons and ballistic missile development programme. 

The government has announced it will send 14 people to North Korea to assist the team, including foreign ministry staff in charge of crisis management.

Last month, North Korea hinted at the possibility of having better ties with Japan, including a visit to Pyongyang by Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida.

Source: NHK World website, Tokyo, in English 0400 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Kenya and Tanzania reach 'landmark' trade agreement
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kenya and Tanzania signed a landmark trade deal on 22 March after months of negotiations aimed at addressing various trade barriers, the state-run Kenyan broadcaster KBC reported.
body:
"The agreement will enable Kenya to resume exporting key commodities to Tanzania such as tea as well as facilitate the clearance of Konyagi and timber from Tanzania," the channel said, referring to a brand of gin popular in the two countries.

"The milestone was achieved during the eighth Joint Trade Committee meeting, co-chaired by Trade Cabinet Secretary Rebecca Miano and her Tanzanian counterpart Stephen Dyabato."

According to KBC, the meeting was held in the western Kenyan county of Kisumu on 18-22 March a the directives of presidents William Ruto and Samia Suluhu Hassan to resolve trade barriers between the two nations.

In 2017 and 2018, the government of late Tanzanian President John Magufuli set on fire over 11,000 live chicks imported from Kenya on grounds that they were smuggled into Tanzania, a move that soured trade relations between the two neighbouring countries.

Source: KBC website kbc.co.ke, Nairobi, 22 Mar 24

title: Mali junta arrests students amid ban of association
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Authorities have arrested an unknown number of students from the Malian Association of Students (AEEM) amid increasing tension between the military-led government and the association, French public radio RFI reported on 31 March.

title: Al-Shabab claims killing 11 police officers in 25 March Kenya attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Somalia-based al-Shabab militant group has said that it killed 11 Kenyan police officers and wounded eight others in a bomb attack in the northern border town of Mandera on 25 March, its mouthpiece Radio Andalus reported on 26 March.

title: Al-Qaeda claims killing over 25 in multiple attacks on Burkina Faso military
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Qaeda in the Sahel has claimed that it killed over 25 in four separate attacks on army personnel and pro-government militia members in Burkina Faso.

title: Some 23 soldiers killed in west Niger militant attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 23 Niger soldiers were killed on 20 March in an ambush by militants between the western localities of Teguey and Bankilare.

title: Pakistan accuses India of violating advance notice pact with missile test
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan has accused India of violating an agreement on advance notification with the recent test of its MIRV-enabled Agni-5 ballistic missile test, The Express Tribune newspaper reported on its website on 14 March.
body:
"The advance notification was shared by India but it did not follow the three-day timeline as stipulated in Article 2 of the Agreement on Pre-notification of the Fight Testing of Ballistic Missiles… The agreement on pre-notification we believe must be complied with in letter and spirit," Foreign Office spokesperson Mumtaz Zehra Baloch said at a weekly press briefing on 14 March.

According to the pact, the two countries need to give advance notice for any test.

India on 11 March announced a successful flight test of the Agni-5 missile with Multiple Independently Targetable Reentry Vehicle (MIRV) technology.

See also: Briefing: Indian media say MIRV-enabled Agni missile message to China, Pakistan

Briefing: China steps up criticism of India over missile, tunnel inauguration

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0330 GMT 15 Mar 24

title: Bangladesh trying to communicate with pirates of hijacked ship - minister
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Bangladeshi Foreign Minister Hasan Mahmud has said that the government is trying to communicate with the pirates of hijacked ship MV Abdullah, who are suspected to be Somalis, The Daily Star newspaper reported on its website.
body:
"Intelligence agencies are working on the matter. The prime minister is very concerned over the incident," he said on 13 March, adding: "We have already contacted with [as received] the different countries."

Meanwhile, the ship's chief officer, Atiqullah Khan, sent information that the hijacked ship has food supplies for around 25 days and 200 tonnes of drinking water, Prothom Alo newspaper's website reported.

On 12 March, suspected Somali pirates hijacked the ship with 23 Bangladeshi crew members in the Indian Ocean, media reports said.

Source: The Daily Star website, Dhaka, in English 1549 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Iran leader thanks people for voting despite 'enemy propaganda'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei has thanked Iranians for their "jihadi" presence in the parliamentary and Assembly of Experts elections on 1 March, "despite propaganda by the enemies" calling for election boycott.
body:
"We call it jihad, because it was carried out in defiance of the enemies' propaganda," Khamenei said in brief remarks during his annual tradition of planting a sapling to mark the Iranian Arbour Day. Khamenei's remarks were published by his website on 5 March.

He claimed that "the enemies" from "around the world" tried to sabotage the elections and dissuade the people from voting, but Iranians countered it "in an epic move". 

The 41% voter turnout is slightly lower than the previous record low of 42.5% in the 2020 parliamentary election, but the authorities have nonetheless hailed the elections as a success.

The supreme leader said the voters fulfilled their "social and civilisational duty", reaffirming his previous remarks on elections being a "duty" amid expectation of low turnouts.

Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi similarly praised the turnout on 2 March, describing it as a "big no" to Iran's opponents.

Khamenei also mentioned the recent floods in the impoverished south-eastern Sistan-Baluchestan province, calling for the "continuation of the ongoing efforts" to help the people in the flood-hit region. His remarks come amid strong criticism by the local population about insufficient measures taken by the government.

Source: Khamenei.ir, Tehran, in Persian 0900 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Ethiopia's Amhara, Tigray regions agree to solve border row
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Ethiopian national panel on the boundary dispute between Amhara and Tigray regions has said there is need to resolve the issue in a "speedy and sustainable manner" and return displaced people to their homes, the private Ethiopian Satellite TV (ESAT TV) reported on 18 March.
body:
"The national committee that was set up to look into the boundary dispute between Amhara and Tigray regions has agreed to solve the political, social and economic problems in areas affected by boundary and identity problems," the report said.

It added that Deputy Prime Minister Temesgen Tiruneh, National Intelligence and Security Director General Redwan Hussien and Amhara and Tigray regional leader Arega Kebede and Getachew Reda, respectively, attended the meeting.

Tigray had rejected a referendum proposed by the federal government to decide ownership of the disputed areas, which have been controlled by Amhara since a two-year civil war erupted in the north of Ethiopia in November 2020.

See Briefing: Ethiopia government, Tigray region feud over peace deal implementation

Source: ESAT TV, Addis Ababa, in Amharic 0400 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Iran judiciary says over 1,000 people detained on recent polling day
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Authorities temporarily arrested over 1,000 people on election day when Iranians headed to polls on 1 March to elect members of parliament (Majlis) and the leadership watchdog, the Assembly of Experts, an official from the country's judiciary has said.
body:
Asghar Jahangir, the head of crime prevention department of the judiciary, said 1,254 arrests were made across the country on grounds of election violations, adding that 1,200 were released on the same day, the judiciary-run Mizan Online reported on 11 March.

Jahangir also pointed out that about 60 individuals remained detained for their involvement in armed conflicts, possession of weapons, and other activities against security.

Briefing senior judiciary officials about the performance of the headquarters for the prevention of crimes and election violations, Jahangir stated that a month prior to the elections ,193 electoral crimes were detected on social media platforms and 29 people were summoned. They later deleted "their published criminal content", he added. Others, he noted, also removed similar problematic content when cautioned via mobile phone messages.

See: Explainer: How Iran is using state media to bring out voters on 1 March

Explainer: What are the main takeaways from Iran's 2024 elections?

Source: Mizan news agency, Tehran, in Persian 0930 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 27 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Hamas condemns 'false Israeli narrative' on hospital strike
body:
The Hamas-run Government Media Office (GMO) issued a lengthy statement on Telegram yesterday which it said "refuted the Israeli occupation's false narrative" about the attack on Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis in southern Gaza on 25 August.

Israeli media reported that the "double-tap" attack that killed 20 people in Gaza had targeted a camera placed on the hospital's balcony and used for observing Israeli forces.

The statement argued that the camera had belonged to cameraman Hossam al-Masry, who had been killed in the attack, and it was "clearly visible like the sun broadcasting live for media outlets".

The GMO denounced Israel's "criminal tactic", saying that the second strike on the hospital had "intentionally hit" civil defence teams, journalists and humanitarian workers, "most of whom were killed in the second strike, not the first one".

Israeli media highlight mass protests

Israeli media this morning continued to cover yesterday's mass protests calling for the release of hostages being held in Gaza.

The Ynet news site reported that the hostages' families and protesters had condemned the government for postponing discussion of a hostage deal.

The outlet highlighted a backlash by the families following reports that ministers had shortened a cabinet meeting in order to attend a "lavish" dinner.

Ynet quoted a hostage family member as saying: "Instead of sending an urgent delegation to negotiations, they discussed expanding the operation [in Gaza] and hurried off to celebrate at dinner."

Right-wing pro-Netanyahu Channel 14 reported last night said that the protestors had disrupted its broadcasting from the "Hostages Square" in Tel Aviv in a "threatening manner", and called the act "anarchy".

Qatar says Israel has not yet responded to Gaza deal

Spokesman for the Qatari foreign ministry Majed al-Ansari yesterday said that Israel had not yet provided any official response to the latest Gaza ceasefire proposal presented by the mediators.

He noted that Hamas had earlier announced its approval of the new proposal "which largely aligns with previous Israeli demands", Qatari foreign ministry quoted him as saying in his weekly press briefing.

Ansari said that the "ball is now in the Israeli court", adding that Qatar was urging "international parties to exert pressure on Israel to respond to the mediation proposal".

In an early morning bulletin, the UAE-based Sky News Arabia highlighted the Israeli security cabinet's "ignoring a discussion of the mediator's proposal to stop the war".

US envoy comments spark condemnation in Lebanon

US Special Envoy Thomas Barrack's scolding of journalists during a press conference in Beirut has been widely criticised by Lebanese media outlets.

Prominent Lebanese broadcaster MTV reported yesterday that Barrack had described the behaviour of journalists during the press conference as "animalistic" and reportedly told them to "shut up for a moment" and be "civilised".

MTV said that his comments had been "met with widespread rejection and criticism".

His press conference came following a meeting between a US delegation and Lebanese President Joseph Aoun, amid discussions over the possible disarmament of Hezbollah.

State news agency NNA reported that the Lebanese presidency had issued a statement expressing "regret" over the "words that were unintentionally uttered".

Iranian hardliners have also seized on Barrack's words. Separately, Saudi-owned Asharq al-Awsat published an interview with Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi in which he insisted that Iran was not interfering in Lebanon, and saying that it was against the break-up of Syria.

We will publish a briefing.

Israeli drone strike in Syria kills six soldiers

Syrian media have confirmed that six Syrian soldiers were killed in an Israeli drone strike south of Damascus yesterday.

Syrian state-run news channel Al-Ikhbariyah al-Suriyah reported that the strike had targeted an area near the town of al-Kiswah, 13 kilometres south of the capital.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights noted that the drones had targeted the vicinity of Matleh in Rif Dimashq province on the road between Damascus and the Druze-majority province of Suweida, stopping the movement of traffic on the road.

Al-Ikhbariyah reported that a civilian had also been killed in a drone strike yesterday in the village of Taranja (also Turnejeh) to the southwest, inside the buffer zone that formerly separated Israeli and Syrian forces in the Golan Heights.

On 25 August, the Syrian foreign ministry described as a "dangerous escalation" an Israeli military incursion in the same area.

See also our Turkey Watchlist for coverage of Turkish condemnation of the strikes and President Erdogan's calls for Kurdish forces to join the Syrian military.

Houthi media spotlight missile attack on Israel

Houthi-run media highlighted a reported missile attack from Yemen targeting Israel late last night.

The group's Al-Masirah TV said a missile fired from Yemen had caused "disturbances in occupied Palestine", pointing to Israeli media reports.

The Israeli military said that its air force had intercepted a missile launched from Yemen, adding that alerts had been activated in the country in accordance with protocol.

Al-Masirah said that "millions of settlers" had rushed to shelters, and that operations at Ben Gurion Airport had been halted.

The outlet also shared a video which it said showed the missile flying over Israel.

It added that the group was expected to issue a statement on the attack "shortly".

Coming up

- US special envoy Steve Witkoff said in an interview with the US right-leaning Fox News network that President Trump would host a meeting today at the White House during which a "very comprehensive plan" for post-war Gaza will be discussed. Witkoff's remarks during the interview were widely reported by mainstream Israeli media, including the Ynet news site and public broadcaster Kan.

- Egypt's Senate election enters its second round of voting for Egyptians living in Egypt, and eligible voters will be able to cast their ballots for candidates in the run-off election until tomorrow. Voting for Egyptians abroad also spanned two days and concluded yesterday. The final results are due to be announced on 4 September. During the first round of voting, political parties allied with the ruling authorities won 175 seats out of 200.

title: Iran to hold run-off parliamentary election on 10 May
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The second round of Iran's parliamentary election will be held on 10 May, the spokesman of the country' election headquarters told Tasnim News Agency on 18 March.

title: Ethiopia releases ex-leader of Somali region from prison
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ethiopia has dropped an incitement charge against the former president of its south-eastern Somali regional state and released him from prison "in the best interest of the general public", the state-affiliated news website Fana has reported.
body:
"The ministry of justice announced that the charges against the former chief administrator of the Somali region, Abdi Mohamed Omar, and the former head of the … Metals and Engineering Corporation (METEC), Major General Kinfe Dagnew, have been dropped in the best interest of the general public," the website said on 14 March.

"Note that Major General Kinfe Dagnew’s legal entanglements pertaining to allegations of corruption were under consideration in the federal high court. On the other hand, it is known that the legal proceedings regarding Abdi Mohamed Omar’s case were under consideration in the first constitutional and terrorist crimes trial," it added.

Omar, also known as Abdi Iley (one-eyed in Somali), was arrested in August 2018 following clashes in the regional capital Jigjiga and other towns as well as attacks on places of worship.

He was charged with inciting violence.

He served as the region's president from 2005 to 2018. His rule was marked by continued unrest in the region and allegations of widespread human rights abuses.

Source: Fana Broadcasting Corporate website, Addis Ababa, 14 Mar 24

title: Japan PM says fighter jet exports to serve national interests
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has said that the government will continue working on a framework to enable exports of next-generation fighter jets to third countries, website of national broadcaster NHK World reported.

title: Russia's Oniks missiles equipped with new active homing seekers - report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's supersonic anti-ship Oniks cruise missiles of the Bastion coastal missile system have received new homing seekers enabling them to hit ground targets of the Ukrainian Armed Forces with high accuracy, TASS news agency reported on 27 March.
body:
"Originally developed as anti-ship missiles, Onikses, thanks to the new active homing seeker, have the ability to hit enemy ground targets with high accuracy," TASS quoted its source from the Russian military-industrial complex as saying.

Another TASS source added that "at the same time, work is underway to ensure the invulnerability of the Onikses to the effects of electronic warfare systems of the Ukrainian Armed Forces."

The P-800 Oniks supersonic anti-ship missile (also known as Yakhont) is designed to combat vessels, as well as coastal targets amidst electronic countermeasures and intense fire. These systems were used to destroy militants' targets in Syria, and are now involved in Russia's so-called "special military operation" in Ukraine, the report said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0030 gmt 27 Mar 24

title: One killed in drone attack on Russia's Belgorod Region - governor
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

One person has been killed in a drone attack on Russia's Belgorod Region bordering Ukraine, according to Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov.
body:
In a statement on Telegram, Gladkov identified the victim as a civilian in the village of Gorkovsky, Gravoronsky Municipal District.

He said two other people had been injured.

Earlier in the day he reported four deaths in a strike on the village of Nikolskoye.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1817 gmt 18 Mar 24

title: Iran's Raisi congratulates Sharif on election as Pakistan prime minister
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi has congratulated Shehbaz Sharif on his election as the prime minister of Pakistan and hoped for expansion of ties between Tehran and Islamabad, according to a statement published by the Iranian official presidential website on 5 March.
body:
In a phone call with Sharif on 4 March, Raisi said that Iran "welcomes the improvement of the level of bilateral, regional and international interactions and relations with the friendly and brotherly country" of Pakistan.

Raisi said that the two countries' relations are "based on deep historical and cultural ties" and hoped that the new government of Pakistan would "take long and successful steps towards the progress and growth of this country".

Iranian Government Spokesperson Ali Bahadori Jahromi also said on 5 March that Sharif invited Raisi to visit Pakistan during the phone call, the official IRNA news agency reported. He added Raisi would travel to Pakistan in the next Iranian calendar year, which starts on 20 March.

Serving as the Pakistani prime minister from 2022 to 2023, Sharif was elected by the country's parliament for a second term on 3 March, three weeks after an inconclusive general election that was marred by allegations of intimidation and vote-rigging.

Iranian-Pakistani relations faced a challenge in January, when Tehran launched drone and missile attacks on Pakistan targeting alleged hideouts of Sunni militant group Jaish al-Adl, prompting Islamabad to reciprocate by attacking an alleged militant group base in Iran's Sistan-Baluchestan Province. The tension led to a brief suspension of ties between the countries.

Source: president.ir website, Tehran, in Persian 0411 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Ewan McGregor and Mary Elizabeth Winstead Go From Fargo to Moscow
snippet:
The first time that Ewan McGregor and Mary Elizabeth Winstead shot a scene together, they were in a bathtub, mostly naked. McGregor, in a maximally unflattering wig, was sticking his gut out as far as it would go.

You were just trying to be as grotesque as you could be, Winstead said affectionately.
body:
This was on a recent afternoon in the chilly basement of a midtown hotel where McGregor and Winstead perched on a love seat, his jacket over his shoulders, his hand on her knee. They met in 2017, on the set of the third season of Fargo, co-starring as Ray Stussy, a hapless parole officer, and Nikki Swango, his grifter sweetheart. (McGregor also played Emmit Stussy, Rays twin.) Two years later, in 2019, they filmed Birds of Prey but did not share scenes. They are also both participants in the Star Wars franchise  McGregor in the 90s and 00s films and the more recent Obi-Wan Kenobi series, Winstead in Ahsoka  though again they did not share scenes. In 2021, Winstead gave birth to their son. The next year, they married.

Now, they have reunited onscreen for A Gentleman in Moscow, which premiered Friday on Paramount+ and debuts Sunday on Showtime. An adaptation of Amor Towless novel, it stars McGregor as Count Alexander Ilyich Rostov, a mustached aristocrat sentenced to house arrest in a luxury hotel in the years following the Russian Revolution. Winstead appears as Anna Urbanova, an actress and the counts sometimes girlfriend. Somehow, in the confines of the hotel, they make a life.

In an hourlong conversation, in a hotel somewhat more modest than Moscows Metropol, they discussed claustrophobia, facial hair and the benefits and detriments of working with a spouse. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.

How did you get involved with A Gentleman in Moscow?

EWAN MCGREGOR It came to me first. I loved the grand nature of the drama, the love and loss and romance. I feel like its rarer and rarer to get a chance to play that stuff. At the heart of it, its about a man whos learning to be a husband and learning to be a dad and crawling out of his ideas of the aristocratic way of life to find who he really is.

MARY ELIZABETH WINSTEAD You had hinted, cheekily, that there was a great female character in there. Reading the book, I just thought, Oh my God, what a great, juicy opportunity that would be to play her. But I was very tentative because the last thing I wanted was to try to win a role and then have somebody think I was trying to get something out of being married to you. I just wanted to quietly say, I think its a great role if you think Im right for it.

Did you ever worry that it would feel claustrophobic, shooting in these few hotel rooms?

MCGREGOR It had to feel like that. It should feel like that. It focuses a magnifying glass on these characters.

WINSTEAD Thats one of the great things about confined spaces. As an actor, its exciting because theres nowhere to go but into the words. Its great to know thats going to be the focus, rather than pyrotechnics.

Did you grow your own mustache?

MCGREGOR I had to. I couldnt have a stuck-on mustache. Ive had them in the past and theyre terrible to wear. You come in in the morning, youve had to shave and then you put glue on that shaved skin, which is [expletive] horrible. Then you stick it on and it stops you from moving your face. The last thing you want to be thinking about when youre acting is not moving. So I grew my own.

During the strike, I didnt know when wed be going back, so I just grew a beard around it. Because you dont want a mustache in your real life. I mean, you do if you like mustaches, but I dont.

Tell me about Alexander.

MCGREGOR Hes an aristocrat. He enjoyed the high life of his class at that time. Then its taken away during the revolution. Hes allowed to live, but the rest of his class is destroyed. So hes somewhat lost.

And what about Anna? Is she a good actress?

WINSTEAD Anna believes that she is. I do think she takes it very seriously. Its something positive in her life that gives her a sense of purpose. She does hang in there, even if shes not always a star. That has to count for something.

They have a superb meet-cute, when the count tames Annas Russian wolfhounds. Whats their initial attraction?

WINSTEAD I instantly find him very intriguing. The way that he handles my dogs, it sparks a little something. Our repartee makes me further intrigued. Then hearing about him and knowing that hes imprisoned in this hotel, the mystery is interesting to me as a woman who gets bored very easily by most men that Im around. Over time, that leads to much, much more.

Its so lovely how much time it takes. Its many years into their relationship before they realize theyre in love. Theres something beautiful about that slow progression. Especially for Anna. She resists that feeling. But it hits her like a wave.

I understand that you didnt know each other before Fargo. But Mary, is it true that you had a crush on him as a teenager?

WINSTEAD The thing is, if you were a teenager when Trainspotting and Moulin Rouge came out, I dont think you could not have an awareness. But I didnt have any posters on my wall. I wasnt writing his name in my notebook.

Good, that would be creepy. What was it like working together on Fargo?

WINSTEAD We loved it.

MCGREGOR We did. It was amazing writing. I feel like there were two shows because I played the two characters. But our story line was amazing. To play Ray and Nikki, what a great pair, what a great partnership, what a great oddball couple.
