WINSTEAD I remember meeting with Noah [Hawley, the showrunner] and my only question was, Does she really love him? And he was like, Yes. And that made it so much more interesting, to play a grifter with a heart, as cheesy as that sounds. So much more fun to have something real at the center of it.

Mary, earlier you alluded to a downside of working together, in that people might think you were offered a role for reasons other than your talent.

WINSTEAD Of course, theres always going to be one person on the internet who makes that comment, but Im secure enough to not worry about that because I know the truth, which is that people want to work with me. When we were first together, I was up for a role in something that he was in. They were worried we would bring some sort of drama to the set, which we thought was very funny because were not very dramatic people. But you have to let time deal with that. Now its clear that were a pretty levelheaded couple, that were not going around smashing vases. Other than that, its really been just upsides, which is that people who know us and like our work are happy and excited to put us together occasionally, which is a really lucky thing for us.

MCGREGOR Theres no downside in terms of actually doing it. Its only great to go to work together, get to work together, come home together. Its as good as it could be, really.

What was it like working together this time?

MCGREGOR It made it so much more fun to play all the cold-shoulder stuff at the beginning of the story. After theyve spent the night together, she wont speak to him or look at him.

WINSTEAD Then the later stuff, when things get deep, it was very emotional. I cant talk about it without crying. It was just all there, which is an amazing thing. Its just like, Oh, Im here in front of my partner. So Ill just let all those feelings wash over.

Did you like him with that mustache?

WINSTEAD You know, I did. I did for a long time. But I did start to miss his face underneath it.

Will you work together again?

WINSTEAD I dont know.

MCGREGOR (simultaneously) Yes!

WINSTEAD We hope so. Its just about finding the right beautiful thing.

title: Heavy rainfall leaves four dead in southern Mozambique
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least four people were killed, and nearly 50,000 others impacted by heavy rainfall in southern Mozambique since 24 March, state-owned AIM website reported on 26 March.
body:
The data was provided by the head of the National Department for Water Basin Management, Agostinho Vilanculo, in a press conference after a meeting of the Technical Council for Disaster Risk Management and Reduction (CTDGRRD) on 25 March in Maputo.

“The preliminary toll of the heavy rainfall recorded in southern Mozambique since 24 March indicates that at least four people died and 49,984 others were affected,” said the report.

Vilanculo said that the National Meteorology Institute had forecast heavy rainfall in northern Mozambique for the next 15 days, leading the CTDGRRD “to propose the activation of a red alert countrywide”.

The report comes as the country recovers from the passage of the tropical storm Filipo, which made landfall in southern Mozambique on 12 March, leaving three dead and 29 others injured.

Source: Agencia Informacao Mocambique website, Maputo, in Portuguese 26 Mar 24

title: Iran refinery blast leaves oil worker dead, three others injured
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A blast and ensuing blaze have left an oil worker dead and three others injured at a refinery in the southern Iranian city of Bandar Abbas, the state broadcaster's IRIB News Agency reported on 7 March.

title: PM accuses unnamed countries of working to 'destroy' Ethiopia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has accused unnamed countries of working to dismantle Ethiopia and called on the public to be cautious of the unnamed "enemies", the state channel ETV broadcast on 5 March.
body:
Abiy made the remarks during discussions with representatives from southern Ethiopia regional states.

"We have to be vigilant as people. We should not be a reason for those who want to destroy, divide and weaken Ethiopia," Abiy said.

"There are countries that are astonishingly fearful of Ethiopia, which are actively working to destroy Ethiopia. It would be good if we, Ethiopians, remain very alert," Abiy added.

The prime minister called on Ethiopians not to expose themselves to "external enemies".

Ethiopia is currently grappling with unrest as the army continues fighting insurgencies in the Amhara and Oromia regions.

Source: ETV News, Addis Ababa, in Amharic 5 Mar 24

title: India says foreign minister's Malaysia visit strengthened ties
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

India has said that foreign minister S. Jaishankar’s visit to Malaysia helped reiterate its commitment to developing the bilateral strategic partnership with Kuala Lumpur, The Hindu newspaper reported on its website on 28 March, citing the PTI news agency.
body:
Jaishankar was in Kuala Lumpur on 27-28 March as part of a regional tour that also took him to Singapore and the Philippines.

He met Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Bin Ibrahim and thanked him for his support in enhancing bilateral ties, the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said in a statement.

For his part, Anwar thanked Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi for assisting Malaysia during a rice shortage, the news report said.

Jaishankar also met his Malaysian counterpart Mohamad Bin Haji Hasan and held talks on various issues including trade, politics and defence.

They exchanged views on regional and global issues also, according to the MEA statement.

The statement described Malaysia as a key partner for India in Southeast Asia.

Source: The Hindu website, Chennai, in English 0741 GMT 28 Mar 24

title: Somalia's parliament approves constitutional amendments
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Members of Somalia's bicameral parliament on 30 March approved amendments to the first four chapters of the country’s constitution despite opposition from several key politicians and the semi-autonomous Puntland regional state, state television reported.
body:
Two hundred and eleven members of the lower house of parliament and forty-two legislators from the upper chamber voted for the changes, Somali National TV said.

The lower house has 275 members and the upper house 54.

“There are no votes against or abstentions. So amendments to the first four chapters of the constitution have been officially approved,” said lower house speaker Adan Madobe.

Former presidents Mohamed Abdullahi Farmajo and Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Ahmed have rejected the amendments, which include a shift to a presidential system of government, the abolition of the post of prime minister and the adoption of a two-party system.

The country's 2012 provisional constitution has been under review for nearly a decade, but efforts to complete the review picked up in late 2023.

See Briefing: Alarm over constitutional changes sparks Somalia political realignment

Also Briefing: Former Somali PM rejects controversial constitutional changes

Source: Somali National TV (SNTV), Mogadishu, in Somali on 30 Mar 24

title: 'Ukraine, of course' behind Moscow attack, says top Russian official
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Nikolai Patrushev, secretary of President Vladimir Putin's Security Council, has claimed that Ukraine was behind the 22 March attack on a concert hall in Moscow in which 139 people were killed.
body:
"Ukraine, of course," the state news agency TASS quoted Patrushev as saying on 26 March in reply to a question from the media about who was behind the attack.

Putin the previous day said it was "the hands of radical Islamists" that committed the attack but also claimed that Ukraine and the West were likely behind the attackers.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1031 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: Dozens killed in new Burkina Faso 'massacre'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Unidentified assailants have killed dozens of people in new attacks in eastern Burkina Faso amid an escalation of violence against civilians in a country about half of which is outside government control, French public radio RFI website reported on 4 March.

title: Kremlin says Nuland played major role in destabilising Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov has accused US Under Secretary of State Victoria Nuland of playing a major role in destabilising Ukraine and deteriorating relations between Moscow and Washington.
body:
"This is a very talented diplomat; this is a diplomat who played quite an important role in the State Department," Peskov said when asked to comment on Nuland's intention to resign.

However, Peskov noted that "it would have been better if she used her talents in a peaceful, constructive sphere".

He made the remarks in an interview with Russian state TV reporter Pavel Zarubin, the Interfax news agency reported on 6 March.

Nuland "played a major role in destabilising the situation in Ukraine in 2014, she played a major role in provoking and executing the coup d'etat in Ukraine", Peskov said, referring to the mass pro-European anti-government Maidan protests in Kyiv.

"She has done a lot to resume confrontation with our country," the Kremlin spokesman added.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1323 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Mali sentences radio host Ras Bath to 18 months in prison
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Malian court has sentenced activist and well-known radio and TV host Ras Bath to 18 months in prison for "criminal conspiracy" and "attacking the state's reputation", Radio France Internationale (RFI) has reported.
body:
Bath, whose real name is Mohamed Youssouf Bathily, has been in detention for a year following his arrest in March 2023 for “falsely” claiming that the late former Malian Prime Minister Soumeylou Boubeye Maiga's death in 2022 was an assassination.

Maiga had been in detention over allegations of committing fraud in the purchase of presidential jets when he died in March 2022, less than a year after he was arrested.

Sources cited by RFI said a court in the capital Bamako on 11 March rejected lawyers' request to release the activist.

Bath has been described both as a “king-maker” and "the enfant terrible of the republic”.

In 2016, he was sentenced to one year in prison for "inciting troops to disobedience" after having castigated the army in his radio show. He was later acquitted.

He is reported to be popular amongst young Malians and has the ability to draw large crowds.

Source: Radio France Internationale, Paris, in French on 11 Mar 24

title: Al-Qaeda claims capturing Mali army barracks, killing 10
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Qaeda in the Sahel has claimed that it seized control of an army barracks and killed "at least" 10 soldiers in an attack in southern Mali.

title: Kremlin says US 'at war' with Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov has said that the US is "at war" with Russia and vowed that Moscow would continue to destroy American tanks and other hardware on the battlefield in eastern Ukraine, which he referred to as "Russian territory".
body:
"America is at war against us. US tanks are moving through the territory of the Russian Federation. This is bad," Peskov told a youth forum held near Sochi on 6 March in remarks quoted by the Interfax news agency.

"And if American planes start flying over our territory, I have no doubt that our valiant military will make sure that these planes burn and fall," he said.

He also said: "We do not like those American leaders who insult our president. We do not love them. And we do not like those American politicians and leaders who say that they will do everything for our country to suffer defeat." He said Russia would prove them wrong.

"We welcome those who want to talk to us," he said.

See also: Briefing: Russian war bloggers promote 'first visual proof' of destroyed Himars

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1108 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says 12 Russian strike drones destroyed
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences shot down 12 out of 15 Shahed-131/136 kamikaze drones Russia launched on the night of 8-9 March, the Air Force Command has reported on Telegram.
body:
The drones were downed over Dnipropetrovsk, Donetsk and Poltava regions, it said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0626 gmt 9 Mar 24

title: US Secretary of State Blinken arrives in Saudi Arabia at start of regional visit
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has arrived in the Saudi coastal city of Jeddah, his first stop on a tour of the region, Saudi flagship channel Al Arabiya reported in its 14:00 GMT bulletin on 20 March.
body:
Blinken was welcomed at the airport by Saudi officials, the channel's newsreader said over footage of his arrival, without identifying them.

The visit comes “in the context of efforts to reach a ceasefire agreement in the besieged Gaza Strip”, the outlet said, adding that Blinken "will conduct further talks with the Saudi leadership regarding the war" in Gaza.

Blinken is expected to hold talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman before heading to Egypt on 21 March, the report said.

This is the sixth visit to the region by the US official since the start of the conflict in Gaza in October, it added. A report published on Al Arabiya's English-language website on 20 March said Blinken will visit Israel on 22 March, echoing reports also in Israeli media.

He does not appear to be slated to visit Qatar, where talks on a Gaza truce are under way.

See also: Israeli team to go to US to discuss planned action in Rafah

Briefing: Pan-Arab media highlight Biden’s plan to build pier in Gaza

Source: Al Arabiya TV, Riyadh, in Arabic 1400 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says nine missiles, nine drones downed overnight
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's air defences shot down nine cruise missiles and nine drones in the early hours of 31 March, the Ukrainian Air Force has reported on Telegram.
body:
It said that Russia launched 11 Shahed strike drones, 14 Kh-101/Kh-555 cruise missiles, one Kh-59 guided aerial missile and one Iskander-M ballistic missile overnight.

The Air Force did not specify which regions were targeted.

Meanwhile, Defence Forces South said on Telegram on the morning of 31 March that eight drones were shot down over Odesa Region during the night. Falling fragments caused a fire at an energy facility, followed by power outages in several population centres.

A mothballed agricultural enterprise was hit in Kherson Region, the military said.

Lviv regional governor Maksym Kozytskyy said on Telegram that a critical infrastructure facility was struck in the region. One man was killed in the strike, he added.

Source: Telegram messaging service 31 Mar 24

title: North Korea warns South, US to pay 'dear price' for joint military drills
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korea has warned that the US and South Korea will pay a "dear price" for conducting joint military drills, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
"The large-scale war drills staged by the world's biggest nuclear weapons state and more than 10 satellite states against a state in the Korean peninsula where a nuclear war may be ignited even with a spark, can never be called 'defensive'," a spokesperson of North Korea's defence ministry said on 5 March. 

"The US and the ROK will be made to pay a dear price for their false choice while realising that it causes their security uneasiness at a serious level every moment," the spokesperson added. ROK refers to Republic of Korea, South Korea's official name.

South Korea and the US began their annual joint military drills on 4 March. The 11-day exercise will involve 48 field training drills and is aimed at boosting deterrence against North Korea's nuclear and missile threats.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0500 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Kazakh ministry denies arms supply talks with Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kazakhstan's Ministry of Defence has denied media reports of ongoing negotiations with Ukraine on the supply of weapons or components, the privately-owned Kazakh news agency Tengrinews.kz reported on 7 March, quoting the ministry's press service.

title: Iran appoints envoys to France, Tunisia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's new ambassadors to Paris and Tunisia have met Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian before travelling to their stations.

title: Ukraine says Moscow attack 'deliberate act of provocation'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Ukrainian military intelligence spokesman has said that the shooting attack on the Crocus City centre in northwest Moscow on the evening of 23 March was a "deliberate act of provocation" by Vladimir Putin's regime.
body:
"This was a deliberate act of provocation by Putin's special services, about which the international community warned. The Kremlin tyrant started his career with this, and wants to end it with the same crimes against his own citizens," Andriy Yusov told the Ukrayinska Pravda news website.

Presidential office adviser Mykhaylo Podolyak said on Telegram that Ukraine had nothing to do with the shooting in Moscow.

"Regarding the events in Moscow's Crocus City in Russia's Moscow Region, where a shooting took place today, there were certain terrorist actions by unidentified persons. Let's make it clear - Ukraine has absolutely nothing to do with these events," he said.

Podolyak insisted that Ukraine never used terrorist methods of warfare.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 2043 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Political leaders, mayoral candidates cast ballots for Turkey's local elections
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Turkey's leaders and mayoral candidates have cast their votes in the country's local elections, mainstream NTV website reported on 31 March.
body:
Voting began at 04:00 GMT (07:00 local time) and will continue until 14:00 GMT.

President Recep Tayyip Erdogan cast his vote in Istanbul and said: "The two elections have exhausted us and our nation [referring to 2023 elections]. I hope this will be the beginning of a new era."

Main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP) leader Ozgur Ozel cast his vote in his hometown in the western province of Manisa and said: "The decision belongs to our people, and we will respect this decision."

Pro-Kurdish DEM Party co-chair Tulay Hatimogullari cast his ballot in Adana, while government-ally Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) leader Devlet Bahceli voted in Ankara.

Ekrem Imamoglu, the mayor of Istanbul who is re-running in the election as the CHP candidate, cast his vote in the city's Beylikduzu district. His rival, the AKP's mayoral candidate Murat Kurum voted in the Hamidiye district of Istanbul.

Erdogan's ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) is seeking to win back major cities it lost to the opposition in 2019, primarily the country's biggest city Istanbul and the capital Ankara.

The opposition parties’ previous alliance disintegrated after their defeat in the 2023 presidential and parliamentary elections and they are running with separate candidates.

Background: Explainer: What's at stake in Turkey’s critical local elections?

See our full coverage here.

Source: NTV Online website, Istanbul, in Turkish 1130 GMT 31 Mar 24

title: Madagascar issues heavy rain alerts as it prepares for new cyclone
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Madagascar's meteorological department, Meteo Madagascar, has issued "yellow alerts" for heavy rains expected in eastern parts of the country ahead of the possible arrival of a tropical cyclone, privately-owned news website L'Express de Madagascar reported on 26 March.
body:
The affected areas include Sava Region and the Atsinanana, Maroantsera, Mananara Avaratra, Soanierana Ivongo and Sainte-Marie districts, the website said. 

"The tropical disturbance in the Indian Ocean could develop into a cyclone within the next two days," a Meteo Madagascar official said.

"The risk of this future cyclone having a direct impact on the country remains low. But the weather in the north and northeast of the country will deteriorate as it moves off our coast," he added.

Heavy rains have been recorded in the low-lying areas of the Sambava and Antalaha districts since yesterday, following intermittent rainfall but no casualties have been recorded.

Madagascar's geographical position makes it vulnerable to storms and cyclones.  At least 12 people were killed in the country during the passage of tropical storm Alvaro in January 2024.

Source: L'Express de Madagascar website, Antananarivo, in French 26 Mar 24

title: Gunmen kidnap at least 15 students in Nigeria's Sokoto State
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Gunmen have kidnapped an unknown number of students in the Gada Local Government Area in Nigeria's north-western Sokoto State, privately-owned Daily Trust website reported has reported.
body:
Liman Abubakar, the owner of Tsangaya school - located in Gidan Bakuso town - said 15 students had been confirmed missing but the exact number of the learners who were kidnapped had not been established, Daily Trust reported. He said the incident took place early on 9 March.

The gunmen had killed three people at Turba village in the Isa LGA, shot a person and kidnapped a woman in the Gidan Bakuso town before the attack on the school, the report said.

"As they were leaving the town, they sighted our students rushing into their rooms and they kidnapped many of them," Abubakar said, according to the report.

The kidnapping comes amid outrage over the kidnapping of at least 300 internally displaced persons in the north-eastern Borno State and the abduction of 287 children in the north-western Kaduna State.

See: Briefing: Nigeria denies talks with 'bandits' over kidnapped students

See: Briefing: Nigeria launches operation to rescue over 280 kidnapped students

Source: Daily Trust website, Abuja, in English 9 Mar 24

title: Ukraine intercepts 38 out of 42 Russian Shahed-type drones
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia launched 42 Shahed-type drones into Ukraine on the night of 5-6 March, Ukraine's Air Force reported on Telegram the following morning.
body:
"As a result of combat operations, 38 Shahed drones were shot down in Dnipropetrovsk, Odesa, Kherson, Khmelnytskyy, Cherkasy, Kharkiv, Vinnytsya, and Sumy regions", it said.

In Sumy, local officials said on Telegram that three drone strikes were recorded in the city, and that first responders provided assistance to victims. They did not specify the number of casualties.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0522 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Pakistan president urges strong economic ties with Iran amid US opposition
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan President Asif Ali Zardari stressed the need for promoting barter trade and economic relations with Iran for the mutual benefit of the two countries, Dawn newspaper reported on its website on 30 March.
body:
While talking to Iran’s Ambassador to Pakistan Dr Reza Amiri Moghadam, Zardari said Pakistan and Iran had great scope for expanding bilateral economic cooperation in diverse fields, the news report noted.

His comments came less than a week after the US again opposed the Pakistan-Iran gas pipeline project and cautioned about the risk of sanctions.

Zardari expressed commitment to further strengthen bilateral relations between the two countries as he called for working together to overcome the common challenges, the report said.

On his part, the Iranian envoy emphasised the need to increase trade volume, banking cooperation, and air and business linkages, the report said, adding that the envoy said Pakistan could benefit from the Chabahar-Zahedan rail road for trade with Central Asia and Europe.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0000 GMT 30 Mar 24

title: Iran minister says plans 'on agenda' to deter Israeli strikes on Syria
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's Defence Minister Brig Gen Mohammad Reza Ashtiani has said Tehran and Damascus were planning to forestall Israel's strikes on Syria, Tasnim News Agency reported on 16 March.

title: Iraqi militias claim launch of drone attacks on southern Israel
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI), an umbrella group of Iran-backed militias in Iraq and Syria, has claimed it launched drone attacks on two positions in southern Israel.
body:
The first attack was said to have been launched on the evening of 26 March against Ovda airbase in southern Israel, the IRI said on Telegram.

It said in another statement that its fighters launched another drone attack on “the Sapir military position" in the early hours of 27 March.

The Sapir Airfield, officially known as Ein Yahav Airfield, is in southern Israel near the Jordanian border.

In recent weeks, the IRI has claimed it launched a series of attacks targeting areas inside Israel, none of which have been confirmed or reported in Israeli media.

These included attacks on high-profile sites IRI said were carried out in a show of solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza, the most recent of which was said to have targeted a power plant in Tel Aviv.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2305 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab reportedly kills four in northern Kenya attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Militants from Somalia's armed group, al-Shabab, have attacked a Kenyan police post in the northern county of Mandera and killed officers manning the station, privately-owned Somalia-based Radio Kulmiye reported on 22 March in its 10:30 GMT news bulletin.
body:
Radio Kulmiye said the attack led to a direct confrontation between the "invading" al-Shabab militants and the officers at the station, with both sides suffering casualties.

“At least four Kenyan officers were confirmed to have been killed while the al-Shabab attackers lost three people,” the radio said.

It added that several other people were also wounded during the attack.

Earlier, pro-al-Shabab’s Radio Alfurqaan in its 05:00 GMT news bulletin on 22 March said the militant group attacked a police station in Alunga village, Lafey town, and that only one officer was wounded.

Kenyan villages near the porous border with Somalia have recorded a sharp increase in attacks claimed by the al-Qaeda affiliates since the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan began last week.

On 20 March, al-Shabab claimed to have killed a total of eight Kenyan soldiers and wounded three others in two separate attacks in the coastal county of Lamu.  

Source: Radio Kulmiye, Mogadishu, in Somali 1030 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Yemen website says arms shipment destined for Houthis intercepted
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Customs authorities at Yemen's Shihan border crossing with Oman have foiled a "massive operation" to smuggle military communication equipment believed to be destined for the Houthi rebels, a leading Yemeni news site reported on 7 March.
body:
Al-Masdar Online cited an informed source as saying that the authorities had on the previous day seized a shipment of 600 Motorola military walkie-talkies hidden inside paper cutting machines.

The shipment also included other equipment such as power converters, antenna network connectors and lithium batteries, the source said.

The website said that there were no details available on the final destination of the shipment but that previous reports had said that shipments of similar equipment that was seized had been on their way to the Houthis. It said that the border crossing was thought to be one of the routes through which weapons equipment was smuggled to the rebels, according to reports by international experts.

Both Iran and the Houthi rebels deny that Tehran supplies the group with weapons and other military support.

Source: Al-Masdar Online website in Arabic 7 Mar 24

title: Somali cabinet approves oil exploration deal with Turkey
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Somali cabinet on 27 March approved an oil and gas exploration and drilling agreement that was signed with Turkey on 7 March, state-owned Radio Mogadishu website reported.
body:
“Under the agreement, Turkey will help Somalia to explore, research, drill and produce oil and gas to enable the Somali people benefit from their natural resources,” the report said.

The US estimates that Somalia may have at least 30 billion barrels of oil and gas reserves.

The energy deal followed a 10-year defence pact between the two countries that would see Turkey train and equip Somalia’s naval forces. 

Although details of the defence agreement have not been made public, media reports suggested that the deal would also allows Turkey to protect Somali territorial waters until the local navy is capable enough to do so.

The two countries share close relations, with Somalia hosting what has been described as Turkey’s largest overseas military base.

See Briefing: Turkish media say defence deal with Somalia will boost influence

Source: Radio Mogadishu website, Mogadishu, in Somali 27 Mar 24

title: Pakistan PM, Saudi defence minister discuss security, regional issues
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif and Saudi Prince Khalid Bin Salman Bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud discussed regional peace and security in the region, news agency Associated Press of Pakistan reported on its website.
body:
The prime minister thanked the Saudi defence minister for attending the Pakistan Day parade as a special guest. Minister for Defence Khawaja Asif and Chief of Army Staff General Syed Asim Munir also attended the meeting. 

Pakistan greatly valued its relations with Saudi Arabia, the prime minister said, adding that Saudi Arabia fully supported Pakistan on every front, the report added.

The premier again extended his invitation to the Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman to visit Pakistan.

Source: Associated Press of Pakistan news agency, Islamabad, in English 0900 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Ukraine reports shooting down 37 missiles, 55 drones
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences destroyed 55 Shahed-136/131 strike drones, 35 Kh-101/Kh-555 cruise missiles and two guided Kh-59 missiles - a total of 92 out of 151 pieces used by Russia against Ukraine in a combined air strike on the night of 21-22 March, the Ukrainian Air force has reported on Telegram.

title: Iraq's highest court orders blocking pornographic content online
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Federal Supreme Court (FSC) in Iraq, the highest judicial authority, has issued a decision ordering the concerned authorities to block websites and social media pages that publish “pornographic and immoral content” and any material deemed to be abusive to religions, beliefs, and people in the country.
body:
This came in a statement the court issued over lawsuits filed before it regarding the “obscene” content online, the privately owned website Shafaq News said on 14 March.

The court said it obligated both the Ministry of Communications and the Communications and Media Commission (CMC), the highest media regulator in Iraq, to “block websites, social media networks and electronic applications that include the making and dissemination of sexual clips and sexual insinuations that violate morals and ethics”.

It also ordered the blocking of “indecent content that violates the Divine Essence, the sanctity of holy books, prophets, messengers and religious symbols, and insults or mocks religions and sects”.

The decision also included blocking “the promotion and publication of immorality, debauchery, prostitution, homosexuality and abusing others”, as well as any other sites that contain abuse and attacks on the morals and values of Iraqi society.

In late 2023, the FSC issued a decision to block pornographic websites based on a request submitted by MP Bassem Khashan, Shafaq News said.

In late 2022, Minister of Communications Hayam al-Yasseri ordered the blocking of pornographic websites in Iraq. Her decision was welcomed by popular, political, Islamic and religious circles, according to the website.

In September 2015, the Iraqi parliament voted in favour of a decision requiring the Ministry of Communications to block pornographic websites, but the decision was not fully implemented, the website said.

Source: Shafaq News website, Baghdad, in Arabic 0843 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: N Korea reaffirms unwillingness to talk with Japan over 'abduction issue'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korean Foreign Minister Choe Son Hui on 29 March reaffirmed Pyongyang's stance that it does not have any intention to hold talks with Japan on the abduction issue, the North's official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
See also: N Korea-Japan stalemate over abduction issue likely to continue - website

"The DPRK [Democratic People's Republic of Korea-the official name for North Korea] has nothing to solve as regards the 'abduction issue' insisted by Japan and, moreover, it has neither the responsibility nor the will to make any effort for it," the minister said in a statement.

The minister issued a statement a day after Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida voiced willingness to push for a summit with the North, the report noted.

The remarks came two days after the sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un issued a statement refusing all contact with Japan after Tokyo took issue with the problem of Japanese abductees and the North's nuclear program.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0000 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Saudi, Brazilian foreign ministers hold talks on Gaza, bilateral relations
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Saudi Foreign Minister Faisal bin Farhan has held talks with his Brazilian counterpart, Mauro Vieira, in the kingdom's coastal city of Jeddah, state news agency SPA reported on 20 March.
body:
The two officials “discussed cooperation and ways to strengthen ties, and boost bilateral and multilateral coordination on issues of common concern,” SPA added.

“The ministers also discussed the latest regional and international developments, most notably the developments in the Gaza Strip, and ongoing efforts to address them,” it said.

The meeting comes on the same day US Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in Jeddah for meetings with Saudi officials, including Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the first stop of a regional tour focused on the situation in Gaza.

Earlier this week Vieira visited the West Bank, Jordan and Lebanon, issuing several statements critical of Israel's actions in Gaza, which he described as "immoral and illegal". 

See also: Briefing: Jordanian, Brazilian foreign ministers holds talks on Gaza

Source: SPA news agency, Riyadh, in Arabic 1029 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Iran seizes 3.5 tonnes of opium in south-eastern province
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The commander of Iranian border guards, Brig Gen Ahmadali Goudarzi, has said his forces have seized more than 3.5 tonnes of drugs and some arms cache in the south-eastern province of Sistan-Baluchestan, the hardline Tasnim News Agency reported on 24 March.
body:
According to Goudarzi, border guards stationed at the Saravan border regiment utilised their intelligence capabilities to uncover the plans of drug traffickers attempting to smuggle narcotics into the country.

Following intelligence gathering, ambush operations and fire exchange, the border guards managed to thwart the drug traffickers' plans, resulting in the arrest of one of the smugglers, added the commander. Additionally, the operation led to the confiscation of two vehicles, a substantial quantity of firearms and ammunition and over 3.5 tonnes of opium, he said.

Situated on the borders with Afghanistan and Pakistan, the marginalised and impoverished province of Sistan-Baluchestan is home to some Sunni militants. It is also an entry point for smuggled arms and drugs, with frequent clashes reported there between law enforcement forces and armed gangs.

Source: Tasnim news agency website, Tehran, in Persian 1303 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Russian Belgorod Region governor says two killed in drone attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two people have been killed in Russia's Belgorod Region bordering on Ukraine as a result of an attack by "kamikaze" drones, regional governor Vyacheslav Gladkov has said.
body:
In addition, a man was seriously injured when three attack drones exploded on the outskirts of the village of Rozhdestvenka in the region's Grayvoronsky urban district, Gladkov said in a post on Telegram on 8 March.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1236 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Russia reports refinery fire following UAV attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A UAV attacked the Kuybyshevsky NPZ oil refinery near Novokuybyshevsk, Samara Region in the early hours of 23 March, resulting in a fire, the Interfax news agency reported, quoting governor Dmitry Azarov.
body:
"The refinery's fractionator was set on fire. There were no casualties," Azarov said. "No damage was caused to the production equipment."

The refinery specialises in production of various motor fuels, the report said.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0428 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: BBCM Iran Watchlist 21 Aug 2025
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Iranian broadcast, press and social media sources

President back in Iran after Belarus visit
body:
Iranian President Massoud Pezeshkian has concluded his visit to Minsk, where he signed 12 cooperation agreements with Belarus. He offered Tehran's expertise in "neutralising sanctions" and proposed a strategic partnership model akin to Iran's deal with Russia.

The talks, against a backdrop of shared opposition to Western policies, focused on boosting bilateral trade through enhanced transit, joint investments, and potential visa waivers.

Pezeshkian pledged to oversee the implementation of the new pacts, which span economic, cultural, and legal fields.

Continued cautious stance on re-engaging with Syria

Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi yesterday stated Tehran is "not in a rush" to restore diplomatic ties with Syria, severed after the fall of its ally President Bashar al-Assad.

Araqchi in an interview cited Syria's internal instability, risk of fragmentation, and economic challenges as reasons for this approach. He said Iran has received no official signals from Damascus on resuming relations.

The remarks follow an alleged diplomatic incident involving Ali Larijani, the secretary of Iran's Supreme National Security Council. Syrian authorities reportedly refused to allow Larijani's aircraft to enter Syrian airspace en route to Lebanon from Iraq on 13 August, forcing it to fly a longer route via Turkey to reach Beirut.

Araqchi declined to confirm details of that event but acknowledged the presence of potential intermediaries and said Iran prefers to wait for suitable conditions before any re-engagement.

Iran weighs limited IAEA engagement amid snapback tensions

Araqchi in the same interview indicated Tehran may send a delegation to Vienna for talks with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), stating a complete halt to cooperation is "not feasible."

Araqchi cited the imminent need for IAEA inspectors to oversee a fuel replacement at the Bushehr nuclear power plant as a practical reason for maintaining limited engagement. However, he stressed that any return of inspectors would require approval from Iran's Supreme National Security Council, in line with a parliamentary law mandating a suspension of cooperation until Iran's enrichment rights are recognised.

Araqchi dismissed the legal authority of the E3 (UK, France, Germany) to trigger a snapback of pre-2015 UN sanctions but conceded it remains a possibility. He revealed that Iran has developed a coordinated response plan with Russia and China should the mechanism be activated.

Regarding the US, Araqchi ruled out an imminent resumption of talks, stating the necessary "negotiation maturity" is absent.

He said that demanding compensation for recent US bombing damage was not a direct precondition but insisted the issue must be addressed within any future negotiation framework.

Top security official meets Swiss envoy amid stalled nuclear talks

Larijani met senior Swiss diplomat Gabriel Luchinger in Tehran yesterday to discuss regional developments and the stalled nuclear negotiations. Switzerland, which represents US interests in Iran, reportedly agreed to share the outcomes of its discussions with other relevant parties with Iran.

A report by Al-Mayadeen claimed the Swiss envoy delivered a US message offering talks with guarantees against military action, but a US official later denied this. Separately, a Tasnim source stated no date is set for the next round of talks with the E3 (UK, France, Germany), and it remains unclear if they will attempt to trigger the snapback of UN sanctions.

Navy to launch missile drill in Indian Ocean, Sea of Oman

Iran's navy launched a large-scale, two-day missile exercise, "Sustainable Power 1404," in the northern Indian Ocean and Sea of Oman this morning. It will involve surface vessels, submarines, drones, and coastal missile units firing precision-guided cruise missiles.

The drill includes electronic warfare simulations and aims to enhance combat readiness and operational planning with domestically developed technology, amid regional tensions and warnings from Tehran of potential conflict with Israel.

title: Pakistan finance minister says 'seriously' considering reviving trade with India
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's Foreign Minister Ishaq Dar said the government was reconsidering reviving trade ties with India, which had been suspended after India's move to revoke the special status of Indian-administered Kashmir in August 2019, widely-read daily The Express Tribune reported on its website.
body:
"We will seriously look into matters of trade with India," the minister said during a  press conference in London, where he was participating in the Nuclear Energy Summit in Brussels. 

The move marks a "potential shift in diplomatic stance" towards India, the report added.

He also said that the new government was working on a five-year road map aimed at Pakistan's economic progress and bring down inflation.

He also highlighted Pakistan's nuclear energy vision saying "nuclear energy is expensive but environmentally friendly, and the world needs it. We are ready to share our expertise with the global community."

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0400 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Iran president warns against foreign dependency for Caucasus security
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's President Ebrahim Raisi has advised thvisiting Armenian Defence Minister Suren Papikyan against relying on foreign powers for security in the Caucasus region, the president's official website reported on 7 March.
body:
During a meeting in Tehran, Raisi said regional security "can only be achieved by countries within the region", adding: "Entrusting security to foreign powers will not be reliable, and security and tranquillity will only be ensured through the collaboration of regional countries." 

The president also said that Iran respects the governing principles of mutual respect for territorial integrity and national sovereignty, rejecting any changes to regional borders and geopolitics.

For his part, the Armenian minister praised Iran's support for peace in the Caucasus, and assured Raisi that peace in the region is Armenia's "top priority". He affirmed Armenia's commitment to peace in the Caucasus, respecting the territorial integrity and national sovereignty of all countries.

Source: president.ir website, Tehran, in Persian 1556 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Death toll from Moscow concert hall attack rises to 143
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The death toll from the 22 March attack on the Crocus City Hall concert venue near Moscow has risen to 143, the Interfax news agency reports.
body:
It said the updated list of those killed, published on the Emergencies Ministry website on 27 March, contained 143 names.

Previously, it had the names of 120 victims, the agency noted.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1724 gmt 27 Mar 24

title: Kremlin says no certainty over who is behind Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov has suggested Russian investigators are yet to establish who was behind the 22 March attack on Moscow's Crocus City Hall Complex despite the Islamic State group saying it carried out the massacre.
body:
"The investigation is underway, no coherent version [of what happened] has been voiced yet," TASS quoted Peskov saying on 25 March.

"Talk was only about preliminary data, no versions at all have yet been put forward," he said.

"It is necessary to wait for information from our official power-wielding bodies," he said.

Peskov declined to comment on the reports and evidence that the arrested individuals have been tortured.

"I will leave this question unanswered," he said.

Russian officials have claimed without evidence Ukraine was somehow involved.

The Insider, an investigative website, says, "a Kremlin network of circulation of fake news" has begun generating articles pointing the finger of blame at the US, Ukraine and the UK's foreign intelligence service MI-6.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0920 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: Official warns Iran to start production in disputed field if Kuwait does same
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian Vice-President for Legal Affairs Mohammad Dehqan has warned Kuwait that if it starts extracting gas from the joint Arash gas field (al-Durra), Tehran will do so too, the Judiciary-affiliated Mizan Online reported on 8 March.
body:
"Just as before, our position is that this [disputed] issue can be resolved peacefully. Arash is an oil and gas filed partly owned by Iran," he added.

He noted that Iran does not have a maritime border with Kuwait but underscored the fact that it was Iran that had discovered the field and drilled in the area first.

"To avoid issues between us and Kuwait, we decided not to exploit the field [further]," he reminded Kuwait.

He called for "integrated drilling operation" in Arash field so that the field exploitation occurs in "a protective fashion".

He accused Kuwait of "not showing any constructive approach" and said that it had separately entered an exclusive accord with Saudi Arabia. Part of the join field is in Saudi waters, he conceded.

"If it turns out that Kuwait starts to extract [gas] from that field, then, we too will start our drilling operations," he warned.

Iran slams Kuwait, UAE on disputed Gulf gas field, triple islands

Source: Mizan news agency, Tehran, in Persian 0807 GMT 8 Mar 24

title: Philippines, India agree to boost maritime security cooperation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Philippines and India on 26 March agreed to boost maritime security cooperation amid ongoing tensions between Manila and Beijing over the South China Sea, the website of Japan's national broadcaster NHK World reported.
body:
The Philippine foreign minister held talks with his Indian counterpart S Jaishankar in Manila on 26 March. Philippine Foreign Secretary Enrique Manalo said the two countries "are having extensive discussions regularly on defence cooperation". During their meeting, Jaishankar said they agreed that the region must adhere to a rules-based order.

Meanwhile, an Indian coast guard ship arrived in Manila on 25 March for a three-day port call.

Recently, the Philippines accused China of "harassing" Filipino scientists doing research work on a sand bar called Sandy Cay, causing minor injuries.

Source: NHK World website, Tokyo, in English 0600 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 1 Sep 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Israeli army document says Operation Gideon Chariots failed
body:
Israeli media revealed last night an internal Israeli army document saying that "Operation Gideon's Chariots"- a ground offensive that Israel launched in Gaza in May - has "failed", citing "ineptitude" in humanitarian planning, exhaustion of forces, and loss of international legitimacy.

Israel Channel 12 reported that despite the chief of staff's words that the operation was successful, the document states that "we failed", and that "Israel made every possible mistake when waging a war".

The document said "war goals were not achieved, Hamas was not defeated the hostages were not returned," though it listed achievements such as "severe blows" to Hamas infrastructure and leadership, the Israeli news site Ynet reported.

Channel 12 reported that the document cited failures in planning and delivering humanitarian aid, which enabled Hamas to wage a "false but effective starvation campaign".

The channel quoted the army spokesperson as saying that the materials were shared "without the approval of the relevant authorities".

Houthis vow revenge against Israel for killing of top officials

Yemen's Houthis vowed retaliation against Israel in a series of statements following confirmation that top government officials were killed last week in Israeli strikes on Sanaa, including Prime Minister Ahmed Ghaleb al-Rahawi.

Houthi Chief of Staff Maj Gen Mohammed al-Ghamari said yesterday that Israel had "opened the gates of hell upon itself", and that the movement's response would be "harsh and painful, with effective and influential strategic options", Houthi-run Al-Masirah TV reported late last night.

It follows a televised address by leader Abdulmalek al-Houthi earlier in the day, offering condolences over the deaths of Houthi government officials. He said that the Houthi military forces' campaign against Israel "whether with missiles, drones or the naval blockade" was "continuing, steady and escalating".

Gaza ceasefire talks continue as mediators wait for Israeli response

Egypt is reportedly continuing talks on a ceasefire in Gaza, waiting for a response from Israel to a recently submitted proposal.

The UK-based, Qatari-funded Al-Araby Al-Jadeed website quoted an informed Egyptian source yesterday as saying that Egyptian intelligence officials are "continuously" communicating with the Israeli side regarding the negotiations.

The source added that the US had requested Egypt and Qatar to put pressure on Hamas to reach a "formula" concerning its future and the fate of its military wing, as part of consultations aimed at opening channels to persuade the Israeli prime minister to resume talks.

The website also quoted a senior Hamas member as saying that the group is still communicating with mediators while waiting for the Israeli response to the latest ceasefire proposal, which it has accepted "unconditionally".

Lebanese media report Israeli 'belt of fire' attacks on south

Southern Lebanon's Nabatieh region was rocked by intense Israeli bombardment early yesterday, killing one person, with Lebanese media describing the strikes as a "belt of fire".

The first ten strikes, using "highly explosive missiles", had hit the Ali Taher hills, causing houses to "shake from the impact of the explosions", followed by more drone strikes, French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour reported. It said that one person riding a motorcycle was killed by a strike.

In a statement, the Israeli army claimed it had targeted Hezbollah-linked underground infrastructure "where military activities were observed".

Yesterday, L'Orient-Le Jour also reported that Israel had dropped "propaganda leaflets" in the southern border village of Aita al-Chaab, "threatening any person carrying out reconstruction work for Hezbollah".

Syrian media report Israeli incursions in Quneitra

Syrian media reported two separate Israeli military incursions into Syria's southern border province of Quneitra yesterday.

State-run Al-Ikhbariyah al-Suriyah TV reported that dozens of Israeli military personnel entered the village of Al-Asha where it conducted searches of residential homes.

Meanwhile, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported that an Israeli contingent consisting of six armoured vehicles and dozens of soldiers entered the town of Jabata al-Khashab in the northern parts of Quneitra where they set up a checkpoint and searched residential homes before withdrawing.

The latest incursions follow Israel's killing of six Syrian soldiers last week in a drone attack south of Damascus, just days after President Ahmed al-Sharaa announced that the two countries were holding "advanced" talks.

Lebanese Speaker calls for calm dialogue over Hezbollah arsenal

Lebanon's influential parliamentary Speaker Nabih Berri called for a "calm and consensual dialogue" over Hezbollah's arsenal.

In a televised speech aired on the state Tele Liban channel marking the anniversary of the disappearance of Shia Imam Moussa al-Sadr in 1978 in Libya, Berri said that "dialogue is the only way to find a solution", coming a day before the army is set to present a detailed timetable for the Iran-backed group's disarmament.

The call comes amid a tense atmosphere in Lebanon, with US pressure being exerted for Hezbollah's swift disarmament, continued and escalating Israeli attacks on the south and leading Hezbollah figures "continuing to radicalise their position regarding disarmament", French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour reported last night.

Syrian Kurdish forces arrest dozens in anti-IS raids

The Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) made 51 arrests of suspected members of the Islamic State (IS) group over the weekend, as it concluded a security operation targeting the group in the north-east Syrian province of Hasaka.

The SDF - which controls much of Syria's north-east - said in a Facebook statement on 30 August that the suspects had been involved in "attacks on civilians" and on security centres and public facilities.

It added that it also dismantled "dangerous terrorist networks", a number of which had allegedly been plotting attacks on the SDF-run Al-Sinaa prison - which houses IS members - and on the al-Hol camp, where families linked to IS are detained.

Last night, the SDF also reported on X that two IS suspects were killed in a foiled attack on a checkpoint, north of Raqqa province.

title: Yemen's Houthis claim fresh attacks on ships, Israel port city
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi movement on 26 March claimed six operations in the Gulf of Aden and the Red Sea, and on targets in the Israeli port city of Eilat over the previous 72 hours.
body:
Houthi-controlled Saba news agency published a statement issued by the group's military spokesman, Yahya al-Sarea, in which he said that rebel forces had carried out joint operations on the US vessels Maersk Saratoga and the Apl Detroit in the Gulf of Aden and Red Sea respectively, in addition to the British Huang Pu ship in the Red Sea and the Pretty Lady bulk carrier.

The forces also targeted two US destroyers in the Red Sea and carried out missile attacks on a number of Israeli targets in the Umm al-Rashrash area (Eilat), the spokesman added.

He said that the operations were carried out in support of the Palestinian people and to mark "the tenth year of steadfastness in the face of the American-British aggression against our country". A Western-backed coalition led by Saudi Arabia launched a military campaign against the rebels launched in 2015, following their takeover of the capital Sanaa in September 2014.

Source: Saba news agency website, Sanaa, in Arabic 1201 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Yemen's Houthis announce attacks on US ship, Israeli targets in Eilat
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi movement has announced an attack on a US ship in the Red Sea and said that its forces had fired missiles on a number of Israeli targets in the port city of Eilat.
body:
The Houthi-controlled Saba news agency published a statement issued on 19 March by the Houthi military spokesman, Yahya al-Sarea, in which he said that the group's forces had targeted the Mado with a number of naval missiles.

He said that they had also launched "a number of winged missiles at Israeli targets on the Umm al-Rashrash [Eilat] area in southern occupied Palestine, which successfully hit their targets".

The Houthis began targeting ships in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden in November last year, saying that the operations were aimed at exerting pressure on Israel to halt its military campaign in Gaza. The group has in recent days expanded the scope of its operations to the Indian Ocean, after vessels travelling from Asia to Europe rerouted via the Cape of Good Hope in order to avoid the Red Sea.

See also: Houthi TV says Indian Ocean attacks 'lightning strike' for Israel-Asia shipping

Source: Saba news agency website, Sanaa, in Arabic 1235 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab claims killing 15 soldiers in southern Somalia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The al-Shabab group has claimed to have killed 15 soldiers in heavy clashes in Basra village in the town of Bal’ad in Somalia's southern Middle Shabelle region, pro-militant Calamada website reported on 21 March.

title: Mozambique president signs revised law on combating terrorism
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Mozambique's President Filipe Nyusi has signed an amended law on combating terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, Mozambican news agency Agencia Informacao Mocambique (AIM) reported on 20 March.
body:
The amendments, which were approved by parliament, are part of Mozambique's efforts to be removed from the international money laundering grey list.

According to the report, the amendments introduce specific financial sanctions for terrorism. They also oblige companies to declare their owners for purposes of accountability.

Recently, Finance Minister Max Tonela said that the law was an important step "towards protecting national interests and the integrity of the financial system."

Source: Agencia Informacao Mocambique website, Maputo, in Portuguese 20 Mar 24

title: Voting ends in Turkey's local elections
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

All polls closed in Turkey's local elections at 14:00 GMT, mainstream Haberturk news channel reported on 31 March.
body:
Voting ended at 13:00 GMT in 32 eastern and south-eastern provinces, in line with previously established Supreme Election Council (YSK) practice.

More than 206,000 polls were set up across the country for 61 million eligible voters.

Media outlets are not allowed to report on results of the vote until the YSK announces the lifting of the election day broadcast ban, which usually happens within hours of the end of voting.

There have been reports of fatal clashes related to neighbourhood head (muhtar) elections in some predominantly Kurdish provinces. The pro-Kurdish Peoples' Equality and Democracy Party (DEM Party) also alleged voter fraud at some ballot stations ahead of the election.

See our full coverage here.

See also: Explainer: What's at stake in Turkey’s critical local elections?

Source: Haberturk website, Istanbul, in Turkish 1400 GMT 31 Mar 24

title: China, Iran presidents congratulate newly-elected Pakistani counterpart
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The presidents of China and Iran have congratulated Asif Ali Zardari on his election as the new president of Pakistan, The Express Tribune reported on its website on 11 March.
body:
Chinese President Xi Jinping and Iranian President Syed Ebrahim Raisi expressed their readiness to strengthen ties with Pakistan under Zardari.

In his message, the Iranian president highlighted "deep-rooted cultural and religious ties" between Iran and Pakistan.

Xi highlighted "iron-clad friendship" between the two countries, saying the two sides had achieved fruitful results in the construction of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).

He also stressed pushing for greater development of the China-Pakistan all-weather strategic partnership.

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 1053 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Aden state TV to return to Yemen interim capital, says pro-separatist official
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Aden state television is expected to return to Yemen's Aden within three months after broadcasting from abroad since the escalation of the Yemen conflict in 2015, according to an official loyal to the separatist, UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC) which seized control of the interim capital in the summer of 2019.
body:
In a report on 14 March, the southern-focused Aden al-Ghad news site said that the undersecretary of Aden province, Salah al-Aqel, had confirmed that he expected Aden state TV and radio to officially resume broadcasting from the southern port city within 90 days.

The report said that Aqel had made the remarks during an event in Aden held by the leadership of the STC for journalists on the previous day to mark the start of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.

Aden TV began broadcasting from the Saudi capital, Riyadh, following the launch of an aerial bombing campaign by a Saudi-led military coalition backing the internationally recognised government against the Iran-backed Houthi rebels.

Source: Aden al-Ghad website, Aden, in Arabic 2055 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Yemen's Houthis announce attacks on 'Israeli, US' ships in Red Sea, Indian Ocean
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi movement has claimed attacks on Israeli and US ships in the Red Sea and Indian Ocean, after the rebel leader announced that the group was escalating its maritime actions by targeting Israel-linked ships transiting via the Indian Ocean towards the Cape of Good Hope.
body:
In a departure from his usual format of delivering a statement filmed in a studio, the group's military spokesman, Yahya al-Sarea, announced the attacks to large crowds of pro-Palestinian protestors gathered in the Houthi-controlled capital Sanaa on 15 March, which was aired live by the rebel movement's Al-Masirah TV station.

Sarea said that Houthi naval forces had fired a number of naval missiles on what he said was the Israeli ship Pacific 01, while the group's air force had targeted a US destroyer in the Red Sea with drones, stressing that the operation "successfully achieved its goals". 

He said that the rebel forces carried out three "successful" operations against Israeli and US ships in the Indian Ocean using a number of missiles and drones.

Source: Al-Masirah TV, Beirut, in Arabic 1217 GMT 15 Mar 24

title: Kenya begins releasing bodies of starvation cult victims to kin
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Kenyan government on 26 March began releasing bodies of victims of a starvation cult to relatives for burial, privately-owned NTV news website reported.
body:
The chief government pathologist, Johansen Oduor, on 20 March said his team had positively linked 34 out of the 428 bodies exhumed from graves within the Shakahola forest in the coastal Kilifi county to relatives.

"One family that lost seven relatives in the Shakahola massacre was the first to have four identified bodies released for burial from the Malindi District Hospital mortuary," the website said.

Pastor Paul Mackenzie of the Good News International Church and 29 others were on 6 February charged with the murder of 191 children who were among the 428 people whose bodies were discovered in dozens of shallow graves in Shakahola. They allegedly fasted to death on the instructions of the cult leader and his close associates in a bid to "meet Jesus".

 Mackenzie has also already been charged with terrorism-related crimes, manslaughter and torture. He was also sentenced to 12 months in prison in December for producing and distributing films without a licence.

Source: NTV, Nairobi, in English 26 Mar 24

title: Japan, India hold joint military drill in desert
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Japan's Ground Self-Defence Force (GSDF) and the Indian Army completed a two-week joint drill at a training facility in a desert in India's western state of Rajasthan on 9 March, the website of national broadcaster NHK World reported.
body:
The exercise, fifth of its kind, involved 40 members from each country. The drill involved an operation to subdue a group of terrorists in hiding and to practice breaking into a building, according to the NHK World report.

The report noted that the exercise comes amid a a long-standing border dispute between India and China. It also highlighted tht the drill is believed to be an attempt to show the strengthening defence cooperation between India and Japan.

A GSDF commander said closer ties between the two countries will help maintain and strengthen a free and open Indo-Pacific.

Source: NHK World website, Tokyo, in English 0500 GMT 9 Mar 24

title: Islamic Resistance in Iraq claims it hit Haifa airport power plant
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI) claimed on 5 March that it had carried out a drone attack on a power station in Israel’s Haifa airport.
body:
The Iran-backed militia said in a statement on Telegram that the attack comes “in support of our people in Gaza, and in response to the Zionist massacres against the unarmed Palestinian civilians”.

The group released a video on 6 March purportedly showing the launch of the drones used in the attack. 

On 3 March, the militia claimed a drone attack on a chemical materials station in Haifa Port.

The IRI is an umbrella group comprising pro-Iran militias active in Iraq and Syria that seemed to have intensified their anti-US activities following the outbreak of the Gaza war.

On 3 November, it announced the expansion of its operations to targets in Israel.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2135 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Iran judiciary dismisses 'false' reports on death of former inmate
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian judiciary has issued a statement dismissing "inaccurate and incorrect news" regarding the death of a 20 year old woman, Sara Tabrizi, the official IRNA news agency reported on 29 March.
body:
Ms Tabrizi was initially arrested in November and spent more than a week in detention before reportedly dying on 24 March in her father's house in Tehran, according to journalist Reza Akvanian.

The journalist told the London-based Persian language Iran International that the Pathology Organisation had said that her death had been caused by pills.

See BBCM Iran Watchlist for 29 March

Social media users had said that she had committed suicide after having been summoned to the Intelligence Ministry on 24 March. A hashtag has been trending in her memory on X.

The judiciary statement, however, noted that "a comprehensive inquiry had shown that no summons had been issued to her by the judicial or security institutions" just before or after the start of the Iranian new year on 20 March.

The statement said that Tabrizi had intended to leave the country on 8 January using false travel documents when she was arrested. She was reportedly released on bail on 15 January.

The statement further noted that Tabrizi did not return to prison in the two months and 10 days after that and before her death. It added that a suspended sentence had been issued against her.

It explained that, in this context, a suspended sentence meant that if she committed no crimes within two years of the issuing of the ruling, the sentence would have been revoked.

Some users argued that the establishment was responsible for her death even if it was a suicide as she died "under the heavy psychological pressure of security officers".

The statement also stressed that the father of the deceased had contacted the police on 24 March, in Shahriar County west of the capital, to say that his daughter was not waking up and was likely dead. Following this contact, added the report, the police and forensic authorities had gone to her place of residence.

Upon confirmation of her death, an autopsy was initiated by the medical staff.

In its concluding paragraph, the statement noted that her father had said that she had gone to the infirmary the previous night after feeling unwell where she received treatment. The exact cause of her death is not yet established pending further examination.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 1621 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Indian FM in Moscow says 'perplexed' at US stance over Russian oil purchase
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Indian External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar said in Moscow on 21 August that India is "perplexed" at the "logic" of the US's argument in its objection to Delhi's purchase of Russian oil, prominent English-language TV news channel NDTV reported.
body:
"... Americans have said for the last few years that we should do everything to stabilise the world energy market, including buying oil from Russiaso quite honestly, we are quite perplexed at the logic of the argument," he said at a joint press interaction with Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov.

Jaishankar was responding to a question about US government statements that extra tariffs have been imposed on India for buying oil from Russia, despite the war with Ukraine.

He also said that India is "not the biggest purchaser of Russian oil, that is China".

The NDTV report described Jaishankar's remarks as "perhaps the strongest reactiondirected directly at Trump's hypocrisy on the tariffs, aimed at damaging India.

Jaishankar was on a three-day visit to Russia from 19-21 August.

On 21 August, he called on Russian President Vladimir Putin during which they discussed bilateral issues and "contemporary global issues of mutual interest", including developments related to Ukraine, India's Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said on 22 August.

Putin is expected to visit India later this year for the annual summit between the two countries.

During his meeting with Lavrov on 21 August, Jaishankar raised concerns over the trade imbalance with Russia and the issue of Indians serving in the Russian army, among other topics. The two ministers also discussed developments related to Ukraine, the Middle East and Afghanistan, the MEA statement said.

title: Belarus leader denies plans to attack Nato member
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Alyaksandr Lukashenka (Alexander Lukashenko) has denied Belarus and Russia plan to attack a Nato member state, his official website has reported.
body:
He was speaking to journalists while on a visit to Ashmyany District to check combat readiness of military units on 26 March.

"This is complete nonsense. We came here today absolutely transparently. We demonstrate to them that we are not going to attack them. We are building a system of defence here," he said.

Lukashenka said that they have to "deal with Ukraine first".

"I said it once: God help us deal with Ukraine first. What war against Nato troops? We do not need this. They are waiting for this. They provoke us to respond to them at least somehow. Let us take sending subversive groups through the Ukrainian border to Belarus. Why do they do this? We are not attacking, we are not doing anything. They provoke us to respond. They are interested in unleashing a war," Lukashenka said.

He also said that Ukrainian troops deployed along the border with Belarus would be replaced with French personnel, which is "good" for Belarus.

"There are 120,000 Ukrainians in the Ukrainian direction now. They want to take them and send them to the front against Russia. Instead, here, as they say, [they will] deploy French or Nato troops at our southern border. This is good for us. They will not protect Ukraine as Ukrainians are doing it now," Lukashenka said, adding that Belarus "is not going to fight them".

Source: Belarusian President's website, Minsk, in Russian 1000 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: Iran reiterates support for Armenian, Azeri territorial integrity
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Defence Minister Mohammad Reza Ashtiani has reiterated Iran's support for the territorial integrity of countries - implicitly referring to Armenia and Azerbaijan in particular - in a meeting with his Armenian counterpart Suren Papikyan.
body:
A report by the semi-official ISNA news agency on 6 March said the two statesmen spoke in the course of a visit by Papikyan to the headquarters of the Ministry of Defence in Tehran.

In the meeting, the Iranian minister reiterated Iran's support for regional countries' "right to sovereignty over their entire territory" and its opposition to "changing internationally recognised borders". This was in reaction to the Baku's controversial proposal for the Zangezur Corridor linking Turkey and Azerbaijan over Armenian soil.

Ashitani added: "We support direct negotiations, stable peace and direct communication between the two neighbours of Azerbaijan and Armenia, and we consider this to be the basis for the progress and development of the Caucasus region."

The minister hailed Armenia's "special importance" to Iran and its policy of strengthening its relations with neighbours.

He also stressed the Islamic Republic's belief that the "security architecture of the region should originate in the region itself", calling any approach by a regional country contrary to that "unacceptable".

"Seeking security outside the region has the opposite effect and turns it into a place of conflict between powers. It [furthermore] causes more challenges to security and stability in the area," added Ashtiani.

The remark was a warning against the Caucasus region turning into "grounds for [territorial] rivalry for others".

Expressing his agreement with the Islamic Republic on strengthening bilateral ties, Papikyan he called for closer relations with regards to regional developments and security.

Source: ISNA website, Tehran, in Persian 1759 GMT 6 Mar 24

title: Nationalist ally backs Turkey's Erdogan after 'last election' comment
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Turkey's Nationalist Movement Party leader Devlet Bahceli, a close ally of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has voiced support for Erdogan's continuation as president after local elections on 31 March.
body:
Erdogan had said on 8 March that the upcoming vote will be his “last election”, reigniting a long-running debate on potential constitutional reforms.

“You cannot leave. You cannot leave the Turkish nation alone. As the [ruling] People’s Alliance, we are by your side,” Bahceli said at his party’s convention on 17 March, mainstream NTV news channel’s website reported.

“We want to see you as the saviour leader of the new century,” he added.

Ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) Spokesperson Omer Celik

downplayed Erdogan's remarks on 12 March, saying the president was referring to the “constitutional limits of his duty”.

Erdogan was re-elected for a five-year term in the May 2023 general elections. His candidacy had sparked debate upon its announcement, with opposition parties saying it violated the constitutional limit of two presidential terms.

After the 2023 elections, Erdogan and AKP officials repeatedly advocated a new constitution.

See also: Briefing: Turkey's Erdogan says local elections will be his 'last', stirring debate

See also: Briefing: Turkey's Erdogan eyes conservative support for new constitution

Source: NTV television, Istanbul, in Turkish 0428 GMT 17 Mar 24

title: China's 'no-first-use' nuclear weapons idea makes 'sense' - Russian official
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov has described as a "grain of common sense" China's call for nuclear-weapon states to negotiate and conclude a treaty on "mutual no-first-use of nuclear weapons".
body:
"We are treating that proposal with consideration, we are studying it," Rybkov was quoted as saying by the Interfax news agency on 12 March.

"It is clear to us that at a time when the collective West has embarked on a course at a nonstop escalation of the overall international situation with no regard for the risks that a direct clash between nuclear powers can lead to ideas of this sort bring a grain of common sense," Ryabkov added.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1516 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Floods reportedly submerge parts of Mozambique capital
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Floods caused by heavy rains have reportedly submerged parts of the Mozambican capital, Maputo, and surrounding areas, the AIM  news agency reported on 25 March.
body:
It said the Maputo Province - comprising  Maputo, Umbeluzi, Incomapti and Limpopo - started experiencing heavy rains in the early hours of 24 March that continued to 25 March morning. It added that the situation is expected to worsen late on 25 March.

The floodwaters have reportedly blocked access to banks and other services in downtown Maputo and impeded traffic on various busy streets, including the Avenida 25 de Setembro.

Authorities are monitoring the basins of the main rivers in the province over fears that they will burst their banks and cause further flooding.

The National Institute of Meteorology (INA) predicts an improvement in the weather conditions starting on 26 March.

Source: Agencia Informacao Mocambique website, Maputo, in English 25 Mar 24

title: Pakistan: Arrest warrants issued for Imran Khan's party leaders
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's anti-terrorism court has issued non-bailable arrest warrants against jailed ex-premier Imran Khan's party leaders in 9 May riots case, including against northwest Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur, widely-read daily The Express Tribune reported.
body:
The court has ordered the authorities to produce the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa chief minister along with others on 2 April, it added.

The case refers to 9 May, when violent protests erupted following the arrest of Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party founder Imran Khan, in an alleged corruption case, with protestors attacking various state and military installations.

Hashtag #BanTerroristPTICult is among the top trends on X in Pakistan, as seen on social media website Trends24 on 03:40 GMT on 20 March, with some users saying "immediate cancellation of such a political party is an important requirement of the country's interest."

See also: Briefing: Pakistani media divided over Imran Khan's arrest in corruption case

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0400 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Senegal candidate's campaign messages barred from state TV
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The campaign of jailed Senegalese presidential candidate Bassirou Diomaye Faye has been barred from running its election videos on state-owned broadcaster RTS following a decision of the country’s National Audiovisual Regulation Authority (CNRA), French radio RFI reported on 11 March.

title: Pro-ISKP group threatens Russia with revenge for 'imprisoned brothers'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A poster by a prominent media group supportive of Islamic State’s Khorasan Province branch (ISKP) has threatened Russia with retaliation over the "imprisonment" and "torture" of "brothers".
body:
This appeared to be a reference to Russian authorities' arrest and apparent torture of individuals suspected of carrying out the 22 March attack at a concert hall near Moscow, for which IS has claimed responsibility.

While the poster, released on 25 March, did not specify who it meant by the "imprisoned brothers", its reference to the attack of "Friday" and "the broadcasting of videos of prisoners being tortured", suggest it was referring to the suspects detained in the latest Moscow attack. 

The poster was issued by the pro-ISKP al-Azaim media group and has so far appeared in Pashto, Tajik, Persian and in somewhat clumsy English. It was circulated on 25 March via pro-ISKP Telegram channels.
