The text warned “all brutal Russians, including Putin” that they will experience further "massacres", and that the imprisonment of "brothers" has sharpened the resolve of their fellow IS loyalists to strike again.

It cited the "Friday" attack to indicate that IS militants are capable of delivering heavy blows, and can do it again. 

The poster featured a picture of a knife-wielding militant, and was entitled: "Threat - to all brutal Russians, including Putin!"

It concluded by saying that “very soon” “you will be massacred all together with your women and children”.

IS itself has not clarified the fate of the four attackers, after it initially said on 22 March that they had managed to "safely" flee the site of the attack. This was before Russian authorities announced the detention of the assailants.

The jihadist group is generally reticent in its official language regarding attacks where suspects have been detained, likely to avoid incriminating its own members.

This appears to be the first al-Azaim product referencing the IS-claimed Russia attack, although pro-ISKP Telegram channels have been full of messaging celebrating and highlighting the attack.

Source: Telegram messaging service in English 1100 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Insurgency in northern Mozambique displaces 1.4 million people
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The insurgency in the northern Cabo Delgado Province has already displaced 1.4 million people in Mozambique, Mozambican news agency AIM reported on 21 March.
body:
The numbers were announced by the justice ministry at a conference in the capital, Maputo.

Although the number of deaths caused by the conflict was not officially confirmed, sources from the government point to over 4,000 victims, the report said.

Speaking at the event, the permanent secretary in the ministry of justice, Justino Tonela, said that the humanitarian situation in Cabo Delgado remains "challenging", seven years after the start of the conflict.

"We are seeing a resurgence of the terrorist threat in the province which affects the population's access to basic services and goods," Tonela was quoted as saying.

Tonela also pointed that while the province has seen an increase in militant attacks since the start of the year, a large number of displaced people have chosen to return to their areas of origin, contributing to the resumption of commercial activities across several districts.

See Explainer: Mozambique attacks elicit calls for dialogue with jihadists

Source: Agencia Informacao Mocambique website, Maputo, in English 21 Mar 24

title: Russia remands one more suspect in Crocus attack case
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Moscow's Basmanny Court has remanded an eighth suspect linked to the 22 March attack on Crocus City Hall, state news agency TASS reported.
body:
Citing its correspondent, TASS reported that the suspect was Kyrgyzstan-born Alisher Kasimov, accused of renting out a flat to the alleged perpetrators of the attack.

The court, which has already ruled to remand seven other suspects in the case, again approved investigators' remand request as regards to Kasimov, keeping him in pre-trial custody until 22 May.

The TASS report identified Kasimov as being a Russian citizen, born in the city of Osh, Kyrgyzstan, a father of three and owner of a cafe in Krasnogorsk.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0940 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: Pro-al-Qaeda media group incites attacks in New York
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A pro-al-Qaeda online media outlet has incited Muslims to attack Jews and Christians worldwide in response to the Gaza war, and specifically urged gun attacks in New York.
body:
The outlet added that the impending Muslim holy month of Ramadan is an auspicious time for such attacks.

Al-Malahim Cyber Army (MCA) issued the incitement in a two-page Arabic statement released via its dedicated Telegram bot on 5 March.

The MCA (aka Al-Malahem Electronic Army, Jaysh al-Malahim al-Electroni), typically focuses on inciting "lone wolf" attacks in the West.

The MCA's 5 March statement said that Muslims have a duty towards Gazans in the face of a "campaign of annihilation". Moreover, it said, protecting al-Aqsa Mosque is the responsibility of "all of us".

Therefore, it asserted that ensuring the victory of the "mujahidin" in Gaza is an individual obligation ("fard ain" in Arabic) on every Muslim.

The MCA claimed that "we" fight on several fronts against a single enemy, which is an alliance of Jews and Christians in a war on Islam in its entirety, not just in Gaza. It is an open war and the whole world is its arena, in its words.

The statement declared that in this light, "we" must believe that anyone who unleashes gunfire in God's name on the streets of New York is helping those firing rockets from Gaza.

This rhetoric of Gaza being part of a global religious war between Muslims and their enemies is reminiscent of al-Qaeda's rival Islamic State group's messaging on the conflict. (See here)

In a reference to Ramadan, which this year starts on around 10 March, the MCA noted that the "month of conquests" is imminent, so it urged Muslims firm up their resolve and launch raids.

It warned that people are either on the side of the "Jewish-Christian coalition" or with Islam, with there being no middle ground.

The statement also urged readers not to believe the West's claim to be neutral on the Gaza conflict and to be upset by what is happening in "Palestine". On this score, it mocked the US for dropping a few food parcels in Gaza, whilst allegedly backing Israel's war.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1659 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: DR Congo restores death sentence for army treason
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

DR Congo’s Minister of Justice Rose Mutombo has announced the lifting of the moratorium suspending the death penalty to combat treason, terrorism, and urban crime, the website of independent local broadcaster Top Congo FM reported on 15 March.

title: Kazakh police to check all public facilities after Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kazakh Deputy Interior Minister Igor Lepyokha has said that all public places in his country will be checked after a recent deadly attack on a concert hall in neighbouring Russia, the state-run news website Kazinform reported on 28 March.
body:
At least 139 people were killed and nearly 200 others injured in the attack on Crocus City Hall in Russia's Moscow Region on 22 March. The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the assault.

"All such facilities in our country are classified as facilities vulnerable to terrorism, including all large shopping centres, concert halls with an area of ​​over 500 square metres, and all educational and healthcare facilities, that is, everywhere that people gather. We are working to carry out additional checks of all these facilities," the report quoted the official as saying.

"We will carry out control checks at those facilities that we checked before, where instructions were given. We will check the others that have not been checked. We will at least visit them, speak to the owners, discuss technical issues and give recommendations," he added.

Lepyokha also spoke about the results of fingerprint examinations introduced for foreigners in his country , the website said.

"You know that we introduced a mandatory fingerprint scan for foreigners entering the country on 1 January. It is already working now. Since the beginning of the year we have already identified 10 criminals who tried to enter our country," he noted.

Source: Kazinform, Astana, in Russian 0545 GMT 28 Mar 24

title: Nine Iranian prisoners extradited from Armenia, Japan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Eight Iranian prisoners from Armenia, and another from Japan, were extradited to Iran on 19 March, the semi-official ISNA news agency reported the same day.
body:
Askar Jalalian, the deputy justice minister for human rights and international affairs, said all nine would continue to serve their prison terms in Iran, the report added.

Five more Iranian prisoners were also repatriated from Armenia in July 2023.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 0914 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Yemen leader appoints new foreign minister
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of Yemen's governing Presidential Leadership Council (PLC), Rashad al-Alimi, has appointed Shayea Mohsen al-Zindani as foreign minister, succeeding Ahmed bin Mubarak who was was sworn in as prime minister in February.
body:
Government-run Saba news agency briefly reported the appointment on 26 March, adding that the decree would be effective from the date it was issued and published in the official gazette.

The Istanbul-based Belqees TV published a report on its website on the following day, noting that Shayea had served as Yemen's ambassador to Saudi Arabia since 2017. It added that previous posts included deputy foreign minister, and ambassador to Britain, Italy, and Jordan.

According to the report, the newly-appointed foreign minister was born in the southern province of (also Dhale, Dali) and holds a PhD in law, a bachelor's degree in law and and an honorary doctorate in diplomatic sciences.

See: Yemen TV channel discusses challenges facing new PM

Source: Saba news agency website in Arabic 1903 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Iran president says Palestinians' struggle will 'destroy' Israel
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi has said that the struggle of the Palestinian people will eventually result in their victory and the "destruction of the Zionist regime [Israel]", in a speech at a Police Academy graduation ceremony on 4 March.
body:
Raisi told the attendees that "people love you" as you serve them, while Israel is "hated globally" and the US army is the "most hated army" in the world. His speech was carried live by the state-run IRINN2 news channel.

Raisi also thanked Iranians for voting in the 1 March parliamentary and Assembly of Experts elections, and the police and the armed forces for providing security on the polling day.

"The world saw people at the ballot boxes," he said, echoing his earlier remarks praising the "passionate turnout", which he described as an "extreme blow" to the opponents of the Islamic Republic.

Raisi further said in his speech that the "enemy" knew that the Iranian nation was "always present at the scene and accepting responsibility", which was the "most important components of our might and power".

Although officials and state media have been promoting participation in the elections as a success, a turnout of around 40% has been reported, which would be the lowest turnout since the founding of the Islamic Republic since 1979.

Source: Islamic Republic of Iran News Network 2 TV (IRINN 2), Tehran, in Persian 0649 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Islamic Resistance in Iraq says it attacked Israeli power plant
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI) has claimed that it targeted a power plant in Tel Aviv using a drone, according to a statement posted on the group’s Telegram channel.
body:
The group said the attack was carried out at dawn on 21 March, and pledged to "continue the destruction of enemy strongholds to complete the second phase of operations to resist the occupation, to support our people in Gaza, and in response to the Zionist massacres against defenceless Palestinian civilians".

The IRI also shared a video purportedly showing the launch of the drones used in the attack. 

As with previous IRI claims, there was no mention in Israeli media of such an incident occurring.

On 3 November, the IRI - an umbrella group comprising pro-Iran militias active in Iraq and Syria that has stepped up strikes on US bases in both countries - announced the expansion of its operations to targets in Israel to support the Palestinians in Gaza. 

None of its attacks have been confirmed or reported in Israeli media so far.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 0054 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Ukraine intercepts two Russian ballistic missiles over Kyiv
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two Russian ballistic missiles fired from Russia-occupied Crimea were intercepted above Kyiv, resulting in falling debris in the centre of Ukraine's capital, Ukrainian Air Force Commander Lt General Mykola Oleschuk reported on Telegram on 25 March.
body:
Five people were hurt by debris, with two requiring hospitalisation, Kyiv Mayor Vitaliy Klitschko said on Telegram. There was significant damage to a three story non-residential building, he said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0920 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Ethiopia, Somalia agree to 'tone down rhetoric', paper says
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kenya's President William Ruto has persuaded the leaders of Somalia and Ethiopia to tone down harsh rhetoric against each other that has raised regional tensions amid a diplomatic row, Kenyan newspaper The EastAfrican has reported.
body:
Ruto separately met Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed and Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud in Nairobi on 28 February.

"Kenya's desire was to ensure the dispute between Ethiopia and Somalia does not boil over" although Mogadishu rejected Nairobi's initial mediation offer, The EastAfrican said on 3 March.

"And, from this week, both Addis and Mogadishu are expected to tone down their public rhetoric against each other, sources privy to the discussions indicated," it added.

The paper said a meeting would be held by Abiy and Mohamud soon to try to resolve a dispute between their two countries.

Somalia and Ethiopia are involved in a diplomatic row over a 1 January agreement between Ethiopia and Somaliland, which Somalia considers part of its territory.

The deal gave Ethiopia the right to build a naval base along Somaliland's coast under a 50-year lease.

In return, Ethiopia agreed to recognise Somaliland as a sovereign nation, drawing an angry condemnation from Somalia.

See Briefing: Ethiopian PM says no intention to harm Somalia amid sea access row

Source: The EastAfrican website, Nairobi, 3 Mar 24

title: Gunman shoots at four reporters in Mexico's Guerrero state, injuring three
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An unnamed gunman opened fire at four journalists who were covering the story of a murder in Chilpancingo, the capital of Mexico's Guerrero state, leaving three of them injured, Mexican news site Animal Politico reported on 28 November.
body:
The report added that Victor Mateo, journalist for local outlet El Grafico, and Jesus de la Cruz, of online news site Reporte Guerrero, were in serious condition.

Oscar Guerrero, photo-journalist for Animal Politico, was grazed by a bullet, the news site remarked.

It did not specify if police authorities had detained any suspects.

The reporters had been covering the murder of a bus driver in the city of Chilpancingo, and were walking down a street in the urban area near a military installation when a gunman on a motorcycle opened fire at them, Animal Politico said.

In recent years, Mexico has become one of the most dangerous countries in the world for journalists, with many high-profile killings of reporters blamed on organised crime.

Source: Animal Politico website (www.animalpolitico.com) , Mexico City, in Spanish 2148 gmt 28 Nov 23

title: At least 12 killed in explosion at Pakistan's Balochistan coal mine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 12 miners were killed in an explosion at a coal mine in the Zardalo area of Balochistan, prominent daily Dawn cited officials as saying.
body:
"The rescue operation has been just completed," the report quoted Balochistan chief inspector of mines Abdul Ghani Baloch as saying.

Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif also expressed grief over the incident.

"Such incidents are extremely painful and saddening. We stand by the victims' families in this hour of grief. The government will provide maximum possible relief to the injured and the affected families," private television channel ARY News reported.

National Assembly Speaker Sardar Ayaz Sadiq and Deputy Speaker Syed Ghulam Mustafa Shah also expressed "deep sorrow".

Last year in December, three coal miners were killed and three injured when a fire broke out in a private mine in Balochistan’s Duki coal field.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0800 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Iran's Raisi congratulates Russia's Putin on re-election
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's President Ebrahim Raisi has congratulated his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin on his re-election for a fifth term, the semi-official ISNA news agency reported on 18 March.
body:
According to the Iranian embassy in Moscow, Raisi congratulated Putin on his "decisive victory" and expressed hopes for further expansion of ties between the two countries.

Putin, who has been in power in Russia for almost 25 years, was declared winner in the uncompetitive 15-17 March presidential election with more than 87% of the vote.

Iran and Russia have become close allies in recent years, especially since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022. Russia have been using Iranian drones in Ukraine, but Tehran denies sending arms to Russia "to be used in Ukraine".

See also (from November 2023): Explainer: How are Russia and Iran growing their economic partnership?

(From December 2023) Explainer: What is driving Russia-Iran military cooperation?

Source: ISNA website, Tehran, in Persian 0819 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: At least 11 people killed in northern South Sudan attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Unknown gunmen have killed at least 11 people in Gogrial county, northern South Sudan, and stolen hundreds of livestock, the private Eye Radio website reported on 16 March.
body:
"On 16th this month [16 March], suspected armed youth from Mayom attacked a place called Wgej area of Gogrial East county...killing 11 civilians and wounding nine... and raided 532 heads of cattle," the report quoted Warrap state's information minister as saying.

The official said the attack was carried out by "people in uniform", implying that security forces might have been involved.

Thousands of people have been killed in cattle rustling-related violence and communal clashes in several parts of South Sudan in recent years.

Source: Eye Radio, Juba, in English 17 Mar 24

title: Former DR Congo president Kabila accused of supporting M23
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The secretary general of DR Congo's ruling  Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) party, Augustin Kabuya, has accused former President Joseph Kabila of supporting the March 23 Movement (M23) rebel group, French public radio RFI reported on 31 March.

title: Zambia army to embark on 'mega' maize farming to tackle drought
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Zambian army will start a mega maize farming food in response to a ravaging drought that affected more than half the country and destroyed 2.2 million hectares of farmland, state-owned Zambia Daily Mail newspaper reported on 6 March.
body:
President Hichilema, on 1 March, directed the army to get involved in food production for local consumption and urged international organisations to offer relief aid.

Zambia National Service (ZNS) commander Lt Gen Maliti Solochi said they have suspended the growing of wheat and will commit all the irrigation equipment to maize farming.

He said two farms in Shikabeta in the capital, Lusaka, and Luena in northern Kawambwa town, measuring 128 hectares and 520 hectares respectively, will be added to those where the army will grow maize.

"By the end of July, the service will have put to crop 1,978 hectares of irrigated maize, which is projected to yield about 15,000 metric tonnes by the end of the third quarter of 2024," Zambia Daily Mail quoted Gen Solochi.

Zambian army commander Sitali Alibuzwi and his Zambian Air Force counterpart Oscar Nyoni have also announced similar initiatives to cushion Zambians against drought.

The drought, which has been blamed on the El Nino weather phenomenon, has affected 84 out of 116 districts across the country.

Source: Zambia Daily Mail website, Lusaka, 6 Mar 24

title: IS yet to clarify which branch behind Moscow attack
snippet: By BBC Monitoring
body:
While Islamic State group (IS) has claimed responsibility for the attack on a concert hall outside the Russian capital Moscow, it has yet to announce which of its global branches was responsible for the operation.

This is because the initial claim on 22 March came through the group's news outlet Amaq, which does not habitually give information about the affiliated branch responsible.

The group is likely to claim the attack in the name of its Caucasus Province branch, which is one of the least active of IS's global affiliates.

In March, IS supporters shared a video of a man, allegedly from the Caucasus branch, pledging allegiance to IS leadership. He was said to have been among several suspected IS militants killed in a shoot-out with police in the Russian North Caucasus republic of Ingushetia on 2 March.

In the short video, the speaker says in accented Arabic "we the mujahidin of the Caucasus wilayah [IS branch]" urge IS's "caliph", Abu Hafs al-Hashimi al-Qurashi, to be resolute on the path of jihad, before telling him "march on", assuring him "there are men behind you [who have your back]".

Some analysts and authorities in Europe, however, have for months now been speculating about the growing ambitions of IS's Afghanistan-focused Khorasan Province branch (ISKP), which is believed to have Russian-speaking Central Asians in its ranks.  

Source: Amaq news agency in Arabic 0000 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Nigerian army kills "bandits" leader in Katsina State
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Nigerian army has announced that its troops killed a “bandits” leader known as Maikusa and some of his fighters in Nigeria’s north-western Katsina State, diaspora-based Sahara Reporters reported on 5 March.

title: Blast kills two soldiers at army base in southern Somalia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An explosion at an army base hosting troops from African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (Atmis) has killed an unspecified number of people including two Somali soldiers in the southern Qoryole town, privately-owned Shabelle Media Network reported on 20 March.
body:
The report said the explosion was from an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) buried inside the base. 

Shabelle said one of the two soldiers killed in the attack is a unit commander of the security forces identified as Shandheere.

"At the time of the explosion, Qoryole district police chief and some commanders of the Atmis forces were at the base… Qoryoley district police chief Ali Waal and the former intelligence chief for Qoryoley, Abdikarim Adow, were wounded in the blast," the report said. 

The Somali police and Atmis have not yet commented on the attack.

The explosion comes amid increased al-Shabab attacks against security forces since the beginning of the Ramadan.

On 18 March, the militants claimed to have killed 13 members of the Somali intelligence agency in an ambush in Afgoye town.

Source: Shabelle Media Network website, Mogadishu, in Somali 0000 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Sudan's Burhan condoles with Putin over Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Sudan has strongly condemned the 22 March evening attack on a concert hall on the outskirts of the Russian capital, Moscow, which killed at least 133 people, the state-run Sudan News Agency (Suna).
body:
"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist attack that happened on Friday evening at a shopping mall on the outskirts of the Russian capital, Moscow," Suna quoted the foreign ministry as saying in a statement on 23 March.

"The ministry... extends its warm condolences to the leadership, government, and people of the Russian Federation, and to the families of the victims," it added, expressing "full solidarity with friendly Russia and confidence in its ability to overcome this ordeal".

Meanwhile, Sudan's de facto president, Lt Gen Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, expressed his condolences in a message to Russian President Vladimir Putin, Suna further reported.

The so-called Islamic State group (IS) has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Source: Suna news agency website, Khartoum, in Arabic, 23 Mar 24

title: BBCM Ukraine Watchlist 14 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Ukrainian broadcast, press and social media sources

ONE PLUS ONE TV
body:
DAY 1,268 OF RUSSIAN INVASION OF UKRAINE

Five principles to end war

Yesterday President Volodymyr Zelensky and European leaders agreed on five principles to end the war in Ukraine, the Suspilne public broadcaster reported on its website. It noted that the decision was taken on the eve of the 15 August Trump-Putin talks in Alaska.

The principles are as follows:

1. Anything concerning Ukraine must be discussed with Ukraine.

2. Preparations should be made for a trilateral format of talks (Zelensky-Trump-Putin).

3. A ceasefire and security guarantees for Ukraine.

4. Russia cannot have veto power over Ukraine's EU and Nato membership prospects.

5. Sanctions pressure on Russia will have to be ratcheted up if it does not agree to a ceasefire during the Alaska talks.

"Ukraine and its European partners have agreed on five joint principles regarding peace negotiations and conveyed them to US President Donald Trump," the Ukrainian president's official website commented.

For his part, Zelensky voiced confidence after virtual talks with Trump and European leaders that a ceasefire in Ukraine should become a key subject of the Alaska summit.

Reaction to principles

The five principles did not go down well with some Ukrainian commentators.

"Zelensky, Trump and EU leaders agreed on the five principles for talks with Russia. Trump and principles... Trump and agreed on... They are like kids upon my soul!" journalist Raul Chilachava said on Facebook.

"And what will happen to Donbas? To Kramatorsk, Druzhkivka and Slovyansk? No information," blogger and army serviceman Yuriy Kasyanov posted on Facebook.

"Zelensky's new 'peace formula', 'peace summit', 'security guarantees' and 'victory plan' rolled into one," an X user commented sarcastically.

Coalition of the Willing

Zelensky hailed the outcome of the sixth meeting of the Coalition of the Willing.

"Together with our partners, we supported the efforts of US President Donald Trump to end the war, stop the killings, and achieve a just and lasting peace. I am grateful to the partners for our shared position: the path to peace cannot be determined without Ukraine, and negotiations can only yield results if they take place under a ceasefire," he said on X in English.

"During the meeting, we coordinated the next steps and agreed to continue working in close contact between Ukraine, all of Europe, and the United States. I thank everyone who is working to bring this war to a just end."

Situation near Dobropillya

The situation around the population centre of Dobropillya, Donetsk Region, where Russian advances were reported in the past days, remains a major media story.

The spokesman for the Dnipro operational-strategic group of forces, Viktor Trehubov, told Suspilne on 13 August that the situation near Dobropillya "is tense but under control", with Ukrainian forces seeking to encircle the Russian forces.

"As of now, reserves have been deployed to hold back and annihilate the Russians there. Work is being carried out to encircle, squeeze out and annihilate them. Competent forces have been deployed, although, in my opinion, the very fact of this situation is quite unpleasant," Trehubov said.

The 1st Azov Corps of the National Guard of Ukraine, which has been reportedly deployed to the Dobropillya area, said on Telegram late on 13 August that "the enemy is suffering significant losses" as a result of "actions" carried out by it and other units.

"As a result of the fighting, 151 occupiers have been liquidated in the corps' area of responsibility. Over 70 invaders have been wounded. Also, eight Russian servicemen have been taken captive over this period," Azov said.

An analyst with the DeepState OSINT project, Roman Mykula, struck and upbeat note in an interview with the Apostrof TV.

"As for Dobropillya, the situation is currently improving. Defence forces are seeking to stabilise the situation, and as soon as one can report the results, of course, everything will be put on the [DeepState] map," he said.

The head of the Ground Forces Reservists' Council, Ivan Tymochko, said that "countermeasures are being taken" near Dobropillya, the TSN.ua website reported. Tymochko predicted that the situation "will become more understandable" by the end of the week.

Situation in Sumy Region

In Sumy Region, the Armed Forces of Ukraine (AFU) "have liberated three villages and advanced by hundreds of meters over the past day", the pooled TV service said this morning in an upbeat report captioned "The front in Sumy Region: the AFU is liberating territory".

Military expert Serhiy Bratchuk was shown saying that Ukrainian forces had carried out "some successful operations" and forced Russian troops to retreat to the border. He also voiced hope that eventually "we will see a better situation on the battlefield".

The TV noted that some 25 Ukrainian population centres are currently in the "active combat zone".

"Some villages have been completely destroyed," it added.

War update

There were 148 combat engagements between Ukrainian and Russian troops on 13 August, the Ukrainian General Staff reported on Facebook the following morning.

The Pokrovsk sector was the hottest spot on the front line in Ukraine, with 56 Russian attacks reported there.

Fourteen clashes were reported in the Novopavlivka sector, 14 in the Siversk sector, 13 in the Lyman sector, seven in the Toretsk sector, six in the Northern Slobozhanshchyna sector (covers parts of Sumy Region) and the Kursk sector, five in the Southern Slobozhanshchyna sector (covers parts of Kharkiv Region), four in Kherson Region, three in the Kramatorsk sector, three in the Kupyansk sector, one in the Orikhiv sector and one in the Hulyaypole sector.

Russia carried out two missile and 87 air strikes using four missiles and 154 glide bombs, and shelled Ukraine 5,758 times, including 82 times with MRLS. Russian forces also used over 4,400 kamikaze drones.

Ukrainian aviation, rocket and artillery troops hit eight Russian clusters of personnel and materiel, two artillery pieces, a fuel-and-lubricant depot, a command post and a radar, the General Staff added.

Zapad 2025

The number of Russian troops already deployed to Belarus ahead of the Zapad (West) 2025 drills "is not big", the Ukrinform news agency quoted the spokesman for the State Border Service as saying.

However, Andriy Demchenko noted that there is still a month before the start for the war games, and Ukraine keeps closely monitoring the situation.

"What must concern us the most [...] is the data about forces Russia can deploy to Belarus. It will determine the threat to our country," he said.

He also warned that Russia may use the drills to force the Ukrainian command to deploy additional forces to the Belarus border.

title: Mali army repulses three militant attacks in the south
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Malian army (FAMa) has announced that it has repelled three militant attacks on customs and army posts in the south of the country, French public radio RFI reported on 16 March.
body:
According to a FAMa statement, a civilian official and several militants were killed during a failed raid on the Banankoro customs post in the Kangaba Cercle of the Koulikoro Region at 00:50GMT on 16 March. 

The attackers retreated to the Kofiate forest where they were killed, the report said.

A few hours later – at about 05:40 GMT – gunmen attacked a FAMa position in Danderesso, Sikasso Region, but the army repelled the raid.

"The FAMa counter-attack was fierce and benefited from significant support from the Burkina Faso Armed Forces from Operation Kapidgou. The surviving terrorists, who had retreated to the border, were pursued," said FAMa.

It added that another attack on a FAMa post in Mahou, in the Koutiala Region – at around 06:40GMT – was 'vigorously repulsed', without giving any casualties.

Both Al-Qaeda's Jamaat Nusrat al-Islam wal Muslimin (JNIM) and Islamic State Sahel Province have claimed several attacks on security forces in recent weeks.

Source: Radio France Internationale website, Paris, in French 16 Mar 24

title: N Korean leader's sister says Japan PM proposed summit with Kim Jong-un
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korean leader's sister has said that Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has proposed holding a summit with Kim Jong-un, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
In a statement on 25 March, Kim Yo-jong said Kishida has conveyed his "intention" to meet Kim Jong-un "as soon as possible".

"As already mentioned, what is important in opening a way out for the improved DPRK-Japan relations is for Japan to make its political decision in actuality," she said.

DPRK or Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the official name of North Korea. 

Kim Yo-jong also said that North Korea's "strengthened self-defence capability will never be a threat to the security of Japan, if the latter respects the former's sovereignty and security interests in a fair and equal stand".

In February, Kim Yo-jong had indicated that the leaders of the two countries could hold a summit.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0800 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Ethiopian, South Sudan army chiefs discuss 'mutual concern'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ethiopian Army Chief Field Marshal Birhanu Jula has arrived in South Sudan on a two-day official visit to the country at the invitation of the government, the pro-government Fana Broadcasting Corporate reported on 20 March.
body:
"Chief of General Staff of the Ethiopian National Defence Forces, Field Marshal Birhanu Jula, has arrived in Juba, the capital of South Sudan, for a two-day official visit," said Fana.

Fana said Birhanu travelled to Juba at the "invitation of the South Sudanese Government".

"Field Marshal Birhanu Jula has discussed with his counterpart Lt Gen Santino Deng Wol [and] other senior military officers on bilateral issues of mutual concern...The two sides discussed ways how to cement cooperation in ensuring sustainable peace and stability in border areas of the two countries and the region at large," said Fana.

South Sudanese armed tribesmen are reportedly launching cross-border attacks from areas they control inside Ethiopia.

Source: Fana Broadcasting Corporate website, Addis Ababa, in English 1810 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Drought-hit Zambia to import maize from Tanzania, Uganda
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Zambia plans to import maize from Tanzania and Uganda to plug a deficit of the staple food after an El Nino-induced drought led to a massive crop failure in the southern African nation, the state-run newspaper Zambia Daily Mail reported on 10 March.

title: Death toll from Moscow concert hall attack rises to 133
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 133 people have been killed in the 22 March terror attack on a concert hall outside Moscow, state news agency TASS reported on 23 March quoting the Russian Investigations Committee.
body:
The search and rescue operations continue, the Investigations Committee said on its Telegram channel.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1331 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: Seven soldiers killed in suspected militant attack in northwest Pakistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Seven soldiers, including two officers, were killed on 16 March in a suspected militant attack on a security forces' post in North Waziristan district of Pakistan's northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Dawn newspaper reported citing the military's media wing, Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR).
body:
Six suspected militants were also killed in the subsequent clearance operation, the report noted.

According to the ISPR, in the early hours of 16 March, a group of six militants attacked a security forces’ post in the general area of Mir Ali of North Waziristan District, the report said.

Meanwhile, Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif and President Asif Ali Zardari, in separate statements, condemned the attack. Sharif called the attack a "coward" move by the militants, the report added.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 1100 GMT 16 Mar 24

title: Indian foreign minister urges addressing trade imbalance with Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Indian Foreign Minister S Jaishankar on 20 August highlighted the growing trade imbalance with Russia and called for diversifying economic engagements to address the issue.
body:
Speaking at the India-Russia Inter-Governmental Commission for Trade, Economic, Scientific, Technological and Cultural Cooperation meeting in Moscow, alongside Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister Denis Manturov, Jaishankar said the trade imbalance has risen to $58.9bn and called for addressing it "urgently", according to a readout by India's Ministry of External Affairs (MEA).

The growing trade imbalance has mainly been attributed to India stepping up oil purchases from Russia in the aftermath of the Ukraine war.

The minister stated that "addressing tariff and non-tariff trade barriers, removing bottlenecks in logistics", promoting connectivity through key corridors, enhancing payment mechanisms, and the "early conclusion" of a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) between India and the countries of the Eurasian region are among key steps which will help the two sides "to address the imbalance and grow our trade".

The terms of reference for the FTA between India and the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) were finalised during the Moscow meeting on 20 August.

Jaishankar highlighted that the meeting was taking place against "the backdrop of a complex geopolitical situation" and urged that both should move beyond "the beaten track" by diversifying the trade basket.

Separately, addressing the India-Russia Business Forum, the minister urged Russian companies to engage "more intensively" with their Indian counterparts.

"Both the diversification and balancing of trade now urgently mandate more strenuous efforts on our part," he said.

Jaishankar is on a three-day visit to Russia aimed at strengthening what Delhi described as a "time-tested" strategic partnership. He was scheduled to hold talks with his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov on 21 August.

title: Pakistan's ex-PM Imran Khan seeks judicial probe into 'poll rigging'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's imprisoned former Prime Minister Imran Khan's party, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) moved the Supreme Court on 20 March against the alleged irregularities in the recently held general elections, The Express Tribune newspaper reported.
body:
The petition demanded the formation of a judicial commission comprising serving apex court judges "holding no bias towards anyone to inquire, audit and examine the manner and process of general elections of 8 February, 2024 and the developments that took place thereafter of compiling false and fraudulent results rendering winners into losers and losers into winners", the report noted.

"All consequential acts of the forming governments at the federal and Punjab [province] levels be immediately suspended until the commission makes the probe public," the petition said. 

The petition demanded that relief be granted in the "best interest of the nation, its electoral mandate, and Constitutional dispensation", adding that the election results were manipulated and the poll body failed to hold free and fair polls.

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0624 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Russia's Shoigu says idea of new mobilisation 'nonsense'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu has dismissed suggestions that a new wave of mobilisation of military personnel is needed.
body:
"This is nonsense," the state news agency TASS quoted Shoigu as saying in response to a question about whether such a measure is needed to create a buffer zone in Ukraine.

Previously, Putin suggested that Russia might create such a buffer zone in response to reported cross-border attacks from Ukraine, TASS recalled.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1230 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: North Korean leader congratulates Syria's Bashar
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has congratulated Syrian President Bashar Al-Assad on the occasion of the "61st anniversary of the March 8 Revolution" in Syria, Pyongyang's state media report.
body:
"Rendering invariable support and solidarity to the Syrian people in their just struggle to defend the sovereignty of the country and achieve territorial integrity under the leadership of the Syria's Baath Arab Socialist Party headed by the Syrian president, the message expressed belief that the traditional relations of friendship and cooperation between the two countries would grow stronger," a 9 March report by the Korean Central News Agency stated.

North Korean state controlled media often highlight Kim Jong-un's messages for Syria's Bashar al-Assad and the latter's responses. Although North Korean state media are usually slow to report on world events, messages of diplomatic exchanges with Syria appear with regularity.

See also: Briefing: North Korean media highlight friendly exchanges with Syria

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 1026 GMT 9 Mar 24

title: China, Sri Lanka sign pact to recognise each other's quality certification
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The China Quality Certification Center and the Sri Lanka Bureau of Standards on 29 March signed a Memorandum of Understanding on mutual recognition of conformity assessment results, the website of Sri Lankan newspaper Daily Mirror reported on 30 March.
body:
Sri Lankan Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena hailed the development as a milestone in China-Sri Lanka cooperation, facilitated by the two countries' joint efforts to establish closer ties, the report said.

He said the pact will help promote mutual recognition of quality certification systems between the two nations, providing more convenient services for bilateral trade and investment.

"This will elevate product quality and competitiveness in both nations, fostering economic prosperity while deepening friendship and welfare for our peoples," he added.

Source: Daily Mirror website, Colombo, in English 0610 GMT 30 Mar 24

title: DR Congo army, peacekeepers push back Codeco attack in east
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The DR Congo army and UN peacekeepers (Monusco) on 19 March pushed back an attack by the rebel group, Cooperative for the Development of the Congo (Codeco), which took place in Ngabo village, Djugu Territory in the eastern Ituri Province, the UN-sponsored Radio Okapi reported.

title: Philippines says China 'humiliating' itself over actions in South China Sea
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Philippines has said China is "humiliating" itself after Manila accused Beijing of firing water cannons on its resupply ships in the disputed areas of the South China Sea, the Philippine Daily Inquirer reported.
body:
Philippines National Security Adviser Eduardo Año on 24 March said that the country would not be deterred from resupplying its military outpost in Ayungin [Second Thomas Shoal] despite China’s latest actions. 

The Chinese are "humiliating themselves" with what they are doing and they are acting "as if it’s already the end of the world over a mere resupply mission," he added.

Ano also said three Philippine troops were injured after the Chinese coast guar fired water cannon on a Filipino supply vessel near a South China Sea reef on 23 March.

See also: Explainer: How does China view South China Sea disputes with its neighbours?

Source: Philippine Daily Inquirer website in English 0300 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 7 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Israeli media anticipate cabinet vote on Gaza occupation
body:
Israeli media are anticipating what it said would be a "fateful" cabinet meeting today where a plan to occupy the entire Gaza Strip is expected to be approved.

The public broadcaster Kan reported that the expanded Israeli military operation, which will focus on Gaza City and the centre of the enclave, is expected to last five months.

Unnamed security sources told Kan that the goal is to push the entire population south to the Mawasi area in a plan that will "serve the voluntary migration programme".

The website of Channel 12 News described the meeting as "fateful", predicting that it will be "particularly heated" amid growing tensions between political and military officials.

Sisi says destruction in Gaza 'unprecedented'

Egyptian President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi has described the destruction in Gaza as "unprecedented", reiterating Egypt's support for the Gaza Strip despite "distortion and misinformation campaigns" that target Cairo in this regard.

Speaking during a visit to the Military Academy yesterday,commended the Egyptian policy saying that Cairo has always realised the threat of any confrontation between "elements in Gaza" and Israel, without explicitly mentioning Hamas.

Meanwhile, Sisi warned that social media outlets have been used to sow divisions, undermine morale and spread rumours among Egyptians, who he described as facing challenges with increasing awareness.

This came against the backdrop of a recent crackdown by authorities against key TikTokers in the country who have been accused of publishing "indecent" content.

Egypt pro-state media change supportive tone for Hamas

Egyptian media have changed their supportive tone towards Hamas and started to blame the group for the deteriorating conditions in Gaza.

Key TV hosts and media figures have lashed out at the group after Hamas criticised Egypt's role in delivering aid to the strip and accused Cairo of "creating the illusion of solidarity" with Gaza.

In his talk show aired on the privately owned TeN TV, key pro-state TV host Nashaat el-Dehi yesterday cited a "major setback" in Gaza as a direct result of "the political and military choices made by Hamas".

Some public figures echoed the same sentiment in interviews with media outlets in which they also defended Egypt's policies towards Gaza.

We will file a Briefing on Egypt's change of tone towards Hamas.

Netanyahu reportedly ignored police request to restrain Ben Gvir

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ignored a police request to restrain far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir after he paid a contentious visit to the al-Aqsa mosque compound earlier this week, the public broadcaster Kan reported this morning.

Marking the Tisha B'Av holiday, Ben Gvir had prayed at the holy site, violating a decades old agreement that forbids Jewish prayer and sparking harsh criticism from Palestinian groups and Jordan.

Tisha B'Av is a Jewish day of mourning commemorating the destruction of two ancient temples that once stood in Jerusalem.

According to Kan, the police told Netanyahu that he has the authority to restrain Ben Gvir and contacted him hoping to prevent further incidents.

Ben Gvir, a key ally of Netanyahu, makes regular visits to the compound, seen by Palestinians. as a provocation.

Hezbollah 'attacks' government ahead of ministerial meeting

Lebanese media highlighted a statement Hezbollah made yesterday rejecting a government deadline to disarm Hezbollah by the end of 2025, ahead of another ministerial meeting scheduled for today.

The group published a statement yesterday accusing the government of committing a "major sin" over its decision on disarmament, and said that it would act "as if [the decision] did not exist".

Separately, the group's Al-Manar channel asked yesterday evening how a country "that seeks to disarm itself" could respond to attacks, highlighting an Israeli strike in southern Lebanon yesterday which killed one child.

The French-language L'Orient-Le Jour daily reported that Hezbollah was "attacking" the government ahead of the meeting today. It said that Hezbollah's statement indicated a potential "political crisis", should the meeting today fail to "smooth things over".

Syrian ministry says Druze blocking entry of staff

Syrian media have highlighted remarks Health Minister Musab al-Ali made to Al Arabiya yesterday evening, in which he said that Druze factions affiliated to controversial cleric Hikmat al-Hajri (also Hijri) were preventing the entry of ministry personnel into the southern Suweida province.

Ali told the pan-Arab Saudi channel that while aid was entering the province daily, Hajri had "obstructed" the entry of ministry staff.

The leading Syria TV reported that such a move would prevent the ministry from "carrying out its fieldwork in the region". It also said that the Syrian Red Crescent was overseeing the entry of fuel and food, but that there remained a "severe shortage" of basic commodities.

The province saw a wave of deadly sectarian violence in recent weeks between Druze factions, local Bedouin tribes, and Syrian government forces.

Damascus signs investment deals worth $14bn

The Syrian government signed several major investment agreements and reconstruction projects in Damascus yesterday.

The Enab Baladi website reported that the deals, signed with - mostly Qatari - international companies were worth $14bn. This included the renovation of Damascus International Airport, the building of a new airport and the construction of a Damascus metro.

It said that the projects spanned over Damascus, Aleppo, Homs, Hama and Tartous.

Enab Baladi cited a Syrian official as saying that such projects would be an "engine" for job creation and international investment.

Interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa and US special envoy to Syria Tom Barrack were present at the signing ceremony, according to Syria TV.

The new Syrian authorities face a major challenge in rebuilding the country after almost 14 years of civil war, which severely damaged the country's infrastructure and residential areas.

Coming Up

- Sudan's Prime Minister Kamil Idris visits Egypt today in his first foreign trip since taking office, Egyptian media reported. Idris will meet his Egyptian counterpart, Mostafa Madbouly, for talks on developments in the ongoing war in Sudan and how to improve living conditions for the Sudanese community in Egypt.

- UAE President Mohammed bin Zayed embarks on an official visit today to Russia, where he will meet President Vladimir Putin. The official UAE news agency WAM said talks will tackle ways to boost economic, trade, investment and energy cooperation. Bin Zayed last visited Russia in October when he took part in the Brics summit in the city of Kazan.

title: Iran's interior minister reports 41% turnout in elections
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian Interior Minister Ahmad Vahidi has announced a turnout of 41% in the parliamentary and Assembly of Experts elections on 1 March, as reported by the Young Journalists' Club (YJC) on 4 March.
body:
During a press conference, Vahidi said approximately 25 million people had cast their votes, with the total number of blank votes nationwide accounting for only 5% of ballots. The turnout figure is the lowest since the 1979 Islamic revolution. 

Vahidi said preparations were underway the second round of parliamentary elections scheduled in the Iranian month of Ordibehesht (20 April - 20 May). However, he did not announce the exact date.

He said the ministry was discussing the dates with the election watchdog, the Guardian Council. "Given the concurrent timing of university entrance exams, we need to assess whether it aligns with the exam period," Vahidi said.

Vahidi commended the ministry's "effective" management of the elections, saying "no violations" were reported on election day. He praised the people's "active participation" in the face of "enemy media propaganda aimed at discouraging voter turnout and some economic challenges they face", considering it as "yet another victory".

This was the first national vote since the 2022 nationwide unrest. The latest poll had predicted a turnout of around 41% in the parliamentary elections.

See: Guide to Iran's 2024 elections

Source: Iranian Young Journalists' Club website, Tehran, in Persian 1329 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: At least one killed, 14 injured in Pakistan's Balochistan blast
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least one person was killed and 14 injured in a blast in Pakistan's Balochistan province, prominent daily Dawn cited officials as saying.
body:
The blast took place in Balochistan's Harnai district after an improvised explosive device targeted an oil and gas exploration company vehicle during a gas exploration survey in the area, it added.

"It was an improvised explosive device (IED) planted at the roadside in Wareekha area at the border of Harnai and Duki," the report quoted Harnai Deputy Commissioner Javed Domki as saying.

Balochistan Chief Minister Sarfraz Bugti condemned the incident as a "deplorable act of violence".

See also: Pakistan's Dunya TV show on pressures on judiciary, militant attacks, economy

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0500 GMT 31 Mar 24

title: Iran police officer dies in clashes with 'drug smugglers'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Iranian police officer has been killed in clashes with "drug smigglers" in the Mehrestan County in the south-eastern Sistan-Baluchestan Province, the official IRNA news agency reported on 12 March.
body:
According to the provincial police department, Sgt Hossein Shibak died of injuries he sustained in an exchange of fire with passengers of two cars that the police officers were trying to stop on the suspicion of smuggling narcotics on 12 March.

The police report said that efforts were underway to identify and arrest the shooters, who managed to flee the scene. 

It added that the officers seized 500kg of narcotics and one of the vehicles, as the other car caught on fire during the clashes.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 0614 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Turkish police detain dozens at pro-Kurdish party's Newroz event in Istanbul
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Turkish police detained over 50 people at a Newroz (Nevruz) celebration in Istanbul on 17 March, organised by the pro-Kurdish opposition People's Equality and Democracy Party (DEM Party), independent news website Bianet reported.

title: Mali drone strike reportedly kills children at Qur'anic school
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 14 people, mostly children, were killed in a drone strike on a Qur'anic school in central Mali, French public radio RFI reported on 25 March.
body:
It said the incident took place in Douna village of Mondoro Commune in Douentza Region at around 10am local time on 23 March, when children were studying the Qur'an around a fire, the report said.

“The images received by RFI are hard to bear: They show deformed, bloodied bodies of children... Nine wounded were evacuated to the Mopti-Sévaré hospital,” RFI said.

The latest targeting error has prompted anger within the army, RFI added, quoting an anonymous officer who demanded that “these blunders must stop”.

The report said that one before the Douna strike, Tuareg groups accused the army of killing another 14 women and children in a drone attack in Amasrakad in Gao Region.

Civilian deaths during security operations are rarely acknowledged by the authorities, who have increasingly resorted to using air strikes against militants and armed groups across the country. 

Source: Radio France Internationale website, Paris, in French 25 Mar 24

title: Ukraine reports downing 18 out of 22 Russian strike drones
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's air defences shot down 18 Russian Shahed-type kamikaze drones in Odesa Region on the night of 4-5 March, the Air Force has said on Telegram.
body:
A total of 22 Russian drones were launched from the area of Balaklava in Crimea, it said.

Drones damaged a recreational facility that has not been operating since the start of the invasion, and a private house on the sea shore, Ukraine's Operational Command South said on Telegram. It reported no casualties.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0450 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab claims killing six Kenyan pastors in southern Somalia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The al-Shabab group has claimed to have killed six Kenyan pastors and wounded another in a bomb attack in the southern Somali town of Dhobley in the Lower Jubba region, the pro-militant Somali Memo news website reported on 29 March.

title: Modi vows to make India hub of manufacturing semiconductors
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has vowed to make the country a manufacturing hub of semiconductors, The Hindu newspaper reported on its website on 13 March.
body:
"When India commits, India delivers and democracy also delivers… This is a historic day as we are taking a strong step towards a bright future," Modi said, after laying the foundation stones for three semiconductor facilities.

The projects worth 1.25 trillion rupees ($15bn) comprises one plant in north-eastern Assam state and two others in western Gujarat state.

Modi added the "Made in India" semiconductor chips will "take the country towards self-reliance and modernity".

Source: The Hindu website, Chennai, in English 0934 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Philippine leader questions premise of China's proposals on South China Sea
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has said Manila did not reject China's proposals on managing disputes in the South China Sea, but added that Beijing's suggestions are based on a questionable premise, The Philippine Star website reported.
body:
"We have not rejected any proposals that China has made to us, but the premise is something that we question. The premise that China has made is that their territory follows what is now described as a 10-dash line," Marcos said on 12 March at a joint briefing with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz. 

"That is not recognized by any country, any international body, certainly not by the Philippines," Marcos added.

"Our baselines have been well established for years now. We have the economic zone that China has already intruded upon. And until that premise that China has made in terms of all its discussions with the Philippines, then it's very difficult to see a way forward," he noted.

Earlier, China said it had put forward initiatives to the Philippines "to control the maritime situation and work together".

Source: The Philippine Star website, Manila, in English 0600 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Rwanda records high temperatures in several regions
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Rwanda Meteorology Agency has said several parts of the country experienced 28˚C to 30˚C temperatures between 11 and 20 March, which was above the maximum average long-term range, private pro-government New Times website reported on 19 March.

title: Russian investigators say Moscow attackers paid money from Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Investigations Committee says it has uncovered information linking Ukraine to the Moscow concert hall attack in the form of a payment from that country to those who carried it out.
body:
"The investigation has obtained access to confirmed information that a substantial sum of monetary funds and cryptocurrency from Ukraine was received by the perpetrators," the committee's press service told the state news agency TASS.

A similar claim was made by the committee on its Telegram channel.

"The initial results of the investigation completely confirm the planned nature of the terrorists' actions, their careful preparation and financial support from the organisers," it said.

"As a result of work done with the arrested terrorists, the study of the technical devices confiscated from them, the analysis of information about financial operations, proof has been obtained of their links to Ukrainian nationalists."

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1451 gmt 28 Mar 24

title: Ethiopia arrests 205 immigration service staff over graft
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of immigration services in Ethiopia has announced the arrest of over 200 staff members over corruption in the past six months.
body:
In an interview with the state broadcaster ETV on 25 March, the Immigration and Citizenship Service director-general, Selamawit Dawit, said her office was striving to address public outcry over poor services and malpractice in the department.

"We got 205 people [staff] arrested and made them face the law in the past six month," said Selamawit when asked what her department was doing to tackle "malpractices" regarding the issuance of passports.

She said others were sacked or suspended.

There have been public outcry over alleged widespread corruption at the department in the recent past.

Source: ETV News, Addis Ababa, in Amharic 1000 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Website says one killed in Yemen mosque clashes, blaming Houthis
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A leading Yemeni website has said one person was killed and several others wounded in clashes between worshippers and Yemen’s Shia Houthi authorities at a mosque in the capital Sanaa last on the evening of 17 March.
body:
The anti-Houthi Al-Masdar Online news website reported this morning that the clashes occurred in the south of the city after Houthi security forces attempted to stop nightly Ramadan Tarawih prayers in order to broadcast a Houthi leader’s speech. After mediation from tribal elders, the clashes subsided and a "siege" on the Omar Ibn al-Khattab mosque was imposed, Al-Masdar Online said. 

The website said that the "Houthi militia is waging a massive campaign against Tarawih prayers, which they stipulate must end before 20:30, in order to prepare the areas to listen to the group’s leader’s speech, which is broadcast at 21:00, and obliges mosques to broadcast it on a daily basis."

It said that Houthi forces deploy gunmen at various mosques, to make people congregate and listen to the daily sermon, "while forcefully stopping any imam who prolongs the prayer beyond 20:30".

Similar tensions were reported in Yemeni mosques last year, and Al-Masdar Online also reported days earlier that the Houthis were trying to impose specific Ramadan practices associated with Shia Islam in territory under the control that contrasted with practices observed by Yemen’s Sunni majority.

Source: Al-Masdar Online website in Arabic 1328 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Ukraine's energy system 'holding together', but situation 'very difficult' - PM
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal has said that the Ukrainian energy system is "holding together" after Russia's massive attack in the early hours of 29 March, but the situation is "very difficult".
body:
"Last night Russian terrorists carried out another massive attack using missiles and drones against our country. The main target of the attack was again our energy sector. We have withstood the attack. The energy system is holding together, but the situation is very difficult. There are problems with power supply in several regions. We are resolving this issue," Shmyhal told a government meeting, as reported by the Interfax-Ukraine news agency.

According to the prime minister, Ukraine is importing electricity from Romania, Slovakia, Poland, Hungary and Moldova to ensure the system's stable operation.

"Today's attack again severely damaged equipment. Again, the attack was directed both against power generation facilities and against the distribution system. It is very important for all of us now to cut power consumption, especially in the evening hours," Shmyhal said.

He noted that some of the facilities damaged during the previous attack had been already restored.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1555 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Korean citizen detained in Russia on suspicion of spying
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia has detained a South Korean national on suspicion of spying, TASS news agency reports.
body:
Law enforcement agencies said the man was arrested in the city of Vladivostok in Russia's far east, where a court had remanded him in custody. He was then sent to Moscow to be further investigated.

TASS said it was the first such case involving a South Korean citizen.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1333 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Russia election: 50 said evacuated after Perm polling station blast
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A woman has blown off her hand after setting off a firework at a polling station in the Urals city of Perm, Baza Telegram channel, which is believed to be close to the security services, reported on 17 March.
body:
At least 50 people had to be evacuated from the polling station after the blast, the report said.

The 64-year old woman, who set off the device in the polling station's toilet, was taken to hospital after the incident, the report said.

According to eyewitnesses, the woman was talking to someone on a phone before the blast. According to the initial information, she may have been talking to scammers, Baza said.

Her bag had been searched by security guards when she came into the building but they did not find any forbidden items, the report said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1525 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Russia: First arrests at 'Noon against Putin' opposition event
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Several arrests have been reported at the "Noon against Putin" opposition action, where voters were encouraged to come to polling stations at noon and vote against the Russian president.
body:
Latvia-based outlet Meduza reported that there were at least 20 arrests in Kazan, where police officers "banned young people who came at noon from voting and asked them to 'come later'".

Telegram channel Nastoyashcheye Vremya (Current TIme) reported arrests in Kazan, Krasnodar, and Volgograd.

Rights monitor OVD-Info reported two arrests in St Petersburg, one of a reporter of local outlet Fontanka and the other of a local opposition activist.

Several local election officials and monitors were detained or barred from performing their duties, including an official who was detained in Moscow for wearing a shirt with "Navalny" written on it, Meduza reported.

Telegram channel Mozhem Obyasnit (We can explain) cited a source as saying that the communist party CPRF "recalled en masse" its election monitors prior to the opposition event.

Meanwhile, online outlets share images of long queues to polling stations in Russia, including in St Petersburg and Moscow, as well as abroad.

Opposition politician Boris Nadezhdin, who was barred from running in the election, cast his vote at noon at a polling station in Moscow.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1025 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Hum TV show on political instability, issues in coalition government
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Newsline", hosted by anchor Maria Zulfiqar Khan on liberal Hum News TV in Urdu at 17:00 GMT on 24 March 2024. Khan invites analysts and politicians to the show to discuss important issues.

Anchor Maria Zulfiqar Khan commented that running a government amidst the current economic problems is "not a bed of roses, but a crown of thorns" and the ruling coalition seems to have realised it very well. She said "revolutionary measures" and a completely new approach are needed for implementing an agenda of economic reforms but the question is whether it would be possible for the coalition government to do so.
body:
Khan noted within the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N), which is the largest party in the ruling coalition, voices are being raised about it being a mistake to take over the government. She was of the view that this is because party members have realised that the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf's (PTI) future politics would be focused on highlighting the alleged injustices done to it and it would also keep criticising the government for its tough decisions.

Khan asked journalist Irshad Bhatti to share his views on the PML-N apparently regretting its decision to take over the government. Bhatti commented "the biggest challenge for the government is the government itself" because the country is facing the worst economic and political crisis and both these crises are "supplementing each other". He said there is no hope that the government would improve the economy and claimed no country trusts it. He added whatever steps are to be taken for the economy would be taken by the military. He alleged there is a power struggle going on within the Sharif family.

Bhatti further alleged there is a rift between Minister of Interior Mohsin Naqvi and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif; another rift is between the provincial government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and the federal government; and there is yet another rift between the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) and the PML-N, particularly over privatisation of state enterprises. He added another rift has emerged between Minister of Finance Muhammad Aurangzeb and former finance minister Ishaq Dar.

Senior journalist Sana Bucha commented this is not a government but a "standby agreement or a standby adjustment phase" through which the country is passing. She appreciated Mohsin Naqvi's performance as the former chief minister of Punjab and said it is good that he is the interior minister now. She added Naqvi has "zero interests politically and personally", so he would be on the right path.

Talking about Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb, Bucha said he wants what he considers to be "his share in the government" and that is why he was being given the chairmanship of an economic coordination committee. She was of the view that if the PTI wanted to come into power, it should have made a coalition government along with the PPP, but it "only wanted to keep making noise".

Senior analyst Raza Rumi said at the moment, governance in the country is in the "grip of factionalism" and various "factions" within the PML-N-led government and power centres are exercising their influence. He noted Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif is trying to take several factions along, so it looks like people would see a "struggling prime minister" in the coming months. He remarked it should be kept in mind that coalition governments always work in this manner.

Commenting on inclusion of Mohsin Naqvi in the cabinet and appointment of former caretaker interior minister Sarfraz Bugti as the chief minister of Balochistan, Rumi said these appointments are "against the spirit of the Constitution" because caretakers should not join the government formed after elections. He was of the view that running the government would be difficult for the prime minister and the present situation is "not good for the future of democracy" in the country.

Bhatti said Ishaq Dar has been appointed as the foreign minister at a time when the "foreign image of Pakistan is very bad" and all the battles are to be fought on the foreign policy front. He noted friendly countries are no longer willing to provide financial support to Pakistan.

Khan played a clip of a statement by PTI politician Asad Qaiser, who said the PTI would launch a protest movement and not let the government "sit in peace". Commenting on the situation, Bhatti insisted political stability would not be possible without holding talks with the PTI or its founder Imran Khan. He added there is a need for a "charter of Pakistan".

Rumi remarked political stability has never been there in Pakistan, except during the years under the military's rule, so people should not be "idealistic" in this regard. He was of the view that the "hybrid system" which has been created would work for the time being. He said the present government could be changed if the PTI decides to give up its narrative that it would not talk to other parties and forms a coalition. However, he added, the PTI is not likely to change its stance because its popularity depends on the narrative that it is the only "clean party" and all other politicians are "thieves and robbers".

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1700 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Twelve die in Sudan after ferry boat sinks the Nile
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 12 people died on 4 March after a ferry boat they were travelling in sank in Blue Nile River in central Sudan, privately-owned Al-Taghyeer newspaper reported.
body:
"Twelve people died on Monday (4 March) after a ferry boat sank in al-Mahs Kutrang al-Masid area in Gezira state in central Sudan," the report said.

"Sources told Al-Taghyeer that the ferry was carrying a number of citizens including some from Benbunab area, and that some bodies have been recovered, while the search for the missing people was underway," it added.

Many civilians in villages near the Blue Nile river use motorboats to flee "the violence and assaults" by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF), the report said citing local sources.

RSF has been controlling majority of Gezira state and areas between the state and the capital Khartoum since December 2023 amid reports of "human rights violations" against civilians by the paramilitary group.

Source: Al-Taghyir (Al-Taghyeer) website, Khartoum, in Arabic 4 Mar 24

title: Nepal finds difficulty bringing back nationals in Russian army
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Nepal's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs Narayan Kaji Shrestha on 13 March said complications remain in bringing back the Nepali citizens who are serving in the Russian army, The Kathmandu Post newspaper reported on its website.
body:
Shrestha on 12 March held talks with the families and relatives of some of the Nepalis who have joined the Russian army and he also met with the Russian ambassador to Nepal, Aleksei Novikov, the report noted.

As per the report, he urged the Russian ambassador to provide details of the Nepali nationals serving in the Russian army, to stop recruitment of the Nepalis and provide compensation to the families of those who have died in the Ukraine war.

Shrestha also reportedly said that he wanted to visit Russia and take stock of the condition of the Nepali nationals in Russia and told the Russian ambassador that if Moscow does not listen and act on Nepal’s requests, the government would seek support from other countries, the report added.

Source: The Kathmandu Post website, Kathmandu, in English 1507 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Chad opposition calls for postponement of 6 May polls
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Chad's opposition "We the People" coalition has called on the transitional government to postpone the 6 May presidential elections to allow "another truly inclusive dialogue", French public radio RFI reported on 17 March.

title: Ethiopia's Fano militia accused of killing 35 civilians
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Fano militia group in Ethiopia’s Amhara Region has been accused of killing 35 ethnic Agew people in a series of attacks, privately owned Ethiopian Satellite Television (ESAT TV) reported on 12 March.
body:
"The [Ayu Guagusa] district administrator [Gebeyehu Berihun] said Ambela Constituency was razed down by so-called Fano forces while several people were killed and displaced and property was looted," said the TV.

"This force was carried out the attacks in an organised manner. Lives were lost, houses were torched and property looted by the extremist force. More than 25,000 people have been displaced from the two districts," said Gebeyehu.

"According to the information we received from residents, 35 people were killed and 14 others injured in Ambela Constituency of Ayu Guagusa District by 1 Megabit 2016 [10 March], while the whereabouts of more than 64 labourers remains unknown," the TV added.

Both Fano and the army are accused of atrocities against civilians as fighting continues in the region for nearly a year.

Source: ESAT TV, Addis Ababa, in Amharic 0430 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Somalia's al-Shabab 'captures' crashed surveillance drone
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Al-Shabab fighters have seized an unmanned aerial vehicle that had crashed in a militant-controlled area of central Somalia’s Hiiraan region, pro-militant Somali Memo website reported on 28 March.
body:
The website did not name the area where the crash happened, but shared several pictures, some showing militants with al-Shabab’s flag standing over a relatively intact drone on the ground.

“A surveillance drone believed to belong to the US has crashed and was subsequently seized by fighters of the Islamic governorate of Hiiraan,” Somali Memo said.

“Photos taken from the scene show limited damage to the aircraft, with its cameras and other intelligence-gathering equipment still there,” it added.

On 17 March 2021, al-Shabab similarly claimed to have seized the remains of a US drone that had crashed in the southern Lower Jubba region.

US forces have been using drones to carry out deadly air strikes against al-Shabab across southern and central Somalia.

Source: Somali Memo website in Somali 28 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Samaa News TV show on commission to look into complaints by judges
snippet: The following is a summary of the talk show "Nadeem Malik Live" hosted by anchor Nadeem Malik, a senior journalist and analyst, on moderate Samaa News TV in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 28 March 2024. The programme invites politicians and analysts to express their opinions on important issues.
body:
Anchor Nadeem Malik said the government has announced constitution of a commission under the Commission of Inquiry Act to look into the issues raised in a letter by six judges of the Islamabad High Court. He noted the commission would be headed by a retired judge. He remarked Pakistan's history shows that the government forms a committee on matters it has "no intention to take action against" and forms a commission on matters which it wants to "bury". Noting that the present government has opted to form a commission, he said he would not question the government because it is "very weak" and is "dependent on the [military] establishment", but he would question why the Supreme Court did not take a suo moto notice and decided to hear the case in an open court.

Malik insisted the Supreme Court should take action in this matter and there is a need to set some standard operating procedures. He said Chief Justice Qazi Faez Isa has an opportunity to take action to end the interference of government and intelligence agencies in judicial matters and ensure that judges issue judgements by meeting requirements of the due process of justice.

Malik spoke with Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) politician Salman Akram Raja and asked him about the way forward. Raja remarked the way forward is very clear and the letter by the judges has identified it. He said allegations have been levelled against the executive and its subordinate officers, and it is clear that the executive cannot conduct an investigation against itself, so a judicial commission needs to be formed.

Raja was of the view that the Supreme Court should have initiated proceedings under suo moto or contempt jurisdiction. He said not just the PTI, but all political parties should play a role in taking this matter to a "logical conclusion". He urged the civil society and human rights defenders to also raise their voice against this issue.
