The interview was conducted by Russian journalist Inna Afinogenova, who used to be a star presenter for the Latin America-oriented broadcasts of Russian state-owned media network RT, before resigning from her position there in early 2022.

Source: Animal Politico website (www.animalpolitico.com) , Mexico City, in Spanish 2121 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Death toll from Indonesia floods, landslides rises to 30
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Indonesian authorities have said that the death toll from flash flooding and landslides on the Indonesian island of Sumatra has risen to 30, Antara news agency reported.
body:
Heavy rains on 7 March triggered the disaster in West Sumatra province, where rivers overflowed and landslides swallowed homes.

"These disasters are quite massive because they caused 27 fatalities in South Pesisir District and three fatalities in Padang Pariaman District," Head of the National Disaster Mitigation Agency (BNPB) Suharyanto said on 11 March. 

He also added that rescue efforts for those missing have been intensified.

Source: Antara news agency, Jakarta, in English 0400 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says Russian missile attack kills three, injures 36 civilians
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Three Ukrainians have been killed and at least 36, including seven children, were wounded as a result of a Russian missile attack on Kryvyy Rih on the evening of 12 March, Dnipropetrovsk regional governor Serhiy Lysak said on Telegram.
body:
Two multi-storey buildings in Kryvyy Rih were damaged and caught fire as a result of the attack, Lysak said in another Telegram post earlier on the day.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1819 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Ethiopian police seize 249 illegal weapons in Amhara Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Police in the restive north-western Ethiopia’s Amhara Region have seized 249 illegal weapons, pro-government Fana Broadcasting Corporate reported on 16 March.

title: Iran leader warns against establishment infighting
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has called on factions within Iran to avoid turning their differences into hostile disputes.

title: North Korea sends delegation to China
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A North Korean delegation, led by Kim Song-nam, director of the international department at the Workers' Party, arrived in Beijing on 21 March on a three-nation tour that also includes Laos and Vietnam, Pyongyang's state media reported on 22 March.
body:
"A delegation of the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK), headed by Kim Song Nam, alternate member of the Political Bureau and director of the International Department of the WPK Central Committee, arrived in Beijing on March 21 to visit China," the official Korean Central News Agency reported.

"The delegation was greeted by the assistant to head of the International Liaison Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the DPRK ambassador to China at the airport," it added.

DPRK refers to North Korea's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. 

North Korea and China are marking the 75th anniversary of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0609 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab claims killing 23 soldiers in Somalia military base attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The al-Shabab militant group has claimed to have killed 23 Somali soldiers and wounded dozens of others during an attack on a military base in the southern Middle Shabelle region.

title: North Korean leader's sister against contact with Japan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korean leader’s sister has said the country will “disregard” and “refuse” all contact with Japan, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
The statement by Kim Yo-jong on 26 March came a day after she said Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida had expressed his willingness to hold a summit with Kim Jong-un.

"Japan has no courage at all to take the first step toward a new North Korea-Japan relationship while changing history and promoting regional peace and stability," Kim Yo-jong said.

"Our government has clearly determined Japan's attitude once again and in conclusion, will disregard and refuse any contact or negotiation with the Japanese side," she added.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0900 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Kazakhstan, UK ink strategic partnership deal on rare earths
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kazakhstan and Britain have signed a roadmap for strategic partnership in the field of critical minerals, the Moscow-based news website Fergana.agency reported on 13 March.
body:
The signing ceremony took place in London on 11 March as part of a Kazakh delegation's working visit to the UK. The purpose of the visit is to participate in a business forum called "Mineral Processing and Circular Economy".  

"As part of the event, Kazakhstan and the UK signed a roadmap for strategic partnership in critical minerals. The signed roadmap opens a new chapter in Kazakhstan-UK relations in the field of sustainable minerals," the report said, citing the Kazakh government.

It added that Kazakh Deputy Industry and Construction Minister Iran Sharkhan met British Minister of State for Industry and Economic Security Nusrat Ghani. At the meeting, Sharkhan told her that his country's basic principle was ""raw materials in exchange for technology and entry into the global value chain", it said.

For her part, Ghani praised the efforts made to build long-term partnership between the UK and Kazakhstan, saying that "the roadmap is an important milestone in taking the current cooperation on critical raw materials between London and Astana to a practical level", it noted.

According to the report, Kazakh and British businessmen also held meetings to discuss the development of cooperation on critical minerals and specific projects.

The UK is one of Kazakhstan's main trading partners and the seventh largest investor in its economy.

Kazakhstan is rich in rare metals and rare earths. Eight of the 18 most important rare earth elements identified by the British Geological Survey are mined in Kazakhstan. Kazakhstan also has large reserves of 15 rare metal deposits. 

In 2020, the Kazakh Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources said Kazakhstan had "500,000 tonnes of rare earth elements".

Source: Fergana news agency website in Russian 1600 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Turkish-trained Somali soldiers graduate in Mogadishu
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud on 8 March presided over the passing out parade of units of the Turkish-trained Gorgor forces in Mogadishu, the state-owned Somali National TV (SNTV) has reported.

title: Togo extends state of emergency in northern region ahead of elections
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Togo’s parliament voted unanimously on 12 March to extend the state of emergency covering the country’s northern Savanes Region for another year, government website republicoftogo.com has reported.
body:
“As we prepare for the legislative and regional elections, the situation remains worrying in view of new attempts, particularly in the sub-region", territorial administration minister, Hodabalo Awaté told MPs.

“The government will make good use of this legal instrument to strengthen and guarantee a healthy and favourable security climate throughout the country so that a peaceful and secure election can be held for all,” he added.

Local elections are scheduled to take place in April.

Since late 2021 when the first attack by al-Qaeda linked militants was reported, Savanes Regions has suffered from several deadly raids by “terrorist groups” based in Burkina Faso, where authorities are grappling with a militant insurgency affecting much of the country.

Source: republicoftogo.com website, Lome, in French 12 Mar 24

title: Highlights from India's Malayalam-language press, websites 22 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items published in India's Malayalam-language press and online media outlets on 22 March 2024.

This BBCM product could not be published due to operational reasons. The next edition of this product will be published on 25 March 2024.
body: Source: BBC Monitoring in Malayalam 22 Mar 24

title: Iran cleric praises election turnout despite 'enemy's propaganda'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An interim Friday prayers leader in Tehran has praised people for taking part in the parliamentary and Assembly of Experts (leadership watchdog) elections on 1 March and said that "the participation of 41%" of the people in the elections was "a strong slap in the enemies' face".
body:
In his sermons, hardline cleric, Ayatollah Ahmad Khatami, said that the "participation of 41% of the people in the elections was acceptable" despite "the propaganda bombardment" carried out by foreign media that had tried to discourage the people from casting votes.

The sermons were broadcast live by Radio Tehran on 8 March.

Khatami added that the "enemies" also "insinuated that the participation would be 10 to 25% maximum" but "the people gave a strong slap in the face of the enemies" with their 41%participation.

Khatami said that "the elections were completely competitive" and in all constituencies, "people of various [political] orientations" participated in the election.

The cleric thanked God that "the elections were held in a safe environment" and "with no problems".

"Although violations have been reported but the Guardian Council [election watchdog] will deal with these violations fairly and decisively," Khatami added.

He said that "the true winner of the elections were the people" while "the real losers of the elections were in fact the enemies of the Iranian nation".

Khatami added that the people had shown their loyalty to the establishment by taking part in the elections and their message to authorities was that they should monitor prices and stop rise in the prices of goods. 

Source: Voice of the Islamic Republic of Iran - local radio service, Tehran, in Persian 0853 GMT 8 Mar 24

title: Pakistan foreign minister stresses need to prioritise economic-diplomacy
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's Foreign Minister Ishaq Dar on 20 March stressed that Pakistan needed to prioritise economic-diplomacy in the current circumstances, in addition to conventional diplomacy, The Express Tribune reported.
body:
He said all missions of Pakistan abroad should focus on attracting investments, while interacting with officers of Pakistan High Commission in London, the report said citing a press release.

He added that Pakistan was blessed with significant natural as well as high quality human resources, the report said.

The country had all the potential to become a great economy provided a coherent approach was adopted to bring fiscal discipline and curtail external deficit, he added.

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0000 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Hungary's Orban congratulates Putin on re-election - Russian report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban has congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin on his re-election, Russian state news agency TASS reported on 21 March, quoting Orban's press secretary Bertalan Havasi.
body:
According to Havasi, after the official announcement of the results of the Russian presidential election on 21 March, Orban sent a congratulatory letter to Putin.

In the letter, the Hungarian leader "noted that he is pleased that cooperation between Hungary and Russia is based on mutual respect and this allows discussing important issues even in the current very difficult geopolitical situation", the press secretary said.

Orban also said in his letter that "Hungary is on the side of peace" and that "maintaining dialogue is a necessary condition for the establishment of peace as soon as possible".

"The prime minister assured the Russian president that Hungary is ready to expand cooperation between our countries in the areas not limited by international law," Havasi added.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1608 gmt 21 Mar 24

title: Ethiopia reports 63 deaths from measles in nine months
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Ethiopian Public Health Institute has said 63 people have died of measles nationwide in the past nine months, privately-owned Ethiopian Satellite TV (ESAT TV) reported on 18 March.
body:
The institute said cases of the highly contagious disease have been reported in 91 districts across 10 regions, mainly affecting Oromia, Amhara - where there have been insurgencies for the past year - and central Ethiopian regions.

According to ESAT, the institute also said that in the last three years, 57,000 people had contracted the disease and 460 of them lost their lives.

Deadly cholera and malaria outbreaks have been also reported in Ethiopia towards the end of 2023.

The health crises are exacerbated by conflicts between government forces and armed groups despite the end of a two-year civil war in the northern Tigray region in November 2022.

Hospitals and medical centres have been severely affected, with extensive damage to facilities in Tigray and shortages of supplies or arbitrary closures in Amhara and Oromia.

Source: ESAT TV, Addis Ababa, in Amharic, 18 Mar 24

title: Ukraine president meets top brass to discuss Russian strikes
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Volodymyr Zelensky has held a meeting of the supreme commander-in-chief's headquarters to discuss the consequences of Russia's strikes on Ukraine's energy infrastructure on the morning of 21-22 March.
body:
"The headquarters meeting. The only topic today is energy. All reports are devoted to eliminating the consequences of the Russian criminal shelling. Kharkiv and the region, Zaporizhzhya, Dnipro, Khmelnytskyy and the region, Kryvyy Rih, Sumy Region, Poltava Region, Odesa and the region, Vinnytsya and the region, Ivano-Frankivsk Region and all the affected cities and communities," he said on Telegram.

The president also heard reports on the restoration works, particularly on restoring power, water and heat supplies to homes, providing people with temporary housing and other assistance.

According to Zelensky, several classified decisions were made at the HQ meeting.

"But only the decision of our partners to provide a sufficient number of modern air defence systems can truly protect Ukraine. We work every day in this regard," he concluded.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1545 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Russian governor says Ukrainian drone killed man in Belgorod
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The governor of Russia's Belgorod Region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, has said that one person has been killed and two others have been injured after a fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) hit a block of flats in the city of Belgorod .
body:
In a post on Telegram on 29 March, Gladkov claimed that the attack had been carried out by the Ukrainian Armed Forces.

He said that one man had been killed in the UAV explosion, while the man's wife received a closed head injury, lacerations to her face and a superficial burn to the thigh.

Another man who received a shrapnel wound went to a hospital on his own, Gladkov said.

According to preliminary reports, the explosion damaged windows and balcony glazing in five flats as well as a car parked nearby, he added.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1255 gmt 29 Mar 24

title: Iran official says AI used in cruise missile delivered to navy
snippet: By BBC Monitoring
body:
Iran's deputy defence minister has provided further information on the Abu Mahdi cruise missiles delivered to the Navy last year.

In a phone call with Fars News Agency on 23 March, Afshin Naderi Sharif said that the missile uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) to counter electronic warfare through adjusting its trajectory. It also aids in recognising the topographic structures of terrains and distinguishing between the right and wrong targets.

Naderi Sharif, who serves as the deputy defence minister for research and technology, revealed more details about the Abu Mahdi missile.

He described the 1,000-km range of the missile as its most important feature, enabling the Iranian military to confront "enemies" from deep inside the country and forcing the "enemy" to stand more than 1,000 km away from Iran's borders.

He added that the missile was capable of flying at low altitudes and therefore evade radar detection.

The missile's manoeuvrability, enabling it to strike targets from multiple directions, was its other main characteristic, Naderi Sharif noted.

The deputy defence minister underscored the "new" explosive used in the warhead of the missile which gave it greater destructive forces.

He said hybrid "seekers" (sensors), comprising of active and passive devices, have been mounted on the missile which enabled it to detect and hit the target with small cross-sections. The missile seeker is a component inside a missile that generates data to be fed into the missile computer.

"Active" seekers emit signals and gather data after these signals are reflected off the targets; "passive" seekers just detect the energy emitted by the target in the form of light or heat.

Iran unveiled the Abu Mahdi missile in 2020, named after Iraqi militia commander Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis killed in a US air strike alongside top Iranian commander Lt Gen Qasem Soleimani earlier the same year.

Source: Fars News Agency website, Tehran, in Persian 0233 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Mauritania arrests transport sector workers over migrant smuggling accusations
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Mauritanian security forces have arrested a number of workers in the transport sector accused of facilitating the transfer of irregular migrants, domestic media reported on 24 March.
body:
The arrests were made between the southern-most province of Guidimaka - which borders Senegal and Mali - and the capital Nouakchott, the privately owned Al-Akhbar news website reported on 24 March.

Those arrested have been transferred to the relevant authorities for investigation, the short report said.

The latest development follows a surge in migration heading north to Europe from West Africa and Sudan as a result of civil unrest and economic woes, with attempts by various North African countries to rein in the situation.

Last month, Senegalese authorities recovered 24 bodies off the country's northern coastline after a boat carrying them to Europe sank, Mauritania's privately owned Sahara Media news website reported at the time.

See: Mauritania says it will not be hub for migrant transit 

Briefing: Mauritania hosts Spanish PM, EU commissioner for migration talks

Source: Al-Akhbar website in Arabic 1721 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab claims seizing 'strategic' town in central Somalia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The al-Shabab group has claimed that it seized the town of Hinlibi near the port city of Hobyo in Somalia's central Mudug region following clashes with government forces, the militants’ mouthpiece Radio Andalus reported in its 10:30 GMT bulletin on 14 March.
body:
“After the mujahideen seized the town, they were warmly welcomed by the residents. The apostate militias in Hinlibi were defeated and fled the town shortly after the fighting broke out,” the radio said.

Radio Andalus added that militants inflicted casualties on the troops and would issue further details in subsequent broadcasts.

Hinlibi is the latest town to be seized by al-Shabab in recent weeks in Mudug region after the group captured Amara, Ba’adweyne, Shabellow, Qey’ad and A’ad towns and villages.

On 13 March, the Somali government said it was assessing the war against al-Shabab but did not say whether this was linked to the recent military setbacks in Mudug region.

Source: Radio Andalus in Somali 1030 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Senegal frees prominent opposition leader ahead of poll
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Prominent Senegalese opposition leader Ousmane Sonko and the presidential candidate he is backing, Bassirou Diomanye Faye, have been released from prison, the website of state broadcaster RTS reported on 14 March.
body:
They were freed on 14 March, 10 days ahead of the presidential election and after President Macky Sall signed an amnesty law passed by the National Assembly.

“The law erases all offences that could be considered criminal or correctional between 1 February 2021 and 25 February 2024, both in Senegal and abroad, related to demonstrations or with political motivations,” the report said.

Faye, the official candidate of the banned African Patriots of Senegal for Work, Ethics and Fraternity (Pastef) party in the 24 March presidential election, was imprisoned in April 2023 after he was convicted of criticising judges on social media.

Sonko, the popular mayor of Ziguinchor in southern Senegal, was detained on 28 July 2023 and later convicted of incitement to insurrection, conspiracy against the state and corrupting the youth.

Source: RTS1 TV, Dakar, in French 14 Mar 24

title: Russia charges Ukrainian former commanders over attacks
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Investigations Committee (IC) has brought criminal charges in absentia against the former commander of the Ukrainian naval forces, and two former commanders of the operational command Vostok [East] and Zapad [West], respectively, TASS news agency reported on 7 March.
body:
Ihor Voronchenko, former commander of the Ukrainian naval forces from July 2016 to June 2020, Oleksandr Nesterenko, former commander of the operational command Vostok from July to December 2019, and Ihor Dovgan, former commander of the operational command West from March 2015 to March 2017, are among those facing IC criminal charges, the report said.

"As a result of their criminal actions, during these periods, numerous attacks were carried out in populated areas of the Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics, resulting in the injury and death of 334 people, including 12 children, as well as massive destruction of civilian infrastructure. Measures are being taken to search for and arrest the accused," the Committee said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0740 gmt 7 Mar 24

title: Uzbekistan beefs up security at malls, public spaces
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Law-enforcement agencies in Uzbekistan have stepped up security at malls, shopping centres and public spaces across the capital, Tashkent, privately-owned news website Gazeta.uz reported on 29 March.
body:
This came after the recent gunmen attack on a concert hall in Russia's Moscow Region, which left nearly 140 people dead, the report said. 

"Officers of the National Guard, the Tashkent city police department and other law enforcement agencies have been put on a heightened state of alert at shopping centres, parks, markets and other public places," it said.

"Photos that have been published show officers of the mobile task force armed with assault rifles standing next to special vehicles and police officers with metal detectors checking visitors' bags before they enter a park," it added.b

The press service of the National Guard said in a statement that officers of the agency were also ensuring security at all mosques during prayers in the holy month of Ramadan.

For its part, the Ministry of Internal Affairs described in a statement as "painful memories for our people" a series of bombings that took place in Tashkent on 16 February 1999, an attempted militant incursion in southern Sariosiyo District in August 2000 and the deadly unrest in eastern Andijan Region in May 2005. 

"Similar situations have happened in other developed countries of the world many times. Some of them are still in a state of war. As a result, many innocent people are dying. The presence of small children among them is deeply saddening humanity," the police said.

For this reason, it called on the people living in the country to "unite and raise awareness in order to protect yourselves from such bloodshed and terrible events, for the sake of peace in our country, city and neighbourhood".

"To do this, it is important to pay attention to people who look suspicious in public and immediately report them to the law enforcement agencies. You should also report immediately any item left unattended by dialling 102," the police said.

Source: Gazeta.uz website, Tashkent, in Russian 1041 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Two workers trapped in mine collapse in Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two miners are caught under rubble in the Kalyinskaya mine in Russia's Sverdlovsk Region, the press service for the mine has said.
body:
"A bump occurred at the SUBR's Kalyinskaya mine. The result was a rock collapse, behind which there are two mine stope workers. The miners are sending signals," the Severouralsk Bauxite Mine (SUBR) said in a statement quoted by state news agency TASS on 25 March.

Two mountain rescue teams have arrived at the scene of the incident and rescue work is underway, the company having cleared debris before the teams' arrival, the statement said.

The Severouralsk prosecutor's office says it has "organised an inspection of compliance with safety requirements during mining operations, as well as legislation on labour protection in connection with the rock burst at the mine. Specialists from other supervisory authorities will be involved in its implementation".

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0815 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: US soldier dies at training ground in Lithuania - army
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A US soldier has died while on duty in Lithuania, the Lithuanian military said on 29 March.
body:
The accident is reported to have occurred at the General Silvestras Zukauskas training ground, Lithuanian news website ELTA reported in English.

"A pre-trial investigation has been opened into the incident. It is being conducted by US law enforcement and the Military Police of the Lithuanian Armed Forces under the lead of the Vilnius District Prosecutor’s Office," the army announced.

The leadership of the Lithuanian Armed Forces extended its deepest condolences to the US soldier’s family and brothers in arms.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 1324 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Russia rejects Western help in Moscow concert hall attack probe
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has said Western help in investigating the Moscow concert hall shooting is neither needed nor wanted, accusing the West of wanting to solely blame the Islamic State group and absolve Ukraine of all blame.
body:
"On the one hand, I'm convinced that we will cope with this investigation," the state news agency TASS quoted Lavrov as telling a news conference on 26 March.

"On the other, we definitely don't need the kind of help that will clearly manifest double standards, and more likely than not, will be aimed at pushing the theory, which is beneficial to the West, that this was done by the Islamic State, and that Ukraine has nothing to do with it," he continued. "I'll say again: We'll cope ourselves."

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0811 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: Kremlin says sending Western troops to Ukraine risks 'irreparable consequences'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov says deployment of Western troops to Ukraine would have "irreparable consequences".
body:
"Sending some foreign military contingents is fraught with very negative, up to irreparable consequences," Peskov told the press on 21 March in remarks reported by TASS news agency.

TASS said his remarks came in response to a request to comment on Ukrainian MP Oleksiy Honcharenko's statement that France was considering sending troops to be deployed on Ukraine's border with Belarus.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1016 gmt 21 Mar 24

title: Pakistan vows swift probe into attack against Chinese workers
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan announced a swift probe into the attack that killed five Chinese nationals in the north-west Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Dawn newspaper reported on its website on 27 March.

title: Envoys of India, China discuss ties with new Nepalese foreign minister
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Envoys of India and China have called on separately Nepal's Narayan Kaji Shrestha, the newly appointed deputy prime minister and minister for foreign affairs, The Kathmandu Post reported on its website on 7 March.
body:
Shrestha, who served as the home minister until 3 March, took the job of foreign minister on 6 March.

Indian envoy Naveen Srivastava discussed strengthening Nepal-India ties and advancing mutually beneficial bilateral cooperation.

Chinese Ambassador to Nepal Chen Song also congratulated Shrestha on his new role and discussed bilateral issues.

Source: The Kathmandu Post website, Kathmandu, in English 0000 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Burkina Faso 'admits' to detaining lawyer
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Burkina Faso authorities have admitted to detaining lawyer and former founder of the political movement Le Balai Citoyen, Guy-Herve Kam, for undermining state security, French public broadcaster RFI reported on 5 March.
body:
"His family and friends had to wait a month and a half after his arrest for news that lawyer Guy-Herve Kam, who was abducted by plainclothes men on 24 January, had indeed been arrested by security agents.," the report said. 

Le Balai Citoyen called for his "immediate" release.

RFI added that an official legal agent gave the information to Kam’s lawyers during a hearing before the administrative court of Ouagadougou on 5 March.

Neither of the two major courts was aware of any trials on such charges.

Human rights groups have accused the military junta of targeting critics, including journalists, trade unionists, civil society actors and politicians, for forced enlistment and requisition in the security forces.

See Briefing: Burkina Faso groups condemn 'forcible conscription' of junta critics

Source: Radio France Internationale website, Paris, in French 5 Mar 24

title: Iran deputy judiciary chief resigns after reported arrest of children
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

First deputy head of Iran's judiciary, Hojjat ol-Eslam Mohammad Mosaddeq, has resigned from his post months after it was reported that two of his sons were arrested on corruption charges.
body:
The judiciary-run Mizan News Agency reported Mossadeq's resignation on 13 March, saying that it was done to "eliminate the suspicion of any influence" by the high-ranking official on his children's case.

"Your presence in this position does not and will not affect the handling of the mentioned case, but according to your request and the points you raised, your resignation will be accepted," Mizan quoted Judiciary Chief Gholamhossein Mohseni Ejei as responding to the resignation request.

The report cited Mosaddeq as saying that he had no contact with any of the people involved in the case, stressing that his resignation aimed at preventing the "opponents and ill-wishers" from exploiting the situation.

Nour News Agency, the media-affiliate of Iran's Supreme National Security Council (SNSC), reported on the same day that Mossadeq's sons were being tried along with 23 other suspects on charges of "forming a network of influence and money laundering" to handle "major cases" of economic crimes in the judiciary.

Source: Mizan news agency, Tehran, in Persian 0905 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: India's Assam state extends controversial security law in four districts
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Authorities in the north-eastern Indian state of Assam have extended a controversial security law in four districts, The Hindu newspaper reported on its website on 29 March citing the PTI news agency.
body:
The government extended the Armed Forces (Special Powers) Act (AFSPA) in Tinsukia, Dibrugarh, Charaideo and Sivasagar districts for six months from 1 April.

The law gives sweeping powers to security forces to conduct operations and arrest anyone without a warrant. 

Police said the law and order situation in the state had improved but one militant organisation was active in the four districts.

“The state government’s home and political department submitted a proposal to this effect to the Union [federal] Ministry of Home Affairs, which, after due consideration, decided to maintain the ‘status quo’ regarding ‘disturbed area’ for an additional six-month period,” an official said.

Source: The Hindu website, Chennai, in English 0942 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: North Korean leader visits headquarters of 'Seoul' tank unit
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has visited the headquarters of a tank unit, which had entered into Seoul during the Korean War, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA)reported.
body:
Kim visited the Seoul Ryu Kyong Su Guards 105th Tank Division and the affiliated First Tank Armoured Infantry Regiment on 24 March, KCNA reported a day later. 

"The division... was the first to charge into Seoul and fly the flag of the DPRK on the puppet capitol building and performed distinguished feats in many battles during the past Fatherland Liberation War, thus adding the title of guards and Seoul to its brilliant name," KCNA said. DPRK refers to Democratic People's Republic of Korea, North Korea's official name.

Kim also said the unit "should hold high the banner as befitting a model of the entire army in the ongoing struggle witnessing the intensive training for finishing war preparations".

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0300 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Russia election head says 'unprecedented number' of DDOS attacks on e-vote
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of Russia's Central Electoral Commission, Ella Pamfilova, has said the new system of distant electronic voting (DEV) has suffered an unprecedented wave of DDoS attacks during the presidential election, TASS news agency has reported.
body:
"This year, we allowed DEV in only 29 regions...[ellipses in original]; we were sure that we could ensure security only for that number, and its good that we did not overdo it. Because the level of DDoS attacks which are going on now against DEV is unprecedented," she said at a news briefing on 17 March.

These DDoS attacks were coordinated by the whole West, she said. "They are beating us like hell, but we will endure it," she said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1505 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Cabinet approves members of Somalia's first media council
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Somalia's cabinet has approved the constitution of a new media council that was formed by the information ministry to regulate the practice of journalism in the country, state-owned Radio Mogadishu website has reported.
body:
The Somali National Media Council is the first media regulator to be formed by the government and will oversee the activities of journalists and news outlets in the country. 

Prime Minister Hamsa Abdi Barre chaired the 14 March cabinet meeting that approved the list of nine that included two veteran ex-BBC journalists.

“The names of members of the council have been proposed to the cabinet by the ministry of information, culture and tourism,” the website said.

Privately-owned Hiiraan Online said the establishment of the National Media Council marks a significant milestone in Somalia’s commitment to media freedom and promoting a pluralistic media environment.

Source: Radio Mogadishu website, Mogadishu, in Somali 14 Mar 24

title: Huge blast, mass shooting reported at Moscow concert hall
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

There are reports of a large explosion and a major shooting attack at Moscow's Krokus (Crocus) City Hall, a major concert hall in the capital.
body:
Various Russian Telegram news channels have published footage of at least one person having been shot, as well as sounds of shooting and scenes of panic.

Popular pro-Kremlin channel Readovka reported that at least 12 people might have died in the attack, and 50 more were injured.

State RIA Novosti news agency reported that at least three attackers wearing camouflage opened fire at the venue.

One video published by popular breaking news Telegram channel Baza showed flames and a huge plume of smoke rising from what was said to be the concert venue.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1700 gmt 22 Mar 24

title: BBCM Ukraine Watchlist 18 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Ukrainian broadcast, press and social media sources

ONE PLUS ONE TV
body:
DAY 1,272 OF RUSSIAN INVASION OF UKRAINE

Zelensky arrives in Washington for talks with Trump

President Volodymyr Zelensky has arrived in Washington where he is scheduled to meet Donald Trump and a number of European leaders later in the day.

"I am grateful to @POTUS for the invitation. We all share a strong desire to end this war quickly and reliably. And peace must be lasting. Not like it was years ago, when Ukraine was forced to give up Crimea and part of our East - part of Donbas - and Putin simply used it as a springboard for a new attack," Zelensky said on X in English.

Zelensky noted the Ukrainian army's "successes" in Sumy and Donetsk regions.

"I am confident that we will defend Ukraine, effectively guarantee security, and that our people will always be grateful to President Trump, everyone in America, and every partner and ally for their support and invaluable assistance. Russia must end this war, which it itself started. And I hope that our joint strength with America, with our European friends, will force Russia into a real peace," he said.

On 17 August, Zelensky Zelensky took part in a meeting of the so-called coalition of the willing ahead of his talks with Trump and said that Ukraine-Russia talks to end the war should take into account the current line of contact while any territorial issues can be discussed only with Russian leader Vladimir Putin at a trilateral meeting involving the US.

Concern in Ukraine ahead of talks with Trump

A number of media outlets, including the ZN.ua website, republished a Bild article according to which Zelensky will first meet Trump one-on-one and only later they will be joined by European leaders - UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, Finnish President Alexander Stubb, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and Nato Secretary-General Mark Rutte.

"One cannot rule out an escalation in the White House," ZN.ua warned, referring to the Zelensky-Trump row in February of this year.

"It seems that the Ukrainian president will have to make some concessions under pressure from circumstances," the TSN.ua website said in an article headlined "A new scandal or step to ending the war: what one should expect from the Trump-Zelensky meeting".

The website noted that a year ago Zelensky said that Ukraine "will never agree to any option of frozen conflict", while yesterday the Ukrainian leader said that "real negotiations" can start "where the current line of contact is".

TSN.ua also noted that Zelensky will be accompanied by "a powerful support group" of the European leaders.

Ukrainians welcome participation of Europeans in Washington talks

The Glavred website described the participation of European leaders in the talks as "a European landing operation in Washington".

"European leaders are concerned that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky may not get from the US leader the same friendly treatment as Vladimir Putin did. Therefore, the EU decided to bolster Kyiv's chances at the meeting," the Telegraf website commented.

"European leaders are going to strengthen Volodymyr Zelensky's delegation in the USA," the Censor.net website said on Facebook.

Former MP Boryslav Bereza hailed the fact that Zelensky will be supported by "adults" at the talks. However, he warned that Zelensky should not take to the White House his chief of staff Andriy Yermak.

"Yermak must not attend this meeting. He is disrespected in the White House and irritates US politicians with his primitivism," Bereza said on Facebook.

Pundit and army serviceman Kyrylo Sazonov predicted that the talks with Trump would be "very difficult".

"This meeting is more important than the Trump-Putin talks. Good luck, Mr president. You definitely need it now," he said on Facebook.

Ukraine's long-range cruise missile

A photo of Ukraine's long-range cruise missiles posted on Facebook by AP photo correspondent Efrem Lukatsky (Yefrem Lukatskyy) has gone viral on social networks and made the headlines in mainstream media.

"Ukrainian-made over 3,000 km range Flamingo missiles, which were launched into serial production, are seen in a workshop of one of the country's leading Fire Point defence company in an undisclosed location in Ukraine on Thursday, 14 August, 2025," Lukatsky said in English.

The specialist Defense Express website said that the Flamingo is an "FP-5 missile made by Milanion Group".

"Its operational range and warhead are twice as powerful as those of the Tomahawk and, most importantly, it is meant for serial production," Defence Express commented.

It noted that the warhead weighs about 1 tonne.

Overnight attacks

At least four civilians were killed and 18 injured as a result of Russian ballistic missile and drone strikes on Kharkiv, regional governor Oleh Synyehubov reported on Telegram.

According to the governor, four Russian strike drones hit a five-storey block of flats.

"A total of six blocks of flats and 15 cars were damaged," he added.

The pooled TV service indicated that the number of casualties may increase given that "a lot of people are still under the rubble".

The TV also reported a ballistic missile strike on Sumy Region. No casualties were reported.

War update

There were 182 combat engagements between Ukrainian and Russian troops on 17 August, the Ukrainian General Staff reported on Facebook the following morning.

The Pokrovsk sector was the hottest spot on the front line in Ukraine, with 58 Russian attacks reported there.

Twenty-eight clashes were reported in the Novopavlivka sector, 21 in the Lyman sector, 13 in the Southern Slobozhanshchyna sector (covers parts of Kharkiv Region), 12 in the Kupyansk sector, nine in the Toretsk sector, five in the Siversk sector, five in the Kramatorsk sector, four in the Northern Slobozhanshchyna sector (covers parts of Sumy Region) and the Kursk sector, four in Kherson Region and one in the Orikhiv sector.

Russia carried out four missile and 80 air strikes using four missiles and 152 glide bombs, and shelled Ukraine 5,173 times, including 73 times with MRLS. Russian forces also used over 5,100 kamikaze drones.

Ukrainian aviation, rocket and artillery troops hit eight Russian clusters of personnel and materiel, two artillery pieces, a fuel-and-lubricant depot, a command post and a radar, the General Staff added.

The Russian army has advanced near the population centres of Hryhorivka and Voskresenka (Donetsk Region) and Temyrivka (Zaporizhzhya Region), the DeepState OSINT project said on Telegram on 17 August.

Coming up

Prime Minister Yuliya Svyrydenko is going to present the government's action plan.

She said on Telegram that the programme consists of "specific steps and goals", while the priorities include strengthening the army, arms production, a stable economic policy and energy security.

"Everything we do is aimed at supporting Ukrainians," Svyrydenko said.

title: N Korea leader 'guides' live-fire drills 'in striking range' of Seoul
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korean leader Kim Jong-un  has guided artillery firing drills involving front-line units capable of striking the "enemy's capital", Pyongyang's state-controlled media reported on 8 March.
body:
"The drill started with the power demonstration firing of the long-range artillery sub-units near the border who have put the enemy's capital in their striking range and fulfilled important military missions for war deterrence," the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.

"The artillery sub-units selected from the large combined units were to take the firing positions according to the order of firing set by lot and fire at the targets and then to be ranked by summing up the number of hits and the time taken for fulfilling their firepower missions," it added.

Kim expressed "great satisfaction" that all the artillery sub-units involved in the drill are "fully ready for constant mobilisation for battle".

Kim had earlier called for intensifying "practical actual war drills" during a visit to a military training base where he inspected training facilities and guided the actual manoeuvres of military units. The artillery firing drills also come as South Korean fighter jets conducted a live-fire exercise on 7 March to boost readiness against North Korean cruise missile and artillery threats.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0345 GMT 8 Mar 24

title: Iran leader says Gaza war 'most tragic' event of past year in Nowruz message
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has called the Gaza war the "most tragic" development of the past Iranian solar calendar year, in an address to the nation to congratulate with Nowruz, the Iranian New Year.
body:
Khamenei made his remarks in his pre-recorded address aired by the state-run IRINN rolling news channel, as well as other channels, in the morning of 20 March, moments after the arrival of Nowruz which is marked at the exact moment of the vernal equinox.

Among other "bitter events of the year", Khamenei listed the Kerman terrorist attack in January, which claimed the lives of at least 96, the recent foods in south-eastern Sistan-Baluchestan Province, and the death of security officers "in the past months". 

Khamenei mentioned the "epic turnout" of people in the state-organised rallies, and holding of "safe and healthy" elections among positive developments of the past year.

Iran held the parliamentary and the Assembly of Experts on 1 March, marked with the record low 41% turnout. Nonetheless, Khamenei had thanked people for their "jihadi" presence in the elections.

Khamenei also lauded the government of incumbent hardline President Ebrahim Raisi for its political and economic moves at the international arena, as well as infrastructural projects and "good performance" in boosting production and curbing inflation, but added that the work "should continue".

Source: Islamic Republic of Iran News Network (IRINN), Tehran, in Persian 0307 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Iran cleric blames US, Israel for IS-claimed Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An interim Friday prayers leader in Tehran has claimed that the US and Israel were behind a deadly attack in Moscow, which killed at least 133 people and wounded over 140 in a concert venue on 22 March.
body:
The Islamic State group (IS) has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Ayatollah Ahmad Khatami claimed in his Friday sermons that the Jihadist group was "an American and Israeli" creation to counter the clerical establishment in Iran. To support his claim, Khatami asked "why the IS is not carrying out attacks in Israel".

His sermons were broadcast live by Radio Tehran on 29 March.

Khatami also touched up on the Israel-Gaza war in his sermons, praising the Axis of Resistance, the coalition of Iran and its allies in the region that includes Palestinian militant groups, for "bringing the Zionist regime to its knees".

The hardline cleric also called on the crowd to attend the pro-Palestinian Quds Day rallies, adding that their participation will "give strength" to "men and women who are surviving" under Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.

Quds Day rallies are an annual tradition taking place on the last Friday of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. The event falls on 5 April this year.

Source: Voice of the Islamic Republic of Iran, Tehran, in Persian 0847 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Yemen website reports infighting between separatist forces in Aden
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A prominent Yemeni news website has reported infighting between forces loyal to the UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC) in the interim capital Aden in the early hours of 19 March, which is controlled by the separatist body.
body:
Al-Masdar Online cited local sources as saying that the forces had used medium and light weapons in the clashes, which broke out between two STC factions in the Dar Saad district in northern Aden following a "series of disputes", the details of which were not yet known.

The fighting "caused a state of panic" amongst local residents, the report said, adding that it had spread to some residential areas but that no casualties were reported at the time of writing.

The website said that the security authorities in Aden had not yet issued a statement about the clashes.

It added that infighting between STC factions had erupted on 16 March, causing casualties.

The STC has been in control of Aden since capturing the city during deadly clashes with government forces in August 2019.

Source: Al-Masdar Online website in Arabic 19 Mar 24

title: Death toll from Moscow concert hall attack rises to 144
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The death toll from the 22 March attack on the Crocus City Hall concert venue near Moscow has risen to 144 after another person shot during the attack died in hospital, Russian state news agency TASS reported on 29 March.
body:
TASS quoted Russian Health Minister Mikhail Murashko as saying that a male patient who had received "severe gunshot wounds" during the attack had died.

"The doctors fought for his life and did everything possible. I would like to express my condolences to the family and loved ones," Murashko said.

According to the minister, 69 people injured during the attack remain in hospitals. One of them is in an extremely serious condition, 16 are in a serious condition (including two children), and 33 people are in a moderate condition, Murashko said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1110 and 1111 gmt 29 Mar 24

title: Pakistan PM announces relief for rain-hit Balochistan province
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's newly-appointed Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on 6 March unveiled a relief package for people of the rain-hit areas of Balochistan province, The Express Tribune newspaper reported on its website.
body:
At least 40 people were killed in rain-related incidents in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, while hundreds lost their homes to floods in Balochistan after inclement weather took a toll on the country in the last few weeks, the report noted.

The prime minister, who took the oath of his office on 4 March, arrived in Balochistan and was accompanied by Chief Minister Sarfaraz Bugti.

Announcing a compensation package for those affected by the deluge, Sharif announced 2m rupees or around $7,100 each for the families of the deceased, 0.5m rupees or around $1,790 for the injured, and 750,000 rupees or around $270 for those whose houses were completely damaged, the report said.

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0000 GMT 6 Mar 24

title: Head of Moldova's Gagauzia meets Putin at youth festival
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Governor of Moldova's southern pro-Russian autonomy of Gagauzia, Eugenia Gutul, has met Putin at the World Youth Festival in Sochi to discuss "the complex regional and geopolitical problems whose epicentre is our Gagauzia". She used the opportunity to tell Putin about the Moldovan government's allegedly "illegal actions" towards the autonomy. Putin "promised to support Gagauzia and its people".
body:
Gutul, a close ally of fugitive pro-Russian oligarch Ilan Sor, reported the meeting on her Telegram channel and posted a photo of her shaking hands with Putin.

"On the sidelines of the World Youth Festival, the president of the Russian Federation, Vladimir Putin, discussed with me the complex regional and geopolitical problems whose epicentre is our Gagauzia. I informed Vladimir Vladimirovich about the Moldovan authorities' illegal actions and their revenge for our civil position and adherence to national interests.

Step by step, Chisinau takes away our powers, cuts out budget, violates legitimate rights, provokes instability and destabilisation of Gagauzia and the entire country.

The Russian leader promised to support Gagauzia and its people in defending their legitimate rights, powers and position on the international arena," she said in the post.

The pro-European media criticised the Moldovan delegations at the festival, which represent the pro-Russian opposition parties, for attending it and thus "showing support for the Russian war against Ukraine".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1751 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Iran president calls for Muslim's unity against 'oppression and tyranny'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's President Ebrahim Raisi has voiced optimism about the Muslim world's potential to combat "oppression and tyranny" as many followers of the faith mark the beginning of the fasting month of Ramadan, the president's official website reported on 11 March.
body:
In his Ramadan message, Raisi expressed optimism about the collective endeavours of the global Muslim community and the steadfastness of the Palestinian people, envisioning the eventual "liberation of Palestine" and the "return of Jerusalem and Al-Aqsa Mosque to the Islamic world".

The president emphasised the critical necessity for unity against "oppressors, particularly against the Zionist regime's actions" and its history of "atrocities that has spanned over seven decades". Recent events in Gaza have only reinforced the "urgent need for swift and effective action against such oppression", part of the message read. 

Raisi stressed the urgency of witnessing the resilience and dignity of Muslims, especially those in Palestinian communities, across various arenas during this significant month.

Source: president.ir website, Tehran, in Persian 1342 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Military plane crashes in northern South Sudan, crew survive
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A South Sudanese military plane crashed at an airstrip north of the country on 19 March, but five people on board the plane escaped unhurt, the Amsterdam-based Radio Tamazuj website reported.
body:
"A military cargo plane carrying mixed goods to Yida in Ruweng Administrative Area [northern South Sudan] on Tuesday morning [19 March] crashed at Yida Airstrip, the director general of Juba International [Airport] confirmed," the website said.

"The reason was that there was poor visibility in Yida and the whole of the Upper Nile area so now we altered the flight to Upper Nile today until the weather could clear,” it quoted the official, Kuol Kur, as saying.

He added that "all four crew members and one soldier who were on board survived the crash and have been taken to hospital for treatment".

Plane crashes are common in South Sudan and have been attributed to the use of old and sometimes unreliable planes by private companies and the military.

Source: Radio Tamazuj website, in English, 19 Mar 24

title: Al-Shabab blast in southern Somalia kills Burundian soldier
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The al-Shabab militant group has killed a Burundian soldier and injured another one in a series of deadly explosions against a convoy of Somali and Burundian troops in the southern town of Jowhar, pro-militant Calamada website reported on 7 March.
body:
The explosions believed to be land mines reportedly destroyed a pickup vehicle.

It is unclear where the troops were heading to before they were targeted by the explosions.

The African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (Atmis) is yet to comment on al-Shabab’s claims.

Al-Shabab usually ambushes and bombs troops travelling in south-central Somalia either to fetch water or transport logistics to nearby bases.  

Source: Calamada website in Somali 7 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's PTV show on new tax scheme, issues faced by investors
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Siyasi Ahwal" (Political Situation) hosted by anchor Shahzada Zulfiqar on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 24 March 2024. The programme invites experts and politicians to express their opinions and analysis on important news of the day.

Anchor Shahzada Zulfiqar said the government is making efforts to improve the economy of the country and for this purpose, it has proposed the Tajir Dost (trader-friendly) scheme to expand and bring small traders into the tax net. He added the government has also planned to float a Panda Bond worth $300m in the Chinese market.
body:
Zulfiqar spoke with Aminullah Kakar, deputy commissioner of inland revenue in Quetta, and asked him to explain the Tajir Dost scheme. Kakar said it is a scheme to bring small traders in the retail sector under the tax net. He noted even though traders and shopkeepers contribute to the economy of the country, they have no contribution in the taxes. He mentioned first the retailers would be registered and then tax collection would be started from 1 July.

Kakar said other sectors like agriculture and service sector are also not included in revenue collection and the government is now trying to bring them under the tax net. He noted the government has made the system easier for traders. He emphasised "tax culture" should be promoted in the country and said automation and digitisation of the tax collection system are needed.

Zulfiqar asked journalist Mehtab Haider about the objective of the tax scheme for retailers. Haider said similar schemes were introduced in the past as well and this time a new effort has been made to launch a "simple and easy" scheme. He mentioned the registration process would begin from 1 April and tax collection would be started from 1 July. He noted the number of retailers in Pakistan is around 3.5 million and the scheme is being launched in six major cities in its first phase. Talking about Pakistan's plan to float the Panda Bond, he said the government has decided to tap into the Chinese market by launching these bonds.

Zulfiqar asked Nawabzada Riaz Nosherwani, chief executive officer of the Royal Minerals Company, to comment on the new tax measures. Nosherwani said taxation is a "two-way traffic" and noted the mining business in Balochistan is the highest contributor to the revenue. He mentioned raw materials like iron ore, manganese, and chromite are exported and the government collects additional taxes on this export. He appreciated the government for finally announcing some steps to support the mining sector.

Nosherwani said the government's focus is more on foreign investment and argued that consortiums of local investors should be encouraged because foreign investors take money out of the country. He noted lengthy bureaucratic procedures and lack of continuity in policy are the major hurdles for foreign investors in Pakistan. He was of the view that Pakistan should try to look at other countries besides China for investments in the country.

Zulfiqar asked Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) politician Sakina Abdullah Khan how her party views the situation of terrorism in the country and how far the National Action Plan against terrorism approved in 2014 has been implemented. Khan said the 20 points of the National Action Plan include clauses regarding "criminal justice". She noted security agencies take action and catch militants, but the justice system is not able to punish those elements, so they are released. She insisted these "flaws in the mechanism" require changes through legislation.

Khan noted "terror groups" have been banned but they re-emerge with new names. She further noted Islamic seminaries have been registered and regulated but there is a need to bring changes in the curriculum of mainstream schools as well. She said websites of the banned groups have been blocked but freedom of expression of other people should not be curtailed in this process. She appreciated the new Chief Minister of Balochistan Sarfraz Bugti (PPP member) for having an "excellent experience" as the home minister of the province and managing it well.

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Chad clears junta chief, nine others for 6 May election
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Chad's Constitutional Council has cleared military leader Gen Mahamat Idriss Deby and nine other candidates to contest for the presidency in an election scheduled for 6 May, privately owned Alwihda Info website reported 24 March.

title: Kremlin spokesman says Russia 'in a state of war'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov has said Russia sees itself as being "in a state of war".
body:
"We are in a state of war. Yes, this started as a special military operation, but as soon as that clique came into being there, when the collective West became a participant in that on Ukraine's side, it became war for us," Peskov told pro-Kremlin weekly Argumenty i Fakty.

"I am sure of this. And everyone should understand this for their own internal mobilisation," Peskov added.

"We have four new constituent parts of the federation," he said, referring to Ukraine's partially occupied Kherson, Zaporizhzhya, Donetsk and Luhansk regions. "And for us the main thing is to make people in these constituent parts safe and to free the territory of these constituent parts that is at present de-facto occupied by the Kyiv regime," he said

He also said, as paraphrased by Argumenty i Fakty, that "Russia cannot let a state that has put on paper [its] intention to use any methods to take Crimea away from Russia, let alone the territory of the new regions, exist on its borders".

In the interview, Peskov also said that "traitors, those who take up arms and start fighting us" must be "destroyed".

Several pro-Ukraine paramilitary groups say they are made up of Russian nationals fighting for a Russia "without repression and fear for one's life".

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0857 gmt 22 Mar 24

title: Passengers evacuated after Ghana air force plane crash-lands
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Twenty-one passengers and crew aboard a Ghana Air Force helicopter survived after the plane made an emergency landing at Bonsukrom near Agona Nkwanta in the Western Region, state-run Graphic Online reported on 19 March.

title: Suspected herders kill 21 in north-central Nigeria market attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Suspected herders have killed 21 people in an attack on a market in Nigeria’s north-central Niger State, privately owned Daily Trust website reported on 22 March.
body:
Local sources said the assailants stormed a market in Madaka village of Rafi local government area on 21 March and opened fire on people.

“Sources alleged that the attackers were on the mission to reclaim the cattle recently recovered from them during air operations in the area and rustle more livestock,” the report said.

State Commissioner For Homeland Security, Bello Abdullahi Mohammed, said security officers have been deployed to pursue the criminals.

The attack comes barely two days after suspected bandits killed five people including a district head in Pangu Gari in the same state.

Niger and neighbouring states have experienced deadly clashes between herders and farming communities for years in a conflict over resources.

Source: Daily Trust website, Abuja, 22 Mar 24

title: Islamic Resistance in Iraq claims it hit site in northern Israel
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI) militia grouping has claimed that it carried out a drone attack on what it said was a “vital site” in the Arab village of Eilabun in northern Israel.
body:
The Iran-backed militia said in a statement on Telegram on 30 March that the attack came “in support of our people in Gaza and in response to massacres committed by the usurper entity [Israel] against Palestinian civilians”.

The group also released a video purportedly showing the launch of the drones used in the attack. 

In recent weeks, the IRI has claimed it launched a series of attacks targeting areas inside Israel, none of which have been confirmed or reported in Israeli media.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2225 GMT 30 Mar 24

title: New Russian bill says 1954 Crimea handover to Ukraine illegal
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A new bill tabled in Russia's State Duma (lower house of parliament) says that the transfer of Crimea to Ukraine in 1954 was illegal, Interfax news agency reports.
body:
It quoted the bill as reading that the regulatory acts of transfer violated the constitutions of both the Soviet Union and the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, and had "no legal force".

The bill was initiated by State Duma member Konstantin Zatulin and Federation Council upper house of parliament member Sergei Tsekov, both of the Kremlin's United Russia party.

Russia seized Crimea from Ukraine by force in spring 2014.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1548 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: No place for Verma in India's squad for Women's World Cup
snippet:
MUMBAI, India (AP)  Opener Shafali Verma missed out on a home World Cup appearance as the India womens squad for the ODI tournament was announced Tuesday.

Pratika Rawal sealed her place instead as the likely opening partner for vice-captain Smriti Mandhana.
body:
India will be led by Harmanpreet Kaur at the Sept. 30-Nov. 2 Women's World Cup.

Verma featured for India A in Australia, but Rawals form  703 runs in 14 innings since her debut in December -- helped secure the spot.

Jemimah Rodrigues makes the cut after missing out in 2022  a first ODI World Cup appearance for the star batter. No. 3 Harleen Deol, allrounders Amanjot Kaur and Arundhati Reddy, left-arm spinners Radha Yadav and Sree Charani, and pacer Kranti Goud will also feature in their first World Cup.

Host India will open its World Cup campaign against Sri Lanka on Sept. 30. The game was slated to be played in Bengaluru, but a change in venue is anticipated because of the post-IPL tragedy involving Royal Challengers Bengaluru where 11 fans lost their lives in a stampede. An ICC announcement is expected this week.

Bengaluru was also supposed to host the final on Nov. 2, and that could also be changed.

Colombo will host the final if Pakistan qualifies. Pakistan will play all its games in Sri Lanka, including against India on Oct. 5.

India will play three ODIs with Australia  on Sept. 14, 17 and 20  in the buildup to the World Cup.

___

India squad: Harmanpreet Kaur (captain), Smriti Mandhana (vice-captain), Pratika Rawal, Harleen Deol, Jemimah Rodrigues, Richa Ghosh, Yastika Bhatia, Deepti Sharma, Sneh Rana, Amanjot Kaur, Radha Yadav, Sree Charani, Kranti Goud, Arundhati Reddy, Renuka Thakur.

___

AP cricket: https://apnews.com/hub/cricket

title: Over 9,000 affected by flash floods in Mozambique's northern town
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

More than 9,000 people have been affected by flooding caused by heavy rains in Mozambique’s northern town of Mocimboa da Praia amid risk of cholera outbreak, state-owned broadcaster TVM reported on 6 March.
body:
TVM said the town’s population does not have access to drinking water and reports of cholera cases have started to emerge.

"People have no way to drink water because the boreholes are all flooded. We already have some cases of cholera. It's a very worrying situation," the mayor of Mocimboa da Praia, Helena Bandeira, told TVM.

"We managed to evacuate a very small number of people, especially children and pregnant women. But we need tents so we can look for safer places to relocate people.”

The official said floods destroyed hundreds of houses across the municipality due to poor drainage and called for assistance for the families affected.

Source: Televiso de Moambique, Maputo, in Portuguese 6 Mar 24

title: Ukraine takes credit for striking Russian ship
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian military intelligence has said that its Group 13 special unit attacked a Russian patrol ship, the Sergey Kotov, while it was patrolling in Ukraine's internationally recognised territorial waters near the Kerch Strait on the night of 4-5 March.
body:
"As a result of an attack by Magura V5 naval drones, the Russian ship Sergey Kotov, Project 22160, suffered damage to the stern, port and starboard", Ukrainian military intelligence said on Telegram. It described the ship as sunken.

Ukrainian intelligence added that the attack had been coordinated with the country's Navy and Digital Transformation Ministry.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0639 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says 12 Russian strike drones destroyed
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences shot down all 12 Shahed kamikaze drones Russia launched on the night 25-26 March, the Air Force Command has reported on Telegram.
body:
The drones were downed over Kharkiv and Mykolayiv regions, it said.

Russia also attacked Donetsk Region with two S-300 missiles, the command said. They were not reported as shot down.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0533 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: India confirms death of national allegedly forced to fight for Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

India confirmed the death of one Indian national in Russia who had gone to work as a helper in the Russian army but was reportedly forced to fight against Ukraine, respected daily The Telegraph reported on its website.
body:
The Indian embassy in Moscow announced the death of Hyderabad-based Mohammed Asfan via a post on X but provided no details on the circumstances leading to his death.

"We have learnt about the tragic death of an Indian national, Shri Mohammed Asfan. We are in touch with the family and Russian authorities. Mission will make efforts to send his mortal remains to India," the embassy said in the post.

The incident comes soon after a video of seven Indians claiming that they had been forced to fight for the Russian army surfaced, seeking government's help to return.

See also: Briefing: India reacts to nationals reportedly seeking release from Russian army

Source: The Telegraph website, Kolkata, in English 0600 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Russian defence chief lists Ukraine's 'destroyed' Western-supplied hardware
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu says Ukraine has lost nine US and German-made tanks, and 27 US-made Bradley armoured vehicles in 2024.
body:
"Four Abrams and five Leopard tanks, 27 Bradley vehicles, six Himars launchers, 11 air defence missile system launchers - including five Patriot systems, have been destroyed since the start of the year," TASS news agency quoted Shoigu saying on 20 March.

"Overall, the Ukrainian Armed Forces' losses in this period, that is to say the period since the start of the year, have exceeded 71,000 people and 11,000 various pieces of weaponry. This is almost triple the figures for a similar period last year," Shoigu added.

TASS said he made the statement in Moscow, at a meeting with top military officials.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1103 gmt 20 Mar 24

title: Pakistan criticises India over 'discriminatory' citizenship law
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan has criticised India over its contentious citizenship law, saying such steps "further expose the sinister agenda" to convert India into a "Hindu nation", Geo News channel's website reported on 14 March, citing the Foreign Office (FO).
body:
The Indian government announced the implementation of the law on 11 March, over four years after it was passed in parliament and led to violent protests. The law allows Indian citizenship to "persecuted" non-Muslim migrants from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan, who entered India before 31 December 2014.

Pakistan alleged that minorities in India were facing "victimisation".

"The rising wave of Hindutva [Hindu nationalism] under the BJP [India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party] government has led to rapid political, economic and social victimisation of Muslims and other religious and social minorities, including Dalits [those at the bottom of the Hindu caste hierarchy],” FO spokesperson Mumtaz Zehra Baloch said at a weekly press briefing on 14 March. 

"The discriminatory steps further expose the sinister agenda of transforming India into a Hindu rashtra [nation], " the Geo News report quoted her as saying.

Indian home minister Amit Shah has said that the law is not against Muslims, and accused the opposition of spreading "lies" over the matter. He said that Muslims can apply for Indian citizenship according to the constitution but this specific law focuses on "persecuted" minorities in Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

See also: Briefing: India implements contentious citizenship law ahead of polls

Source: Geo News TV website, Karachi, in English 0330 GMT 15 Mar 24

title: Russian TV news: Incursion from Ukraine, oil production falling but economy boom
snippet:
Main themes on Russian primetime TV news on NTV, Rossiya 1 and Channel One on 12 March 2024

The "attempted" incursion of anti-Kremlin Russian paramilitary groups from Ukrainian territory was the top story for all three channels, which relayed official Russian assurances that the Ukrainian "terrorists" and "saboteurs" were not allowed to cross into Russia and suffered grievous losses.
body:
In updates about the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the channels said Russian forces had taken yet another village in Donbass and destroyed more Western equipment.

Newly elected UK MP George Galloway and US TV personality Tucker Carlson were shown parroting the Kremlin's propaganda narratives on Ukraine, while Russian Duma speaker Vyacheslav Volodin appeared to threaten Germany over possible deliveries of Taurus missiles to Kyiv.

In a lengthy Rossiya 1 report about Putin meeting the next generation of Russian managerial talent, the president was shown casually admitting that Russian oil production is falling and Russia is at risk of losing its traditional markets. Another Rossiya 1 report said that despite "external pressure", the Russian economy is showing a strong and accelerating growth.

Incursion from Ukraine

All three channels led with what they described as an attempted but unsuccessful cross-border raid into Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions by Ukrainian "terrorists" and "saboteurs".

The attempt was a "complete failure" and the "Ukrainian terrorist formations" were not allowed to cross into Russia, losing hundreds of men, seven tanks and several armoured vehicles, including US-supplied Bradley IFVs, state-controlled Channel One told its viewers.

Footage of damaged or destroyed armoured vehicles was shown to corroborate these claims, but it is not immediately clear where or when that footage was recorded.

Ukrainian claims that anti-Kremlin paramilitary groups manned by Russian nationals had turned Russian border guards to flight and seized a village in Kursk Region were dismissed as enemy propaganda.

"While Ukrainian tanks were burning, Kyiv propagandists were posting videos supposedly showing terrorists crossing the Russian border, but what the videos actually showed were ordinary passers-by," Channel One said.

It also showed what it said was footage from the Russian villages which the anti-Kremlin paramilitaries had earlier claimed to have seized. The footage shows that the Russian military are fully in control of both villages and there is no sign of any fighting there, Channel One's presenter said.

Another Ukrainian village seized, Galloway and Carlson parrot Kremlin propaganda

In other Ukraine-related news, the three channels relayed the Russian MoD's report that Russian forces had seized the Donbas village of Nevelske, continued to make steady advances on other stretches of the front, and destroyed valuable Western equipment, including another Himars MRL system.

Turning to the subject of Western support for Ukraine, state-owned Rossiya 1 showed newly elected UK MP George Galloway warning (in a Russian voiceover) that Russia will use all the weapons it has in its arsenals in the event of an "existential threat", and that French President Macron and other European leaders who "fantasise" about getting directly involved in the war in Ukraine will be completely defeated.

Over on Channel One, US TV personality Tucker Carlson, lionised by the pro-Kremlin media as an eminent US voice of reason, was shown arguing that US sanctions against Russia break international rules and undermine the world's confidence in the US dollar.

Rossiya 1 and Channel One also showed Russian Duma speaker urging the German Bundestag to investigate the audio leak on which top German officers are heard discussing possible use of Taurus missiles for a strike against the Kerch Bridge between Crimea and the Russian mainland.

The involvement of German officers in such discussions is seen in Russia as "aggression and a threat to our security", and Russia "has what it takes to respond to such threats", including "the most advanced, high-tech weapons" which no other country has, Vyacheslav Volodin was shown saying on Channel One.

Putin admits falling Russian oil production

With only a few days remaining until the Russian presidential election, all three channels aired lengthy reports about Vladimir Putin attending a forum of the next generation of Russian managerial and state governance talent.

The reports mostly highlighted Putin's banter with the event's participants and their words of praise for the Russian leader - but on Rossiya 1, he was also shown casually admitting in a chat with a relatively youthful deputy energy minister that Russian oil production is declining and Russia risks losing its traditional oil markets.

"Opec+ is really helping us to keep the oil prices [high], generating revenue for our treasury, but our oil production is in fact falling," Putin was shown saying.

"And because production is falling [in Russia] but rising in other countries, such as the United States, we risk losing our markets," the president went on.

The Russian government imposed a one-year ban on the publication of oil and gas production statistics in April 2023. On 7 March, Interfax news agency said the ban had been extended until 1 April 2025.

Russian economy said to be growing strongly

In other economic news, Rossiya 1 showed Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin announcing that Russian GDP grew at an annualised rate of 4.6% in January 2024, up from the 3.5% growth reported for the whole of 2023.

"The Russian economy is successfully adapting to the challenges, regardless of the external pressure," Rossiya 1 told its viewers.

Source: BBC Monitoring in Russian 1800 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Uganda's president appoints son as chief of defence forces
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Uganda’s President Yoweri Museveni on 21 March appointed his son, Gen Muhoozi Kainerugaba, as the new Chief of Defence Forces (CDF), privately-owned The Monitor website reported.
body:
Kainerugaba had previously served as the senior presidential advisor, a position he assumed after he was demoted from commander of land forces in 2022 over offensive tweets, including one where he threatened to capture Kenya’s capital, Nairobi.

“He replaces Gen Wilson Mbasu Mbadi, who was appointed Minister of State for Trade in the new cabinet reshuffle announced this evening [21 March],” the report said.

Kainerugaba’s appointment comes days after Museveni put all elements of the Uganda People’s Defence Forces under the command of the CDF on 17 February.

Kainerugaba’s appointment could feed into the long-held belief that Museveni was grooming his son for presidency once he retires. Museveni has not shown any indication that he plans to vacate his long-held seat ahead of elections scheduled for 2026.
