Source: Daily Monitor website, Kampala, in English 21 Mar 24

title: Ethiopian army chief vows to bury Amhara militia 'soon'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ethiopian army chief Field Marshal Birhanu Jula has said that the army will "soon" bury the Fano militia fighting it in north-western Amhara Region, state-owned ETV reported on 2 March.
body:
Birhanu made the remarks on 2 March during the 128th Adwa Victory ceremony in Addis Ababa. The ceremony marks the day Ethiopian forces defeated colonial Italian troops in the northern town of Adwa in 1896.

"With their [Fano militia's] main force having been annihilated, they are in agony and we will witness their burial soon," Birhanu said.

He also accused the militiamen of launching "a major offensive" with the help of unnamed foreign forces, but added that Ethiopia has "a strong defence force capable of properly beating off our enemies".

The Fano have claimed to have taken control of a number of towns in Amhara amid reports of major clashes with federal forces in recent days.

Source: ETV News, Addis Ababa, in Amharic 2 Mar 24

title: Tajik opposition in Germany rallies for members 'abducted' in Turkey
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A group of Tajik activists and opposition members in Germany on 14 March staged a protest rally urging the Turkish authorities to release two fellow activists believed to be held in Istanbul, the Warsaw-based Tajik news and analytical channel Azda TV website reported on the same day.
body:
The members of the outlawed Tajik opposition Group 24 said that Suhrob Zafar, leader of the movement, and its member Nasimjon Sharifov should not be handed over to the Tajik authorities, the report said.

They rallied outside the Turkish Consulate in Hurth, holding posters with various slogans and photos of the two activists, it noted.

Earlier Group 24 said that Zafar, who has been living in Istanbul since 2014, disappeared on 10 March, while Sharifov had been missing since February.

This was the first opposition protest over the disappearance of the Group 24 leader and its activist in Turkey, the Prague-based private Tajik news website Bomdod.com said on 14 March.

The protesters expressed concern over the disappearance of their two associates in quick succession, and demanded that the Turkish authorities find them as soon as possible and bring those responsible for their "abduction" to account, the website said.

"The colleagues are worried that Suhrob Zafar and Nasimjon Sharifov were abducted in Turkey, and that they will be illegally taken to Tajikistan," it added.

According to Bomdod, Tajik opposition groups and activists are planning similar protest rallies outside Turkey's diplomatic missions in other European cities, including Vienna and Berlin.

Neither Dushanbe nor Ankara has been reported to have commented on the alleged abduction of these two Tajik citizens in Turkey.

Group 24 was set up by businessman-turned-opposition leader Umarali Quvvatov, who was killed in Istanbul in 2015, a year after the Tajik Supreme Court outlawed his organisation as "extremist". Dozens of people have been convicted and jailed in Tajikistan for membership in the group and dozens of other members and supporters took refuge in Turkey and other European countries.

Last year, there were reports alleging that Tajikistan had helped Turkey "abduct" two Turkish nationals suspected of having links to exiled cleric Fethullah Gulen. 

Source: Azda.tv website, Warsaw, in Tajik 14 Mar 24

title: North Korea unveils new tank during military drill
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korea has unveiled a new battle tank during a training exercise overseen by leader Kim Jong-un, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported on 14 March.
body:
Kim drove the tank during a "training match" between tank units on 13 March as part of efforts to assess the troops' combat capabilities, the KCNA report said.

"Swiftly negotiating the various worst combat circumstances, the heavy tanks hit targets at once with powerful strikes and broke through strong defence lines with high manoeuvrability," it added. Kim also called the new tanks "most powerful tanks in the world".

The development comes amid ongoing joint military drills between South Korea and the United States.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0400 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Kremlin says Ukraine lost 550 soldiers in attempted border raids
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov has said that over the last few days Ukrainian "saboteurs" tried to infiltrate Russia's Belgorod and Kursk Regions several times but all their attacks were repelled.
body:
President Vladimir "Putin receives constant reports from the military about attempts to attack our territory in Belgorod and Kursk Regions in recent days. All attacks have been repelled," state news agency TASS quoted Peskov as saying on 16 March.

"Out of 2,500 saboteurs, 1,700 were hit. The enemy's irreplaceable losses amounted to 550 people," Peskov said.

"Last night, the enemy made several more attempts of incursion into Belgorod and Kursk Regions. They were all thwarted. None of the attempts succeeded in reaching the Russian border. The irreversible losses amounted to 60-70%," he said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1706 gmt 16 Mar 24

title: South Korea: Seven go missing after fishing boat capsizes off southern coast
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A fishing boat with nine crew members on board capsized off the southern coastal city of Tongyeong in South Korea on 9 March, leaving seven of them missing, Yonhap news agency reported citing the Coast Guard.
body:
According to officials, two South Koreans and seven Indonesians were aboard the 29-ton vessel when it overturned in waters 68 kilometers south of an island in Tongyeong of South Gyeongsang Province.

Two crew members were later found unconscious inside the vessel, and have been sent to a hospital, they said, adding that the nationalities of the rescued crew members were not immediately known.

The officials said 11 Coast Guard patrol vessels, two Navy vessels and five helicopters are conducting a search operation at the accident site, the report added.

Source: Yonhap news agency, Seoul, in English 0131 GMT 9 Mar 24

title: Ukraine's Zelensky urges help as Russia hits energy objects
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that Russia used over 60 Shahed kamikaze drones and nearly 90 missiles to hit Ukraianian energy facilities primarily on the night of 21-22 March.

title: Two civilians reported killed in new Belgorod shelling incidents
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two people have been killed and a dozen injured by Ukrainian shelling in Russia's border Belgorod Region on 17 March, governor Vyacheslav Gladkov has said.
body:
Gladkov said in a Telegram post that all casualties were in the city of Belgorod where a man "died from his wounds" at a parking lot when the shelling started. Eleven people were also injured, he noted.

In an earlier post the same day, Gladkov said a 16-year-old girl was killed and her father injured after her house was hit by Ukrainian fire. The shelling also damaged several other houses and cars, he added.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1332 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Pakistan minister says government making efforts to reduce inflation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's federal Minister for Housing and Works Riaz Hussain Pirzada said that the government was working towards reducing inflation and electricity prices, news agency Associated Press of Pakistan (APP) reported on its website.
body:
The minister visited the utility stores in Vehari district, checked the quality of the food items provided at cheap prices under the prime minister's Ramazan Relief Package.

"We are trying to get the country out of crisis," the minister said during a visit to the utility stores in Vehari district in Islamabad.

He also said that the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) contested the general elections to improve the inflation, the report added.

See also: Briefing: Pakistani media note 'broad spectrum' of challenges for new government

Explainer: Pakistani parties focus on the economy in election campaign

Source: Associated Press of Pakistan news agency, Islamabad, in English 0600 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Islamic Resistance in Iraq claims it hit Ben Gurion airport
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI) has claimed that it carried out a drone attack on Israel’s Ben Gurion airport.
body:
The grouping of Iran-backed militias said in a statement on Telegram on 19 March that the attack comes “in support of our people in Gaza and in response to the Zionist massacres against the unarmed Palestinian civilians”.

The group also released a video purportedly showing the launch of the drones used in the attack. 

This is IRI’s second statement alleging an attack on the airport this month. 

Israeli media have not reported an attack on the airport.

In recent weeks, IRI has claimed it launched a series of attacks targeting areas inside Israel, none of which have been confirmed or reported in Israeli media.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2228 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Russian security source says US tip-off on Moscow attack was too 'general'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian secret services have acknowledged that the United States had tipped them off about a possible terror act ahead of the 22 March attack at a concert hall outside Moscow in which dozens of people were killed, but said the information given was "too general", the Interfax news agency reported on 23 March, quoting a source in the secret services.
body:
"In connection with the statement by a representative of the National Security Council of the American administration, Adrienne Watson, about the sharing of data with the Russian side on an impending terrorist attack, a source in the Russian intelligence agency confirmed that such information had indeed been received," the news agency said.

"However, the source emphasised that this information was of a general nature, without any specifics," Interfax added.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0919 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: Russian envoy in Pakistan stresses need to promote bilateral ties
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's newly appoint­ed Ambassador in Pakistan Albert P. Khorev has stressed on need to further promote ties between the two countries, The Nation daily reported.
body:
The envoy made the comments during a meeting with officials and experts at the Institute of Strategic Studies Islamabad (ISSI) on 12 March,  the report stated.

The meeting was chaired by Pakistan's former Foreign Secretary and the Director-General of ISSI Sohail Mahmood. Mahmood welcomed the new envoy and expressed the hope that ties between Pakistan and Russia would continue to grow during his tenure, as per the report.

Both sides expressed satisfaction over the positive trajectory of Pakistan-Russia bilateral relations, cooperation on regional issues and collaboration in multilateral fora, the report said.

They also acknowledged the importance of exploring new avenues for mutually-benefi­cial cooperation, particularly in the economic, trade, energy, se­curity, and people-to-people do­mains, it added.

This was Russian envoy's first visit to ISIS - an entity dealing with international issues - after assuming charge.

Source: The Nation website, Islamabad, in English 0820 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 31 July 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Israeli media see Canadian move as part of rift against it
body:
Israeli media this morning discussed Canada's announcement that it will recognise a Palestinian state, subject to several changes it is demanding from the Palestinian Authority (PA) including holding elections.

The website of Channel 12 News said the move was part of a "political rift against Israel".

The main headline on the front page of the mass circulation daily Yediot Ahronot said: "This is how we lost the world", calling recent international moves to recognise a Palestinian state a "political tsunami that is only intensifying".

Meanwhile, PA President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the move, thanking Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney in a phone call. A statement by the official Palestinian news agency Wafa also mentioned holding elections, which would be the first time in nearly 20 years.

Hamas has not yet been observed to respond to Canadian or UK plans to recognise a Palestinian state.

We will file a briefing.

Witkoff reportedly in Israel for meeting with Netanyahu

US Middle East special envoy Steve Witkoff will reportedly meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel today to discuss the humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip and prospects for a ceasefire deal after weeks of stalled talks.

An unnamed political source told Channel 12 News: "The window of opportunity for a deal is now closing. Israel will not be patient for long."

According to Channel 12 News, Witkoff might also visit Gaza to assess aid centres run by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF).

Meanwhile, several videos circulated on social media showed US healthcare workers in Gaza calling on Witkoff to visit hospitals in the Palestinian territory to see conditions there.

Director general of the Gaza-based health ministry Munir al-Barsh also invited Witkoff to Gaza, saying: "Come and witness what siege, bombing, and starvation have done."

Egypt warns against 'campaign' to undermine its support for Gaza

Egyptian Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly has warned against a "systematic campaign to undermine and distort Egypt's role in the Palestinian cause", emphasising that Egypt remains committed to delivering humanitarian aid.

His remarks yesterday followed statements attributed to the Central Emergency Committee in Gaza and carried by pan-Arab outlets that said Egypt's official statements about the entry of aid into the strip "do not reflect reality". The committee urged Cairo to publish statistics for aid entering Gaza through the Rafah border crossing instead of "creating the illusion of solidarity".

The Egyptian army spokesperson said in a statement yesterday that four military aircraft took departed to air drop tonnes of food aid in Gaza. Domestic media also reported that a fourth humanitarian aid convoy reached the Karm Abu Salem crossing, adding that Israeli delays have slowed the entry of life-saving supplies.

Pro-government pundits spoke with pan-Arab media to defend Egypt's position, with one political analyst accusing the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood of taking part in the campaign.

We will file a briefing.

Israel strikes missile base on Syrian coast

The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported a series of explosions overnight at a missile store near the coastal town of Jableh.

The SOHR, a reliable monitor of the Syria conflict, posted footage of the blast at the army's 107 Brigade base in the Zama area.

Immediately following the fall of the Assad government in December, Israel targeted aircraft and weaponry across Syria, and have since carried out multiple further strikes.

The new Syrian authorities have cautiously engaged with Israel since taking power.

The Israeli military has not yet commented on the strike.

We will be watching for further reaction.

Hezbollah chief says group's weapons exist to resist Israel

Chief of the Lebanese group Hezbollah, Sheikh Naim Qassem, said in a speech last night that its weapons are for "resisting Israel" and are not intended for domestic use.

His remarks, relayed by the Hezbollah-run Al-Manar TV, come against the backdrop of calls, spearheaded by US efforts, for the group to lay down its weapons.

"Today, everyone who is demanding the handing over of weapons is demanding that they be handed over to Israel," Al-Manar TV quoted Qassem as saying.

Qassem described the group's weapons as a "force for Lebanon", saying "we are ready to discuss how these weapons can be part of Lebanon's strength".

He also accused US special envoy Tom Barrack of using threats in order to help Israel.

Coming up

Syrian Foreign Minister Asaad al-Shibani will meet his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, in Moscow today, the Istanbul-based Syria TV reported. The outlet cited Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Vershinin as saying that Shibani and Lavrov will hold "very extensive" talks on trade and political relations.

Vershinin further said that "contacts regarding Russian bases in Syria are ongoing", adding that the Russian bases "are a stabilising factor in the region and play a humanitarian role in Syria".

Syria TV described the visit as "the most significant development in relations" between the new Syrian government and Russia.

title: North Korea confirms return of its envoy from Cuba
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korea has said its ambassador to Cuba paid a farewell visit to Cuban President Miguel Diaz-Canel on 16 March before concluding his mission, the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
During the meeting with Ambassador Ma Chol-su, the Cuban president "expressed the stand of the Cuban party and government to invariably develop the historic tradition and relations between the DPRK and Cuba building socialism against the US imperialists, their common enemy," KCNA reported on 18 March. 

DPRK refers to Democratic People's Republic of Korea, North Korea's official name.

The development comes after South Korea and Cuba forged formal diplomatic ties on 14 February in a move that many experts noted was a a diplomatic blow to the North, which has long maintained close ties with Cuba.

Source: Yonhap news agency, Seoul, in English 0900 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Iranian cleric killed in south-western Khuzestan Province
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Iranian cleric has been killed by "robbers" in the city of Mahshahr in the south-western Khuzestan Province, the conservative Mehr News Agency reported on 23 March.
body:
Hamzeh Akrami, a religious seminary teacher who also worked as a taxi driver at Iranian ride-hailing app Snapp, was killed in the morning of 23 March, Mehr said.

The perpetrator also stole his car and mobile phone, the report added.

A later report by Mehr on the same day cited the local prosecutor, Mehdi Mohammadi, as telling reporters that an investigation was opened after the discovery Akrami's body. Mohammadi asked journalists to "refrain from any speculation" in order to support the investigation.

There have been several assaults on clerics in Iran lately, including a murder of a senior cleric and a member of Iran's Assembly of Experts in April 2023.

Source: Mehr news agency, Tehran, in Persian 1817 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Nigeria deploys 157 peacekeepers to South Sudan UN mission
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Nigerian army has deployed 157 peacekeepers to the United Nations Interim Security Force in Abyei (UNISFA) to support efforts to pacify the volatile disputed region on the border between Sudan and South Sudan, privately owned Daily Trust website reported on 21 March.
body:
Army chief of operations Maj Gen Boniface Sinjen told the 15 officers and 142 soldiers that they were part of over 100,000 peacekeepers Nigeria has deployed to at least 40 missions since the first one in the Congo in 1960.

“All Nigerian peacekeepers, together with others from all over the world, have upheld the course of humanity while helping nations in distress to restore peace and enthrone much-desired development,” Gen Sinjen was quoted as saying.

Major Gen Ademola Adedoja, who presided over the pre-deployment training, said the troops took part in a course covering sexual exploitation and abuse, conflict-related sexual violence, conduct and discipline, and protection of civilians. 

Deadly communal violence has persisted in Abyei despite the presence of UN peacekeepers since 2011.

Source: Daily Trust website, Abuja, 21 Mar 24

title: Gunmen 'abduct dozens' from north-west Nigeria school
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Gunmen have abducted an unspecified number of pupils from a school in Nigeria's north-western Kaduna State, privately owned Daily Trust website reported on 7 March, citing residents.
body:
The head teacher of LEA Primary School, Kuriga 1 in Chikun local government area was feared to be among the victims of the attack in the morning of 7 March.

"The number of persons abducted couldn't be ascertained as of press time, but residents said they were about 100," Daily Trust said.

Several pupils escaped when the gunmen stormed the school shortly after the morning assembly, residents cited by the website said.

Kaduna State security commissioner Samuel Aruwan and police authorities were yet to comment on the attack, the report said.

Nigeria's federal government on 1 March ordered heightened military operations in the north-western states of Kaduna, Zamfara and Katsina, where armed gangs often engage in mass kidnappings for ransoms.

Source: Daily Trust website, Abuja, 7 Mar 24

title: Russian warplane 'crashes' near Crimea
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Russian warplane has crashed off Sevastopol in occupied Crimea, according to reports by the peninsula's Moscow-installed governor and Russian Channel One TV host Ruslan Ostashko.
body:
Mikhail Razvozhayev, "the governor" of Sevastopol, said the jet "crashed into the sea".

Citing Russian war correspondents, Ostashko said "The enemy has shot down a Su-35 in the Sevastopol area". However he soon amended his post to read: "A Su-35 has crashed in the Sevastopol area".

Both Ostashko and Razvozhayev said the pilot ejected and was alive.

Telegram channel VChK-OGPU said "early data" suggested the jet may have been downed by Russian air defence.

Its post included video footage of a jet on fire falling down vertically.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1525 gmt 28 Mar 24

title: Ukraine: Russian missile strike kills 14, wounds 46 in Odesa
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 14 people were killed in a Russian missile strike on Ukraine's city of Odesa on 15 March, regional head Oleh Kiper has reported on Telegram.
body:
He added that 46 people were wounded.

According to the Suspilne public broadcaster, the first explosion rocked the city at 11:04 (09:04 GMT), just three minutes after an air raid siren had been sounded. Then there was another explosion.

First responders and medics are among the victims, Oleh Kiper said. He added that 16 March would be declared a day of mourning in Odesa and the region.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1204 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Zelensky appoints Ukraine's new foreign intelligence chief
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Volodymyr Zelensky has appointed Oleh Ivashchenko as head of the Foreign Intelligence Service of Ukraine, the presidential website has announced.
body:
Prior to this, he dismissed Oleksandr Lytvynenko from the post, appointing him as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council.

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1217 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: Pakistan security forces kill eight militants in restive North Waziristan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistani security forces have gunned down at least eight militants, including a militant commander who was behind the attack in North Waziristan district's Mir Alia in north-western Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, private television channel Geo News cited the military as saying.
body:
"Sanitization operations are being conducted to eliminate any other terrorists found in the area as the Security Forces of Pakistan remain determined to wipe-out the menace of terrorism from the country," the military's media wing, the Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR), said in a statement.

According to the military's media wing, the forces carried out the operation following reports of the presence of militants.

The military also said that those killed included the militant commander Sehra alias Janan, the "highly wanted by the law enforcement agencies", who was involved in the attack on a security forces' post in Mir Ali on 16 March.

Source: Geo News TV website, Karachi, in English 0900 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Iranian policeman, 'thug' killed in clashes in south-eastern province
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Iranian police conscript and a "thug" have been killed in an armed clash at a police checkpoint in the village of Panag, Rudbar County, south-eastern Kerman Province, the hardline Fars News Agency reported on 14 March.
body:
Fars said that Younes Mahmoudi died at a hospital after being shot in the clash in the morning of 14 March, while another conscript was also wounded and undergoing treatment.

Police forces shot dead one "thug" and wounded another during the clash, while also seizing "a large amount of ammunition" from their car, the report added.

Source: Fars News Agency website, Tehran, in Persian 0652 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Officials among 15 killed in eastern South Sudan attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 15 people, including an official and a senior army commander were killed in an ambush by armed youth near Nyat town, eastern South Sudan, the Amsterdam-based Radio Tamazuj website reported on 19 March.
body:
“The commissioner of Jebel Boma county in the Greater Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA), Jeremiah Lothiboi, the area’s SSPDF [South Sudan People’s Defence Forces] commander, Col Kaka Thombum, and 13 other people were killed on Tuesday morning [19 March] when their convoy was ambushed on the outskirts of Nyat town,” the website said.

“GPAA Information Minister Abraham Kelang told Radio Tamazuj on Tuesday that the local government officials, the South Sudan People's Defence Forces (SSPDF) commander, and their bodyguards were among the 13 killed individuals,” it added.

“Those attackers were heavily armed youth but we are yet to find out where they came from,” the official said.

The region has been the scene of bloody communal attacks and cattle-related violence that has left thousands dead in the last few years.

Source: Radio Tamazuj website, in English, 19 Mar 24

title: Japan leader pledges to enhance defence capabilities
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has vowed to enhance the country's defence capabilities, during a speech at a defence academy near Tokyo, the website of national broadcaster NHK World reported.
body:
Kishida warned of military buildups, including nuclear and missile development, growing around Japan. "He noted growing attempts to unilaterally change the status quo by force. He said Japan's security environment is the most complex and challenging since the end of the Second World War", the NHK report added.

"He said the government is aiming to boost its diplomatic and defense capabilities to maintain peace and deter security emergencies. He said the government will be united in its effort to achieve targets laid out in three documents on Japan's national security," it added.

See also: Japan likely to allow sale of next generation fighter jets

Japan, India hold joint military drill in desert

 

Source: NHK World website, Tokyo, in English 0523 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Church leader blames 'Russia's ill-wishers' for deadly concert hall attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Patriarch Kirill, head of Russia's Orthodox Christian Church, has described the 22 March deadly concert hall attack in Moscow as an attempt by "Russia's ill-wishers" to incite ethnic and religious discord in the country.
body:
"Scenarios are being played out with the use of a religious and inter-ethnic factor. We realise that perfectly well looking at the actual perpetrators of the atrocity committed at Crocus City Hall. Russia's ill-wishers tried to use internal problems to do with migration, exacerbating the inter-ethnic relations in our country using, among other things, the radical Islam factor," Patriarch Kirill told a meeting of the World Russian People's Council on 27 March.

"An attempt was made to make two traditional religions clash, to divide people along the line of religion and make them too clash with each other. We cannot of course allow anything of the sort to happen in Russia," he added, as quoted by TASS news agency.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1028 gmt 27 Mar 24

title: Yemen website reports case of prominent lawyer 'tortured' by UAE-backed forces
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Forces loyal to Yemen's powerful UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC) have transferred a prominent human rights lawyer from "secret" detention to a hospital after his health deteriorated due to being subjected to torture in prison in the interim capital Aden, a prominent domestic news site said on 8 March.
body:
Al-Masdar Online cited informed sources as telling it that separatist STC forces had taken Sami Yassin al-Sharjabi to a hospital in Aden to receive medical treatment before transferring him to the notorious UAE-run Bir Ahmed prison.

The report added that the US-based non-profit organisation the American Center for Justice had called on the STC and its Security Belt forces to provide information on the lawyer and quoted his mother as saying that her son had been prevented from communicating with the outside world since he was "forcibly disappeared" on 16 November 2023.

Al-Masdar said that Sharjabi had taken on a number of cases of people who had been arbitrarily imprisoned by the STC.

See also from 2022: Yemen website follows case of journalist held by separatists in Aden

Yemen media say detainees at UAE-run prison announce hunger strike

Source: Al-Masdar Online website in Arabic 8 Mar 24

title: Pakistan PM calls security meeting after attack on Chinese
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on 27 March called a top-level meeting to review security following back-to-back attacks in the country, The Express Tribune daily reported on its website.
body:
The meeting came a day after six people, including five Chinese engineers, were killed in a militant attack in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.

The meeting, attended by the army chief and other senior leaders, was scheduled to discuss security of Chinese nationals working and living in the country.

The meeting was likely to conduct a security audit, the report said. 

Pakistan witnessed three high-profile attacks in a week. A day earlier, Pakistani forces thwarted an attack by Baloch militants on a key naval base in Turbat district of Balochistan. Before that, militants targeted the China-funded Gwadar port.

See also: Briefing: Militants continue attacks on Chinese economic interests in Pakistan

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 1026 GMT 27 Mar 24

title: Iran sentences auto part tycoonto total of 65 years in jail
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran has sentenced Abbas Iravani, the former CEO of major auto parts company Ezam Khodro, to a total of 65 years in prison on several charges including "organised smuggling", the judiciary-run Mizan news agency reported on 7 March.
body:
Iravani will have to serve 25 years of the total term, as Iran's Penal Code states that when an individual is convicted of at least three separate crimes that do not carry the death penalty, they will serve only the longest of those sentences.

Iravani was accused, in one of his cases, of "disrupting the performance of the national economy" through "organised smuggling" of more than $664m of auto parts into the country.

In another case, he was charged with "acquiring property and large funds from Iranian banks through illegal methods", including "1.4bn UAE dirhams, 48m US dollars, 13m euros and 2.6bn Iranian rails". He was also charged with presenting tens of fake "inspection certificates" to banks to receive funds through credits.

Iravani has denied all the charges in several court sessions. The first session of the trial of the auto parts tycoon, who is said to have close ties to some high-ranking officials, was held in Tehran in October 2019.

Hardline Tasnim News Agency, among others, reported on 6 March that Intelligence Ministry agents arrested Iravani as he did not surrender to the judicial authorities to serve his prison term.

The court has convicted nine other individuals connected to Iravani and Ezam Khodro in two separate cases.

Source: Mizan news agency, Tehran, in Persian 0745 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Myanmar armed rebels take control of town after military defeat - news website
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Arakan Army (AA), an ethnic armed group, said it has "seized" Rakhine state's Ponnagyun town after defeating the military in a clash on 4 March, Thailand-based specialist website The Irrawaddy reported.

title: Uzbekistan jails influential businessman caught in anti-crime raid
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A court in the Uzbek capital of Tashkent has sentenced influential businessman and sports official Salim Abduvaliyev, who is believed to be one of the leaders of the criminal underworld in the country, to six years in prison for illegal arms possession, privately-owned Uzbek news website Qalampir.uz reported on 23 March.
body:
The 73-year-old man, who has extensive connections and held the posts of deputy chairman of the Uzbek National Olympic Committee and chairman of the Sports Wrestling Association of Uzbekistan, was detained as part of the 40-day-long campaign conducted by the Uzbek law-enforcement bodies across the country in late 2023 to crack down on organised crime.

"Salim Abduvaliyev, better known among people as Salimboyvachcha [Salim the rich], has been sentenced to six years in prison," the report quoted a source as saying.

"Salim Abduvaliyev was found guilty under Article 248 Part 2 (illegal arms possession) of Uzbekistan's Criminal Code at a hearing held behind closed doors at the Mirobod district criminal court in Tashkent. It ruled that he will serve the term in a penal colony. It is expected that an appeal will be filed in connection with the trial," the report added.

The website noted that the verdict was handed down on 19 March but no official information had been given about it.

(Also see Briefing: Uzbek police shed light on high-profile arrests)

Source: Qalampir website (www.qalampir.uz), Tashkent, in Uzbek 0600 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Putin: Western troop deployment would not impact war in Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian President Vladimir Putin has said that he does not believe an official deployment of Western troops to Ukraine would impact the situation in the combat zone.
body:
Putin was responding to a question from Russian TV host Dmitry Kiselyov about French President Emmanuel Macron's recent statement on the possible deployment of Western troops. In the interview broadcast on 13 March, Putin said:

"In fact, troops from Western countries have been in Ukraine for a long time now, even before the coup d'etat [Euromaidan protests in Kyiv], while after it, their number has increased significantly. Currently, they are involved directly as advisers, they are also being hired as foreign mercenaries and are suffering losses.

"But if we speak about the official military presence of the foreign states, then I am sure this will not change the situation on the battlefield - this is the most important - just like the supply of arms changes nothing," he said.

Putin went on to claim that Poland could try to take advantage of any deployment of its troops to Ukraine, sending troops to Ukraine's western borders under the guise of allowing Kyiv to free up troops there to send to contact line in the east.

"Polish armies would never leave the area. That's what I think. They are dreaming of returning the lands they think historically belong to them and were taken away from them by the 'Father of Nations' Josef Vissarionovitch Stalin and handed over to Ukraine," Putin claimed.

Source: Rossiya 1 TV, Moscow, in Russian 0747 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: South Sudan concludes UK-US journalist killed in crossfire
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A South Sudanese government investigation team said on 21 March that British-American journalist Christopher Allen, killed in the country in August 2017, had died “as a result of crossfire", privately-owned broadcaster Radio Tamazuj reported.
body:
Allen was shot dead while covering clashes between the South Sudanese army and the then-rebel Sudan People's Liberation Movement In Opposition (SPLM-IO) in Kaya town in the southern Central Equatoria state.

"Christopher Allen was unintentionally killed as a result of crossfire. The attack occurred at 5:30 AM, when visibility was extremely limited. It was only after the attacking forces were repelled that soldiers conducted a damage assessment, discovering among the seven corpses a white man,” said the head of the government investigation committee, David Charles Ali Bilal.

The government previously denied the army killed the journalist and insisted that he died “in a crossfire”.

In October last year, South Sudan announced setting up a team to probe the killing of the journalist, bowing to Western pressure calling for investigations into his death.

Source: Radio Tamazuj website in English 21 Mar 24

title: Iranian president says in Nowruz message 'enemy failed' in Gaza, Iran
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi has spoken of  the "enemy's failure" in the Gaza war as well as in Iran in the last Iranian calendar year, in his address on Nowruz, the Iranian new year.
body:
The pre-recorded speech was aired by the state-run IRINN rolling news TV channel and other channels on the morning of 20 March. His address was preceded by an address from Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei.

Raisi said the Gaza war showed how "standing up to the enemy" resulted in their "failure", even though Israel was equipped with "the newest arms and billions of dollars".

He said the Kerman attack in January, which killed at least 96 people, was the "enemy's revenge" against Iran "for their own regional failure". "Iran was wounded in heart, but it remained strong," he added.

The Islamic State group (IS) claimed responsibility for the Kerman attack, but Iranian officials maintain that the jihadist group is a product of the US and its allies' policies.

Raisi also said that "the enemy's plan to boycott the elections" also failed, referring to the 1 March parliamentary and Assembly of Experts elections. The elections were marked by a record low 41% turnout, but officials and hardline media still celebrated the turnout as a success.

Raisi also mentioned the 2022 nationwide protests sparked by the death of Mahsa Amini in morality police custody, describing them as "the enemy's failed imposed sedition".

He also praised Iran's supposed economic progress and said there had been some $11bn in foreign investment in the past year. He boasted of Iran's expansion of international ties, including its joining of the Brics group of nations.

Source: Islamic Republic of Iran News Network (IRINN), Tehran, in Persian 0319 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says one killed, 22 wounded in Russian air attacks on two cities
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least one civilian was killed and 16 were wounded as a result of a Russian attack on Kharkiv on 27 March, the head of the Kharkiv regional military administration has reported.
body:
According to preliminary data, Russia struck Kharkiv for the first time with a large-calibre guided munition, Oleh Synyehubov said on Telegram.

He said that blocks of flats were hit.

Ukraine's Air Force Command earlier reported a launch of guided aerial bombs by Russian aircraft in Donetsk and Kharkiv regions.

Russia also hit the city of Mykolayiv, presumably with an Iskander-M ballistic missile, Ukraine's Defence Forces South reported.

Russia "continues to destroy industrial facilities" and wounded the employees of a company, it said.

Earlier, Mykolayiv regional head Vitaly Kim said that six people were injured. He provided no other details.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 27 Mar 24

title: Ukraine intelligence confirms railway bridge damage in Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's military intelligence (HUR) has confirmed that a railway bridge in Russia's Samara Region was damaged, HUR said on Telegram on 4 March. It did not explicitly claim responsibility for the explosion.
body:
Train activity in the area has been paralysed, Russian media have reported.

"The railway was used by the aggressor state to transport military cargo, in particular ammunition, produced by the Polimer plant in the city of Chapayevsk, Samara region", the HUR said.

The bridge was damaged in an explosion that occurred around 06:00 local time (03:00 GMT) on 4 March, it said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0654 gmt 4 Mar 24

title: Russia election authorities claim over 80% in two occupied Ukraine regions
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The election authorities in two Russian-occupied regions of Ukraine have claimed a turnout of over 80% in the Russian presidential election.
body:
"The final voter turnout in the Russian presidential election based on the results of three days of voting and early voting in the Luhansk People's Republic was 87.12%," Elena Kravchenko, chair of the Moscow-appointed local electoral commission said on 17 March in remarks quoted by TASS news agency.

In another partially-occupied region of Ukraine, Kherson, voter turnout was 83,87%, according to the Russian electoral commision there, TASS said in another report.

The Russian presidential election is being held on 15-17 March, but voting began early in the occupied parts of four Ukrainian regions - Luhansk, Kherson, Donetsk and Zaporizhzhya.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1513 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Chad PM pledges probe into opposition leader's death
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Chad’s prime minister, Succes Masra, on 4 March announced that the authorities plan to establish an “international style investigation” into the killing of opposition leader Yaya Dillo Djerou by security forces, French public radio RFI website has reported.
body:
“The government has undertaken to conduct an international enquiry to establish who was responsible at all levels. There are photos, but there is also film, film of the events. I would like to invite everyone to watch the film of all the events,” Masra told RFI during a stopover in Paris. 

Masra added that Dillo’s death was “regrettable” and offered condolences to his family and the families of the soldiers killed in the clashes which led to his killing.

The opposition leader was reportedly killed in a shootout with security forces on 28 February at his party headquarters after attempting to storm the security service headquarters on 27 February.

Yaya Dillo’s allies and family have openly accused the Chadian authorities of “executing” a political adversary ahead of elections in May.

Source: Radio France Internationale website, Paris, in French 0001 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Iran police seize 1,230kg of narcotics in Sistan-Baluchestan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's border police have seized a lorry carrying 1,230kg of hashish in the south-eastern SIstan-Baluchestan province, the semi-official ISNA news agency reported on 4 March.
body:
Brig Gen Reza Shojai, the provincial border police commander, said the drugs were found hidden inside a cargo lorry at the Milak checkpoint near the border with Afghanistan in Hirmand County. He added that the driver was also arrested.

Situated on the borders with Afghanistan and Pakistan, the marginalised and impoverished province of Sistan-Baluchestan is an entry point for smuggled arms and drugs, with frequent clashes reported there between law-enforcement forces and armed gangs.

Source: ISNA website, Tehran, in Persian 0450 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says seven crew killed in drone attack on Russian warship
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's military intelligence (HUR) said that seven crew members of the Russian patrol ship Sergey Kotov died and six were injured in an attack by Ukrainian sea drones on the night of 4-5 March, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported.
body:
The other 52 crew members were evacuated, the HUR told the news agency.

Ukraine's military intelligence reported sinking the Sergey Kotov earlier on 5 March.

The Sergey Kotov patrolled the Kerch Strait, Ukrainian Navy spokesman Dmytro Pletenchuk told the national TV marathon on 5 March.

He noted that the Russian vessel had illegally entered Ukrainian waters. "The ship had the task of guarding the Kerch Strait. Of course, it was executing [this task] illegally in Ukraine's territorial waters. I recall that Ukraine banned shipping in those waters last year. Nevertheless, the Russians do not listen to our advice," Pletenchuk said.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1136 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Yemen rebel official accuses rivals of obstructing Houthi plans to reopen roads
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Yemeni Houthi official has accused rival forces of obstructing the rebel group's efforts to reopen roads as a war of words over the issue between the country's warring parties continues.
body:
In a report on 12 March, the Houthi-controlled Saba news agency quoted the rebel minister of public works and roads, Ghaleb Mutlaq, as saying that "armed militias" affiliated with the Saudi-led coalition backing the internationally recognised government had "besieged" the Houthi committee tasked with co-ordinating the reopening of a road leading from Sanaa to the interim capital Aden.

According to Mutlaq, the committee had arrived in the southern province of Dalea as part of arrangements to reopen the road leading from the rebel-held capital to Aden, the seat of the internationally recognised government, but that "mercenaries" had prevented them from proceeding with the measure and had targeted them with weapons.

The government and the Houthis have in recent weeks exchanged accusations over their respective plans to reopen roads, which has been a sticking point in peace talks between the two sides.

See our additional reporting on the issue: Yemen official continues war of words with Houthis over reopening roads

Briefing: Houthis announce reopening of roads to government-held territory

Briefing: Yemen website sceptical as warring parties plan reopening of key roads

Source: Saba news agency website, Sanaa, in Arabic 12 Mar 24

title: Iran police officer killed in clash in southeast
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Iranian conscript serving a commando unit has been killed in a fire-fight with "armed thugs" in the town of Rudbar in Kerman Province, southeastern Iran.
body:
A report by the hardline Tasnim News Agency on 15 March quoted the police commander for Kerman Province, as saying that the shooting began after the officers of Commando Unit 115 ordered a suspicious passenger vehicle to stop in Zehkalut County.

The occupants of the vehicle opened fire instead, killing the young conscript Younus Mohammadi and injuring another.

The Kerman commander said one of the assailants was also killed and another arrested.

"Two Kalashnikov weapons and a quantity of ammunition were seized from the criminals," added the official.

Source: Tasnim news agency website, Tehran, in Persian 1032 GMT 15 Mar 24

title: Iran's Guards Corps commander awarded 'Victory' medal
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The top commander of the Islamic Revolution Guards Corps (IRGC), Maj Gen Hossein Salami, has been awarded the Fath Medal (Victory Medal) by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme leader and the commander in chief of its armed forces, Tasnim News Agency reported on 10 March.

title: Cyclone Gamane kills six, displaces over 2,000 in Madagascar
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least six people have been killed in Madagascar's north-eastern Sava Region as tropical cyclone Gamane made landfall in the country on 27 March, privately-owned news website L'Express de Madagascar reported on 28 March.

title: Highlights: Russia Kaliningrad Region Media 26 Feb-3 Mar
snippet:
The following are media highlights from Kaliningrad's state-owned GTRK Kaliningrad TV, Strana Kaliningrad newspaper, websites Rugrad, New Kaliningrad and Klops for the period 26 Feb-3 Mar 2024

Domestic economic
body:
Kaliningrad's regional government will subsidise air tickets for all residents of the region, GTRK Kaliningrad TV reported on 3 March. Students who study in Kaliningrad institutes and universities will also be eligible for a discount. The discounted tickets will apply to the flights to Arkhangelsk, Yekaterinburg, Zhukovsky, Kaluga, Moscow, Murmansk, Saint-Petersbourg and Sochi. Earlier, the discount was available only to certain groups, such as younger and older people as well as people with disabilities, the report said. (GTRK Kaliningrad TV, 3 Mar 24)

The decision to subsidise tickets for air travel was made after Russian President Vladimir Putin's visit to the region, Strana Kaliningrad newspaper said on 28 February. The newspaper also said that the decision will likely come into force on 1 May. (Strana Kaliningrad newspaper, 28 Feb 24)

Despite salary increases in Kaliningrad in January 2024 compared to the same period in the previous year, wages in the region are lower than the average in Russia, the Rugrad website reported on 29 February. The average salary in the Kaliningrad region is 45,800 roubles (about 500 dollars). (Rugrad website, 29 Feb 24)

Service fees for gas equipment maintenance in Kaliningrad Region are higher than in other regions of Russia, the New Kaliningrad newspaper reported on 29 February. The region is more expensive than Arkhangelsk, Pskov and Saint-Petersboug. The Moscow Region is the only territory with higher prices than Kaliningrad, the report said. (New Kaliningrad, 29 Feb 24)

International political

The head of the regional administration's press office, Dmitry Lyskov, has said that the Baltic Sea will never become part of Nato, Klops news website quoted him as saying on 26 February. "We are living on our land and developing our region. It is our neighbours that are showing off their arms, those who have suddenly forgotten good neighbourly relations," he said as he reacted to a statement by Lithuania's ambassador in Sweden on the region. (Klops news website, 26 Feb 24)

Other

A book festival called March was cancelled in Kaliningrad, the New Kaliningrad website reported on 2 March. The festival was due to be held on 8-10 March. The telegram channel of the organisers of the festival said that they received a refusal from the city administration on 1 March, but no explanation as to why the festival would not be hosted was given. (New Kaliningrad website, 2 Mar 24)

A man and a woman from Yekaterinburg have been arrested for what was described as "a desecration" of the eternal flame to those who fought and died in World War Two, Klops news website reported on 27 February. The report quoted the local authorities as saying that the man and the woman, who were drunk, danced around and jumped over the fire, while later, the man picked up the flowers at the monument and left together with the woman. (Klops news website, 27 February).

Source: Kaliningrad Region media highlights, in Russian 2359 gmt 3 Mar 24

title: At least 20 migrants reported dead as boat sinks off Turkey's west
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least 20 irregular migrants have lost their lives after their boat sunk off Turkey's western province of Canakkale, mainstream NTV news channel's website reported on 15 March.
body:
"Four people have been rescued so far... Four of the deceased are children and babies, according to preliminary findings," the report quoted Canakkale Governor Ilhami Aktas as saying.

Aktas said the migrants' rubber boat sunk late on 14 March and the local authorities dispatched rescue helicopters and coast guard units immediately.

He warned that the death toll may rise, considering the survivors' statements regarding the number of people onboard.

Turkey has in recent years become a major transit route for irregular migrants seeking to enter the EU. 

Migrants have often attempted to cross to Greek islands in the Aegean, particularly in spring and summer when conditions are relatively favourable.

Source: NTV Online website, Istanbul, in Turkish 1112 GMT 15 Mar 24

title: Putin extends Russia's death-in-war payments to civilian personnel
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian President Vladimir Putin has extended the 5m-rouble ($55,300) death-in-Ukraine-war payments to the Defence Ministry's civilian personnel, TASS news agency reports.
body:
The payment, previously given to the families of the service personnel killed in the war, also extends to the civilian personnel from a number of other Russian government bodies - including the interior ministry, the prison service and the court bailiffs service.

The same presidential decree says that the civilian personnel from the above mentioned government bodies are entitled to 3m-rouble payments in the event of being wounded in the Ukraine war.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1348 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Iran police officer killed by 'drug smugglers' near Afghanistan border
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The commander of a police border guards station in Iran's eastern South Khorasan Province has been killed in a clash with "drug smugglers" near the border with Afghanistan, the official IRNA news agency reported on 5 March.
body:
Brig Gen Hossein Dehaki, the provincial border guard commander, said that Sgt Alireza Moazzen was killed in a shootout with drug traffickers in the province's Nehbandan city near the border. 

He added that two other officers were wounded, while the "armed thugs were subdued".

South Khorasan Province shares a 331 km border with Afghanistan, which is a frequent conduit for narcotics entering Iran.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 1957 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Ukraine intel source says Russian ship hit by sea drones
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian sea drones have hit the Russian patrol ship Sergey Kotov, the Ukrayinska Pravda news website reported on 5 March, quoting its source in the Ukrainian military intelligence (HUR).
body:
The Sergey Kotov is a corvette-class large patrol ship of the Project 22160 series that can carry Kalibr cruise missiles.

The extent of damage to the ship is being clarified, the source said.

"The Main Intelligence Directorate [HUR] was behind the special operation", Ukrayinska Pravda quoted the source as saying.

Russia has stopped railway traffic to Crimea and the bridge from mainland Russia to Crimea has been blocked for eight hours, the website reported, quoting Russian media.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 0550 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: North Korea extends congratulations to Nepalese deputy PM
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

North Korea has extended congratulations to Nepalese leader Narayan Kaj Shrestha, upon his appointment as deputy prime minister and foreign minister of Nepal, Pyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.
body:
"DPRK Foreign Minister Choe Son Hui on March 15 sent a congratulatory message to Narayan Kaj Shrestha upon his appointment as deputy prime minister and foreign minister of Nepal," the 16 March KCNA report added.

DPRK refers to North Korea's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. 

"The message expressed belief that the friendly and cooperative relations between the two countries with long history and traditions would invariably develop, wishing him success in his responsible work," the KCNA report added.

Source: KCNA website, Pyongyang, in English 0827 GMT 16 Mar 24

title: Pakistan PM emphasises zero tolerance for border attacks
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on 20 March asserted that the government would not tolerate any cross-border terrorism, The Express Tribune newspaper reported.
body:
"We will unequivocally reject and respond firmly to any act of terrorism originating from across our borders," Sharif said during the inaugural session of the federal cabinet.

His remarks came in the wake of recent terror incidents along Pakistan-Afghanistan border, where Pakistan undertook intelligence-driven anti-terror operations within Afghanistan. 

While stressing the importance of regional cooperation in combating terrorism, he said: "We aspire to foster peaceful coexistence with our neighbouring nations and seek to bolster trade and bilateral relations."

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0602 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Pakistan opposition set to hold nation-wide protests against 'stolen' mandate
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's opposition Pakistan Tehreek-i-Insaf (PTI) party has announced countrywide protests on 10 March against “mandate theft” following a call by imprisoned party founder Imran Khan, prominent daily Dawn reported on its website.
body:
According to a PTI spokesperson, the nation would not accept the “corrupt persons as the president and prime minister of the country against their will,” the report added.

The protests would be held to reclaim the “stolen” mandate, the report further cited the spokesperson as saying.

See also: Briefing: Pakistani media urge upholding democracy after split electoral verdict

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0500 GMT 10 Mar 24

title: Sudan's RSF 'detains' over 20 commercial trucks in North Kordofan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) group are reportedly holding more than 20 commercial trucks and passenger buses in North Kordofan state town of Um Samima, privately-owned Al Taghyir news website reported on 27 March.
body:
Sources said the more than 20 commercial trucks, eight buses and a group of small vehicles were detained on 26 March while travelling between North Kordofan and West Kordofan states.

The RSF told the passengers to return to their places of origin and asked the trucks owners to abandon their vehicles, the report said.

It was not clear why the RSF detained the vehicles, but RSF reportedly “charge” commercial vehicles and motorists for using the road.

The RSF, which controls Um Samima town, has many checkpoints set up on the road that links En Nuhud town in West Kordofan to El-Obeid, the capital of North Kordofan state, which is controlled by rival Sudan’s army.

Source: Al-Taghyir (Al-Taghyeer) website, Khartoum, in Arabic 27 Mar 24

title: India opposition alliance to hold mega rally amid heavy police deployment
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

India's opposition coalition Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (I.N.D.I.A.) is set to hold a mega rally amid deployment of Delhi Police and paramilitary personnel in Delhi on 31 March, over several issues, including the arrest of Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal, respected daily The Hindu reported.
body:
The Congress said on 30 March that the event was focused on saving the Constitution and democracy and sending out a message of solidarity, it added.

It also said that the rally will raise issues like the ruling Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP)-led government's misuse of federal agencies, surging prices, unemployment rate, social polarisation, and farmers' demands among others. 

The Delhi Police has said that tractor trollies or weapons will not be allowed during the rally, news agency Press Trust of India reported.

Source: The Hindu website, Chennai, in English 0500 GMT 31 Mar 24

title: Islamabad says 'enemies of Pakistan-China friendship' carried out suicide attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan’s Foreign Office has said that a recent suicide attack in the country which killed five Chinese nationals was “orchestrated by the enemies of Pakistan-China friendship", leading English-language daily Dawn reported on its website.
body:
Five Chinese engineers and their Pakistani driver were killed in the bombing which took place on 26 March in northwest Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province’s Shangla district.

“Such despicable attacks further strengthen Pakistan’s resolve in combatting terrorism in all of its forms and manifestations…Pakistan and China are close friends and iron brothers. We have no doubt that the Bisham terror attack was orchestrated by the enemies of Pakistan-China friendship,” Foreign Office spokesperson Mumtaz Zahra Baloch was quoted as saying at a weekly press briefing on 28 March.

She added that Pakistan was “fully committed to bringing terrorists, and their facilitators and abettors to justice”.

China has demanded a thorough investigation into the blast while Pakistan has announced a swift probe into the incident.

The spokesperson also vowed to continue working with Beijing to ensure the safety of Chinese nationals and projects in the country.

See also: Briefing: Militants continue attacks on Chinese economic interests in Pakistan

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0909 GMT 28 Mar 24

title: Iran police arrest suspected member of Sunni militant group on southern island
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian police have apprehended a member of the Sunni militant group Jaish al-Adl (Army of Justice) in the southern province of Hormozgan, the official IRNA news agency reported on 25 March.
body:
Brigadier General Ali Akbar Javidan, the chief of police in Hormozgan, said the individual, identified as "A Seddiqi", was captured on Qeshm Island. He said the suspect has "multiple counter-security and criminal records, including armed robbery and fraud".

Javidan said the detained suspect had been previously apprehended in the Persian year 1401 (2022-23) for engaging in counter-security activities in Iranshahr, in the south-eastern province of Sistan-Baluchestan. He added that technical and police investigations were under way regarding the individual.

Sistan-Baluchestan, known as one of Iran's most economically disadvantaged provinces, frequently experiences clashes involving Jaish al-Adl. The group garners support from some Sunni Baluch tribes residing both within the province and across the border in Pakistan. Iran has designated Jaish al-Adl as a terrorist organisation and refers to it as Jaish al-Zolm (Army of Injustice).

See also: Explainer: Baluchi dissidence in Iran, Pakistan and Afghanistan

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 1242 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Somalia's interim Khatumo state launches new radio
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Somalia's Khatumo State, which was recently recognised by the Somali federal government, hasestablished a new Radio in the regional capital, Las Anod, privately-owned Radio Daljir reported on 4 March.
body:
"The radio, which is a mouthpiece for SSC [Sool, Sanaag and Ayn] was launched in Las Anod," Radio Daljir said.

Daljir did not provide additional details about the programming of the radio or the languages of broadcast.

SSC-Khatumo has been battling troops of the self-declared Somaliland for months in order to form its own independent state.

The Somali federal government on 19 October 2023 recognised Khatumo State as an interim administration and said it will work with its leaders.

Radio is the most important media source for many Somalis and all the regional administrations in the country operate their own radio and television stations.

The country's oral culture, common language and low literacy levels have made broadcast media sources popular.

Source: Radio Daljir, Gaalkacyo, in Somali on 4 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Kaliningrad Region Media 4-10 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from Kaliningrad's state-owned GTRK Kaliningrad TV, NTRK Kaskad TV, Newkaliningrad.ru and RBC Kaliningrad websites for the period 4-10 March 2024:

Domestic economic
body:
Kaliningrad's tulip industry is experiencing significant losses in 2024 due to tulip bulbs being added to an anti-Russian sanctions list, leading to a fivefold increase in import costs. This has resulted in empty stems, impacting flower prices. While exploring new suppliers, the region's government aims to achieve self-sufficiency in tulip bulb production within five years. (RBC Kaliningrad website, 5 March)

In Kaliningrad supermarkets, prices have slightly decreased, mainly due to significant discounts on the chicken fillet, which now averages 380-400 roubles (4.1 - 4.3 $) per kilogramme. Eggs have somewhat recovered from a previous sharp increase, now selling at 130-140 roubles (1.4-1.5 $) per dozen, compared to nearly half the price a year ago. Dairy prices stayed relatively stable, while prices for rice, buckwheat, and pasta fluctuated. Meanwhile, prices for apples, lemons, oranges, and bananas have increased in various stores. (New Kaliningrad website, 8 March)

The cancellation of subsidised air ticket sales has caused a public outcry. The local government spokesperson, Dmitry Lyskov, claimed that the sales are frozen for a programme overhaul, not due to funding shortages. Consequently, until 1 May, Kaliningrad's pensioners, students, and others must pay full fares. Lyskov said the situation is misrepresented, arguing that subsidised tickets were previously hard to obtain due to flaws in the system. (New Kaliningrad website, 10 March 24)

Other

Governor Anton Alikhanov inspected the damaged roads in Kaliningrad and demanded that the city redistribute funds from other expenses for urgent street repairs. It was also reported that Kaliningrad had decided to abandon the construction of two streets, with the city manager, Elena Dyatlova, proposing to reallocate funds from the regional budget for the road repairs. (GTRK Kaliningrad, NTRK Kaliningrad, 10 March 24)

Source: Kaliningrad Region media highlights, in Russian 1000 gmt 18 Mar 24

title: Tajik opposition group in Turkey says its leader missing
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The outlawed Tajik opposition movement Group 24 has said in a statement that its leader, Suhrob Zafar, has been missing in Turkey's Istanbul since 10 March, the Prague-based private Tajik website Bomdod.com reported on 11 March.
body:
According to the statement, the opposition leader has been unreachable since the morning of 10 March and his phone is also switched off. "No information is available about him and his whereabouts," it said. The statement added that Zafar, who has been living in Turkey since 2014, has been "receiving threatening messages" that "he will soon be killed or kidnapped and taken to Tajikistan".

This is the second case of a Group 24 member going missing in Istanbul over recent months. Nasimjon Sharifov, 39, another representative of Group 24 went missing on 23 February and his whereabouts remain unknown. 

The Turkish police had arrested both Zafar and Sharipov several times at the request of the Tajik authorities. However, Turkey rejected the request to extradite them to Tajikistan due to the fact that their cases were "politically motivated", and released them.

"So far the Tajik authorities have never succeeded in returning Group 24 members in Turkey via official means, that is through extradition. For this reason, his comrades do not rule out that Suhrob Zafar has been abducted," Bomdod noted.

Group 24 was set up by businessman-turned-opposition leader Umarali Quvvatov, who was killed in Istanbul in 2015, a year after the Tajik Supreme Court outlawed his organisation as "extremist". Dozens of people have been convicted and jailed in Tajikistan for membership in the group.

Last year, Tajikistan helped Turkey to kidnap two natives of Turkey, who were accused of having links to exiled cleric Fethullah Gulen. Emsal Koc and Koray Vural were kidnapped in the Tajik capital Dushanbe and taken to Turkey in the summer of 2023. Emsal Koc was the former head of the scientific and cultural organisation Dialogue in Dushanbe and Koray Vural was the director of one of the Tajik-Turkish lyceums in Dushanbe and had been engaged in business since the lyceum's closure.

Source: Bomdod, Prague, in Tajik 11 Mar 24

title: LRA rebels kidnap at least 70 youths in northern DR Congo
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The rebel group Lord Resistance Army (LRA) has kidnapped at least 70 youths in DR Congo's Haut Uele and Bas Uele provinces, the privately-owned Goma-based Top Congo FM Radio reported on 19 March.

title: Sudan's RSF accused of rape, sexual assault in central state
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Sudanese doctors' union has accused the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) of committing rape and sexual assault against girls and women in the central state of Gezira, the Amsterdam-based Radio Tamazuj website reported on 19 March.
body:
"The Sudan Doctors’ Union’s Preparatory Committee has accused members of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) of sexually assaulting three girls, one of whom is a nurse, at the El-Hasahisa Children’s Hospital in Gezira state," the website said.

"In a statement obtained by Radio Tamazuj, the Sudan Doctors’ Union affirmed that RSF members raped two girls who were accompanying patients at the children’s hospital and assaulted a nurse who tried to intervene and help the victims by raising an alarm," it added.

The group "urged those RSF elements responsible to be held accountable for the violations," it further added.

Human rights groups have repeatedly accused the RSF of committing atrocities including killings, rape and looting in areas under their control. The group denies the charges.

Source: Radio Tamazuj website, in English, 19 Mar 24

title: Outgoing Senegal leader votes in presidential election
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Outgoing President Macky Sall and First Lady Marieme Sall voted in his home town of Fatick, north-east of the capital Dakar, state-run RTS1 reported on 24 March.

title: Pakistan's PTV show on top court's ruling in Bhutto's death sentence review
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Riasat" (The State), hosted by anchor Shahzad Raza on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 6 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Anchor Shahzad Raza said the Supreme Court gave a ruling in the Zulfikar Ali Bhutto (former president and prime minister) reference case on 6 March and stated that a fair trial was not held. He noted Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif welcomed the ruling and said redressal of the mistake is not possible, but admission of the mistake is a good move.
body:
Raza said around 44 years ago, Bhutto was given a death sentence and his party [Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP)] and the Bhutto family kept saying that it was a "judicial murder". He mentioned former president Asif Ali Zardari sent a presidential reference to the Supreme Court in 2008 for a review of the judgement. Raza said it is a welcome development that an institution has admitted its mistake.

Raza asked senior lawyer Yasin Azad why a decision on the reference took such a long time. Azad noted Asif Ali Zardari sent the reference when he was the president and the judgement has been given at a time when Zardari might again be made the president on 9 March. He said usually the trial of a murder case is conducted in a sessions court, but Bhutto's case was initiated directly in the Lahore High Court. He added out of the seven judges, three had declared that it was not a murder case and ordered Bhutto's acquittal, but four judges upheld the death sentence. He mentioned Justice Nasim Hasan Shah, a member of the bench hearing the case, later wrote in his book and also said in a TV interview that Bhutto's sentence was a judicial murder.

Azad claimed everyone in Pakistan said that Bhutto's sentence was against the law. He said he would give credit to the present-day Supreme Court, headed by Chief Justice Qazi Faez Isa, which took up the review case. He remarked in a short order, the Supreme Court as an institution, has admitted that requirements of justice were not fulfilled.

Azad said there are several other cases in which "disputed judgements" have been issued and they should be revisited by a full court. He complained the parliament "does not play its due role in legislation". He noted ever since Chief Justice Isa has taken over the office, the Supreme Court has "recognised the supremacy of the parliament", which is a welcome development. He said there are many "difficulties" in the Constitution which should be removed by the parliament.

PPP politician Syed Hasan Murtaza said it is good that such a verdict has been given which has "helped in correcting the history" and a family [referring to the Bhutto family] has finally been awarded justice after 44 years. He was of the view that it would have been better if a verdict had been issued which stated that it was a judicial murder and had also identified the murderers.

Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Raja Qamar ul Islam, noting that the correction came after 44 years, said it is "better late than never" and termed it a sign of "judicial evolution". He noted the PML-N and PPP remained hostile towards each other for several years but they also signed a "charter of democracy" and resolved to move forward after admitting their mistakes.

Speaking about the controversy around the recent election results and the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf's (PTI) allegations that the results were manipulated, Azad said the PTI will have to prove its allegations before the election tribunals through evidence.

Commenting on the continuous protests by the PTI, Murtaza remarked such acts are damaging to the country and the democratic system. He urged Imran Khan (former PTI chairperson) to stop the confrontation and maintain a "working relationship" in the parliament as political instability would further devastate the economy.

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 6 Mar 24

title: BBCM Ukraine Watchlist 29 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Ukrainian broadcast, press and social media sources

ONE PLUS ONE TV
body:
DAY 1,283 OF RUSSIAN INVASION OF UKRAINE

Day of mourning in Kyiv

Kyiv is observing a day of mourning on 29 August after a Russian combined drone-and-missile strike killed 23 and injured over 60 civilians the previous day, the Ukrayinska Pravda news and analysis website reported.

As many as 225 residential buildings were damaged across the city, it added.

According to the pooled TV service, the search-and-rescue operation continues in Kyiv's Darnytskyy district with at least seven people believed to be missing.

"This strike clearly shows that Russia's goals have not changed. They want war - and they are striking not only our people, not only our cities and communities. Russia is now striking at everyone in the world who seeks peace. It is a strike against Ukraine. It is a strike against Europe. And it is also a strike by Russia against President Trump, and against other global actors," President Volodymyr Zelensky said in his nightly address.

Zelensky noted that other Ukrainian cities are also suffering from Russia's deliberate strikes on civilian infrastructure and called on the international community to take "strong steps" to "compel" Russian leader Vladimir Putin to end the war.

"Russia kills every day. Therefore, every day they must feel the pain for what they are doing. And this is possible. The world's sanctions. Tariffs. Support for Ukraine. Our strong army. Our ability to defend lives and respond powerfully to the Russian war machine," Zelensky added.

Zelensky holds online talks with leaders of Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Denmark

During a coordination online meeting with the leaders of Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Denmark, Zelensky noted a "negative signal" from Russia regarding his possible talks with Putin.

"Honestly, we think Putin is still interested only in continuing this war. That's exactly why we need new strong pressure on Russia - tough sanctions, strong tariffs, both from Europe and from America," the Ukrainian president's official website quoted Zelensky as saying.

"Putin has not done what he said. It's time to move. We need a strong joint signal. And it would really help if that signal also came from you, dear friends," Zelensky said.

"And when we talk about security guarantees, we need clear answers - who will help us defend on the ground, in the air and at sea if Russia comes again. And how exactly you can take part - I'm asking you to define your role."

Zelensky also took to X to thank Polish counterpart Karol Nawrocki for organising the virtual summit.

"Our strength is in our unity. And it is reassuring that our stance is unanimous: more pressure on Russia is needed to bring peace," Zelensky said in English.

Ukraine-Hungary row

President Zelensky condemned Hungary for banning Ukrainian Unmanned Systems Forces Commander Robert Brovdi (Magyar), an ethnic Hungarian, from entering Hungary and the Schengen zone.

"If Hungary has indeed closed entry into Hungary and the entire Schengen zone to one of Ukraine's military commanders, who is an ethnic Hungarian and a citizen of Ukraine, this can only cause outrage," Zelensky said.

According to Zelensky, "Hungarian officials have gone so far as to attempt to discriminate against members of the Hungarian community in Ukraine for their participation in the defence of our state and our people".

"I have instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine to clarify all the facts and respond accordingly," he added.

Earlier on 28 August, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said on X that Brovdi had been banned due to Ukraine's strikes on Russia's Druzhba pipeline supplying oil to Hungary.

The Foreign Ministry summoned the Hungarian ambassador, Foreign Minister Andriy Sybiha said.

"He was given a protest note in response to Hungary's discrimination against the Hungarian minority in Ukraine, particularly our Hungarian-descent defender who was banned from entering the country of his ancestors. We urge Hungary to further refrain from unfriendly actions and instead engage in constructive dialogue, for which Ukraine remains ready," Sybiha said on X in English.

Earlier Sybiha lambasted his Hungarian counterpart Peter Szijjarto for banning Brovdi, while Magyar himself took to Facebook to respond to the ban. In particular, he accused Szijjarto of being "complicit in the multiplication of blood money" by defending Russian oil supplies and told him to "shove your sanctions and restrictions on visiting Hungary up your ass".

The story took another twist after Polish Foreign Minister voiced support for Brovdi.

"While Russian missiles rain death on Kyiv, Hungary bans a brave ethnic Hungarian who dares to fight for Ukraine's freedom. Commander Magyar: if you need some R&R and Hungary won't let you in, please be our guest in Poland," Sikorski said on X in English.

"Endangering Hungary's energy security has nothing to do with the freedom of Ukraine!" Szijjarto retorted.

Sybiha welcomed Sikorski's statement.

"Well said @sikorskiradek. Official Budapest, in its flirtation with the aggressor, has gone so far as to threaten and violate the rights of members of the Hungarian national minority. The reasons behind the blocking of Ukraine's path to the EU are now becoming blatantly obvious," he said on X in English.

"The scandal with Hungary's sanctions against Unmanned Systems Forces Commander Robert Brovdi (Magyar) has become a pan-European story. It showed the stance on Ukraine and its warriors defending their land," the reputable ZN.ua website said on Facebook.

Overnight attack
