title: Pakistan's Samaa TV show on political confrontation, trial by military courts
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Nadeem Malik Live" hosted by anchor Nadeem Malik, a senior journalist and analyst, on moderate Samaa News TV in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 25 March 2024. The programme invites politicians and analysts to express their opinions on important issues.

Anchor Nadeem Malik commented no political party or worker can defend the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged members of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, PTI). He was of the view that the incidents were a result of a "flawed political approach" and took place after heightened "polarisation" that developed in the country. He remarked 9 May has rightly been termed a "black day".
body:
Malik said political workers arrested for their involvement in the 9 May incidents can be divided into two categories: first, those who actively indulged in arson and vandalism and second, those who joined rallies and chanted slogans. He added the question is whether these people should face trials in military or civilian courts. He noted while hearing the case on 25 March, the Supreme Court questioned how many people accused in the 9 May incidents have been found innocent in the military courts, and the prosecution could not answer it. He argued military courts are "not acceptable in a democratic country", so civilian courts should be empowered to handle such cases.

Malik noted rumours of formation of a "forward bloc" of the PTI in the Punjab Assembly have been circulating lately. He said it is to be seen whether there is any truth in these reports.

Malik spoke with Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Azma Bokhari whether everyone accused in the 9 May incidents should be awarded the same sentence or some distinction should be maintained. Bokhari said according to the criminal law, punishments should be awarded according to the actions of the accused. She claimed the PTI has been denying its involvement in the incidents despite evidence.

Bokhari said the PTI has neither condemned, nor disassociated itself from those involved in the attacks. She noted the PTI has nominated people like Murad Saeed who have been declared "proclaimed offenders" in the 9 May incidents for National Assembly (lower house of the parliament) and Senate (upper house of the parliament) elections. Replying to a question on which courts should people face trials in, she said it is very clear that if someone has intruded into an airbase or the Army's headquarters, "they cannot be tried under the Land Revenue Act" and trials in such cases are held under the Military Act.

Malik asked former Sindh governor Imran Ismail whether those involved in the 9 May incidents should face trial in military courts. Ismail said everyone, including members and leaders of the PTI, condemned the 9 May incidents. However, he added, it is the responsibility of government institutions to hold investigations and initiate trials. He expressed the view that it should be decided whether someone should be tried in a military or civilian court based on investigations.

Ismail said every government in Pakistan tries to get the support of the military and security institutions, while those in the opposition criticise these institutions. He emphasised politicians should stop seeking help from the military and perform their duties on their own. He condemned the 9 May incidents and agreed that it was a "black day".

Replying to a question on whether he would re-join the PTI, Ismail said he has not made a final decision in this regard. Responding to a question on how the current confrontation can be resolved, he said it is an ideal suggestion that all major parties should sit together and try to find a solution to the issues, but it is not happening because the government which should show flexibility seems to be "bending backwards" to oppose the PTI.

PTI politician Zain Qureshi said what happened on 9 May should not have happened, but whether the PTI had any role in it is to be determined by the courts. He termed the 9 May incidents a "false flag operation" and claimed thousands of PTI workers have been put in jail without any evidence. He emphasised the legal system should not be "politicised" or "weaponised". Commenting on reports about a forward bloc in the PTI, he said all PTI members are loyal to the party and there is no truth in these rumours.

Source: Samaa TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1500 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Experts highlight significance of India's new naval base in Lakshadweep
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

India's English-language news channel NewsX has held a discussion on the importance of the development of a naval base on Minicoy Island in federally-ruled territory Lakshadweep.
body:
The news anchor, Devika Chopra, noted that the base, named INS Jatayu, will boost the navy's operations against piracy and narcotics in the Arabian Sea. It will also strengthen the navy's surveillance capabilities, she said during the programme aired on 3 March.

NewsX is an English-language channel supportive of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).

Defence expert UK Devnath, interviewed on the show, noted the geographical proximity of Minicoy Island to the Maldives. He said that deployment of ships and aircraft close to it will "go a long way in ensuring our ability to keep a surveillance on mischievous activities” by navies, especially the Chinese navy.

He also pointed out that the base would help all Indian ships operating in the Arabian Sea replenish logistical items including consumables.

Another analyst Robinder Sachdev noted that the development of the base coincides with India’s growing geopolitical importance and the base would help the country protect its sovereignty.

He added that considering Minicoy Island’s strategic location, it will help India project its naval abilities. He highlighted that India will also be able to monitor Chinese "maritime expansionism" in the Indian Ocean as well as "play a bigger role" in the region.

According to another analyst AK Siwach, the new base will help India economically as well as militarily. 

India has realised the importance of gaining influence in the Arabian Sea and the development of the Jatayu base would have "tremendous impact" on India’s efforts in countering Chinese influence in the Maldives as well as in the Indian Ocean, Siwach said.

Source: NewsX in English 0921 GMT 3 Mar 24

title: Highlights from press, websites in Indian-administered Kashmir 20 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a selection of major news items from select Urdu, English and Kashmiri-language press and online media sources in Indian-administered Kashmir on 20 March 2024.

Tameel-I-Irshad
body:
Senior BSF officer visits LoC, reviews operational preparedness

Y B Khurania, Special Director General (SDG) of the Chandigarh-based Western Command of the Border Security Force (BSF), on 19 March visited the forward areas along the Line of Control (LoC) in north Kashmir's Kupwara district and reviewed operational preparedness of the troops on ground. According to unidentified sources, the visit comes at a time when the vigil along the LoC in Jammu and Kashmir has been stepped up after the announcement of the parliamentary elections in the country. With the snow starting to melt on the high mountain passes along the LoC, the counter-infiltration grid has also been put on high alert. Unidentified officials said the Special DG, besides reviewing the ground situation, also interacted with troops and applauded them for their unwavering performance under challenging situations. The BSF is deployed along the LoC in Kashmir and works under the operational control of the Indian Army. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[Urdu-language Tameel-I-Irshad is a pro-Kashmir separatist daily that focuses on local issues in Indian-administered Kashmir. The daily favours India-Pakistan talks for the resolution of the Kashmir dispute.]

Srinagar Times

Regional parties hint at pre-poll alliance in Jammu and Kashmir

The Jammu and Kashmir Apni Party (JKAP) and the Democratic Progressive Azad Party (DPAP) on 19 March said they are open to discussions with "like-minded" parties for a pre-poll alliance ahead of the forthcoming parliamentary elections in Jammu and Kashmir. JKAP general secretary Rafi Mir said the party is trying to talk to various like-minded parties who want to work for the prosperity of the people. Mir, however, ruled out any tie-up of Altaf Bukhari-led JKAP with the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), for now, due to ideological differences. Meanwhile, chief spokesperson of the DPAP, Salman Nizami, said discussions with like-minded parties for the alliance were in initial stages. He said the final decision in this regard will be made by DPAP chairman Ghulam Nabi Azad. [Online, Approximate Words: 150]

[Urdu-language Srinagar Times is a pro-Kashmir separatist, pro-militant daily that focuses on local issues in Indian-administered Kashmir. The daily favours talks with Pakistan for the resolution of the Kashmir dispute.]

Nida-I-Mashriq

Editorial says efforts to create divide between Jammu, Kashmir

A 20 March editorial said there are nefarious attempts to create a divide between Jammu region and Kashmir on political, ideological, and sectarian grounds for political gains. The editorial said: "Along with the reorganisation of Jammu and Kashmir, in which the state was divided into two parts, the new demarcation of legislative assembly and local body constituencies is disrupting the electoral fabric of Kashmir and Jammu. The division is still acceptable to people to some extent, but the way the division is now being brought forward along the political, regional, religious, sectarian and caste-based lines, only a few people will benefit from it. No political party cares about this loss and division. On the contrary, every political party sees this division as the means of fulfilling their political interests. The division will prove to be a killer of the unity, integrity, public brotherhood, and communal amity between Kashmir and Jammu. People are divided on different political beliefs and ideological lines, which itself is not desirable for the development of the two regions and can prove to be extremely harmful in coming days." [Online, Approximate Words: 850]

[Urdu-language daily Nida-I-Mashriq is a pro-separatist daily that focuses on local issues of Kashmir. The daily is critical of the state and the federal government, and favours talks with separatists and Pakistan for the resolution of Kashmir.]

Daily Chattan

Editorial calls for clean, transparent elections in Kashmir

A 20 March editorial said while the ruling alliance, led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), has started campaigning for the forthcoming parliamentary elections in Jammu and Kashmir in a big way, there has been no organised campaigning by the opposition parties so far. The editorial called for clean and transparent elections in the region. It said: "After the announcement of dates for the parliamentary elections, preparations in Jammu and Kashmir are going on in a big way. The ruling alliance has already started campaigning in Jammu and Kashmir and election rallies are being held at various places. Several federal ministers are also expected to participate in the rallies. However, no organised campaign has been started by the opposition parties so far. No political party in the opposition has yet organised any major rally at any place. Meanwhile, electronic voting machines have reportedly been delivered to Srinagar. To maintain the dignity of democracy and the sanctity of votes, it is necessary to make the entire election process clean and transparent. Complete impartiality on the part of the Election Commission is very important to make election campaigning dignified." [Online, Approximate Words: 700]

[Urdu-language Daily Chattan is a pro-Kashmir separatist, pro-militant daily that is popular in the northern part of Indian-administered Kashmir. The daily favours talks with Pakistan for the resolution of the Kashmir dispute.]

Daily Aftab

Editorial calls for preservation of Kashmiri culture

A 20 March editorial said the Kashmiri language and culture are dying, and there is an urgent need to preserve it. The editorial said: "The Kashmiri people themselves are determined to strangle their culture, civilisation, language, and literature. Today, the situation is such that the funeral of Kashmiri language and literature has been taken out. People have forgotten the Kashmiri lifestyle; speaking of culture, the next generations will not know who the Kashmiri people were, how they lived, what their language was like. It is often seen that the Kashmiri language has no importance for the new generation and even small children avoid speaking in Kashmiri. Many people feel inferior wearing Kashmiri clothes. When we look at other nations, they have strongly held on to their language and literature, lifestyle and culture. Ladakhis proudly wear such clothes and it makes them recognisable from a distance. In southern India, people do not feel ashamed to go out wearing dhotis and speak only in their language. There is no shame in it. In comparison, we teach our children other languages, not Kashmiri. The Kashmiri women have forgotten their traditional dress. The ways of living, eating and drinking have changed. Therefore, respectable citizens of Kashmir, personalities associated with Kashmiri language and literature should go ahead and make efforts to save their culture. Every possible method should be adopted." [Online, Approximate Words: 650]

[Urdu-language Daily Aftab is a pro-separatist daily that focuses on local issues of Kashmir valley. The daily is critical of the state and the federal government, and favours talks with separatists and Pakistan for the resolution of India-Pakistan dispute over Kashmir.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Urdu and Kashmiri 20 Mar 24

title: TV talk show discusses foreign forces' alleged war crimes in Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Afghan commentators appearing on the private Ariana News TV's Tahawol (Change) debate programme on 27 March discussed the allegations levelled by UK's Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Johnny Mercer, that members of Britain's SAS (Special Air Service) were engaged in "war crimes" during their mission in Afghanistan.

title: Highlights from Pakistan's Sindhi-language TV, press 14 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items published in Pakistan's Sindhi-language TV and press media outlets on 14 March 2024.

Awami Awaz
body:
Parliament passes resolution to declare former PM Bhutto a martyr

The National Assembly (lower house of parliament) has passed, with majority votes, a resolution declaring former prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto a national martyr and his death sentence illegal. The resolution was tabled by the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) member, Shazia Marri. The resolution says that the reference against Bhutto's sentence was filed in the Supreme Court by President Zardari and pursued by PPP chairperson, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari. [The Supreme Court had recently in its opinion on the case had said that Bhutto was not given a fair trial.] The Senate and the provincial assemblies (parliaments) of Sindh, Punjab and Balochistan recently passed similar resolutions. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 200]

Former PM Khan warns of Pakistan becoming like Sri Lanka

Founder of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party and former prime minister, Imran Khan, talking to journalists at the Adiala Jail in Rawalpinidi (in Punjab province) said that the hopes of the nation were shattered by rigging at the (8 February) elections. He said that all his reservations are proving correct and now Pakistan is going to be "like Sri Lanka". Khan said that inflation will increase further and the people will be on the streets. He said that the country is being run on lies. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

[Daily Awami Awaz is a progressive, secular and liberal, left-leaning Sindhi-language newspaper published from Karachi, Sindh. The daily possesses a good reputation among relatively educated and aware people. It is regarded as the "Dawn" of Sindhi-language newspapers.]

Ibrat

Pakistan fulfils conditions for IMF tranche

Pakistan has fulfilled all conditions of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to receive the last tranche of its standby programme. The finance ministry has said that the negotiations with the IMF delegation will continue from 14 to 18 March. Meanwhile, the federal Minister of Finance, Muhammad Aurangzeb, has said that Pakistan wants a bigger and long-term new programme from the IMF. He also said that the Pakistani economy will improve with this new programme. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

Sindh cabinet briefed about law and order situation

Sindh's Minister of Interior, Zia Lanjar, briefed the Sindh cabinet about law and order in the province. Lanjar told the meeting that no one involved in street crime in Karachi (capital city of Sindh) will be spared. He also told the meeting that his priority is to crush the dacoits in the riverine areas of upper Sindh. He said that honest and upright police officers will be deployed to disturbed areas. Lanjar said that paramilitary forces will also be used against the dacoits in the riverine areas. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

[Daily Ibrat is a moderate Sindhi-language newspaper owned by the politically influential Qazi family of Sindh, traditionally affiliated with Pakistan Peoples Party. The daily is published from Hyderabad, Sindh. Readers over 40 years of age prefer reading Daily Ibrat.]

Kawish

Sindh rejects appointment of river authority chief

The Sindh government has criticised the appointment of the new chairperson of the Indus River System Authority (IRSA) and demanded of the federal government to withdraw this appointment. Sindh's Minister of Irrigation, Jam Khan Shoro, has strongly protested and made this demand. A former chairman of the Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA), Zafar Mahmood, has been appointed chairperson of IRSA) through an ordinance issued during the previous caretaker government. Mahmood has been a strong advocate of the disputed Kalabagh dam. Three provinces - Sindh, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and Balochistan - had opposed the construction of the Kalabagh dam in the past. Moreover, the appointment of the IRSA chairperson is carried out from among IRSA members from every province and the federal government. Mahmood is not from among these members, which is a violation of the IRSA Act. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 250]

Information minister says PTI opposing GSP Plus status

Federal Minister for Information, Attaullah Tarar, when addressing a press conference in national capital Islamabad on 13 March, said that the PTI has written a letter to the European Union (EU) asking to withdraw the GSP Plus status (which allows for trade concessions) from Pakistan. Tarar said that with the GSP Plus status, the Pakistani currency will be stablised. He said that the PTI does not want the economy to improve. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 200]

[Daily Kawish is the most widely read Sindhi-language newspaper published from Hyderabad, Sindh. The paper is popular among young people and has a liberal and progressive editorial policy. It is also the largest circulated daily.]

Hot Issues (Prime-Time Talk Show on Sindh TV News at 14:00 GMT)

Discussion on economic situation, IRSA chairperson

Anchor Sabeen Memon said that they would discuss the country's economic situation. She noted that an IMF delegation is to come to Pakistan for negotiations for the last installment of a standby programme. What will be the impact of the IMF conditions on the common people of Pakistan, Memon asked. In the second part of the programme, she said they would discuss the appointment of the new IRSA chairperson, who is an advocate of the disputed Kalabagh dam. Panellists included economist Jabbar Memon, and senior journalists Qurban Baloch and Khaleeq Kiani.

Memon said, "The finance minister has been appointed and it seems that he is well aware of the economic situation. There is no doubt that he is a banker and a very successful one. It has yet to be seen whether he can be an economist or not. This portfolio will be good for his CV. If he overcomes the crises of economy and climate change, then he will be successful. He has said that Pakistan will seek a long-term and extended programme. Everyone knows that we need to expand our tax base so that we can increase our revenue collection. We have to bring about reforms to our tax system and real estate, retail and agriculture sectors have to pay taxes. We need to build the trust of the people in the government. The government high officials have to give up their perks and privileges."

Kiani said, "Zafar Mahmood is the former chairman of WAPDA and this appointment seems to be a violation of the IRSA Act, which was prepared by all the four provinces. This appointment will annoy the provinces. The IRSA chairman has to be a member of IRSA from the province or the federation. I think all four provinces will have reservations on this appointment. This appointment has to be reversed. President Zardari will have to play his leadership role. Now, IRSA will be under the Ministry of Water Resources. This is a dangerous appointment, which may disturb the federation."

Baloch said, "This is an issue of giving IRSA total control of the federal government. No notification of this appointment has been issued by the establishment division. This is a violation of the IRSA Act, which says that the chairman can only be from among the members of IRSA. The Sindh Minister of Irrigation, Jam Khan Shoro, has also condemned this appointment. It seems that the autonomy of IRSA is no more and it has come under the federal government. I think that the provinces should approach the Council of Common Interests (CCI). This amendment to the IRSA Act, which allows a chairman from outside IRSA members, was done during the caretaker government."

[Sindh TV News is the second largest Sindhi-language TV channel and supports nationalist views.]

Insight with Najia Mir (Prime-Time Talk Show on KTN News at 15:00 GMT)

Discussion on economy

Anchor Najia Mir said that after the federal government, provincial cabinets have also been formed. Some new faces have been introduced, she said. Will this be able to end the political and economic crises, Mir asked. Panellists included former diplomat GR Baloch, economist Asad Ali Shah and analyst Professor Abdul Majeed Chandio. 

Shah said, "Aurangzeb is the new finance minister and is a clear-headed banker. Whatever we earn through taxes goes into debt retirement and we take more loans to run the country. Our economy is still in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). The standby agreement is ending in March and we will get the last [IMF] tranche. We need continuous support from the IMF. Unfortunately, no political party had provided an economic programme in its election manifesto. We have to see how the new finance minister tackles the economic challenges. Our politics is very polarised. I do not see any disruption to economic activity because of political disputes. The next two to three years will be very difficult for our economy. We need to get an extended programme from the IMF worth $7-8bn. With this, we have to bring reforms to our economy."

Baloch said, "Our economic structure has holes in it and there are dozens of government enterprises in loss. This is bleeding our economy. I think that the only solution is the privatising of these loss-making enterprises. The power [electricity] theft is also alarming. There should be an economic advisory board that should look into the economic quagmire. The members should be independent economists and not government servants. We have to stop the bleeding of our economy. Tax evasion is also a huge problem. Only technical experts can take tough decisions. Our economy has to stand on its own feet and for this we have to be on a treatment table for a long time. The foreign policy of every country reflects its internal strength, both political and economic. The political parties should have a grand dialogue on stabilising our economy and politics."

Chandio said, "The finance minister said that he will reduce the interest rate. The IMF wants to increase the tax base. We also need to increase our exports. We can export cotton and other agricultural products. The economy will not improve if we ourselves do not think of out-of-the-box solutions. The PPP wants a public-private partnership whereas I think that the only solution is complete privatisation. The PTI is trying to de-stabilise our economy by writing to the IMF and European Union (EU) not to help Pakistan. It is so unfortunate that no political party has an economic team. The grand political dialogue should also include regional political parties. We need to address our governance as well."

[KTN News is the most widely watched Sindhi-language news TV Channel owned by Kawish media group, which also owns Daily Kawish. The channel has a liberal position and is normally critical of Pakistan Peoples Party.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Sindhi 14 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's PTV show on newly appointed cabinet of ministers
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Riasat" (The State), hosted by anchor Shahzad Raza on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 11 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Anchor Shahzad Raza said newly elected President Asif Ali Zardari administered oath to a 19-member federal cabinet on 11 March. He noted Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif has included "very seasoned people" in his cabinet but portfolios of the ministers have not yet been announced.
body:
Raza asked Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Qaiser Ahmed Shaikh whether he would be assigned a ministry related to business and economy. Shaikh agreed and remarked one can perform only if he is assigned a task in which he has a background and experience. He noted "business confidence" in Pakistan is at the lowest ebb and the main task before the government at the moment is to fix the economy. He mentioned the prime minister spoke in detail about the economic issues and expressed the resolve that his government's full-fledged attention would be on the economy.

Raza asked Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) politician Nadir Gabol whether his party would join the cabinet at a later stage. Gabol replied Bilawal Bhutto Zardari (PPP chairperson) has repeatedly stated that his party would not join the cabinet but would support Shehbaz Sharif's government on an "issue to issue basis". He said the objective of it is to give Sharif a chance to focus on governance and select a cabinet of his choice. He added the PPP wants that relief should be provided to the people and the issue of terrorism should also be addressed.

Gabol said the PPP might review its decision about joining the cabinet after a few years if the situation improves. He explained his party does not want to join the cabinet because its ideology is very different from that of the PML-N as the former is a "progressive centre-left party".

Raza asked analyst Sana Mirza whether political stability is expected since Asif Ali Zardari from the PPP has been elected as the president and the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has also joined the parliament. Mirza replied, "If we think that the PTI will sit quietly because it is now in the parliament, it is wrong". She noted after elections, the PTI claimed that its right has been taken away as other parties have formed a government.

Mirza claimed the PTI will not let the parliament work if its demands are not addressed. She noted Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur has demanded that a commission should be formed to look into the election results and the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged PTI members after the arrest of the then-chairperson Imran Khan) but it would be a lengthy process. She further noted PTI politician Asad Qaiser claimed if a "certain personality [referring to former chief minister of Punjab Mohsin Naqvi]" is appointed as the interior minister, "doors of talks would be closed permanently". She said the PTI has alleged that Naqvi played an important role in the rigging of elections in Punjab.

Mirza said the people included in the cabinet are those who can work with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif. She claimed the [military] establishment also had some influence in the selection of the cabinet. She was of the view that a "technocrat government" is needed at the moment to solve the economic problems of the country.

Shaikh noted the allegations of election rigging have been levelled by the PTI in every election. He appreciated the PPP's decision to support the PML-N government and said by not joining the cabinet, PPP has allowed the PML-N to form its government and adopt its manifesto. He termed it a "favour by the PPP" and expressed hope in the two parties working in coordination with each other.

Shaikh said Prime Minister Sharif is "dedicated" and "determined" to solve the economic problems, increasing exports, and promoting industries. He remarked the government's direction will become clear in the next few months. He was of the view that the PTI would not continue its protests for a very long time because that would make it unpopular among its voters. He opined the government would decrease the interest rate gradually because an interest rate over 10 to 12 per cent would be unfavourable for business development.

Gabol said President Zardari would not have executive powers but he would play a different role. He recalled during his previous tenure, Zardari had contributed significantly to economic matters.

Shaikh disagreed with the view that the government would not be stable and insisted Pakistan is at a "make or break stage". He said the country cannot continue taking more loans, so all stakeholders will have to sit together. He was of the view that "drastic changes" would be brought by the new government regarding allocation of funds to different areas. He also mentioned election reforms would be discussed in the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament).

Mirza said the team chosen by Prime Minister Sharif includes people who have proven themselves as good administrators. She was of the view that Sharif is the "ultimate choice for prime ministership" at the time when Pakistan is facing many issues and he should try to perform with a "limited team".

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Pakistan paper warns against 'complacency' amid climate change threat
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An editorial in English-language Pakistani newspaper Daily Times has underscored Pakistan's "growing vulnerability to climate change".
body:
Daily Times is a moderate newspaper, which is generally critical of jihadist groups.

"Recent deaths in some parts of Balochistan and India-held Kashmir [Indian-administered Kashmir] due to heavy rains and landslides serve as a stark reminder to the new government in the wake of Pakistan's growing vulnerability to climate change," said the editorial on 11 March.

"While major cities like Karachi and other urban areas remained safe from untimely rains, heavy rains and unseasonal snowfall in Balochistan and northern areas showcase a concerning picture, and perhaps warn the people about upcoming times," it warned.

"Memories of last year's floods, which impacted over 30 million people, are still fresh. Pakistan, already categorised as one of the countries most susceptible to climate change, faces a heightened threat. The time for complacency is over," it emphasised. 

Listing possible actions, the editorial said that "firstly, institutions responsible for disaster management, including disaster management authorities and irrigation departments, must begin immediate preparedness efforts."

"Secondly, raising public awareness is crucial. Educating the public on flood safety measures, early warning systems, and evacuation procedures will empower them to respond effectively in case of emergencies. Thirdly, long-term climate change mitigation strategies cannot be ignored," it added.

"Fourthly, international cooperation is paramount. The government must actively participate in global climate change dialogues and seek assistance in mitigation efforts and adaptation strategies," it further said.

Reiterating the call for action, the paper said that "it is time to act. We can choose to ignore the warning signs and face the consequences, or we can act collectively, embracing proactive solutions." 

See also: Pakistani daily urges development of 'comprehensive' climate adaptation policy

Source: Daily Times website, Lahore, in English 0000 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Highlights from Maldives' Dhivehi-language press, websites 8 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items published in Maldives' Dhivehi-language press and online media outlets on 8 March 2024.

Sun.mv
body:
Ex-speaker continues to be lawmaker despite being abroad

Former speaker of parliament and Member for Machchangolhu Medhu constituency, Mohamed Nasheed, has spent over a month abroad, while being a lawmaker. Nasheed, who had been speaker during a large part of the current parliament term, had resigned after the Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP) submitted two no-confidence motions against him. On 12 December 2023, Nasheed announced that he was stepping away from politics and moved to Ghana on 30 January, where he has taken on the role of Secretary General of the Climate Vulnerability Forum (CVF). He has, however, still not resigned from him parliament seat. The President of The Democrats, of which Nasheed is a member, Hassan Latheef, when questioned on the matter, said Nasheed had issued a statement prior to moving to Ghana, and as such he had no role in the matter in his capacity as party president. The parliament secretariat on 31 January had said Nasheed had not informed the secretariat of his move to Ghana, that he had not taken leave, and would continue to receive the salary and benefits as a representative of the parliament for the three months remaining in his term. [Online, Approximate Words: 350]

[This is a prominent Dhivehi-language news website that generally carries objective reporting. It is owned by the Sun Media Group, the largest private media house in the Maldives.]

Avas

President pledges to allocate tax revenue to local councils

President Dr Mohamed Muizzu on 7 March announced that a certain percentage of revenue collected by the Maldives Inland Revenue Authority (MIRA) will be allocated to local councils. At a meeting he held with residents of Keyodhoo in Vaavu Atoll, the president said amendments will be brought to tax laws to implement the said change, which will allow councils to provide services in the islands using these funds. In addition, he also announced that changes will be made to the Goods and Services Act and the Tourism Act, to allocate a certain percentage of GST collected from guesthouses in the islands to the island council. The president said these changes will need to be made through the parliament and appealed to the public on the need for a parliament that extends cooperation to the government (parliament elections are scheduled for 21 April and the opposition currently holds a majority). [Online, Approximate Words: 250]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website run by "Mundoo" Adam Haleem and owned by former lawmaker Abdullah Sinan. The website is generally critical of the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party and Jumhooree Party.]

Mihaaru

Government to reduce raw fish exports to zero

Minister of Fisheries and Ocean Resources Ahmed Shiyam on 7 March, at a press conference held to share progress on the government's 100-day pledges for the sector, said the government's objective is to reduce the export of raw fish from the country to zero. Shiyam highlighted that the addition of value will increase revenue for the sector, noting that 75% of current fish exports is as raw material. The previous Solih administration had also said the fisheries sector can only be diversified and value increased by reducing the exports of raw fish, and instead add value in the country prior to export. Efforts were also made during that administration to increase processing capacity and extend cold storage facilities, although none of these efforts came to fruition. [Online, Approximate Words: 230]

[Mihaaru is a Dhivehi-language daily that generally carries objective reporting and does not appear to favour any political party. The newspaper widely covers political developments, radicalisation, and counter-terrorism-related developments in the Maldives.]

Raajje.mv

Minister sets new deadline for payments to fishermen

Minister of Fisheries and Ocean Resources Ahmed Shiyam on 7 March announced that 280m rufiyaa ($18.2m) remains outstanding to fishermen for fish purchases and, despite a previous deadline to pay the outstanding by 5 March, 50m rufiyaa ($3.2m) will be issued on 5 March. At a press conference held by the ministry, he reiterated that the backlog will be cleared by the beginning of Ramadan (10 March). Fishermen had protested at the government fish purchase and processing facility due to delays in payments due to them. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[This is the Dhivehi-language website of widely watched, privately-run television news channel Raajje TV that supports the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website provides detailed coverage of government actions and statements and sometimes criticises Chinese involvement in the Maldives.]

Vaguthu

President concludes tour of three atolls

President Muizzu on 7 March returned to capital after concluding his tour of Dhaalu, Meemu, and Vaavu Atolls. The tour is part of a series of visits the president has embarked on with the objective of visiting all atolls across the country and meeting with all local councils during the year. The president has to date met with 145 councils across the country. Muizzu has announced that a similar visit to all islands will be made in 2026. The president meets with the local councils, women's development committees, and residents of the islands during his visits. [Online, Approximate Words: 250]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website that was founded by a youth group that favours the ruling Progressive Party of Maldives and People's National Congress and criticises politicians from the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website generally backs China and strongly criticises India.]

Channel News Maldives

Parliament condemns minister's statements

The Maldivian parliament on 7 March issued a statement condemning statements by the Minister of Cities, Local Government and Public Works, Adam Shareef. Shareef, at a meeting held by President Muizzu with residents of Dhiggaru island in Meemu Atoll, had said that Muizzu faced challenges in implementing his vision and policies because of the parliament and intimated that he was controlling the urge to physically assault lawmakers. The parliament, in its statement, said the minister's statements may encourage violence against lawmakers and that such statements are not befitting of a person in such a position. It also called on the government to extend its cooperation on efforts to ensure the safety and security of lawmakers. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website formerly known as Voice of Free Press run by prominent journalist Ismail Rasheed. It carried original reporting, editorial and commentaries primarily on domestic political and socio-economic issues and does not favour Indian or Chinese involvement in the country.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Dhivehi 8 Mar 24

title: Highlights from Maldives' Dhivehi-language press, websites 12 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items published in Maldives' Dhivehi-language press and online media outlets on 12 March 2024.

Sun.mv
body:
Trade group calls to allow importers to pay fees in rufiyaa

The Maldives Trade Association (MTA) on 11 March called on the Maldives Ports Limited (MPL) to change its decision to levy vessel fees in US dollars from April. In a statement it issued, the MTA said that with current shortages in the availability of US dollars from banks, importers already purchase dollars for their transactions at high rates. The association said that having to pay vessel fees in dollars may further increase import prices. It highlighted that state-owned enterprises (SOEs) are allowed to pay their fees in local currency and called for the same policy to be established for all businesses in the country in order to maintain prices of local goods. [Online, Approximate Words: 150]

[This is a prominent Dhivehi-language news website that generally carries objective reporting. It is owned by the Sun Media Group, the largest private media house in the Maldives.]

Avas

President says Commonwealth 'important partner' for Maldives

President Dr Mohamed Muizzu on 11 March said that the Commonwealth is an important partner for Small Island Development States (SIDS) developing countries such as the Maldives. In his message to mark Commonwealth Day, the president said that the Commonwealth is a strong advocate for climate action, increased and simplified access to finance, gender equality, and increased trade and building resilience. He added that as the 75th anniversary of the Commonwealth is marked in 2024, it had helped member countries address and overcome their vulnerabilities and pushed to deliver on shared commitments. He reaffirmed the Maldives' commitment to working within the Commonwealth to explore new ways to address common challenges. The Maldives re-joined the Commonwealth on 1 February 2020, after it left during former president Abdulla Yameen's administration. [Online, Approximate Words: 240] 

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website run by "Mundoo" Adam Haleem and owned by former lawmaker Abdullah Sinan. The website is generally critical of the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party and Jumhooree Party.]

Mihaaru

First batch of Indian military personnel leave Maldives

The Maldives National Defence Force (MNDF) on 11 March said that all Indian military personnel stationed in Addu City, to operate a helicopter donated by India, have departed from the country. An MNDF official said that in accordance with the government's decision to remove the first batch of Indian military personnel from the Maldives by 10 March, all military personnel at Addu City departed by that date and have since been replaced by civilians to operate the helicopter. The Maldivian and Indian governments have agreed to remove Indian military personnel in Kadhdhoo in Laamu Atoll and Hanimaadhoo in Haa Dhaalu Atoll by 10 May. Removing foreign military personnel stationed in the Maldives had been one of President Muizzu's election pledges. [Online, Approximate Words: 220]

[Mihaaru is a Dhivehi-language daily that generally carries objective reporting and does not appear to favour any political party. The newspaper widely covers political developments, radicalisation, and counter-terrorism-related developments in the Maldives.]

Channel News Maldives

President says salaries to be raised when economy recovers

President Muizzu on 11 March said that he wanted to increase salaries for staff in all sectors. In his response to a question from a member of the public on the "Raees ge Javaag" (President's Answers) platform, Muizzu said that the parliament, in its passage of laws on decentralisation, had categorised local council staff at a low rank, and that there is no avenue for the Ministry of Finance to change council staff salaries (salaries are set under decentralisation laws for local councils, to be determined by the parliament). However, he said, as the economy recovers and prospers, he wishes to increase the salaries of all state-employed staff. The president also noted that amendments will have to be made to the law to change salaries of local council staff. [Online, Approximate Words: 180]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website formerly known as Voice of Free Press run by prominent journalist Ismail Rasheed. It carried original reporting, editorial and commentaries primarily on domestic political and socio-economic issues and does not favour Indian or Chinese involvement in the country.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Dhivehi 12 Mar 24

title: Highlights from Pakistan's Sindhi-language TV, press 28 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items published in Pakistan's Sindhi-language TV and press media outlets on 28 March 2024.

Awami Awaz
body:
Pakistan resolves to eliminate 'terrorism'

Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on 27 March chaired a high-level security meeting in national capital Islamabad, which was attended by the army chief, General Syed Asim Munir. The meeting was held after a 26 March terror attack in the Shangla district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) province killed five Chinese engineers. Serious concerns were expressed at the meeting, regarding the "sanctuaries of terrorists" across the border (with Afghanistan). It was highlighted that there is a need for a regional approach to counter terrorism. General Munir said that they would fight "till the elimination of the last terrorist" who wants to target Pakistani citizens and Pakistan's guests. He also said that the armed forces are determined to remove the scourge of terrorism from the country. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 200]

Conference against dacoits to be held in Sindh on 29 Mar

Under the auspices of the Qaumi Awami Tehreek (QAT, political party also known as Awami Tehreek), a conference against dacoits is scheduled to be held at the Hyderabad press club (in Sindh province) on 29 March. The QAT has extended invitations to participate in the conference, to the Sindh United Party (SUP), National Party (Sindh chapter) and other parties and groups. The QAT central general secretary, Noor Ahmed Katiar, said that the government has been handed over to the Special Investment Facilitation Council (SIFC). There is no law and order in Sindh, which is being ruled by the dacoits, he said. The head of the SUP, Syed Zain Shah, said that all the nationalist parties will have to struggle together to get rid of dacoits in Sindh. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

[Daily Awami Awaz is a progressive, secular and liberal, left-leaning Sindhi-language newspaper published from Karachi, Sindh. The daily possesses a good reputation among relatively educated and aware people. It is regarded as the "Dawn" of Sindhi-language newspapers.]

Ibrat

Top court meets regarding claims made by Islamabad judges

A full court meeting of the Supreme Court was chaired by Chief Justice Qazi Faez Isa on the afternoon of 27 March, on the issue of the letter by the judges of the Islamabad High Court (about the "establishment's" alleged interference in the judiciary). All the judges of the Supreme Court participated in the meeting, which lasted over two hours. According to sources (unspecified), the letter by the Islamabad High Court judges was discussed in detail and its constitutional and legal status was reviewed. The letter alleges interference by the security agencies in judicial matters. The chief justice also consulted the attorney general in this regard. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

Minister says Afghanistan 'source of terrorism' in Pakistan

Minister of Defence, Khawaja Asif, in a statement on social media platform X, said that the source of terrorism in Pakistan is in Afghanistan. He said that in view of an "increase in terrorist incidents" in Pakistan, there is a need for "fundamental change" regarding the "border situation". Asif said that despite Pakistan's efforts, Afghanistan is not making any progress on the issue and militants are freely operating against Pakistan from Afghanistan. He said that the Pakistan-Afghanistan border is not a traditional border but if the attacks continue in Pakistan from Afghanistan, then Pakistan will have to apply international laws on the border with Afghanistan. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

[Daily Ibrat is a moderate Sindhi-language newspaper owned by the politically influential Qazi family of Sindh, traditionally affiliated with Pakistan Peoples Party. The daily is published from Hyderabad, Sindh. Readers over 40 years of age prefer reading Daily Ibrat.]

Kawish

PM Sharif to meet chief justice on 28 Mar

Prime Minister Sharif will on 28 March meet with Chief Justice Isa regarding the issue of the letter by the judges of the Islamabad High Court (IHC). According to sources (unspecified), significant progress has been made on the issue of the letter by the IHC judges and the chief justice has sent a message to Prime Minister Sharif requesting a meeting in this regard. Sources said that after receiving the chief justice's message, the prime minister will meet his legal team on the morning of 28 March. Minister of Law, Azam Nazeer Tarar, confirmed the meeting while talking to a private television news channel. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 120]

Party demands judicial commission look into judges' letter

Chairperson of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party, Barrister Gohar Ali Khan, along with PTI secretary general Omar Ayub, held a press conference in Islamabad, demanding that a judicial commission look into the issue of the letter by the six IHC judges. Khan said that the interference of the establishment in judicial matters is highly condemnable. He also demanded protection for the families of the six judges. Ayub said that the target of this interference was the PTI founder, Imran Khan. He said that the PTI will raise this issue in the National Assembly (lower house of parliament) and provincial assemblies (provincial parliaments). [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 300]

[Daily Kawish is the most widely read Sindhi-language newspaper published from Hyderabad, Sindh. The paper is popular among young people and has a liberal and progressive editorial policy. It is also the largest circulated daily.]

Hot Issues (Prime-Time Talk Show on Sindh TV News at 14:00 GMT)

Discussion on militancy, protest campaigns

Anchor Sabeen Memon said that they would discuss the security situation in the country. For some time now, terror activities have been taking place on a daily basis, she said. Pakistan and Afghanistan relations have soured due to this issue, Memon said. The opposition wants to start a campaign against rigging in the elections. Security and the economy are inter-connected, she added. Panellists included Islamabad bureau chief of Sindh TV News, Shakir Solangi, and senior analyst Shaheen Qureshi. 

Solangi said, "The law and order situation in KP is deteriorating by the day. During the election campaign, Maulana Fazlur Rehman [head of the Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam, or JUI] had said that he could not campaign in KP's Dera Ismail Khan due to terror threats. The Afghan authorities are not cooperating with Pakistan. Just yesterday, Chinese nationals were attacked. Several arrested terrorists are from Afghanistan. Today, the prime minister chaired a meeting with regard to security and decided to continue the fight against terrorists. The investor will not come to Pakistan in this situation. There is no terrorism in Sindh but there is a law and order situation, in which dacoits are openly threatening the Sindhi society. The traders in Sindh are worried and cannot run their businesses peacefully. Similar is the situation in Balochistan. There is peace in Punjab province only. The PPP had restored peace in Swat during 2008-13 government. The PTI and the PML-N have a soft corner for the terrorists. The TTP has the weapons left by the United States in Afghanistan. The Afghan government is unmoved on Pakistani concerns about these terrorists. Maulana Rehman has announced that he will start his campaign from 25 April, protesting against rigging in the general elections. The PTI always hold violent protests, whereas Maulana Rehman's protests have always been peaceful. Hence, it is not possible that these parties will protest jointly."

Qureshi said, "Pakistan is being attacked at a time when it is facing its worst economic situation. The terrorists are targeting Chinese nationals. China is helping Pakistan to stabilise its economy. Pakistan needs political and economic stability. This attack is very serious. We need to be aware the we are a target for our enemies. We are under a lot of debt. Today we are living in a hybrid system. The parliament seems to have lost its importance and credibility. Our interior minister is also heading the cricket board. It seems to have a very unserious attitude. Only parliament can unite the nation. The PTI had released terrorists during its tenure in government and wanted to bring those terrorists in to the main stream politics. The situation today is the result of confusion about the policy about these terrorists. The National Action Plan is in cold storage now. The situation is very alarming. Security agencies are being accused of interfering in the judiciary."

[Sindh TV News is the second largest Sindhi-language TV channel and supports nationalist views.]

Insight with Najia Mir (Prime-Time Talk Show on KTN News at 15:00 GMT)

Discussion on judiciary, militancy

Anchor Najia Mir said that the six judges of the IHC have written a letter to the judicial commission. A petition against these six judges has also been filed, she said. The PTI, in a strong reaction, has demanded to declare all the sentences against Imran Khan as null and void, Mir said. The Supreme Court has held a full court meeting in this regard. The security situation in the country is also very serious, she said. The killing of Chinese nationals is another serious matter, she added. Panellists included Dr Karim Khawaja of the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP), former diplomat Alam Brohi, analyst Aijaz Qureshi and journalist Aijaz Mehar. 

Khawaja said, "Five years ago, another judge, Shaukat Siddiqui, had also accused security personnel of interference in judiciary. This is a continuation of the same. Pakistan has a history of judicial crises. The judiciary itself is to blame for being weak. It is hoped that the full court will decide in the interests of the country. [The killing of Chinese nationals] is a condemnable act. This is to fail the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). Whatever happens in Pakistan will destabilise the whole region. It is being said that in the next 20 years, China will be the superpower of the world."

Brohi said, "The attacks on Chinese nationals have taken place several times. We are continuously confronting security issues. We need to have a consensus on security issues. This situation is for the last two decades. The purpose of targeting Chinese nationals is to stop foreign investments in Pakistan. The question arises whether we hold such talks in the media after every incident and then forget the issue. Recently attacks were also conducted in Gwadar and Turbat in Balochistan. It is a golden opportunity for all stakeholders to decide on the judicial matters once for all and correct all its past mistakes. The establishment has been interfering in politics and the judiciary for a long time."

Mehar said, "The CPEC was a game-changer programme for Pakistan. India is not happy with it and the United States also has reservations. There are several foreign elements that do not like this project. Freelance jihadis may have conducted this attack. If security agencies interfere in political issues, then these attacks may happen. The timing of the letter is very important. This is the time when Imran Khan's cases are being heard in the courts. The former chief justice [Umar Ata] Bandial did not take up Justice Siddiqui's case. The situation in the judiciary is very unfortunate. Now we have to see what the full court decides in this case. Let's wait for the full court's decision. Parliament should also discuss the issue in detail. In the past, the judiciary has been undermining the parliament."

Qureshi said, "The timing of this letter is very important. Pakistani judicial history tells us that such interference started at the beginning of inception of this country. The judiciary introduced a doctrine of necessity and that started all this interference. We had several judges in the past who were supported by the military establishment. I agree that parliament should play its role. We are in a very difficult situation. Chinese are being killed because China is helping Pakistan. This is a very important juncture in our history. Terrorism is destabilising the country."

[KTN News is the most widely watched Sindhi-language news TV Channel owned by Kawish media group, which also owns Daily Kawish. The channel has a liberal position and is normally critical of Pakistan Peoples Party.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Sindhi 28 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's PTV show on militant attack on soldiers, political developments
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Siyasi Ahwal" (Political Situation) hosted by anchor Shahzada Zulfiqar on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 17 March 2024. The programme invites experts and politicians to express their opinions and analysis on important news of the day.

Anchor Shahzada Zulfiqar said a "shocking incident of terrorism" took place on 16 March in the Mir Ali area of South Waziristan in which seven Army personnel, including two officers, who were fighting "terrorists" were martyred. He mentioned Minister of Information and Broadcasting Attaullah Tarar expressed distress over an alleged social media campaign ridiculing the martyrs.
body:
Zulfiqar spoke with former caretaker minister Zubair Jamali and asked him to comment on the recent incident of the martyrdom of military officers. Jamali said it is a very gloomy event for a family to receive the dead body of their young son. He noted a lieutenant colonel, captain and five soldiers have been martyred, and they have sacrificed their lives for the country. He remarked such incidents prove to be a "binding force" for the country and people need to realise that if they are living safely in their villages and cities, it is "at the cost of soldiers who are fighting against terrorism on borders and within the country". He added people should be thankful to the martyrs and their families for their sacrifice.

Senior journalist Saleem Shahid said it was a very sad incident, but it should be noted that the officers and soldiers fought against "terrorists" and killed six of them before embracing martyrdom. He noted incidents of terrorism have increased recently. He was of the view that such incidents cannot be planned and executed by a small group and large-scale resources are behind them which are only available to a state. He claimed due to this, some state is behind these incidents and is funding such elements.

Zulfiqar noted President Asif Ali Zardari expressed grief over martyrdom of the military personnel and expressed a firm resolve that "revenge" would be taken for the killing. He asked Mir Saadat Baloch, pro-vice chancellor of the Panjgur University, to comment on the same. Baloch paid tributes to the martyred soldiers and said Zardari's reaction to the incident is "understandable" because his family has also been a victim (his wife and former prime minister Benazir Bhutto was killed in an attack).

Commenting on the alleged social media campaign ridiculing the martyrs, Jamali insisted elements involved in "insulting propaganda" should be "gripped with a hard fist". He said the martyrs have offered the ultimate sacrifice by laying down their lives, so the government and civil society should "thrash" such elements.

Shahid said the propaganda insulting martyrs is "highly deplorable" and such comments are very painful for their families. He added people should realise that "their existence is linked to the existence of the country" and being "country-less" is a huge tragedy. He insisted the government should take serious action against such people.

Baloch condemned those targeting martyrs with malicious campaigns and said a "strategy" should be devised, not only against those who are active on social media, but also against those who are encouraging them. He recalled a foreign institution had conducted a survey before elections to assess whether people's confidence in the military had declined. He noted according to the results of the survey, "89 per cent of the youth all over Pakistan expressed confidence in the military". He agreed that action must be taken against those involved in propaganda.

Commenting on a recent meeting between Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, Jamali said it is a "positive gesture" as everyone needs to work jointly for the country. Shahid commented coordination among different institutions is necessary for improving the economy. He noted the caretaker government took important steps to solve economic issues which should be taken forward by the new government. He said opposition parties should not create hurdles in the working of the new government. Baloch remarked people need to rise above party politics in the larger interest of the country.

Zulfiqar said Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif met a young student from Balochistan on 17 March. He noted Sharif had met the student in 2022 while visiting flood-hit areas and had helped the youth enrol in a reputable college. Jamali appreciated the prime minister's action and urged him to establish a network of quality schools in Balochistan, like he did in Punjab under his government. Baloch remarked it is a "welcome message" from the prime minister which would encourage students to focus more on their education.

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 17 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's PTV show on political developments, empowerment of local governments
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Riasat" (The State), hosted by anchor Shahzad Raza on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 14 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day

Anchor Shahzad Raza said a meeting between Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif took place on 13 March. He noted the meeting was cordial and Gandapur, who is known as a "hard-hitting batsman" of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), maintained a political tone in the media talk after the meeting. He remarked it is good that people sitting in the opposition seem to be convinced that they should remain a part of the parliamentary system.
body:
Raza spoke with Asiya Ishaq, a member of Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM), and asked her whether she is optimistic about the PTI remaining in the parliament this time and playing the role of the opposition despite reservations. Ishaq replied it is good to see that the PTI has passed through an "evolutionary process". Recalling that earlier the PTI had resigned from the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament) and had suffered setbacks due to wrong decisions, she expressed hope about the party learning from its past mistakes. She commented the party again "committed a blunder" when it decided to join the Sunni Ittehad Council (SIC) and could not get a share in the reserved seats for women due to it.

Raza spoke with Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Ramesh Singh Arora and asked him how far has Punjab Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz's style of politics changed after becoming the chief minister as she was an "aggressive politician" earlier. Arora replied there is a "background" for Nawaz's aggressive politics as she and her entire family had to face persecution for several years "from [former president] General Pervez Musharraf's government to [former prime minister] Imran Khan's civilian martial law". He said through her aggressive politics, Nawaz emerged as the top crowd-puller politician of the country. He added Nawaz now stands for "performance, delivery, reconciliation and corruption-free Punjab". He noted in her first speech as the chief minister, Nawaz said she would serve the people of Punjab. He mentioned after being elected as the chief minister, she went to the opposition leader to say that she is not only the chief minister of her government, but also the opposition.

Raza asked senior journalist Saleh Zaafir how President Asif Ali Zardari would leverage his political weight during the next five years. Zaafir said as the president, Zardari has no administrative powers but being a senior politician from the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP), which has its government in Sindh and a coalition government in Balochistan, is his "strength".

Raza asked Ishaq about her party's demand that local governments should be empowered. Ishaq said for the MQM, empowerment of local governments is very important, and it had a "one-point agenda" during talks for an alliance with the PML-N before elections that three amendments should be brought into the Constitution for this purpose. She added these amendments would be beneficial for the entire Pakistan. She mentioned the MQM has demanded that the office of the mayor should be mentioned in the Constitution like offices of chief ministers and the prime minister, the federal government should transfer funds directly to districts, and elections for the National Assembly and provincial assemblies should not be held before local government elections.

Raza asked Arora whether his party supports empowerment of local governments. Arora replied the PML-N has been a victim regarding local governments as the previous PTI government had sent all the elected local government members in Punjab home immediately after coming into power. He supported the MQM's demands and said all political parties should work jointly for such issues. He further said he is not clear about the party line on direct funding to district governments from the federal government, but in his "personal opinion", provinces should distribute funds to the districts.

Zaafir claimed political governments in Pakistan have always felt threatened by local governments. He was of the view that it would be better if funds to districts are distributed by the provinces.

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dunya TV show on politics, crime rate in Sindh, gas prices
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Dunya Kamran Khan Kay Saath" (World With Kamran Khan), hosted by senior journalist and TV host Kamran Khan on moderate Dunya News TV in Urdu at 16:30 GMT on 19 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Politics of PML-N
body:
Anchor Kamran Khan said the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) has emerged with a "new identity" as its narrative of resistance and accountability has transformed into "compromise with reality". He noted it is in this situation that Nawaz Sharif (senior PML-N politician) has awarded party tickets to several non-PML-N candidates for the Senate (upper house of the parliament) elections and they would contest as independent candidates.

Khan mentioned Minister of Finance Muhammad Aurangzeb, Minister of Interior Mohsin Naqvi, Minister of Establishment Ahad Cheema and technocrat Mustafa Ramday would be elected by the PML-N's votes in Punjab. He questioned whether it is a mere coincidence that the party did not choose its long-time loyalists like Rana Sanaullah, Khawaja Saad Rafiq, and Khurram Dastgir for the Senate elections. He commented it looks like the PML-N has "actually put its politics at stake" to save the state.

Khan spoke with political commentator Kamran Shahid and asked him to share his views on the PML-N's claim that is has sacrificed its politics, political narrative and political identity to save the state. Shahid disagreed with the claim and said the PML-N's politics has been destroyed by results of the recent elections as it was "voted out" after the polls. He expressed the view that the PML-N has probably realised that it does not have the strength of vote and can get the prime ministership "only through a collaboration with the [military] establishment".

Shahid noted Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's government has been formed in coalition with several parties because it did not have enough votes in the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament). He called it "power politics" and said it was not an attempt to save the state. He remarked the 8 February elections have shown that politics and power are not with the PML-N at the moment.

Crime rate in Sindh

Khan said the law and order situation in Sindh is "out of control". He added this is the situation when the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) has completed 15 years in government in the province and has still not been able to end street crime and abductions there. He noted street criminals in Karachi (capital of Sindh) take life of one citizen every second day and nine citizens are looted every hour.

Khan asked Dunya News bureau chief Talha Hashmi about reports regarding crime in Sindh and the Sindh government's reaction. Hashmi said it was decided that an operation would be launched with the help of paramilitary forces against dacoits in the riverine area, but it is yet to be implemented. Talking about the law and order situation in Karachi, he mentioned most people who have been killed were young and some were students, so it looks like a kind of "genocide of the youth of Karachi". He noted only 10 per cent of the crimes get reported which means the number of crimes committed every day is much higher.

Khan spoke with Karachi's Inspector General of Police Khadim Hussain Rind and asked him why street crime is increasing in the area. Rind agreed that there has been a surge in the crime rate in January and February. He noted the crime rate has been increasing every year but claimed it has been controlled to some extent in March. He further claimed Karachi was the 11th most dangerous city in the world in 2013 and its ranking is below 100 in 2024. He added 688 police officers have lost their lives in the last few years.

Gas prices

Khan said gas prices would further increase and noted gas tariff has increased by 260 per cent in the last four months. He noted gas companies have proposed an increase of 147 per cent for domestic consumers.

Khan spoke with Tahir Abbas, an expert on energy affairs, and asked him about the reason behind the proposed increase. Abbas said the proposal includes an increase to meet the arrears. He was of the view that the government would approve a much lower increase. He mentioned gas is being used by captive power plants to generate electricity in industries but these plants are "very inefficient". He suggested this gas could be diverted to efficient power plants which could help reduce the cost of electricity.

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1630 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dunya TV show on politics, tax reforms, crime rate in Sindh
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Dunya Kamran Khan Kay Saath" (World With Kamran Khan), hosted by senior journalist and TV host Kamran Khan on moderate Dunya News TV in Urdu at 16:30 GMT on 25 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Performance of chief ministers
body:
Anchor Kamran Khan said newly formed governments in Punjab and Sindh have completed the first month after their formation and noted that Maryam Nawaz has taken over the chief ministership of Punjab for the first time, while Murad Ali Shah has become the chief minister of Sindh for the third time and has been working in the province since the last eight years. However, he added, there is a huge difference between the performance of these two governments.

Khan said on one hand, Nawaz has been very active in the province and has announced several new projects but on the other, Shah has remained "absent from the scene" throughout the month. He noted Nawaz has been visiting public places and trying to solve the issues of the people.

Khan played a video report on Nawaz and Shah's activities during the past month. The report noted Nawaz has announced low-cost houses for people with low income, e-bikes and urban bus projects for the youth, and has decided to provide ration to the poor during Ramadan (month of fasting for Muslims). The report further said Nawaz has been overseeing all these projects and calling meetings on dozens of issues. It added she announced "safe city projects" for 18 cities of Punjab would be completed in the next three months and has launched an overseas property transfer service for the Pakistanis living abroad.

The report noted Sindh Chief Minister Murad Ali Shah visited south Karachi once in the last one month and inspected the condition of the rainwater drainage system there. It said apart from this, Shah was not seen in any public place. It further said meeting of the cabinet was held only once but an agreement for the Karachi safe city project was approved after a long wait of 16 years.

Scandal surrounding new federal minister

Khan said in the initial weeks of the new government in the centre, a scandal has surfaced which has created upheaval in the highly reputed Aitchison College of Lahore. He mentioned Punjab Governor Baligh ur Rehman, who is the chairperson of the board of governors of the college, ordered waiver of college fees and fine for two sons of the newly appointed federal minister Ahad Cheema. He added due to this, college principal Michael A Thomson resigned from his post. He noted in a letter, Thomson wrote that he would leave on 1 April and not play any role in management of the upcoming admissions.

Khan mentioned after the principal's resignation, Syed Babar Ali (senior member of the college's board of governors) also resigned in protest over political interference in the affairs of the college.

Tax reforms

Khan said a "historic step" is about to be taken by bringing the retail sector under the tax net as well as all other sectors which are currently not under the tax net. He mentioned traders in major cities would be registered through the Tajir Dost (trader-friendly) scheme. He noted Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif recently claimed 14,000bn rupees ($50bn) can be collected in taxes if the tax net is expanded to all the sectors.

Khan spoke with Zeeshan Merchant, an expert on tax affairs, and asked him whether the new scheme is implementable. Merchant said the focus these days is on "digitisation" and several changes are being made for this purpose. He added the question is whether any discussion was held with the traders for whom this scheme has been announced. He recalled similar schemes in past had failed and enforcement is the biggest issue due to which tax revenue has not increased in the past years. He was of the view that the scheme should be discussed with the stakeholders before its implementation and suggested that the system should be simplified as much as possible.

Crime rate in Sindh

Khan said the crime rate has "hugely increased" in the interior Sindh due to which freight containers cannot pass through the highways in the province and everything that needs to be transported upcountry remains stuck in Karachi. He added robbers loot trucks, freight containers and oil tankers on the main highways connecting Sindh and Punjab. He noted cases of shooting, robberies and kidnapping of transporters for ransom have increased in the last few months. He insisted a decisive operation against dacoits is necessary in this situation and it should be launched jointly by the Sindh and Punjab police.

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1630 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Highlights from India's Marathi-language press, websites 26 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items from select Indian Marathi-language press and online media outlets 26 March 2024.

Loksatta
body:
News report notes 'deadlock' in seat sharing in coalition

The seat sharing for Lok Sabha (lower house of parliament) elections in Mahayuti [coalition mainly comprising of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), Shiv Sena (Chief Minister Eknath Shinde faction) and Nationalist Congress Party (NCP, Ajit Pawar faction)] in western state Maharashtra has reached a ''deadlock''. The development comes after Shiv Sena and NCP refused the formula of 30 seats, 13 and five seats for BJP, Shiv Sena and NCP respectively. The BJP has staked claim over Thane seat, contested and won by undivided Shiv Sena in 2019, impeding any breakthrough in talks. Shiv Sena has also reportedly opposed induction of Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) into Mahayuti. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 250]

[Loksatta is the third largest-circulation Marathi-language daily, which is run by the Indian Express Group that owns respected English-language daily The Indian Express. The daily generally carries objective reporting on local Maharashtra and regional issues.]

Saamana

Politicians hold discussions regarding elections

Maha Vikas Aghadi [MVA, coalition mainly comprising of Uddhav Balasaheb Thackeray party, NCP-Sharadchandra Pawar party and Congress party] on 25 March held a meeting at the residence of Uddhav Thackeray. Sharad Pawar and Thackeray held separate discussions over strategy to defeat the BJP in elections. Thackeray faction spokesperson, Sanjay Raut, and NCP-Sharadchandra Pawar party State Chief, Jayant Patil, were also present during the meeting. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 100]

Police bust drug factory in western city

Mumbai Police on 25 March busted a drug factory in an agricultural field of Irali village in Kavathe- Mahankal block [administrative division in Sangli district, Mumbai]. According to initial reports, 100kg mephedrone has been recovered. [Page: 1, Approximate Word: 150]

[Saamana is the mouthpiece of the Maharashtra-based political party Shiv Sena. This nationalist and right-leaning daily supports the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) government on national security, terrorism and Kashmir issues. However, it is very critical of the government on economy and unemployment issues.]

Tarun Bharat

Politician remarks on party ending alliance

Sanjay Raut on 25 March said that decision of Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) to end the alliance with the Thackeray faction of Shiva Sena a year ago was ''unilateral'' and ''unfortunate''. Raut said that the VBA chief should have held discussions with Uddhav Thackeray before taking such a decision, adding that when the alliance was stitched, Lok Sabha elections were not on agenda. [Online, Approximate Words: 200] 

[Tarun Bharat is a Marathi-language daily that is largely supportive of right-wing political entities, including the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party.]

Lokmat

News report notes election plan of Hindu nationalist body

Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh [RSS, Hindu nationalist organisation and ideological patron of BJP] has reportedly issued directions through its meetings and those of its 36 affiliate bodies that their machinery should be mobilised on the voting day to ensure that 'our [their]' voters cast vote by 11 am (0530 gmt). According to sources quoted in the news report, such meetings were held in every district on the same day in the second week of March, followed by block-level meetings.
