This event aims to celebrate the achievements of the republic's heroes, promote cultural awareness, and provide a platform for learning about significant events and new facts, it said.

Society

Public activists and former political prisoners in Ingushetia were released from detention centres with warnings against participating in uncoordinated events, only to be called in hours later by the Centre for Counteraction to Extremism for questioning regarding their involvement in protests and their reported connection to the "Ingush case", the Fontanga news agency reported on 21 February. Security forces showed them photos of unidentified individuals from protests, indicating a continued investigation into protest organisers. (Fontanga news agency, 21 Feb 24)

A meeting was held in Magas featuring Husen Matiev, an eyewitness to the Ingush deportation, who shared experiences with schoolchildren about the hardships faced in exile and the eventual return to Ingushetia, emphasising the challenges of rebuilding their lives upon returning to their homeland, Ingushetia weekly reported on 22 February. (Ingushetia weekly, 22 Feb 24)

The official government website of Ingushetia Republic reported on 23 February that a commemorative event for the 80th anniversary of the Ingush deportation was held in Nazran, attended by officials and community members. Head of Ingushetia Mahmud-Aly Kalimatov stressed the importance of remembering the tragedy and preserving Ingush culture, with collective prayers and food kit distribution as part of the ceremony.

Sports

The head of Ingushetia Republic, Mahmud-Aly Kalimatov, and professional boxer Kostya Tszyu discussed organising a sports tournament in May, coinciding with the 100th anniversary of Ingush statehood, Magas news agency reported on 22 February. The planned event aims to promote boxing and sports development in the region, with support from various sports figures and acknowledgement of the sport's popularity among youth in Ingushetia. (Magas news agency, 22 Feb 24)

Source: Ingushetia Media Highlights in Russian 2359 gmt 19 Feb 24

title: Russia says Moscow attack suspects intended to flee to Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Investigations Committee has said that the four gunmen thought to have carried out the concert hall attack in a Moscow suburb on 22 March intended to flee to Ukraine while their activities before and after the attack were being coordinated by an unidentified man who sent them voice messages on Telegram.
body:
"In their initial testimony, during subsequent interrogations and other investigative activities with their participation, those accused of committing the terrorist attack said that their actions, both at the preparation stage and after the armed attack in Crocus City Hall, were coordinated through voice messages via the Telegram messenger by a man who introduced himself to them under a pseudonym," the Investigations Committee said in a post on its Telegram channel on 29 March.

"At the direction of the coordinator, after committing the crime, the terrorists drove in a car towards the Russian-Ukrainian border to subsequently cross it and arrive in Kyiv to receive the reward they had been promised," it added.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1545 gmt 29 Mar 24

title: Russia: Number of close-up shots of Kadyrov in official videos said falling
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian investigative website Agentstvo says Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov is no longer being shown close up in videos of him published on his Telegram channel and on government-controlled TV.
body:
Agentstvo's finding is derived from an analysis of videos of Kadyrov's appearances at various public functions published on his Telegram channel. It follows speculation in independent Russian media in early autumn 2023 about Kadyrov's allegedly ill state of health.

According to Agentstvo, the latest video from "an event with Kadyrov's participation", dated 23 March, is different from the previous ones in that it has a fewer number of close-up shots of the Chechen leader. It said in the two-and-a-half-minute-long video Kadyrov was shown close up only four times (five by BBC Monitoring count) with each video sequence not exceeding 2 sec in duration.

A video report about the same event produced by state TV channel Grozny showed Kadyrov close up three times, and in all three instances his body posture was exactly the same, Agentstvo said.

Agentstvo said that while "short" close-ups are common for the videos published on Kadyrov's Telegram channel (rarely are they longer than 5 sec), "as a rule" Kadyrov appears in these videos "far more often - normally several dozen times".

It said no video published since 3 January included as few close-up shots of Kadyrov as that published on 23 March apart from three videos published on 5 February, 20 February and 16 March, all which were, Agentstvo pointed out, a minute shorter than the video published on 23 March.

Agentstvo also said that in the video published on 23 March Kadyrov spoke in Chechen "slower than usual". For comparison, it used a video published on 1 February.

Agentstvo said that in February Kadyrov had missed President Vladimir Putin's state-of-the-nation address for a second time in two years. Kommersant newspaper's Kremlin-friendly journalist Andrei Kolesnikov said then that Kadyrov had caught a cold, however Novaya Gazeta Europe said that he may have been undergoing a round of treatment.

Agentstvo said flight trackers suggested Kadyrov's plane had since late February been "actively flying to Moscow" where he according to Novaya Gazeta Europe has been receiving treatment.

Agentstvo also cited a Telegram channel that claims to report insider information saying that Kadyrov can now receive the same treatment in Chechnya after the delivery there of state-of-the-art medical equipment.

Source: Agentstvo in Russian 27 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Vladivostok Media 12-18 Feb 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from OTV Prim Maritime Territory Public TV news and PrimaMedia news agency for the period 12-18 February 2024:

Reaction to Navalny's death
body:
Vladivostok residents have been visiting the monument to victims of political repressions to pay tribute to opposition leader Alexei Navalny who died in a penal colony, PrimaMedia news agency reported. His photo appeared at the monument, people came and brought candles, carnations and roses. Police present at the monument took down personal details of those who came to the monument explaining it by security considerations. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 17 Feb 24)

'Patriotic' motor rally

On 13 February, PrimaMedia news agency reported on the course of a "patriotic" motor rally from Vladivostok to Russia-occupied Luhansk, organised by the regional branch of the Russian Historical Society and the association of indigenous peoples of the Far North, Siberia and the Far East. Two cars are participating in the motor rally and they have already passed Tomsk, Barnaul and Novosibirsk. On their way the motorists met representatives of regional branches of the Russian Historical Society and People's Front and picked up some humanitarian aid collected for participants in "the special military operation" in Ukraine. In Novosibirsk, the rally participants met students of the Novosibirsk State Teachers' Training University and told them about the purpose of the rally. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 13 Feb 24)

Crime

A Vladivostok court has given a CPRF activist a suspended sentence of one year, OTV Prim TV reported on 15 February. Maxim Chikhunov used a tube from a grenade launcher to imitate shooting at a plate to monarchist and leader of the White Movement in Siberia and the Far East Mikhail Diterikhs back in 2022. The prosecutor's office is not content with the sentence as it asked for five years in prison and plans to appeal against the verdict as too lenient. (OTV Prim, Maritime Territory Public TV news, 15 Feb 24; PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 15 Feb 24)

Presidential envoy visits Vladivostok

Presidential envoy to the Far Eastern Federal District Yuri Trutnev has arrived in Maritime Territory on a working visit, OTV Prim TV reported on 15 February. Trutnev discussed the implementation of major investment projects with the regional authorities. As of today there are over 2,000 investment projects with state support being implemented in the region.

Over 10 years a total of 718bn roubles has been invested in projects in the region, Trutnev said and recalled: "Ten years ago we started work on the development of the Far East with the setting up of a system of attracting investment. I am sure that now it is key to economic and social development. Thanks to this we have managed to exceed the majority of indicators of economic growth compared to an average level across Russian regions".

Maritime Territory is among the leaders in the Far East based on the attraction of investments and creation of new jobs, OTV Prim TV continued the next day. A lot of investment projects are linked to the development of Maritime Territory's logistics potential which is especially important now in the light of Russia's turn to the east. The new reality requires the expansion of transport corridors and introduces new requirements for ports, roads and other infrastructure, Trutnev said.

The participants also discussed the implementation of projects in shipbuilding, agriculture and tourism, which envisage the investments of 290bn roubles. (OTV Prim, Maritime Territory Public TV news, 15 Feb 24; PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 15 Feb 24; OTV Prim, Maritime Territory Public TV news, 16 Feb 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 18 Feb 24

title: Schools in Russia's Kursk told to switch to remote learning
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Authorities in Russia's city of Kursk and two other areas in Kursk Region bordering Ukraine have announced that schoolchildren will be temporarily moved to remote learning until the end of the school week.
body:
Writing on his Telegram channel on 12 March, Kursk city mayor Igor Kutsak ordered the temporary measure for schools "in connection with recent events".

"On 13-15 March, children will study remotely. In kindergartens, if parents are unable to leave their children at home, skeleton crews will be working," he said.

Following a decision of the regional capital's mayor, the region's government announced on its Telegram channel that two more areas of Kursk Region - the Glushkovsky and Sudzhansky districts would move to remote learning until 16 March. In the latter, the change was effective as of 12 March.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1206 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Vladimir Putin votes online in presidential election - Kremlin text
snippet:
Text of 'Vladimir Putin voted in the Russian presidential election' published in English by Russian presidential website on 15 March

The President has voted in the Russian presidential election online.
body:
The presidential election in the Russian Federation is being held March 15 through 17. For the first time, the polling stations are open for three days including remote online voting, which is available in almost a third of the regions.

Source: President of the Russian Federation website in English 1800 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Kaliningrad Region Media 19-25 Feb 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from Kaliningrad's state-owned GTRK Kaliningrad TV, NTRK Kaskad TV, and websites, Newkaliningrad.ru and Klops.ru for the period 19-25 February 2024:

Economic
body:
Lithuania has decided to close down two of four checkpoints on its border with Belarus, GTRK Kaliningrad TV has reported. According to the decision, those travelling on trains through the checkpoints will not be allowed to leave the carriages. Lithuania said the decision was motivated by its national security concerns and was also aimed at stopping the smuggling of the sanctioned products. "From the point of view of the residents of Kaliningrad, this might actually be not that bad, as people used to buy tickets to Moscow but would stay in Lithuania. This often meant that the people of Kaliningrad Region and the main part of the Russian Federation who really wanted to use the Kalingrad-Moscow train could not find tickets," Alexander Shenderyuk-Zhidkov, senator for Kaliningrad region, said. (GTRK Kaliningrad, 25 Feb 24).

Dmitry Lyskov, spokesman of Kaliningrad's regional administration, has said that Lithuania's decision prohibiting transit passengers from going through its border to leave the transport impacts negatively the country's own railway, "Klops" news website reported on 22 February. "By its actions, Lithuania is harming its own railway, which leads to further cuts in staff, routes, and in the end, the bankruptcy of the Lithuanian railway," Lyskov said, adding that the move is "yet another example of Russophobia." ( Klops news website, 22 February)

Only three out of dozens of projects approved by the council working on improving the investment climate in Kaliningrad have promised to construct social infrastructure in the region, the New Kaliningrad website reported on 21 February. The report said that out of these three projects, one will finish sometime after 2027, the construction of the second one is on hold, and the records on the plans of the third "have disappeared from the registry." According to the report, dozens of the investments approved by the council imply giving land to the investor companies without tenders and competition. However, the expectation in this case was that the companies would invest in social infrastructure, such as building kindergartens and schools. (New Kaliningrad website, 21 Feb).

Crime

Kaliningrad law enforcers have arrested smugglers of amber to Lithuania, NTRK Kaskad TV channel reported on 25 February. The arrested reportedly smuggled over 189 kilogrammes of amber worth 25m roubles (about 270,000 dollars) by using a quadcopter. They were arrested during their attempt to smuggle 334 kilograms more. (NTRK Kaskad TV, 25 Feb)

Source: BBC Monitoring, 25 Feb 24

title: Russia, Belarus to launch Union State media holding
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia and Belarus are to co-fund the establishment of a Union State media holding, according to the state secretary of the supranational union, Dmitry Mezentsev.
body:
Mezentsev told the Izvestia newspaper that the two countries will invest a total of about 1bn roubles (about 110m roubles) into the holding, of which close to 450m roubles would be earmarked for a television and radio broadcasting organisation.

Additionally, 263m roubles would go into funding a newspaper called Soyuznoye Veche (Union Veche) and another 209m roubles into funding a newspaper called Soyuz Belarus-Rossiya (Union Belarus-Russia).

A further 67m roubles will go into funding a magazine called Soyuznoye Gosudarstvo (Union State), which is currently published by Komsomolskaya Pravda.

The launch of the holding with a head office in Moscow and a branch in Minsk is scheduled for 2025, the report said.

Source: Izvestia website, Moscow, in Russian 2001 gmt 10 Mar 24

title: BBCM Iran Watchlist 6 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Iranian broadcast, press and social media sources

Reaction to return of veteran statesman as security chief
body:
Many Iranian newspapers reacted this morning to the appointment of former parliament Speaker and veteran politician Ali Larijani as the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council (SNSC), Iran's top security body.

Larijani's appointment by President Massoud Pezeshkian, which had been speculated about for a week, followed the creation of a new Defence Council under the SNSC aimed at centralising strategic military decision-making.

Larijani previously held the same top security position from 2005 to 2007 and was parliamentary speaker from 2008 to 2020. He also registered his candidacy in the 2021 and 2024 presidential elections, but was disqualified by the hardline vetting body, the Guardian Council.

The state broadcaster-run daily Jaam-e Jam newspaper said "With Larijani's appointment and the formation of the Defence Council, Iran has unveiled a new security and defence arrangement."

Conservative daily Farhikhtegan said "Larijani's return to the SNSC after 20 years signals a reconstruction of national affairs with a centrist approach".

The paper in a separate op-ed said "Larijani 3.0 must rebuild national unity from a centrist stance - neither the hardliner of the past nor the reformist ally of the Rouhani era".

The reformist Sazandegi said Larijani's return could mean "a shift from maximalist resistance to greater rationality in security policymaking".

On X, Larijani's appointment was either welcomed or tacitly accepted by users from across the political spectrum.

Some users said the appointment signified changes in strategies of Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, echoing recent speculation and chatter on upcoming senior staffing changes.

Others highlighted his nonpartisan nature and perceived "moderate approach", expecting a "positive change" in the top security body.

Some users described Larijani as a critic of hardliners, saying that a shift towards a more moderate approach was desperately needed in the current situation.

Meanwhile, some hardline figures sought to warn Larijani that he must adhere to Iran's conservative policies, especially in foreign policy especially towards the US and Trump's mounting pressure on Iran.

Hardline MP Amir Hossein Sabeti suggested Larijani was appointed to compensate for Pezeshkian's weaknesses.

Public offices closed in most provinces amid heat, energy crisis

Public offices in more Iranian provinces will be closed today. According to some outlets, 28 out of Iran's 31 provinces are affected.

State TV reported the closures in their morning bulletins today, but named only 13 provinces affected by the shutdowns, while state media cited "over 20" provinces. The reports and decisions on closures of new provinces were being released gradually until last night.

The shutdowns, aimed at saving electricity and water, come amid recurring blackouts and concerns over unprecedentedly bad water shortages this summer. Although Iran has been experiencing energy and water shortages for several years, the situation has significantly worsened this year.

State media has noted that essential service providers such as hospitals and select bank branches remain open during the closures in all affected provinces.

Iran executes alleged 'Mossad spy', 'IS terrorist'

The Iranian judiciary announced this morning that it had carried out the execution of an alleged Mossad spy and an "Islamic State [IS] terrorist".

In two separate reports, the judiciary-run Mizan News Agency described the individuals as "an operative of the Mossad spy-terror network who had engaged in espionage", named Roozbeh Vadi, and a "member of Daesh [IS]" who "intended to carry out terrorist operations", named Mehdi Asgharzadeh.

Mizan said Vadi was "employed in one of the country's key and sensitive institutions, and given his level of access, he had become an attractive target" for foreign intelligence. The report said he travelled to Vienna and met Mossad officers on five occasions.

Mizan also added that Vadi had provided Mossad with information about one of the Iranian nuclear scientists assassinated during the 12-day military campaign by Israel, which included targeting of top commanders and nuclear scientists.

On the case of the alleged IS member, Mizan said a "terrorist cell's safehouse was identified before any attack could take place" and that security forces "killed four terrorists in an armed clash" while raiding the house, while Asgharzadeh managed to flee and was later arrested.

title: Russia's Putin holds call with Belarusian leader Lukashenko - Kremlin
snippet:
Text of report in English by Russian presidential website on 2 March

Vladimir Putin had a telephone conversation with President of the Republic of Belarus Alexander Lukashenko.
body:
The Russian President once again congratulated Alexander Lukashenko on the successful parliamentary and municipal elections in Belarus, which were held on 25 February, 2024.

The leaders had an in-depth discussion on current issues related to furthering friendly Russian-Belarusian relations, based on the principles of allied and strategic partnership, as well as key aspects of the international situation.

Source: President of the Russian Federation website in English 1200 gmt 2 Mar 24

title: Putin, Mali leader 'agree to step up' anti-terror work - Kremlin
snippet:
Text of report in English by Russian presidential website on 27 March

Telephone conversation with Interim President of Mali Assimi Goita
body:
27 March 2024

Vladimir Putin had a telephone conversation with Interim President of the Republic of Mali Assimi Goita who resolutely condemned the terrorist attack at the Crocus City Hall concert venue and offered his deep condolences to the people of Russia.

The presidents discussed further steps to strengthen Russia-Mali ties in various fields, including the implementation of joint projects in energy, agriculture, and mining sector. Assimi Goita expressed special gratitude for the deliveries of Russian wheat, fertiliser, and fuel, free of charge.

The presidents conducted a detailed exchange of opinions in the context of the uneasy situation in the Sahara-Sahel region. They agreed to step up practical interaction to counter terrorism.

27 March 2024

Source: President of the Russian Federation website in English 1200 gmt 27 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Vladivostok Media 18-24 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from state-owned GTRK Vladivostok TV news, the PrimaMedia news agency and Vl.ru website, as well as the Telegram channels Eksperty Primorskogo Kraya and Primorsky Mamkoved for the period 18-24 March 2024:

Presidential election aftermath
body:
Maritime Territory has shown a record high support for Vladimir Putin in the 15-17 March presidential election, the PrimaMedia news agency reported on 18 March. He gained 88.34% of the vote in the region amid the voter turnout of 75.05%. At the previous presidential election in 2018, Putin gained 65.26%. LDPR candidate Leonid Slutsky is the second with 4.07% of the vote and CPRF nominee Nikolai Kharitonov is the third (3.35%). Vladislav Davankov nominated by the New People party gained 2.72%. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 0155 gmt 18 Mar 24)

"The voter turnout and the election results in the Far East are unprecedented and record-breaking," director of the International Institute of the Newest States Alexei Martynov said. The reasons are simple, he went on: this is the war on Ukraine, which people from all Far Eastern regions participate in, and the external threat as a "negative trigger", as well as the country's U-turn to the East as a positive motivation.

The opposition-mindedness of the Far East has become a thing of the past, states Yevgeniya Stulova, head of the political technology committee at the Russian Association of Public Relations (RAPR). "It is evident that the president has been paying unprecedentedly high attention to the Far East for years. The Far East has been declared a priority for the entire 21st century... No other federal district can boast of such a number of special programmes developed for it. This undoubtedly improves the social feeling," she noted.

"People of the Far Eastern Federal District see with their own eyes that thanks to consistent actions taken by Vladimir Putin, the federal authorities in general and the presidential envoy's office in particular, the quality of life has been changing for the better and they express their absolute trust to the head of state. The votes for candidate Putin ensure that the Far East will continue developing at a fast pace," said Daria Kislitsyna from the Expert Institute of Social Studies. (GTRK Vladivostok TV news, Vladivostok, 0225 gmt 18 Mar 24)

Vladivostok, previously known for an extremely low voter turnout and disloyalty to the country's leadership, did not differ from other areas in the region in terms of the average election results, the Telegram channel Eksperty Primorskogo Kraya said on 18 March. In 30 months mayor Konstantin Shestakov's administration managed to transform the city from an opposition-minded one into a city where supporters of the incumbent head of state dominate, the Telegram channel claimed. According to experts, the dialogue with city residents conducted by the city administration and Shestakov personally and the attraction of additional financing to resolve the most acute problems facing the city contributed to this. People of Vladivostok felt the practical effect of participating in national projects and state programmes, which impacted the general level of satisfaction with the authorities' performance, Eksperty Primorskogo Kraya stated. (Telegram messaging app, 0743 gmt 18 Mar 24)

Far Easterners have united in the face of a threat being presented by the West, and this resulted in the high voter turnout and high support for Vladimir Putin, Telegram channel Primorsky Mamkoved opined. Also, they see the practical use of the Russian economy's U-turn to the East, which manifests itself in unprecedented growth indices in economy and social sector. Support from Far Eastern regions at the state level has made it possible to turn once-protest-minded macroregion into Vladimir Putin's stronghold, the Telegram channel noted. (Telegram messaging app, 0335 gmt 18 Mar 24)

War on Ukraine

Twenty-one residents of Maritime Territory captured by Ukraine in the course of Russia's war on Ukraine returned home in 2023, PrimaMedia news agency reported on 20 March, citing a report made by regional human rights' ombudsman Yuri Melnikov to regional lawmakers. According to it, 63 requests to assist in a PoW exchange or release from captivity were received. The number of requests to help find missing servicemen increased from seven to 35. Complaints about violations of military service regulations increased from 35 to 144. The number of complaints about the course of mobilisation reduced from 167 to 15. The observance of war participants' rights and support for their families remain a top priority for the regional ombudsman's office, Melnikov stated. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 0230 gmt 20 Mar 24)

Anniversary of Crimea occupation

A rally and concert to mark the 10th anniversary of Crimea's occupation by Russia has been held in Vladivostok, GTRK Vladivostok TV reported on 18 March. Politicians, public activists and locals attended the event. According to the PrimaMedia news agency, it gathered over 300 people. Crimea's occupation is a historic event thanks to which Russian people have united and become far stronger, GTRK Vladivostok TV said, adding that this wa primarily important for young people of Maritime Territory and Crimea since "the young generation should know the history of their country". "I am convinced that this festive event demonstrates that it is possible to overcome any hardships and achieve any goals thanks to our unity," Vladivostok mayor Konstantin Shestakov said. "Crimea is our territory. It was, has been and will be so. I am sure that all sober-minded people on the planet realise this," Vladivostok legislative assembly head Andrei Brik claimed. (GTRK Vladivostok TV news, Vladivostok, 1142 gmt 18 Mar 24; PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 0140 gmt 20 Mar 24)

Ties with North Korea

A regional delegation led by governor Oleg Kozhemyako has gone on a visit to North Korea, the PrimaMedia news agency reported on 18 March. The visit will include a number of business meetings on developing cooperation in humanitarian fields, such as sport and tourism, and an entertainment programme. "We see that year after year North Korea has been increasingly opening [to visitors] and increasingly more people want to go there and familiarise themselves with this unique country, its traditions and culture, that is why we will pay visits there and establish contacts to live in peace and friendship with our neighbours," Kozhemyako said. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 0750 gmt 18 Mar 24)

High-profile crime case

Head of Vladivostok State University (VVSU) Gennady Lazarev, 76, has been detained on charges of organising a criminal community, the Vl.ru website reported on 22 March. According to investigators, the criminal group was engaged in stealing state property belonging to the university and state funds earmarked for state defence orders placed with the Vostochnaya Verf shipyard, which Lazarev co-owns. Lazarev is facing a prison term ranging from 12 to 20 years. He has been placed into custody for two months, until 24 May. Nine people who are believed to be the criminal group members have been detained as well, including Lazarev's son. (Vl.ru website, Vladivostok, 0543 gmt 22 Mar 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 24 Mar 24

title: Two killed in shelling of Russia's border region - governor
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two civilians have been killed during shelling in Russia's Belgorod Region, governor Vyacheslav Gladkov wrote on Telegram on 16 March.
body:
A man driving a lorry and a woman feeding stray dogs were killed, he stated, and at least three people injured.

Air defence systems shot down eight Vampir multiple-launch rocket rounds above the city of Belgorod and adjacent Belgorodsky District, Gladkov said.

There was minor damage to blocks of flats, houses, buildings and cars in Belgorod and three settlements in Belgorodsky District, he continued.

Earlier, at 05:01 GMT, Gladkov announced that missile warning was in place for Belgorod and Belgorodsky District. He announced alert recall at 05:23 GMT.

On 16 March, Defence Ministry said on Telegram that around 05:30 GMT it shot down two Ukrainian drones over Belgorod Region.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0707 gmt 16 Mar 24

title: Russia develops battlefield thermal masking system - report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian scientists have developed a thermal screen coating called Teplosfera that makes it harder to detect military equipment using thermal imagers, pro-government newspaper Izvestia's website reported on 11 March.
body:
The coating, based on polyurethane, has already been tested in the "special military operation" in Ukraine and demonstrated its effectiveness, the report said.

The coating is a response to so-called "kamikaze drones" or unmanned combat air vehicles (UCAV) fitted with thermal-imaging sensors, analysts told Izvestia.

The new coating, which has been developed by Bauman Moscow State Technical University's (MGTU) Centre for Digital Materials Science, insulates vehicles, making them practically impossible to discern thermally, the report said.

The basis of the material is polyurethane and hollow-glass microspheres made by Russian manufacturers, it added.

The composition is a filled two-component polyurethane mastic with an adjustable curing rate in the temperature range from -20 to +40 degrees Celsius, according to the report.

Polyurethane has high deformation and strength properties (frost resistance, wear resistance) and high adhesion to the surfaces of various materials, it said.

Mastic based on it has the ability to liquefy under mechanical stress and increase viscosity at rest, so it can be applied to vertical and inclined surfaces manually or, after a slight dilution with a solvent, mechanically using airless sprayers, Alexander Kalinnikov, deputy director of the Bauman Digital Materials Centre, told Izvestia.

The coating can be applied to a range of equipment from cars to heavy armour and self-propelled guns, the report said, adding that Teplosfera also has civil applications, and is suitable for use as insulation in Arctic conditions.

Polyurethane has some disadvantages however, being flammable and breaking up over time due to exposure to sunshine and moisture, the report explained.

The proposed use of glass spheres as a thermal insulation additive is an interesting solution that can find application in the field of polyurethane-based thermal insulation materials for both household and special purposes, a scientist who spoke to the paper said.

The most difficult problem, however, may be avoiding overheating of equipment while moving under such a coating, the scientist added.

Source: Izvestia website, Moscow, in Russian 2101 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Another suspected Moscow attack accomplice appeals against custody
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Another suspect arrested over alleged links to the four gunmen thought to have carried out the concert hall attack in a Moscow suburb on 22 March has filed an appeal against his custody, the Russian state news agency TASS reports.
body:
Isroil Islomov was remanded in custody along with his two sons - Aminchon Islomov and Dilovar Islomov - on 25 March.

Dilovar Islomov was the owner of a car that was sold to the gunmen and allegedly used in the attack, TASS said.

Another suspect, lisher Kasimov, accused of renting out a flat to the alleged perpetrators, was remanded in custody on 26 March.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1327 gmt 28 Mar 24

title: Death toll from Belgorod rocket strike rises to four - governor
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The death toll following a rocket artillery strike on the village of Nikolsk in Russia's Belgorod Region has risen to four, local governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said on Telegram on 18 March.
body:
Photographs in his post showed rescue workers picking through the rubble of a demolished building, following what Gladkov described as a "terrorist attack on the part of the Ukrainian Armed Forces".

Earlier, Gladkov had said the casualty list from the incident was two dead and four injured.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1543 gmt 18 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Ingushetia Media 26 Feb - 3 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are highlights from the website of the Ingushetia administration, the website of the state Ingushetia newspaper and the Magas and Fortanga news agencies for the period 26 February - 3 March 2024:

War on Ukraine
body:
Ingushetia head Makhmud-Ali Kalimatov had presented Orders of Courage to the families of six soldiers who had been killed in Ukraine. Kalimatov emphasised the valour of the soldiers, whose sacrifices "will not be forgotten", and posthumously awarded them for their "bravery, courage and selflessness" in fulfilling their military duty. (Ingushetia newspaper website, 26 Feb 24)

The people's assembly of Ingushetia has organised a charity event during which its members visited the families of soldiers killed in Ukraine, highlighting their "sacrifices and loyalty". The event aimed to honour the memory of those soldiers, seen as "models of courage and dedication", and was timed to coincide with the 30th anniversary of the constitution and people's assembly of Ingushetia. (Ingushetia newspaper website, 27 Feb 24)

A new batch of military and humanitarian has been was sent to the frontline, assistant to the organiser of the campaign, State Duma MP Bekhan Barakhoev, reported. The aid included 20 high-mobility vehicles, three KamAZ trucks with drones, thermal imagers, other necessary equipment and gear for the servicemen. "Three weeks ago, I asked my assistants to find out what our fighters at the front needed. All their requests were taken into account," Barakhoev noted. (Ingushetia newspaper website, 28 Feb 24)

Domestic political

Ingushetia resident have recorded a video in the Midagrabin waterfalls valley, located in North Ossetia, about five kilometres from the Georgian border, highlighting the absence of a checkpoint for document verification to enter the gorge, contrasting sharply with the strict border regime in the mountainous region of Ingushetia. The video criticises Ingushetia's leadership for not protecting citizens' rights, not easing passport controls, and not promoting the region's tourism industry, unlike in North Ossetia where private investors can access mountainous areas. Additionally, the border zone in Ingushetia's Dzheirakh District requires Russian citizens to present identification and foreigners to obtain FSB border permits, with passport checks and inspections at the Dzheirakh post for those entering through Prigorodny District, causing delays and discomfort for tourists. (Fortanga website, 29 Feb 24)

Crime

On 3 March, a special operation to neutralise suspected militants concluded in the city of Karabulak, after which law enforcers conducted a sweep of a flat where members of illegal armed groups plotting high-profile terrorist attacks in the region were hiding. The sweep aimed to determine the number of militants eliminated, estimated to be five to six people, while earlier reports of civilian casualties on social media were unfounded, with civilians evacuated from the operation area. (Magas.ru website, 3 Mar 24)

The identities of the militants eliminated in Karabulak were preliminarily given as supporters of the banned international terrorist organisation Islamic State, involved in several crimes including an attack on a traffic police post in the republic and the murder of three law enforcement officers last March. Three of the neutralised militants, including their leader, were on the federal wanted list. The operation resulted in no casualties among security forces or civilians, and automatic weapons, ammunition, grenades and explosive devices were found at the scene. (Ingushetia newspaper website, 3 Mar 24)

Ingushetia head Makhmud-Ali Kalimatov has instructed authorities to provide immediate assistance to all residents of Karabulak whose homes were damaged during the counter-terrorism operation. Construction and repair work will begin shortly to quickly restore damaged housing so that people could return to their normal lives. Individual support will be provided both materially and morally, under his personal oversight. Additionally, he directed the regional government to create a commission to assess the damage and tasked utility services with evaluating the infrastructure damage. Furthermore, deputy prime minister Indira Sagova was instructed to organise transportation for students and those needing to visit medical facilities. (Ingushetia administration website, 3 Feb 24)

Other

A total of 84 ancient structures have been discovered in the Verkhniy Barkhane architectural complex in Ingushetia, including 53 stelas, 10 residential and one semi-military tower, 18 tombs, a Cyclopean structure from an early period, and a stone wall. (Ingushetia newspaper website, 27 Feb 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 3 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Chechnya Media 26 Feb - 3 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are highlights from the government newspaper Vesti Respubliki, the state news agencies Chchnya Segodnya and Grozny-Inform, the state CHGTRK Grozny TV and the Chechen Republic head's press service for the period 26 February to 3 March 2024:

Political
body:
Head of Chechen Republic Ramzan Kadyrov praised President Vladimir Putin's annual state-of-the-nation address, highlighting its focus on national security, defence, and family values, while expressing support for the announced national projects and initiatives to support veterans and soldiers, the press service of the Chechen government reported on 29 February. Although Kadyrov did not attend the event, he commended Putin's initiatives and emphasised the importance of implementing the projects efficiently, the report said. (Chechen government's press service, 29 Feb 24)

The Congress of the People of the Chechen Republic, attended by representatives of various ethnic groups and foreign guests, unanimously declared support for Vladimir Putin in the upcoming presidential election, emphasising his role in ensuring Russia's interests and development, CHGTRK Grozny TV reported on 3 March. Headed by Ramzan Kadyrov, the event emphasised historical continuity and faith in Putin's leadership as crucial for Russia's international standing and internal stability, the report said. (CHGTRK Grozny, 3 Mar 24)

Speaking at the congress, Kadyrov expressed confidence in an exceptionally high voter turnout in the upcoming Russian presidential election, attributing it to the unity between the people, authorities, and clergy in Chechnya, CHGTRK Grozny TV reported on 3 March. (CHGTRK Grozny TV, 3 Mar 24)

Economic

Head of Chechen Republic Ramzan Kadyrov met with Minister of Industry and Trade Denis Manturov in Moscow to discuss several key issues, including the construction of a nitrogen fertiliser plant and the modernisation of Chaborz M-3 buggies for the Ministry of Defence, Vesti Respuvliki newspaper reported on 26 February. Manturov pledged support for these projects and discussed plans to build a technology park and an engineering centre in Chechnya. (Vesti Respubliki newspaper, 26 Feb 24)

Kadyrov met with Minister of Agriculture Dmitry Patrushev in Moscow to discuss agricultural development in Chechnya, with Patrushev praising the progress made in the region's agro-industrial complex, Chechnya Segodnya state agency reported on 26 February. Kadyrov emphasised the importance of agriculture in the republic's economy and discussed plans for the upcoming spring sowing campaign, expressing gratitude for Patrushev's understanding of the issues. (Chechnya Segodnya, 26 Feb 24)

Society

The Visaitovsky district court of Grozny sentenced Nikita Zhuravel to 3.5 years in prison for burning the Quran and committing hooliganism motivated by religious hatred against 13 imams of Grozny mosques, Grozny Inform news agency reported on 27 February. Although Zhuravel admitted guilt in burning the Quran for financial gain, he denied involvement in hooliganism during the trial, the report said. (Grozny Inform news agency, 27 Feb 24)

Ukraine war

State Duma Deputy Adam Delimkhanov discussed the leaked recordings of German officers discussing plans to strike the Crimean Bridge, and emphasised the need for close attention to the issue and warned of a strong response if Russian territory is attacked, Chechnya Segodnya reported on 1 March. State Duma speaker Vyacheslav Volodin announced that upon deputies' return, the issue of German officers discussing plans to strike the Crimean Bridge will be addressed in a State Duma meeting, with a demand for an investigation to be sent to the Bundestag, Delimkhanov said.

Source: BBC Monitoring 3 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 5 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Netanyahu, Israeli army at odds over Gaza occupation plans
body:
Israeli media this morning highlighted growing tensions between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and army chief of staff Lt Gen Eyal Zamir over plans to occupy the entire Gaza Strip.

Senior ministers told media that Netanyahu had decided to expand fighting in Gaza, against army recommendations and intensified public calls for a ceasefire, and used the phrase "occupation of the Strip".

Outlets further quoted ministers as saying: "If this is not suitable for the chief of staff, let him resign."

The public broadcaster Kan reported that Zamir may resign from his post if the plan is implemented.

According to the Ynet news site, Netanyahu is to raise the plan at a cabinet meeting today.

We will file a briefing on Israeli reporting and commentary on the issue.

Pan-Arab media highlight Israeli 'disagreements' over occupying Gaza

The UAE-based Sky News Arabia and Saudi-funded Al Arabiya reported this morning on the "disagreements" and "division" between senior Israeli officials.

Sky News Arabia said in one report: "Netanyahu's decision apparently does not appeal to the military institution."

Qatari flagship Al Jazeera highlighted reports according to which "Trump granted Netanyahu the green light to occupy Gaza".

A Palestinian analyst told Al Jazeera that Netanyahu "aims to tame the Israeli military and security institution".

Another expert argued that this option would cost Israel "a very high price in confrontations in the field in terms of human losses".

Qatar-based Al-Araby TV's correspondent in Gaza said the Israeli army already controls most areas in Gaza, either with ground troops or through air strikes and shelling.

We will file a briefing on pan-Arab media coverage.

Hamas urges UNSC to stop Gaza 'genocide'

Hamas has called on the UN Security Council, which will hold a session today to discuss the conditions of the Israeli hostages held in Gaza, to pressure Israel to stop what it describes as the "genocidal war" in Gaza.

Hamas called on the UNSC "to issue clear and binding resolutions to the occupation to halt its genocidal war, including massacres, violations, starvation and the destruction of civilian life in Gaza," in a Telegram post yesterday, quoting senior group official Osama Hamdan.

Hamdan urged the UNSC to oblige Israel to withdraw from Gaza, open border crossings to humanitarian aid and stop its violations against prisoners in Israeli jails.

He also condemned what he called "the US-backed occupation's policy of distributing aid as part of a plan to engineer starvation and chaos".

Also read: Briefing: Hamas says ready to deliver food aid to Israeli hostages

Israeli media persist in denying Gaza hunger crisis

As photos of emaciated children in Gaza continue to emerge, prompting global outrage over Israel's restrictions on the entry of humanitarian aid, Israeli media have largely refrained from reporting on the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

Israeli media have largely cast reports of hunger in Gaza as "false Hamas propaganda", saying images of starving children are fake or only show those with pre-existing health conditions.

Minimal Israeli reporting on the crisis in Gaza has largely assigned blame for any suffering there to Hamas and even then has been met with strong domestic criticism.

However, a recently leaked WhatsApp chat between journalists at the popular Channel 12 News revealed internal debates over whether they should be covering the issue.

Israeli government votes to dismiss attorney general

The Israeli government voted unanimously yesterday to dismiss Attorney General Gali Baharav-Miara, the chief prosecutor in Netanyahu's ongoing corruption case.

Baharav-Miara has frequently been at odds with the government, challenging the legality of a number of its moves including its controversial judicial overhaul plan.

According to domestic reports, the Supreme Court issued an injunction blocking the move.

The attempt to remove Baharav-Miara is the latest in a fierce battle between Netanyahu's government and the legal system.

The Ynet new site quoted Justice Minister Yariv Levin as saying during the government discussion on the attorney general's firing: "It is impossible to accept a situation in which the court will try to impose on the government a legal adviser who is completely political."

Growing protests reported in southern Yemen

Yemeni media reported escalating protests yesterday over poor public services in the southern city of Seiyun in Hadramawt province.

Demonstrators marched towards the city's main government building in protest over prolonged power outages. They also lamented the rising cost of living, exacerbated by the collapse of the Yemeni rial and rise in basic goods and energy prices, demanding an improvement in essential services.

The privately-owned Al-Masdar Online reported that demonstrators also erupted in several other districts in Hadramawt including al-Mukalla, Tarim and Shihr.

We are watching for further developments.

'Escalating protests' reported in Yemen's southern Seiyun district

Briefing: Yemen tribal bloc calls for autonomous rule in Hadramawt amid unrest

Houthis claim new Ben Gurion strike

The Houthi movement has claimed a new strike on Israel's main international airport, saying it was an act of solidarity with the Palestinians in Gaza.

The group's military spokesman, Yahya al-Sarea, said in a statement this morning that the rebel forces had fired a "Palestine 2" hypersonic ballistic missile at Ben Gurion Airport, noting that it had "successfully achieved its goal".

Repeating the language of previous statements, he added that the attack had "caused millions of Zionists to flee to shelters, bringing the airport to a standstill".

The Israeli military said on X late yesterday that it had intercepted a missile launched from Yemen after air sirens sounded in several areas in Israel.

The Houthis also claimed an attack on the airport on 1 August.

Coming up

The Lebanese cabinet will discuss today the disarmament of Hezbollah, a key US and Israeli demand, in what domestic media have described as a "decisive" session.

The discussion will also include a timetable for the group's disarmament.

Leaders of the Iran-backed group have repeatedly refused to give in to the demand to disarm, saying the problem is in Israel's continued attacks against Lebanon despite a ceasefire agreement reached in November 2024.

title: Suspected Moscow attack accomplice pleads not guilty, files appeal
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

One of the suspects arrested over alleged links to the four gunmen thought to have carried out the concert hall attack in a Moscow suburb on 22 March has pleaded not guilty and filed an appeal, the Russian state news agency TASS reports.
body:
Aminchon Islomov, who was remanded in custody along with two other suspects on 25 March, filed an appeal against his remand order, TASS on 28 March quoted a representative of the court as saying.

The appeal has been registered in the court, the report said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1045 gmt 28 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Chelyabinsk Media 11-17 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from state online channel Rossiya 1, state-owned Pervy Oblastnoy TV channel, privately-owned Channel 31 TV news and Nakanune.ru news agency for the period 11-17 March 2024:

Presidential election
body:
Local residents in Chelyabinsk will be able to win three flats participating in a quiz, known as Entire Family for Chelyabinsk, during the presidential election, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 13 March. The quiz will be held by the Our City public organisation as part of the Year of Family campaign. There are 300 items of household appliances, 10 cars and three flats among the prizes. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 13 Mar 24)

Chelyabinsk Region governor Alexei Teksler has discussed the forthcoming presidential election with heads of municipalities and members of the regional government, Pervy Oblastnoy TV reported on 13 March. Teksler urged the subordinates to monitor the process and promptly respond to emergencies and provocations. (Pervy Oblastnoy TV news, Chelyabinsk, 13 Mar 24)

On 15 March, the first day of the presidential election, more than 18% of local residents took part in the voting in Chelyabinsk Region, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 15 March. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 15 Mar 24)

According to the interim results, the turnout in the presidential election in Chelyabinsk reached 69.31%, including online voting, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 17 March. According to the regional electoral commission, more than 1.78 million people have already cast their votes. Observers from Columbia, France, Ghana, Malaysia and Nepal monitored the election in the region. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 17 Mar 24)

Political

While in Moscow, Chelyabinsk Region governor Alexei Teksler has discussed the construction and renovation of churches in the region with Patriarch of Moscow and All-Russia Kirill, Pervy Oblastnoy TV reported on 11 March. The meeting was held at the Cathedral of Christ the Savior. Cooperation of the regional government and the Chelyabinsk Region diocese was also on the agenda. (Pervy Oblastnoy TV news, Chelyabinsk, 11 Mar 24)

Vitaly Litke has been appointed minister of education and science in Chelyabinsk Region, Pervy Oblastnoy TV reported on 13 March. An order to this effect was signed by governor Alexei Teksler. (Pervy Oblastnoy TV news, Chelyabinsk, 13 Mar 24)

Chelyabinsk Region governor Alexei Teksler has been awarded with a medal of the Defence Ministry for his contribution to the strengthening of Russia’s defence, Pervy Oblastnoy TV reported on 13 March. The medal was given to the governor by acting head of the Central Military District staff Alexander Linkov. (Pervy Oblastnoy TV news, Chelyabinsk, 13 Mar 24)

Chelyabinsk Region governor Alexei Teksler has visited Sosnovsky District, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 14 March. The governor inaugurated two nurseries and a sports centre. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 14 Mar 24)

Economic

Chelyabinsk Region has been ranked 29th in a national rating in household debt, Channel 31 TV reported on 11 March. The statistics shows that the loan debt of each resident of the region reaches about 374,000 roubles (around $4,040 at the current exchange rate). In the last 12 months, the sum of a per capita debt rose by 77,500 roubles. In 2023, local residents took out 578.5bn roubles worth of mortgages, loans and micro-loans. (Channel 31 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 11 Mar 24)

The Sverdlovsk Region court of arbitration has refused to revoke an arrest from assets of the Kuznetsk ferrous alloys owned by Chelyabinsk billionaire Yuri Antipov, Channel 31 TV reported on 11 March. The company, as well as the Chelyabinsk Electrometallurgical Plant (ChEMK) and the Serov factory of ferrous alloys, is part of the Etalon holding. Under a court ruling, all those companies must be handed over to the state. (Channel 31 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 11 Mar 24)

In 2023, cash incomes of local residents went up 13% against 2022, reaching 1.5bn roubles, Rossiya 1 TV quoted representatives of the regional ministry of economic development as saying on 12 March. The per capita income also grew by 13%, amounting to 37,000 roubles. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 12 Mar 24)

In 2024, the regional ministry of agriculture is planning to harvest at least 1.8 million tonnes of grain, Pervy Oblastnoy TV reported on 12 March. According to regional minister of agriculture Alexei Kobylin, about 350m roubles will be allocated from the regional budget to agrarians to purchase seeds. (Pervy Oblastnoy TV news, Chelyabinsk, 12 Mar 24)

The presidential envoy to the Urals Federal District, Vladimir Yakushev, has summed up the interim results relating to the connection of households to a gas supply network, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 13 March. In 2020-23, about 100,000 households were connected to the gas supply network in the Urals Federal District. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 13 Mar 24)

In 2023, investment growth rose by 19.5% in Chelyabinsk Region, Pervy Oblastnoy TV quoted governor Alexei Teksler as saying at a meeting with heads of municipalities and members of the regional government on 13 March. Teksler added the economic sector had seen an 8% rise. “We are using the current situation for our objectives, implementing import substitution projects and setting up new companies,” Teksler said. (Pervy Oblastnoy TV news, Chelyabinsk, 13 Mar 24)

The Prosecutor-General’s Office has filed a lawsuit to the Chelyabinsk Region court of arbitration to recover about 26bn roubles from Chelyabinsk businessman Yuri Antipov’s family, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 15 March. According to the watchdog, in 2022, the Ural-Siberian Metallurgical Company, the majority stake in which is owned by Antipov’s family, discharged the businessman’s debt of 23bn roubles and a debt interest of 3bn roubles. The prosecutor’s office demands that the agreement be deemed null and void and the entire sum be recovered to the state. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 15 Mar 24)

Society

The Chelyabinsk diocese is to set up a centre for those in trouble, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 11 March. About 15 people simultaneously will be able to reside at the centre. According to representatives of the diocese, the premises was provided by a charity giver free of charge. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 11 Mar 24)

Chelyabinsk Region is to provide help in reconstructing the occupied Ukrainian town of Avdiivka destroyed during hostilities, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 12 March. Two more regions will also become sponsors of the "liberated" town in the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic (DNR). The decision was announced following a working visit of deputy head of the presidential administration Sergei Kiriyenko to Donbas. According to DNR head Denis Pushilin, the local residents need bread, bottles of cooking gas, and petrol for power generators. Chelyabinsk Region is also reconstructing Yasinovataya and Volnovakha. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 12 Mar 24)

In 2024-25, regions representing the Urals Federal District are to help rebuild more than 240 facilities in Donbas, Rossiya 1 TV quoted presidential envoy Vladimir Yakushev as saying on 14 March. “It will be roads, residential buildings, recreation and sports grounds,” Yakushev said. The presidential envoy specified that the reconstruction of Avdiivka, which has recently been "liberated" by the Russian army, would not be among 240 projects. In 2022-23, regions representing the Urals Federal District constructed 412 blocks of flats, 108 facilities of the housing and utilities sector, 59 schools, 34 nurseries, 27 hospitals and 21 social facilities. (Rossiya 1 TV online news, Chelyabinsk, 14 Mar 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 17 Mar 24

snippet:

title: Video of alleged IS member involved in Ingushetia shoot-out shared online
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A high-profile supporter of Islamic State group (IS) has shared a video showing a man pledging allegiance to the jihadist group and who was said to have been among the suspected IS militants killed in a shoot-out with police in the Russian North Caucasus republic of Ingushetia on 2 March. IS has not officially claimed any link with this incident.
body:
Last week, the Russian authorities said that said six suspected IS fighters were killed in an anti-terrorist operation following a clash in the town of Karabulak in Ingushetia on 2 March. They said that the men had been behind an attack on a traffic police post and the killing of three police officers in March 2023.

On 10 March, the pro-IS Telegram channel "Tafa'ul Mustamir" (Constant Interaction) shared the 02:46-minute video. It was subsequently promoted by another prominent pro-IS media outlet, "Bariqa News Agency".

The video features one man who holds a rifle, with the trademark black IS banner behind him, as he "renews" his pledge of loyalty to IS leadership.

He delivers his message in very good Arabic, but with a slight accent, indicating he is not a native speaker of the language. The video does not indicate the date of recording.

While the speaker does not identify himself nor speaks about any specific events in the clip shared online, the post by Tafa'ul Mustamir identifies him as "Abd al-Karim al-Ingushi [from Ingushetia]". It says he and his "brothers" (fellow militants) "died fighting the criminal Russian authorities in Karabulak, Ingushetia"

The speaker, however, does indicate that he is a member of IS's so-called Caucasus Province branch, which is one of the least active of IS's global affiliates. The last time that branch claimed an attack was on 28 December 2020, when it said one of its militants killed a police officer in Chechnya.

The message

In the short video, the speaker says "we the mujahidin of the Caucasus wilayah [IS branch]" urge IS's "caliph", Abu Hafs al-Hashimi al-Qurashi, to be resolute on the path of jihad and "be fair on all matters". He tells him to "march on", assuring him "there are men behind you [who have your back]".

Following from that, he "renews" his pledge of allegiance to Abu Hafs.

The speaker then turns to address "our brother mujahidin everywhere, particularly those in Syria, Khorasan [Afghanistan-Pakistan region] and Africa", expressing his "love" and "solidarity".

He also tells his fellow jihadists in these branches to avoid divisions and differences, adding that "we must be like a single body against the infidels".

It is unclear if this was general advice against disunity, or implies possible internal divisions across some branches. The same goes for the advice to Abu Hafs to be "fair to all" and firm on the path of jihad, and whether that too was general advice or implied some deeper meaning.

The speaker concludes his message by addressing male and female prisoners affiliated to IS, telling them "we have not forgotten about you nor ever will", adding that "freeing you is our priority".

Such messages to IS-linked prisoners is a staple of IS leadership addresses, which often tell the group's followers worldwide to make the freeing of prisoners their "topmost priority".

IS itself has not shared the latest video nor indicated any involvement in the 2 March clashes in Ingushetia.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2128 gmt 10 Mar 24

title: Rocket strike kills 10 Russian soldiers at Luhansk training ground - report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least ten Russian soldiers have been killed by a suspected Himars rocket strike on a training ground in Ukraine's Luhansk Region, ASTRA Telegram channel reported on 14 March.
body:
"Three unidentified missiles (presumably Himars) attacked a military training ground in the area of the occupied village of Trokhizbenka, Luhansk Region on the morning of 13 March," Astra said. At least 10 military personnel were killed as a result of the attack, but the exact number of dead and wounded is unknown, the report said.

Dozens of Russian soldiers were reportedly killed in two separate rocket strikes on training grounds on 21 and 22 February 2024 in occupied Donetsk.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0650 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia North Ossetia Media 4-10 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from state-owned GTRK Alaniya TV, Severnaya Osetiya, Vladikavkaz and Slovo newspapers, Region15.ru and OsNova information portals, as well as Krylya TV information and analytical portal, for the period 4-10 March 2024:

Presidential election
body:
About 460 staffers of the regional directorate of the Emergencies Ministry are to be on duty at polling stations during the presidential election in North Ossetia, GTRK Alaniya TV reported on 10 March. (GTRK Alaniya TV news, Vladikavkaz, 10 Mar 24)

Former Vladikavkaz mayor Mikhail Shatalov has chaired a meeting of the local public council, Severnaya Osetiya newspaper reported on 5 March. A number of pressing issues, including the forthcoming presidential election, were on the agenda. Vladikavkaz mayor Alexander Patsiorin said they received many requests from the "special military operation zone" to “make the right choice” in the election. (Severnaya Osetiya newspaper, Vladikavkaz, 5 Mar 24)

Political

North Ossetia head Sergei Menyaylo has held a meeting of the council for interethnic and inter-confessional relations, GTRK Alaniya TV reported on 4 March. Representatives of the clergy, heads of municipalities and public organisations discussed a positive role of ethnic and cultural communities, as well as religious organisations. According to regional minister for ethnic policy and foreign ties Alan Bagiyev, ethnic holidays and festivals, cultural and other events harmonise relations. Menyaylo said interethnic and inter-confessional concord should be preserved in the republic to counter destructive information and ideological influence outside. (GTRK Alaniya TV news, Vladikavkaz, 4 Mar 24)

Menyalo has chaired a weekly meeting with members of the regional government, heads of federal and local government authorities, Severnaya Osetiya newspaper reported on 4 March. The integration of energy and utility networks, signing of state and municipal contracts on construction and repair works, as well as renovation and repairing of memorials to late defenders of the Motherland, were on the agenda. Menyaylo told off representatives of local government authorities who failed to draw up bidding documents. Menyaylo said he would revoke federal and regional funds from districts which foiled the implementation of projects. The money will be returned to the budget or given to other districts, Menyaylo added. (Severnaya Osetiya newspaper, Vladikavkaz, 4 Mar 24)

Menyaylo has visited the World Youth Forum in Sochi, Slovo newspaper reported on 7 March. The republic head voice support to local young people participating in the forum and discussed topical problems relating to education, development of the country in the new international circumstances, economic and scientific opportunities. (Slovo newspaper, Vladikavkaz, 7 Mar 24)

Boundaries of the master plan of Vladikavkaz should be renewed, Region15.ru portal quoted chairman of the regional government Boris Dzhanayev as saying at a working meeting on land problems on 8 March. Dzhanayev also spoke about the sanitary condition of the city territories, especially parks and recreation areas. (Region15.ru information portal, Vladikavkaz, 8 Mar 24)

Economic

In October-December 2023, North Ossetia has ended up among outsiders in the unemployment rate in a rating compiled by the RIA Novosti news agency, Osnova portal reported on 4 March. The republic was ranked 81st. Almost six months on average are needed to find a job in North Ossetia. (Osnova information website, Vladikavkaz, 4 Mar 24)

Public sector employees are to be paid their salaries for February in the next few days, Region15.ru portal quoted acting regional minister of finances Oleg Isakov as saying on 4 March. (Region15.ru information portal, Vladikavkaz, 4 Mar 24)

Society

About 30 young families, 22 of which are with many children, have received housing certificates in Vladikavkaz to improve their living conditions, Region15.ru portal reported on 6 March. According to Vladikavkaz administration head Vyacheslav Mildzikhov, 53m roubles (around $576,900 at the current exchange rate), including more than 9.6m roubles from the city budget, were allocated to implement the programme. (Region15.ru information portal, Vladikavkaz, 6 Mar 24)

More than 5,000 mothers of large families have retired early in North Ossetia, Osnova portal reported on 7 March. (Osnova information website, Vladikavkaz, 7 Mar 24)

Representatives of all 36 ethnic and cultural communities registered in the republic are to take part in the festivities to mark the 100th anniversary of North Ossetia’s foundation and the 240th anniversary of Vladikavkaz, Region15.ru portal quoted regional minister for ethnic policy and foreign ties Alan Bagiyev as saying on 7 March. (Region15.ru information portal, Vladikavkaz, 7 Mar 24)

Military

About 100 kamikaze drones worth 5m roubles have been given to the Alaniya subversive and reconnaissance unit, Osnova portal reported on 6 March. The equipment was anonymously purchased by a local businessman. The unit, together with other units from North Ossetia, is working near the village of Orekhovo, performing the most difficult missions in the "special military operation zone". (Osnova information website, Vladikavkaz, 6 Mar 24)

Students of the local culture college have collected humanitarian aid to participants in the “special military operation” in Ukraine, GTRK Alaniya TV reported on 9 March, citing the republic head Sergei Menyaylo’s Telegram channel. The servicemen will receive water, hygiene items, socks, tea and coffee. (GTRK Alaniya TV news, Vladikavkaz, 9 Mar 24)

Crime

Criminal proceedings on charges of fraud have been initiated against three more lawyers representing the North Ossetia law chamber, Krylya TV portal reported on 5 March. In September-November 2022, the suspects produced forged information on services provided to their defenders and illegally received payments for it. (Krylya TV information and analytical portal, Vladikavkaz, 5 Mar 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 10 Mar 24

title: Moscow attack gunmen were on drugs - state media report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian state news agency TASS has quoted a source in the law enforcement agencies as saying that the four gunmen thought to have carried out the concert hall attack in a Moscow suburb were under the influence of drugs.
body:
"The four were under the influence of drugs. An examination is under way to establish what kind of drug or psychotropic substance they used," the source was quoted saying.

The source also suggested that the suspects may have taken illegal drugs before the day of the attack, TASS said.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1017 gmt 28 Mar 24

title: Putin said 'ready to further strengthen practical interaction' with Azerbaijan
snippet:
Text of report in English by Russian presidential website on 24 March

Telephone conversation with President of Azerbaijan Ilham Aliyev
body:
24 March 2024

During the conversation, President of the Republic of Azerbaijan Ilham Aliyev strongly condemned the terrorist attack at Crocus City Hall, which claimed the lives of over 100 innocent civilians, expressed deep condolences to their families and friends, and wished a speedy recovery to the injured.

Ilham Aliyev stressed that the people of Azerbaijan stand together with the Russian people on this day of national mourning and expressed confidence that the severe punishment of the criminals and those who masterminded that crime was unavoidable.

Vladimir Putin thanked the President of Azerbaijan for his words of support and expressed readiness to further strengthen practical interaction in the spirit of strategic partnership and alliance between Russia and Azerbaijan.

24 March 2024

title: Ex-cadet sentenced to 12 years in Russia for spying
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Moscow's Second Western District Military Court has sentenced a former cadet at a Russian command school in 12 years for in a prison for high treason in the form of espionage, news agency TASS reported on 6 March.
body:
The court considered in mitigation that the accused, named as Vladislav Boyarshinov, had made a full admission of guilt and actively repented. Boyarshinov was found guilty of collecting intelligence data during his studies that could be used against national security, TASS said.

The trial was closed to media and public as the case documents were classified as top secret. It was processed under a special procedure, without examination of evidence, as Boyarshinov admitted his guilt, the report added.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0104 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Russian official says Moldova's CFE treaty suspension irrelevant
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The deputy speaker of Russia's Federation Council Konstantin Kosachev has said Moldova's announcement that it is suspending compliance with the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty (CFE) is "irrelevant", state-owned TASS news agency reported on 6 March.
body:
"The step is completely irrelevant from the point of view of the current security situation," he said. "The basic CFE Treaty lost its meaning at the moment when the Nato countries, unlike Russia and three other CIS states, refused to ratify its adapted version. And from that moment on, preserving the treaty lost all meaning, which was reflected in the Russian Federation's decision to denounce the CFE Treaty in May 2023," he said.

The CFE Treaty was signed in 1990 and adapted in 1997. Nato countries did not ratify the adapted version of the document, continuing to adhere to the 1990 provisions that contain conventional weapons rules based on the balance between the alliance and the now disbanded Warsaw Pact.

President Vladimir Putin signed the law on Russia's denunciation of the CFE Treaty on 29 May 2023; it entered into force on 9 June. Moscow has repeatedly stated that the blame for the cessation of the agreement will fall on the United States and its allies, TASS noted.

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1418 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: MP said dropped from state TV shows over 'enemy' of Russia rhetoric
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's state TV channel Rossiya 1 has stopped inviting war-mongering MP Andrei Gurulyov to its current affairs talk shows, according to a report by investigative website Agentstvo.
body:
Agentstvo said Gurulyov has not appeared on any Rossiya 1 show since 14 December and that he has not appeared since 16 December on Solovyov LIVE (Soloviev LIVE), the online show of Vladimir Solovyov, one of Rossiya 1's leading presenters.

Agentstvo said Gurulyov was dropped from state TV following his "scandalous" call to reinstate the death penalty in Russia for its "internal enemies", and to "destroy enemy" writer Boris Akunin.

Until then, Gurulyov had been a regular guest on Solovyov's Sunday Evening with Vladimir Solovyov and the weekday day-time talk show 60 Minut (60 Minutes).

Since then however Gurulyov has made just one appearance on state TV, according to Agentstvo - he gave "a brief commentary" to state news channel Rossiya 24 in January.

According to Telegram channel BRIEF, Gurulyov was given a dressing down for his remarks by the leadership of the State Duma lower house of parliament and his United Russia party.

Agentstvo said Gurulyov had been dropped by Russian state TV before, from late October to the beginning of December 2022, following his criticism of the Defence Ministry.

Source: Agentstvo in Russian 11 Mar 24

title: Antidepressant sales in Russia at five-year high - report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The number of packages of antidepressants sold in Russian pharmacies is up by 33% year-on-year, reaching a five-year high, according to a report by the business newspaper Vedomosti.
body:
About 3.6m packages were sold in the first 11 weeks of 2024, up from 2.7m in the same period last year, the paper reported on 26 March, quoting data collected by analytics firm DSM Group.

Escitalopram, an SSRI, and trazodone, a serotonin modulator, are the two most commonly sold medications, according to the report.

Source: Vedomosti website, Moscow, in Russian 2139 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Vladivostok Media 11-17 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from state-owned GTRK Vladivostok TV and OTV Prim Maritime Territory Public TV news, the PrimaMedia news agency and the Telegram channels Neshport and DFO.INFO for the period 11-17 March 2024:

Presidential election
body:
The Far Eastern Federal District demonstrated a high average voter turnout and the best regional results in the country amidst a record low number of violations in the presidential election held on 15-17 March, the Telegram channel Neshport said on 17 March. As a result, experts expect an "extremely high level of support" for incumbent President Vladimir Putin. "The election campaigning was held without excessive information and administrative pressure. On the contrary, constant attempts to rock the boat via social networks had the opposite effect," pundit Alexander Asafov, a member of the Russian Civic Chamber, said. According to him, the high voter turnout stemmed from the proper arrangement of voting and few instances of election violations and ballot stuffing. The population's trust in the federal authorities has considerably grown over the past five years thanks to both unprecedented support measures and the authorities' care for local residents, the expert said.

Political analyst Mikhail Kuznetsov attributed the high voter turnout to the successes of the socioeconomic development in the district in recent years, whereas pundit Yevgeny Chadayev emphasised Far Easterners' patriotic feelings that came to the fore in decision-making. "In a situation of the special military operation [the war on Ukraine], external challenges and the sanctions pressure on Russia new political views have formed. People are very patriotically-minded. They cast their votes for our state. I visited eight polling stations today and saw a genuine desire to defend our motherland everywhere," the expert said.

"There is nothing unusual in the high voter turnout: this is a cocktail of society's high confidence about the need to save Russia and its being tired with external pressure. In fact, the West provided for these voting results on its own by endlessly showering Russians with sanctions," the Telegram channel DFO.INFO claimed. (Telegram messaging app, 17 Mar 24, 0600 gmt 16 Mar 24 and 0920 gmt 16 Mar 24) Political

Several activists of the regional HQ of the opposition politician Boris Nadezhdin, who was denied registration for the presidential race, have been arrested for displaying extremist symbols, the PrimaMedia news agency reported on 14 March. They will spend six days in a remand centre as an administrative punishment. The head of the regional HQ, Igor Krasnov, was found guilty of demonstrating the symbol of the international LGBT movement, which is banned in Russia, in the Telegram messenger. Activist Anastasia Konkova was found guilty of demonstrating the Nazi swastika on Telegram. Activist Daniil Laptev was punished for posting on Telegram the Black Sun symbol, which is believed to be propaganda of national-socialist ideology, which is also seen as a public display of Nazi symbols. (PrimaMedia news agency, 14 Mar 24) Economic

Vladivostok mayor Konstantin Shcherbakov has delivered a report on the city administration's performance in 2023, OTV Prim reported on 14 March. He focused on major projects aimed at developing the city's infrastructure and improving locals' living conditions. Seventeen points of attraction, such as parks, public gardens and embankments, were revamped and 18 new ones built. Road repairs took place at 60 sections and over 80 kilometres of heating supply networks was upgraded. The city's budget exceeded 30bn roubles, while investment in the city economy has increased by 150% over the last three years, Shestakov said, as reported by GTRK Vladivostok TV. Seventy-seven international companies got registered as residents of the offshore area on Russky Island, he said, adding that 30% of container shipments was processed via the Vladivostok ports in 2023. The number of small and medium-sized businesses was dynamically growing. Over 32,000 people got registered as self-employed, which is a record high among the Far Eastern regions. (OTV Prim, Maritime Territory Public TV news, 0602 gmt 14 Mar 24; GTRK Vladivostok TV news, Vladivostok, 0527 gmt and 0058 gmt 14 Mar 24)

title: Russia develops naval unmanned air vehicle system - report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia is about to field a naval variant of one of its "kamikaze drones" or unmanned combat air vehicles (UCAV), pro-government newspaper Izvestia's website reported on 10 March.
body:
The unnamed system, which is undergoing final testing, will be deployed on larger warships as well as small cutters, the report said, citing unnamed Defence Ministry sources.

It will be capable of engaging surface and land targets, for example in support of marines landing ashore, said the report, which did not give more specific information about the system.

Source: Izvestia website, Moscow, in Russian 2249 gmt 10 Mar 24

title: Ukraine minister says troops should 'feel' shell bump soon
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba has said that Ukrainian troops on the frontline will feel an increase in ammunition "in the near future" thanks to a Czech initiative, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency quoted him as saying at a news conference with his Moldovan counterpart, Mihai Popsoi, in Kyiv on 13 March.
