body:
"This week we will be in contact with our Czech colleagues, and they will present the plan of ammunition supply in detail and explain how it will all work. We are ready for full cooperation," Kuleba said.

"According to preliminary signals, which we have received, our boys on the frontline will already feel the increase in ammunition supply in the near future. So, it will not take many months," he added.

Kuleba said the Czech initiative was meant to be implemented within a year.

"The first rounds of ammunition will be supplied in the near future. And then new batches will come throughout the year," he said.

On 7 March, Czech President Petr Pavel said his country had secured financing for the purchase of 800,000 artillery shells for Ukraine.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 0928 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: Ukraine minister, army chief discuss defence ties with Norway
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian Defence Minister Rustem Umyerov and Commander-in-Chief Oleksandr Syrskyy have discussed defence cooperation with Norwegian Defence Minister Bjorn Arild Gram.
body:
"We talked about the situation on the frontline and Ukraine's immediate needs, including artillery and air defence. We discussed, in particular, further cooperation in the defence sector," Syrskyy posted on Telegram.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1322 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Zelensky says Ukraine war of 'global significance'
snippet:
The war Ukraine wages to protect its territory and sovereignty is of global significance, since this is a war for the dignity of people and every nation that seeks its own destiny, President Volodymyr Zelensky has said on the second anniversary of the liberation of Kyiv Region from Russian occupation. The following is the text of Zelensky’s speech posted on the presidential website in English on 31 March:

Dear Ukrainians! And everyone who stands with Ukraine!

title: Putin wants to blame Moscow attack on Ukraine - Zelensky
snippet:
The following is the text in English of President Volodymyr Zelensky's address to the nation published on his official website on 23 March:

Dear Ukrainians,
body:
Today, throughout many cities and communities of our state, municipal services, repair teams, and energy workers have been tirelessly working on the aftermath of the Russian terrorist attack that occurred on Friday. People have been working continuously for the second day.

At this moment, normal power supply has been restored almost everywhere. There were some problems today in our city of Odesa – there were emergency shutdowns. Everything possible is being done to normalize the situation. Unfortunately, in Kharkiv, it's still very challenging. Today, there was another missile strike from Russia – these strikes continue daily. And everyone who is working to keep normal life in Kharkiv, in the region, in other border cities and communities, they are all true heroes. I thank every rescuer of our State Emergency Service of Ukraine, all employees of energy companies involved, police officers, local services, volunteers – everyone who is helping. Thank you for your dedication to protecting people!

I want to specifically acknowledge and thank the experts in Ivano-Frankivsk region, Vinnytsya, Khmelnytskyy, Sumy region, Poltava region, our Dnipropetrovsk region, and Zaporizhzhya. Thank you for your efficient work! Today, I received reports from the regions, from the head of the government, from the Ministry of Internal Affairs, of course, from our military. The state must ensure a systematic response to every Russian strike.

I also want to recognize all the leaders of states, heads of international institutions, and all our partners who have expressed their support for Ukraine these days. It is important to act together every time missiles and drones attempt to destroy our lives. To act to reduce the potential for terror, to block it. This particularly concerns air defense systems, as well as sanctions. All these Iskander, Kinzhal and other Russian missiles have dozens of components imported for terror from other countries. The missiles used in this attack against Ukraine, against our energy system, had at least three hundred types of components from ten countries. Together with the "Shahed" drones, there were at least seven and a half thousand components in total. Each of them represents a violation of sanctions regimes against Russia, each one represents someone's attempt to make money from destroying lives. This needs to be stopped.

Another thing. What happened yesterday in Moscow is obvious, both Putin and other scoundrels simply try to blame everything on someone else. They always resort to the same methods. It's been done before. There have been blown-up houses, shootings, and explosions. And they always blame others. They have come to Ukraine, burn our cities – and try to blame Ukraine. They torture, rape people – and accuse them. They have brought hundreds of thousands of their terrorists here, to Ukrainian land, they fight against us, and they don't care what's happening inside their own country. Yesterday all this happened, and this absolute miserable Putin, instead of attending to his own citizens of Russia, addressing them, remained silent for a day – thinking about how to link this with Ukraine. Everything is absolutely predictable. Those hundreds of thousands of Russians who are now killing on Ukrainian land would surely be enough to stop any terrorists. And if the Russians are ready to silently die in "Crocus Halls" and not ask any questions to their security and intelligence agencies, then Putin will try to turn such a situation to his personal advantage again.

Terrorists must always lose. I thank everyone who truly defends life! I'm grateful to all our people who are fighting against terror. And around the world, we must defend against those who consider people merely expendable.

Glory to Ukraine!

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in English 2000 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Ukraine downs 26 out of 28 Russian attack drones
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences overnight downed 26 out of 28 Russian attack drones over Odesa, Kharkiv, Dnipropetrovsk, and Zaporizhzhya regions, Air Force commander Lt Gen Mykola Oleschuk reported on Telegram.
body:
He added that Russia also launched three Kh-22 cruise missiles, one Kh-31 anti-ship missile, and S-300 anti-aircraft missiles. 

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0526 GMT 28 Mar 24

title: Ukraine, Greece start working on security deal - Zelensky
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine and Greece have begun work on a bilateral security agreement, President Volodymyr Zelensky said during Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis' visit to Odesa on 6 March.
body:
"We have started preparing a bilateral agreement with Greece on security guarantees, our cooperation in the field of security. I hope that our teams will soon prepare the agreement for signature. It should also set out the level of cooperation and support already achieved for this year, as well as for the next 10 years," Zelensky said on Telegram.

He later said that he visited together with Mitsotakis the Holy Transfiguration Cathedral in Odesa which was severely damaged by a Russian strike in July 2023.

"The vast majority of Russian targets are ordinary civilian objects. We must restore each and every one of them. I am grateful to Greece for its willingness to participate in the restoration of our cultural heritage, particularly in Odesa," Zelensky said.

Greece volunteered to take part in restoring cultural heritage objects in Odesa a few days after the July 2023 strike.

An explosion rocked Odesa while Zelensky and Mitsotakis were there on 6 March.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1555 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Ukrainian intel chief says Russia still gives no details on deadly plane crash
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia has not given any new details about or shown the bodies of the POWs who allegedly died in an air crash in January 2024, the head of Ukraine's Military Intelligence Directorate, Kyrylo Budanov, has said.
body:
"No one has seen the bodies yet. This brings us back to the same issue: who was there [on board of the aircraft], how many of them were there, or was anyone at all on board and what really happened? When Russia says: everything is clear, Ukraine shot down [the aircraft], and then it does not let anyone in there [scene of the accident] and does not show either debris or bodies, which were supposed to demonstrate to the world that Ukraine is guilty, we cannot it happened," Budanov told the national telethon, as quoited by the Interfax-Ukraine news agency.

Budanov said that in the two months since the accident, Russia has not released any new details.

"There are neither bodies nor international experts, investigators there... Apparently, Russia is hiding the true circumstances," he said.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1103 GMT 31 Mar 24

title: Ukraine court jails woman for 8 years for spying for Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A resident of Ukraine's Kharkiv Region has been sentenced to eight years of imprisonment for sharing with Russia information about the movements and locations of the Ukrainian military in the region.
body:
"In July 2023, a resident of the village of Vilshany, Kharkiv District, started communicating with a Russian citizen through the Odnoklassniki social network, which is banned in Ukraine, and received a task to pass information about the defence forces in the region," the regional prosecutor's office said on Telegram.

The woman was arrested in October 2023.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1329 GMT 28 Mar 24

title: Ukraine court jails former Luhansk rebel fighter for 15 years
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A court in Lviv has found a resident of Luhansk Region guilty of treason, participation in a terrorist organisation and involvement in activities of illegal armed formations, and sentenced him to 15 years in prison, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported.
body:
According to prosecutors, the man volunteered to join the "people's militia" in 2022. Later he was transferred to a military unit and fought against the Ukrainian army in Donetsk and Luhansk regions.

The Ukrainian military detained the militant in Donetsk Region.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1621 gmt 7 Mar 24

title: Belarus president offers condolences to Putin over Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Belarusian President Alyaksandr Lukashenka (Alexander Lukashenko) has called his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin to express his condolences in connection with the 22 March attack on the Crocus City Hall music centre near Moscow, the Pul Pervogo Telegram channel reported on 23 March.
body:
"The presidents confirmed their readiness for further active interaction between the two countries and maintaining contacts between the relevant services in order to effectively respond to the threats of terrorism and extremism," the report said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0957 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Top Ukraine aide, Chinese envoy discuss path to peace
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of the Ukrainian presidential administration, Andriy Yermak, and Chinese ambassador to Ukraine Fan Xianrong have discussed the results of a recent visit by China's special envoy on Eurasian affairs Li Hui to Ukraine, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported on 13 March.
body:
It quoted the presidential press service as saying that the two officials also discussed further cooperation, namely on President Volodymyr Zelensky's peace formula.

Yermak also informed his interlocutor about preparations for the inaugural peace summit that is planned to be held in Switzerland at the level of heads of state.

Yermak thanked China for its interest in achieving a just peace for Ukraine, the report notes.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1743 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says 47 citizens evacuated from Gaza
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Another 47 Ukrainians have been evacuated from the Gaza Strip, the Defence Ministry's Main Intelligence directorate (HUR) reported on Telegram on 12 March.
body:
HUR said the evacuation mission had been implemented by its representatives in cooperation with Ukrainian diplomats in Israel and Egypt.

The group of evacuees was taken from the Gaza Strip to Egypt and then it flew over to Moldova from where people came to Ukraine's Odesa by road.

Ukraine has evacuated a total of 363 of its citizens from the Gaza Strip after the escalation in the region in October 2023, HUR recalled.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1617 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Ukraine summons Vatican envoy over Pope's 'white flag' remark
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine on 11 March summoned the Vatican's top diplomat in Kyiv after Pope Francis said the war-torn nation should have the "courage of the white flag" and negotiate with Russia, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported.
body:
"Visvaldas Kulbokas was informed that Ukraine was disappointed with the Pope's words regarding the 'white flag' and the need to 'show courage and negotiate' with the aggressor," the Foreign Ministry said, adding that the Pope should instead have called on the international community to "immediately unite to ensure that good defeats evil".

See Briefing: Outcry as Pope says Ukraine should have 'courage of white flag'

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1800 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Ukraine, India leaders discuss peace proposals, trade
snippet:
Text of report by Ukrainian president's official website on 20 March in English

President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky had a phone call with Prime Minister of India Narendra Modi.
body:
The Head of State thanked the interlocutor for supporting the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine, as well as for the humanitarian assistance provided by India to our country.

The President noted the continuous dialogue between the two countries at various levels, in particular, on the support of the Ukrainian Peace Formula.

Volodymyr Zelensky thanked for the active participation of Indian representatives in meetings at the level of national security and foreign policy advisers and emphasised the importance of India's participation in the inaugural peace summit, which is being prepared in Switzerland.

The President of Ukraine and the Prime Minister of India discussed the development of bilateral relations, one of the elements of which should be a meeting of the teams and a session of the Intergovernmental Ukraine-India Cooperation Commission in New Delhi in the near future.

Volodymyr Zelensky emphasised Ukraine's interest in strengthening trade and economic relations with India. According to him, the most promising areas are agricultural exports, in particular sunflower oil, cooperation in the aviation industry, and trade in pharmaceuticals and industrial products.

Ukraine will also welcome the return of Indian students to Ukrainian educational institutions, the Head of State noted.

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in English 1409 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says one civilian killed, seven wounded by Russian strikes
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

One person was killed and at least seven were wounded by Russian strikes on Ukraine's Donetsk Kherson and Dnipropetrovsk regions on 16 March, local officials reported the following morning.
body:
One person was killed in the Ocheretyne community and another one wounded in Novoselivka Persha, Donetsk Region, governor Vadym Filashkin reported on Telegram.

Filashkin also said that 872 people, including 101 children, were evacuated from the region.

Four residents of Kherson Region were wounded by Russian strikes on thirteen population centres and on the city of Kherson, governor Oleksandr Prokudin said in Telegram.

Two people were wounded in Nikopol District, Dnipropetrovsk Region, governor Serhiy Lysak said on Telegram.

Governors of Kharkiv and Zaporizhzhya regions did not report casualties among civilians on 16 March.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1200 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says Russian naval vessels deployed in Mediterranean
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's navy on 14 March said that there are three Russian naval vessels deployed in the Mediterranean Sea capable of launching a combined salvo of 12 missiles, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported.
body:
It noted that there are currently no Russian military vessels in the Black or Azov Seas, bodies of water where Moscow has traditionally maintained a significant naval presence.

The report comes as the United States is upping its capabilities in the Mediterranean Sea to address the ongoing conflict in the Middle East.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 0541 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says Patriot air defence systems guarding frontlines
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's anti-aircraft systems including the US-provided Patriot system are operating near the front-line, air force chief Mykola Oleshchuk said on Telegram on 14 March.
body:
"The enemy continues to attack Ukraine in various directions with guided bombs and aerial missiles. The air force uses all available means and means to counter the enemy's tactical aviation, keep it at a distance, restrain the actions of the enemy's troops as much as possible and, if possible, destroy the enemy! I assure you, that anti-aircraft missile units, in particular Patriot, continue to perform tasks in certain areas of the front-line territories."

He added Ukrainian pilots also fly combat sorties daily and are paying a "high price" to degrade Russian forces from the air.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1009 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Ukraine imports record amount of electricity on 26 March
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine plans to import a record amount of electricity since the beginning of the year on 26 March, the Ukrenerho state energy company has said on Telegram.
body:
It said Ukraine would import 18,649 MWh from Romania, Slovakia, Poland, Hungary, and Moldova with a maximum capacity of up to 1,537 MW in some hours. No export is planned.

However, the energy system is operating steadily and no shortage is forecast, the company said.

As many as 405 population centres were without electricity due to fighting on the morning of 26 March, and 69 in Odesa Region due to weather conditions.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1009 gmt 26 Mar 24

title: Ukraine: Kharkiv mayor says all power stations ruined
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Co-generation heat and power plants and all major transformer substations in Kharkiv were destroyed in the latest Russian missile strikes, city mayor Ihor Terekhov has told the national pooled telethon, as quoted by the Ukrayinska Pravda website.
body:
Energy utilities are not able to ensure reliable power supply in the city while repair workers cannot give a date for when it will be fully restored, Terekhov said.

Power supply was resumed at some 40% of households while heating is supplied to about 60% of residential buildings in the city, Terekhov also said, adding that stabilisation outages are now applied in Kharkiv during which power is supplied at scheduled slots.

See also: Briefing: Massive Russian air strike targets Ukraine energy facilities.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1608 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Three killed by blast in south Ukraine while dismantling drone
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Three men were killed when a combat drone they were trying to disassemble exploded in Ukraine's Kherson Region on 18 March, governor Oleksandr Prokudin has reported on Telegram.
body:
Residents of the village of Lvove, Beryslav District, found it in a private yard.

The explosive inside went off, wounding the men. They died on the way to hospital, Prokudin said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 2037 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Anti-Kremlin Russian unit shows 'POWs' from Belgorod, Kursk
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The anti-Kremlin Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK) has said that they captured 25 Russian servicemen during raids in Belgorod and Kursk regions.
body:
In a video posted by the RDK on Telegram on 16 March, a man identified as a Russian officer said that he was captured while his unit was planting mines, adding that all of the unit's members were killed except him.

The video also showed some 25 uniformed men held in minivans, with their faces blurred.

Addressing the governor of Russia's Belgorod Region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, the RDK suggested holding a meeting for the handover of the POWs.

Fighters of the Freedom of Russia Legion (FRL), the Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK), and the Siberian Battalion, reportedly entered Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions on 12 March.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0709 gmt 16 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says Russian strike in Sumy disrupts TV, mobile comms
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian air strikes in Sumy Region in Ukraine on 14 March have disrupted television, radio, and mobile services, local authorities reported on Telegram.
body:
"The enemy is waging an information war, destroying Ukrainian broadcasting. We will not allow him to win. Do not succumb to panic and informational provocation. Switch to alternative means of communication, trust only verified sources of information," the message said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0835 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Fifteen Russian servicemen jailed in absentia in Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Ukrainian court has found 15 Russian servicemen guilty of breaching laws and customs of war during the occupation of the village of Yahidne outside Chernihiv in March 2022 and sentenced each in absentia to 12 years in prison, the Prosecutor-General's Office has reported on Telegram.
body:
According to the investigation, the Russian servicemen forcibly kept 368 civilians, including 69 minors, in the basement of a school building, using them as a "live shield" against possible Ukrainian attacks.

Ten of these civilians died due to difficult conditions and absence of medical aid.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1230 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says protesters block three crossings on Polish border
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Polish protesters are blocking lorry traffic at three border crossings, the Ukrayinska Pravda quoted Ukrainian State Border Service spokesman Andriy Demchenko as saying.

title: Ukraine failed to offer ex-army chief significant military post - website
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's former army chief Valeriy Zaluzhnyy, who was recently selected for the post of ambassador to the UK, earlier resigned from military service as neither the president nor the defence minister offered a post in the military that would match his skills and experience, the ZN.ua website has reported, citing its sources.
body:
According to the website, Zaluzhnyy decided to resign from military service "in order to have the opportunity and the right to do something else".

A medical commission concluded that he was unfit for military service, the website noted.

According to another news website, Ukrayinska Pravda, Serhiy Shaptala, a former chief of the General Staff and close ally of Zaluzhnyy, was also deemed unfit for service and removed from the military register. The website learned this from several sources in the Defence Ministry and has asked the ministry to provide an official commentary.

Zaluzhnyy was dismissed as commander-in-chief on 8 February. President Volodymyr Zelensky presented the decision as part of a big reshuffle in the command of the Armed Forces to boost their performance after an unsuccessful land offensive in summer and autumn 2023.

For background, see: Briefing: Top five topics in Ukraine in second year of war

Source: ZN.ua website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 0633 gmt 9 Mar 24

title: Ukraine PM says restoring power to consumers to take 24 hours
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal says that power engineers will need 24 hours to restore electricity supplies to all household consumers following Russia's attack on Ukraine's energy infrastructure on the night of 21-22 March.
body:
"This was one of the biggest attacks on the energy sector in two years of the big war. And the most massive attack during this autumn-winter period. About 20 substations and power plants were hit, including the Dnipro hydroelectric power station. There are problems in several regions. There are outages in Kharkiv, Dnipropetrovsk, Odesa, Kirovohrad, Sumy and Poltava regions. But the key thing now is that the energy system is intact and working stably," Shmyhal told a government meeting, as quoted by the Interfax-Ukraine news agency.

According to the prime minister, there is no shortage of capacity in the energy system.

"We are now working to fix everything. Repair teams are working 24/7 to restore power supply to Ukrainian homes as quickly as possible," he said.

"Preliminarily, we need 24 hours to power all household consumers. We will gradually restore everything," Shmyhal noted.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1425 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Seven killed, 34 wounded by Russian strikes on Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Seven civilians were killed and at least 34 were wounded by Russian strikes on Ukraine on 20 March, including the 20-21 March overnight missile attack on Kyiv, local officials reported on 21 March.
body:
In Kharkiv, five people were killed and nine were wounded when a Russian missile hit an industrial facility, regional governor Oleh Synyehubov reported on Telegram. Five other people were still missing as of the evening of 20 March, according to city mayor Ihor Terekhov.

One more person was wounded in the village of Barvinkove, Kharkiv Region, Synyehubov said in the same report.

In Donetsk Region, two residents of Maksymivka were killed and two people were wounded in Hirnyk, governor Vadym Filashkin said.

At least 13 Kyiv residents, including one child, were wounded by debris of missiles destroyed during the Russian overnight strike on the city, administration head Serhiy Popko said.

Four people were wounded in Kyiv Region and some 40 houses were damaged by missile debris in the same strike, administration head Ruslan Kravchenko said.

Four people sustained wounds when Russian forces shelled ten population centres in Kherson Region, governor Oleksandr Prokudin reported.

Two people were wounded in cross-border attacks on Sumy Region, the regional administration said. Russian forces delivered 56 strikes on 12 communities in border areas, it added.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 21 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of Moldova One TV Mesager news 4 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on public broadcaster Moldova One TV on 4 March at 19:00 GMT

Presenter Elena Bancila.
body:
1. 0010 Headlines over video.

2. 0101 A member of the Supreme Council of Prosecutors (CSP), Olesea Varlan, steps down. The CSP dismisses the deputy acting prosecutor-general, Igor Demciucin, following a motion by Acting Prosecutor-General Ion Munteanu. Correspondent's report.

3. 0435 The Chisinau authorities and the Labour and Social Protection Ministry trade accusations over wages of social workers. Correspondent's report.

4. 0637 The Chisinau health authorities report a decrease in the number of acute respiratory diseases. Correspondent's report.

5. 0727 Over 58,000 unemployed Moldovans purchased medical insurance in January-February 2024. The number is higher than in the same period of the past year. Correspondent's report.

6. 1132 Infrastructure Minister Andrei Spinu says that the ministry will not backtrack on the new Transport Code despite private minibus drivers' protests. Video report.

7. 1243 Foreign news: The Russian war against Ukraine; the German-Russian leak; Canada's fresh sanctions against Russia; Poland's calls for more EU action to limit import of Russian, Belarusian farming produce.

8. 2132 Several employees of the Environment Agency are suspected of corruption. Correspondent's report.

9. 2343 Law enforcers detain a person suspected of fraud. Video report.

10. 2343 The Bolduresti village head will remain in custody for killing a minor in a traffic accident. Correspondent's report.

11. 2432 Romanian Speaker Nicolae Ciuca says to Moldova One TV that Romania benefited greatly from EU membership. He says Romania is ready to share its European integration experience with Moldova. Video report.

12. 2728 Culture.

13. 2910 Presenter signs off.

Source: Moldova One TV, Chisinau, in Romanian 1900 gmt 4 Mar 24

title: Russian polls will largely not affect Belarus - pundits
snippet:
The following is the text of the article by Danila Lutskevich, entitled "What can be expected from the election in Russia and how will it affect Belarus? Analysts talk", published on the Belarusian website Nasha Niva on 13 March; subheadings have been inserted editorially:

Putin’s legitimacy could weaken
body:
Russian pundit Abbas Galyamov has said that in terms of the formal results, there will be nothing unexpected. "But questions could arise from the point of view of real content. Will the real sense of Putin’s legitimacy correspond to the official data?" [he said]. Galyamov believes that the overwhelming majority of Russians, both inside the country and abroad, think the entire process of the vote is falsified. 

"It is too clear to everyone, since even in the beginning stage of preparing for the election, not one single alternative candidate has been allowed. There is noone among those allowed to run who has spoken out against the war. The authorities have completely removed people’s choice since the issue of the war is the main issue on the Russian political agenda", the expert said.

The pundit explains that candidates like [Yekaterina] Duntsova or [Boris] Nadezhdin not being allowed to run by sayings that the Kremlin, looking over its shoulder at Belarus, tried to avoid mistakes made there and did not allow anyone to run who could become a Russian Tsikhanowskaya.

Galyamov noted he was certain events would develop in that way. 

"They saw what can happen with the example of [Belarusian former presidential candidate Svyatlana] Tsikhanowskaya. Those in the Kremlin understand that if a candidate were running with a specifically anti-war position, then no matter what their personal qualities were, Putin would have no chance", the expert said. 

In his opinion, about one-third of Russians were against the war initially, but now a large number of people disappointed in or simply tired of the war have joined them.

"So it was clear from the very beginning that the Kremlin would not allow any anti-war candidate to run, so as not to see a repeat of the Tsikhanowskaya phenomenon".

Speaking of changes Russia can expect after the vote, the pundit listed growth in discontent, increased suppression and a possible new wave of mobilisation. In terms of repression, Galyamov said Putin behaves more flexibly and intelligently than [Belarusian President Alyaksandr] Lukashenka [Alexander Lukashenko].

"He understands that that path is a dead end and will try to take as few steps as possible on it until the very end, attempting to get by without employing repression and using it only where ends cannot be met without it.

"In contrast to Putin, Lukashenka immediately started on that path. But it was easier for him, since even without legitimacy, Lukashenka still has Putin to help him. But Putin does not have his own Putin like that".

As far as the likelihood of protest is concerned, Galyamov noted that there is not enough mass discontent for it to begin: "There has to be a sense that the regime is weak, a sense that the protest will not be in vain. In a situation when you cannot expect anything from a protest except repression, there will be no protest".

At the same time, Galyamov said: "If, for example, the protest 'Noon against Putin' really does become massive, then the result will be a sharp decrease in his legitimacy. You could say it has been 'limping on one leg' until now. There was a sense that the president was doing something not quite right, but at the same time, the majority understood that he had the right to his post.

"After this election, his legitimacy will probably 'limp' on two legs. It is likely that not only will the sense of our not liking the course he takes increase, but that he will lose the right to speak in the name of the people. After this current election, the opinion could form that he does not have the right to speak for 150m Russian citizens and that he is not a president elected by all of the people, but a usurper", the expert said.

He said that if events unfolded in that way, it would significantly weaken Putin’s position. Including his relationship with the elite. "In situations like these, there are conspiracies, mutinies in the military and coups. And so although the situation will formally remain the same, its content will change", Galyamov said. 

But nothing will change for Belarus

As far as Belarus is concerned, the Russian pundit said one should not expect any changes in relations with our country after the election in the Russian Federation. 

Alyaksandr Klaskowski, an analyst with the Pozirk agency, believes one should not expect any surprises from the presidential election in Russia. Klaskowski said the Russian opposition’s plan for the "Noon against Putin" protest is a weak strategy: "The mechanism for falsifying the election in Russia is as well worked out as in Belarus, so we can only be talking about Putin being reelected, and his simply 'sealing' a new term for himself".

Putin’s being elected to a new term does not change anything for Belarus overall, or for Lukashenka in particular. "I think that for Lukashenka, Putin’s being reelected will have political consequences, since he will get an indirect carte blanche for his own reelection. If you imagine Putin naming his own successor, then the Kremlin could pose questions to Lukashenka. But if Putin gets a new term, then the field of play is open for Lukashenka, and he will have no psychological barriers".

The analyst said Putin and Lukashenka currently have a good relationship. And the Kremlin only really had thoughts of replacing Lukashenka in 2020 when Moscow, during the mass protests, thought Belarus would not be able to get out of its political crisis.

"But Lukashenka cemented the situation using repression. Besides that, Putin started a full-scale war against Ukraine, one in which Lukashenka acted as an ally", Klaskowski said.

In his opinion, the Kremlin is quite satisfied with Lukashenka right now and does not intend to change horses midstream. Klaskowski does not think Putin will want to absorb Belarus after the election as a consolation prize for the lack of large successes in Ukraine: "Belarus’s dependence on Russia is growing bit by bit without that, and that is probably satisfactory to the Kremlin. And it can also be used well as a counter to Ukraine. As if to say, see, if you are friends with Russia, everything will be good."

The original article can be found and read here.

Source: Nasha Niva, Minsk, in Russian 0859 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Russian strikes on Ukraine hydropower plant threaten Moldova - Zelensky
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that Russia's purposeful strikes on the Dniester hydroelectric power plant pose a threat not only to Ukraine, but also to Moldova.
body:
"The terrorist country wants to repeat the environmental disaster that we saw in Kherson Region [referring to the destruction of the Kakhovka Dam in June 2023]. But now not only Ukraine, but also Moldova is under threat. The water will not stop at the border pillars, just as the Russian war will not stop if we do not stop it in Ukraine together and in time," he said on Telegram after a meeting of the supreme commander-in-chief's HQ.

According to the report, Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal, Energy Minister Herman Halushchenko, and the heads of the national energy operators Ukrenerho and Naftohaz, Volodymyr Kudrytskyy and Oleksiy Chernyshov, reported on the damage inflicted and restoration work. 

"We discussed the most effective methods of physical protection and their implementation at other facilities," Zelensky noted.

The meeting participants also discussed contracts for the supply of weapons and ammunition.

"The need for air defence has come to the fore. Due to the intensity of the Russian shelling, it is necessary to replenish supplies more quickly. I gave instructions to step up work with partners. We count on their quick reaction," Zelensky concluded.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1314 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Belarus leader signs order on procedure for wartime state operations
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Belarusian leader Alyaksandr Lukashenka (Alexander Lukashenko) signed an order introducing an updated procedure for switching the state's mode of operation from peacetime to wartime, the Belarus 24 TV channel has reported.
body:
The document sets out the procedure for transferring official bodies and other organisations from peacetime to wartime operations and for ensuring their effective interface in case of threats to national security.

It also identifies the affected state bodies, including the All-Belarusian People's Assembly, both houses of parliament, the Constitutional Court, and the Supreme Court.

Also, the order provides for conferring military ranks on the heads of some state bodies and organisations if martial law is introduced.

Source: Belarus 24 TV, Minsk, in Russian 1800 gmt 4 Mar 24

title: Ukraine reports destroying Russian command post
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's Air Force on 11 March destroyed a Russian command post, the news website Ukrayinska Pravda has reported, quoting its commander.
body:
In a Telegram video post, Mykola Oleshchuk said: "Thanks to the pilots for the successful combat work against the enemy control point!"

He did not provide any other details.

Ukrayinska Pravda quoted its sources as saying that the command post, located on a ship, was destroyed in Kherson Region.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1550 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Russia said using ground robot vehicles with grenade launchers in Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Ukrainian military has said that Russian forces are using ground robotic platforms with automatic grenade launchers on the battlefield in Ukraine.
body:
The respective video was posted by the 47th separate mechanised brigade on Telegram.

"The occupiers have begun to use ground robotic platforms with an AGS-17 automatic grenade launcher. Both were destroyed in the Avdiivka sector by the strike UAV company of the 47th separate mechanised brigade using FPV drones," the brigade said.

According to the report, the Russians have used such equipment only a few times so far.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1242 GMT 30 Mar 24

title: Pro-Ukraine insurgents urge Russians in Belgorod to seek shelter
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Three anti-Kremlin Russian volunteer units that entered Russia on 12 March have called on residents of Belgorod and Kursk regions to stay in bomb shelters on 15 March due to military activity there, the Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK) has reported on Telegram.
body:
"Due to intensifying military activity in Russia, the Russian Volunteer Corps, the Freedom of Russia Legion and the Siberian Battalion call on residents of Belgorod and Kursk regions to stay in shelters on 15 March. The best decision in these days will be to leave the territory of Belgorod and Kursk regions until the active phase of the limited military operation is complete," it said.

The group also announced a humanitarian corridor for those wishing to evacuate the area on the night of 15-16 March (from 2100 Moscow time [1800 GMT] on 15 March to 0700 [0400 GMT] on 16 March).

It advised residents who are unable to evacuate to avoid crowds and stay home.

On 14 March, the RDK offered another humanitarian corridor for civilians after warning about a "massive attack" on Russian forces in Kursk and Belgorod the following day. It said in a later post that 7,000 cars had evacuated from Belgorod and the region and some 600 cars from Kursk.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0435 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Ukraine lists priorities for Ramstein meeting
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's top priorities at the 20th meeting of the Ukraine Defence Contact Group in Ramstein, Germany are procuring air defence systems, long-range missiles, artillery shells, modern electronic warfare systems and armoured vehicles, the Defence Ministry said on Telegram on 19 March.
body:
The post reads that the Ukrainian delegation will be represented by Defence Minister Rustem Umerov.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1040 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Ukraine's GDP grew by 5.3% in 2023 - government
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The State Statistics Service has said that Ukraine's GDP grew by 5.3% in 2023 against the 2022 data, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported on 28 March.
body:
Ukraine's GDP shrank by 28.8% in 2022, it added.

Ukraine's nominal GDP in 2023 was about $168bn, according to the statistics agency.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1406 GMT 28 Mar 24

title: Head of Moldova's Gagauzia sees Putin's 'win' as 'support' for his course
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The governor of Moldova's southern autonomy of Gagauzia, Eugenia Gutul, has said that Putin's "confident victory in the Russian presidential election" attests to ordinary Russians' "active support" for his domestic policies and foreign policy course.

title: Zelensky says air defence systems 'critical' for Ukraine
snippet:
The following is the text of Volodymyr Zelensky's nightly address to the nation published on the Ukrainian president's official website on 30 March:

Dear Ukrainians,
body:
A few important points this week:

Firstly, we continue to reboot our state institutions. Several changes have been made this week, and there are still more decisions in preparation. Today, new decrees regarding advisors were issued. I am grateful to everyone for their work. We are making the Office more functional.

Secondly, last night, as almost always during this war, our mobile fire groups, other air defense units, and the Air Force had things to do – successful target interceptions. Thank you to all the soldiers and commanders who defend us, and who save Ukraine from Russian terror. During this day, the warriors of the mobile fire groups in Dnipropetrovsk, Poltava, Kherson, and our Odesa region distinguished themselves. Thank you!

Thirdly, our energy workers, repair teams, and construction workers have worked tirelessly throughout the week. These are the people working on recovery efforts after Russian strikes, as well as protecting energy facilities in various regions. They are many, and they literally save our country's normal life. These are thermal power plant employees, engineers, grid masters, and electricians. These are the people who restore generation and power. I would like to thank everyone who works so hard to ensure that Ukraine can live normally, with power and the ability to work, in all cities and villages.

Russian terrorists are currently carrying out such heinous attacks in an attempt to drain Ukraine's power. We sent necessary signals and concrete requests to all of our partners who have the necessary air defense systems and missiles. America, Europe, and other partners all know exactly what we need, and they all understand how critical it is to assist Ukraine in defending itself against these strikes right now. I thank all leaders who are demonstrating leadership right now, especially those who truly uphold our agreements and keep their word.

I also want to personally thank those people here in Ukraine, those workers in the energy sector, who have distinguished themselves with their work in these days and weeks. Vinnytsia region – Yevheniy Kosmyna. Dnipropetrovsk region – Roman Bakholdin, Anatoliy Bondarenko. Donetsk region – Vitaliy Soroka and Oleksandr Nechytailo. Zaporizhzhia region – Oleksandr Babenko, Yuriy Bokhan, Vitaliy Ivanchenko. Kirovohrad region – Oleksandr Zakrevskyi and Yevhen Chernyshov. Lviv region – Andriy Protsiuk. Poltava region – Bohdan Beresten and Serhiy Kuzmin. Odesa region – Anatoliy Murakhovskyi and Roman Poturnak. Kherson region – Ruslan Zhylin, Andriy Riabchenko, Fedir Dorohov. Our Kharkiv region – Yevheniy Diakov, Mykhailo Parfeniuk, Vitaliy Lubianytskyi. Khmelnytsky region – Roman Hnatiuk, Ivan Shvets, Serhiy Mykytiuk. Ivano-Frankivsk region – Vasyl Budnyi, Oleh Danyliv, Bohdan Voytsekhivskyi. Cherkasy region – Yuriy Vlasenko, Vladyslav Holovniov. Thank you, guys!

We must always remember that Ukraine's strength lies in the strength of our people, in concrete persons who do their utmost so that Ukraine can do its utmost so that we all endure so that we all can achieve common results and protect our state and our lives. Everyone must now do their part – one hundred percent – so that Ukraine largely achieves what is needed. I thank all of you who live by this rule now.

Thank you to everyone who fights and works for Ukraine! Thank you to everyone who helps!

Glory to Ukraine!

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1911 GMT 30 Mar 24

title: Ukraine earmarks $129m for more drones
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Ukrainian government has earmarked an additional 5 billion hryvnas, the equivalent of about $129 million, to purchase more drones for its military to fend off Russian forces, Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal said on Telegram on 18 March.
body:
"We continue to support the Ukrainian army in the fight against the Russian aggressor. Every hryvnya that comes to the state budget in the form of taxes will be used to strengthen our defence capability", Shmyhal said.

Economy Minster Yuliya Svyridenko also commented on the move, saying: "In total, agreements with UAV manufacturers worth about 30bn hryvnyas [about $0.8bn] have already been signed, and contracts worth 14bn hryvnias are currently being prepared".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1002 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Envoy explains Russia's stance on Transnistrian congress appeal
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian ambassador to Moldova, Oleg Vasnetsov, has informed rebel Transnistrian leader Vadim Krasnoselskiy that the appeal to Russia to ensure "protection" of the separatist region, adopted by the 28 February congress of Transnistrian deputies, is "under consideration",  the website of the Transnistrian president has reported.

title: Ukraine premier plans reform, deep public sector cuts
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal has said that his government plans to implement reforms and reduce the number of ministries by a third, Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported on 4 March.
body:
"We are working to change the format of the government. In particular, reducing the number of ministries. We want to reduce the number of ministries by a third and reduce the number of civil servants", Shmyhal told reporters.

He also said that the government was working on a centralised system to handle administrative services.

"Ministries should have a small number of very good specialists who will formulate public policy, and the Government Centre will provide legal support in personnel, accounting and financial spheres, and the Government Centre should quickly prepare documents for a particular ministry," he added.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1012 gmt 4 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of Moldova One TV Mesager news 6 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on public broadcaster Moldova One TV on 6 March at 19:00 GMT

Presenter Elena Bancila.
body:
1. 0010 Headlines over video.

2. 0101 The Public Services Agency (ASP) will start issuing new identity cards to Moldovan citizens in 2025. They will replace the current domestic ID papers and willbe used for foreign travel. The cost of the identity card will be 280 lei ($15). ASP head Mircea Esanu is shown commenting. Correspondent's report.

3. 0425 Economic expert Viorel Girbu says limiting cash payments will not reduce illegal financial activities. Parliament has given the second reading to a bill on limiting cash circulations. It is planned to enter in force on 1 January 2025. Correspondent's report.

4. 0727 Moldovan farmers are divided on the bill creating the so-called "agricultural chambers". The government says the chambers should boost cooperation between farmers. Correspondent's report.

5. 0910 The EBRD will issue a loan to Moldova for building a Moldovan-Romanian power grid interconnector. Presenter-read report.

6. 1010 President Maia Sandu addresses the congress of the European People's Party (EPP) in Romania. She says that "there is no other more urgent task than supporting Ukraine and ensuring peace". She stresses that "what happens in Ukraine will shape Moldova's future for decades to come". She adds that "Russia wants to keep Moldova into its sphere of influence" but the Moldovan people "have chosen a different path". "Moldova is not on the table as Russia wanted. Instead, Moldova is at the table. Our people made a sovereign and conscious choice not to be forced to stay in Russia's sphere of influence," Sandu is shown saying. Romanian Speaker Nicolae Ciuca says Moldova and Ukraine should become EU members "as soon as possible". Video report.

7. 1432 Foreign news: Nato-Russia; the Russian war against Ukraine; Super Tuesday in the USA; Yuliya Navalnaya's calls for protests on polling days in Russia.

8. 2321 The ruling pro-European PAS will poll 22.7% in a parliamentary election, a poll shows.The pro-Russian opposition Electoral Bloc of Communists and Socialists (BECS) will get 19.7% and the populist pro-Russian Sansa party, sponsored by fugitive pro-Russian oligarch Ilan Sor, 6.7%. A correspondent notes that around 34% of respondents do not know who they will vote for or if they will take part in the election.

The survey also shows that President Maia Sandu would get 29.8% in a presidential election, the executive secretary of the pro-Russian opposition Party of Socialists, Igor Dodon, 14.8% and fugitive pro-Russian oligarch, Ilan Sor, 8.5%. Former Prime Minister Ion Chicu and former Gagauzia governor Irina Vlah would get 5% each.

Around 50% would vote for Moldova joining the EU in a referendum. Correspondent's report.

9. 2526 The Education Ministry encourages parents to move their schoolchildren from small schools to hub schools. Correspondent's report.

10. 2726 The Labour and Social Protection Ministry launches a new project to teach seniors to use gadgets. Correspondent's report.

11. 3121 Presenter signs off.

Source: Moldova One TV, Chisinau, in Romanian 1900 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Ukraine opposition blasts speaker, demands return to 'normal'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's opposition European Solidarity party, led by ex-President Petro Poroshenko, has demanded that the parliament speaker "resume the work of the highest legislative body", the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported.
body:
In a statement issued online, European Solidarity accused Ruslan Stefanchuk of exploiting martial law to disrupt lawmaking sessions and infringing on the opposition's rights.

"It has already become a tradition for the current leadership of parliament to justify unprofessionalism and inaction by blaming martial law," the statement said.

"We demand the leadership of the Supreme Council [parliament] resume parliamentary work as usual, consisting of at least two working weeks per month, a window to ask questions, transparency and highlighting of activities, to return journalists, to stop blocking inter-parliamentary activities, and adequately form the agendas of plenary sessions."

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1543 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: Ukraine reports downing 17 out of 22 Russian Shahed-type drones
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences downed 17 out of 22 Russian Shahed-type strike drones on the night of 17-18 March, Ukraine's Air Force posted on Telegram the following morning.
body:
Russia also attacked Kharkiv Region with five S-300 or S-400 missiles and fired two KH-59 air-launched missiles on Sumy Region.

UAVs were downed in Kyiv, Poltava, Khmelnytskyy, Cherkasy, Kropyvnytskyy, Dnipropetrovsk, Vinnytsya, Zaporizhzhya and Rivne regions.

In Kryvyi Rih, falling debris from an intercepted drone fell on a residential building and caused a fire, regional authorities reported on Telegram.

In Kropyvnytskyy Region, industrial facilities and residential buildings were damaged, local officials said on Telegram.

In Poltava Region, explosions were reported but no damage was recorded, local officials said on Telegram.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0538 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Ukraine downs 58 UAVs, 26 missiles during massive Russian barrage
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences intercepted 58 attack drones and 26 missiles during a massive Russian aerial barrage overnight which targeted energy infrastructure and other critical facilities, Ukraine's air force said on Telegram.
body:
A total of 99 aerial weapons were launched by Russia, including: 60 Shahed strike drones, three Kinzhal missiles, two Iskander ballistic missiles, and various other types of cruise missiles launched from warplanes in Russian airspace.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0636 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Moldova's Transnistria sees Russian arms depots as 'threat'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The foreign minister of Moldova's breakaway Transnistria, Vitaliy Ignatyev, has said that the stockpiles of the Russian arms, which have been stored in the Cobasna depots for over three decades, "pose a certain threat" to the region. He denied reports that the separatist authorities were against their removal and disposal, but pointed out that the depots are the Russian property and the issue cannot be resolved without Moscow's involvement.
body:
Ignatyev said this in an interview with the Russian RTVi TV channel, the transcript of which was published by the Transnistrian government-funded Novosti Pridnestrovya news agency on 27 March.

He started by defending the presence of the two Russian military contingents in Transnistria.

"We view the Russian [military] presence exclusively from the viewpoint of ensuring security: there is the peacekeeping operation and the [Russian military contingent, the OGRT, which] safeguards the arms depots that historically remained on our territory," Ignatyev explained.

"These huge stockpiles of arms and munitions remain on our territory. They certainly pose a certain threat and creates risks," he said.

Asked "how many tens of thousands of tons of munitions" were stored in Cobasna, he replied: "Well, there are tens of thousands of tones. I cannot tell you exactly how many because I am not a specialist. But they are stored there. They did not vanish and they do require proper maintenance and safeguarding."

He rejected accusations that Transnistria was against their removal and disposal.

"They try and accuse Transnistria of our objection to removing these arms and munitions. The Moldovan side often speculates that the munitions should be taken away. But one should understand that this amount and conditions of the munitions [the bulk of which is believed to be obsolete] make it impossible to grab a shopping bag and take them somewhere. Where to? There are some munitions that cannot be transported any longer. In other words, they should be disposed of. But this is a complex process: factories should be built there and we need to ensure their ecological and physical safety.

"We know for sure that the Russian side was ready for that. In 2019, Russian Defence Minister [Sergei Shoigu] visited our region and Moldova. His initiative had to do with resolving the munitions problem. But as I understand, the Moldovan side was not prepared for that at the time. So the things are where they were," Ignatyev said.

He stressed that "all reasonable people would like to get rid of this problem".

"We are trying to explain to our Moldovan colleagues... that we need to find common ground for that, that certain issues should be resolved for that purpose and that we need advanced technologies and serious funding," he added.

Ignatyev agreed with the interviewer "that the munitions cannot be moved anywhere without Russia's consent". "This is the Russian property," he said.

During the interview, Ignatyev also repeated his earlier statements about Moldova's allegedly hostile economic steps, the need to revive the Transnistrian conflict settlement process and hopes for international recognition.

Source: Novosti Pridnestrovya website, Tiraspol, in Russian 1127 gmt 27 Mar 24

title: Ukraine Air Force: No Russian spy planes spotted recently
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia has significantly reduced the number of attacks with guided aerial bombs and has not been using A-50 early warning and control aircraft near the Ukrainian border for more than a week following significant aviation losses, Ukraine's Air Force Commander Mykola Oleshchuk has said on Telegram.
body:
"The enemy continues to attack our positions with guided aerial bombs, but no longer dares to fly too close," Oleshchuk said.

"There are still no early warning and control aircraft in the Sea of Azov and other areas, which reduces the enemy's ability to conduct radar reconnaissance," he added.

"According to our information, certain 'discussions' have already begun among Russian pilots about the decisions of the military leadership to send them one way. Such discussions, and possibly sabotage, during the occupiers' missions will only increase as the Air Force receives more means from its Western partners to protect our skies from enemy air attacks," Oleshchuk suggested.

In the second half of February, the Ukrainian military reported shooting down 13 Russian warplanes: 10 Su-34 fighter-bombers, two Su-35 fighters and one A-50U spy plane. Two more Su-34s were destroyed on 1-2 March. One A-50 was destroyed in mid-January.

See: Briefing: Ukraine media relish Russian warplane losses

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1112 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Ukraine power producer said lost 50% of generation after Russian strikes
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's largest private electricity producer DTEK lost some 50% of its generating capacities as a result of the 21-22 March Russian missile strikes on the country's energy infrastructure, the head of the Yasno power supply company, Serhiy Kovalenko, has told the national telethon.
body:
"The DTEK group has lost 50% of its generating capacities. Now, we can state this information officially. We know what equipment, etc., was damaged," the Interfax-Ukraine news agency quoted him as saying.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 2032 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Russia massing new 100,000-strong force - Ukraine commander
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine has not been able to gain an advantage on the battlefield as Russia is building a new force of over 100,000 troops, Lt General Oleksandr Pavlyuk, commander of the Ground Forces of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, reported.

title: Newspaper warns neighbours against attacking Belarus
snippet:
The following is the text of the article by Alyaksandr Tsishchanka, entitled "Belarus calls on its neighbours to not cross 'red lines'", published on the Belarusian progovernment website Belarus Segodnya on 28 March, subheadings appear as in the original article:

The borders of peace

title: Ukraine, Hungary to hold intergovernmental meeting
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of the Ukrainian president's office, Andriy Yermak, and Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto have agreed during a phone conversation to hold a meeting at the ministerial level, the presidential website reported on 14 March.
body:
Yermak and Szijjarto stressed the importance of personal contacts, it noted. The intergovernmental meeting they agreed on will be held between 18 and 24 March.

Szijjarto held talks with his Ukrainian counterpart Dmytro Kuleba and presidential chief of staff Andriy Yermak in the Ukrainian border city of Uzhhorod on 29 January. Kuleba said after the meeting that they "spoke frankly about our fears about each other's intentions".

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1839 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Ukrainian journalists arrested, deported from Poland
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two Ukrainian journalists from the news website rayon.in.ua were detained in the city of Braniewo in Poland while investigating the country's energy trade with Russia, and then deported, the Ukrayinska Pravda website has reported.
body:
Rayon.in.ua issued an official statement on 13 March, saying: "Editor Yuriy Konkevych and videographer Oleksandr Pilyuk were detained on 7 March while recording the crossing of the border by trucks between Kaliningrad Region of the Russian Federation and the Republic of Poland."

"The Polish police detained us and confiscated our property, did not notify the consul, did not give us the opportunity to call Ukraine, and the Internal Security Agency accused us of endangering the national security of Poland and deported us", Konkevych said.

Polish authorities said the journalists were arrested for photographing critical infrastructure, specifically the import of Russian liquefied gas.

Konkevych and Pilyuk have been banned from entering the Schengen area for five years by Polish authorities.

Rayon.in.ua chief Ihor Denysyevych said: "The editorial team has now single-handedly started the process of challenging the deportation, which prohibits our journalists from visiting the countries of the Schengen zone for five years. But we are appealing to international media organisations for support, because this move by Polish police does not just threaten Ukrainian journalists. We also demand the return of property, which is valuable and has material value."

On 27 February, Ukrayinska Pravda journalist Mykhaylo Tkach was arrested by Polish authorities while filming the movement of goods between Poland, Russia and Belarus.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1130 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: Belarus refines military registration rules
snippet:
The following is the text of the article by Yuliya Demyashka, entitled "The system for military registration is improving - Khrenin on innovations to legislation on national security issues", published on the Belarusian website  Belarus Segodnya on 20 March:

The system for military registration, call-up notices and ensuring citizens’ attendance to events when summoned is being improved, Belarusian Defence Minister Viktar Khrenin said during a meeting of the 11th session of the Republican Council of the National Assembly on 20 March, when draft law "On amendments to laws on national security issues" was presented. He said legislation was being brought in line with laws "On the All-Belarusian People’s Assembly" and "On the people’s militia". Overall, the draft law envisions changes to 12 laws.
body:
"During times of war and during periods of mobilisation, citizens will be obliged to appear at recruitment points after receiving a notice by SMS," Khrenin said, discussing the innovations in the draft law, "In peacetime, these SMS messages will be an additional source of information for citizens. The manner in which citizens will undergo medical examinations when being summoned to military service is being simplified. Specifically, by removing the obligation to undergo a medical examination immediately before being sent to serve in the armed forces, the chances of unscrupulous citizens evading military service will be minimised".

The minister added that the age at which male citizens are initially added to military service rolls is being raised from 16 to 17 years, which will make it possible to bring the results of citizens’ medical waivers as close as possible to the time they are registered or called to serve in the military.

"The list of those obligated to serve but who are given deferrals to mobilise is being clarified and this will make it possible for the most socially vulnerable categories of citizens to obtain deferrals," Khrenin said. "The list of military registration and call-up events for which those obliged to serve can obtain the right to temporarily leave their jobs while their jobs and average wages are retained for them and compensation for travel expenses is provided is being widened. State security agencies are being given the authority to draft protocols on administrative violations against citizens on registration rolls for failing to appear to be registered without admissible reasons. Sanctions are being raised against citizens who violate rules on military registration, fail to appear for military service or who fail to appear to be registered. The maximum fine for violations of military registration rules is being increased from five to 30 base units".

The ability for citizens to participate voluntarily in defence-related work during peacetime is also being reviewed.

"Compensation for such work will be provided by paying the average wage at their place of employment or by paying out a fixed sum for those citizens who are unemployed," Khrenin said. "The obligation for local executive and administrative bodies to pay insurance and retirement premiums for citizens during call-ups and mobilisation training is being strengthened, with exceptions for citizens who have such guarantees and compensation from their places of employment." 

The minister also said that an authorised body is being established to draft state policy on preparing the economy for mobilisation. Military draft officers will be given the right to limit citizens’ rights to exit the country in ways that violate military registration rules or for evading military registration or military service. Prior to this, the restriction did not apply to military service and did not extend to the category of people "summoned to military training".

The original article can be found and read here.

Source: Belarus Segodnya, Minsk, in Russian 1012 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Visiting EU official praises Ukraine's anti-corruption effort
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A top EU anti-corruption official praised Ukraine's anti-corruption efforts during a visit to Kyiv on 11 March, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported.
body:
Allan Pagh Kristensen, head of the EU Anti-Corruption Initiative in Ukraine (EUACI), was quoted as saying: "Recently, we have seen a lot of progress in the fight against corruption. We, as an anti-corruption programme, have studied progress in this area... Ukraine is fighting, the war is ongoing, but at the same time Ukraine is demonstrating perhaps the best results in all the years in part of the fight against corruption."

The EUACI chief said that there were significant anti-corruption legislation and improved investigative processes.

He added: "There is still a lot to be done... And we hope that progress will be seen in the future."

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1258 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Ukraine army chief says mobilisation target revised downwards
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, Gen Oleksandr Syrskyy, has said that the General Staff has "significantly" revised downward its target of mobilising 500,000 Ukrainians.
body:
"After reviewing our internal resources and the combat strength of the Armed Forces, this figure was significantly reduced," Syrskyy said, as quoted by the Ukrayinksa Pravda website, when asked about the previously voiced mobilisation targets.

"We expect that we will have enough people capable of defending the Motherland. This includes not only the mobilised but also volunteers," he noted.

According to Syrskyy, the General Staff is currently reviewing the size of certain units that do not participate in fighting, based on an audit of their activities. He noted that this made it possible to send thousands of servicemen to combat units.

"However, it is necessary to refrain from extremes. All armies of the world have personnel who do not take part in combat operations, but provide for combat units. This is an equally important part of the work," he noted.

Also, the general said that citizens who join the army under mobilisation "do not immediately go to the front", with the vast majority of such people being sent to training centres. According to Syrskyy, the number of people undergoing such training, as of February 2024, was 84% of the total number of those mobilised.

In December 2023, President Volodymyr Zelensky said that the Ukrainian military required an additional 450,000-500,000 of newly mobilised personnel.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 0832 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says another Russian missile shot down
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine has shot down a missile near the city of Kryvyy Rih in Dnipropetrovsk Region, the head of the local military administration, Serhiy Lysak, reported on Telegram on 5 March.
body:
"Minus one missile! The defenders of our sky shot it down in Kryvyy Rih district," he said.

Lysak did not specify the type of the missile.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1318 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: BBCM Iran Watchlist 13 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Iranian broadcast, press and social media sources

Security chief arrives in Lebanon after Iraq visit
body:
Secretary of the Supreme National Security Council (SNSC) Ali Larijani this morning arrived in Lebanon following a two-day visit to Iraq.

Before departing, Larijani told reporters that "the Resistance is part of the fabric of the people of the region" and called it to be supported.

Iran refers to the pro-Iranian groups across the region as the "Axis of Resistance", or simply the "Resistance".

Ahead of Larijani's departure, some Iranian outlets highlighted Lebanese users on X apparently welcoming him with pro-Iranian hashtags.

Hassan Kazemi Qomi, a former ambassador to Iraq (2006-10) and ambassador to Afghanistan (2022-24), told Iranian state TV yesterday that the US and Israel seek to disintegrate regional states like Syria, Iraq and Yemen, and that "Resistance groups are the only obstacle".

He also said accusations that Iran commands "proxy forces" are false. Groups like Hezbollah defend their nations, while Israel "is the West's true proxy for destabilisation", he said.

Kazemi Qomi also said demands to disarm "Resistance" factions aim to clear the path for US-Israeli domination, but "regional peoples will never accept surrender or partition".

Online anger after government spokesperson downplays Zangazur corridor

Iranian online users criticised government spokesperson Fatemeh Mohajerani who during a news conference yesterday, pointing to the map, dismissed concerns regarding the so-called Zangazur corridor, saying it was just a "little part" of Iran's borders.

A prominent anti-establishment user said on X she would say the same about three islands in the Gulf, controlled by Iran and claimed by the UAE, maintaining that "reformists" do not care about national interests.

Hardline users were equally critical of her, with one saying that "it would be no surprise if tomorrow they declare the Persian Gulf a small, insignificant speck of water".

A hardline journalist said that "Iran is losing the war of corridors".

Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi yesterday told his Armenian counterpart Ararat Mirzoyan by phone that the new route agreed in the recently signed US-brokered Armenia-Azerbaijan deal "must not cut Iran's access to other communication routes".

Iranian outlets also cited Armenian media as saying yesterday that President Pezeshkian would visit Armenia on 18-21 August in the wake of the deal.

Police say Iran arrested 21,000 during Israel war

Police spokesman Brig Gen Saeed Montazerolmahdi said yesterday that 21,000 individuals were arrested during the 12-day Iran-Israel war in June. He did not say how many were released.

Montazerolmahdi added that the police detained 2,774 undocumented foreign nationals, uncovering 30 special security cases from their phones. They also arrested 261 people suspected of espionage, and held 172 individuals for unauthorised filming.

Iranians react to Netanyahu's address on water issues, call for uprising

Many Iranians have reacted to a video posted on X on 12 August by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In it, he addressed Iranians in English, saying Israel will share water desalination technology with Iran as soon as Iran is "free", and calling on them to take risks for their future and hit the streets in protest.

"I stand with you, Israel stands with you, the entire world stands with you," he says in the video with Persian subtitles, concluding the address with a phrase "Iran for Iranians" in Persian.

A prominent anti-establishment user said Netanyahu's address implied that a "resumption of clashes" between Iran and Israel was expected in a very near future.

Another anti-establishment user claimed that Iran has suffered a defeat in propaganda war much worse than in the battle, as Netanyahu "has turned himself into the most popular non-Iranian political figure among the Iranian people".

Meanwhile, some pro-establishment users pointed to Israel's own drought problems.

One user, referring to Netanayhu's remarks on helping Iran with the water problem, published a photo of thirsty Palestinian children drinking water from a pipe, while hardliners used the chance to blame pro-reform President Massoud Pezeshkian for the water issues.

Prominent hardline conspiracy theorist Aliakbar Raefipour warned that the message meant Israel will now "activate the internal and border unrest that they failed to provoke during the 12-day war".

Coming up

Chief of the South African National Defence Force Gen Rudzani Maphwanya is on a visit to Iran. He has already met Iranian Army Commander Maj Gen Amir Hatami.

title: Ukraine warns Russia plots to discredit Kyiv, West in Mideast
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia is intensifying its disinformation campaign in the Middle East aimed at discrediting Ukraine and the West, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported, citing Ukraine's military intelligence (HUR).
body:
The HUR suggested Moscow hopes to justify its military goals and exert political and economic influence in the volatile region.

 "To achieve these goals, Russia is heavily using its spy network, propaganda and diplomatic missions.  Employees of the Russian embassy in Egypt received instructions from the Kremlin to hold a series of meetings under diplomatic cover to spread disinformation about the war and carry out recruitment activities," the HUR said.

The HUR said Moscow has sent propaganda materials that depict Russia as a victim of the West to its diplomats posted in the Middle East and spread Russian narratives of how the war in Ukraine should end.

 "It includes depriving Ukraine of military assistance from the West, military surrender, Russia maintaining control over occupied Ukrainian territories and other nonsense such as 'eternal non-aligned status', 'denazification' and 'demilitarization'," the HUR added.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1334 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Russian attacks knock out 10-12% of Ukraine's generating capacity - expert
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine has lost 10-12% of its generating capacity due to Russia's massive strikes on the country's energy system recently, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported, citing experts of the Centre for Energy Research (CER).
body:
"The strikes on generation have been significant, with much generation capacity destroyed. We have lost more than 10% of the generation that was available to us on 20 March. This is something that, most likely, cannot be restored quickly. Probably, most of these facilities will not be restored before the next autumn-winter season," CER director Oleksandr Kharchenko told a briefing on 29 March.

At the same time, according to the expert, the national energy operator Ukrenerho has securely protected its main networks, and has a reserve and equipment for restoration, while the worst situation is observed in coal power generation, with both protection and restoration.

"I don't see how coal power units can be restored," Kharchenko noted.

He added that the situation is complicated by the fact that one of the 1GW nuclear power units is undergoing emergency repairs.

According to Kharchenko, preparations for the next winter season require emergency measures and a quick response.

"If we do not at least partially compensate for the existing losses, then we will have a significant lack of generation capacities to cover winter consumption," the expert said.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1125 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Ukraine news aggregator says blocked by US domain names registrar
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A popular Ukrainian news aggregator and mail host, Ukr.net, has been unavailable from 23:35 GMT on 6 March after the US-based domain registrar Network Solutions blocked it, the portal said on Telegram on 7 March.
body:
The portal was unavailable as of 11:00 GMT on 7 March.

Ukr.net said it had failed to solve the problem via Network Solutions' support service and did not find out the reason for blocking.

It turned to the Ukrainian ambassador to the USA, Oksana Markarova, for assistance.

"We regret that millions of Ukrainian users who read news on the Ukr.net portal every day and use the @ukr.net mail service cannot do it now. We are doing everything possible to resume operation," the portal said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0835 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Three said hurt as Ukraine downs two missiles in Odesa Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Three civilians, including two minors, were injured by the debris of Russian X-59 missiles shot down in Odesa Region on the afternoon of 29 March, according to regional head Oleh Kiper.
body:
"According to updated information, three were injured in the missile attack on Odesa. They were taken to medical institutions. Two of them are children aged 15 and 10. The people were injured by falling debris. All injuries are light, and, fortunately, there is no threat to life," Kiper said on Telegram.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1412 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Ukraine intel 'checking' reports of Su-27 crash near Belgorod
snippet:
Text of report by Ukrainian public television channel First (previously UA: First) on 12 March

Ukraine's military intelligence [HUR] has commented on the downing of an enemy Su-27 aircraft near [Russia's] Belgorod. HUR representative Andriy Yusov told the national telethon that this information is being checked. This morning [12 March], eyewitnesses in the village of Valuyki [Belgorod Region] heard a powerful explosion. After that, an aircraft crashed in a forest and a fire started.
body: Source: First TV (previously UA:First), Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1104 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Damage from Russian strikes at Ukraine power plants said 'colossal'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring
