Two Ukrainian thermal power plants operated by utilities company DTEK - the Burshtyn station in Ivano-Frankivsk Region, and the Ladyzhyn station in Vinnytsia Region - were severely damaged by  on 22 March, DTEK CEO Dmytro Sakharuk told the economics unit of news website Ukrainska Pravda.
body:
"All units at the Burshtyn station and all units at the Ladyzhyn station were affected. Power units experienced various degrees of destruction: from complete to more than 50%," Sakharuk said.

He estimated the damage to be over $200 million, and added that the Kurakhove station in Donetsk Region was also heavily damaged by bombing and not operational.

"In total, almost 2 GW of available power was lost in the system," he said.

"The scale of destruction is colossal, so companies will not be able to recover without the support of international donors," Sakharuk stressed.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1430 GMT 27 Mar 24

title: The Actress Who Looks Out for Denmark
snippet:
Hunting murderers, delivering babies or guarding inmates, Sofie Grabol plays women who try to keep their country safe.

If you watch much Danish television  and that is an option these days, wherever you happen to live  a question rises: How would Denmark function without Sofie Grabol?
body:
In The Killing (Forbrydelsen), which put Danish TV on the map and made Grabol a star back in 2007, the countrys justice system was held together by her morose detective, Sarah Lund. In her two most recent series, Grabol expands her public-service portfolio. In The Shift she plays Ella, the head midwife at Copenhagens best public pediatric hospital. And in Prisoner shes Miriam, a reform-minded guard at a prison threatened with closing. Whether she is catching Denmarks murderers, delivering its babies or minding its inmates, Grabol is indispensable.

To follow Grabols progress through the Danish infrastructure, the American viewer will need the streaming service MHz Choice (free trials currently available), which carries The Shift (2022) and premiered Prisoner (2023) this week. The three seasons of The Killing are on the streamer Topic, which will merge with MHz Choice on April 1, consolidating this segment of Grabols catalog. (She also plays a public official in the eerie British series Fortitude, available on multiple streamers.)

The shows centered on Sarah, Ella and Miriam are quite different  The Killing is a lurid crime thriller, The Shift, a big-hearted medical soap opera, Prisoner, a grim social-problem drama  but the characters have much in common.

Each is aggrieved but indomitable, a working-class Sisyphus pushing ahead through institutional neglect and cowardice  a very squeaky wheel at work  while weighed down by personal trauma. Each is estranged from the only close family member still in her life; two become reluctant surrogate mothers to the women their troubled sons get pregnant. Perhaps Grabol has been typecast over the years, or has typecast herself. Or maybe the grouchy, standoffish, self-righteous pain in the butt is a character that resonates in Denmark.

Grabol is an economical actor, able to communicate a world of emotion through her liquid eyes and seemingly offhand movements. (Shes also blessed with a notably dramatic pair of eyebrows.) She makes all of these bottled-up, difficult women believable and, even when they push everyone away, sympathetic  you can see the layers of pain and weariness that they shelter behind and occasionally break through.

The shows share a sensibility with Grabols performances; they are unflashy, meticulously made, superior examples of their genres. (The Killing was a trendsetter in transferring the outr violence of 1990s movie murderers into TV, but it presented their offenses with a Nordic reserve.)

The Shift is a forthright hospital melodrama, and theres even an amusing twist on Greys Anatomy in which Ella is followed around the hospital by her mother, an orderly who breaks into meetings to pester her daughter about her health and love life. The mostly female midwives serve the dramatic function that nurses often do in American stories, putting up with and bailing out the mostly male doctors. The shows theme is the chronic understaffing of midwives in the public hospital, while its running motif is the staffs obsession with food, from the critical attention paid to the pastries in the break room to the prescribing of toast and tea for all noncritical medical issues.

But in the hands of its creator and showrunner, the talented director Lone Scherfig (An Education), The Shift (the Danish title translates as Day and Night) has a winning sincerity and humor; it isnt cloying, and it doesnt traffic in bad outcomes to gin up emotion. Tricky story lines  a midwife who doubts herself when shes gaslighted by a struggling doctor, another who sees her patients through the lens of her own history of abuse  are handled delicately. Ella fights for more midwives and finds herself pregnant at 46 (by a married doctor), but shes chipper and funny, and Grabol gets to show a slightly softer side.

Prisoner, created by Kim Fupz Aakeson with Frederik Louis Hviid and Michael Noer and written by Aakeson (who, in the small world of Danish TV, wrote two episodes of The Shift), takes the critique of the countrys social welfare in a much darker direction. It is structured as a tragedy: Three guards at a failing prison all have fatal vulnerabilities  a secret love life, a junkie son with debts, a friendship with an inmate  that drag them down into a tense and cleverly worked-out spiral of lies and vengeance.

Grabol is primary in the ensemble of The Shift, but in Prisoner the attention is evenly split among her, Youssef Wayne Hvidtfeldt as the idealistic new guard Sammi and David Dencik as the compromised veteran Henrik. Its largely Denciks show. Henrik, who vacillates between surly anger and puppy dog neediness, is the most interesting character, and Dencik (Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy, Chernobyl) is terrific.

The beat-downs, drug runs, racial animosities and inevitable spasm of group violence are all familiar, but in its six fairly tight episodes, Prisoner makes them credible and achieves a fair measure of the documentary-style grittiness it goes for. Grabols Miriam goes down some dark roads  shes not the justice-obsessed grind of The Killing or the dedicated crusader of The Shift  but her heart is in the right place. Denmark is still lucky to have her.

title: Ukraine says Russian drones hit infrastructure in Odesa, Kharkiv
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's major cities of Odesa and Kharkiv came under attack of 25 Russian Shahed-type kamikaze drones on the night of 10-11 March, the national wartime telethon and local officials have reported.
body:
An infrastructure facility and administrative buildings were hit outside Odesa, regional governor Oleh Kiper said on Telegram on the morning of 11 March. No casualties were reported, he said.

Russian UAVs approached Odesa Region from the Black Sea in several groups. The attack lasted for about an hour and a half. While approaching targets, the drones manoeuvred at low altitude in densely populated areas complicating work of the air defences, the Southern Defence Forces spokesperson Nataliya Humenyuk told the telethon.

Two multi-storey residential buildings, a hotel, an infrastructure facility and a municipal service's office building were damaged in Kharkiv, governor Oleh Synyehubov reported. He also said that cars and people's other property were damaged but no human casualties were observed.

The Ukrainian air defences shot down 15 out of 25 drones the Russian forces launched in the overnight attack, the telethon said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0700 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: TV in Russia-occupied Ukraine: 'This is what real democracy should look like'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian presidential election affected the scheduling of weekly news reviews on TV channels in occupied Ukraine over the weekend of 16-17 March. In occupied Kherson and Luhansk regions, the regular shows were not broadcast on 17 March, the closing day of the election.
body:
First Republican: 'Main political event of the year'

Donetsk-based First Republican TV's Temy Nedeli (Themes of the Week) on 16 March led with the start of the main voting days in the presidential election (15-17 March), described by presenter Darya Parafanova as the "main political event of the year". It went on to broadcast in full President Vladimir Putin's four-minute 14 March address to the citizens of Russia, in which he underlined the importance of the election for the development of the country in the coming years.

First Republican: 'Our candidate is a strong leader'

During early voting in the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) in the period 10-14 March, voting urns and screens were set up in the open air in cities across the region, First Republican reported. Voters were said to have come out in entire families and groups of co-workers - "electricians, metallurgists, veterans and athletes".

"For working people, this format was very convenient," Parafanova commented.

In Donetsk, a group of uniformed "Donetsk Cossacks" were among the first to vote collectively, a correspondent reported.

Their leader, Ataman Sergei Bumagin, said it was convenient for them to come and vote "compactly and quickly". "We see our candidate as a strong leader," he added.

Another Cossack said they voted for "our Russia, our future, our hopes and aspirations; we think we made the right decisions".

Other voters said they voted for: "stability"; "the future, for our children, for us to have a peaceful sky at last"; "for peace on earth, for freedom, for our children and grandchildren to live in free country".

First Republican: 'Not even the threat of death stops our people'

"Terrible news" was said to have shaken Donetsk at dawn on the first of the main voting days, 15 March, when three children were said to have been killed by Ukrainian shelling.

"Not even the threat of death stops our people," Parafanova insisted.

DPR leader Denis Pushilin was said to have been one of the first to vote on 15 March. "It is the unchangingness of the path we have taken since 2014," he said afterwards. "It is the awareness of the value of this choice we made and continue to make. That we are voting today is our absolute involvement in the future of our country. It gives confidence and internal euphoria."

Other stories featured included:

- Pushilin visits "liberated" Avdiivka with the first deputy head of the Russian Presidential Administration, Sergei Kiriyenko; they meet some of the few remaining residents, who talk about the problems they face, including infrequent bread deliveries, and the lack of gas and fuel for generators; Kiriyenko assures them the administration is working on solving these problems: "Don't worry, everything will be fine," he says. "You've made it through, there's only a little bit left";

- the city of Volnovakha is said to be still "recovering" as it marks the second anniversary of its "liberation from Ukrainian neo-Nazis"; Russian specialists are "literally breathing life into homes, schools and streets"; around 250 housing blocks and social infrastructure facilities are said to have been restored by Russian builders; the hospital is said to be "unrecognisable" after being rebuilt by specialists from the northern Yamal-Nenets region.

Tavriya: 'Thank you, Russia, that we're with our family at last'

In a Novosti news bulletin at midnight local time on 17 March, presenter Pavel Miroshnichenko said that the final day of voting in Kherson Region passed "without incidents and strictly in line with the law".

In a report from Henichesk, a Tavriya correspondent noted that a "gastronomic festival" was held in the city centre right next to a polling station in the Moskva (formerly Ukrayina) cinema, making it "virtually impossible" to pass by without stopping. In addition, an orchestra was performing nearby. The polling station was said to be packed.

"I voted because I'm for Russia," a woman said. "My son lives in Moscow."

"I am very happy that it so happened that we will be living in a free country, where everything is done for people, for our children," another said. "Thank you, Russia, that we're with our family at last."

An election observer said everything was going "smoothly and quietly" and voters were "in a good mood".

International observers were also said to have found no violations.

"Judging by what I saw here, it was an absolutely transparent vote without pressure or propaganda," French observer Christian Ro said. "In essence, it was what can be called ideal democracy. This is what real democracy should look like."

In a report from Nizhny Syrohozy, a local resident said that everything was getting better compared to the way it was under Ukraine. The correspondent noted that the building where the polling station was located was derelict under Ukraine, but now it has a new facade and the interior has been refurbished.

Luhansk 24: 'People were happy that they were electing a real leader'

The leader of the self-proclaimed Luhansk People's Republic (LPR), Leonid Pasechnik, said at a meeting with Italian observers that the Russian presidential election in the LPR was "fair, open and without violations", Luhansk 24 reported in a news bulletin on the evening of 17 March.

The Italians were said not to have observed violations at polling stations and to have praised the "security, transparency and legality of the voting process", as well as the presence of medics at polling stations.

One of the Italians, captioned as Donato Lorenzo Tilly, praised the care taken for elderly voters and people with disabilities, including provision of ballots in braille.

"In addition, the foreigners noted the active involvement of young people in voting, which they said was not typical for European youth," the presenter added. "They said that there is a connection between generations, which gives hope of a bright future."

Another observer, Giorgio Deschi, noted that this was his second visit to Donbas and that he previously observed the regional elections in 2023.

This time he saw the same "calm atmosphere" and "accuracy, transparency and truth that I saw in September".

"I saw people who were happy that they were part of a big family, and that they were electing a real leader," he said.

(Deschi is reported to be the founder of the separatist movement Liberazione Triestina.)

The international experts were said to have debunked Italian media reports that Donbas people were forced to vote at gunpoint, and to have said Donbas elections were more transparent and correct than in Italy.

Source: BBC Monitoring 17 Mar 24

title: Belarus sets up roadblock near Lithuanian border - OSINT group
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Belarusian military has set up a security roadblock on the M7 motorway some 10 kilometres from the Kamenyy Loh-Medininkai crossing point on the border with Lithuania, the Belaruski Hayun OSINT project has said on Telegram.
body:
It includes a T-72B tank and a BMP-2 APC and is manned by servicemen of the 19th mechanised brigade who came to Ashmyanski District as part of an ongoing inspection of combat readiness of the Belarusian Armed Forces.

Belaruski Hayun quoted the Defence Ministry as saying that the servicemen "moved from the concentration area to a military disposition and began implementing training and combat tasks".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1526 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Ukraine sets up Aviation Centre of Security Service
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Ukrainian government has given the green light for setting up the Aviation Centre of the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU).
body:
According to MP Taras Melnychuk, this budget-funded organisation was created at the SBU's own proposal.

MP Oleksiy Honcharenko said on Telegram that "the institution will fulfil the tasks set by the SBU to protect sovereignty, constitutional order, territorial integrity, and to stop and uncover crimes against the peace and security of humanity, and terrorism".

"Especially when performing tasks in the areas of hostilities, together with the Armed Forces of Ukraine [AFU] and other military formations," he added.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1421 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Ukraine starts building 'dragon's teeth' in Dnipropetrovsk Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine has started building dragon's teeth-type fortifications in Dnipropetrovsk Region, Dmytro Lykhoviy, the spokesman for the Tavriya operational strategic group of forces, has said on the national TV marathon.
body:
The Interfax-Ukraine news agency quoted him as saying on 8 March that there were pictures of those fortifications on the social media pages of the head of the Dnipropetrovsk regional military administration, Serhiy Lysak.

Lykhoviy asked residents of Zaporizhzhya Region, which is south of Dnipropetrovsk Region, not to panic over the fact that a line of defence is being built behind them. "There are never too many fortifications. The more of them, the better. Under these conditions, this is another reason why residents of rear cities and villages should sleep more peacefully," he said.

Speaking about the construction of fortifications in 2023, he said: "Last year, the war was an offensive one for us. We were conducting an offensive operation. Everyone wanted a counter-offensive with subsequent results. Back then, our sapper and engineering units were involved in offensive actions, paving the way for our infantrymen through the fences and fortifications created by the enemy."

Now Ukraine has switched to a defensive operation, including in the area of responsibility of the Tavriya operational strategic group of forces, he added.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1528 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Mine said to kill tractor driver in Ukraine's Kherson Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A tractor driver has been killed after hitting a mine in a field near the village of Topolyne in Beryslav District of Kherson Region, according to regional head Oleksandr Prokudin.
body:
"While working in the field near the village of Topolyne, a tractor driver ran over an explosive device. As a result of detonation, the machinery caught fire. While putting out the fire, rescuers discovered the body of a deceased 50-year-old man," Prokudin said on Telegram on 29 March.

According to the governor, about 60% of Kherson fields may be mined, and it is safe to work only in those that have been cleared by engineers.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1318 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Ukraine stabilising front despite shortage of arms - Zelensky
snippet:
The Ukrainian military is stabilising the front, President Volodymyr Zelensky has said. In his regular nightly address, he noted that this was being done despite a shortage of Western-supplied weapons. He further said that Ukraine was building 2,000 km of fortifications, expressing the hope that these and other efforts would thwart Vladimir Putin's "sick plans". The following is the text in English of Zelensky's address published on his official website on 11 March:

Dear Ukrainians!
body:
Today, most of the day was devoted to military and war issues. First, the meeting of the Staff. Detailed reports on each direction of our frontline: from Kupyansk to Kherson Region. The Commander-in-Chief, the Chief of the General Staff, the commanders of the directions, the Ministry of Defence.

The troops are now stabilising our positions at the front. And they are doing so despite the fact that supplies from our partners remain significantly limited. I am grateful to every soldier and commander - to all our warriors who ensure our defence and our frontline operations with their strength and resilience. And I am grateful to every enterprise here in Ukraine and to all joint ventures with partners for the continuous increase in our own supplies, for the much-needed weapons for our independence: drones, shells, artillery, and vehicles.

There was also a report on the construction of fortifications. More than 2,000 kilometers of tasks, shoring up the existing fortifications and creating new ones - at least three lines of our strength. They are designed to meet the threats. All the necessary resources have been deployed. The government, regional leaders and the military are personally responsible for the result. The result should speak for itself, with its reliability for every soldier.

Today, Commander-in-Chief Syrskyy and Defence Minister Umerov made a separate report. They spoke about the current situation at the front and about planning our actions. There should be no place of rest for the occupier. Today we also discussed preparations for the next Ramstein meeting and the key points of our communication with partners regarding weapons and ammunition.

Chief of the Defence Intelligence of Ukraine Budanov also delivered a separate report. Several issues were raised. First of all, Russia's military plans. Not only against our country, but also against other nations. The common task of the world now is to thwart this sick Putin's fantasy that he allegedly has time to continue the war. Perhaps he will intensify mobilisation after the imitation of "elections" now in March. Mobilisation of Russians. However, we must further limit the mobilisation of resources and finances, tightening the remnants of Russia's ties with the world even more severely. And everyone who values the lives of their people must do this - every leader. I am grateful to everyone who helps.

Today I held several meetings with government officials, the financial and economic block of our government and the National Bank, to discuss the state of our financial system. We ensure the stability and reliable operation of financial institutions. We also discussed this year's budget work. I am grateful to all entrepreneurs who work, pay taxes and preserve jobs.

This is the period of our maximum concentration, our maximum initiative to ensure that it is Ukraine that determines a just end to this war. We can endure. We have to win.

Glory to all who fight and work for the sake of Ukraine and Ukrainians! Glory to everyone in the world who upholds justice!

Glory to Ukraine!

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in English 1856 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Polish farmers continue to block lorries at Ukraine border
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Polish farmers continue to block lorry traffic at six border crossings with Ukraine, Andriy Demchenko, the spokesman for Ukraine's State Border Service, told the national TV marathon on 5 March.
body:
There are some 2,350 lorries waiting to enter Ukraine, Demchenko said.

The Shehyni-Medyka border crossing point had been completely blocked for lorries going both ways from 1 March until the morning of 5 March. Now it still remains blocked for lorries going to Poland.

Also, Polish farmers have completely blocked lorry traffic towards Poland at the Yahodyn-Dorohusk crossing while allowing only a few lorries per hour to enter Ukraine. On 4 March, only 50 lorries managed to enter Ukraine from Poland there, according to Demchenko.

All other categories of transport, including cargo and passenger trains, cars and buses cross the border without any obstacles, Demchenko said.

Source: First TV (previously UA:First), Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1135 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Moldova's Transnistria to open six polling stations ahead of Russian polls
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The authorities in Moldova's breakaway Transnistria will open six polling stations ahead of the Russian presidential election on 15-17 March, the local government-funded Novosti Pridnestrovya news agency has reported, quoting the Russian embassy in Moldova.
body:
There would be three polling stations in Tiraspol, and three more in Bender, Ribnita and Grigoriopol, the news agency said.

Earlier, the Moldovan government authorised the opening of only one polling station at the Russian embassy in Chisinau.

There are around 220,000 to 250,000 Russian nationals living in Transnistria.

Source: Novosti Pridnestrovya website, Tiraspol, in Russian 1040 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Ukraine building three defensive lines, 2,000 km of fortification
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine is building three main defensive lines that will stretch over 2,000 km, President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Telegram on 11 March.
body:
Commenting after a meeting with his senior military leadership, Zelensky said, "Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal's report on the pace of construction of new defence lines. Protecting 2,000 kilometres across three lines is a massive task, but the pace is good now. I count on timely completion."

Zelensky added that he received information from Defence Minister Rustem Umerov and Strategy and Industry Minister Oleksandr Kamyshin about "actual and future delivery of shells, missiles, and other weapons of domestic production".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1332 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says Polish activists blocking border checkpoint
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Polish activists on 20 March blocked passenger busses attempting to pass through the Medyka-Sheghini checkpoint on Poland's border with Ukraine, the Ukrainian State Border Service has reported on Telegram.
body:
"They plan to allow one bus at a time every two hours, both for entry into Ukraine and for departure. The terms of the blockade for passenger busses is unclear. We ask bus companies and citizens to take this information into account when planning their trips!" Ukrainian officials said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1021 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Ukraine busts Russian network operation under church cover
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian authorities on 12 March detained four citizens in Kyiv suspected of working for Russia, and identified another 15 people working for Moscow, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported.
body:
"The SBU neutralised a large-scale FSB [Russian intelligence] network, which, under the cover of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow patriarchate), tried to destabilise the situation in Ukraine," the SBU said.

The detainees are suspected of operating a criminal organisation to create and disseminate pro-Russian narratives aimed at destabilising Ukrainian society.

The SBU emphasised this group was one of the largest in Ukraine and had a clear hierarchy, task delegation, and direct lines to Russian handlers.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1325 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Ukraine military intel supporting anti-Kremlin fighters in Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's military intelligence (HUR) is providing direct support to anti-government fighters within Russia, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported, citing HUR officer Andriy Yusov.
body:
"The Main Intelligence Directorate of the Defence Ministry helps volunteer formations. If we are talking about the actions of the Russian Volunteer Corps  and the Freedom of Russia Legion, the Siberian Battalion, then this is also the responsibility of Ukraine," Yusov said.

"These people came to the aid of Ukrainians to free themselves from the Russian occupiers and proved themselves courageously and heroically in many sectors of the front, taking direct part in serious operations. Therefore, of course, Ukraine should help those Russians who are fighting Putin’s regime," he explained.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 0945 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Ukraine presidency ex-official becomes aide to defence minister - report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The former deputy head of the Ukrainian president's office, Kyrylo Tymoshenko, has been appointed adviser to Defence Minister Rustem Umerov from 1 March 2024, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported on 8 March.
body:
"The main area of Kyrylo Tymoshenko's activity is media and communications, coordination of information policy in the Defence Ministry and its subordinate structures, as well as construction of a unified information agenda in the Defence Forces of Ukraine for the duration of martial law," Tymoshenko's press service told Interfax-Ukraine.

According to earlier media reports, Tymoshenko has held the position of full-time adviser to the defence minister since 1 March 2024, based on the relevant appointment order.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1915 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 12 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Pan-Arab media say Cairo talks seek 'radical' Gaza deal
body:
The UAE-based Sky News Arabia has reported that the Egyptian government is hosting "secret talks" aimed at reaching a comprehensive deal to end the Gaza war.

"The deal could offer radical solutions that go beyond a mere ceasefire, including a prisoner exchange, a restructuring of the civilian administration in Gaza and the establishment of international mechanisms to ensure stability," the website reported this morning.

The Saudi-funded Al Arabiya said that a Hamas delegation had arrived in Cairo to resume indirect talks with Israel.

In an attempt to calm tensions with Egypt, the delegation will also seek to offer clarifications on recent statements by Hamas leaders which have angered Cairo, Al Arabiya reported yesterday.

We will be publishing a briefing.

Israeli media pessimistic on ceasefire talks

Israeli media reported indications from political sources this morning that the Israeli government is now seeking a comprehensive, and not partial, deal for the release of all hostages, despite unnamed sources telling outlets that chances for a deal were low.

The Ynet news site said part of the talks would include negotiations on areas from which the army would withdraw and the establishment of "American-Arab supervision" of Gaza until a permanent solution on disarmament could be reached.

Channel 12 News noted that this was the first time Egypt had proposed the disarmament of Hamas amid what it said was a crisis in relations between the two.

Unnamed sources told both Ynet and the Haaretz daily that chances of reaching a deal remained low.

We will be publishing a briefing.

Gaza media office says Israel has killed 238 journalists

The Government Media Office in the Gaza Strip has published the names of the 238 journalists and media workers it says the Israeli army has killed since the start of the Gaza war.

The list was released this morning following the killing of prominent Al Jazeera reporter Anas al-Sharif in a targeted strike on a tent in Gaza City on Sunday night.

Al Jazeera correspondent Mohammed Qreiqeh and cameramen Ibrahim Zaher, Mohammed Noufal and Moamen Aliwa were also killed in the attack.

Hamas's al-Aqsa TV continued to give prominence to the killings this morning, discussing what it said was the "systematic silencing of [media professionals'] voices".

The Committee to Protect Journalists said at least 186 journalists have been killed since the start of the war.

Lebanese minister condemns Iranian 'interference'

Lebanon's Agriculture Minister Nizar Hani told leading Saudi pan-Arab channel Al Arabiya al-Hadath late yesterday that the government could summon the Iranian ambassador to Lebanon if Tehran officials continued their "interference" over the disarmament of Hezbollah.

Hani's remarks came after senior Iranian cleric Ahmad Jannati said yesterday that disarming the group was a "delusional dream".

The Lebanese government had already expressed anger on 10 August over comments by Ali Akbar Velayati, a senior adviser to Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who said that disarmament would not succeed and urged Lebanon's leaders to reject the plan.

The Lebanese government has set the end of 2025 as a deadline for Hezbollah to hand over its weapons, with has been met with resistance from members and supporters of the group.

SDF delegation in Damascus for talks amid tensions

Syria's leading news channel, Syria TV, reported this morning that a delegation from the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) had arrived in Damascus for talks with the Syrian government on implementing the 10 March integration agreement.

The report cited Al Jazeera, with neither Syrian state media nor SDF-affiliated outlets carrying any statements on the talks.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) cited its sources yesterday as saying that a "technical delegation" from the SDF-backed Autonomous Administration of North East Syria (AANES) had arrived in Damascus to find "solutions to avoid military escalation".

The SDF yesterday accused pro-government forces of "provocative movements" in Aleppo province. Damascus had earlier expressed anger over an SDF conference it said undermined national unity and which prompted it to boycott upcoming talks in Paris.

Nationwide power cut hits Iraq amid 'unprecedented' heatwave

A number of Iraqi provinces yesterday witnessed a total electricity outage as the country was hit by soaring temperatures.

The electricity ministry attributed the outages to "the unprecedented rise in temperatures, rising demand and the increase in electrical loads", the privately owned Al-Sumaria TV reported yesterday.

The ministry said it was working to gradually restore power in the affected provinces, the state-owned news agency Ina reported yesterday.

Ina also said that the temperature reached up to 50C in nine provinces yesterday.

Recurring power cuts helped spark the 2019 nationwide anti-government protests.

On X, several Arabic keywords criticising the power outage are trending in Iraq.

One user said "it is unfortunate to talk about the collapse of the electrical system in a rich country like Iraq with its abundance of natural resources."

We will be publishing a briefing.

Coming up

- Jordan will host a tripartite meeting today between Foreign Minister Ayman al-Safadi, Syrian Foreign Minister Asaad al-Shibani and the US special envoy to Syria, Tom Barrack, focused on Syria's reconstruction and stability, according to a Jordanian foreign ministry statement issued on 10 August.

- Egyptian President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi receives his Ugandan counterpart Yoweri Museveni in Cairo for talks on ties and a number of regional and international issues of mutual interest, the Egyptian presidential spokesman said in a Facebook statement this morning.

As Egypt struggles to reach an agreement with Addis Ababa to resolve the conflict over its Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) - to be officially inaugurated in September - it is developing closer ties with other Nile Basin countries, including Uganda.

- A humanitarian aid convoy set out this morning from Egypt towards the Gaza Strip, the state-run Al-Qahera News TV reported today. A correspondent near the Rafah border crossing said the convoy was carrying thousands of tonnes of relief and medical aid.

He noted that the first part of the convoy, made up of around 50 aid lorries, had started moving to the Karam Abu Salem crossing - ready to unload there if Israeli approval was received.

title: US aide brings 'message of bipartisan support' to Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian presidential chief of staff Andriy Yermak has said that he received from visiting US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan an "absolutely unambiguous message of US bipartisan support", the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported from a news conference after their meeting in Kyiv on 20 March.
body:
Sullivan expressed US support for Ukraine. "I am here to say that we believe in you. We believe that you will win. We believe that you will build a bright future for the Ukrainian people, a strong democracy and a stable and secure country that will be able to repel any aggression in the future. And we will be your partner at every stage on that path," he was quoted as saying.

Sullivan also described what Ukraine's victory will look like. "I said today that Ukraine should win. What does it mean? It means that Ukraine will emerge from this war a sovereign, independent and free country capable of containing future aggression, with a strong and dynamic democracy, enhanced democratic institutions, with an economy that grows not only in traditional sectors but in high-tech as well, in the sector where you introduce innovations even despite Russian attacks," Interfax-Ukraine quoted him as saying.

Commenting on the date of a future peace summit, Yermak spoke against changing it. "I do not think it should be postponed. I think we should use the current moment. You know that the latest meeting of advisers to heads of state was attended by 84 countries. And I think the number of such countries is growing," he was quoted as saying. "I can tell you that the latest visit by China's special envoy gives cautious hope that China will also take part in the process."

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1900 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Polish protesters unblock checkpoint at Ukraine border
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Polish protesters unblocked for lorries the Shehyni-Medyka crossing point on the border with Ukraine, the Ukrayinska Pravda website has reported.
body:
Polish border guards informed their Ukrainian colleagues that the protesting farmers lifted their blockade for lorries at the entrance and exit to and from Poland on the evening of 20 March, the website quoted Ukrainian State Border Service spokesman Andriy Demchenko as saying.

According to Demchenko, as of the morning of 21 March, four crossings on the border with Poland still remain blocked for lorries, where some 850 lorries stand in queues on both sides. These are Yahodyn-Dorohusk, Ustyluh-Zosyn, Uhryniv-Dolhobyczow, and Rava-Ruska-Hrebene.

Earlier it was reported that Polish protesters allowed passage of cars and buses via the Shehyni-Medyka crossing point after a complete blockade.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 0716 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Moldovan party leader, Gagauzia head discuss ties with Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The governor of Moldova's southern autonomy of Gagauzia, Eugenia Gutul, has said on Telegram that she met the leader of the pro-Russian opposition Communist Party, MP Vladimir Voronin, to discuss Gagauzia's efforts to expand cooperation with Russia.
body:
She explained that Voronin was in Gagauzia for a conference held by the local branch of his party.

Gutul said to Voronin that "the Gagauzia authorities make a great effort to expand contacts with our strategic foreign partners, Turkey and Russia".

She stressed that during her visit to Russia in the first decade of March she had "secured support of Russia's top officials and several governors in strengthening inter-regional cooperation between Gagauzia and Russian regions".

Gutul praised Voronin, who was the Moldovan president in 2001-09, for signing several partner agreements with various Russian regions and "supporting Gagauzia's ambition to expand social, economic and cultural ties with the friendly peoples".

She also used the opportunity to criticise Moldova's current pro-European government and personally President Maia Sandu for their alleged attempts "to obstruct our right to participate in the implementation of Moldova's foreign policy".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0659 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of Moldova One TV Mesager news 8 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on public broadcaster Moldova One TV on 8 March at 19:00 GMT

Presenter Elena Bancila.
body:
1. 0010 Headlines over video.

2. 0121 Dozens of people, including human rights activists, take part in a Feminist March in central Chisinau on the occasion of International Women's Day. The slogan of this year's march is "You do no sweep sexual violence under the carpet". Labour and Social Protection Minister Alexei Bizgu and Education Minister Dan Perciun take part in the march. "We are here to express our solidarity and readiness to continue working to build a more equal society," Perciun says. He encourages schools to pay more attention to the health education discipline. The first Feminist March was held in Chisinau in 2015. Correspondent's report.

3. 0425 In-studio guest, the executive director of the Political Club of Women 50/50, Ecaterina Mardarovici, says sexual violence has been on the rise in Moldova in the past decade. She notes that women in Moldova still get paid less than men.

4. 1516 Chisinau road police inspectors give flowers to female drivers on International Women's Day. Correspondent's report.

5. 1817 An exhibition of paintings by 13 female artists from Gagauzia opens in Comrat. Correspondent's report.

6. 2010 Foreign news: Thousands of Ukrainian women fight against Russian invaders.

7. 2323 Around 100 people welcome Gagauzia governor Eugenia Gutul at Chisinau airport upon her return from Russia where she met President Vladimir Putin. Rumours that Gutul would be detained at the airport did not materialise, a correspondent says. "One could expect anything from the current authorities. But I am not afraid because the people of Gagauza and the truth are with me. I have not violated the law and I have done nothing wrong. On the contrary, I want us to be on friendly terms with everyone, especially with the Russian Federation," Gutul is shown saying. She dodges the question whether she supports Russia's war against Ukraine. The Moldovan government describes Gutul's meeting with Putin as "servility". Gutul is a suspect in the case over illegal funding of the banned pro-Russian Sor Party, which supported her during the 2023 governor election in Gagauzia. Acting Prosecutor-General Ion Munteanu has recently said that the case would be forwarded to court soon. Correspondent's report.

8. 2617 Foreign news: Biden's speech in the Congress; Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky visits Turkey.

9. 3030 Moldova's national energy regulator, the ANRE, suspends the gas supply licence issued to the controversial Nordgaz Furnizare company again. Presenter-read report.

10. 3121 The Labour and Social Protection Ministry and the Chisinau authorities continue to trade accusations over wages of social workers. Correspondent's report.

11. 3323 Culture news.

12. 3655 Presenter signs off.

Source: Moldova One TV, Chisinau, in Romanian 1900 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Ukraine restores broadcasting after strikes on north regions
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine has fully restored broadcasting in Kharkiv and Sumy regions interrupted after Russian air strikes on TV and radio infrastructure, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported on 19 March, quoting State Service for Special Communication and Information Protection as saying.

title: Ukraine jams Russian TV in border regions
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine has allocated 152m hryvnyas ($4m)  to the State Service of Special Communication and Information Protection to build a system for jamming Russian TV and radio broadcasts in border territories, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported.
body:
The jamming system will be in place in nine Ukrainian regions, including Volyn, Rivne, Zhytomyr, Kyiv, Chernihiv, Sumy, Kharkiv, Vinnytsya and Odesa regions.

"The implementation of the project will allow to push out 'the Russian world' off Ukraine's information space. An effect of Russian propaganda on Ukraine's population will be reduced while the level of information security in Ukraine will be improved," the agency quoted the service's report as reading.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1355 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Trumps Defense Team Argues First Amendment Prohibits Georgia Charges
snippet:
Fulton County prosecutors say Donald J. Trumps comments about the 2020 election were meant to advance a broad criminal scheme to overturn the election results.

Donald J. Trumps lead defense lawyer in Georgia argued in court on Thursday that the former presidents criminal indictment should be dismissed because it was based on comments that Mr. Trump had made about the 2020 presidential election that were protected by the First Amendment.
body:
The lawyer, Steven H. Sadow, said that Mr. Trumps comments, writings and internet posts after the November 2020 election amounted to political speech, which courts have considered sacrosanct under the First Amendment.

Take out the political speech, no charges, Mr. Sadow said at the hearing in a courtroom in downtown Atlanta.

Fulton County prosecutors pushed back, arguing that Mr. Trumps statements were part of a broad conspiracy to illegally overturn his election loss. The scheme is outlined in a sweeping racketeering indictment that was handed up in August and that named Mr. Trump alongside 18 co-defendants. Four of the co-defendants have since pleaded guilty.

The argument that First Amendment grounds should block Mr. Trump from being prosecuted criminally for efforts to overturn the 2020 election results has previously been rejected by a U.S. District Court judge, Tanya Chutkan, in a separate federal prosecution that is unfolding in Washington, D.C.

Georgia prosecutors noted the earlier ruling in court on Thursday. They also argued that Mr. Trumps comments should not be considered on their own, but as part of a series of actions aimed to advance crimes including racketeering.

Mr. Trumps statements were employed as part of the pattern of criminal conduct in numerous ways, so theres nowhere to go, said Donald Wakeford, a prosecutor in the Fulton County district attorneys office.

Scott McAfee, the presiding judge in the case, did not make a ruling from the bench on Thursday.

The hearing was the first to take place since the Georgia case took a detour after defense lawyers asserted that Fulton Countys district attorney, Fani T. Willis, had created a conflict of interest when she engaged in a romantic relationship with Nathan J. Wade, a lawyer she hired to manage the prosecution team.

This month, Judge McAfee ruled that an actual conflict of interest did not exist but that the appearance of impropriety remained. To solve the problem, the judge gave Ms. Willis a choice: either Mr. Wade could step away from the case, or she and her entire office could do so. Mr. Wade resigned from his job as special prosecutor a few hours later.

Defense lawyers are seeking to appeal the judges ruling on the disqualification matter and reassert their argument that Ms. Willis and her office ought to be removed from the case. Judge McAfee has said that the issue merits review by the Georgia Court of Appeals. The appeals court itself must now decide whether to take the matter.

title: Pro-Russian Moldovan party attends CIS forum in Moscow
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A delegation of the pro-Russian Moldovan Renastere Vozrozhdeniye party, sponsored by fugitive oligarch Ilan Sor, is taking part in the CIS International Economic Forum in Moscow on 28-29 March, he party has reported on its Telegram channel.
body:
Moldova is in the process of withdrawing from the CIS, a Russian-led regional bloc of nine former SOviet republics. The country's pro-European government is planning to leave it by the end on 2024.

The 16-member Renastere Vozrozhdeniye delegation is led by its senior member, pro-Russian MP Vasile Bolea, and includes other Moldovan MPs and members of local councils elected on the party's list in 2023.

Like other parties, sponsored by Sor, Renastere Vozrozhdeniye is against Moldova's departure from the CIS.

"Despite the current government's attempts to sever ties with the CIS, Renastere Vozrozhdeniye believes in the importance of maintaining dialogue with members of this union, especially with the Russian Federation. As a member of the CIS, which [allegedly] depends on this market for trade and development, it is strategically important for Moldova to maintain partner relations with the countries [of the bloc]," the party said.

It claimed that cooperation with the CIS would bring "new technologies, investment and expertise" to Moldova and "crate a favourable economic climate and stability in the region".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1026 gmt 28 Mar 24

title: Anti-Kremlin fighters publish Russian army losses in Belgorod, Kursk regions
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The pro-Ukraine, anti-Kremlin Freedom of Russia Legion has posted a list of losses the Russian army has suffered since the start of the Legion's latest incursion into Russian territory on 12 March.
body:
Destroyed military hardware for the period of 12-18 March includes: seven tanks, 20 infantry fighting vehicles, six D-30 howitzers, four armoured personnel carriers, four mortars, two MT-12 antitank guns, two 2S19 Msta-S self-propelled howitzers, one BM-21 Grad MRLS, dozens of light and heavy vehicles, and a few pieces of specialised equipment, like a mobile EW system.

The Legion also claims damaging two tanks, one infantry fighting vehicle, one BM-21 Grad MRLS, one 2S19 Msta-S self-propelled howitzer, one TOS-2 thermobaric MRLS, one 2S1 Gvozdika self-propelled artillery systems, and host of lesser vehicles.

As for military personnel, the anti-Kremlin units inflicted 613 "irreplaceable losses" (likely killed and missing) and 829 "temporary losses" (likely wounded), and taken 27 prisoners, the Legion said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0903 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: Pro-Ukraine Russian fighters say 'power slipping out of Putin's hands'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Three anti-Kremlin Russian volunteer units fighting for Ukraine have said that they "liberated" two settlements in the course of a "limited military operation" in Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions and suggested that "power is slipping out of Vladimir Putin's hands".
body:
In a joint statement on Telegram on 21 March, the Freedom of Russia Legion, the Russian Volunteer Corps and the Siberian Battalion said: "Our liberation movement has once again demonstrated the strength and power of the spirit and arms of the Russian volunteer and the weakness of Vladimir Putin's regime. Together with our brothers in arms we have proved to the entire world that Putin is increasingly losing control of the situation with every day and is no longer capable of defending the borders of his own country. In a couple of days, Russian volunteers have liberated two settlements from the Putin regime. Putin's army has lost a huge amount of equipment and more than 1,000 troops, who in a panic were thrown to the slaughter under our guns. But as it turned out, even in a critical moment for their authorities - the days of the presidential election [14-17 March] - Putin's entire army was unable to resist us."

They went on to say that the Kremlin was unable to hold the presidential election in Belgorod and Kursk regions "under bombs and artillery fire". "Nobody in their right mind after all that could claim that Putin was elected legally."

"Vladimir Putin has lost what remained of his legitimacy, power is slipping from his hands. He has less and less control over processes in Russia. Russians see it and more and more compatriots are joining our ranks. Soon we will move on to other towns," the statement said.

Representatives of the volunteer units told a press conference in the Ukrinform news agency in Kyiv on 21 March that the operation would continue.

"Stabilisation measures are being carried out," Freedom of Russia volunteer Alexei Baranovsky said. "So our liberation operation on the territory of our homeland will continue."

On 12 March, the three volunteer units said they had crossed the border and begun an operation aimed at "freeing Russia from dictatorship". 

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1329 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Ukraine, German leaders discuss cooperation, army needs
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Volodymyr Zelensky has discussed further cooperation and the needs of the Ukrainian army with German Councillor Olaf Scholtz, the presidential website reported.
body:
The discussion focused on further political, economic and defence cooperation between the two states, including localising defence production in Ukraine.

Zelensky informed Scholtz about the army's priority needs in armoured hardware, artillery and air defences. He also thanked Germany for joining the Czech initiative for procurement of artillery shells for Ukraine.

Another issue discussed was the Ukraine Recovery conference to be held in Berlin in June.

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 1506 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Mayor says two-thirds of Kharkiv homes lack power, half - heating
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The mayor of Kharkiv, Ihor Terekhov, has said that power supplies have been restored to only a third of homes in the city, and heating to half of them.
body:
"We started to restore power supply in some districts of Kharkiv. According to reports, approximately 35% of residential buildings are connected to power supply, and as for heating, we managed to connect some 50% of houses of Kharkiv residents," he told the pooled TV service, as quoted by the Interfax-Ukraine news agency on 23 March.

"As for power supply, street lighting is absent and electric transport is not working since there is simply not enough capacity," Terekhov noted.

According to the mayor, it is currently impossible to forecast when the power system will be fully restored, since the infrastructure was damaged significantly by Russian strikes.

On the night of 21-22 March, Kharkiv's power infrastructure was subjected to a massive missile attack, leaving 700,000 consumers without electricity.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1838 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Ukraine defence minister, army chief brief Pentagon head
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian Defence Minister Rustem Umyerov and Commander-in-Chief Oleksandr Syrskyy have briefed Pentagon head Lloyd Austin about the situation in the war zone, the news website Ukrayinska Pravda reported on 5 March.
body:
"We informed Secretary of Defence Austin about the current situation at the front line and discussed changes in the most important areas. We are working together to meet the needs of the Armed Forces and increase the capabilities of the Ukrainian army," Umyerov said on Telegram.

Source: Ukrayinska Pravda website, Kyiv, in Ukrainian 0413 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Quotation of the Day: Japan Raises Interest Rate After 17 Years
snippet:
This decision was based on the confidence that the Japanese economy itself is changing, rather than on short-term concerns.

SHIGETO NAGAI, head of Japan economics at Oxford Economics, on the nation raising interest rates for the first time in 17 years.

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 15 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Pan-Arab media signal cautious optimism over Trump-Putin meeting
body:
Pan-Arab outlets have discussed the significance of Trump-Putin meeting in Alaska today, with some outlets expressing cautious optimism that it could lead to a breakthrough in the Russia-Ukraine war.

UAE-based Sky News Arabia discussed the possible outcome of the summit with some political experts who noted that more efforts were necessary to reach a solution to the conflict.

The Saudi-funded Al Arabiya led its morning bulletins with reports on the Alaska summit underlining its "exploratory nature". The need for a ceasefire in Ukraine and the complexity of including European interests and Zelensky's participation in talks with the US were also discussed.

Qatari flagship Al Jazeera said the summit could indicate a shift in Trump's position towards Russia and Ukraine.

We will publish a Briefing.

Gunmen attack Kurdish fighters in Deir al-Zour

A war monitor reported yesterday that clashes in Deir al-Zour province between pro-government fighters and Kurdish-led forces had left one dead and three wounded.

The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) said gunmen had attacked the Syrian Democratic forces (SDF), seizing six fighters and later releasing two.

Syrian media have reported renewed clashes in northeast Syria between the SDF and pro-government forces.

This week, Turkey and Syria signed a military cooperation agreement under which Ankara will provide weapons and training for the Syrian army.

Turkey is one of Damascus's main allies since the fall of former President Bashar al-Assad.

It has threatened to take action against the SDF which controls large areas of north east Syria, unless the group integrates into Syria's army.

Palestinian factions call for 'national unity' meeting

Palestinian factions meeting in Cairo yesterday issued a joint statement in which they called on Egypt to sponsor and host an emergency national unity meeting of all Palestinian forces to discuss a "national strategy and practical programme to confront the occupation's schemes".

The statement condemned Israeli remarks on taking control of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, calling on the international community to pressure Israel to halt its operations and hold it responsible for its ongoing "violations".

The factions stressed their "full responsiveness to initiatives and proposals for a solution that meets national requirements, including an end to the aggression, the withdrawal of the occupying forces, and the lifting of the unjust blockade on Gaza".

They also expressed appreciation for "the great efforts" made by the mediators - Egypt and Qatar - in supporting "the Palestinian cause and halting the aggression" against Palestinians.

New settlements will 'bury the idea of a Palestinian state' - Smotrich

The far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said plans to build over 3,000 settlements in the occupied West Bank will "bury the idea of a Palestinian state", Israeli media reported yesterday.

The controversial "E1" plan, which has been on hold for decades, seeks to extend the settlement of Maale Adumim, cutting off occupied East Jerusalem from the West Bank and separating the northern and eastern parts of the enclave.

The Maariv daily quoted Smotrich as saying after announcing the plan: "This is Zionism at its best - building, setting and strengthening our sovereignty in the Land of Israel."

Israeli media have reported that the government is expected to formally approve construction plans next week.

Smotrich's remarks draw backlash

Smotrich's remarks have provoked harsh criticism by Palestinian factions and some Arab countries.

Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, along with other groups, issued statements to denounce the move and called on international and regional powers to work to halt the plan.

Qatar, Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan also officially criticised the plans, describing them as "violation" of international law.

The Palestinian presidency also said the plan undermined any chance to implement the two-state solution.

Israeli minister visits Marwan Barghouti

The far-right national security minister Itamar Ben Gvir visited prominent Palestinian Fatah leader Marwan Barghouti, currently serving five life sentences in an Israeli prison, domestic media reported yesterday.

In a video, the first published documentation of Barghouti (also Barghuthi) in years, Ben Gvir could be heard telling him: "You won't win."

"Whoever messes with the nation of Israel, whoever murders women and children, we will wipe them out," Ben Gvir added.

Barghouti appeared shaven-headed in the video, and domestic media later cited his family as saying they were "shocked" by his appearance, adding that he looked hungry.

The Haaretz daily said the release of such footage was "very unusual" and would usually require permission from the Prison Service.

We will be publishing a Briefing.

Yemen minister criticises Houthi presence in Iraq's Karbala

A senior official from Yemen's internationally recognised government has said that the appearance of members of the Iran-backed Houthi movement in the Iraqi city of Karbala, to mark the end of the Arbaeen pilgrimage, revealed the group's "alien agenda".

In a statement yesterday, Information Minister Muammar al-Eryani made the remarks in response to photos and videos shared online purportedly showing members of the rebel group participating in the predominantly Shia pilgrimage.

The minister stressed that the government had "warned from the outset that the Houthis were... an Iranian tool implementing a sectarian project".

Anti-Houthi Suhail TV also criticised the footage, reporting that the Houthis had been distributing "millions of free meals" every day to pilgrims while "stealing from the mouths of the hungry in Yemen".

We will publish a Briefing.

Lebanese army to present disarmament plan on 2 Sep

Lebanon's environment minister Tamara al-Zein, has told the privately owned Al-Jadeed channel that the country's army will present a plan for the disarmament of armed groups, namely Hezbollah, on 2 September.

Other media outlets, including El Nashra, Nida al-Watan, Al-Markazia, L'Orient-Le Jour, widely picked up on her statements.

Zein, who is a member of Amal - a key Hezbollah ally - was one of several ministers to walk out from a cabinet session last week that approved a US proposal for the disarmament of Hezbollah and to consolidate an ongoing ceasefire with Israel.

The details of the plan are "worrying and every clause contains a trap," she further told Al-Jadeed.

Tunisia union threatens general strike in standoff with president

Tunisia's trade union has threatened to call a general strike after government supporters attacked its headquarters, escalating a standoff with President Kais Saied.

In a statement posted online on 12 August, the General Labour Union (UGTT) said that it would hold a mass rally next week to protest against the "barbaric attack".

On 7 August, protesters rallied outside the UGTT headquarters in Tunis, chanting "mafia" and "corruption". The union said some tried to storm the building in a "planned attack".

In a later video address, the president backed the protesters, saying they had no intention of violence.

Since dissolving parliament in 2021, the president has ruled by decree.

The UGTT has become one of the few organised groups able to challenge him.

We will publish a Briefing.

title: Four killed, 21 wounded by Russian strikes on Ukraine on 9-10 March
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Four people were killed and 21 wounded by Russian strikes on Ukraine's Donetsk, Kherson, Kharkiv, and Chernihiv regions on 9-10 March, local officials and law enforcers have reported.
body:
Two residents of Dobropillya, Donetsk Region, were killed by a Russian drone attack, while a resident of Chasiv Yar was killed by a Russian artillery strike, Donetsk regional governor, Vadym Filashkin, reported on Telegram.

Twelve people were wounded when three Russian missiles hit the city of Myrnohrad in the early hours of 10 March, Filashkin also said.

At least four other people were wounded due to military actions on 9 March in Donetsk Region's Selidove, Maryinka and Ocheretyne communities and in Pokrovsk District, the Prosecutor-General's Office reported on Telegram.

A man was killed when Russian forces shelled the border village of Volokhivka, Kharkiv regional governor Oleh Synyehubov said.

Three people sustained wounds as a result of numerous Russian strikes on population centres in Kherson Region on 9 March, governor Oleksandr Prokudin said.

A man was wounded by a Russian drone strike on Antonivka on 10 March, Kherson city military administration head Roman Mrochko reported.

In Chernihiv Region, a 51-year-old civilian was injured when his house in the Semenivka community was hit by a shell on 9 March, regional head Vyacheslav Chaus reported.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 10 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says alleged UAV attack on Transnistria Russian provocation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The alleged drone attack on a military base in Moldova's breakaway Transnistria region was an act of provocation organised by Russia, the Ukrainian Centre for Fighting Disinformation (CFD) has said on Telegram.
body:
According to the CFD, in the absence of a joint border with Transnistria, Russia is trying to escalate the situation there in the information space.

"The Russians are conducting acts of provocation and trying to manipulate in the information space by spreading fakes specifically to escalate the information situation," the CFD said.

Moldova's rebel Transnistria region reported a drone attack on a military base on 17 March.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1633 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Transnistria rejects Moldova's statements of drone attack forgery
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Transnistrian foreign ministry has rejected Moldovan government officials' statements that the alleged drone attack in Tiraspol on 17 March is "fake news" and the video of it is a "forgery", the government-funded Novosti Pridnestrovya news agency has reported.

title: Ukraine recovers bodies of 100 soldiers
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine has received the bodies of 100 fallen troops, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported, citing the Coordination Headquarters for the Treatment of Prisoners of War.
body:
"The Armed Forces of Ukraine ensures the transportation of repatriated bodies and remains to certain government institutions for transfer to law enforcement officials and forensic experts to establish identities. The bodies of our defenders, after identification, will be handed over to families for a dignified burial," the Coordination Headquarters for the Treatment of Prisoners of War said.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1015 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Ukraine needs more air defence systems, Zelensky says after strike
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Volodymyr Zelensky has reiterated his call for more air defence systems to be supplied to Ukraine following the latest deadly Russian strike on the city of Kharkiv.
body:
In a Telegram post on 27 March, he said that one civilian was killed and 19 more, including children, were wounded in the attack, adding that "Russian terror against the city is becoming particularly treacherous".

"Strengthening Ukraine's air defences and speeding up the delivery of F-16's to Ukraine are vital tasks. There are no and can be no rational explanations why Patriots - there are enough of them in the world - are still not covering the sky over Kharkiv and other cities and communities suffering from Russian terrorists," Zelensky said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1617 GMT 27 Mar 24

title: Three killed, eight wounded by Russian strikes on Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Three civilians were killed and eight, including a 12-year-old child, were wounded in Ukraine's Donetsk, Zaporizhzhya and Kherson regions on 30 March, local officials have reported.
body:
Two residents of Krasnohorivka, Donetsk Region, were killed due to military actions. Five civilians were wounded, including one in Krasnohorivka, one in Kostyantynivka and three in Kurakhove, governor Vadym Filashkin said.

One man was killed in the Maryinka community, Filashkin said in another report.

A 12-year-old boy was wounded in a Russian artillery strike on the village of Dolynka, Polohy District, Zaporizhzhya Region, governor Ivan Fedorov said.

Two people in Kherson Region sustained wounds due to Russian strikes on populated areas, governor Oleksandr Prokudin reported.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 31 Mar 24

title: Irelands Prime Minister Stepped Down. So What Happens Now?
snippet:
Leo Varadkar, the prime minister of the Republic of Ireland, resigned unexpectedly, prompting a political scramble. Heres what to know about what happens next.

The leader of the Republic of Ireland, Leo Varadkar, resigned on Wednesday, prompting a political scramble in the government after his announcement in front of the parliament building in Dublin.
body:
Mr. Varadkars decision, which he attributed to both personal and political reasons, was unexpected, with some members of his government given only a few hours notice of his plans.

A medical doctor and former health minister, Mr. Varadkar first became taoiseach, or prime minister, in 2017, at a time when his Fine Gael party was still one of the countrys two dominant parties, a position it had enjoyed nearly uninterrupted since the founding of the Irish state.

During his years in office, though, public opinion shifted, and as Fine Gaels popularity dipped, his departure seemed inevitable, experts said. Now, as Ireland grapples with what comes next for its government, heres what to know.

Who might be Irelands next leader?

Despite calls from the opposition for a general election, Mr. Varadkars resignation does not mean an end to the current government.

Fine Gael, a center-right party, currently governs in coalition with two other parties, Fianna Fil, its longtime rival, and the Green Party. Under the terms of their power-sharing arrangement, it is up to Fine Gael to appoint a new leader, who will then become the prime minister.

Because of the surprise nature of Mr. Varadkars announcement, there was no immediate successor waiting in the wings, leading to an initial rush of speculation about who might fill his position.

By Thursday evening, though, it appeared that Simon Harris, the minister for education, might be vying for the role uncontested. For years he has spoken of his desire to one day lead the party, and on Thursday evening he confirmed to the national broadcaster RT, I want to be the next leader of Fine Gael, adding, If given the opportunity, I will give this my all.

Mr. Harris, who is 37, will become the youngest-ever taoiseach if he does become the partys leader, edging out Mr. Varadkar, who initially took up the leadership role at 38. So far, it appears that other members of the party are rallying around him.

Other potential contenders included party stalwarts like Paschal Donohoe, the minister for public expenditure and reform, and Heather Humphreys, the minister for social protection. Both are longtime Fine Gael lawmakers, but in the past 24 hours both have said they have no intention of putting themselves forward.

How long until the new leader is announced?

In his resignation speech, Mr. Varadkar laid out an aspirational timeline for Fine Gael to appoint a new leader, saying that he wanted a successor to be elected before the partys annual conference on April 6. That person would then become prime minister when parliament resumed on April 9, after an Easter break.

The process to get there, though, could become complicated if more than one lawmaker contests the election.

One reason for the urgency to choose a new leader is that Ireland will hold local and European elections in June.

In addition, Irelands Dil, the popularly elected lower house of parliament, has a maximum term of five years, so a national election must be held before March 22, 2025. That means that whoever replaces Mr. Varadkar will serve as taoiseach for less than a year before an election is called.

What does this mean for Irish politics?

Mr. Varadkar, the young, gay son of an Irish mother and an Indian father, once seemed like an emblem of a new, more energetic and inclusive Ireland. Now, he is the face of an increasingly unpopular establishment.

His resignation follows years of waning support for the long-dominant parties, Fine Gael, which dropped to the third most popular in the countrys last general election in 2020, and Fianna Fil. It crystallizes the perception that Irish politics is in a moment of flux and uncertainty.

Meanwhile, Sinn Fin, once the political branch of the I.R.A., rose from its position as a fringe player to win the most votes in the last election. No party came close to a majority, forcing the formation of a coalition.

All of the major parties are fighting political headwinds, as Ireland faces a number of domestic challenges. A severe housing shortage  caused partly by the failure of successive governments to invest in affordable housing  and a cost-of-living crisis have created widespread frustration with the political establishment.

With the number of asylum seekers arriving in the country rising sharply, the government has had to contend with an anti-immigration backlash driven in part by far-right rhetoric online. That has increasingly spilled over into violence, with arsonists targeting planned housing for asylum seekers and a violent riot in Dublin late last year that drew international attention.

Concerns about immigration seem to be benefiting independent candidates. Even Sinn Fin, still the most popular party in the polls, has seen its support fall. And with a general election on the horizon, the countrys leading politicians must now grapple with how to address a deeply divisive issue without inflaming it further.

title: Incident reported at Russian embassy in Moldova on polling day
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Moldovan law enforcers have detained an individual who threw two containers of flammable substances over the fence of the Russian embassy in Chisinau as voting in the Russian presidential election was underway, the public broadcasting Moldova One TV channel reported on 17 March.
body:
It quoted the police as saying that the incident took place at around 09:30 GMT on 17 March.

"The suspect was immediately detained and identified and is currently at the police inspectorate. During questioning, he cited his dissatisfaction with the actions of the Russian authorities as the motive behind his actions," the police said.

It added that the detained individual, a 54-year-old Moldovan citizen, claims to also hold Russian citizenship. This is yet to be verified by the authorities.

Source: Moldova One TV, Chisinau, in Romanian 1108 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Two killed, three wounded by Russian fire in Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two civilians were killed and three were wounded by Russian strikes on Ukrainian regions in the east, north and south of the country on 3 and 4 March, local officials reported.
body:
One man was killed in Kherson Region on 3 March, governor Oleksandr Prokudin said on Telegram.

Russian forces shelled 14 population centres and the city of Kherson, damaging nine multistory buildings and 16 cottages. Administrative buildings, infrastructure facilities, a school and a bakery were damaged, Prokudin also said.

Another civilian was killed as a result of a Russian cluster munition strike on the village of Rizdvyanka, Zaporizhzhya Region, governor Ivan Fedorov reported on 4 March.

Two people sustained wounds in Donetsk Region on 3 March, governor Vadym Filashkin said.

Filashkin also reported extensive damage to civil facilities due to intensive fighting in the region.

One man was wounded in Kupyansk District, Kharkiv Region, on 3 March, governor Oleh Synyehubov said.

Some 15 population centres came under Russian fire in Kharkiv Region over the past day. Ukrainian forces repelled 11 Russian attacks near the villages of Synkivka and Tabayivka, Synyehubov reported on the morning of 4 March.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1730 gmt 4 Mar 24

title: Russian shelling causes power cuts in Ukraine's Kharkiv Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian shelling of Kharkiv Region resulted in several overhead power lines and substations being switched off, leaving thousands of residents without electricity, the Zn.ua news website reported on 19 March. However, trains are still running.

title: Ukraine says 27 Russian drones shot down overnight
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian air defences intercepted all 27 Shahed-131/136 kamikaze drones that Russia launched on the night of 14-15 March, the Air Force Command reported on Telegram.
body:
The drones were downed over Kyiv, Kirovohrad, Kharkiv, Kherson, Khmelnytskyy, Mykolayiv and Vinnytsya regions, it said.

According to the report, Russia also fired seven S-300/S-400 missiles at Kharkiv and Donetsk regions and one Kh-59 missile at Poltava Region, none of which appear to have been shot down.

The Kyiv city military administration reported that about 15 Shahed drones were intercepted around the capital. It said that according to preliminary information, there have been no casualties or damage in the city.

A drone attack on Vinnytsya Region in central Ukraine killed two people and wounded three others, said the regional military administration.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 15 Mar 24

title: Ukraine's Odesa governor says building fortifications in region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Defensive fortifications are being built in Ukraine's Odesa Region, governor Oleh Kiper has reported.
body:
"We are actively building fortifications and installing defensive barriers, including dragon's teeth, antitank ditches and non-explosive obstacles. Some 150 workers and 80 pieces of hardware are involved," Kiper said.

Earlier, the governors of Rivne and Volyn regions in northwestern Ukraine said they were building fortifications on the border with Belarus.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 1548 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of Moldova One TV Mesager news 7 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on public broadcaster Moldova One TV on 7 March at 19:00 GMT

Presenter Elena Bancila.
body:
1. 0010 Headlines over video.

2. 0101 Moldovan law enforcers raid safe houses of the pri-Russian parties sponsored by Sor and seize 5.5m lei ($310,000) that were to be used to destabilise Moldova and Romania. The head of the General Police Inspectorate, Viorel Cernauteanu, says three former police officers were arrested after the raids. A video of people speaking about a "pay" for participation in Sor's protests is shown. Russia is seen behind the destabilisation plans. The head of the Information and Security Service (SIS), Alexandru Musteata, has spoke about them at a recent news conference. Correspondent's report.

3. 0425 Gagauzia governor Eugenia Gutul meets Russian President Vladimir Putin at the World Youth Festival in Sochi. Government spokesman Daniel Voda says that the "regular bows to the Kremlin by representatives of the criminal Sor group does not serve interests of Moldovan citizens". He calls on people to get information from official and reliable sources not to be manipulated disinformation and propaganda disseminated by Russia and "its servants". Gutul is the only Moldovan politician to meet Putin since the start of the Russian war against Ukraine. Gagauzia-based journalist Mihail Sircheli says the meeting is "clear evidence" of Gagauzia governor's "work against Moldova". Correspondent's report.

4. 0726 Former SIS head Vladimir Dediu suggests that Gutul's meeting with Putin was organised by fugitive pro-Russian oligarch Ilan Sor. Expert Andrei Curararu says that the photo of Gutul shaking hands with Putin will be used to improve Gutul's image. undit Nicolae Negru says Putin looks pathetic and isolated if he meets people Gutul's level to discuss geopolitics. Video report.

5. 0929 The head of the General Police Inspectorate, Viorel Cernauteanu, says that Moldovan and Romanian law enforcers prevented plans to disrupt the congress of the European People's Party held in Bucharest on 6-7 March. Around 200 people were to travel there by buses to stage provocations for which Sor's people promised to pay to them "several thousand lei a day". The presenter recalls that the leader of the radical Romanian AUR party, George Simion, is banned from Moldova "for security reasons". Presenter-read report.
