“I am aware of certain legal restrictions that do exist in Poland. This is not about a political decision at all levels or something. There are very clear legal restrictions. To my mind, this is a problem that needs to be discussed at all levels,” the prime minister said.

This issue must be raised at bilateral formats with Polish leaders, according to Simonyte.

“A solution needs to be found that allows fitting into Polish legislation. On the other hand, since Poland is a NATO country, and NATO is a collective defence alliance, and an attack on one country means an attack on all, this contradiction between, let us say, international obligations and domestic legislation needs to be addressed,” the prime minister stated.

Lithuania must be ready to defend itself for at least two weeks in the event of a Russian attack, Ben Hodges, the former commanding general of US Army Europe, told the Vilnius Security Forum last week.

NATO’s Article 5 guarantees are not automatic as it needs political will to be activated, he said. This means that Lithuania must be prepared to stand its ground until allied reinforcements arrive.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 1646 GMT 1 Mar 24

title: Ukraine denies Russia captured Nevelske village
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian forces control the village of Nevelske near Avdiivka in Donetsk Region, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported.
body:
It cited a spokesperson for Ukraine's Tavria group of forces, Dmytro Lykhoviy, as saying: "Nevelske is controlled by the Defence Forces of Ukraine."

On 12 March, Russia's Defence Ministry said its forces had seized Nevelske.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1340 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: Lithuanian, Polish foreign ministers meet in Warsaw
snippet:
Text of report by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 20 March in English

Vilnius, March 20 (ELTA) - On Wednesday in Warsaw, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Lithuania Gabrielius Landsbergis met with Minister of Foreign Affairs of Poland Radoslaw Sikorski.
body:
"Historical strategic partnership between Lithuania and Poland is only growing stronger and provides a new impetus for all of Europe," Landsbergis said at the meeting, emphasising the bilateral agreement to continue the dialogue.

Lithuanian and Polish foreign ministers agreed that it is crucial to fundamentally change the West's long-lasting views as regards Russia's threat and to prioritise its full containment.

Landsbergis stressed that one of the measures to weaken Russia and achieve Ukraine's victory is to tighten sanctions on Russia and Belarus further. Countries bordering Russia must follow common sanction implementation mechanism and join efforts to prevent sanction circumvention, said the minister.

The interlocutors also discussed the need rally the efforts of like-minded countries in preparation for the NATO summit in Washington, DC, to strive for faster integration of Ukraine in the EU and NATO, as well as not to delay the implementation of critical infrastructure projects, which both strengthen Lithuanian and Polish economies and their security environment.

The head of Lithuania's diplomacy invited his Polish counterpart to attend the annual meeting of heads of Lithuanian diplomatic missions.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 1231 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Lithuanian troops train at Nato drill in Germany
snippet:
Text of report by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 19 March in English

Vilnius, 19 March: Multinational Field Training Exercise Allied Spirit 24 running on 26 February-22 March at the Joint Multinational Readiness Center near Hohenfels, Germany, and surrounding areas trains over 6,000 NATO Allies and Partners from 10 countries - Denmark, Italy, Spain, US, UK, Netherlands, Croatia, Hungary, Germany and Lithuania, the military said in a press release.

title: Estonian minehunter participating in drills in Norway
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Baltic News Service on 7 March

Tallinn, 7 March: The minehunter Ugandi of the Estonian Navy is taking part in a training exercise in Norwegian waters as part of the NATO mine countermeasures group from Tuesday to March 13.
body:
In the exercise, codenamed Nordic Response, Ugandi and other mine countermeasures vessels will help clear the sea area of mines and other munitions and lead landing units through the cleared area, military spokespeople in Tallinn said.

"As part of the NATO Mine Countermeasures Group, our goal is to conduct various mine countermeasures operations and ensure the safety of landing units, thereby supporting the movement of allied forces from sea to land," said Lt. Cmdr. Janno Lauri, commander of Ugandi.

A total of 20,000 military personnel from 13 countries are taking part in the exercise that is held simultaneously in the northern parts of Norway, Sweden, and Finland. The activities of the exercise are conducted on land, at sea, and in the air. Maritime operations play a crucial role in the exercise, with over 50 vessels involved, including frigates, corvettes, submarines and various landing craft, in addition to the vessels of the mine countermeasures group.

The exercise involves over 100 aircraft, including fighter jets, transport and reconnaissance planes, CH43 Super Stallion transport helicopters, Merlin and Cobra helicopters, and an Osprey multi-purpose aircraft. Ground forces units comprise over 10,000 military personnel along with tanks, armored vehicles and artillery systems.

Nordic Response is part of the Steadfast Defender series of exercises, in which more than 90,000 service personnel will take part. The exercise is held to practice the deployment of NATO troops to potential conflict areas and the defense of these areas. Of the exercises taking place in Estonia, Kevadtorm (Spring Storm) and Swift Response, both of which will be held in May, are part of the Steadfast Defender framework.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 1422 gmt 7 Mar 24

title: Lithuanian president says to work with Poland to beef up Nato flank
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Baltic News Service on 5 March

Vilnius, 5 March: Lithuania and Poland will work together to beef up NATO's eastern flank, President Gitanas Nauseda said as he observed Poland's Dragon 2024 national military exercise together with his Polish counterpart Andrzej Duda on Tuesday.
body:
"Lithuania and Poland share the same understanding of security threats," Nauseda's office quoted him as saying in Poland. "We will continue to work together to strengthen the security of our countries and the entire NATO Eastern flank."

Nauseda emphasised that Russia will remain the main and long-term military threat to the Alliance as a whole, thus Lithuania sees close security cooperation with Poland as a strategic priority, his office said.

According to the president, Poland is directly involved in bolstering the security of the Baltic region, actively participates in NATO's Baltic air policing mission and takes part in joint military exercises.

"I am confident that we will continue to strengthen our partnership through security initiatives, as well as through the joint development of the defence industry," he said.

Nauseda and Duda observed allied forces' joint operation of crossing the Vistula River.

Dragon 2024 is part of NATO's Steadfast Defender 24, the largest NATO exercise in Europe since the Cold War.

The exercise in Poland "will certify Allied forces for deterrence and defence tasks, prepare for a potential aggression against NATO Allies and executive combat actions across land, air and maritime domains", the Lithuanian Armed Forces have said in a press release.

"The centerpiece operation of Dragon 24 is deployment of the Very High Readiness Joint Task Force in assistance to an Ally in the event of aggression which will also highlight the nuances and potential challenges of military mobility across national borders," the military said.

After the exercise, Germany's "enhanced Vigilance Brigade battalion will relocate for continued training in Lithuania as of March 7".

The exercise is taking place amid discussions in Lithuania about whether Poland's laws would allow it to defend its neighbour in the event of an attack.

Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte said last week that Poland's legal restrictions "do not provide for an obligation" to send troops abroad, even in the event of war.

In response, Nauseda said that joint Polish-Lithuanian exercises were aimed at the two neighbouring countries acting together.

Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk said during his visit to Vilnius on Monday that that the solidarity between the two countries was unquestionable.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 1244 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Estonia experts: Sweden in Nato to strengthen Baltic security
snippet:
The following is the text of an article by journalist Maria-Ann Rohemae, entitled "Experts: Sweden’s accession to Nato will facilitate the planning of Baltic Sea security" and published by the ERR News website operated by the Estonian Public Broadcasting, on 3 March:

After Turkey’s and Hungary’s long delays, Sweden will now become a Nato member. According to experts, this will facilitate the planning of Baltic Sea security, but may also leave the Baltic states on the border of two commands.
body:
Sweden’s accession to Nato is like the last piece of the puzzle that will turn the Baltic Sea region into one whole picture.

"It means a faster exchange of information. It also means that it will be easier to plan with them. If we look at the geographical map, it is clear that there will be no gaps in the Baltic states, that we know that Sweden is with us from the start," said colonel Eero Rebo, chief of the Defence League’s [voluntary arm of Estonian Defence Forces] General Staff.

"In this context the Gotland island is very important, which in principle is a big lock of the Baltic Sea. Somewhat similar to what Iceland is for the Atlantic, hence strategically very important," noted Margus Kolga, former Estonian ambassador to Sweden.

Sweden has a strong navy with long-lasting traditions, which can skilfully operate on the Baltic Sea. Its submarines are also important.

"Militarily, submarines are a hidden resource or hidden capability. Those who have them can conduct operations with other, significantly more comprehensive methods than others," said Kolga.

Sweden’s navy has been specifically developed for operation in the Baltic Sea region. The submarines are therefore smaller, they have never been designed for operation in the North Atlantic, for example," said security expert Martin Hurt.

There has been much talk about the strength of Sweden’s navy, but they have also other capabilities.

"Certainly one key capability is air superiority. To my knowledge, Sweden has 120 Gripen fighter aircraft, which is a very, very potent military force," Kolga said.

"Sweden’s airports will increase options. Also, all kind of dispersion of aircraft is good and this allows to add depth to our defence activities," Rebo said.

Sweden also contributes to Nato with advance warning systems. They also have significant intelligence capability and defence industry.

"Sweden is allegedly one of the few European states that produces military platforms in all military dimensions and for all weapon types. There are supposedly only four such states in Europe. Besides Sweden, also the United Kingdom, France and Germany. These are also historically very deep and long-term and technologically advanced solutions," Kolga said.

But Sweden’s land force has decreased in the past decade. According to Hurt, after the Cold War it focused on expedition forces and field operations.

"When Sweden’s defence forces began to be strengthened after Crimea’s occupation in 2014 and the start of Russia’s aggression against Ukraine, then clearly too little money was allocated for that, hence this defence capability is certainly in a developmental stage," he said.

"If we look at Sweden’s 12-billion annual budget then this allows them develop very fast in the future. Especially because they have in industrial base," Rebo noted.

Even though Nato’s Baltic Sea puzzle is now ready, there is still the outstanding question of how well various pieces fit together. The military command and planning of the alliance has been divided between different joint force commands. Denmark and Finland are under Brunssum in the Netherlands, while Norway is under US-based Norfolk. Now Sweden is also looking to the USA. This has led to a fear that the Baltic states will remain on the border of two commands and planning.

"Sweden is partly a Baltic Sea state but partly also an Arctic state and it is looking towards the north, and historically has always done so. Sweden has somewhat different interests than Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The decisions about where those borders will be drawn between different Nato joint force commands, have not been made yet," said Hurt.

This border is an imaginary border, which can be coordinated and about which either additional plans can be developed, or partial plans with which Sweden can also support the Baltic states," Rebo said.

According to Rebo, it is obvious that with Sweden’s membership, Nato’s defence activities will become more effective and that this will also reduce the Russian threat.

"If we speak about Kaliningrad, then from the Russian perspective their chances of success on the sea and in skies will decrease, which means that the defence of the Suwalki gap will be an increasingly important issue for our southern neighbours," Rebo said.

"Supplying Kaliningrad is complicated already in peacetime, but in a time of war it will become even clearer that Sweden would not passively observe when Russia is trying to supply Kaliningrad," Hurt said.

According to Hurt, no military-technical revolution will take place in Sweden upon accession to Nato.

"Rather this is about changing the mindsets of people, which is important and will certainly take years. Until now, Sweden has gotten used to being outside alliances, which means that for a long time it has assumed that it will remain outside military conflicts," Hurt said.

(See the original here.)

Source: ERR News website, Tallinn, in Estonian 1922 GMT 3 Mar 24

title: Baltic foreign ministers, Blinken discuss war in Ukraine, regional security
snippet:
Text of report by privately-owned Baltic News Service on 26 March in English

Washington DC, 26 March: Baltic foreign ministers met US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken in Washington on Monday to discuss helping Ukraine win its war with Russia, increasing the cost of war for Russia, Baltic security and the NATO Summit in Washington in July.
body:
Blinken was met by Latvian Foreign Minister Krisjanis Karins (New Unity), Estonian Foreign Minister Margus Tsahkna and Lithuanian Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis.

As Karins writes on the X platform, they had a fruitful meeting with Blinken and agreed on the need to accelerate support to Ukraine.

They also discussed preparations for NATO's Washington Summit, security in the Baltics, Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine, the war in Gaza and cooperation with global partners.

Meanwhile, Tsakhna expressed the hope that the NATO Summit in Washington in July would lead to steps towards Ukraine becoming a NATO member.

"There is no more room for grey areas in Europe, so we hope that Ukraine will be admitted to the Alliance as soon as conditions allow," Tsakhna said.

Tsakhna stressed that Russia remains the most significant and long-term threat to the Alliance's security, as evidenced by its hybrid operations in the West, in addition to its aggression against Ukraine.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 0438 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 4 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

Videos of emaciated hostages ignite debate on Israel's war priorities
body:
Israeli media discussed this morning the role of the Israeli government and some media outlets in the fate of the remaining Israeli hostages in captivity, following the release of videos by the military wings of Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) and Hamas showing the hostages suffering from severe malnutrition.

The Maariv daily reported that "the families of the hostages, along with an entire nation, are watching their loved ones die before their eyes". "This is a terrible, disproportionate punishment inflicted upon us by Israel's criminally negligent government," it added.

The daily Haaretz criticised the media coverage, saying: "Even in the face of videos proving that Israel's policy is killing the hostages, they continue to deny reality." It added: "Channel 14 skips over it, while Channel 12 babbles on, in both cases normalising the abandonment of the hostages for the most important goal of all: to keep crushing, dismantling, and destroying Gaza."

The videos were released amidst Israeli media's consistent doubt of the extent of hunger in the Gaza Strip, calling it a "false starvation campaign".

Hamas says ready to deliver food aid to Israeli hostages

Hamas has said that it is ready to respond "positively" to any Red Cross request to deliver food and medicine aid to Israeli hostages.

"We stipulate that humanitarian corridors must be opened on a regular and permanent basis for the passage of food and medicine to all our people in all areas of the Gaza Strip, and that all forms of enemy air strikes must be halted at the time of receiving parcels for prisoners," Abu Ubaida, the spokesman of Hamas's military wing, the Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades, said in a Telegram statement yesterday.

This came after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke to the head of the Red Cross in the region, requesting his immediate involvement in providing food and medicine to hostages.

Netanyahu made his request after videos of emaciated Israeli hostages were released by Hamas and the PIJ recently.

UAE airdrops more humanitarian aid to Gaza

The UAE has said it conducted its 61st airdrop of humanitarian aid in Gaza in coordination with Jordan.

This brings the total volume of humanitarian aid delivered by air to more than 3,818 tonnes of food and relief materials, directed toward supporting the most affected and vulnerable communities in Gaza, the UAE's official news agency Wam reported yesterday.

Moreover, the agency said that the UAE also facilitated the entry of 20 trucks loaded with food aid into Gaza yesterday.

The country said it also delivered 11 trucks carrying about 65 tonnes of medical supplies to Gaza in cooperation with the World Health Organisation, according to Wam.

Syrian security forces regain control of Suweida after clashes

A security source has said that Syrian Internal Security Forces (ISF) have regained control on areas in the southern restive province of Suweida (also Sweida) following clashes between government forces and Druze militants, state news agency Sana reported last night.

The ISF said that it regained control of the Tal al-Hadid, Rima Hazem and Walgha security checkpoints after five government personnel were reported killed following an attack by militants linked to the controversial Druze cleric Hikmat al-Hajri (also Hijri).

Sana said that "Hajri's militias continued to violate the ceasefire agreement by launching treacherous attacks on internal security forces on several fronts, in addition to shelling some villages with rockets and mortar shells".

The latest unrest follows the announcement of a ceasefire in southern Syria by interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa last month following weeks of deadly violence.

Syria army, Kurdish force trade accusation over attacks in north

The Syrian defence ministry said that its forces carried out "precision strikes" targeting the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) after they shelled the village of Kayariyeh and its vicinity near Manbij in the northern province of Aleppo, state news agency Sana reported late on 2 August.

Earlier on the same day, Sana cited the ministry as saying that Syrian troops had repelled an attempted infiltration by the SDF into a military post near Kayariyeh, and also reported rocket launches by the SDF targeting residential homes in the village which injured four army personnel and three civilians.

Syrian Kurdish news agency ANHA reported that factions affiliated to the interim Syrian government launched attacks on the frontline with the SDF, chiefly in Deir Hafer.

The report said that "unregulated" groups affiliated to the government had shelled "populated" areas on the evening of 2 August, describing the attack as a "dangerous military escalation" and saying that the SDF had responded with heavy weaponry.

Over 50 migrants reported drowned, missing in boat capsize off Yemen

More that 50 migrants have been reported drowned and others missing following a boat capsize off the coast of Yemen's southern Abyan province due to bad weather, domestic media said yesterday.

Rescue teams recovered the bodies of 54 male and female irregular migrants, most of whom were Ethiopians, a health official in Zinjibar district was quoted by the privately owned Al-Masdar Online website as saying. The official said that rescue operations were still underway to try and recover the remaining bodies and that the boat was carrying around 150 people, the website reported.

In a Facebook post, the Abyan Security Department called on "all relevant local and international parties to urgently intervene and take deterrent measures to halt the illegal flow [of migrants] through Yemeni territorial waters, which poses a growing humanitarian and security threat".

Saudi Arabia, Palestinian groups condemn Ben Gvir's Al-Aqsa visit

Saudi Arabia issued a statement yesterday condemning the visit of Israeli government officials, including far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir to the Al-Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem, describing such actions as "provocative". The site is referred to by Jews as Temple Mount.

The kingdom's foreign ministry warned that the visits of Israeli "occupation" officials to the site would further "fuel conflict" in the region, and called on the international community to intervene.

Pan-Arab media including Qatar's Al Jazeera TV reported that over 1,000 Israeli "settlers stormed" the compound early yesterday and noted that it was the highest number of Jewish visitors to visit to date and that police did not prevent them from performing prayers and "Talmudic rituals" and waving Israeli flags.

Palestinian factions also condemned Ben Gvir's visit to the compound as "provocative" and violating the site's status quo.

Lebanon marks fifth anniversary of Beirut port explosion

Lebanon is marking the fifth anniversary since the Beirut port explosion which killed some 235 people and injured thousands, domestic media reported.

After a two-year hiatus due to procedural appeals, the reopening of the domestic probe early this year "offers hopes for answers", with hearings finally resuming and with political guarantees by Prime Minister Nawaf Salam - former ICJ president, French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour reported late last night.

Salam stressed the government's commitment to follow up on the case "until justice is served", telling families of the dead in a ceremony yesterday that "we will not compromise on justice or the truth".

He participated in the naming of a street close to Beirut port "August 4th Victims Street" following a request from relatives of the dead, in a ceremony attended by other ministers and Beirut Governor Marwan Abboud, the daily reported.

Egyptians start voting in Senate election

Egyptians start voting today in the Senate election, which will continue over two days.

Around 424 candidates are competing for 100 seats under the individual system, including 183 independent candidates and 241 representing political parties, according to the Egyptian privately owned Al-Bawabah News website.

Voting took place on 1-2 August for Egyptians abroad.

The total number of Senate members is 300, including 100 to be appointed by the president.

A run-off vote will be held abroad on 25-26 August and at home on 27-28 August. The results of the first round will be announced on 12 August, while the run-off results will be made public on 4 September.

The Senate serves as a consultative chamber within Egypt's bicameral parliamentary system, while legislative authority rests solely with the House of Representatives.

title: Lithuanian president highlights defence cooperation with Poland
snippet:
Text of report in English by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 5 March

Vilnius, 5 March: President of Lithuania Gitanas Nauseda on Tuesday is paying a visit to Poland, where together with President of Poland Andrzej Duda he observed Polish-led military exercise Dragon 2024.
body:
"Lithuania and Poland share common understanding of security threats. We will continue working together enhancing the security of our countries and NATO's entire eastern flank," Nauseda said in Poland.

The president emphasised that Russia would continue to be the primary and long-term military threat for the Alliance. Therefore, close cooperation with Poland in security and defence is a strategic priority for Lithuania, he said.

The president is sure that both countries will continue strengthening their partnership by implementing initiatives in the area of security and in joint development of the defence industry.

Nauseda pointed out that joint allied actions showcased at the exercise proved NATO's effectiveness and military interoperability capabilities.

The president also noted that fast military aid for Ukraine must remain the main priority as the country needs ammunition, air defence systems and greater production capabilities in all categories of armaments.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 1255 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Nato plans foresee use of Polish troops in Lithuania defence - army chief
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Baltic News Service on 5 March

Korzeniew, Poland, 5 March: NATO plans foresee the use of Polish troops in Lithuania's defence, and, therefore, it's not a matter of bilateral relations, Lithuania's Chief of Defence General Valdemaras Rupsys says as he's visiting Poland where the Dragon 2024 exercise is taking place.
body:
His comment comes amid the recent debate on whether Poland has the legal right to defend Lithuania if it is attacked.

"I don't know of any legal restrictions. The operational use of the Polish army is foreseen in NATO plans, it is a NATO issue. It is not a matter of our bilateral relations, it is a NATO matter," the army chief said. "As far as I know, the task of the Polish army is clearly defined on our territory as well, and I do not see any problem with that."

In his words, Poland, like other NATO countries, is guided by all the articles of the North Atlantic Treaty, including Article 5.

"There is no doubt that we will stand together anywhere, if necessary. (...) And on the issue of sending troops, they will be here," Rupsys said.

The Dragon 2024 exercise is aimed at testing allied ability to carry out deterrence and defence tasks by countering aggression by a potential enemy against NATO countries and conducting combat operations combining land, air and maritime components.

The exercise is one of the components of this year's NATO Steadfast Defender 2024 exercise.

According to the Lithuanian army, the centerpiece operation of Dragon-24 is the deployment of the Very High Readiness Joint Task Force to assist an ally in the event of aggression, which will also highlight the nuances and potential challenges of military mobility across national borders. When the exercise ends, the German enhanced Vigilance Brigade battalion will relocate for continued training in Lithuania as of March 7.

A platoon from the Lithuanian army's Iron Wolf Infantry Brigade's reconnaissance company with JLTV all-terrain vehicles is currently participating in the exercise in Poland. In total, 20,000 troops and 3,500 pieces of military equipment from ten NATO countries are participating in the exercise.

The exercise is taking place in Lithuania amid a debate on whether Poland's own laws would allow it to defend Lithuania in the event of an attack on it.

Lithuanian Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte said last week that Poland's legal restrictions "do not impose an obligation" to send troops abroad, even in the event of war, which would also apply in the event of an attack on neighbouring Lithuania.

Later, the prime minister added she did not mean that "the Poles will not defend us", but rather that she was referring to specific legal constraints, which she was seeking to resolve with Poland at the "political level". The prime minister also said that she could not specify which restrictions she was referring to.

Speaking earlier in the day, Kestutis Budrys, an adviser to Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda, said that a defence plan for the Suwaiki Corridor was drawn up back in 2022, and Polish troops would also defend the territory in Lithuania, so there is no legal restriction on it.

Nauseda said on Monday that join Lithuanian-Polish army exercises were meant to make sure that both countries act together.

For his part, Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk, who visited Lithuania on Monday, said that Lithuanian-Polish solidarity was unquestionable. He also added that the Polish and Lithuanian foreign and defence ministers would soon "decide on all the details so that there are no communication issues and uncertainties", to avoid speculation on the issue.

NATO's Article 5 stipulates that an armed attack on one or more of allied countries will be considered an attack on all of them. According to this article, all NATO members must agree to take action to help the attacked ally. However, any action requires the agreement of all NATO countries.

So far, this article has been activated once, in 2001, after the September 11 terrorist attacks in the US.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 1349 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Latvia minister stresses need for Baltic, Black sea security
snippet:
Text of report by Latvian news agency LETA on 1 March in English

Riga, 1 March: Safe navigation in the Baltic Sea and the Black Sea is critical for global stability, Foreign Minister Krisjanis Karis (New Unity) said during a meeting with his Bulgarian, Greek, Estonian, Lithuanian and Romanian counterparts on Friday [1 March].
body:
Karins today joined a video conference with his colleagues for a discussion on current developments in the Baltic Sea and Black Sea regions, including a greater involvement of NATO bodies in the strengthening of the security of those regions. The video conference was held at the initiative of the Bulgarian Foreign Minister Mariya Gabriel.

Since Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine began on February 24, 2022, safe navigation in the Black Sea has been under a serious threat due to incidents caused by Russia. Certain risks have also been observed in the Baltic Sea. "Given that Russia's threat does not end at the borders of Ukraine and affects the entire Euro-Atlantic space, coordination between NATO countries is of particular importance. I emphasized that successful cooperation between the countries in the Baltic and Black Sea region is a precondition for restricting in Russia successfully," noted Karins.

With Finland and Sweden joining NATO and thereby reducing the influence of the Russian navy in the Baltic Sea, security has increased across the region. Turkey, Bulgaria, and Romania, for their part, signed a Memorandum of Understanding on the establishment of the Task Force to Combat Sea Mines in the Black Sea (MCM Black Sea).

At the initial stages of the invasion, the Russian navy laid sea mines along the Black Sea coast, which pose threat to navigation and curb the efforts of Ukraine to break Russia's sea blockade. The mine countermeasures task force is to supervise the operations of the demining mission in the Black Sea.

Source: LETA website, Riga, in English 1654 GMT 1 Mar 24

title: German troops to arrive in Lithuania for training
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Baltic News Service on 7 March

Vilnius, 7 March: Around 700 German troops with more than 200 pieces of military equipment are set to arrive in Lithuania for training on Thursday.
body:
The troops from the 91st Infantry Battalion of the German enhanced Vigilance Activity Brigade (eVA) assigned to Lithuania are coming from Poland where they took part in the first part of the Grand Eagle 24 exercise, trained and assessed the needs and challenges of military mobility across national borders.

The second part of the exercise will take place in Lithuania.

Both exercises are part of NATO's Europe-wide spring exercise Steadfast Defender 24.

The German eVA assigned to Lithuania has been on standby since 2022, and its forward command element is also deployed in the country.

Last year, the German army's 21st Panzer Brigade took over command of the eVA that consists of around 4,000 troops.

Berlin and Vilnius have agreed on the permanent deployment of the German brigade in Lithuania, and this is scheduled to be done by 2027. In total, around 5,000 troops and civilians will move to Lithuania.

Vilnius is looking for suitable infrastructure for the incoming German troops and their families.

German troops are being deployed in Lithuania in response to the increased Russian threat following the Kremlin's attack on Ukraine.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 0823 gmt 7 Mar 24

title: Situation in Ukraine 'not getting better' - Lithuanian minister
snippet:
Text of report by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 25 March in English

Vilnius, 25 March: A missile launched by Russia at western Ukraine entered Polish airspace on Sunday night. Minister of Foreign Affairs of Lithuania Gabrielius Landsbergis, who paid a working visit to the United States, calls to send a clear message to Russia that missiles or drones entering NATO airspace will be shot down.
body:
“This is not the first time that this is happening. There have been a number of violations of airspace in Romania and this is not the first time that Polish airspace was violated. So you could tell that one time is a mistake but if we allow that to happen, it sounds like an invitation. So we have to change our position, we have to change our posture and send a very clear message that if it happens again, the missiles, the drones, they will be taken down,” Landsbergis told Fox News during his visit to the USA.

The head of Lithuania’s diplomacy stressed that Ukraine has lacked US and European support recently.

“The situation in Ukraine is definitely not getting better. What Russians are doing with those rocket barrages over the last couple of days is they’re testing whether Ukraine does still have enough ammunition to take them down,” he said.

The minister added that Russia is amassing many new troops and there are talks about an additional mobilisation of half a million new soldiers.

“So the situation is getting worse and we have to have an answer to that. If Ukraine falls, Putin will not stop, that’s for sure,” Landsbergis stated.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 0818 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Lithuanian land troops taking part in Nato drills in Poland
snippet:
Text of report in English by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 14 March

Vilnius, 14 March: Command Headquarters personnel of the Lithuanian Land Force alongside Allies from 23 NATO members are training at a command-post exercise Loyal Leda 2024 (LOLE 24), reports the Armed Forces.
body:
The exercise conducted by the NATO Joint Force Training Centre in Poland is designed to train and certify headquarters of units in subordination of the Headquarters Multinational Corps Northeast (HQ MNC NE) to plan and execute wide-scale defensive operations while organizing interoperability and coordinating actions with friendly forces.

"Exercise LOLE 24 is a vital event in our combat training cycle that certifies our readiness to deliver on our designated tasks. I can say ahead of the exercise that we are ready but we want to be even more ready. We want to demonstrate with this exercise to everyone that we are united with NATO Allies in defending our families and people against any threat," said HQ MNC NE Commander Lt Col Jurgen-Joachim von Sandrart on the day of the exercise opening.

Exercise LOLE 24 takes place in three stages. During the first phase, over 800 exercise participants were improving military decision-making, as well as command and control and interoperability procedures at unit integration training.

Over the second stage, unit command posts carried out defensive and indirect impact operation planning, interact with the civilian environment and adjacent units, coordinate actions with the superior headquarters, and create tactical operational plans using a tactical command and control information system.

In the third phase a simulation system is used to put to test operational concepts created by the unit command posts. The simulation system follows the training concept developed by the Control Party to allow creation of a tactical situation for generating events and incidents and adapting to the dynamic and ever-changing situation while executing command and control procedures, taking timely tactical decisions in coordination of actions between units, ensuring uninterrupted execution of operation in coordination with the superior staff and functionality of command posts.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 0549 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Experts list measures to strengthen Estonia's defence capabilities
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Baltic News Service on 12 March

TALLINN, Mar 12, BNS - As measures to strengthen Estonia's defence capabilities, experts speaking at the CGI media morning on defence and aerospace industry in Tallinn on Tuesday listed the digitalisation of the defence industry, increasing defence spending from 3 percent to 5 percent of GDP, and the need for better collaboration between the state and the private sector.
body:
Tarmo Ranisoo, retired colonel and expert at CGI Eesti, said that as a country on NATO's eastern border, we need to prepare consistently. He stressed that it is the battlefield that determines what is needed in the market and what works.

"Digitalisation is essential to speed up combat operations and improve situational awareness. Artillery without a round inside is a halfway solution. Just like hardware that doesn't come with smart enough software," he said.

Taavi Veskimagi, the chairman of the supervisory board of the Estonian Defence and Aerospace Industry Association, said in a panel discussion that Estonia's defence spending of 3 percent of GDP is not enough and will probably grow to at least 5 percent in the near term.

"I'm more than sure that we're going to see a significantly higher contribution than 3 percent, at least 5 percent, over the next five years to achieve sufficient deterrence," Veskimagi said. It will be then necessary that everything we can produce locally in order to strengthen our defence capability is produced here as well, by our own industries, he added.

Veskimagi said defence spending rising to 5 percent of GDP would be an opportunity for Estonian defence industry companies.

"What will matter is how Estonian companies will furnish this 5 percent, because if all that money - 5 percent of our GDP - goes abroad, it will already be a problem in terms of the foreign trade balance." To mitigate this, Veskimagi says, everything that is possible must be produced and done locally in Estonia. "This is necessary both to increase defence capabilities and for economic development, to maintain and create jobs."

Brig. Gen. Vahur Karus, chief of the Estonian Military Academy, said the introduction of new technologies in national defence always comes with a price tag.

"This raises the question of whether we also have the human resources who know how to put new technologies to work and whether we are able to train people, adapt hardware, maintain it, keep it going," Karus said.

"Last year, we began to understand that the defence forces need a large number of engineers. Now, we train tactical operators in the defence forces who can handle basic operation of equipment because all training exercises include components of digital warfare. It makes no sense to establish an engineering course at the Estonian Military Academy in a situation where engineering is taught in five universities in Estonia. Therefore, our strategy is to incorporate engineers into the needs of the defence forces for a fixed term so that they return to civilian jobs with the experience gained and continue to contribute to the next technological developments there. This is human resource development that goes in long cycles," Karus said.

CGI is a global software company with operations in 40 countries, whose national branches have a high degree of overlap with NATO member states. In Estonia, CGI has been operating since the early years since the country regained its independence. With 200 employees, CGI Eesti is the largest aerospace company in Estonia, whose digital solutions are used in the energy sector, the public sector and agriculture.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 1721 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Lithuania Nato entry 20 years ago 'tremendous achievement' - PM
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Vilnius, 29 March: Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte has sent a message of greetings to the people of Lithuania on the occasion of the 20th anniversary of the country’s Nato membership. It was on this very day, 29 March, that Lithuania proudly assumed its place as a full-fledged member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, stated the prime minister’s press service.
body:
“Lithuania’s 20th anniversary of Nato membership is a tremendous achievement and a privilege for our country to build prosperity on the foundation of freedom, peace, and security. It is only under a secure sky that democracy can thrive, civil society grow and prosper, and a nation share its individuality with the world. Today, we have all this, and much of our success is a credit to our membership in the strongest defence alliance, which has been pursued with purpose and perseverance by countless people, leaders and diplomats dedicated to the country,” says Prime Minister Šimonytė.

“This privilege, unfortunately absent in the besieged Ukraine defending itself, the free world, and its values, still doesn’t turn security into a given, reminding us that it is we ourselves that bare the duty for a secure tomorrow. This responsibility falls on each of us as citizens and together as a society. Our Ukrainian brothers and sisters remind us every day of the strength that lies in unity and the will to defend ourselves. Let us build and nourish this strength, which, alongside Nato’s principle of unity – ‘one for all, and all for one’ – is the strongest, most unshakeable foundation of our security,” the head of government said in the message of congratulations.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 1036 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Germany stands shoulder to shoulder with Baltics - Scholz
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Baltic News Service on 27 March

Riga, 27 March: Germany stands shoulder to shoulder with the Baltic states and is ready to defend every inch of NATO territory, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said today after a meeting with Latvian Prime Minister Evika Silina.
body:
Scholz acknowledged that these are difficult times in international politics and that some of the things we relied on are no longer what they should be, in particular with regard to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

The German chancellor noted that Latvia and Germany have been close partners for the past 20 years in the EU and NATO, with Germany contributing to NATO's eastern flank with its troops in Lithuania and airspace control in Estonia and now Latvia.

"I am aware that this cooperation involves sending a message of solidarity and our NATO principles -- that we stand up for each other and are ready to defend every inch of NATO territory together. This is also my message to the Baltic states -- we stand together shoulder to shoulder," Scholz said.

Turning attention to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Scholz said that the West "must do more and enough to support Ukraine."

The chancellor indicated that Germany is providing large amounts of support -- almost 28 billion euros in total in arms supplies and other forms of aid.

Scholz also welcomed recent decisions to support Ukraine more broadly, such as the Czech ammunition supply initiative.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 1716 gmt 27 Mar 24

title: Outside Nato Estonia might have been under threat - FM
snippet:
Text of report by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 29 March in English

Tallinn, 29 Mach: On 29 March, Estonia celebrates the 20th anniversary of joining the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation or Nato. To mark the day, Foreign Minister Margus Tsahkna said that the importance of Nato in ensuring Estonia’s security, prosperity and stability in the long term could not be overestimated, stated the MFA.

title: Nato jets scrambled five times from Lithuania last week
snippet:
Text of report by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 26 March in English

Vilnius, 26 March: On 18-24 March, the NATO Air Policing Mission fighter aircraft were scrambled five times to intercept aircraft of the Russian Federation violating flight rules in international airspace over the Baltic Sea, reports the Ministry of National Defence.

title: U.S. Vows to Continue Support for Ukraine, Despite Funding Doubts
snippet:
The American defense secretary told a meeting of Kyivs backers that the fight against Russia remains one of the great causes of our time.

The United States and European nations vowed on Tuesday to maintain military support for Ukraine, even though future American aid remains snarled in Congress and modest donations of new weapons reflected an alliance with relatively little left to give as the war against Russia enters a critical stretch.
body:
The U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III, in Germany for the start of a meeting of about 50 governments that are supplying Kyivs forces, said that allies would dig deeper to get vital security assistance to Ukraine.

To that end, Germanys defense minister, Boris Pistorius, said Berlin would send Ukraine 10,000 rounds of badly needed artillery shells, 100 armored infantry vehicles and transport equipment in a new $544 million infusion of support. The Finnish defense chief, Antti Hkknen, announced a $32 million donation to help the Czech Republic buy 800,000 rounds of ammunition, including from beyond NATO-member militaries and manufacturers.

And Mr. Austin highlighted the new $300 million package of attack and air defense missiles, artillery rounds and armor systems that the United States pledged for Ukraine last week.

Yet Ukrainian forces could burn through much of the new aid within months, if not weeks. It is unlikely that the Biden administration will be able to send much more unless Republicans in the House of Representatives unlock a $60 billion emergency spending plan for additional weapons for Ukraine and to bolster armament production in the United States.

We will have to deal with it, and we will deal with it, Mr. Pistorius said on the sidelines of the meeting, held at Ramstein Air Base, an American military hub in Germany, when asked about the blocked funding in Washington.

He said Germany was prepared to continue supporting Ukraine, and Im sure and Im convinced the United States will, like it used to do before, too.

Mr. Austin declared at the meetings start that Ukraines battle remains one of the great causes of our time. Later, he cast the war as crucial to our own security in remarks that seemed directed more toward critics in Congress than to the journalists before him in Germany.

The United States would face grave new perils in a world where aggression and autocracy are on the march, and where tyrants are emboldened, and where dictators think that they can wipe democracy off the map, Mr. Austin said.

Today, Ukraines survival is in danger and Americas security is at risk, he said. They dont have a day to waste, and we dont have a day to spare either.

While the United States remains the single largest donor of military support to Ukraine, Mr. Austin praised recent donations of weapons by Denmark, France, Germany and Sweden. He also noted the Czech campaign to scrounge the world for artillery shells, the first tranche of which could arrive on the battlefield within weeks.

Ukraines soldiers are already running out of many munitions: A shortage of artillery shells helped force a retreat in the eastern city of Avdiivka, and air defense missiles have been rationed around the highest-priority cities and infrastructure to protect against Russian strikes.

On Monday, after meeting Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine ticked off a list of missiles, fighter jets and shells that he said were urgently needed on front lines.

In his own summary of the Monday meeting in Kyiv, Mr. Graham predicted that at least some American assistance to Ukraine would arrive as loans, as former President Donald J. Trump has urged, instead of donated outright.

I know Americans want to help our friends and allies, but I also believe we must consider our economic situation as we help others, Mr. Graham said in a statement. He said he would also demand that the Biden administration send longer-range missiles to Ukraine, enabling its forces to strike Russian-held territory, and speed training for Ukrainian pilots on F-16 warplanes.

The uncertainty over the American commitment to Ukraine has largely left European allies to try to fill the gap, but producers of key weapon systems and artillery ammunition have struggled to ramp up and are unable to keep pace with the demand.

Some European leaders  especially in the Baltics, Nordic countries and nations that border Ukraine  have also raised alarms about the specter of Russias invading NATO territory should it win the current conflict.

Mr. Austin echoed those concerns ahead of the meeting at Ramstein, where he sat next to Ukraines defense minister, Rustem Umerov. It was Mr. Austins first in-person return to the group since two hospitalizations this year, including a dayslong stint in January related to complications from prostate cancer surgery that he did not disclose to the White House, prompting criticism.

Lets not kid ourselves: Putin will not stop at Ukraine, Mr. Austin said. But as President Biden has said, Ukraine can stop Putin if we stand with Ukraine and provide the weapons that it needs to defend itself.

Eric Schmitt and Christopher F. Schuetze contributed reporting.

title: Lithuania in talks on production of artillery shells
snippet:
Text of report in English by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 7 March

Vilnius, 7 March: Lithuania is in talks with ammunition manufacturers concerning production of artillery shells in the country.
body:
"Very concrete talks are ongoing with an investor and a manufacturer. Perhaps this is not linked directly with Giraite [ammunition factory]. This has to do more with the needs of Lithuania and the region," said Anusauskas at a press conference on Thursday.

The minister said that in the near future it should transpire where the production would take place and what volume of shells would be made. According to him, countries, including those on NATO's eastern flank, are expanding production of 155 mm artillery shells and thus talks on the matter are ongoing.

Anusauskas added that Lithuania on Thursday was able to transfer some 155 mm artillery shells to Ukraine because a schedule for their replenishment has been created.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 1725 gmt 7 Mar 24

title: Latvia detects Russian reconnaissance aircraft near its airspace
snippet:
Text of report by Latvian news agency LETA on 26 March in English

Riga, 26 March: A Russian radio-electronic reconnaissance aircraft was detected near Latvian airspace on Monday, the Air Force of the National Armed Forces said in a tweet.
body:
A Russian IL-20 aircraft was identified near Latvian airspace on Monday.

The Latvian Air Force expresses its gratitude to NATO's German Eurofighter fighters, which continuously guard Latvian airspace.

Source: LETA website, Riga, in English 0440 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Lithuania, Poland see eye-to-eye on threats - PM Simonyte
snippet:
Text of report in English by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 5 March

Vilnius, 5 March: Drawing from bitter lessons of the past, Lithuania and Poland understand that indecision, disunity, or concessions to aggressors like Russia only serve to embolden them and escalate conflicts, emphasised Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte during her meeting with Poland's Prime Minister Donald Tusk in Vilnius on Monday.
body:
The two prime ministers agreed that the shared perception of threats, bolstering regional security, and standing by Ukraine are pivotal aspects of cooperation, the Government said in a press release.

The prime ministers discussed support for Ukraine, the strengthening and implementation of sanctions against Russia and Belarus, relevant items on the EU agenda, preparations for the 2024 NATO Summit in Washington, as well as the bilateral relations between Lithuania and Poland.

"Russia's objectives remain unchanged - the obliteration of Ukraine's independence and identity, undermining democracy, and substituting the rules-based world order with power politics, thus posing a grave threat to the entire free world. Hence, supporting Ukraine today, urgently and with all that is necessary for its victory, is the best thing we can do for the Ukrainians who suffer daily terror and for our own security," said Prime Minister Simonyte.

As noted at the meeting, Lithuania and Poland see eye-to-eye on threats, as both countries are aware that Russia will remain a long-term military threat, which is evident not only from its aggressive rhetoric, but also from its aim to rebuild the capabilities lost in Ukraine and the orientation of the country's economy towards military objectives.

In this context, Simonyte pointed out that Poland's leadership in strengthening its defence is an important example for allies to follow. Reinforced defence, together with support for Ukraine, is the best investment in the security of NATO as a whole. The Alliance's defence must not be weakened, and Lithuania, for its part, has been increasing its defence budget in recent years and will continue to build its national defence, the Lithuanian prime minister added.

Lithuania highly values Poland's contributions to regional security, bilateral defence cooperation, and is eager to further enhance these ties, Simonyte noted.

The prime minister stressed the need to sustain and intensify pressure through sanctions on Russia and its ally Belarus, while also striving for more effective implementation of the existing sanctions.

While current efforts are focused on security, Prime Minister Simonyte also recognised the increasingly strong bilateral cooperation spanning from infrastructure to cultural exchanges.

Ingrida Simonyte thanked Donald Tusk for excellent partnership and commitment to joint work towards interconnecting the Baltic electricity grids with continental Europe via Poland by February 2025.

The prime minister also said that the transport links that the two countries are developing - the Rail Baltica and Via Baltica - are not only significant projects in terms of the security of the region, but they also bring real, practical benefits to the people of both countries.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 0650 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Lithuania gears up for 20th Nato entry anniversary
snippet:
Text of report by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 1 March in English

Vilnius, 1 March: Celebration of Lithuania's 20th anniversary of joining NATO are about to begin, the Ministry of National Defence said Friday [1 March]. The country became a full-fledged member of NATO, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, on 29 March 2024.
body:
The Ministry of National Defence invites everyone to take this opportunity to look back on the journey Lithuania has had over the twenty years, what we have received from cooperation with the Allies and were able to give in exchange.

“It’s a privilege to be able to mark the 20th anniversary of membership in the world’s largest and most powerful defensive Alliance which is growing in meaning day by day. NATO membership is our security guarantee. Today Lithuania and over 30 of its Allies act in concert and contribute to the implementation of the Euro-Atlantic security goals and our common security,” Minister of National Defence Arvydas Anusauskas is cited as saying in the ministry’s press release.

On March 2, this Saturday, exhibition “Strong Together” will open at Vytautas the Great War Museum in Kaunas, the first event in the commemorative series this year.

Viewers of the exhibition will learn about Lithuania’s path to NATO, the increasing capability of the Lithuanian Armed Forces, participation in international missions and operations and every possible support Lithuania renders Ukraine.

Minister of National Defence Arvydas Anusauskas and Minister of the Interior Agne Bilotaite at the opening event will engage in a discussion on Security, Defence and the New Geopolitical Reality: How Ready Are We?

The exposition in Kaunas is the first of the many events to be held to mark the NATO membership anniversary. The events and initiatives organized by the Ministry of National Defence and other institutions will be different in types to catch the attention of as wide the public as possible.

The commemoration will culminate on March 29 in a solemn commemoration of the 20th NATO membership anniversary in Daukantas Square and an artistic installation #WeAreNATO in the Cathedral Square in Vilnius.

Besides the mentioned events the public is invited to take part in the Runway Run in the Lithuanian Air Force Base in Šiauliai on the main runway. Also, to visit an interactive “November. Alpha. Tango. Oscar” exhibition in Vilnius, visit a historical-cultural programme “Sūduvis (M52): Mission: Baltic Security” in the Lithuanian Sea Museum. Aside from all these events, Vilnius will be hosting the international Baltic Military Conference “From Vilnius to Washington” to mark the 75th anniversary of NATO and the 20th anniversary of Lithuania’s NATO membership.

Lithuania has taken firm steps towards a new perspective in 2004 bearing the responsibility to agree and implement decisions on its own and with Allies building national and collective security. NATO membership has turned around decades of Lithuania’s fate determined by historical and geological circumstances and has become our security and success story.

“Together Strong” opens on March 2 in Kaunas, Vytautas the Great War Museum, at 2.00 p.m.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 1838 GMT 1 Mar 24

title: Lithuanian PM thanks Germany for security contribution
snippet:
Text of report by Lithuanian news website ELTA on 15 March in English

Vilnius, 15 March: Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte, who paid a visit to Germany, thanked German Chancellor Olaf Scholz for Germany’s longstanding contribution to the security of Lithuania and the region, underlining the importance of the Western democracies’ support for Ukraine to victory, said the prime minister’s press service.
body:
“We are grateful to Germany for the decision to station a brigade in Lithuania, which strengthens the security of the entire NATO alliance, and for its contribution to the security of Lithuania and our region for many years on the run. Such leadership is key against the backdrop of current geopolitical challenges. The decision on the brigade takes our security cooperation to a qualitatively new level and I hope that we will soon be able to talk about new breakthroughs in other areas. I have no doubt that having more Germany in Lithuania and more Lithuania in Germany would contribute to the prosperity of both countries,” said the prime minister.

Simonyte also noted the strong public support for the stationing of the German brigade in Lithuania, assuring that Lithuania, as the host country, will provide all necessary conditions for German troops and their families.

It is reassuring to see the process progressing smoothly, added the head of Government.

Regarding the security situation amidst Russia’s aggression against Ukraine, Prime Minister Simonyte emphasised that Russia’s intimidation should not weaken our resolve nor hinder our support for Ukraine.

The prime minister thanked Germany for its critical support to Ukraine, emphasising its role in defending freedom on a daily basis. She stressed the importance of ongoing and increased assistance from democracies aligned with Ukraine’s defence needs, highlighting its crucial role in Ukraine’s journey to victory - a goal shared by all states committed to upholding the rule of law.

Additionally, the meeting between the German chancellor and the Lithuanian prime minister discussed the necessity of strengthening the defence industry in EU countries in response to long-term security threat from Russia, also other issues of mutual interest.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 0521 GMT 15 Mar 24

title: Kremlin: Macron 'increasing' French involvement in Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov has criticised France's President Emmanuel Macron for what he said was France's increasing involvement in the conflict in Ukraine.
body:
In comments to the "Moscow.Kremlin.Putin" TV show on state Rossiya 1 TV channel, shown in a video posted by Kremlin journalist Pavel Zarubin on 7 March, Peskov said the French leadership had recently made a series of "contradictory statements" about the situation around Ukraine.

On the one hand, Peskov said, Macron had aired the idea of soldiers from Nato states ending up on the front lines in Ukraine, only for the French foreign minister to dismiss the idea.

"But one thing is clear. Mr Macron is convinced of his policy of inflicting a strategic defeat on our country," Peskov said. "He continues to increase the level of direct French involvement in this war. From our point of view, this in no way corresponds to the interests of the French."

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1407 gmt 7 Mar 24

title: Moscow calls US nuclear sites in northern Europe 'legitimate targets'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

US nuclear weapons sites in northern Europe would become legitimate targets in the event of a direct armed clash between Nato and Russia, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova has said, state TASS news agency reported on 6 March.
body:
Speaking on the sidelines of the World Youth Festival, she said: "You don't need to be a military strategist to understand that such sites would present a source of direct military threat, and naturally, it is inevitable they would be on the list of legitimate targets in a military conflict scenario between our country and Nato."

Zakharova was commenting in response to Finnish Prime Minister Alexander Stubb's comment that it was important that his country "should have nuclear deterrent forces".

Zakharova said in the event American nuclear weapons appeared in northern Europe, "the security of those states accepting those these weapons will not be increased, but will clearly suffer, because other countries: neighbouring countries, countries of the continent - and given the development of technology, not only of the continent - will be forced to take all this into account".

Source: TASS news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0957 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dunya TV show on political tensions, economic issues
snippet: The following is a summary of the talk show "Think Tank", hosted by anchor Marrium Zeshan on moderate Dunya News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 10 March 2024. Experts Rasul Bakhsh Rais and Hasan Askari, journalists Salman Ghani and Rasheed Safi are regular analysts on the programme and express their opinions and analysis on important political issues.
body:
Anchor Marrium Zeshan said leaders and workers of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) staged protests against alleged rigging in the recent elections. She noted rallies were staged in various cities and some of the protesters, including Sardar Latif Khosa and Salman Akram Raja (prominent PTI politicians), were arrested. She mentioned Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur (PTI member) addressed a protest rally in Peshawar and demanded that Imran Khan (former PTI chairperson) should be given the right to a fair trial and the PTI's "stolen mandate" should be returned to it. She added Gandapur also demanded that a commission should be formed to look into the allegations of election rigging.

Zeshan questioned whether the arrest of people is justified when peaceful protest is a democratic right. Journalist Salman Ghani said peaceful protests are a right but the opposition has always been facing the same situation in Pakistan. He added protest and resistance politics is effective only for a certain time, and if protests continue for a long time, political workers get tired of them. He was of the view that this protest by the PTI would affect the economy of Pakistan and not the government.

Noting that the PTI could not stage a big show in Punjab, particularly in Lahore, Ghani said the party should review its actions like writing a letter to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) against the release of funds to the government. He reminded the PTI leadership that protests ultimately come to an end through dialogue.

Analyst Hasan Askari was of the view that matters are not being handled "democratically" and said principles of democracy and fundamental rights should be applied across the board. He remarked "coercive apparatus" of the state can control the protests for the time being but it would increase hatred. He criticised the government for not focusing on solving the problems of the people. He claimed there is so much despondency among the people that "80 per cent of the people would leave Pakistan if given an option".

Analyst Rasul Bakhsh Rais said the PTI cannot bring about a revolution or topple the government through these protests, nor can it change the election results. He added the party wants to reinforce an impression continuously in the country and abroad that the elections were rigged. Noting that the goal of politics is to resolve disputes, he remarked no political leader in Pakistan is ready to address the cause of political tensions.

Journalist Rasheed Safi said demand for a commission over the election results is a "realistic demand" and it would be good if it is accepted. However, he added, it is not likely that the demand would be taken into consideration. He was of the view that Imran Khan is also not likely to be given any relief. He urged the federal government to play its constitutional role in dealing with the provinces and also asked Gandapur to not use his constitutional position to promote his political interests. He warned if tension persists, it would provide an opportunity to anti-state elements to promote hatred in the province [KP], which is already in the "grip of terrorism".

Ghani disagreed with Askari's view that 80 per cent of the Pakistanis would leave the country if they are given a chance to do so. He said Pakistan did not face such issues till 2017 when it was the "24th largest economy". He claimed the economy was derailed by removing former prime minister Nawaz Sharif from power. He agreed that a commission should be formed to look into the allegations of election rigging, along with several other issues. He claimed the PTI's politics of protest is aimed at damaging the country's economy.

Zeshan noted prices of essential items have skyrocketed even before the beginning of Ramadan (the month of fasting for Muslims) and asked Ghani what could be the solution to this issue. Ghani replied it is a very sad situation that prices have doubled within two days and would further increase during Ramadan. He said this is a challenge for the new government.

Askari noted the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) government cannot control the prices because its main support base is made up of traders and businessmen. He said instead of solving the issue of inflation, the government starts distributing free items. He mentioned political activists get arrested but no shopkeeper is arrested for profiteering because the party gets votes from them.

Rais was of the view that the government should bring reforms to manage the supply of food items from farms to common consumers so that it can control hoarding and price hikes.

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1500 GMT 10 Mar 24

title: Highlights from Pakistan's Sindhi-language TV, press 18 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items published in Pakistan's Sindhi-language TV and press media outlets on 18 March 2024.

Awami Awaz
body:
President Zardari resolves to fight terrorism

President Asif Ali Zardari paid rich tributes to the soldiers of the Pakistan Army, who were martyred in the Mir Ali area of North Waziristan in a terror attack two days ago [16 March]. President Zardari attended the funeral of martyred officers at Chaklala Garrison and expressed his determination to give "a befitting response to terrorists". He said, "Our brave brothers and sons are protecting the borders and their blood will not go in vain. The people and the army are together." [Terrorists attacked a check post in Mir Ali, killing seven soldiers, including a lieutenant colonel and a captain of the Pakistan Army.] [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

Editorial expresses concern over IMF conditions

"The 18th amendment of the constitution has been under discussion for a while, which is leading to uncertainty in the country. The amendment, which gives the provinces their due rights, has also left the federal government concerned. The federal government thinks that its share in the finances has been reduced due to this amendment and the provinces get a majority. The amendment was passed by the parliament and now is a part of the constitution. Any effort to interfere with this may cause big chaos in the country... We spend a lot of public money on ministries in the federal government. They should be completely devolved to the provinces so that the money can be saved... The federal government has burdened the public because inflation is skyrocketing. The burden of the strict conditions of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is being borne by the people of this country. It has been reported that the IMF wants changes in the National Finance Commission [NFC, mechanism to distribute national funds to the provinces and the federal government]. If the federal government makes changes to NFC, it will amount to abrogating the constitution. We think that instead of entrusting the country's economy to an international financial institution, the government should activate the local industry and agriculture." [Page: 4, Approximate Words: 700]

[Daily Awami Awaz is a progressive, secular and liberal, left-leaning Sindhi-language newspaper published from Karachi, Sindh. The daily possesses a good reputation among relatively educated and aware people. It is regarded as the "Dawn" of Sindhi-language newspapers.]

Ibrat

Minister says politicians seem to have 'contact with terrorists'

Defence minister Khawaja Asif said a majority of the terror incidents are occurring in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) province and "most of these terrorists are coming from Afghanistan". Addressing a press conference in Sialkot, Punjab on 17 March, Asif said those who issue statements against the Pakistan Army [referring to PTI politicians] "must have some contact with these terrorists". He said the Pakistan Army is "offering great sacrifices" and must be respected. "Some people are making fun of the martyrs who sacrificed their lives fighting terrorism," he added." [Page: 1, 150]

Air force chief granted extension in service

Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif sent a summary to President Asif Ali Zardari, proposing a one-year extension in the tenure of Air Chief Marshal, Zaheer Ahmed Babar Sindhu. It was approved by the president. Air Chief Marshal Sindhu had taken charge on March 16 2021 and was to retire on 17 March 2024. Sindhu is the first air chief whose tenure has been extended. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 120]

[Daily Ibrat is a moderate Sindhi-language newspaper owned by the politically influential Qazi family of Sindh, traditionally affiliated with Pakistan Peoples Party. The daily is published from Hyderabad, Sindh. Readers over 40 years of age prefer reading Daily Ibrat.]

Kawish

Last round of negotiations with IMF on 18 Mar

18 March is the last day of negotiations with the IMF for receiving the last tranche of the loan programme. According to reports, Pakistan has fulfilled all the conditions of the IMF for the final installment. It is expected that taxes will be imposed on the real estate; taxes may also be increased. The federal government has suggested to impose extra tax on the buying and selling of property by a non-filer. It is also expected that there will be an increase in property tax. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 200]

Benazir Bhutto's daughter submits nomination papers for bypoll

Aseefa Bhutto Zardari, the youngest daughter of former prime minister, late Benazir Bhutto, filed her nomination for a bypoll on the vacant seat from Nawabshah, Sindh. This seat was vacated by her father, Asif Ali Zardari. The bye-election for this constituency is scheduled for 21 April. Zardari had defeated Sher Mohammad Rind in elections, held on 8 February. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 90]

[Daily Kawish is the most widely read Sindhi-language newspaper published from Hyderabad, Sindh. The paper is popular among young people and has a liberal and progressive editorial policy. It is also the largest circulated daily.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Sindhi 18 Mar 24

title: Russia says 'mass precision missile attack' carried out on Ukraine
snippet:
Text of 'Defence Ministry summary of the progress of the special military operation' published by the Defence Ministry Telegram channel on 22 March

Today [22 March], the Russian Armed Forces launched a massive strike with precision-guided long-range air, sea, ground-based weapons and unmanned air vehicles against energy facilities, the defence industry, railway junctions, arsenals, Ukrainian Forces and foreign mercenaries positions.
body:
As a result of the strike, the functioning of industrial enterprises producing and repairing weapons, military equipment and ammunition has been disrupted. In addition, foreign military equipment and weapons delivered to Ukraine from Nato countries were destroyed, the transfer of enemy reserves to the front line was disrupted, and units of the Ukrainian Armed Forces and mercenaries were damaged in areas where combat capability was being restored. All the aims of the mass strike have been achieved.

From 16-22 March, in response to shelling of our territory, attempts to break through and capture Russian border settlements, the Armed Forces have carried out 49 retaliatory strikes with precision-guided long-range air-launched weapons, including Kinzhal hypersonic missiles, missile systems and unmanned air vehicles.

As a result of these strikes, Ukrainian Armed Forces command posts, airfield infrastructure facilities, workshops for repairing weapons and military equipment, storage depots for UAVs and unmanned boats, logistics bases, as well as temporary deployment points for special operations forces and foreign mercenaries have been destroyed.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1125 gmt 22 Mar 24

title: Zelensky briefs Nato's Bauer on Ukraine's priority defence needs
snippet:
Text of report by Ukrainian president's official website on 21 March in English

President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with Admiral Robert Bauer, Chair of the NATO Military Committee.
body:
"Thank you for your first visit to Ukraine since the beginning of the full-scale war. This is a strong signal of support for our society. The support of NATO and its member states is primarily important for the morale of our troops and civilian Ukrainians. We appreciate that we can count on you," the Head of State said.

The President briefed the Chair of the Military Committee on Ukraine's priority defence needs and emphasised the urgent need for additional air defence systems to reliably protect Ukrainians from constant missile and drone attacks.

Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Robert Bauer discussed opportunities to strengthen the Alliance's coordination role in supporting Ukraine, in particular in enhancing existing defence capabilities, as well as in developing the future military potential of our country in line with NATO standards and interoperability requirements.

The Head of State also outlined the expectations of the Ukrainian side from this year's NATO Summit in Washington.

"We count on fair assessments of our country's achievements and decisions of the Washington Summit that will bring Ukraine closer to NATO membership," the President noted.

Source: Ukrainian president's website, Kyiv, in English 1701 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Taiwans Top Diplomat Says U.S. Aid to Ukraine Is Critical for Deterring China
snippet:
Foreign Minister Joseph Wu said in an interview that a Russian victory could embolden China to move against Taiwan and would fuel anti-American propaganda.

Joseph Wu, the foreign minister of Taiwan, said on Thursday that a halt in U.S. arms shipments to Ukraine would embolden China in its aggressions against Taiwan and fuel propaganda from Beijing that the United States is an unreliable partner.
body:
When people ask us whether it is OK for the United States to abandon Ukraine, the answer is no, because the world is operating not in a black-and-white way, or if you only look at one theater at a time, he said. The world is interconnected.

If Russia is able to occupy more of Ukraine and claim victory, he added, it would be seen as a victory of authoritarian states because Russia, China, North Korea and Iran, they are now linked together.

Mr. Wus comments, made in a wide-ranging hourlong interview in Taipei, come as the Biden administration tries to get Congress to pass a supplemental funding package that would give $60 billion of aid to Ukraine.

Many House Republicans are staunchly opposed to giving more aid to Ukraine, adopting the America First posture embraced by former President Donald J. Trump, a pro-Russia candidate who has pressed them to reject the package. For months they claimed they would be willing to consider providing more assistance for Kyiv if the Biden administration imposed severe immigration restrictions at the United States border with Mexico. But at Mr. Trumps urging, they balked at a funding package that would have done that, calling the border measures too weak.

The package also includes $8 billion of aid to counter China in the Asia-Pacific region, $1.9 billion of which would refill stocks of U.S. weapons sent to Taiwan. And it includes $14.1 billion of military aid to Israel.
