Some Republican lawmakers contend that China is a bigger threat than Russia and that the funding proposed for Ukraine should go toward countering China. But other Republican officials in Congress and many Democrats make the same argument as Mr. Wu: that Taiwans security is linked to that of Ukraine, because China will see weakness on the part of the United States  and a greater chance of success in a potential invasion of Taiwan  if Ukraine is defeated.

Chinese leaders have said for decades that Taiwan, a de facto independent island, must be brought under the rule of the Communist Party, by force if necessary. Xi Jinping, Chinas leader, has continued to promote that position.

The U.S. and Taiwanese governments have been trying to deter China from notions of invading Taiwan, including through military buildup in the region and bolstering alliances with other democratic nations.

If the United States abandons Ukraine, Mr. Wu said, China will take it as a hint that if it can keep up sustained action against Taiwan, the United States is going to back off, the United States and its allies are going to back off. The thinking among Chinese officials would be this, he said: OK, since Russia could do that, we can do that as well.

So the U.S. determination in providing support to those countries suffering from authoritarian aggression, it is very important, Mr. Wu said.

After U.S. troops withdrew from Afghanistan in 2021, China pushed propaganda through traditional state-run media and social media that the U.S. commitment to anything is not firm, Mr. Wu said. We suffered from a huge wave of cognitive warfare.

China has also spread disinformation stressing Russian narratives of the war, Mr. Wu said, including the idea that the expansion of NATO forced President Vladimir V. Putin to attack Ukraine, and that the United States is ultimately not committed to supporting Ukraine.

On the eve of Russias invasion in February 2022, Mr. Putin visited Mr. Xi in Beijing, and their two governments announced a no limits partnership.

Mr. Wu said some Central and Eastern European nations seeking to forge anti-authoritarian partnerships had strengthened their relations with Taiwan during the war.

His comments on the need for the United States to keep supporting Taiwan echo those of other senior Taiwanese officials. In May 2023, Bi-khim Hsiao, then Taiwans de facto ambassador to the United States and now the incoming vice president, made similar arguments to reporters in Washington.

And in February, Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi, Democrat of Illinois, said during a visit of American lawmakers to Taiwan that the current president, Tsai Ing-wen, and the president-elect, Lai Ching-te, made clear to the lawmakers that if for some reason the Ukrainians do not prevail, that will only encourage hostilities against Taiwan.

title: Biden tries to rally support for Ukraine as unity in Congress gives way to bickering.
snippet:
Two years ago, Russias invasion of Ukraine dominated President Bidens first State of the Union address before a Congress that, for all of its divisions, was largely united in vowing American help to a country fighting to repel the advancing troops of President Vladimir V. Putin.

When Mr. Biden introduced first lady Jill Bidens guest, the Ukrainian ambassador, Republican and Democratic lawmakers, some wearing blue and yellow and waving Ukrainian flags, leaped to their feet in applause.
body:
This years address will be different. Ukraines first lady, Olena Zelenska, declined an invitation, citing a scheduling conflict. Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of the Russian opposition leader who died in a Russian prison last month, Aleksei A. Navalny, was also invited but is unable to attend.

And it is unclear how many lawmakers will be waving Ukrainian flags this year, as the initial outrage that welled after Mr. Putins invasion has given way to the partisan squabbling and gridlock that now characterize politics in the United States.

Mr. Bidens latest aid package proposal  $60.1 billion for badly needed artillery ammunition, air defense interceptors and other weapons  remains stalled in Congress, already undermining the fight on the ground in Ukraine, where American officials say more than 500,000 have been killed and injured between the two sides.

Mr. Putins military was forced to abandon its drive to Kyiv, the capital, on April 2, 2022, thanks to stiff Ukrainian resistance helped by real-time intelligence provided by the United States and NATO allies, not to mention poor logistics and tactical decision-making on the Russian part. But Russia decimated many cities and towns in the east and established a land bridge connecting the mainland with Crimea, the peninsula that Mr. Putin illegally seized in 2014. And two years on, depleted Ukrainian forces are still trying to hold off advancing Russian troops in the east.

Mr. Biden will certainly exhort Congress to move forward on the aid package in his speech, administration officials said. But some contingency planning is also underway.

The administration is trying to cobble together a stopgap package of artillery ammunition and air defense interceptors, paid for with money from Army contracts that came in under bid, U.S. officials said. That measure, which could also include some longer-range guided missiles known as ATACMs, was unlikely to be ready in time to announce during Mr. Bidens remarks on Thursday, they added.

But at best, the makeshift solution would only keep advancing Russian troops at bay for a few weeks.

Mr. Biden will be able to point to at least one success that has resulted from Mr. Putins invasion: One person who accepted the White House invitation is the Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson of Sweden, which became NATOs newest member just a few hours before Mr. Bidens speech was scheduled to begin.

Sweden along with Finland decided to apply to join NATO shortly after the invasion began, expanding the alliance that has so bedeviled Mr. Putin.

title: Biden Offers Ironclad Commitment to Allies, Defying Russia (and Trump)
snippet:
The president hosted leaders of Poland at the White House as he sought to reassure NATO members of American steadfastness in the face of threats from Moscow and former President Donald J. Trump.

President Biden pledged an ironclad commitment to Americas allies on Tuesday as he sought to reassure NATO members that the United States would not abandon its international obligations despite the threats of aggression by Russia and disruption by his all-but-certain fall election rival, former President Donald J. Trump.
body:
Hosting the leaders of Poland at the White House, Mr. Biden made a show of defiance not only against President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who continues to wage war on Ukraine, but also, implicitly at least, against Mr. Trump, who has said he would encourage Russia to attack NATO members that do not spend enough on their militaries.

When we stand together, no force on earth is more powerful, Mr. Biden said, citing former Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the Czech-born diplomat who championed NATO membership for Poland, Hungary and her homeland, finalized on this day in 1999 with the support of Mr. Biden, then a senator. I believed that then, and I believe it now, he added.

The meeting with President Andrzej Duda and Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland marked the 25th anniversary of their countrys accession to NATO, which was the beginning of a quarter-century post-Cold War expansion of the alliance into parts of Europe previously dominated by the old Soviet Union. Just this month, NATO formally welcomed Sweden, which like Finland joined in response to Russias full-fledged invasion of Ukraine in 2022, increasing the alliance to 32 members, up from 16 when the Berlin Wall fell.

Mr. Biden used the occasion to announce $300 million in additional weapons and military equipment for Ukraine, a small fraction of what he has asked Congress for but all he could squeeze out of savings from previous arms transfers without additional legislative authority. He pressed House Republican leaders to stop blocking legislation passed by the Senate for $60 billion in security aid to Ukraine, a measure that has bipartisan support and would almost surely pass if brought to the floor.

We must act before it literally is too late, before its too late, because as Poland remembers, Russia wont stop at Ukraine, Mr. Biden said. Putin will keep going, putting Europe, the United States and the entire free world at risk.

Mr. Biden praised the Polish leaders not only for investing in the alliance but also for taking in about one million Ukrainians who have fled the war. Youre doing Gods work, he told the leaders. You really are. Its incredible what youre doing, what the Polish people are doing.

He also promised Poland a $2 billion military loan and approved the sale of 96 Apache attack helicopters to Warsaw.

Poland sits on the frontline of the alliance, perpetually wary of Russian revanchism and staunchly supportive of Ukraine, which is not a NATO member, as it defends itself against Mr. Putins forces. Poland spends more on its military as a proportion than any other member of the alliance, nearly 4 percent of its economy, twice the alliances goal. Mr. Duda used the White House visit to propose that NATO increase its target from 2 percent of gross domestic product to 3 percent.

Other allies must take more responsibility for the security of the alliance as a whole, Mr. Duda said as he sat with Mr. Biden in the East Room of the White House. Two percent was good 10 years ago. Now 3 percent is required in response to the full-scale war launched by Russia right beyond NATOs eastern border.

The alliances leaders agreed in 2014 to the 2 percent goal, but it was a nonbinding aspiration to meet by 2024. While several American presidents have pushed NATO to do more for its own defense, Mr. Trump was more bellicose in demanding that allies raise their military spending and spoke of it as if they owed the money to the United States, which was not true.

Under Mr. Trump, the number of NATO members meeting the 2 percent goal increased to nine from six. Under Mr. Biden, it has doubled to 18, reflecting rising fear of Russia since its invasion of Ukraine. The United States spends 3.5 percent of its gross domestic product on the military, and most of the other top spenders are in Eastern Europe, closer to Russia. Collectively, the European allies are spending 2 percent of their combined gross domestic product this year, or $380 billion.

While Mr. Biden did not mention Mr. Trump by name on Tuesday, Mr. Tusk seemed to allude to comments in which the former president scoffed at the mutual defense obligation in Article 5 of the NATO treaty. We treat our obligations seriously, more than anyone else in Europe, Mr. Tusk said. And we hope that none of our NATO partners will undermine the most important obligation, which is Article 5 of the treaty.

The visit by the Polish leaders was the first since a landmark election in October, when opposition parties defeated the ruling Law and Justice party, a right-wing faction accused of subverting democracy as it consolidated power over major institutions like the judiciary, the news media, the central bank and large state-controlled corporations.

Mr. Duda and Mr. Tusk, who was installed in December as prime minister, are fierce rivals who have clashed repeatedly at home. Mr. Duda is an ally of Law and Justice who curried favor with Mr. Trump when he was in office, while Mr. Tusk is a veteran centrist who during a previous stint as prime minister from 2007 to 2014 worked with Mr. Biden, then the vice president.

Their conflict led to a dramatic showdown in January when Mr. Duda gave shelter in the presidential palace to two former officials from his party previously convicted of abuse of power. Mr. Tusk accused Mr. Duda of obstruction of justice, and the police were sent into the palace to arrest the former officials.

But in a measure of how seriously Poland takes the Russian threat, the two rivals agreed to put aside their differences for their joint visit with Mr. Biden. I differ politically with President Andrzej Duda on almost everything, Mr. Tusk wrote in Polish on social media, but when it comes to the security of our homeland, we must and will act together. Not only during a visit to the USA.

title: U.S. to Send $300 Million in Weapons to Ukraine Under Makeshift Plan
snippet:
The package will keep advancing Russian troops at bay for only a few weeks, an official said.

The Biden administration announced on Tuesday that it was sending up to $300 million in weapons to Ukraine, the first new aid package for the country since funding ran out in late December.
body:
The package, pulled together from money that Army accountants cobbled from savings from contracts that came in under bid, includes air defense interceptors, artillery rounds and armor systems, senior defense officials said. Two U.S. officials said the package also includes an older version of the Armys longer-range missile systems known as ATACMS, which can travel 100 miles.

It is a stopgap measure at best, the officials said, but Ukraine is in dire need of air defense systems in particular, as Russia has continued its bombardment of towns particularly in the east.

The makeshift solution would keep advancing Russian troops at bay for only a few weeks, one official said.

Announcing the aid package at the White House, the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, said that Ukrainian troops have fought bravely, are fighting bravely throughout this war, but they are now forced to ration their ammunition under pressure on multiple fronts.

He said the new package would keep Ukraines guns firing for a period, but only a short period. Mr. Sullivan called for Congress to pass a new Ukraine aid bill as soon as possible.

He said that Ukraine desperately needed the assistance to hold the line against Russian attacks, but that it goes without saying this package does not displace and should not delay the critical need to pass the bipartisan national security bill.

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, in his overnight address, thanked the United States and all Americans who value freedom for their support of his country.

The Senate passed an emergency aid bill including $60.1 billion for Ukraine. But the measure faces an uncertain fate in the House of Representatives, where Republican leaders have refused to put the measure to a vote. While congressional officials say there is a critical mass of support for continuing to arm Ukraine in its fight against Russian aggression, the Republican Party is increasingly turning away from its traditional hawkish posture and belief in projecting American power and democratic principles around the world.

House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican of Louisiana who has opposed aiding Ukraine, must navigate a handful of ultraconservative lawmakers who have said they will move to oust him if he allows a vote on Ukraine aid without stringent immigration measures attached.

On Tuesday, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, urged Mr. Johnson to hold a vote on the Ukraine aid package.

I want to encourage the speaker again to allow a vote, he said.

For President Biden, who has led the way in calling for the West to stand up for Ukraine against Russias invasion and occupation, the issue has become an embarrassing one on the international stage.

The American political paralysis has led, Pentagon officials said, to critical shortages on the battlefields of Ukraine. As each day goes by without a fresh supply of munitions and artillery, and Ukrainian crews ration the shells they have, morale suffers.

When Russian troops advance and its guns fire, Ukraine does not have enough ammunition to fire back; thats costing terrain, Mr. Sullivan said. Its costing lives and its costing us, the United States and the NATO alliance, strategically.

Since Russias February 2022 invasion of Ukraine, the Biden administration has sent more than $75 billion in cash and equipment to the country for its defense. Most of the aid has gone to Ukraines military operations, keeping its government running and addressing its humanitarian needs.

The money ran out in December, and Mr. Biden asked Congress for the authority to begin a new infusion of cash and equipment that only it can approve. But many Republicans object to pouring more taxpayer dollars into the conflict.

Senior intelligence officials warned on Monday that without additional American aid, Ukraine faced the prospect of continued battlefield losses as Russia uses a network of arms suppliers and increases its supply of technology from China.

In public testimony during the annual survey of worldwide threats facing the United States, the officials told Congress that any continued delay of U.S. aid would lead to additional territorial gains by Russia over the next year, the consequences of which would be felt in Europe and in the Pacific.

On Tuesday, Denmark also announced a new $340 million military aid package for Ukraine.

Constant Mheut contributed reporting.

title: Vowing the U.S. Will Do Our Job, Johnson Searches for a Path on Ukraine
snippet:
The Republican speaker, with his job on the line, has privately told people he would make sure the House moves to assist Ukraine, a step that many members of his party oppose.

When Speaker Mike Johnson opened the floor for questions at a closed-door luncheon fund-raiser in New Jersey last month, Jacquie Colgan asked how, in the face of vehement opposition within his own ranks, he planned to handle aid for Ukraine.
body:
What followed was an impassioned monologue by Mr. Johnson in which he explained why continued American aid to Kyiv was, in his view, vital  a message starkly at odds with the hard-right views that have overtaken his party. He invoked his political roots as a Reagan Republican, denounced President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a madman and conceded the issue had forced him to walk a delicate political tightrope.

Reminded by Ms. Colgan, a member of the American Coalition for Ukraine, a nonprofit advocacy group, of the adage that the only thing necessary for the triumph of evil was for good people to do nothing, Mr. Johnson replied that he kept a copy of the quotation framed in his office.

Thats not going to be us, he assured her. Were going to do our job.

The exchange reflects what Mr. Johnson has privately told donors, foreign leaders and fellow members of Congress in recent weeks, according to extensive notes Ms. Colgan took during the New Jersey event and interviews with several other people who have spoken with him.

While the speaker has remained noncommittal about any one option, he has repeatedly expressed a personal desire to send aid to Ukraine  something he has voted against repeatedly in the past  and now appears to be in search of the least politically damaging way to do it.

The challenge for Mr. Johnson is that any combination of aid measures he puts to a vote will likely infuriate the growing isolationist wing of his party, which considers the issue toxic. Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, who has repeatedly said she would call a snap vote to unseat the speaker if he allowed a vote for Ukraine aid before imposing restrictive immigration measures, filed a resolution on Friday calling for his removal, saying she wanted to send him a warning.

Even if Ms. Greene follows through on the threat, Mr. Johnson could still hold onto his job. Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the minority leader, has said he believed a reasonable number of Democrats would vote to save the speaker were he to face a Republican mutiny for acting on the Senate-passed aid package, though on Friday Mr. Jeffries said that had been an observation, not a declaration.

In a lengthy statement on Friday after Ms. Greene had filed her resolution and the House departed Washington for its Easter recess, Mr. Johnson said that when lawmakers returned in two weeks, they would take the necessary steps to address the supplemental funding request.

We have done important work discussing options with members, he said, and are preparing to complete our plan for action.

Privately, Mr. Johnson has expressed an interest in linking Ukraine aid to a measure aimed at forcing the Biden administration to reverse its moratorium on liquefied natural gas exports, according to three people familiar with his deliberations who were not authorized to discuss them. Mr. Johnson pressed the issue at a White House meeting last month with President Biden and congressional leaders, arguing that by prohibiting new exports of domestic energy, the administration was increasing reliance on Russian gas, effectively enriching Ukraines enemy.

In that meeting, according to a person familiar with the comments, Mr. Johnson raised the case of Calcasieu Pass 2, a proposed export terminal that would be situated along a shipping channel that connects the Gulf of Mexico to Lake Charles, La., and would dwarf the countrys existing export terminals. The Biden administration in January had paused a decision on whether to approve it.

He has puzzled over whether to put the aid to a vote on the House floor packaged with assistance for other U.S. allies, including Israel and Taiwan, or allow lawmakers to vote on them separately to register their support for each individual nation.

With many Republicans bent on blocking aid to Ukraine, any legislation carrying it would need to be considered using a special procedure that bypasses House rules and requires a two-thirds majority for passage, relying heavily on votes from Democrats. But a combined aid package for both Ukraine and Israel like the one that passed the Senate last month could be doomed by a coalition of right-wing Republicans opposing the money for Kyiv and left-wing Democrats opposing aid for Israel.

Mr. Johnson has pondered imposing new sanctions against Russia. And he has debated how the money should be structured  straight assistance versus a loan  and whether it should be exclusively for lethal aid, a type of assistance that is more widely supported by his conference, or also include nonmilitary assistance.

There is a big distinction in the minds of a lot of people between lethal aid for Ukraine, and the humanitarian component, Mr. Johnson said at a news conference at the Capitol last week.

Both he and Representative Michael McCaul, Republican of Texas and the chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, have publicly floated the idea of paying for some of the aid by selling off Russian sovereign assets that have been frozen using legislation called the REPO Act.

Mr. Johnson has faced mounting international pressure to allow a vote on aid to Ukraine, fielding almost weekly visits and calls from NATO allies and pro-Ukraine activists both at his offices in Washington and Louisiana. When Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland visited Washington earlier this month, he had a sharp public message for the speaker.

This is not some political skirmish that only matters here in America, Mr. Tusk told reporters. The absence of this positive decision of Mr. Johnson will really cost thousands of lives there  children, women. He must be aware of his personal responsibility.

Meeting privately with Mr. Johnson in his office in the Capitol, President Andrzej Duda of Poland appealed to the Louisiana Republicans respect for President Ronald Reagan, whose portrait hung beside the speaker during the meeting. Mr. Duda quoted Mr. Reagan extensively and praised his willingness to call out good versus evil during the Cold War, according to a person familiar with the comments who requested anonymity to describe them.

Some skeptical Ukraine backers, both on and off Capitol Hill, have fretted that Mr. Johnsons agreeable comments have simply reflected his penchant for telling people what they want to hear. Early in Mr. Johnsons tenure as speaker, lawmakers noticed that he had a habit of leaving listeners from warring factions with the impression he agreed with each of them.

Yet at the fund-raiser in New Jersey last month, he was fairly candid about his calculations.

Mr. Johnson told the audience that he was working to figure out the best route forward, Ms. Colgan recalled, adding that he said that half of House Republicans wanted to move it together as a package with Israel and Taiwan, and the other half wanted to do it on its own.

At a separate fund-raiser in Binghamton for a congressman in New Yorks Hudson Valley last month, Christina Zawerucha, the executive director of the Together for Ukraine Foundation, and Anatoliy Pradun, the groups president, who was born and raised in Ukraine, approached the speaker to press him on holding a vote.

Mr. Pradun had hoped to appeal to Mr. Johnsons faith by telling him of the strong evangelical Christian community in Ukraine. But realizing they had little time to make their case, Ms. Zawerucha and Mr. Pradun instead gave the speaker a pin with the Ukrainian and American flags, showed him their poster advertising an upcoming interfaith vigil for Ukraine and implored him to schedule a vote on aid to Kyiv.

He didnt turn us away, Ms. Zawerucha said. He pointed at our poster and said, I will take care of this. I will take care of this.

When Ms. Zawerucha relayed the interaction to fellow activists after the luncheon, they asked what she thought he meant.

And at this point, I dont know, she said. Its been over a month since Speaker Johnson said he would take care of this. And a vote for Ukraine still has not been allowed on the floor.

Julian Barnes contributed reporting.

title: Afghan TV talk show discusses top Taliban defence officials' Doha visit
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Afghan political commentators on private Tolo News TV's regular Farakhabar (Beyond the News) programme on 5 March discussed the significance of the visits of the Taliban's defence minister and their joint chief of staff to Qatar.
body:
Mullah Mohammad Yaqoob, the Taliban de facto government's defence minister and Qari Fasihuddin Fitrat, the Taliban army's chief of staff, travelled to Doha on 3 March for talks with Qatari officials and to attend an international defence expo.

Pro-Taliban political commentator Fazl Rahman Orya said that the visit underscored the close diplomatic ties between Kabul and Doha.

"It is a high-profile trip by the Afghan defence minister. In addition to serving as a defence minister, he is also the deputy head of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. He was accorded a very high diplomatic welcome there. It is a kind of informal recognition of the Afghan government," he added.

Orya expressed hopes that Qatar can play an important role in bringing Washington and Kabul together and resolving disputes between the two sides.

"Qatar is protecting America's interests in Afghanistan. This is another role that Qatar is playing in Afghanistan. Hence, Qatar can again be a good host between America and Afghanistan and a good mediator between the two countries. It can play a role in creating an understanding between America and Afghanistan."

"Qatar has good experience in playing complicated games. In the current situation, Qatar can jointly take steps to secure the legitimate interests of the three countries. America, Qatar, and Afghanistan can identify the common grounds between the three countries and find out how to nurture and secure their common interests," he added.

The analyst welcomed the expansion of ties between Kabul and Doha, saying that the relationship between the two countries is getting deeper and wider every day.

"We can consider Qatar's role in Afghanistan as positive and in the interests of the people of Afghanistan and Qatari nationals," he asserted.

Commenting on the Afghan military official's participation at a defence expo in Doha and their efforts to modernize the Afghan army, the pundit said that Afghanistan must acquire nuclear weapons to maintain balance in the region.

"I feel that Afghanistan requires all types of modern weaponry - for ground and air purposes or air defence systems. In addition, Afghanistan would also require nuclear weapons in future. This is because, on the one hand, Iran possesses nuclear weapons; on the other hand, Pakistan possesses nuclear weapons. China also possesses nuclear weapons, Russia possesses nuclear weapons, and India possesses nuclear weapons. Hence, it would be difficult to maintain a balance," he said.

Attending the talk show via video call from outside Afghanistan, university lecturer and political commentator Mohammad Ishaq Atmar said, "Doha is an important place for building a relationship between the government of the Taliban and the world."

"Qatar wants to play a greater role in regional issues. Qatar is a country that considers itself a friend of Afghanistan," he stated.

Regarding the Afghan military official's visit to Qatar and their participation in the Doha defence expo, Atmar said: "We should not forget that the ruling Taliban government is in pursuit of obtaining new weaponries. Their invitation to the international defence exhibition can prepare the ground for it."

Atmar expressed hope that such visits could pave the ground for solving the existing disputes between the Taliban administration and the international community.

Source: Tolo News TV, Kabul, in Dari 1400 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: New finance minister says Pakistan will seek a long-term IMF loan to stabilize the economy
snippet:
ISLAMABAD (AP)  Pakistan plans to seek a long-term loan from the International Monetary Fund to help stabilize the country's ailing economy after the end of the IMF's current $3 billion bailout package, the country's newly appointed finance minister said Friday.

Muhammad Aurangzeb, who plans to meet with IMF officials in Washington in April, did not specify the amount that Pakistan would seek in comments to reporters in the capital, Islamabad. However, officials previously have said Pakistan wants to get up to $8 billion from the IMF over three years.
body:
Cash-strapped Pakistan has been facing one of its worst economic crises since last year when weekly inflation at one point crossed 40% amid fears the impoverished Islamic nation could default on its payment of foreign debt.

In June 2023, the IMF approved the current, one-year $3 billion loan package to Pakistan after the country agreed to slash subsidies and raise taxes to comply with the bailout terms. Pakistan is to receive the final $1.1 billion tranche in April.

Aurangzeb said the inflation rate has since come down to 23%, and that he would seek to bring it down further, to provide some relief to residents who have struggled to pay electricity and gas bills.

title: Egypt says it has reached a deal with the International Monetary Fund to increase a bailout loan to $8 billion
snippet: CAIRO (AP)  Egypt says it has reached a deal with the International Monetary Fund to increase a bailout loan to $8 billion.

title: Pakistan and IMF reach preliminary deal to release $1.1 billion from bailout fund, IMF says
snippet:
ISLAMABAD (AP)  Pakistan and the International Monetary Fund reached a preliminary agreement for the release of $1.1 billion from a $3 billion bailout following dayslong talks in Islamabad, the IMF said Wednesday.

Under the deal, Pakistan will receive the final tranche from the bailout that was approved by the IMF in July to save the nation from defaulting on its debt repayments.
body:
An IMF statement said it "has reached a staff-level agreement with the Pakistani authorities" and noted that approval by the IMF's executive board is considered a formality.

The announcement came after talks between the IMF and the new government of Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif concluded in Islamabad. Pakistans Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb and the IMF's mission chief to Pakistan, Nathan Porter, led their teams during the talks, which began on Thursday last week.

Pakistan signed the latest short-term agreement last year to overcome one of the worst economic crises in its history that had raised fears the South Asian Islamic nation could default on the payment of foreign debts. The $3 billion bailout was signed by Sharif, who replaced former Premier Imran Khan after a no-confidence vote in parliament.

Sharif was again elected the countrys premier this month following Feb. 8 parliamentary elections.

The latest development came weeks after Khan wrote a letter to the IMF urging it to link any talks with Islamabad to an audit of the recent elections, which his Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party says were rigged. Authorities have dismissed the charge as baseless.

Pakistani authorities have criticized Khan for writing the letter, saying it was a bid to harm the country's already ailing economy. Pakistan narrowly averted a default on foreign payments last summer.

In its statement on Wednesday, the IMF said Pakistans economic and financial position has improved" in recent months. However, it noted the growth is expected to be modest this year and inflation remains well above target, and ongoing policy and reform efforts are required to address Pakistans deep-seated economic vulnerabilities amidst the ongoing challenges posed by elevated external and domestic financing needs and an unsettled external environment."

The IMF said Sharif's government is committed to continue the policy efforts that started under the current bailout to entrench economic and financial stability for the remainder of this year."

It said Pakistani authorities are determined to take steps to further improve the country's economy by broadening the tax base, and through the timely implementation of power and gas tariff adjustments, while protecting the vulnerable through existing progressive tariff structures.

The IMF said Pakistan has also expressed interest in receiving a new bailout. Pakistan wants to seek a new bailout of up to $8 billion when the current one expires this month, it said.

title: Programme summary of Somalia's Radio Shabelle news 0500 gmt 04 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on Somalia's private commercial Radio Shabeelle on 4 March at 05:00 GMT

1. Headlines.
body:
2. Puntland regional state police have confirmed the arrest of six al-Shabab militant group fighters, including a woman, who were caught smuggling equipment into the north-eastern Somali town of Garowe, the state’s capital city. The group was headed to the mountainous areas of Bari region within the state.

3.The second meeting of the forum for Somalia’s religious scholars was held in Mogadishu’s Beerta Nabadda (peace park), yesterday afternoon. They blamed social media platforms for creating rifts between families and married couples.

4. South West regional state Dervish forces backed by Somali National Army conducted security operations against al-Shabab militant group and opened roads that had been previously closed by the insurgents between the south-western Somali towns of Baidoa and Berdale.

5. Somalia’s finance minister accompanied by the national planning investment and economic development minister and the Central Bank president opened a meeting on financial reforms in the Somali capital, Mogadishu. Government officials and representatives of the International Monetary Fund were present at the meeting .

6. International news.

Source: Radio Shabeelle, Mogadishu, in Somali 0500 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of Somalia's Radio Goobjoog news 1130 gmt 11 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on Somalia's privately-owned Radio Goobjoog on 11 March at 11:30 GMT

1.  Headlines.
body:
2. International Monetary Fund issued a report today commending the results of the Somali government’s financial reforms and economic development following the recent debt relief milestone achieved by the country.

3. Speaking to Radio Goobjoog in the Somali capital, Mogadishu today, residents have called on communities to abide by the orders of the Somali government to take up the Ramadan fast at once. The concern was raised after it was found that most residents in the central Somali state of Galmudug were not fasting today.

4. Somali government forces backed by international partner drones conducted operations against al-Shabab militant group in the southern Somali region of Lower Shabelle, leading to the  destruction of the insurgents’ bases and the deaths of several fighters, among them the group’s leaders and foreigners.

5. A group of young Somali women lawyers have opened a new office in the Somali capital, Mogadishu today to advocate for women’s rights. 

6. Sports news.

7. International news.

Source: Radio Goobjoog, Mogadishu, in Somali 1130 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Pakistan opposition party denies organising protest outside IMF office
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Opposition Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) chief Gohar Ali Khan has denied any involvement in organising a protest outside the International Monetary Fund (IMF) office, widely-read daily The Express Tribune reported on its website.
body:
The denial comes amid several accusations of disrupting the bailout package negotiations with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's newly-formed government, the report added.

Speaking to the press outside Adiala Jail, where jailed PTI founder Imran Khan awaits trial, the party chairman rejected reports on moves to prevent aid to Pakistan in the letter to the IMF.

PTI founder Imran Khan also, while commenting on the IMF protest, said he was not aware of any anti-army sloganeering during the demonstration.

The IMF delegation arrived in Pakistan for a second review of the current $3bn loan programme, which was agreed last year. The visit comes at a time when Islamabad is looking to secure a long-term pact with the IMF to tackle its economic challenges.

See also: IMF criticises Pakistan ministry's declaration on loan programme - news report

Pakistan to seek 'longer, larger' IMF programme

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0000 GMT 17 Mar 24

title: BBCM Middle East and North Africa Watchlist 18 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Arabic broadcast, press and social media sources

YNET
body:
Israeli media highlight mass rallies, far-right backlash

Israeli media highlighted this morning the mass rallies and the partial strike that took place in Israel yesterday, saying hundreds of thousands took to the streets across the country demanding an end to the war and a release of the hostages following the cabinet's decision to take over Gaza City.

The daily Haaretz reported that the "protest preoccupied the government and its members far more than the return of the hostages to their homes", adding that some ministers dismissed the protests as a failure.

Far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich wrote on X: "A toxic and harmful campaign", while MK Hanoch Milwidsky called them "riots in support of Hamas", and Minister of Heritage Amichai Eliyahu said on X: "Every call to stop the fighting is another dose of oxygen for Hamas in the tunnels."

Far-right Channel 14 focused on headlines from Arab media saying that they framed the protests as "an internal uprising", and a "psychological crack in Israeli cohesion", and a sign to the Arab world that "Israel is split from within".

Houthi missile intercepted by Israel after strikes on Yemen

A Houthi missile targeting Israel was reported by the army to have been intercepted yesterday afternoon, coming after Israeli naval strikes targeted Yemen's energy infrastructure earlier in the day.

The strikes hit the Haziz power station south of Houthi-controlled Sanaa, leading to a large fire and power outage, Houthi-run Al-Masirah TV reported yesterday.

Work to repair the damage and restore the power outage was underway, Houthi Deputy Prime Minister Mohammed Muftah said after inspecting the site.

This morning, Israel's Maariv daily said that the naval strikes were part of Israel's multi-pronged military approach to dealing with the Houthis and "all players in the region", which included its air force and drone technology.

Egypt, Qatar reportedly hand new ceasefire proposal to Hamas

Egypt and Qatar have reportedly handed Hamas a new proposal to resume the Gaza ceasefire talks.

The Saudi-funded pan-Arab Al Arabiya website quoted unnamed sources today as saying that representatives from Egypt and Qatar conveyed the new initiative to the movement in the presence of leaders of several Palestinian factions.

The sources added that faction leaders urged Hamas to prepare a response to the proposal "within the coming hours", according to the website.

This comes as Israel prepares for a large-scale operation to control Gaza City, including plans to relocate residents of the city to the southern Gaza Strip.

Egyptian, Palestinian PMs discuss developments in Gaza

Egyptian Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly has received his Palestinian counterpart Mohammed Mustafa in the Egyptian coastal city of Alamein, where they discussed developments in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

Madbouly stressed Egypt's commitment to the unity of the Palestinian territories in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip under the leadership of the Palestinian Authority, according to a Facebook statement posted yesterday by the Egyptian cabinet.

The Palestinian prime minister is set to visit the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing with Gaza today, according to Sky News Arabia.

The visit will include inspecting the Egyptian Red Crescent's logistics centre for aid to review the mechanism of the humanitarian operation.

Egypt reiterates rejection of Israeli plans to displace Palestinians

Egypt has reiterated its rejection of any Israeli plans to displace Palestinians in the Gaza Strip or the West Bank after reports of Israeli negotiations with some countries to receive Palestinians displaced from Gaza.

The Egyptian foreign ministry said in a Facebook statement yesterday that it made communications with those countries which "confirmed their rejection of such denounced plans".

The ministry emphasised Egypt's "categorical rejection" of any Israeli plans to displace Palestinians "whether voluntarily or by force through policies of starvation, confiscating lands, settlements and making life impossible in Palestinian territories".

It stressed that Egypt will neither accept displacement nor participate in it, describing it as a "historical injustice that has no moral or legal justification".

Hundreds of Bedouin fighters reject secession calls by protesters in Syria's Suweida

Protests in Syria's restive southern province of Suweida (also Sweida) on 16 August calling for secession drew condemnation from Bedouin tribes and fighters, Syrian media reported yesterday.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported that "hundreds of fighters" from tribes of southern Syria had gathered in Rakham, a village in Deraa province near Suweida, to denounce the calls.

Meanwhile, the pro-government Zaman al-Wasl website reported yesterday that tribes "displaced" from recent clashes in Suweida had condemned the presence of Israeli flags at the protest, blaming "militias led by Hajri" - a reference to controversial Druze cleric Hikmat al-Hajri.

The latest comes after Suweida witnessed a wave of deadly sectarian violence in mid-July between Druze factions, local Bedouin tribes and Syrian government forces.

Suicide explosion reported in Aleppo, no casualties

A suicide bomber detonated his belt outside a bakery in the northern Syrian commercial hub city of Aleppo yesterday afternoon, with no casualties reported.

Halab TV reported that the assailant detonated the belt near the Al-Wahda bakery in the central Al-Maysar neighbourhood, while a leading war monitor said the incident in front of a bakery "raised many questions" as to the motive.

It comes after a car explosion was reported in the western Damascus neighbourhood of Mezzeh on 16 August, also causing no injuries, state news agency Sana reported. Specialised units combed the area to ensure the safety of citizens and prevent any potential acts of terrorism, a security official told Sana.

Syria has been grappling with violence targeting minorities over recent months. In June, a suicide bombing at the Mar Elias church in Damascus killed at least 25 people and wounded over 60.

Jordan to fast-track national military service plans following announcement

Jordanian media prominently reported the announcement yesterday by Crown Prince Al Hussein Bin Abdullah that national military service would be re-activated "soon".

Responding to the decision, Prime Minister Jaafar Hassan said that the plans would be fast-tracked and that the government would immediately begin with the necessary executive and legislative procedures to reactivate mandatory service, the kingdom's popular Roya TV channel said last night.

Hassan announced the allocation of funds to begin preparations for the programme which is expected to begin early next year, the channel reported.

The latest announcement comes amid mounting regional tensions in view of Israel's expanded offensive in Gaza, its latest settlement expansion announcement, the freezing of church funds in Jerusalem, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's "Greater Israel Vision" remarks last week, which were condemned across the region, including in Jordan.

Lebanese president tells Al Arabiya 'Iran will not interfere' domestically

Lebanon's President Joseph Aoun has reiterated his message that Iran will not interfere in internal Lebanese affairs, in an interview broadcast yesterday on pan-Arab Al Arabiya TV.

Aoun told the channel that he had informed top Iranian security official Ali Larijani last week that Beirut-Tehran relations are "based on respect" but that "our message is clear, Iran will not interfere".

He stressed that restricting Hezbollah's arms was a "Lebanese decision and does not concern Iran" and that the US paper presented by envoy Thomas Barrack included an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon and a plan to revitalise the Lebanese economy, Al Arabiya reported.

The remarks coincide with intense public and political debate in Lebanon over the country's ability to deter near-daily Israeli attacks upon Hezbollah's disarmament. The group has rejected calls for it to disarm.

title: Pakistan, IMF reach staff-level agreement for release of $1.1bn loan tranche
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's talks with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) led to an announcement on 20 March on a staff-level agreement for the release of the $1.1bn loan tranche after the global lender said there was improvement in Pakistan's economic and financial positions, prominent daily Dawn reported on its website.
body:
"The IMF team has reached a staff-level agreement with the Pakistani authorities on the second and final review of Pakistan’s stabilization program supported by the IMF's $3 billion SBA approved in January," the IMF said on its website.

"Pakistan’s economic and financial position has improved in the months since the first review, with growth and confidence continuing to recover on the back of prudent policy management and the resumption of inflows from multilateral and bilateral partners," it added.

However, the IMF warned that since inflation was above target, Pakistan will have to increase gas and electricity prices during the current fiscal year, it added.

The development followed a visit by an IMF team, led by Nathan Porter, during 14-19 March for talks on the second review of Pakistan’s economic program, it also said.

The agreement is subject to approval by the IMF's Executive Board, the report added.

See also: IMF criticises Pakistan ministry's declaration on loan programme - news report

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0700 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: India urges IMF to monitor Pakistan loan utilisation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

India has urged the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to ensure "strict monitoring" of the utilisation of any emergency aid provided to Pakistan over its potential misuse, The Hindu reported on its website.
body:
The request was put across by India's representative at the IMF executive director Krishnamurthy Subramanian, during a recent review of $3 billion short-term loan granted to Pakistan in July 2023 by the funds executive board, the report stated.

“Such monitoring is imperative to ensure that funds received to meet development imperatives are not diverted towards defence spending and repayment of external debt owed to third countries," India is learnt to have stressed to the IMF’s executive board, according to the report.

The development comes at a time when Pakistan’s newly-elected prime minister Shehbaz Sharif has directed officials to initiate talks with the IMF for completion of the ongoing Standby Arrangement and request a new a new long-term bailout package simultaneously.

Pakistan’s economy had contracted in 2022-23 leaving significant challenges for the new government to stabilise it.

Source: The Hindu website, Chennai, in English 0155 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Saudi cabinet approves agreement to establish IMF regional office in Riyadh
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers has approved an agreement to establish a regional office for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in the capital Riyadh, official state news agency SPA reported on 20 March.
body:
The decision was made during a cabinet session held the previous day in the coastal city of Jeddah and presided over by King Salman, SPA said.

In a report published on its website on 20 March, Saudi's flagship Al Arabiya TV said the move "reflects the kingdom's status as the region's largest economy and one of the most important G20 economies".

“This move is anticipated to enhance coordination on economic policies and reforms, thereby contributing to enhanced regional stability and growth,” the English-language Saudi-owned pan-Arab Arab News website noted on 20 March.

The announcement comes less than a month after the kingdom’s Shura (Consultative) Council endorsed the agreement at a session held on 26 February.

See: Bin Salman hails Saudi's 'leading' role after Riyadh wins World Expo 2030 bid

Source: SPA news agency, Riyadh, in Arabic 1724 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Pakistan, IMF extend talks over review of $3bn loan programme - news report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The visiting International Monetary Fund (IMF) delegation has agreed to extend discussions with Pakistani authorities by a day to conclude the review of a $3bn bailout programme that was agreed upon by both sides in 2023, local media outlets have reported.
body:
The talks between the two were initially due to conclude on 18 March.

However, a report by Dawn, citing unnamed officials, said that some agenda items remained uncovered as the meetings were affected by reduced working hours due to Ramadan.

The final wrap-up meeting will now take place on 19 March, the report noted, adding that the letter of intent (LoI) and Memorandum of Economic and Financial Policies (MEFP) - a policy implementation document - on behalf of Pakistan's finance minister and the governor of central bank will be finalised the same day. 

The IMF team arrived in Pakistan last week to carry out the second and final review of the  $3bn loan programme. The successful completion of the review will be followed by the release of a remaining tranche of around $1.1bn.

The two sides would remain in contact in the run-up to pre­sentation of Pakis­tan’s case to the fund’s executive board for approval of the final tranche, the report added.

Pakistan has already received $1.9bn out of the $3bn agreed under the agreement.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0334 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: IMF expresses concern over conflicts in Ethiopia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has expressed "distress" over the conflicts in Ethiopia’s Amhara and Oromia regions even as it prepares to send a delegation to the country, private The Reporter website reported on 9 March.
body:
"The International Monetary Fund (IMF) says it is 'distressed' by violent conflicts in the Amhara and Oromia regional states as it prepares to send a mission to Addis Ababa in the coming weeks as part of the Ethiopian government’s three-year quest for a financial package deal," said The Reporter.

"We are closely following these developments [conflicts] and we note the concerns from the United States, and we hope for a peaceful resolution of this issue," The Reporter quoted  IMF Communications Director Julie Kozack as saying.

Kozack further said that the clashes could influence the funds Ethiopia would like to secure from international financial institutions.

The Ethiopian army is fighting Fano militia groups and the Oromo Liberation Army (OLA) in Amhara and Oromia regions, respectively, resulting in civilians casualties and destruction of property.

Source: The Reporter, Addis Ababa, in English 9 Mar 24

title: Pakistan PM directs negotiations with IMF for new loan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's newly-elected prime minister Shehbaz Sharif has directed officials to start negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a new long-term bailout package, local media have reported.
body:
The prime minister issued the instructions at a meeting with senior government officials, held to discuss matters related to the economy on 4 March, The News daily reported.

Sharif gave directives to prepare "emergency steps" for economic revival and proceed with talks with the IMF for completion of the ongoing Standby Arrangement and request a new three-year deal simultaneously, after he was briefed about the current fiscal situation, the report said.

"We have got the mandate to improve the economy and this is the top priority of our government,” he was quoted as saying. 

The meeting was held just hours after Sharif was sworn in as the 24th prime minister of Pakistan, amid protests by the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf and other opposition parties, who claimed that the election results were manipulated, Dawn daily reported on its website.

Pakistan needs a long-term bailout from the IMF for debt repayments and current account deficit financing. The country had secured a short-term IMF bailout under an Extended Fund Facility last year but the programme expires in April, news reports said.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 5 Mar 24

title: Pakistan prime minister pledges to free country from foreign debt
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif has vowed to get Pakistan out of foreign debt, saying the country would get rid of the International International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailouts, Geo News website reported.
body:
The prime minister made the comments while addressing the first meeting of the newly-formed federal cabinet on 11 March.

“We will get rid of IMF InshaAllah," Shehbaz was quoted as saying.

The comments came at a time when Pakistan is looking to secure another long-term bailout programme with the IMF to pull the country out of the current economic crisis.

As per the report, the IMF is expected to dispatch its mission to Pakistan to hold talks on the second review of ongoing $3bn Stand-by Arrangement (SBA) programme, which expires next month.

Speaking about the rising foreign debt, Sharif said he has asked ambassadors of foreign states that he would “now not seek loans but investments” from "friendly countries", the report said.

He also called for ending subsidies for "elites". There "is no justification" for such grants while the poor people are crushed under the burden of inflation, the prime minister said, as per the report.

Source: Geo News TV website, Karachi, in English 11 Mar 24

title: Pakistan: New finance minister says talks with IMF likely to begin soon
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan’s newly-appointed Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb has confirmed Islamabad's plan to send formal request to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for holding "curtail talks" regarding the bailout programme, The News daily reported on its website.
body:
The minister, who took the oath of office on 11 March, hoped that the talks with the US-based lender would begin this week, the report added.

The report, citing unnamed official sources, said the Pakistani side would dispatch an email to the IMF headquarters in Washington DC to send its review team to Islamabad for the talks on a $3bn Stand-By Arrangement and release of the last tranche worth $1.1bn.

The government might also request to commence talks for a fresh medium-term bailout package of $6bn Extended Fund Facility (EFF) with the strong chances to increase it with climate financing of $1.5-to-$2bn more to secure additional financing from the IMF compared to the allocated quota for Pakistan, the report added

Pakistan’s current programme with the IMF expires next month. Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif had last week directed officials to start negotiations with the IMF for a new long-term bailout package.

Meanwhile, the newly sworn-in finance minister said the current fiscal year would be a difficult one. Highlighting the urgency of the situation, he said that "now there was no time for mere talks and it was, in fact, time for action", the report added.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 12 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dunya TV show on IMF deal, signs of improvement in economy
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Dunya Kamran Khan Kay Saath" (World With Kamran Khan), hosted by senior journalist and TV host Kamran Khan on moderate Dunya News TV in Urdu at 16:30 GMT on 20 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Anchor Kamran Khan said a staff-level agreement between the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Pakistan was signed on 19 March after a final review of the standby arrangement. He added the IMF's confidence in Pakistan's steps for economic revival seems to be growing and noted it is a result of the steps taken under the Special Investment Facilitation Council (SIFC) during the caretaker government's tenure. He mentioned exports, large-scale manufacturing, agriculture, remittances and foreign investment have increased in the last few months, with exports increasing by 9 per cent in the current fiscal year.
body:
Khan asked journalist Shahbaz Rana about the government's preparations for acquiring a new IMF programme. Rana said an element of uncertainty in the economy has been reduced in the last nine months and reports about a possible default are not being heard anymore. He explained the reason behind it is that an "umbrella" of the IMF is available to Pakistan. He noted since the previous IMF programme had failed, there was a lack of confidence in Pakistan, which has now decreased.

Rana noted Pakistan had achieved a "phase of stability" earlier as well but governments started taking political decisions after that. However, he said, the situation this time would be different because all stakeholders and foreign players having interest in Pakistan's economy have said this is the "last chance for Pakistan" and there is "no room for mistakes". He was of the view that in the next programme, the IMF would want Pakistan to reform its power sector so that the cost of electricity can be reduced.

Khan spoke with former finance minister Miftah Ismail and asked him to share his views on the current signs of improvement in the economy. Ismail said several good things have taken place, for example, cotton crop has been very good this year. However, he added, there have been problems in some sectors as the government has massively increased gas and electricity prices and it is affecting the industries. He noted it has been proven that things can improve if focused measures like controlling the Afghan Transit Trade and stopping illegal transfer of foreign exchange are taken. He was of the view that the IMF agreement for release of the third tranche is "very encouraging" and Pakistan would be able to smoothly go into the next three-year programme.

Khan spoke with Imtiaz Gadar, an expert on economic affairs, and asked him why the stock market is cautious even though the economy has started showing signs of improvement. Gadar said the market has certainly taken a "cautious stance" because it probably wants to see some of the things materialise. He noted the IMF programme prioritises stability and then moves towards growth. He expressed the view that if Pakistan goes into a long-term IMF programme, a "built-in discount in the economy" that Pakistan's external position is very weak would change, and the country can work towards growth in the second phase of the programme. Commenting on the SIFC as a platform for multiple stakeholders in the economy, he emphasised the results would certainly be good if all stakeholders are on the same page and work for combined objectives in the economy.

Ismail insisted the interest rate should be reduced. Noting that the current prices of Pakistan's bonds are at the "highest in two years", he said this indicates that "the world is happy that Pakistan is going in the right direction" and investors have greater confidence in Pakistani bonds.

Khan commented China is one of Pakistan's most important friends and the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (mega development project) is to be "revitalised", but at the same time, the United States (US) is also important to Pakistan. He asked Ismail how Pakistan can strike a balance between China and the US in economic matters. Ismail said Pakistan can neither leave China, nor the US. He mentioned China is Pakistan's "biggest single country lender" and most of the electricity in Pakistan is being generated due to its support. He added at the same time, the US and Western Europe are the biggest buyers of Pakistani exports.

Ismail was of the view that Pakistan needs to take China and the US along simultaneously, which is a very "delicate" task and is not easy. He said the situation would get better and a balance between China and the US would be maintained if Pakistan starts collecting more taxes and stands on its own feet. He remarked a country as big as Pakistan needs to maintain friendly relations with all the countries.

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1630 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's PTV show on talks with IMF delegation, upcoming Indian elections
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Riasat" (The State), hosted by anchor Shahzad Raza on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 13 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Talks with IMF
body:
Anchor Shahzad Raza said an International Monetary Fund (IMF) delegation will start talks with Pakistan on 14 March regarding a standby agreement and the country is expected to get the last tranche of $1.1bn from the IMF under the agreement. He noted Pakistan now has a new government and a new economic team under Minister of Finance Muhammad Aurangzeb will be holding talks with the IMF delegation. He added after this review, Pakistan will have to go into another IMF programme.

Raza spoke with Dr Khaqan Hassan Najeeb, an expert on economic affairs, and asked him for his views on the prospect of talks with the IMF. Najeeb said he has constantly been saying that leaving the IMF would be an action that would put Pakistan in "more discomfort" and it is good that the new government has realised this. He noted the standby agreement is an "interim arrangement" that enables Pakistan to acquire bilateral, multilateral and commercial funds. He mentioned the country would be going into the 24th IMF programme but 21 of those programmes have remained incomplete.

Najeeb remarked it is not an IMF programme but "Pakistan's programme which is being financed by a lender [IMF]". He noted Pakistan got IMF funding in the past for some "breathing room" but did not implement "deeper reforms" due to which the economy could not stabilise.

Raza spoke with Dr Shimail Daud, former president of the Rawalpindi Chambers of Commerce and Industry, and asked him why the country's economic challenges have grown after 2018. Daud replied continuity of policy was not maintained due to the changing governments. He said governments avoided taking tough decisions to implement reforms because it led to a "political fallout". He added those governments tried making "populist decisions" and giving excessive subsidies. He was of the view that such wrong actions were continuously "stacked" and problems kept growing.

Daud commented the IMF tries to "discipline" the economy, but as soon as the government gives up that discipline, it loses the steps forward. He added that is why issues in the economy have remained unresolved, like loss-making enterprises not being privatised, circular debt increasing and tax to gross domestic product ratio continuing to be low. He was of the view that the leadership should take people into confidence that tough measures are not wrong decisions but necessary corrective steps. He insisted "belt-tightening" is needed in the coming years.

Suggesting some reforms to improve the economy, Najeeb said Pakistan needs to reduce the size of the federal government to control its expenditures. He added the country needs to stop unnecessary subsidies and pensions should not be state-funded.

Raza contacted Haroon Sharif, former chairperson of the Board of Investment, and asked him whether pending mega projects like the oil refinery by Saudi Arabia, revival of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (mega development project), and the Pakistan-Iran gas pipeline could materialise now since an elected government with a "clear-cut agenda" is in place. Sharif replied these projects have remained pending for several years and that is because "macro-economic vulnerabilities" of governments impacted the flow of foreign investment. He noted Pakistan's risk on external payments has remained high. He was of the view that the government should facilitate "relatively smaller investment deals for the private sector" besides focusing on the mega projects. He emphasised Pakistan needs to reduce the cost of doing business and increase the ease of doing business.

Upcoming elections in India

Talking about the upcoming Indian elections, Raza said it looks like the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is trying to win elections with an "anti-Muslim" and "nationalist Hindu" sentiment. He asked political analyst Raza Muhammad Khan to share his views on the BJP's election campaign which isolates a large part of the population, which is non-Hindu, from the system. Khan replied the BJP's election formula is a "tested one" as it has helped the party win elections twice but it is also a "very dangerous formula".

Khan claimed the economy or good governance have no role in the BJP's election campaign and it aims to "divide people on the basis of religion, hatred towards Muslims in India and Kashmir, and hatred against Pakistan". He added it degrades other minorities like the Sikhs and Dalits. He remarked it looks like the BJP is not bothered about alienating a large population of Muslims, Dalits, Sikhs and others.

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Samaa News TV show on politics, arrest warrants for chief minister
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Nadeem Malik Live" hosted by anchor Nadeem Malik, a senior journalist and analyst, on moderate Samaa News TV in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 19 March 2024. The programme invites politicians and analysts to express their opinions on important issues.

Anchor Nadeem Malik said a court in Rawalpindi has issued non-bailable warrants of the arrest for Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur. He noted the warrants have been issued in connection to the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged members of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, PTI). He remarked issuing arrest warrants against a sitting chief minister is an "unusual step" and it is to be seen what "fallout" this step would have on the political scenario in Pakistan.
body:
Malik noted negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have entered the "final round" and it is expected that a letter of intent would be issued by the night of 19 March. He said an arrangement with the IMF is important for Pakistan to fill the gap in its "balance of payments" as other countries and institutions which gave loans to Pakistan have agreed to extend their support once the country is in an IMF programme. He mentioned Pakistan not only needs the last tranche of the current programme, but also wants to enter into a larger programme for three to four years.

Malik further noted inflation is not likely to decrease because under the IMF's conditions, the interest rate should be kept high, value of the rupee should be flexible, and power and gas tariffs should be increased.

Interview with minister of planning

Malik spoke with Minister of Planning, Development and Special Initiatives Ahsan Iqbal and asked him for how long the economy of Pakistan would remain weak. Iqbal said the current economic situation of the economy is certainly very challenging. He remarked it is not an underdeveloped economy, but an "under-managed or mismanaged economy" that can start a journey towards robust growth and development if its resources are used properly. He noted the main issue with Pakistan is its "political instability" because of which economic policies have been "reversed and disbanded" repeatedly. He emphasised political stability and continuity along with right economic policies could lead to economic progress.

Malik remarked a "civil-military dialogue" is necessary so that the military establishment stops "experiments" of intervention to install people of its choice for managing the economy. Iqbal was of the view that there is a realisation [within the military establishment] that continuity is necessary and the objective of the Special Investment Facilitation Council is to end tension and mistrust and take decisions with everyone's ownership in a "whole of government approach". He said there is need for an "economic National Action Plan" on the same lines as the National Action Plan against terrorism which was devised with a consensus from all.

Iqbal termed the meeting between KP Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif a "very positive development". Talking about Gandapur's arrest warrants, he said it may be a part of the judicial process and hoped that it would not cause any disruption that would increase political confrontation. He commented the people of Pakistan will not support any kind of "negative politics" in the current scenario. He expressed confidence that an agreement with the IMF would be finalised soon.

Arrest warrants against Gandapur

Malik asked KP government's spokesperson Muhammad Ali Saif about his reaction to the arrest warrants against Gandapur. Saif said it is a "routine action" and not a big legal or political issue as issuing bailable or non-bailable warrants during case proceedings is a normal procedure under the criminal procedure code. He claimed the Punjab government "does not want to miss any opportunity to exploit an issue against PTI members", so it would keep highlighting this issue.

Saif said the PTI would like to get the problems of KP resolved through dialogue with a "positive mind" and that is why Gandapur held a meeting with the prime minister. However, he added, it cannot be a one-sided process and the other side should also reciprocate.

Replying to Malik's question on why the KP government is demanding that Imran Khan (PTI founder) should be handed over to it from the Adiala jail in Punjab, Saif said the Punjab government has been saying that there are threats to jails in Punjab, which is a "pretext to disallow people from meeting Khan". He added if Khan is not safe in one of the largest jails of Punjab, Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz should hand him over to the KP government.

Source: Samaa TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1500 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Samaa TV show on political uncertainty, need for new political party
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Nadeem Malik Live" hosted by anchor Nadeem Malik, a senior journalist and analyst, on moderate Samaa News TV in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 11 March 2024. The programme invites politicians and analysts to express their opinions on important issues.

Anchor Nadeem Malik said a case regarding harassment of journalists was heard by the Supreme Court on 11 March and noted Chief Justice Qazi Faez Isa gave "very apt remarks" on the issue. He added Chief Justice Isa, however, did not pass any order for release of the arrested journalist Asad Toor or for arresting the people involved in journalist Matiullah Jan's abduction and shooting at Absar Alam, who were visible in the CCTV footage. He remarked it is unfortunate that the family of slain journalist Arshad Sharif is still awaiting justice.
body:
Malik noted President Asif Ali Zardari and a new federal cabinet have taken oath. He said the present government has taken over at a time when Pakistan is facing serious challenges and continues to be in a state of "economic collapse". He mentioned the rupee has depreciated massively and there seems no chance of any improvement in the situation. He added the country needs financing of around $30bn and will have to seek funding from friendly countries like China, United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Saudi Arabia.

Malik further said the present government is a "minority government" which would be dependent on the support of its coalition partners and would also need backing from the military establishment all the time.

Malik spoke with Shahid Khaqan Abbasi, who was previously associated with the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N), and asked him whether the present government would be able to address the problems of the country. Abbasi said he wishes for the government to meet the challenge but it does not seem likely that it would be able to do so. He noted the people in the new cabinet are the same people who were a part of the previous government and they "do not seem to have the ability to respond to challenges".

Abbasi emphasised the government will have to go for a "broader engagement" politically and talk to all the stakeholders. Replying to a question on whether Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif should contact former prime minister Imran Khan, he said Sharif should politically contact everyone, including Khan. He added Sharif should take everyone into confidence about the challenges faced by the country and seek support on the steps taken by the government to address the challenges. He was of the view that the confidence of investors cannot be restored without ending the current political polarisation.

Abbasi noted questions have been raised on the recent elections and Chief Justice Isa should play a role in resolving these issues. He said the Supreme Court has suo moto powers in matters related to elections and it is a serious issue which should be investigated and settled. Speaking about the issue of reserved seats, he said the Sunni Ittehad Council did not present a list of its candidates for the seats reserved for women and minorities, but these seats cannot be distributed to other political parties.

Malik contacted former finance minister Miftah Ismail and asked him whether he agrees with the view that the new cabinet lacks the competence to address the issues faced by Pakistan. Ismail said he is "glad" that Muhammad Aurangzeb has been made the Minister of Finance and former finance minister Ishaq Dar has not been given the portfolio again. He was of the view that had it been Dar, an agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) would have been very difficult. He remarked Aurangzeb is a "very competent" person.

Ismail noted rest of the cabinet members did not deliver during the previous government, so there is little hope from them that they would perform well now. Speaking about the election results, he alleged Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) candidate Salman Akram Raja had won the election but Awn Chaudhry from the Istehkam-e-Pakistan Party (IPP) was declared the winner. He said he refuses to believe that former prime minister Nawaz Sharif really won the election in Lahore.

Abbasi refused to comment on the issue of election results and insisted that the Supreme Court should look into it.

On Malik's question whether Imran Khan should be released from jail, Ismail said he does not believe that Khan or anyone else should be released because they got votes. However, he added, if the court gives him relief through the process of law, it would be fine. He recalled Khan's government sent many of his political opponents to jail without any reason.

Malik asked Abbasi whether he is planning to form a new political party. Abbasi said he would launch a party because "all three main political parties [PML-N, PTI and Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP)] have failed to respond to the real issues of the country". He was of the view that political parties should focus on national issues instead of levelling allegations on their opponents.

Ismail said he would not join a new party if it approves of dynastic politics and he would want a party which aims to bring improvement to the country and the people.

Source: Samaa TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1500 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's PTV show interviews former minister of energy Khurram Dastgir
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Riasat" (The State), hosted by anchor Shahzad Raza on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 4 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Anchor Shahzad Raza interviewed Khurram Dastgir, a Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician and former minister of energy, who lost the recent national elections.
body:
Raza asked Dastgir why he lost the election even after showing an "excellent performance" as a minister during the previous government. Dastgir said the election did not seem to be tough during the campaign but on the election day, and even after that, several incidents took place against which he has been seeking a "legal recourse".

Responding to Raza's question on why he could not resolve the issues in the power sector as the minister, Dastgir said the previous government made huge progress in power generation by adding 5,000 megawatts to the system. He added the government also improved the power transmission system and new technology was introduced in distribution to stop power theft. He noted the power sector circular debt, which was 2,500bn rupees ($8.9bn) under the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) government, was reduced to 2,300bn rupees ($8.2bn).

Dastgir said consumers assess the performance through electricity bills and the bills had increased after an agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He was of the view that the biggest challenge for the incoming government would be to reduce electricity bills and give relief to the people. He noted during the 16 months of the PML-N-led government, several measures were taken and he is hopeful that the next government would move forward in this regard. He remarked he would be ready to provide "guidance and assistance" to the new government.

Speaking about the government's policy on alternate energy, Dastgir said the government already has a plan to "immediately add 10,000 megawatts of solar energy to the power system".
