He noted solar energy is much cheaper but is "not a solution to all the issues", yet a major relief could be provided to the people in the next two or three years.

Talking about the payment of independent power producers (IPPs), Dastgir said the initial contracts or the capacity payment agreements of many of the IPPs which had started working during the 1990s would expire in the next two or three years, freeing the country of a "major burden". He noted the two big dams which are under construction would be completed by 2026 or 2027 and more hydro power would be available. He expressed hope that in the next five or six years, the situation would be far better and the government might be in a position to provide relief to the people.

Dastgir claimed the issue of electricity theft in several areas is a "governance crisis more than an electricity crisis" and said prime minister-elect Shehbaz Sharif's government will have to work on the issue. He mentioned the previous government which was in power for only 16 months had made a plan for solar cell manufacturing, battery manufacturing and converting petrol-consuming two-wheeler and three-wheeler vehicles to alternate energy, and said the new government could implement the plan immediately.

On the political situation, Dastgir said he does not see the opposition as a "big challenge" because it threatens the government of blocking legislation in the parliament but that is an issue of "temporary management" and "cannot create hurdles in governance". He added the opposition cannot obstruct the government from delivering to the people of Pakistan.

Speaking about Shehbaz Sharif's call for a "charter of reconciliation", Dastgir said the PML-N is always ready for reconciliation with all parties, but there is one "red line" and that is the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged PTI members after the arrest of the then-chairperson Imran Khan). He added the "planners, abettors and executors" of the 9 May attacks will have to face the law in its "strictest sense" because the state cannot tolerate another attack. However, he said, if there are people who have been imprisoned but were not involved in the incidents, they would certainly be released. He argued the issue is that the opposition has declared all its opponents "traitors and infidels". He commented the opposition should "show maturity" in the parliament and Shehbaz Sharif would be ready to shake hands with everyone.

Dastgir said the new government would also face a big "communication challenge" as it would have to tell the nation the truth on how big the challenges are and how it would address them. Noting that "no one listens to press conferences now" and interest in watching TV talk shows is also declining, he suggested communication through mobile phones would be needed to inform the people about the issues, programmes and achievements.

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dawn TV show on political uncertainty, economy
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Khabar Se Khabar" (From News to News), hosted by anchor Nadia Mirza on liberal Dawn News TV in Urdu at 17:00 GMT on 24 March 2024. Mirza discusses important political and foreign policy issues with experts and politicians.

Political instability
body:
Anchor Nadia Mirza remarked the government seems to be unsure about whether it would be able to complete its term. She noted Rana Sanaullah, a senior Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician, recently commented that appointment of Minister of Finance Muhammad Aurangzeb and Minister of Interior Mohsin Naqvi is a "guarantee for the government's survival".

Mirza noted it is for the first time in the history of Pakistan that stability and sustainability of a newly formed government are said to be dependent on the appointment of certain personalities as finance and interior ministers. She asked senior journalist Amir Zia to comment on the situation. Zia said the [Prime Minister] Shehbaz Sharif-led government apparently seems quite strong but not only its opponents, but also the people inside the government keep asking whether it would be able to complete its tenure. He added the present government represents "unity in diversity" but there are "competing interests" at work against each other within it.

Zia criticised a statement by Minister of Foreign Affairs Ishaq Dar that trade relations with India should be restored and commented there are "no takers of peace in India" and the election campaign there is based on an "anti-Pakistan" sentiment. He added Pakistan's "stated stance" is that talks with India are not possible till the latter annuls its steps taken on 5 August 2019 regarding the status of Kashmir.

Zia was of the view that the finance minister should be empowered, but "unfortunately whenever a technocrat is appointed to the position, he does not get political support". He mentioned Aurangzeb has close links with the Sharif family, yet he is "not being fully trusted". He insisted Dar should have nothing to do with the finance ministry, and if Aurangzeb is not allowed to work freely, it would be unfair to Pakistan.

Talking about former prime minister Nawaz Sharif's future in politics, Zia said his politics suffered a "setback" in the 8 February elections and it is to be seen whether his daughter and Punjab Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz would be able to revive the politics launched by him and win the power tussle within the Sharif family. He claimed Maryam Nawaz's actions are being "overly publicised".

Speaking about the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), Zia said the party is facing "very complex problems" but it does not look like the government can take advantage of the issues within the party.

Politics within PTI

Mirza said the PTI is facing internal issues because Imran Khan (PTI founder) is in jail and there are restrictions on the party's activities. She noted on 23 March, PTI politician Sher Afzal Marwat revealed that dissidents in his party have formed a forward group in the Punjab Assembly, but several other party members have denied the reports of division within the PTI.

Mirza contacted Marwat and asked him whether he stands firm on his statement or will he take a U-turn. Marwat commented he never takes a U-turn on his statements. He claimed his statement was based on information shared by several "responsible members" in a party meeting and statement of the opposition leader in the Punjab Assembly. He was of the view that it would be good if PTI politicians in the parliamentary party have control over the members of the assemblies.

Marwat emphasised the PTI should focus on Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and Punjab Assembly during the Senate (upper house of the parliament) elections because many "powerful people" would be contesting as independent candidates. He said the PTI should try to win at least nine Senate seats from KP and two from Punjab.

Economy

Mirza asked economist Shahid Hasan Siddiqui whether the new finance minister would be able to improve Pakistan's economy. Siddiqui said it is for sure that loans would be granted to Pakistan but the economy would further weaken. He added if the same policies continue after the 24th International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme, Pakistan would have to go into a 25th programme as well because there is a "nexus of Pakistani and foreign elite" who want these policies to continue. He was of the view that the United States (US) wants Pakistan to remain in the IMF programme for its political interests and the Pakistani elite want to continue the IMF programme to "please the US" and increase the tax burden on people under the cover of the IMF. He noted the government has not offered any new suggestions since 2001 for expanding the tax net and noted the tax to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio has declined in the last few years.

Source: Dawn News TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1700 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dunya TV show on PTI's politics, relations with other countries
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Dunya Kamran Khan Kay Saath" (World With Kamran Khan), hosted by senior journalist and TV host Kamran Khan on moderate Dunya News TV in Urdu at 16:30 GMT on 6 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

PTI's politics
body:
Anchor Kamran Khan said just like in 2013, the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has once again become the ruling party in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), and an opposition party in the rest of Pakistan. He remarked Imran Khan (former PTI chairperson) has to decide whether his party would continue the politics of resistance. He claimed the PTI has adopted an "aggressive attitude" and its decision to appoint Ali Amin Gandapur as the chief minister of KP indicates that it has "initiated an aggressive political innings".

Khan contacted PTI politician Ali Mohammad Khan and asked him whether the PTI has decided to continue its aggressive politics. Ali Khan said the most important thing is that the mandate given to the party in elections should be accepted. He added Imran Khan does not want the party to remain in an "aggressive or battling position" all the time, but protests will continue till it gets its "right". He mentioned Imran Khan spoke with him about "truth and reconciliation" and said everyone will have to tell the truth. He questioned whether Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif would accept that he lost the election and came into power with a "fake mandate".

Ali Khan said the people of KP voted for the PTI for a third term because it had performed well. He remarked his party does not accept Shehbaz Sharif as the prime minister and that is why Gandapur has been made the chief minister of KP and he did not attend the prime minister's oath-taking ceremony. He mentioned Gandapur will perform his state duties but would continue to protest till the party's "rights" are given to it.

Relations with other countries

Khan spoke with senior political analyst Husain Haqqani and asked him whether he would agree that the world is not concerned about the issues in elections in Pakistan and wants cordial relations with the new government. Haqqani fully agreed with the view and said it has happened nowhere in the world that governments of other countries have refused to recognise a government after an election. He remarked it is a result of "political immaturity and lack of understanding" of international relations that PTI politicians were expecting that upon their expression of reservations about elections, foreign countries would not accept the new government.

Khan asked Haqqani to comment on the congratulatory messages given to Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif after his election. Haqqani said while messages are a formal activity, the swiftness with which these messages were conveyed in the context of a controversial election proves that all countries want Pakistan to be a stable country. He added Pakistan's stability is in the interest of all countries which have given loans to it. Talking about India, he said it is in a position of an "economic take off" and confrontation with Pakistan is an "irritant" for it. Therefore, he added, all countries want to engage with Pakistan and improve relations with it.

Replying to Khan's question on how Pakistan can maintain a balance in its relations with China and the United States (US) simultaneously, Haqqani said at present all countries in the world are in search of a "balanced foreign policy", and the far eastern countries have recently said that they want relations with both China and the US and would not want to get involved in any conflict between the two countries. He insisted Pakistan will also need to adopt this "sagacious attitude" and "detach emotions from foreign policy".

Speaking about the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) programme, Haqqani said Pakistan had to seek loans from the IMF repeatedly because it did not follow the IMF's conditions which were aimed at reforming its economy. He added Pakistan should complete an IMF programme to achieve economic stability. Talking about the need for internal political stability, he insisted "national reconciliation" is necessary and if there is no internal harmony, Pakistan will not be able to have any reconciliation or negotiations with other countries.

Haqqani said restoration of Pakistan's relations with the US at the highest level have begun and noted US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken held meetings with Chief of Army Staff Asim Munir during his visit to Washington. He expressed confidence in US Vice President Kamala Harris contacting Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif in the near future. He claimed under Imran Khan's government, there was an issue that nothing was kept confidential. He remarked in "populism", the leader wants to say everything which can earn an applause from the public but in diplomacy, "many things have to be done quietly".

Replying to Khan's question on whether the US policy towards Pakistan would change if Donald Trump (former US president) or the Republican party comes into office after the November elections, Haqqani said the US foreign policy is based on national interest and not on personalities, so a change in government may not bring any major change in the foreign policy.

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1630 GMT 6 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Geo TV show on differences within political parties, cipher case
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Aaj Shahzeb Khanzada Kay Saath" (Today With Shahzeb Khanzada), hosted by anchor Shahzeb Khanzada on liberal, pro-PML-N Geo News TV in Urdu at 17:00 GMT on 25 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Issues in coalition government
body:
Anchor Shahzeb Khanzada said running a coalition government and putting the economy back on track is a major challenge for the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N). He noted questions have been raised about the powers of the finance minister as well as Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's decisions and his "quick U-turn" on those decisions. He said reportedly differences exist within the PML-N regarding appointment of Muhammad Aurangzeb as the finance minister. He added when Aurangzeb was appointed as the finance minister, instead of giving him the chairmanship of committees linked to important economic matters, the prime minister decided to keep them with himself or other PML-N senior members. He mentioned after criticism of this decision, chairmanship of one committee was given to the finance minister.

Khanzada spoke with journalist Shehbaz Rana and asked him why there are issues in appointing the heads of committees. Rana said in the decision to appoint Aurangzeb as the finance minister, the prime minister had a major role to play, even more than the military establishment. He noted under former finance minister Ishaq Dar, targets of an International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme were not achieved and that is why it was continuously being said that Dar would not be made the finance minister again. However, he added, due to pressure from a camp within the PML-N, Dar was given some role in economic management by giving him positions in some of the committees.

Rana was of the view that Pakistan needs to provide "united support" to the finance minister so that "hard negotiations" with the IMF for a new programme can be held.

Alleged division within PTI

Khanzada said elections for 48 seats of the Senate (upper house of the parliament) would be held on 2 April and the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has claimed that it would win two seats from Punjab. He added the PTI has alleged that its members in Punjab are being pressurised into changing their party loyalty.

Khanzada asked PML-N politician Rana Sanaullah whether his party is trying to influence PTI members in the Punjab Assembly to form a "forward bloc". Sanaullah said the PTI has got "strange kind of people elected to the assemblies" who are destroying the party. He referred to a statement by PTI politician Sher Afzal Marwat, who claimed 40 members of the PTI parliamentary party in the Punjab Assembly have changed their party loyalty, and commented it is not easy to influence 40 members to change their political affiliation and no one is trying to win over their loyalties.

Sanaullah said Aurangzeb's appointment as the finance minister was a decision by the prime minister and noted that it has helped the government successfully complete talks with the IMF for the last tranche of the standby programme. He remarked since this is a coalition government, the PML-N has to accept certain "compromises". He commented the PML-N is not desperate to remain in power, but is "desperate to make this government successful". He mentioned he was not in favour of the PML-N forming a government in the centre but the party took the final decision of making its government. He added Shehbaz Sharif has accommodated demands of all the parties in the coalition.

Scandal surrounding new federal minister

Khanzada reported on a recent scandal regarding "misuse of political authority", involving newly appointed federal minister Ahad Cheema and Punjab Governor Baligh ur Rehman, due to which principal of the prestigious Aitchison College of Lahore had to resign. He said Cheema and Rehman changed a policy of the college to benefit the former's children. He spoke with Cheema and sought an explanation from him. Cheema claimed the policy was changed by Rehman for the benefit of all the students, and not just his children.

Cipher case

Khanzada reported on a hearing of former prime minister Imran Khan and former foreign affairs minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi's appeal in the Islamabad High Court against their conviction in the cipher case. He cited remarks of the judges and arguments of the counsels. He mentioned the hearing has been adjourned till 26 March.

Source: Geo News, Karachi, in Urdu 1700 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dawn TV show on issues surrounding ex-PM Khan's party
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Khabar Se Khabar" (From News to News), hosted by anchor Nadia Mirza on liberal Dawn News TV in Urdu at 17:00 GMT on 17 March 2024. Mirza discusses important political and foreign policy issues with experts and politicians.

Anchor Nadia Mirza remarked after a period of "instability" for 16 months, it was being hoped that political and economic stability would return after elections, but all those hopes have been "dashed to the ground" because the recent polls were "the most controversial elections in the history of Pakistan". She noted protests were started on streets and also inside the parliament after elections. She said the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has claimed that it will not let the parliament and government function, raising concerns over how talks would be held with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and how economic challenges would be handled.
body:
Mirza further noted for the first time in the history of Pakistan, the Senate (upper house of the parliament) has been "practically inactive" as its elections are to be held on 9 or 11 April.

Mirza contacted Imran Ismail, former governor of Sindh and an estranged member of the PTI, and asked him about his activities after leaving the party and quitting politics. Ismail said leaving politics was difficult as he had been affiliated with Imran Khan (PTI founder) since 1993. He added after leaving politics, he has been focusing on his business and family.

Responding to a question on whether he would go back to the PTI, Ismail said political conditions are very difficult for the party at the moment and several of its members are in jail. He added he does not know who is managing the party right now, so he will think about it later, but he is currently not planning on returning to politics.

Ismail said he believes the PTI is a good political party and not a "terrorist party". He added it is a party which stands with the military and other institutions like the judiciary. He claimed no government in Pakistan can work "without the support of institutions", and as long as the PTI was in power, it enjoyed full support from the Army and other institutions of the military. He remarked it is very encouraging for a government to "remain on the same page as the military".

Ismail mentioned after a vote of no-confidence against the PTI government in the centre, he resigned from the governorship of Sindh because he felt he could not get along with the new government. He was of the view that former president Arif Alvi should also have resigned if he was "unable to work freely".

Ismail strongly condemned an alleged negative social media campaign against military personnel martyred a few days back and called the people involved in it "criminals of the nation". He said he decided to leave the PTI after the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged PTI members after the arrest of Imran Khan).

Mirza asked senior journalist Muhammad Malick about politicians in the PTI feeling that the party has been "hijacked by lawyers". Malick said Khan gave party tickets to a large number of lawyers before elections, thinking that lawyers would not be disqualified and the courts would also be lenient towards them. He noted the PTI stands divided into four to five factions at the moment as there is a "communication gap" between the party and Khan since he is in jail.

Malick was of the view that the issue of reserved seats is not important because the PTI will not be able to form its government even if it gets those seats in the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament). He remarked the issue is between two individuals: Imran Khan and Chief of Army Staff Asim Munir. He added if these two individuals "take two steps back and reach big decisions", things would become better for the PTI. He predicted some relief would gradually be given to the PTI, but not to Khan.

Talking about Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur's meeting with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, Malick said it should not be seen as "defiance" to Khan. He added the two would continue to meet in future as well because they are constitutional office holders.

Source: Dawn News TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1700 GMT 17 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Samaa TV show on presidential election, protests by PTI
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Mere Sawal" (My Questions), hosted by anchor Muneeb Farooq on moderate Samaa News TV in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 10 March 2024. The programme invites politicians and analysts to express their opinions on important issues.

Anchor Muneeb Farooq announced former president Asif Ali Zardari got re-elected and took oath as the 14th President of Pakistan. He noted meanwhile, the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has given a call for a countrywide protest against what it claims to be a "theft" of its mandate. He said Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur (PTI member) led the protest in Peshawar and the police launched a crackdown on protesters and several PTI members were arrested. He questioned whether the crackdown was initiated because the protests were against the law.
body:
Farooq spoke with Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Azma Bokhari and asked her why the government arrested PTI protesters. Bokhari said people did not come out in support of the PTI and there were hardly 25 people in the protest. She claimed no one was arrested and argued no government could allow blocking of roads and causing inconvenience to the public.

PTI politician Nadeem Qureshi claimed on 8 February (polling day), the entire nation rejected the parties which have formed the government. He said the government took action because it was "scared" of the protesters. He alleged several people were arrested during the protest and questioned why the government deployed a large police force if people did not come out to join the PTI's protest.

Farooq said many things have changed in Pakistani politics and a lot is still changing. He asked journalist Mujibur Rahman Shami whether Zardari's election and presidency with full support from the PML-N indicate that "things have been stitched up so well that [Prime Minister] Shehbaz Sharif's government will survive for a full five-year term". Shami said at the moment it seems that the government will remain intact but nothing can be said with certainty about Pakistani politics in which "any government can derail any time". He added Sharif and Zardari are both "champions of reconciliation" and "signs" indicate that the arrangement would be sustainable.

Senior journalist Muhammad Malick claimed it is true that the election was "stolen" and if that had not happened, a leader of another party would have been there in the prime minister's house. He said the PML-N government is dependent on support from the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) and noted the latter is in the "most comfortable position". He was of the view that the PPP decided to not join the cabinet because it knew the government would have to take very tough actions, particularly after an agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). He remarked the first year of the government would be "very crucial".

On Farooq's question whether Imran Khan (former PTI chairperson) could get some relief in the coming months, Malick said no relief is likely to be given immediately as "the [military] establishment has formed the government" and Khan is out of power except for in one province [KP]. He added Khan is not in a position to "publicly soften his stance" because that would damage his support base.

Farooq asked Shami to comment on the PTI's protest which was not joined by many people but several PTI members were still arrested in Punjab. Shami said political governments cannot afford a "policy of arrests and victimisation" and those who had adopted such a policy in the past eventually lost power. He insisted Punjab Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz should not follow former caretaker chief minister Mohsin Naqvi's policy because the latter was a caretaker and was not going to contest elections, but the former is a "political representative of the people".

Source: Samaa TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1500 GMT 10 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Dunya TV show on politics, foreign policy challenges, talks with IMF
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Dunya Kamran Khan Kay Saath" (World With Kamran Khan), hosted by senior journalist and TV host Kamran Khan on moderate Dunya News TV in Urdu at 16:30 GMT on 13 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Easing political tensions
body:
Anchor Kamran Khan said Pakistani politics has witnessed a "very pleasing scene" after many years which indicates a "significant decrease" in the country's "political temperature". He noted Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif held a "pleasant meeting" on 13 March. He mentioned after the meeting, Gandapur expressed the resolve to play a positive role in the interest of the country and the two leaders agreed to work together to solve the issues of the country.

Khan spoke with senior journalist Iftikhar Firdous and asked him to comment on the unexpected development. Firdous said this was "unprecedented" and noted ever since Gandapur took oath, tension had prevailed between KP and the centre. He noted the meeting was held at the request of the KP government.

Firdous said the "inside story" is that a meeting of the Special Investment Facilitation Council has been called on 14 March in which chief ministers of all the four provinces would be present. He remarked it was necessary to settle certain issues of KP with the federal government, particularly those about the economic stability of the province and the security situation. He added there are dues which the federal government has to pay to the province for security and repayment of loans. He noted if the funds are released, it would be the second government after 2008 which would pay arrears to the province. He agreed with Khan that Imran Khan (former chairperson of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, PTI) was "in loop" about the meeting.

Foreign policy challenges

Khan said Ishaq Dar from the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) has been appointed as the foreign minister in the new government. He mentioned Dar has no experience in foreign ministry and his appointment is being termed "interesting" by serving and retired diplomats. He noted Dar has been appointed as the foreign minister at a time when Pakistan is facing serious challenges on the foreign policy front and the most important issue is maintaining a balance in its relations with the United States (US) and China.

Khan asked former diplomat Maleeha Lodhi what is the most serious challenge for Pakistan on the foreign policy front. Lodhi replied foreign policy begins at home, so the biggest challenge for Pakistan is its economy as foreign policy cannot be very effective unless the economy improves. She said foreign policy challenges include relations with China, Afghanistan, the US and India, but China is the "strategic priority" for Pakistan. Noting that Pakistan has entered the second phase of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (mega development project), she said it is important to keep it on a positive trajectory.

Lodhi was of the view that it could be a "declaratory policy" that Pakistan wants to maintain balance between relations with China and the US, but "China is its priority, not the US". She emphasised the country needs to reset its relations with the US but it needs to wait to do so because it is election season there.

Talking about US President Joe Biden's policy towards Pakistan, Lodhi said it seems Biden has a "blind spot" for Pakistan as he has never shown any interest in the country throughout his tenure. She noted Donald Trump (former US president) can be re-elected as the president, so Pakistan should be prepared for it.

Commenting on relations with India, Lodhi said if Pakistan wants a working relationship with India, there should be "reciprocity" from India as well. She noted it would be a challenge for Pakistan that India has "completely removed the Kashmir issue from the agenda of bilateral talks".

Speaking about Dar as the foreign minister, Lodhi said it should be kept in mind that there is continuity in Pakistan's foreign policy and no matter which government comes to power, there is "no departure" in the foreign policy. She added Dar brings a lot of experience even though his experience is in finance and he has a lot of "international exposure" as well. She mentioned the foreign ministry, as a highly professional institution, would provide support to him. She claimed Dar enjoys the confidence of the top leadership of the party and "people take such a foreign minister much more seriously".

Talks with IMF

Khan said Pakistan needs excellent relations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) as the government wants a new "larger and longer-term" IMF programme of at least $7bn. He noted an IMF delegation has arrived in Islamabad (Pakistan's capital) and will begin talks regarding the final tranche of $1.1bn under the current agreement. He mentioned it would be the first test of Minister of Finance Muhammad Aurangzeb.

Khan spoke with Uzair Younus, an expert on economic affairs, and asked him whether Pakistan's plan to acquire a new extended IMF programme is achievable. Younus replied it is very much achievable and noted the new finance minister had "clarity in communication" when he said Pakistan needs to negotiate for a new longer and larger programme.

Younus said a "blueprint of the contours of the programme" already exists, so the focus of negotiations should be on its implementation. He commented if the finance minister comes to Washington (US capital) with an implementation plan, it would not be difficult to negotiate a longer programme. He expressed hope that there would be economic stability in the country in the coming months.

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1630 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Russia says it killed 234 fighters while thwarting an incursion from Ukraine
snippet:
Ukrainian long-range drones smashed into two oil facilities deep inside Russia on Tuesday, officials said, while an armed incursion claimed by Ukraine-based Russian opponents of the Kremlin unnerved a border region just days before Russias presidential election.

The attack by waves of drones across eight regions of Russia displayed Kyivs expanding technological capacity as the war extends into its third year. The cross-border ground assault also weakened President Vladimir Putins argument that life in Russia has been unaffected by the war, though he remains all but certain to win another six-year term after eliminating all opposition.
body:
The Russian Defense Ministry said that Moscows military and security forces killed 234 fighters while thwarting the incursion. In a statement, the ministry blamed the attack on the Kyiv regime and Ukraines terrorist formations, insisting that the Russian military and border forces were able to stop the attackers and avert a cross-border raid. It also said the attackers lost seven tanks and five armored vehicles.

The reports of border fighting earlier on Tuesday were murky, and it was impossible to ascertain with any certainty what was unfolding in Russias Kursk and Belgorod regions. Cross-border attacks in the area have occurred sporadically since the war began and have been the subject of claims and counterclaims, as well as disinformation and propaganda.

Soldiers who Kyiv officials say are Russian volunteers fighting for Ukraine claimed to have crossed the border. The Freedom of Russia Legion, the Russian Volunteer Corps and the Siberian Battalion released statements and videos on social media claiming to show them on Russian territory. They said they wanted a Russia liberated from Putins dictatorship.

The authenticity of the videos couldnt be independently verified.

Fighters coming out of Ukraine attempted to reach the town of Tetkino, which lies close to the border, according to the governor of Russias Kursk region, Roman Starovoit. He said Tetkino was being shelled.

There was an attempt by a sabotage and reconnaissance group to break through. There was a shooting battle, but there was no breakthrough, he said in a video message on Telegram.

The Russian Defense Ministry said the Tetkino attacks were driven back, but provided no further details.

It also said Ukrainian fighters made at least four attempts to cross into the Belgorod region but all attacks were repelled by warplanes, artillery and missiles.

The representative of Ukraines intelligence agency, Andrii Yusov, told Ukrainska Pravda that the military groups are made up of Russian citizens.

On the territory of the Russian Federation, they operate completely autonomously and independently, he said.

In May, Russia alleged that dozens of Ukrainian militants crossed into one of its border towns in the Belgorod region, striking targets and forcing an evacuation, before more than 70 of the attackers were killed or pushed back by what the authorities termed a counterterrorism operation. Ukrainian officials have denied any link with the group.

Meanwhile, one Ukrainian drone struck and set ablaze an oil refinery in the Nizhny Novgorod region, according to regional governor Gleb Nikitin. That region is located some about 775 kilometers (480 miles) from the Ukraine border.

In another deep strike, a drone was shot down in the Moscow region, Moscow mayor Sergei Sobyanin said. Though it was brought down well south of the city center, the drone was close to Zhukovsky Airport, one of Mocows four international airports.

Another drone hit an oil depot in Oryol, 116 kilometers (95 miles) from Ukraine.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said last year that his country had developed a weapon that hit a target 700 kilometers (400 miles) away, in an apparent reference to drones.

The Russian Defense Ministry said Ukrainian drones were also intercepted Tuesday over the Belgorod, Bryansk, Kursk, Leningrad and Tula regions of Russia.

Kyiv has staged increasingly bold attacks behind the 1,500-kilometer (930-mile) front line running through eastern and southern Ukraine. It has also increasingly deployed sea drones in the Black Sea, where it claims to have sunk Russian warships.

Kyivs forces are hoping for more military supplies from Ukraines Western partners, but in the meantime are struggling against a bigger and better-provisioned Russian army that is pressing hard at certain front-line points inside Ukraine.

Zelenskyy said that recent Russian advances have been halted and that the battlefield situation is now significantly better than in the past three months.

We had some difficulties due to the lack of artillery shells, long-range weapons, sky blocking and the high density of Russian drones, Zelenskyy said in an interview with Frances BFM TV and Le Monde published late Monday on the Ukrainian presidential website.

Also on Tuesday, an Il-76 heavy-lift transport plane of the Russian air force with 15 people on board crashed while taking off from an air base in the Ivanovo region in western Russia, the Defense Ministry said. Its statement didn't specify whether there were any survivors. The ministry said that an engine fire during takeoff was the likely cause of the crash.

In Ukraine, three people were killed and 44 more were wounded on Tuesday evening as the result of a Russian missile strike on the city of Kryvyi Rih, Zelenskyy's hometown, Ukrainian officials said. Serhii Lysak, governor of the Dnipropetrovsk region where the city if located, said two residential buildings were damaged.

___

Follow APs coverage of the war in Ukraine at https://apnews.com/hub/russia-ukraine

title: Ukrainian attacks increasingly sap the power of Russia's Black Sea fleet
snippet:
Ukrainian sea drones reportedly sank another Russian warship in the Black Sea on Tuesday, the latest in a series of strikes that has crippled Moscows naval capability and limited its operations with the war now in its third year.

Successful Ukrainian drone and missile strikes have provided a major morale boost for Kyiv at a time when its undermanned and under-gunned forces are facing Russian attacks along the more than 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line.
body:
Challenging Russias naval superiority also has helped create more favorable conditions for Ukrainian grain exports and other shipments from the countrys Black Sea ports.

Here's a look at recent Ukrainian attacks against Russian naval assets and their consequences.

RELENTLESS STRIKES

In the latest reported strike, Ukrainian naval drones attacked the Sergei Kotov patrol ship near the Kerch Strait, which links the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov, according to the Ukraine's military intelligence agency. The strike, which couldn't be independently verified, killed seven members of the Russian crew and injured six others, while 52 were rescued, the agency said.

The Russian Defense Ministry didnt comment on the claim, but some Russian military bloggers confirmed the ship's loss and said its crew had been rescued.

The strike, if verified, would mark the latest successful use of Ukraine's domestically produced Magura drones, the agile uncrewed boats that have become the Russian navy's nemesis. Just last month, drones sank Russia's Caesar Kunikov amphibious landing ship and Ivanovets missile corvette. The Russian military hasnt acknowledged those losses, either, but they have been reported by Russian military bloggers and some media.

In another attack in late December, Ukraine said it destroyed the Novocherkassk landing vessel in Crimeas port of Feodosia with long-range cruise missiles. The Russian Defense Ministry said the ship was damaged in the attack, but Russian war bloggers said it was lost.

The Ukrainian military also has launched a series of persistent cruise missile and drone strikes on Russian radar facilities, air defense assets and air bases in Crimea, a region of Ukraine that Russia annexed in 2014. Increasing the pain for Moscow, Ukrainian troops also downed two Russian early warning and control aircraft over the Sea of Azov in January and February, depriving the Russian military of some of its most precious intelligence-gathering assets.

The strikes followed other highly efficient Ukrainian attacks earlier in the war, including the April 2022 sinking of the Black Sea fleets flagship missile cruiser, the Moskva, and a missile strike last September on the fleets headquarters in the port of Sevastopol.

UKRAINE'S DEADLY WEAPONS

The smart use of remote-controlled drone boats laden with explosives has allowed Ukraine to tip the scales of naval warfare in its favor despite Russia's massive superiority in firepower. The Magura drones are equipped with advanced GPS and cameras, and have a low radar signature that makes them hard to detect.

Its latest version, the Magura V5, is 5.5 meters (18 feet) long, weighs up to 1,000 kilograms (2,200 pounds) and has a range of up to 800 kilometers (500 miles), 60 hours of battery life, and a 200-kilogram (440-pound) payload, according to Ukrainian authorities. It also beams live video to operators.

Ukraine also has relied on cruise missiles provided by the U.K. and France for striking Russian assets in Crimea. The missiles  produced jointly by Britain and France and called Storm Shadow by the U.K. and SCALP-EG by France  are launched from Ukraine's Soviet-era warplanes and have a range of more than 250 kilometers (155 miles).

Western officials praise the efficiency of the Ukrainian attacks, noting that Kyiv has smartly used its limited resources to defeat far stronger Russian forces and destroy about 20% of the Black Sea fleet, effectively blunting Moscows naval dominance.

ENDING THE RUSSIAN BLOCKADE

The successful strikes on Russian naval assets have allowed Ukraine to increase its food and other Black Sea exports despite Russias withdrawal last summer from a deal that guaranteed safe shipment of Ukrainian grain.

Moscows pullback from the deal raised the possibility of Russian attacks on ships carrying Ukrainian grain and other products, posing a threat to the Ukrainian economy and global food security.

But the steady series of successful Ukrainian attacks on Russian warships and other military assets in the area have put Russia's fleet on the defensive, limiting its offensive capability.

HOW DID RUSSIA REACT?

Although the Russian Defense Ministry has mostly kept quiet about the Ukrainian drone and missile attacks on its naval assets, Russian military bloggers and commentators have harshly criticized the military brass for its slow and sloppy response to the threat.

The strikes have forced the Russian navy to take precautions that have affected its operations, including relocating some of its ships from ports in Crimea farther east to Novorossiysk to better protect them.

Despite the damage from Ukrainian attacks, the Black Sea fleet remains a powerful force and is still capable of launching long-range cruise missile strikes at Ukraine. Russian air bases in Crimea also have remained operational, hosting warplanes that have continued flying combat sorties to support its ground operations in the region.

Russian military bloggers reported that the head of the Black Sea fleet, Adm. Viktor Sokolov, was dismissed last month following the latest losses of warships. There was no official confirmation of his ouster.

___

Find more AP coverage at https://apnews.com/hub/russia-ukraine

title: Russia claims killing 234 people in attempted border incursion
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Ministry of Defence says Russian troops and border guards on 12 March killed 234 men as they stopped an incursion into Russia from Ukrainian territory.
body:
In a statement on Telegram, the MoD said Ukrainian "terrorist formations attempted" at about 03:00 (00:00 GMT) an incursion into Russia in three areas - from Odnorobivka in Ukraine's Kharkiv Region and near the border villlages of Nekhoteyevka and Spodaryushino in Russia's Belgorod Region.

According to the Russian Ministry of Defence, the attackers failed to cross the Russian border.

It said the the attempted incursion followed "intensive fire" directed at civilian facilities and was supported by tanks and armoured vehicles.

It said Russia used operational-tactical and army aviation, Lancet drones, and artillery. "All attacks by the Ukrainian terrorist formations were repelled", with "60 Ukrainian terrorists destroyed" near Odnorobivka alone, with another 45 killed across the border from Nekhoteyevka and 100 killed across the border from Spodaryushino.

The attacking forces had a total of 234 "militants" killed and lost seven tanks, three Bradley vehicles and two armoured personnel carriers.

The Defence Ministry said a further four attempted attacks by "Ukrainian saboteur and reconnaissance groups" were stopped between 08:00 and 08:25 near Tetkino, Kursk region.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1653 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Russia says another border incursion repelled
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian Defence Ministry has said that it has repelled Ukrainian forces in their attempt to penetrate Belgorod Region near Russia's border village of Kozinka on 14 March.
body:
In a Telegram post the day later after the incursion, the ministry said two Ukrainian helicopters landed about 30 soldiers 1 km from the Russian border and entered Kozinka. They were forced to retreat after artillery and air strikes, the report said. The attackers then ran into a minefield previously planted by the Russian forces, the report said.

The report said more Ukrainian troops were killed by a Tornado rocket launcher during an attempt to evacuate their injured and dead, bringing the total number of Ukrainian fatalities to 50 that day.

The Defence Ministry claimed that in the course of the three days of border attacks, the Russian forces killed over 1,500 Ukrainian soldiers, destroyed 18 tanks and 23 armoured vehicles.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0441 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Russia decorates soldiers for capturing Moscow concert hall attack suspects
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian Defence Ministry has presented state awards to military servicemen involved in the detention of the four gunmen accused of the 22 March attack on a concert venue on the outskirts of Moscow on 22 March, in which at least 137 people were killed.
body:
The ministry said in a 25 March post on Telegram that the Deputy Commander of the Leningrad Military District, Lieutenant-General Esedulla Abachev, had given the awards to the servicemen for "distinguishing themselves during the detention of terrorists who participated in the attack on the Crocus City Hall".

A 58-second video included in the post, showed Lt Gen Abachev handing the awards to the servicemen clad in fatigues inside a military facility, which the post said was the premises were their military unit was based.

The servicemen, who "completed the combat task of blocking the terrorists in the territory of Bryansk Region" that borders Ukraine, were awarded the medal For Courage and the medal of the Russian Ministry of Defence For Military Distinction, the post said.

Earlier, in a post on 24 March, the head of the Chechen Republic, Ramzan Kadyrov, announced on his Telegram channel that 12 medals For Courage and 20 other state awards had also been presented to members of the Akhmat Rossiya regiment of the Russian Defence Ministry, deployed to protect the Russian border in Bryanks Region.

On 24 March, a court in Moscow ordered that the four men accused of involvement in the Moscow concert hall attack be remanded in custody until 22 May.

The four, who were charged with committing an act of terrorism, have been identified as citizens of Tajikistan, the Interfax news agency has reported.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0436 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: Russian MoD claims capture of village in Ukraine's Donbas area
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russian troops have seized Nevelske, a village just west of the occupied Ukrainian city of Donetsk, according to Russia's Defence Ministry.
body:
"In the Donetsk sector, units of the South grouping of forces through active operations liberated the settlement of Nevelske (DPR) and took up more advantageous positions," Interfax quoted the Defence Ministry saying on 12 March.

DPR stands for the so-called Donetsk People's Republic, part of the Russian occupied territory in Ukraine.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1108 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Two killed, four injured in Russia's border region shelling - governor
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The governor of Russia's Belgorod Region bordering Ukraine, Vyacheslav Gladkov, has said two people have been killed and four injured in a Ukrainian missile attack on the Belgorod district.
body:
"As a result of a direct hit at a private residential building, two people have died: a young man of 17 years old and a man - they died from their wounds on the spot even before the ambulance arrived," Gladkov wrote on his Telegram channel on 18 March.

Earlier that day, Russia's Defence Ministry reported that its air defences had "destroyed" ten missiles over Belgorod Region.

"Around 08.30 Moscow time [05:30 GMT], an attempt by the Kyiv regime to carry out a terrorist attack on targets on the territory of the Russian Federation using the RM-70 Vampire multiple launch rocket system was foiled," the ministry said on its Telegram channel.

"On-duty air defence systems destroyed ten rockets in the air over the Belgorod region," the ministry said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0915 gmt 18 Mar 24

title: Fire, drone attacks reported at power plant in Russia's Rostov Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A fire has been reported at a thermal power plant in the city of Novocherkassk in Rostov Region, known as one of the largest facilities of its type in Russia's south.
body:
According to eyewitnesses cited by the breaking news Baza Telegram channel, two power units of the Novocherkassk State District Power Plant was put out of order as a result of drone attacks.

"According to preliminary reports, several drones took part in the attack on the power plant. Presumably, the first of them attempted to attack at 2:30 am," Baza said early on 25 March.

Governor of Rostov Region Vasily Golubev has confirmed the incident on his Telegram channel.

"Tonight, a fire occurred at the transformer substation of the Novocherkassk State District Power Plant, which was promptly extinguished by the station workers. There were no casualties. The causes of the fire are being established," he said.

The anonymous VChK-OGPU channel posted an eyewitness video clip purporting to show what it described as the "UAV strike" against the Novocherkassk thermal power plant.

Meanwhile, Russia's Defence Ministry has reported that its air defences repelled 11 Ukrainian unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) over Rostov Region.

"On the night of 25 March, an attempt by the Kyiv regime to carry out a terrorist attack using fixed-wing UAVs against targets on the territory of the Russian Federation was foiled," the ministry said on its Telegram channel.

"Eleven Ukrainian unmanned aerial vehicles were intercepted by on-duty air defence systems over the territory of Rostov Region," the report added.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0234 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: Russia gives numbers of 'mercenaries destroyed' in Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Defence Ministry says Russian forces have killed nearly 6,000 foreign "mercenaries" in Ukraine.
body:
According to a report by the Defence Ministry's Zvezda TV, of the 5,962 "foreign mercenaries destroyed" in Ukraine since the start of Russia's full-scale invasion in February 2022, 1,497 were from Poland, 561 from Georgia, 491 from the US, 422 from Canada, 360 from the UK, 349 from Romania, 147 from France and 88 from Germany.

The report also said a total of 13,387 mercenaries had travelled to Ukraine from the above-mentioned countries (Poland 2,960, USA 1,113, Georgia 1,042, Canada 1,005, UK 822, Romania 784, France 356, Germany 235).

The report did not say how the Russian Defence Ministry obtained these figures.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1147 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Russia: Oil refinery on fire, one killed after drone attacks
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Air defences intercepted and destroyed 12 Ukrainian fixed-wing UAVs overnight, the Russian Defence Ministry said on Telegram on 23 March.
body:
It described the incidents as "attempts by the Kyiv regime to commit terrorist attacks at facilities on Russian territory".

Five drones each were shot down in Bryansk and Belgorod regions, and one each in Voronezh and Saratov regions, the ministry stated.

Air defences also shot down 11 projectiles launched by a Vampir MRLS above Belgorod Region at around 04:00 GMT, the Defence Ministry said in a statement cited by the Interfax news agency.

One person was killed in Belgorod Region's Chernyanka District, governor Vyacheslav Gladkov wrote on Telegram. The city of Belgorod and Stary Oskol District were also hit, he added.

The OEMK electrometallurgical works in Belgorod Region's city of Stary Oskol was subjected to a drone attack, the enterpsise said on VK. No-one was injured, no equipment was damaged, and the enterprise continues to work normally, the post said.

The Kuybyshevsky oil refinery near the city of Novokuybyshevsk in Samara Region had its fractionator on fire in a drone attack, governor Dmitry Azarov stated.

The fire at the Kuybyshevsky refinery was put out at 06:05 GMT, the Interfax news agency cited the regional administration's press service as saying.

No damage was reported from the drone attacks in Bryansk and Saratov regions.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0414 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: Russia claims 195 Ukrainian soldiers killed in attempted border raid
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian Defence Ministry says its troops killed "up to 195 Ukrainian military servicemen" as they stopped another incursion into Russia's Belgorod Region from Ukrainian territory on 14 March.
body:
Russian warplanes and artillery troops also destroyed five tanks, four armoured combat vehicles, three UR-77 self-propelled mine clearance rocket launchers and three engineering clearance vehicles, state news agency TASS quoted the ministry as saying.

On the same day the ministry posted two videos on its Telegram channel purportedly showing the destruction of "VSU" (Armed Forces of Ukraine) vehicles and soldiers.

The governor of Belgorod Region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, said that Russian air defence forces had shot down 10 "aerial targets" approaching the city of Belgorod and Belgorodsky District.

According to Gladkov, a civilian was killed when the car she was driving was blown up during the attacks, while three other people were injured. Several apartments in eight residential buildings, three private residential households and three commercial buildings were damaged in the city of Belgorod, he said.

In Belgorodsky District, three children were slightly injured and several private houses were damaged, the governor said.

Later, Gladkov said that the town of Grayvoron and the Grayvoronsky urban district had come under attack again. Four people were injured in the town and another man was injured in the village of Kozinka, he said.

Shortly afterwards Gladkov posted a video on his Telegram channel in which he said that, in total, two people had been killed and several others had been injured as a result of the attacks on the city of Belgorod and the Grayvoronsky urban district on 14 March.

Meanwhile, independent Mozhem Obyasnit (We can explain) outlet published an interview with a man named as Alexander "Fortuna", the chief of staff of the Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK), a group reportedly affiliated with the Ukrainian military, in which he claimed that RDK fighters had advanced "several tens of kilometres" into Russian territory in some areas and had taken prisoners. He also denied that RDK had suffered any losses in Belgorod Region.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1232 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Russia scrambles jet to intercept UK planes over Black Sea
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Defence Ministry has said its forces scrambled an Su-30 fighter jet to intercept three United Kingdom Royal Air Force aircraft over the Black Sea on 6 March.
body:
In a message on its Telegram channel that day, the Defence Ministry said the Russian fighter identified the planes as an RC-135 ELINT plane and two Typhoon fighter jets, which turned away from the Russian border when intercepted.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1559 gmt 6 Mar 24

title: BBCM Armenia Watchlist 13 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Armenian broadcast, press and social media sources

Armenia corrects dates for Iranian president's visit
body:
The official visit by Iranian President Massoud Pezeshkian to Armenia will take place on 18-19 August, not 18-21 August as reported earlier, Armenpress state-owned news agency reports, quoting the office of the Armenian prime minister.

Pro-Moscow group calls for rally against anti-Russian protest

The Mother Armenia movement has called for a public gathering in response to a protest planned against the Russian 102nd military base stationed in Gyumri.

The call comes after the pro-Western For the Republic party announced plans to stage a protest outside the base on 23 August to call for the closure of the base and for Armenia's withdrawal from the Moscow-led Collective Security Treaty Organisation (CSTO).

In June, Yerevan had said that it had no plans to shut down the base and that under the current agreement, the lease runs until 2044.

Mother Armenia said in a statement that the pre-announced anti-Russia protest is being organised by "pro-Western forces that are pursuing anti-Armenian interests".

The movement condemned "provocative actions" aimed at undermining the presence of the Russian military in Armenia and described the base as a key component of national security.

The statement further warned that "following the fall of [breakaway] Karabakh, rising tensions in Syunik, and the de facto establishment of the Zangazur corridor [aka Trump Route - a prospective route via southern Armenia], efforts are now being directed at removing the Russian base, a step that would pave the way for Armenia's complete capitulation to Turkey and Azerbaijan".

The statement also called on the Gyumri mayor and law enforcers to prevent the anti-Russian protest, arguing that it serves the interests of Armenia's adversaries.

Washington deals draw criticism from opposition

Armenia's parliamentary opposition has described the declaration signed by the Armenian and Azerbaijani leaders in Washington on 8 August as a "new existential threat" and an act of "capitulation" for Armenia, Azaturtyun.am, the Armenian service of Radio Liberty, has said.

The Armenia faction said the peace deal with Azerbaijan, initialled in the States, legitimised Azerbaijan's "ethnic cleansing" in Karabakh, would erase the issue from the international agenda and lead the way for further Azerbaijani "aggression" through an "unimpeded corridor" - the so-called Trump Route, aka Zangazur corridor - through Armenia.

"No one can point to what exactly the Armenian interest is in this document - aside from the word 'peace' written on the paper, is there anything truly positive for Armenia?" said Artsvik Minasyan, secretary of the opposition Armenia faction in an interview with Azatutyun.

Non-parliamentary opposition figure Edmon Marukyan raised concern over the lack of a clearly defined map in the agreement, arguing that this leaves Armenia vulnerable to possible future Azerbaijani territorial claims, the report said.

Political analyst Stepan Danielyan warned that Armenia's agreement to allow Azerbaijani checkpoints in Armenia's southern Syunik Region without any Armenian control undermines Armenia's sovereignty. He also raised concern about the possible involvement of foreign private security forces.

Danielyan linked the timing of the Washington deal to the upcoming USA-Russia summit, suggesting it was used to strengthen the US position during the talks with Russia.

He also pointed to broader geopolitical risks, noting rising influence from the UK, Turkey and Israel in Azerbaijan, and warned the deal could further entrench great power competition in the region.

Former Armenian Foreign Minister Vartan Oskanian (Vardan Oskanyan) harshly criticised the "government's concessions" over the so-called Zangazur corridor, accusing the authorities of presenting a "strategic defeat" as a "strategic victory".

Oskanian said that handing over a strip of land stretching from east to west under conditions allowing unimpeded Azerbaijani access for 99 years without customs checks, border control or the right to inspect what passes through constitutes a loss of national sovereignty.

"No political manoeuvre can change this reality. You are leasing part of your sovereignty for at least two generations. This is not diplomacy; it is the sale of national dignity," he said, describing the proposed route as a "corridor of dependence and humiliation".

The website of the pro-opposition Hraparak daily says that following the Washington declaration a harsh Russian reaction was expected, with many predicting that Moscow would not forgive Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan for "ditching" it and abandoning the Russian-mediated 9 November 2020 deal. The daily, however, says that sources close to the Russian authorities say Moscow is largely indifferent to developments in and around Armenia.

According to the daily, various Russian government circles have conveyed to Armenian counterparts that no steps will be taken if the Armenian public considers the latest developments acceptable. The daily says that even Iran has sought clarity on Russia's stance to coordinate its own actions but received the same response.

Sources cited by the daily say the main reason for this attitude is that Russia is waiting to see what kind of resolution there will be on the Ukrainian front. Moscow believes that the Washington agreement has so many pitfalls that its implementation is simply unrealistic. But through internal channels, they have also made it clear to the Armenian authorities that regarding the unblocking of regional roads, they are in favour of implementing the trilateral agreements negotiated with their participation.

The daily concludes that Moscow has decided to closely observe how far Armenia's leadership will go, questioning how a government that spent four years negotiating with Russia and had a 30-year partnership could suddenly pivot to the USA. The daily says that once they understand it, they will plan their actions accordingly.

Separately, Hraparak says, citing its sources, that before signing the Washington deals, Azerbaijan not only engaged in prolonged preparatory work but also launched psychological pressure campaigns targeting Armenia's leadership, exploiting their known vulnerabilities.

Sources say that over the past month, Azerbaijani military aircraft conducted repeated reconnaissance flights along Armenia's borders, displaying "aggressive" behaviour. The Armenian government reportedly failed to grasp the real motive behind this increased activity, especially given that the Washington meetings and the intialling of the peace deal had already been agreed upon.

The daily also reports that Armenia's Foreign Intelligence Service provided a briefing to the government, warning that Azerbaijan was discussing multiple scenarios, and if "the negotiations regarding the Zangazur corridor fail, Azerbaijan, with the support of Turkey, is ready to use force to seize key parts of Syunik Region". This, the daily says, effectively put an end to all hesitation, and Pashinyan hastily went and signed everything, exclusively in the context of Azerbaijani demands. While some believe this information was deliberately leaked by Azerbaijan as part of its "cunning" politics, the daily notes that fear ultimately silenced rational voices within the Armenian leadership.

Separately, Hraparak's website says that the published text of the peace treaty between Armenia and Azerbaijan initialled in Washington contains no provisions favourable to Armenia.

The daily says that the document makes no mention of the rights of Karabakh Armenians, the release of Armenians held by Baku, the withdrawal of Azerbaijani troops from "occupied" Armenian territories, or any specific map for border delimitation. Instead, it includes clauses that are not only not aimed at establishing peace, but will also provoke internal unrest, plunge Armenia into a new period of turbulence, create new and unsolvable problems, and lay the groundwork for new concessions.

The daily highlights Clauses 8 and 9 of the treaty as particularly problematic. Clause 8 states that the parties condemn and will combat intolerance, racial hatred, separatism, and terrorism. The daily questions why such language is included, given that both countries are already party to relevant international conventions.

The answer, the daily says, lies in Clause 9, which obliges both sides to address cases of missing persons and enforced disappearances from the conflict through information exchange, noting that relevant arrangements will be negotiated and thoroughly agreed upon in a separate agreement. Thus, according to Clause 9, a separate agreement addressing all the above-mentioned issues still needs to be concluded, the contents of which and the pitfalls it may contain for Armenia are unknown.

The daily warns that this clause could enable Azerbaijan to demand criminal investigations into participants in the First Karabakh War, targeting Armenian military figures and war veterans under the pretext of implementing justice. And if Armenia rejects such demands, it could be accused of supporting separatism, undermining Azerbaijan's territorial integrity, or obstructing justice.

Furthermore, the daily warns that Baku will demand to punish all the "revanchists", those accusing Azerbaijan of vandalism and genocide, those fighting against the destruction of Armenian cultural heritage in Karabakh, and so on. All of this, the daily says, would be coordinated through a follow-up agreement, uniquely required only for these specific clauses out of the treaty's 17 clauses, suggesting their strategic importance to both Baku and, potentially, the current Armenian leadership.

Finally, the daily argues, this follow-up agreement may be used not only to suppress domestic opposition to Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan, but also to silence those opposing Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev and Azerbaijani "aggression".

Minister praises Baku-Yerevan declaration

Meanwhile, Armenian Economy Minister Gevorg Papoyan highlighted the economic significance of the Washington declaration. He noted that during the Iran-Israel war, the South Caucasus served as the only safe air route, prompting global recognition of the need for a secure land route as well. He said the new corridor will turn Armenia into a key cargo hub between China and Europe, enhancing its security importance as any disruption during future conflicts would draw greater international attention. He added that cargo transit through Armenia will generate customs revenue, infrastructure development and economic benefits. Additionally, the opening of new routes will reduce transportation costs for Armenian exports and with the reopening of the Turkish border, Armenia can access Mediterranean ports, which could further lower import and export costs.

According to Papoyan, the agreement will lead to significant economic investments and boost exports, imports and overall foreign investment in Armenia. Papoyan stated that as a transport hub, Armenia will play a key role in global trade and enhance its strategic importance and security. He said that if US companies build a railway along the potential Trump Route for Peace and Prosperity (TRIPP; aka Zangazur corridor, via southern Armenia), it would not harm Armenia but would bring major benefits and operate under Armenian law, just like the Russian Railways currently does. He said Armenia should find a formula to live peacefully with its neighbours and the agreement signed in Washington is that formula. Those who oppose it, he argued, prefer Armenia to remain a tool in the hands of other powers and reject peace. Papoyan added that the new route would also be economically beneficial for Iran, as it would allow direct access from Armenia's Meghri to Azerbaijan's Naxcivan railway, then through Armenia's Yeraskh into Armenia, enabling faster cargo transport. He noted that both Iran's president and foreign minister have confirmed they see no security risks in this arrangement.

Papoyan also noted that there are no issues with Russia regarding this matter, as Armenia is a member of the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU), maintains close partnership with Russia and is a strategic ally. He emphasised that all relevant matters are resolved within this relationship.

Exiled separatist Karabakh MPs say Baku-Yerevan peace deal omits key issues

Parliamentary factions of Azerbaijan's defunct breakaway Nagorno-Karabakh region have issued a statement in response to the 8 August trilateral meeting of the leaders of Armenia, Azerbaijan and the United States in Washington.

While acknowledging past international peace efforts, the parliamentary factions criticised the dissolution of the OSCE Minsk Group and accused its co-chairs of abandoning their mediation role. They said that the lack of condemnation of the 2020 Karabakh war, which they said was started by Baku, led to further escalation and the exodus of Karabakh Armenians in 2023, and that the Minsk Group ignored the International Court of Justice resolution on the right of Karabakh Armenians to return to their homes.

The statement warned that any Armenia-Azerbaijan peace deal excluding key issues, such as the safe return of Karabakh Armenians, protection of cultural heritage, and the release of Armenian detainees held by Baku would fail to deliver a lasting peace. The statement called for a process based on justice, rights and mutual trust.

Armenia, Georgia discuss regional peace prospects

Armenian Foreign Minister Ararat Mirzoyan has told his Georgian counterpart Maka Bochorishvili in a phone call that Baku and Yerevan's Washington deals are a fresh opportunity for regional cooperation and peace, News.am said.

Commenting on the outcomes of the 8 August meetings in Washington, Mirzoyan emphasised that the agreements reached create new opportunities for regional cooperation and peace. The sides also discussed their bilateral partnership agenda.

Russia allocates 25m dollars for Armenia's school meals programme

Russia has allocated over $25m for the next phase of the School Feeding Programme (202530) run by the UN World Food Programme in Armenia.

Since 2010, Russia has contributed 43m dollars in total, benefiting over 102,000 schoolchildren, modernising facilities and improving attendance and performance. The UN has praised the programme's success and bilateral cooperation, the report said.

In the meantime, the Russian House culture centre in Armenia will launch a free four-month robotics course for children and teenagers starting 25 August as part of the Russian Engineering School international educational project. Participants will improve their Russian language skills, learn robotics using unique Russian methods and explore leading Russian universities and scientific achievements, Sputnik Armenia said.

title: Russia claims it destroyed another Ukrainian Abrams tank
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Defence Ministry has stated that its armed forces have destroyed another US-supplied Abrams tank near the Ukrainian town of Avdiivka.
body:
"The enemy lost up to 95 servicemen, three tanks, including one US-made Abrams, two infantry fighting vehicles, nine cars, as well as two US-made M777 howitzers and 2 D-30 guns," the ministry said in its 28 March war report on Telegram.

This is the latest incident involving an Abrams tank in Ukraine after it was reported mid-March that Russia destroyed a fourth US-supplied Abrams tank near the village of Berdychi just north-west of Avdiivka.

Popular war bloggers Kiril Fyodorov and Boris Rozhin (Colonelcassad) shared a drone video purporting to show the destruction of the Abrams tank.

The Ukrainian side has not so far made any comments on the alleged incident.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1128 gmt 28 Mar 24

title: Russian Defence Ministry claims advances on multiple fronts in Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Russia's Defence Ministry says Russian forces in Ukraine have made advances on multiple fronts.
body:
In a statement quoted by the Interfax news agency on 15 March, the Defence Ministry said units from Russia's grouping of forces West inflicted losses in personnel and hardware on six mechanised brigades of the Ukrainian armed forces at Berestove and Pishchane in Kharkiv Region, as well as Serebryanka in Donetsk Region.

It also said they had "improved their forward line position".

The ministry added that Russian forces had also "taken more advantageous" positions in the Donetsk, south Donetsk and Kherson sectors and "continued" their advance in the Avdiivka sector.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1316 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Briefing: Russian bloggers confirm Ukraine 'destroyed' Sergey Kotov warship
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At a glance
body:
- Ukraine said on 5 March that it had sunk a Russian Black Sea Fleet patrol ship off occupied Crimea

- While Russian pro-war bloggers confirmed that the Sergey Kotov warship has been 'destroyed', the Defence Ministry in Moscow and Russian state media have so far kept silent about the incident

Full story

Russia's Black Sea Fleet Sergey Kotov large patrol ship has reportedly been sunk by Ukrainian sea drones off occupied Crimea, Ukrainian military intelligence reported on its Telegram channel on 5 March.

According to the report, the Sergey Kotov was attacked on the night of 4-5 March by Ukraine's military intelligence Group 13 unit.

"As a result of a strike by Magura V5 maritime drones, the Russian ship Project 22160 Sergey Kotov sustained damage to the stern, starboard and port sides," it said, noting that the incident happened "near the Kerch Strait".

The ship was worth about $65 million, the report added.

In a later post,Ukrainian military intelligence shared its own video footage purporting to show the destruction of the Sergey Kotov.

Russian pro-war bloggers acknowledge incident

Russian pro-war bloggers aren't disputing the attack on the warship, with some saying the crew are alive.

Voenny Osvedomitel (Military Informant) blogger was among the first to share a 15-second video footage purporting to show a massive blast on the ship following cross-fire shooting.

Dva Mayora Telegram channel reshared the same video, saying that the Russian servicemen on board had "bravely fought" with the attackers. It said that "according to local reports, the ship was destroyed". However, it noted that "according to our information, the entire crew are alive, evacuated, there are several wounded".

Prominent war reported Alexander Kots said on his Telegram channel that the Sergey Kotov patrol ship had long been the target of Ukrainian maritime drones, and had already been subjected to three unsuccessful attacks.

According to Kots, the penultimate such attack against the vessel occurred in September 2023, when it repelled five Ukrainian unmanned drones.

"The crew fought heroically to the end. This can be seen from the published video. But this time it is a story without a happy ending," Kots wrote.

On 14 September 2023, the Russian Defence Ministry reported that the ship had repelled an attack by five Ukrainian sea drones.

The Defence Ministry in Moscow has not yet commented on the latest incident with the Sergey Kotov ship. And no mention of it has also been observed on Russian state TV, according to media monitoring tool Medialogiya.

'Most modern patrol ship'

According to information in Russian open sources, th Sergey Kotov patrol ship was entered into service at the beginning of 2021. The ship officially joined the Black See Fleet in July 2022. Russia's state-controlled Channel One thendescribed the ship as the "most modern patrol ship" with its special design and coating making it "virtually invisible to enemy radars".

Russia's Black Sea Fleet has four such patrol ships manufactured within the same project. The lead ship Vasily Bykov was commissioned in 2018, and the other two production ships - Dmitry Rogachev and Pavel Derzhavin - entered service in 2019 and 2020 respectively.

This is the latest incident involving a Russian Black Sea Fleet ship after it was reported that Ukraine destroyed the Tzezar Kunikov large landing ship off Russian-occupied Crimea mid-February 2024.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0505 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Russian governor says Ukraine shelling kills one, injures three in Belgorod
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

One person has been killed and three others have been wounded in an alleged Ukrainian missile strike near the Russian city of Belgorod, the governor of Belgorod Region bordering Ukraine, Vyacheslav Gladkov, reported on 14 March.
body:
"According to preliminary data, a driver died as a result of the car being hit. The ambulance service also received a phone call about two injured women and one man. Ambulance crews have rushed to the scene," Gladkov wrote on his Telegram channel.

Gladkov said that the Russian air defence had shot down "eight air targets on approach to the city", noting that the strikes had damaged a few houses and a medical facility.

"In the city of Belgorod, damage was inflicted on two households and on the territory of a healthcare facility - the roof was broken and the fifth and sixth floors of the building were damaged. One car was also damaged," Gladkov wrote, adding that rescuers were working at the scene.

In his later update, Gladkov reported that Belgorod Region's city of Grayvoron had been shelled by Ukrainian forces, too. He said one person had been wounded as a result and several buildings and vehicles had been damaged.

Meantime, the breaking news Readovka channel has reported that one of the "Ukrainian shells" had hit a forensic examination building in the region's village of Sosnovka. The report included a video purporting to show the consequent damage inside the building.

Russia's Defence Ministry reported the same day that its air defences had repelled 14 Ukrainian unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) over Belgord and Kursk regions.

"Air defence duty systems intercepted and destroyed 14 UAVs over the territories of Belgorod Region (11 UAVs) and Kursk Region (three UAVs)," the ministry wrote on its Telegram channel.

In its follow-up report, the ministry said that at about 08:30 Moscow time (05:30 GMT), its air defences had shot down eight missiles over Belgorod Region.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 14 Mar 24

title: Russia says Ukrainian 'saboteurs', arms destroyed in border region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring
