Russia's Defence Ministry has said that its forces have destroyed manpower and equipment of "sabotage and reconnaissance groups" deployed by the Ukrainian army across the border in Russia's Belgorod Region.
body:
In its 21 March post on Telegram, the ministry said Russian forces carried out "pre-emptive strikes by aviation and artillery of the Western group of forces in the area in Ukraine bordering Belgorod Region".

The post included a 28-second aerial video purporting to show clips of explosions from the missile strikes at various undisclosed locations.

In the previous day's war update on Telegram, the ministry confirmed that clashed had happened between Russian forces and "Ukrainian saboteurs" in the village of Kozinka, near the Ukrainian border.

It said Russian forces had carried out a "full mopping up operation", and that the Ukrainian groups had "lost 650 fighters, two armoured vehicles and two Czech-made Vampire multiple-rocket launch systems".

According to the pro-war blogger Zapiski Veterana (Veteran's Diaries), Kozinka saw "full-fledged combined arms combat using artillery, aviation and heavy equipment". Consequently, "almost nothing remains of the village", the channel said.

Earlier on 21 March, the head of the nearby town of Grayvoron, Gennady Bondarev, called on residents to "temporarily leave the border areas" for Yaroslavl Region, saying the situation "remains tense". I ask you to make the right decision and temporarily leave the border areas.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0819 gmt 21 Mar 24

title: Russia MoD says Ukrainian helicopter shot down near Belgorod Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Defence Ministry in Moscow has said air defence units have shot down a Ukrainian Mi-8 military helicopter that was heading towards Russia's Belgorod Region.
body:
In a Telegram post on 17 March, the ministry said a Verba man-portable surface-to-air missile had brought the helicopter down over the Ukrainian border village of Luksahivka. The Mi-8 was flying towards the village of Kozinka in Belgorod Region, it said.

Russian Defence Ministry's Zvezda TV also posted video of what it said was the downing of the Ukrainian helicopter.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1323 gmt 17 Mar 24

title: Kenya's president reaffirms commitment to deploy a police force to Haiti to help quell gang violence
snippet:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP)  Kenyan President William Ruto said Wednesday the country will still lead a U.N.-backed multi-national police force to help quell gang violence in Haiti once a transitional presidential council is formed in the Caribbean country.

Ruto said in a post on X, formerly Twitter, that U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had briefed him on the latest developments in Haiti and that he assured Blinken of Kenyas commitment to deploy a police force to Haiti.
body:
I assured Secretary Blinken that Kenya will take leadership of the U.N. Security Support Mission in Haiti to restore peace and security," Ruto said.

Kenya's Foreign Affairs Principal Secretary Korir Sing'oei on Tuesday said Kenya had put on hold the deployment of 1,000 of its policemen until a clear administration is in place in Haiti. The announcement came after Haiti Prime Minister Ariel Henry said he would resign once a presidential council is created.

Kenya had agreed last October to lead a U.N.-authorized international police force to Haiti, but the countrys top court in January ruled it unconstitutional, in part because of a lack of reciprocal agreements on such deployments between the two countries.

Ruto said that he and Henry had witnessed the signing of the reciprocal agreements between Kenya and Haiti on March 1, clearing the path for the deployment.

Under the plan, the U.N.-backed multi-national police led by Kenyan officers was to help quell gang violence that has long plagued Haiti. But violence escalated sharply since Feb. 29, with gunmen burning police stations, closing the main international airports and raiding the countrys two biggest prisons, releasing more than 4,000 inmates.

Scores have been killed, and more than 15,000 are homeless after fleeing neighborhoods raided by gangs. Food and water are dwindling and the main port in the capital of Port-au-Prince remains closed, stranding dozens of containers with critical supplies.

After returning from a trip to Kenya where he had gone to salvage plans for the African countrys deployment, Henry has been locked out of his own country and has remained in Puerto Rico since last week.

____

Follow APs Africa coverage at: https://apnews.com/hub/africa

title: Russia appoints new deputy defence minister for logistics support
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President Vladimir Putin has appointed Lt Gen Andrei Bulyga as deputy defence minister for overseeing logistics support, the Russian Defence Ministry said in a Telegram post on 11 March.
body:
Bulyga replaces Colonel General Alexei Kuzmenkov, who has returned to his post of deputy head of the Russian Guard (Rosgvardia), the Meduza news website reported the same day.

According to Meduza, this is the third time since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine that Putin has appointed a new deputy minister of defence for logistics support.

Previously, Bulyga held the post of deputy commander in charge of logistics in Russia's Western Military District, the Defence Ministry said in its Telegram post.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1606 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Russia confirms crash of Il-76 military plane in Ivanovo Region
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Russian Il-76 military transport plane with 15 people on board has crashed in Ivanovo Region, the Russian military has said, confirming earlier reports on social media.
body:
In a statement quoted by the Interfax news agency on 12 March, Russia's Defence Ministry said that "at about 13:00 [Moscow time, 10:30 GMT], while taking off for a scheduled flight, an Il-76 military transport aeroplane crashed in Ivanovo Region".

"There were eight crew members and seven passengers on board," the ministry said, adding that according to a report from the scene, the reason for the crash was a fire in one of the engines during takeoff.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1050 gmt 12 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Yekaterinburg Media 4-10 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are highlights from state-owned Rossiya 1 TV's regional news slot, Nakanune.ru news agency and e1.ru Yekaterinburg city portal for the period 4-10 March 2024:

Presidential election
body:
More than 8,000 public observers are to monitor the presidential election in Sverdlovsk Region, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 4 March. (Rossiya 1 TV "Vesti Ural" news, Yekaterinburg, 4 Mar 24)

Schools in Yekaterinburg have been recommended to switch to distance learning during the presidential election on 15-16 March, Nakanune.ru reported on 7 March. The relevant document was sent to the principals of municipal schools. (Nakanune.ru news agency, Yekaterinburg, 7 Mar 24)

Political

Representatives of the regional branch of the LDPR have met local residents in Yekaterinburg and a number of other towns in the region as part of the All-Russia Reception of Citizens project, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 4 March. They consulted local residents on social allowances and payment holidays, as well as discussed problems in the housing and utilities sector, transport, medicine, education and urban development projects. The All-Russia Reception of Citizens project was initiated by LDPR chairman Leonid Slutsky in November 2023. Slutsky is one of four presidential hopefuls. (Rossiya 1 TV "Vesti Ural" news, Yekaterinburg, 4 Mar 24)

Members of the Yekaterinburg city duma have exempted the Ural Federal University named after first Russian President Boris Yeltsin from paying a land tax for 12 months, Nakanune.ru reported on 5 March. City councillor Alexander Kolesnikov also suggested that the name of Sergei Kirov, Soviet politician and Bolshevik revolutionary, be returned to the educational establishment. The university will not be paying the land tax for a plot of land in Novokoltsovsky District which was used for a new campus. (Nakanune.ru news agency, Yekaterinburg, 5 Mar 24)

The presidential envoy to the Urals Federal District, Vladimir Yakushev, has visited stands of the regions representing the district at the World Youth Forum in Sochi, Nakanune.ru reported on 6 March. Yakushev also held a meeting with representatives of delegations representing the Urals Federal District. More than 620 people and 275 volunteers from the Urals Federal District are participating in the forum. (Nakanune.ru news agency, Yekaterinburg, 6 Mar 24)

Society

A female pensioner from the village of Verkhnyaya Bobrovka has staged a one-man picket near the residence of the Sverdlovsk Region governor against a landfill to be set up in Sysert District, Nakanune.ru reported on 4 March. Earlier, the Sysert district territorial electoral commission rejected a request by local residents to hold a referendum on the landfill. The people claim that the decision is illegal and that violations in the procedure relating to the referendum, which the officials point to, are unfounded. According to founder of the Uralgiprotorf institute Arkady Shamparov, effluents from the landfill might pollute a local river. The regional authorities are planning to set up the Yekaterinburg-South waste sorting facility, which will be the largest in the Urals Federal District, near the village of Shchelkun in Sysert District. The cost of the project is 25bn roubles (around $275.86m at the current exchange rate). The concessioners are Tyumen businessmen close to governor Yevgeny Kuyvashev. (Nakanune.ru news agency, Yekaterinburg, 4 Mar 24)

A Yekaterinburg resident is standing trial on charges of setting up a financial pyramid and defrauding 352 people of more than 80m roubles, Nakanune.ru reported on 4 March. According to the prosecutor’s office, from October 2020 to August 2021, the man attracted money to be invested to purchase lucrative assets of bankrupt organisations at a price lower than the market cost. (Nakanune.ru news agency, Yekaterinburg, 4 Mar 24)

In 2024, 18 schools are to be overhauled in Sverdlovsk Region, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 5 March. More than 1bn roubles are to be allocated to implement the projects. (Rossiya 1 TV "Vesti Ural" news, Yekaterinburg, 5 Mar 24)

A major transport reform is expected in Yekaterinburg in August 2024, Rossiya 1 TV quoted city mayor Alexei Orlov as saying on 5 March. Outlining the plans, Orlov said all transport operators would sign gross-contracts, a special transportations control centre would be set up and fines for stowaways would be raised. Orlov added the city authorities did not intend to raise public transport fares in the near future. (Rossiya 1 TV "Vesti Ural" news, Yekaterinburg, 1545 gmt 5 Mar 24)

Military

More than 30 migrants with Russian citizenship are to be put on a military register following a raid on the warehouse of the Wildberries online retailer in Yekaterinburg, Nakanune.ru quoted representatives of the military investigations directorate of the Russian Investigations Committee for the Central Military District as saying on 6 March. Since late November 2023, following raids, about 600 migrants have been put on a military register in Yekaterinburg alone. More than 180 foreigners, legally staying in Russia, voluntarily signed contracts with the Russian Defence Ministry. (Nakanune.ru news agency, Yekaterinburg, 6 Mar 24)

Yet another group of volunteers, 38 residents from Sverdlovsk, Chelyabinsk and Kurgan regions, has left for the “special military operation” in Ukraine, Rossiya 1 TV reported on 6 March. They will be performing military missions as members of the BARS-15 Cossack volunteer detachment. (Rossiya 1 TV "Vesti Ural" news, Yekaterinburg, 6 Mar 24) 

Source: BBC Monitoring 10 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia North Ossetia Media 11-17 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from state-owned GTRK Alaniya TV, Severnaya Osetiya, Vladikavkaz and Slovo newspapers, Region15.ru and OsNova information portals, as well as Krylya TV information and analytical portal, for the period 11-17 March 2024:

Presidential election
body:
A young girl has sprayed lists of voters with iodine at a polling station in Mozdoksky District, Osnova portal reported on 15 March, quoting chairman of the territorial electoral commission Vladimir Grechany. According to head of the regional central electoral commission Zhanna Morgoyeva, the “unpleasant incident” did not hamper the voting process and the documents were spoiled slightly. The girl was detained by the police. (Osnova information website, Vladikavkaz, 15 Mar 24)

On 15 March, representatives of the regional government, including chairman of the Vladikavkaz assembly of deputies Alexander Patsiorin and mayor Vyacheslav Mildzikhov, cast their votes in the presidential election in North Ossetia, Vladikavkaz newspaper reported on 16 March. Local residents will be able to vote at 331 permanent polling stations and one temporary polling station. (Severnaya Osetiya newspaper, Vladikavkaz, 16 Mar 24)

On 16 March, the second day of the presidential election, North Ossetia head and secretary of the regional branch of the United Russia party Sergei Menyaylo has exercised his constitutional electoral right, Slovo newspaper reported on 16 March. Menyaylo and his wife voted at school No 2 in Alagir. “This political event is important not only to our country, but to the whole world, I think,” Menyaylo said speaking to journalists. He added he had voted “for the strong president, great Russia, for its future and prosperity”. (Slovo newspaper, Vladikavkaz, 16 Mar 24)

According to preliminary results, the turnout in the presidential election in North Ossetia reached 91%, Region15.ru portal quoted representatives of the regional central electoral commission as saying on 17 March. About 462,000 local residents have already cast their votes. (Region15.ru information portal, Vladikavkaz, 17 Mar 24) 

Economic

The chairman of the North Ossetia parliament, Taymuraz Tuskayev, has chaired a round-table discussion on the problems and prospects of cattle breeding in the republic, Severnaya Osetiya newspaper reported on 12 March. The meeting was initiated by the regional parliament’s committee on agrarian and land policy, ecology and natural resourses. Representatives of relevant ministries and departments, heads of higher educational establishments and agricultural companies were invited to the discussion. Tuskayev said that new programmes should be drawn up taking into account sectors which are the most important for the republic’s economy. The regional minister of agriculture, Alan Kusrayev, said in 2023 that more than 2.2bn roubles (around $23.75m at the current exchange rate) had been used to implement a state programme for developing the agricultural sector and regulating markets of agricultural products, raw materials and foodstuffs. According to preliminary estimates, the gross output reached 46bn roubles, 3.5bn roubles up year-on-year. (Severnaya Osetiya newspaper, Vladikavkaz, 12 Mar 24)

Representatives of three local companies – Luch, Rusmodus-Fid and Tsekh – have left for Kazakhstan to find partners abroad, Osnova portal quoted republic head Sergei Menyaylo as saying on his Telegram channel on 14 March. The trip was organised as part of the International Cooperation and Export national project. Menyaylo praised such business missions and mentioned the North Ossetia-based Monolitny Penobeton (Monolithic Foamed Concrete) company, the output of which is being used to build elite detached houses in Saudi Arabia after one of such business trips. (Osnova information website, Vladikavkaz, 14 Mar 24)

In 2023, about 449 tonnes of seeds of the “elite” category were produced at the Fat-Agro agricultural company, the largest in Europe centre for producing seed potato, in North Ossetia, Region15.ru portal reported on 17 March. In 2024, the company is planning to produce 6,000 tonnes of seed potato and 40,000 tonnes in 2027. The company also produces five million mini-seed pieces and one million of micro-plants. (Region15.ru information portal, Vladikavkaz, 17 Mar 24) 

Society

The North Ossetia authorities have formed a plot of land, measuring 46.5 ha, to be used for private housing construction for large families in the Gizelskoye rural settlement in Prigorodny District, Region15.ru portal quoted regional minister of state property and land relations Ruslan Tedeyev as saying on 11 March. The minister said about 130m roubles were needed to resolve the problem with utility infrastructure. (Region15.ru information portal, Vladikavkaz, 11 Mar 24)

The head of Mozdoksky District, Gennady Gugiyev, has met mothers and wives of servicemen killed in the “special military operation” in Ukraine, Mozdoksky Vestnik newspaper reported on 15 March. He once again expressed condolences to the women and thanked them for "real men". (Mozdoksy Vestnik newspaper, Mozdok, 15 Mar 24)

Military

The Victory train has arrived in Vladikavkaz, GTRK Alaniya TV reported on 11 March. The mobile museum has been travelling around Russian cities since 23 February as part of the Strength in Truth project of the Russian Defence Ministry. Among other things, mobile centres for those willing to sign military contracts were set up at the railway station square. The patriotic train is expected to visit 75 cities in Russia and finish its journey in Moscow on 8 May. (GTRK Alaniya TV news, Vladikavkaz, 11 Mar 24)

Crime

Criminal proceedings on charges of illegal crossing of Russia’s border have been initiated against a Russian woman in North Ossetia, Krylya TV portal reported on 13 March. Moving to Georgia, the woman deliberately produced a forged passport at the Verkhny Lars checkpoint. (Krylya TV information and analytical portal, Vladikavkaz, 13 Mar 24)

A court in North Ossetia has found a local resident guilty of using violence against a representative of law enforcement agencies and sentenced him to two years in a maximum security prison, Krylya TV portal reported on 12 March. In September 2023, the man hit a police officer in a chest at a police station in Ardonsky District where he had been taken for drinking alcohol in a public place. (Krylya TV information and analytical portal, Vladikavkaz, 12 Mar 24) 

Narcotics

The number of people involved in drug-related crimes has gone down in North Ossetia, Osnova portal quoted head of the regional anti-drug commission Luiza Lebedeva as saying at a meeting with republic head Sergei Menyaylo on 13 March. In 2023, 572 people were involved in those crimes, against 976 people in 2020. Since 2020, 92 people diagnosed with drug addiction for the first time have been registered as drug addicts. About 88 people were registered as hardened drug addicts. (Osnova information website, Vladikavkaz, 13 Mar 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 17 Mar 24

title: Putin meets Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School graduates - Kremlin text
snippet:
Text of 'Meeting with graduates of the Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School' published in English by Russian presidential website on 8 March

Ahead of March 8, the President visited the Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School, named after Hero of the Soviet Union Anatoly Serov, and met with its graduates.
body:
Ahead of the meeting, Vladimir Putin and Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, Presidential Plenipotentiary Envoy to the Southern Federal District Vladimir Ustinov and Krasnodar Territory Governor Veniamin Kondratyev inspected the personnel training facility. While in one of the classrooms, the President was shown aircraft simulators in action. School Head Anatoly Yudin provided explanations.

Established in 1938, the Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School now trains crews for operational-tactical, long-range, military-transport and naval aviation units. Since September 2017, the education institution has been training female students.

* * *

President of Russia Vladimir Putin: To be honest, our meeting is taking place in an unusual format. We are meeting with young female pilots in the run-up to March 8.

I would like to congratulate all of you on the upcoming holiday. This is a good and very positive spring holiday. I wish you every success in your careers, a happy family life and marital bliss. I am confident that you will accomplish everything because you are strong-willed people. You are acting purposefully and steering towards your goals.

Mr Shoigu told me how the first cadets enrolled here. I do not know whether this young woman is present here or not. A prospective cadet who failed to enrol pitched up a tent in front of the gate. Indeed, this attitude towards life and her future career is worth a lot. I am confident that, given such an attitude, you will accomplish everything. This is the first thing.

Second, female professionals achieve results in many fields. This is hardly surprising because, apart from their impressive training levels, women meticulously analyse the smallest details linked with their career. Young women display a highly responsible attitude towards the work with which they have been entrusted. On the whole, this allows them to achieve good results.

I am confident that you will also attain results, all the more so as you have graduated from a school that is closely linked with Russia and our Armed Forces. Suffice it to recall the Great Patriotic War. Your school's graduates served as prototypes for many books, artistic works, films and even an opera. Many graduates became Heroes of the Soviet Union, Heroes of Russia and heroes of other countries where our pilots were actively involved in hostilities.

They destroyed literally thousands of enemy tanks, as well as aircraft and artillery crews. Your school's graduates rammed enemy planes on 20 occasions during the Great Patriotic War. This is a heroic educational institution. I am confident that you will also continue the wonderful traditions of this pilot training school.

Of course, the uninitiated tend to link aviation with romantic blue skies. However, you have probably felt that there is something more to it, apart from the romance. Well, of course, it is impossible to do without the omnipresent romance here. And now ... Is your name Katya? Am I right?

Yekaterina Battalova: Guards Lieutenant Battalova.

Vladimir Putin: She was now operating the controls, and we could hear that she was quite composed. She is made for this job. She is enjoying her work, and she is quite enthusiastic about her future lifetime career, to which all of you have decided to devote your lives.

What am I trying to say? Quite possibly, elements of a romantic blue sky are present here. However, this career requires high standards of professional training and a serious attitude towards work. This is a complicated sphere: one should have a good knowledge of equipment and be able to operate it. This amounts to large-scale and responsible work. I want to wish you all the best.

Our women and quite young girls currently serve in the special military operation zone. They worthily serve the Motherland in various fields everywhere.

Once again, I congratulate you on the upcoming holiday, and I wish you all the best.

I am at your service, if there is anything that you would like to discuss, please do.

Violetta Kasilovich: Comrade Supreme Commander-in-Chief.

Before I ask my question, let me take this opportunity to thank you and the leadership of the Russian Ministry of Defence for giving us, ordinary girls, the opportunity to become military pilots of the Russian Aerospace Forces.

The year 2023 was particularly important for us. The most memorable event for us is graduation from the Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School. What was the most memorable event in 2023 for you?

Vladimir Putin: You know, my life consists of an endless number of events and activities. Sometimes I compare it to a waterfall: standing under a waterfall, it pours constantly.

Even when I am with my loved ones, I try not to show any signs of stress, and, on the contrary, I pretend that everything is fine, we are quite at ease and having a rest. But I know that in five minutes I will get a phone call from someone, in ten minutes I will have to call someone else, and within 30 minutes there will be some event and I'll have to understand what happened and, if necessary, react to it somehow or adjust something. So, it's just a series of events.

But, of course, like for the country as a whole, for me and for you, I think, all the brightest, most significant things happened on the battlefield - in the zone of the special military operation. Then, of course, there are a lot of issues related to the economy, to maintaining it, its development, to ensuring a rate of economic growth. This is the foundation that everything is built on, our whole life - both our social life and our military successes are based on benchmarks in the economy, in the real sector of industry. So, everything is basically there.

The most vivid events are, of course, meetings with our men, or with our women, our girls who serve in the special military operation, or with members of their families. Frankly, I try not to show emotion, but still, these events, these meetings have the brightest emotional colouring. So everything is connected with these events, just like for you, just like for the overwhelming majority of our citizens.

Yelizaveta Fedotova: Comrade Supreme Commander-in-Chief, may I ask you a question? Lieutenant Fedotova.

You have flown and even personally piloted many types of aircraft, and recently you flew on a Tu-160M Ã¢??Ã¢??strategic missile carrier. Please tell us about this experience. Do you have any plans to master other modern planes?

Vladimir Putin: Just now I flew a simulator with the comrade lieutenant - this is also a definite experience. But as for piloting... You know, I really piloted a glider, flew with cranes - if you remember, it was several years ago. But that was not a simulator, I actually piloted it, it's true.

But I also had to train then, because the sky is a serious business. Who else but you knows this? We flew low, I also flew low - about 400 metres. As soon as the wind blows, it shakes. These are not simulators, 400 metres is a bit high. That is when I piloted.

And other planes I flew on were a Su-25 attack plane, then a Su-27 fighter, a Tu-160, and a Be-200 when we were putting out fires. Of course, I did not pilot anything. However, it was all useful and interesting, and I needed to understand what it was all about. You always need to understand what a thing is, touch it with your hands, then you will better understand what is happening.

I do not mean to offend anyone, but I think that the hardest type of service is piloting an attack plane. G force! I just cannot understand how these guys control the plane, because up and down, strikes are carried out visually, when they see the target, they descend sharply, and then rise just as sharply. The G force is so great that only the hands and fingers move effectively. I cannot understand how they fly the plane.

The only so-called piloting element was on the Su-27, when the commander suggested that I perform a "roll." I did this myself. He said: "I am delegating you the controls. Be smooth, no sudden movements, move the controls to the right, and we will do a roll." I did it myself, it's true. We rolled easily, the plane is very powerful. But he said just that: "The plane is powerful, very responsive, manoeuvrable, take your time with it." So I did it myself.

In 2005, we experienced a remarkable five-hour flight on the Tu-160, which was an absolute delight. The trip was a unique experience, particularly during the imperceptible transition to supersonic speed. The click associated with this shift is inaudible on the plane but audible on the ground.

The last flight [on the Tu-160M] was not originally planned because the Minister [of Defence Sergei Shoigu] said that we cannot fly because the machine had not yet been officially accepted, a sentiment echoed by the industry. However, during our visit to the enterprise [Gorbunov Kazan Aircraft Production Association] and a tour around it, the aircraft's commander assured me, "Mr President, we are ready. We can be in the air in two hours. I suggest you give it a try." I agreed, proposing to schedule it for the next day due to prior commitments. The commander responded, "We will be ready." And so, we boarded and took to the skies.

It was interesting to see the transformation the aircraft has undergone since my last flight in 2005. The changes were extensive: it is practically a new machine. The crew told me about the numerous updates, emphasising that nearly everything, including the avionics, had been revamped. The commander encouraged me to turn on the engines, press some buttons, and so on. It was very enlightening to get some hands-on experience.

This modernisation was carried out at the initiative of the Minister of Defence. While various proposals were considered, with some suggesting closing this chapter and opening an entirely new one, it became evident that such a shift would likely result in a gap in our access to combat-ready strategic aviation.

I think we made the right decision, and the Minister had a good suggestion. We actually created a new aircraft that is unparalleled globally: a supersonic machine operating at unprecedented speeds. This strategic aircraft is equipped to carry nuclear weapons, thereby fortifying our nuclear triad.

One more thing: I attempted to operate a simulator myself. When the lieutenant suggested I take control, I declined, saying that she would do much better. Instead, I decided to try my hand at piloting a helicopter. I found it to be the most challenging type of flying. Just a millimeter of difference in the control can send it veering in different directions, making it tricky to pinpoint the exact landing spot. I think helicopters are the most difficult to pilot.

Except, of course, what I really piloted when flying with the cranes. But this was a real situation. This is a simulator, but it's a complicated job. This is a very complicated job where every millimeter matters. This is why army aviation, which is performing very serious missions today that we badly need on the battlefield, naturally deserves the highest praise and respect. That probably takes care of my entire aviation history.

But having felt all this and flown various aircraft, I might say that it seems like a man's job, although it is certainly accessible to girls and women. In general, I believe there are no jobs that women shouldn't do and can't achieve success with. Young women work and achieve success everywhere in our country. True, there have been no women yet in maritime aviation, torpedo or missile aviation. After all, these jobs are particularly risky, and I think we should protect young women.

Go ahead, please.

Yana Vasina: Comrade Supreme Commander-in-Chief, permission to speak please. I am Lieutenant Vasina.

Russia has been and remains a great aviation power. Starting from the time of Captain Nesterov and Valery Chkalov and up to this day, military pilots have been glorifying our Motherland through their courage and bravery. However, they take their first steps to the skies within the walls of a flight school. As a pilot, I would like to know what you think about pilot training and the future of aviation training.

Vladimir Putin: It is difficult for me to give my advice. But there is one thing I know for sure, and we discussed this with the Defence Ministry officials - we need modern, effective simulators. And, of course, we need instructors that can do this job.

As I understand it, we do not have problems with simulator availability today, but if we have a problem, we'll resolve it. At any rate, we have everything we need for high quality simulators to be available. I believe we have even surpassed our competitors with some simulators - ours are very effective.

And what do you do now, after graduation?

Yana Vasina: I serve on Tu-154 in Khabarovsk in the Far East.

Vladimir Putin: When you trained as a pilot, what did you think should have been added to your training?

Yana Vasina: Certainly, a simulator. This is an essential part of flight training now. It is possible to master flying without it, but it makes the process much easier.

Vladimir Putin: Did you learn to fly without a simulator?

Yana Vasina: I haven't yet flown a Tu-154 simulator.

Vladimir Putin: You mean specifically a Tu-154 simulator. I see. In this case, Mr Shoigu, we need to have simulators for all aircraft models for young women and men to learn on in the future.

Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu: Mr President, the Tu-154 has been out of production for many years.

Vladimir Putin: Yes, I see. I am also referring to other aircraft.

Sergei Shoigu: You are correct about other aircraft. We must provide simulators for Tu-214s. We have aircraft of this class. Under your instructions, we are beginning to manufacture the Tu-96 again, and we need simulators for those as well. So our plan will be as follows - every consignment of aircraft, especially training planes, will include simulators in the contract.

Vladimir Putin: Let us do it without fail, it must be included in the state defence order. This is very important. Comrade Lieutenant asked me how I flew and what I flew. You know, it's important, it really matters. Because on one type of aircraft the pedals move in one way, and on other types of aircraft - in a different way, and this little thing can make a difference when piloting. It does make a difference.

Unfortunately, we have also had mistakes that have led to tragedies, when crews transfer from one type of similar aircraft to another similar aircraft, with systems that operate somewhat differently.

Sergei Shoigu: You mean the Yak-40, Yak-42?

Vladimir Putin: Yes. That is why it is the right thing to do. We will definitely pay attention to it. You are right.

Yana Vasina: Thank you.

Vladimir Putin: Yes, please.

Darya Ignasheva: Comrade Supreme Commander-in-Chief.

You have a very intense working schedule, including constant long flights. Tell me, please, what was your longest flight and how do you manage to keep yourself in such excellent physical shape with such a busy schedule?

Vladimir Putin: As for physical fitness, I'll tell you now.

There were a lot of long, long flights, I don't remember now, but we probably flew to Latin America somewhere, to Mexico - such flights across the ocean. Although, you know, sometimes you can fly from one point in Russia to another faster than across the ocean. It's a big country, the sun never sets on it.

I have to spend a lot of time on the plane. There was a moment, I can't remember exactly when, when I had the impression that I was living on a plane. Yes, yes.

And as for staying in shape, I always answer the same, and there is no magic trick. I always say: sport, you should play sports. And I kind of recommend everyone else do it - I recommend everyone plays sports, that's it.

More to the point, we - if you have been paying attention, we talked about this recently - we will even offer tax deductions for people who regularly participate in sports and meet the Fit for Labour and Defence standards. We will treat them accordingly and help people who take care of their own health.

This is why sport is really an important way to stay fit. But it goes without saying that I almost never drink alcohol. In fact, I try not to talk about it, although, probably, it should be talked about. But I definitely try not to drink strong drinks.

Cold exposure training is a very good procedure: this is important for you as officers. It is true. Hot and cold showers or contrast baths are an effective way to strengthen your health. I remember, you know, when I was still young and lived in Leningrad, we had... we did not even have a bath tub in our communal apartment, but nevertheless I went out into the yard in the winter and wiped myself with snow. I was still a kid.

Why am I telling you this? Because you can always find a way to achieve the result you need if you want it. Taking care of your health is important, not only personally, but for the state, so I wish for you to stay healthy, beautiful, and successful.

Yes, please.

Yulia Zakalyukina: Lieutenant Zakalyukina.

How would you feel if the captain of Air Force One was a woman?

Vladimir Putin: First, I will tell you, I do not select the crews of the aircraft I fly on: this is done by the management of certain aviation services. But they are all distinguished and very experienced people who are dedicated to their work and highly professional; I have no doubts about this. I saw it for myself several times.

In fact, I believe we should still be guided not by gender, but by business principles when promoting anyone, not only in the military, but in general, in business, anywhere. If a person is competent and has good results in their work, then in no case should they be restricted by gender, like, "well, a woman does not need to be promoted; she has a family and children, and should have her own life." This is wrong.

On the other hand, I believe it's misguided when it is required to have a certain percentage of women in certain areas: this percent in management, that in parliament, this in local administration, and that one in the Army. People should not be judged in terms of percentages, but by personal and business qualities, by attitude.

So, if there is a choice, and a woman is successful in an assignment in any place, position, or when moving up the career ladder, of course, there should be no restrictions.

Kristina Zhdanova: Permission to speak, Sir?

Vladimir Putin: Go ahead, please.

Kristina Zhdanova: Lieutenant Zhdanova.

What would you wish, on the eve of International Women's Day, for the women that are performing their duties and missions in the special military operation?

Vladimir Putin: To return home as soon as possible. I wish them happiness, personal happiness and successes - both combat success and success in their personal lives. I am completely sincere in saying this.

I said I hope for them to return home as soon as possible. But I also know something different about military versus civilians. I will talk about journalists, war correspondents. I saw how they work on the frontline, including young women, performing their journalistic duty. I instructed the top managers of the main channels to withdraw women from the battle field. Why expose women to that risk?

What was the result? They took a vacation and stayed there on their own. And, the TV channel managers told me these women were ready to quit their jobs and would go there anyway. The same is true for many other women on combat missions there. I know this - I talked to them. They consider it their duty to be there. They are serving the Motherland; this is their mission, their inner life impulse.

Incidentally, this has been the case in many other periods of our history, including the events in Afghanistan. I know personal examples, women who believed they should be there, and that was that. Nevertheless, I want them to return home to their families and their responsibilities in this area as soon as possible.

However, I am certainly most grateful to them for what they are doing, for their attitude towards their service, their work, their service to the Fatherland and I wish them happiness.

Maria Kuzina: Comrade Supreme Commander-in-Chief!

I am Lieutenant Kuzina.

We seriously realise the complexity of the military-political situation and today's historical period. Like over 80 years ago, Nazism has raised its head today and is trying to rule the world. Allow me to express support and deep gratitude to you on behalf of the graduates and all military personnel of the Armed Forces.

Mr President! You may rely on the Officer Corps of the Russian Federation. We will not let you down.

Vladimir Putin: I have no doubt about this. The Russian Officer Corps has always - I want to emphasise the word "always" - at all historical turns and all historical stages has demonstrated its highest loyalty to the Motherland, the Fatherland and their duty. Due to these qualities in our officers, Russia has always achieved results and has always emerged victorious from the most difficult trials.

But when the military is telling me "We will not let you down," I hear "We will not let our Motherland down." As the Supreme Commander-in-Chief, I would like to reply to you by saying "Thank you for your service."

Do you have any other questions? Are all of you content with the jobs you received upon graduating from flight school? Do you have any other needs or questions? Or would you like to tell me something without the minister and other chiefs in attendance? No? Is everything okay with you?

Remark: Yes, everything is okay.

Vladimir Putin: Then, I would like to wish you every success. Happy holiday, happy March 8!

I wish you all the best. Have a good day!

Source: President of the Russian Federation website in English 0800 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Russia claims capture of village, railway station in East Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian Defence Ministry claimed on 21 March that its forces had advanced in Ukraine's Donetsk Region, which Russia refers to as the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR).
body:
According to the statement, "coordinated actions of the Tsentr [Centre] group of troops have liberated the settlement of Tonenke" west of Avdiivka. Also, "units of the Southern group of troops have seized the Alebastrova railway station" between Klishchiyivka and Andriyivka south of Bakhmut, the ministry said.

State news agency TASS quoted "DPR head advisor" Igor Klimakovksy as saying that the village of Tonenke was the base of the Vampire MRLS, with which "Ukrainian armed formations" had stricken "the centre of Donetsk in 2022 and 2023" claiming dozens of civilian lives.

The news came just two days after the Defence Ministry had claimed the capture of the village Orlivka near Avdiivka.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1027 gmt 21 Mar 24

title: Report says 2,000 men on Ukraine's Russian PoW list
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A Ukrainian government project has published a list of some 2,000 names of people it describes as Russian prisoners of war, Russian investigative website Vazhnyye Istorii (Important Stories or IStories) reports.
body:
IStories said it analysed the Khochu Zhit (I want to live) list and found on it 64 dead persons and "at least" 66 individuals regarded as missing. It also found 15 duplicate entries.

IStories said it had contacted family members of some of the people on the list.

In one case, a Russian serviceman's sister had already learned from the Russian Defence Ministry of her brother having been taken prisoner. However, in another case, the Russian serviceman's relative in question did not know he was a prisoner of war.

IStories said there were no accurate numbers of Russian prisoners of war. It said the most recent statement from Russian officials had come from Denis Pushilin, the Moscow-installed head of the so-called Donetsk People's Republic in occupied Ukraine who in October 2023 put the number of Russians troops held by Ukraine at 500.

IStories cited an official saying that 543 Russian service personnel had been brought back to Russia in 2024 in three separate swaps. According to IStories, a majority of those included in the 3 January 2024 swap were former convicts. It speculated at the time that the reasoning behind that may have been that it should be easier to make a convicted person go back to war.

IStories said Russia had secured the release of a total of 2,000 service personnel since the start of the war, but it could not give the exact figure because in some cases the Russian authorities withheld numbers.

It also said it was aware of cases of Chechen units "buying out" Ukrainian prisoners of war to subsequently swap them for Chechen troops. There have also been unofficial swaps on the front line.

Khochu Zhit is a Ukrainian government project set up to encourage Russian servicemen to surrender. It promises humane treatment in line with the international conventions and opportunities to seek asylum in Ukraine or outside it or return to Russia in a prisoner swap.

Source: Vazhnyye Istorii (Important Stories) in Russian 1630 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Chechnya Media 11-17 Mar 24
snippet:
The following are highlights from the government newspaper Vesti Respubliki, the state news agency Grozny-Inform and the Chechen Republic head's press service for the period 11-17 March 2024:

Presidential election
body:
Refugees from Gaza residing in Chechnya will vote in the 15-17 March presidential election, the Vesti Respubliki newspaper reported, quoting Ayshat Nunayeva, secretary of Shali District's electoral commission.

"The regional administration, the regional electoral commission and the management of the Gorny Klyuch camp have informed the Gaza refugees about the upcoming election," Nunayeva said. "Using a special application, we assisted them with applying to vote at the polling station closest to their place of abode. There were many wishing to vote but, given that most of them have no [Russian] citizenship, only 32 individuals were provided with the opportunity." (Vesti Respubliki newspaper, 13 Mar 24)

The Zapad-Akhmat battalion of the Russian Defence Ministry has destroyed Ukrainian units equipped with heavy armour attempting to cross the border near Kharkiv, Chechnya head Ramzan Kadyrov reported on Telegram.

"Our lads had no problems repelling such a disorganised offensive," Kadyrov said. "Aerial reconnaissance in conjunction with artillery and UAV operators performed well." He added that a Ukrainian tank blown up on a Ukrainian mine had allegedly been "finished off" by munitions dropped by drones. (Grozny-Inform news agency, 13 Mar 24)

A total of 454,406 eligible residents of Chechnya (55.63% of the 816,869 voters) voted in the presidential election on the first voting day (15 March), the regional electoral commission reported on Telegram. (ChGTRK Grozny TV, 15 Mar 24)

A total of 741,575 eligible residents of Chechnya (90.78%) had voted in the first two dates of the presidential election (15 and 16 March), the regional electoral commission reported. (ChGTRK Grozny TV, 16 Mar 24)

Chechnya head Ramzan Kadyrov, his mother, wife, and children cast their votes in the presidential election, Kadyrov's press service reported, quoting his post on Telegram.

Kadyrov said that the atmosphere at the polling stations in Chechnya was "celebratory" as people viewed the presidential election not just as the voting process but also as an opportunity to express their views and contribute to the forming of a happy future.

"Even at a time of active fight on international terrorism, with high risks present, residents of our republic went to polling stations and made their humble contribution to the forming of power branches," he wrote. "This is evidence of the Chechen people's firm civic position." (Press service of the Chechnya head, 16 Mar 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 17 Mar 24

title: Highlights: Russia Volgograd Region Media 5-11 Feb 24
snippet:
The following are media highlights from Volgograd's state-owned GTRK Volgograd TV, V1.ru and Novosti Volgograda websites and Vysota 102 news agency for the period 5-11 Feb 2024:

Election
body:
Three thousand observers are set to monitor the upcoming presidential election in Volgograd Region, as reported by GTRK Volgograd TV. The regional public chamber will be responsible for their preparation, as outlined in an agreement signed on 8 February. Public observers will monitor the adherence to election laws at polling stations and cross-check information in media and social networks. The effort involves 26 public organisations and five political parties. A public observation centre will be operated by the public chamber during the voting days from 15 to 17 March. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

Trusted representatives of Leonid Slutsky, the presidential candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, meet residents of Volgograd Region at his electoral headquarters twice a week. Currently, 10 representatives operate in the region, focusing on listening to people and providing consultations. According to experts, the youth, aged 18 to 35, actively express civic engagement, with inquiries often related to social issues. Older residents inquire about pension matters, housing, communal services, and food prices. Street surveys are also conducted to gather opinions and requests, contributing to a regional database of appeals, with an effectiveness rate of around 40%. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 9 Feb 24)

Political

Russian President Vladimir Putin awarded six residents of Volgograd Region, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. According to his decree signed on 5 February, the medals of For Merit to the Fatherland Order 2nd class were conferred to Frolovo mayor Vasily Dankov and Muslim Ganiyev, the senior research associate of the department of the All-Russian Scientific Research Institute of Irrigated Agriculture of the Kostyakov Federal Scientific Centre of Hydrotechnics and Reclamation's branch. The head of the peasant farm enterprise, Vladimir Obyedkov, was awarded the For Work in Agriculture medal. The chairman of the agricultural production cooperative, Pavel Dubrovin, and heads of peasant farm enterprises, Andrei Lippardt and Ruslan Pakhomov, were bestowed with the Honoured Worker of Agriculture titles. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

The mayor of the town of Leninsk, Dmitry Smirnov, was removed from his position due to a scandal involving violations in public procurement, the Novosti Volgograda website reported. Following an inspection by the prosecutor's office, which revealed a conflict of interest in public procurement, lawmakers of the urban settlement decided to terminate Smirnov's powers on 8 February. Marina Sasova, the chief specialist of the local administration, will serve as the temporary acting head. (Novosti Volgograda website, 8 Feb 24)

Military

A reconnaissance assault soldier, who died in Ukraine in late November 2023, was laid to rest in Rudnyansky District, the V1 website reported. Vyacheslav Shpilyov, 54, signed a contract with the Russian Defence Ministry on 24 April 2023. (V1.ru website, 5 Feb 23)

Cpl Roman Kondratyuk, 33, who died in "the special operation" zone during shelling on 16 December, was buried in Kamyshinsky District, the V1 website reported. He signed a contract with the Russian Defence Ministry in April 2023. Kondratyuk is survived by his wife, mother and a 10-year-old son. (V1.ru website, 6 Feb 23)

A 56-year-old from Novonikolaevsky District died during "the special military operation," the Vysota 102 news agency reported. Alexander Golokolenov, a contract soldier, was wounded on the front, returned for treatment in Volgograd Region, and went back to the front without waiting for a medical commission. He is survived by his wife, three adult children, and two grandchildren. (Vysota 102 news agency, 7 Feb 24)

Enver Yanmaev, who died in the "special military operation" zone, was buried in the village of Chervlenoye in Svetloyarsky District. (Vysota 102 news agency, 10 Feb 24)

More than 100 drones have been dispatched to the "special military operation" zone from Volgograd Region, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. These drones were procured using funds from the regional For Victory support fund, dedicated to assisting servicemen and volunteers. In addition, the region has provided extra technical equipment and construction materials to meet the daily requirements of the fighters. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

Volunteers from the Bastion battalion were honoured with distinction badges in Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. Parents of participants in "the special military operation" were also presented with the Father of a Soldier medals. Certificates of appreciation were bestowed upon volunteers engaged in rear support, personally delivering humanitarian aid to the zone of "the special military operation." (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

The one-time regional compensation payment for individuals involved in "the special military operation" from Volgograd Region has been tripled from 100,000 to 300,000 roubles ($1,000 to $3,300) in 2024. Governor Andrey Bocharov announced this increase at the regional military commissariat assembly point, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. Combined with the payment from the Russian Defence Ministry, the total support for regional servicemen fighting in Ukraine now amounts to 500,000 roubles ($5,500). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

A 34-year-old resident of Volgograd was arrested by the regional branches of the FSB and Interior Ministry on charges of supporting Ukraine and inciting violence against Russians on social media. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 7 Feb 24)

Volgograd activists from the We Are For Our People! movement produce 3D-printed items based on the requests of "the special military operation" fighters, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. A group of volunteers purchased six printers for 3D printing, and work facilities were provided by one of the enterprises. They produce parts for quadcopters and plastic devices that help quickly reload weapons under any conditions. Lightweight parts are made from plastic supplied by a local enterprise. Up to 30 kilogrammes of raw materials are used for production each month. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

Large-scale tactical special exercises were conducted at two chemical plants in Volzhsky, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The scenario involved a short circuit in electrical equipment, leading to a fire that damaged containers storing hazardous substances. The exercises included various authorities such as firefighters, gas rescuers, medical personnel, police, and military command. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 9 Feb 24)

Economic

The debt burden on Volgograd Region residents has increased by 1.5 times over the year, the Vysota 102 news agency reported, citing the Volgograd branch of the Russian Central Bank's Southern Main Directorate. In 2023, residents of the region took out loans amounting to 329.4 billion rubles (about $3.6bn), which is 46.5 per cent more than in 2022, but less than the Russian average of 42.9 per cent. The retail lending portfolio in the region grew by 21.7 per cent, reaching 397.1 billion rubles (about $4.3bn) as of 1 January. The increase was mainly due to mortgages, the volume of which increased by nearly 30 per cent over the year, from 148.6 to 193 billion roubles (about $2.1bn). High demand for them continued to be supported by preferential government lending programmes despite the tightening of their issuance conditions. Their peak occurred in the second half of 2023 when people were eager to buy housing as soon as possible, expecting lending conditions to worsen. Consumer loans grew at a slower pace, by 14.9 per cent, and reached 204.1 billion roubles by the end of the last year (about $2.2bn). (Vysota 102 news agency, 5 Feb 24)

Volgograd Region ranks 58th among the country's regions in terms of the average size of bank deposits, amounting to 185.2 thousand roubles (about $2,000) per capita, GTRK Volgograd TV reported, citing a study by RIA Rating. It marked a growth of 28.6 per cent over the year. Within the Southern Federal District, Volgograd Region holds third place after Rostov Region and Krasnodar Territory. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

Volgograd ranked seventh among 102 cities in Russia in terms of public transport quality, GTRK Volgograd TV reported, citing a rating by the Simetra company, which excluded Moscow and Saint Petersburg from its assessment. Over the year, Volgograd improved its position by eight spots. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

In 2023, purchase prices for crop products in Volgograd Region decreased by 4.1 per cent, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The purchase price of rye fell by 10.2 per cent, barley by 9.7 per cent, corn by 8.5 per cent, sunflower seeds by 7.5 per cent and cucumbers by five per cent. Additionally, the price of wheat decreased by 10 per cent over the year, with the cost of Grade 3 falling by five per cent, Grade 4 by 10.1 per cent and Grade 5 by 11 per cent. According to the Volgogradstat regional statistics body, Volgograd Region ranks third within the Southern Federal District in terms of the producer price index, trailing behind Rostov Region and annexed Sevastopol. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

Air service between Volgograd and Sochi will be restored from 1 June, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The flights will be operated by the Pobeda low-cost airline. Tickets are already on sale. The flight programme between the two southern regions has been inactive for about 1.5 years, since the fall of 2022. The Volgograd airport is among the few in the Southern Federal District not subject to flight restrictions imposed from 24 February 2022, when the Russian full-scale invasion of Ukraine started. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

The turnover of organisations in Volgograd Region amounted to more than 2.4 trillion rubles (about $26.4 billion) for the year 2023, a nine per cent increase compared to 2022, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The largest share is attributed to the manufacturing industries, with 34.8 per cent, or 850.1 billion roubles (about $9.3 billion). Wholesale and retail trade, together with repairs of motor vehicles and motorcycles, accounted for 791.8 billion rubles (about $8.9 billion). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

In 2024, Volgograd Region is set to fund 529 community projects with a budget allocation of 341 million rubles (about $3.7 million), GTRK Volgograd TV reported on 7 February. These projects, determined by residents through the initiative budgeting programme, predominantly focus on upgrading socially significant infrastructure and creating modern and comfortable public spaces. The selected initiatives include the renovation of educational institutions, rural culture houses, libraries, museums, and addressing issues related to water supply, street lighting, and road infrastructure repairs in specific localities. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 7 Feb 24)

In 2023, 606 kilometres of quality roads were built in Volgograd Region, GTRK Volgograd reported. Several industry projects were implemented within the framework of the Safe Quality Roads national project, including the opening of traffic on four renovated bridges in Novonikolaevsky and Novoanninsky districts, as well as in Volgograd and Volzhsky. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 7 Feb 24)

At least 50,000 jobs are planned to be created in Volgograd Region over the next 10 years. Governor Andrey Bocharov discussed the results of joint efforts to develop the region and strategic tasks for the next decade with representatives of the business community, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. Annually, since 2014, about 180 billion roubles (about $2bn) have been invested in the economy of Volgograd Region, with significant growth in 2022-2023. In 2023, the investment volume amounted to 226.5 billion roubles (about $2.5bn) and 216.5 billion roubles the year before (about $2.4bn). The forecast for 2024 is estimated at 240 billion roubles (about $2.6bn), with the majority of projects related to industry. By the end of 2034, it is planned to implement investment projects in the region totalling 3.4 trillion roubles (about $38bn). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

The gross regional product of Volgograd Region for 2023 is estimated at 1.3 trillion rubles (about $14bn), GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The consolidated budget saw revenues of almost 200 billion roubles (about $2.2bn), which is a 9.5 per cent increase from 2022. Despite external pressure and restrictions, the economy of the region continues to show stable development across various sectors, governor Andrey Bocharov said at a meeting with representatives of businesses. He added that "enterprises and organisations of the real sector have largely adapted to modern conditions" thanks to overall cooperation, implementation of national and regional projects, modernisation of production and skilled personnel. According to him, an important task is to grow the gross regional product by almost 2.5 times, ensure an accumulated investment volume of at least 3.4 trillion rubles over a decade and increase the income of the regional budget to 300 billion rubles (about $3.3bn). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

In 2023, Volgograd Region residents spent 183.8 billion rubles (about $2bn) on various services, which is 2.3 per cent more than in 2022, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The largest share was spent on utility services - 20.5 per cent. Transport services accounted for another 15.3 per cent. Household and telecommunication services made up 13.9 per cent and 13.1 per cent, respectively. The share of medical services was 10.2 per cent, while education system services accounted for 7.1 per cent. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 9 Feb 24)

HEALTH

In Volgograd, there is a severe shortage of imported drugs for treating pneumonia in children, notably the children's antibiotic Klacid, V1.ru reported on 5 February. Pharmacies in the city, including the Volgopharm chain, have confirmed a critical scarcity of this medication manufactured in Italy due to disrupted logistics. The report notes that this shortage compounds previous issues with medication availability in late 2023, especially impacting imported children's antibiotics. (V1.ru website, Volgograd, 05 Feb 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 11 Feb 24

title: Russia says border village cleared of Ukrainian 'militants'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Russian Defence Ministry has said that the village of Kozinka in Belgorod Region bordering on Ukraine has been completely cleared of Ukrainian "militants".
body:
"In the Belgorod direction, Russian units have completely cleared the settlement of Kozinka from the remnants of Ukrainian militants and continue to take measures to prevent the penetration of sabotage and reconnaissance groups of the VSU [Ukrainian Armed Forces into the border territory," Interfax news agency quoted the ministry as saying on 20 March.

"As a result of air strikes and artillery fire, the enemy lost up to 650 militants, two armoured combat vehicles and two Czech-made Vampire MRLS combat vehicles," the ministry added.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 1221 gmt 20 Mar 24

title: China, Iran, Russia warships conduct fire drills in Gulf of Oman
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Russian military news agency Interfax-AVN on 13 March

Russian, Chinese and Iranian warships have practised firing at sea and air targets as part of the Maritime Security Belt 2024 exercise in the Gulf of Oman, the Russian Defence Ministry said in a statement on Wednesday [13 March].
body:
"Warships of the three states have fired heavy machine guns and small-calibre naval artillery at sea and air targets simulating naval drones and UAVs," the statement said.

Russia's Varyag missile cruiser and Marshal Shaposhnikov frigate practised joint tactical manoeuvring and had a signals drill together with Chinese and Iranian colleagues, it said.

"Later today, the exercise participants will practise releasing a pirate-seized ship with the assistance of helicopters and deployed inspection teams," it said.

This is the sixth Maritime Security Belt international naval exercise. The first one took place in the Arabian Sea in 2018. Iran, China and Russia are the regular participants.

The Varyag missile cruiser is the flagship of the Russian Pacific Fleet. The Marshal Shaposhnikov is a Russian Pacific Fleet frigate upgraded to carry Kalibr cruise missiles, designed by Almaz-Antey's Novator Bureau.

Source: Interfax-AVN military news agency, Moscow, in English 0716 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: Russia, Iran, China to hold Gulf of Oman naval drills
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Russian military news agency Interfax-AVN on 11 March

A unit of the Russian Pacific Fleet led by the Varyag missile cruiser arrived at the roadstead of the Iranian port of Chabahar on Monday [11 March], the Russian Defence Ministry said.
body:
"The Russian ships will take part in the Marine Security Belt 2024 joint exercise, which also involves ships, boats and marine aircraft of the Iranian and Chinese navies," the ministry said.

"The practical stage of the exercise will be held in the Gulf of Oman in the Arabian Sea. The primary objective is to practise ensuring the security of maritime economic operations," it said.

"Besides the Varyag missile cruiser, the exercise will involve the Marshal Shaposhnikov destroyer, upgraded to a frigate, two warships and a supply vessel of the Chinese Navy, and over ten ships, boats and supply vessels and three helicopters of the Iranian Navy," the ministry said.

"Naval representatives of Pakistan, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Oman, India and South Africa will serve as observers," it said.

The exercise aims "to provide regional security for the common good," Iranian media quoted Iranian Navy Commander Shahram Irani as saying in February.

Iran has said that the drills will be completed by the end of the Iranian year, i.e. 19 March.

Russia, Iran and China have held similar exercises before. In particular, the exercises included live artillery fire.

Source: Interfax-AVN military news agency, Moscow, in English 1239 gmt 11 Mar 24

title: Russia to hold Yars strategic missile systems drill
snippet:
Text of report in English by privately-owned Russian military news agency Interfax-AVN on 25 March

An exercise involving Yars land-based mobile missile systems will take place as part of a comprehensive readiness check of the Irkutsk Division of the Russian Strategic Missile Forces, the Russian Defence Ministry said in a statement.
body:
"The exercise will focus on camouflaging Yars land-based mobile missile systems, countering existing and prospective air surveillance systems together with units and formations of the Central Military District, and the operations of a new detachment, a reconnaissance unit (using UAVs)," the statement said.

The exercise involves over 3,000 troops and around 300 pieces of hardware, it said.

Yars is a land-based and silo-based strategic missile system. Official information says it operates at a top range of 11,000 kilometres and carries multiple independently targetable reentry vehicles.

According to the statement, the key goals of the check include "the evaluation of the formation's current state and combat readiness level and the performance of commanding officers in ensuring that training year objectives are met" as key goals of the check.

Source: Interfax-AVN military news agency, Moscow, in English 1316 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: Russian weekly TV highlights: Putin, 'Nazi' Ukraine, nuclear again, more Macron
snippet:
Main themes on Russian TV weekly news review programmes on Rossiya 1, Channel One and NTV on 17 March

‘Reformatting of world order’
body:
On an election-themed night on Russia’s three main TV channels on 17 March, host Irada Zeynalova of NTV’s Itogi Nedeli (Results of the Week) spoke of “links in the same chain” (both “our elections”, “regarded in the West as a vote in support of the course that has been taken”, and those to come in the US and the EU). This, she said, is about “reformatting the world order”. Everything is viewed “through the same prism of the Ukrainian conflict by everyone”.

“That is to say, the entire system of global relations is now being tested. Everyone understands that in the end the world will definitely become different, a new alliance will be formed, new rules, a new order will begin to work. And that the international institutions that were created after World War II no longer work, or the treaties that everyone voluntarily promised to observe, precisely because they no longer solve the problems that emerge, and their opinion is appealed to only when it is convenient for politicians,” as per Zeynalova’s seemingly abstract commentary at the top of the news.

In the meantime, it was tonight’s news reviews that were reformatted as Vladimir Putin claimed his fifth term as Russia’s president. On NTV, Itogi Nedeli made an earlier start than usual, at 1850 Moscow time (1550 gmt), against its usual start time of 1900 (all Moscow time henceforth). Rossiya 1 brought forward its Vesti Nedeli (News of the Week), with Dmitry Kiselyov, by an hour, to start at 1900 rather than its usual 2000. At an hour and 55 minutes, the programme was shorter than usual, to make way for a version of election coverage in the form of an unscheduled Vesti bulletin for the next two hours.

Channel One’s “special” Vremya (Time) edition started at its usual time of 2100 but it extended its bulletin late into the night to include the latest speeches by Vladimir Putin, which took the programme into four-hour territory. Its veteran host Yekaterina Andreyeva was at the helm, not always smoothly, throughout the programme.

Early, pre-exit poll coverage

NTV’s Itogi Nedeli and Rossiya 1’s Vesti Nedeli were aired well before exit poll data was officially announced at 2100, which gave Putin a landslide share of 87% of the vote. Accordingly, their reports were confined to heavy hints from voters about the kind of candidate they would like to lead Russia in the next six years. “We need someone who will lead our country for the next six years. Someone who is decisive, who is courageous and who will bring us to victory,” a man captioned as ex-navy told NTV. 

The discourse claimed a high turnout and emphasised the importance of the vote as a manifestation of unity and consolidation in the face of external pressure and hostility. This was Dmitry Kiselyov of Vesti Nedeli, for example: “We need to understand the nature of such high civic activity. This, now, is a special election. In effect, it is a wartime one, as both missile salvoes and drone swarms head in our direction every day in the hope that they can disrupt the electoral process through intimidation. However, exactly the opposite has happened. People rallied and even those who had not done so before went to vote. Such a high turnout is the answer to all attempts to interfere with the election.”

The vox pop in the reports was monotone, not to say apparently scripted, as voters, to camera, expressed their sentiment in near-identical terms. Some recalled the hardship of the 1990s and by contrast invoked what they described as the many changes for the better in their lives now. Others professed their pride in Russia, apparently the envy of the world. Separately, voters in Russia’s “new regions” (such as Donbas and other occupied Ukraine) were given the floor to say they were happy to be back with Russia again.

Separate reports were fashioned to describe the vote in Russia’s border Belgorod Region, where voters were unafraid to be active even though it has been under continuous attack from Ukraine, as the story ran.

“The fact is that Russia has a very transparent and democratic electoral system, as international public observers note,” according to Rossiya 1’s summary of the state of affairs. 

Ukraine’s ‘terrorist tactics’

In the context of Belgorod and more generally, Ukraine was described as either a terrorist or Nazi “regime”, or both. On Rossiya 1’s Vesti Nedeli, Kiselyov used the slur “Bandera Nazi regime” repeatedly and pointedly throughout his programme. A start on this usage was made as Kiselyov looked back to his interview with Putin at the start of last week, to which he returned again and again during his programme. “It is important to realise the historical inevitability of the battle with the Bandera Nazi regime, which, with the support of the West, has encroached not only on its own Russians [in Ukraine], but also on Russia itself. And the Russians are today the largest divided nation in the world,” Kiselyov said. “If we abandon these people today, then tomorrow our losses may increase many times over, and our children will not have a future, because we will feel insecure. We will be a third or fourth class nation. No one will take us into account if we cannot protect ourselves. And the consequences could be catastrophic for Russian statehood,” Putin told Kiselyov. “The West also understands that for Russia this is a matter of life and death. They dream about the death of Russia. Hence all these insane quantities of weapons and money provided to the Bandera Nazi regime. They have even begun to discuss sending troops. Maybe we should also take an unconventional step and ask to send North Korean troops to help us? After all, the friendly DPRK has an army of more than two million, and we once helped North Korea a lot in the battle with America. Putin’s response was that on the one hand, he did not obviously rule out such a turn, but at the same time, there is no need to turn to North Korea now. We can handle it ourselves,” Kiselyov said. “But a categorical no was the response to the question whether it ever occurred to us, during difficult moments for the front last year, to use tactical nuclear weapons,” Kiselyov added.

As elsewhere, Channel One described what it framed as “attempted breakthroughs”, that is to say incursions into Russia from Ukraine by hostile forces, as an attempt to destabilise Russia during the presidential election. “Carried out by elite Ukrainian special forces along with foreign mercenaries, with armour and artillery support”, they were repelled. “As a result, hundreds of militants are dead, dozens of pieces of equipment destroyed, but the Russian border is still securely locked,” according to Channel One’s Yekaterina Andreyeva’s summary. “After this rout, the adversary switched to its usual terrorist tactics as it launched strikes against peaceful neighbourhoods, including with drones stuffed full of explosives,” it added.

Channel One went on to liken Ukraine to Nazi Germany, branding Kyiv “a Nazi regime” and “direct successor to Hitler's”, complete with a campaign of “mass terror”.

Over on NTV, the Belgorod raid was framed as an attempt at distraction amid bad news from the battlefield. “Militants have been trying to get into the Kursk region and Belgorod region like cockroaches since Tuesday. Ever since then, action has been taken to crush them like bedbugs,” the report remarked.

Escalation, nuclear again

As NTV’s Zeynalova continued to ponder the issue of escalation, she invoked US diplomat George F. Kennan’s 1997 op-ed as an argument against Nato’s expansion (“A Fateful Error”). This, she said, is “hybrid war, in which any methods are being used”, complete with “fakes” and “discussions about nuclear use” and “statements about an imminent retaliatory offensive”; all “a game of escalation according to Kennan’s logic of an escalation ladder”. She went on to quote an unspecified essay in Responsible Statecraft, with the apparent suggestion that it was time for the West to push Ukraine towards negotiations. What with US President Joe Biden’s new Iran sanctions waiver and Nato Deputy Secretary General Mircea Geoana‘s reported remarks about the years of tense relations with Russia to come, Zeynalova said, there is a chance for de-escalation. 

“Compared to statements about our strategic defeat, this may already mean something simple - there is a chance over the years to move away from the dangerous threshold with talk of nuclear use. If we use it, we will have a chance to find reasons to build new relationships. But, as Putin says, it takes two to tango,” Zeynalova said.

Here, on NTV, as on the other two channels, Putin’s assurances, in his interview with Kiselyov, that Russia is willing to negotiate about Ukraine provided Russia is given security guarantees were televised. 

Putin’s latest nuclear rhetoric, also in his interview with Kiselyov, also made an appearance, in which he said Russia was ready for nuclear war “from a military-technical point of view”. But other than a long extract from Putin himself televised on Vesti Nedeli, it was not especially dwelt on in any of the commentary. If anything, it seemed to be purposely played down. The phrase “from a military-technical point of view” was present in Kiselyov’s account of this point from his interview with Putin, but the words “[ready] for nuclear war” contained in the question’s wording were absent, replaced as they were with Kiselyov’s comment that this appertained to the status of Russia’s strategic missile forces. Over on NTV, meanwhile, these words were omitted altogether, its relevant commentary confined to what Putin said about the newness of Russia’s nuclear triad, even though elsewhere in its commentary, rebuttal appeared mixed with satisfaction at the effect of Putin’s latest nuclear outburst.

“American propaganda assigns the role of the first strike to Vladimir Putin. Therefore, everything he said in the interview about the possibility of using nuclear weapons became a real bomb shell, even though the Americans themselves were not uninvolved in whipping up this hysteria. CNN reported last week that Russia was planning a nuclear strike on Ukraine at the end of 2022 and that the United States itself was carefully preparing for the consequences. A little earlier, meanwhile, the United States convinced the whole world that Russia was about to use nuclear weapons in space,” NTV’s story ran.

More Macron, ‘mercenaries’

As over the previous couple of weeks, Russian TV’s news reviews continued to be preoccupied with French President Emmanuel Macron’s series of pronouncements on Russia’s war in Ukraine. There was extensive anti-Macron content especially on Rossiya 1 and NTV, plus a segment on Channel One.

Rossiya 1 was especially strident in its anti-Macron commentary. In his dispatch, inter alia, its Europe correspondent Mikhail Antonov described France’s ministerial duo of PM Gabriel Attal and Foreign Minister Stephane Sejourne as “the homosexual pair, Attal and Sejourne, completely controlled” by Macron (the word “homosexual” present in the broadcast version but mysteriously absent from media monitoring service Medialogia’s text transcript).

Apparent contrast was served up with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s caution, with his refusal to supply Ukraine with the Taurus long-range cruise missile. Nevertheless, the channels felt it necessary to amplify warnings against such an eventuality. Further claims of a Nato split on support for Ukraine provided an accompaniment.

In the same report, incongruously (given Russia’s actions), Antonov asserted that any Taurus supplies to Ukraine would amount to an act of “aggression against a foreign state”, any such German involvement also “prohibited” by its constitution.

On Channel One, it invoked a 2022 “Ukrainian propaganda” production, its gist “to frighten the Germans with computer simulation of an ostensible missile attack on the centre of Berlin” (cue part of the montage where a member of the public in front of the Brandenburg Gate ducks in fear as an object like a missile streaks low over her). The question the report went on to pose was: “What if Kyiv strikes Russian targets but the Germans get hit [in retaliation]?”
