Over on NTV, meanwhile, it discerned Macron’s attempt to walk back on some of his statements as he met Scholz and Polish PM Donald Tusk. “Perhaps to backtrack, on Friday in Germany, at a meeting with Scholz and Tusk, who had returned from Washington, Macron said that the [three] were not parties to the conflict and would never initiate escalation. Although Macron tried to present the alliance of the three countries as a single fist to fight Russia, there has been no talk of unity for a long time,” it said.

All this was combined with discourse about what was framed in unison as the use of “foreign mercenaries” by Ukraine, on the back of the Russian Defence Ministry’s claims. The reports’ usage was “soldiers of misfortune”, to convey the message of the inevitable fate that awaits them – death at the hands of the Russian military.

Source: BBC Monitoring in English 1600 GMT 17 Mar 24

title: Taliban say Afghanistan's neighbours not cooperating in combating drug smuggling
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Taliban have accused regional countries of failing to cooperate in the fight against drug smuggling and trafficking.
body:
"Countries should fulfil their responsibilities. They have not cooperated with the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. They have promised, but they have not taken practical action. Secondly, they should pay more attention to drug trafficking in their countries," the private Tolo News TV quoted Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid as saying on 17 March.

Mujahid's remarks were made in response to recent comments by Iranian and Tajik officials about the continued flow of drugs from Afghan territory.

"We have seized 4,450 tonnes of various drugs produced in Afghanistan... over the past five years," Tolo News TV quoted Eskandar Momeni - the secretary general of Iran’s Drug Control Headquarters - as saying.

Although several international organisations and commentators have voiced concerns over the past year about what they say is a rise in drug cultivation and smuggling out of Afghanistan, the Taliban have repeatedly rejected the reports, claiming that their 2022 national drug ban has been successful.

Source: Tolo News TV, Kabul, in Dari 1330 GMT 17 Mar 24

title: Ukraine intel suggests dead Russian troops can still 'vote'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukraine's military intelligence (HUR) does not rule out that officials in Russia will count "votes" from deceased, captured and missing Russian soldiers in the presidential election on 15-17 March.
body:
"Obviously the Russian 'electoral commissions' will try to increase the number of Putin's voters by attracting the so-called 'dead souls' to the 'voting'," the HUR said on Telegram.

Russian servicemen fighting in Ukraine can already vote without casting ballots at a polling station, making it easier for election officials to rig the election, it noted.

"According to the latest instructions from the main military-political directorate of the Russian Defence Ministry, the criteria for the identification of voters from among military personnel are simplified to the extent that there is no need for their physical participation in voting. And you don't need a passport or military ID to confirm your identity - a photocopy of the documents is enough", the HUR said.

According to the HUR, the Kremlin "is carrying out a whole set of measures for the fictitious holding of the so-called 'elections of the president of the russian federation'".

See also: Briefing: Russia holds presidential election in occupied Ukraine

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0806 gmt 15 Mar 24

title: Transnistrian TV says Moldova briefly detained Russian military journo
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Moldovan border guards have temporarily detained the correspondent of the Russian Defence Ministry's official Zvezda TV channel, Stanislav Ivashchenko, who arrived in Chisinau ahead of the 28 February Transnistrian congress of deputies, the government-funded First Transnistrian TV channel has reported in its main news programme Kak Eto Bylo.
body:
It claimed that Ivashchenko was forced to stay in a Chisinau hotel "until the congress was over" and then allowed to go to Transnistria.

"They asked me why I was going to Transnistria and whether I was planning to attend the congress. I said I might," Ivashchenko was shown saying in a studio of First Transnistrian TV.

He alleged that the borders guards explained their decision to detain him by saying that pro-European President Maia Sandu "will be watching and wondering why we allowed you to go to the congress".

The channel explained that Ivashchenko, a former resident of Transnistria, had two passports on him, Moldovan and Russian, "but Moldovan security officers took both away".

According to First Transnistrian TV, he was taken to a Chisinau hotel from the airport.

"I am to stay here until 1700 local time and then I will be allowed to go to Transnistria. The hotel is located at 44/1 Mihai Eminescu Street. I am in a deluxe room. It is a special room without windows. The officers of the Moldovan Security Service [SIS] are outside, near the door. It is possible that they are listening and recording everything I am saying," Ivashchenko was shown saying.

The channel explained that the Russian journalist was eventually allowed to go to Tiraspol and report about the congress. "Censorship at the hands of the Moldovan border guards did not work," it concluded.

Source: First Transnistrian TV, Tiraspol, in Russian 1900 gmt 4 Mar 24

title: Pakistan swears in newly elected Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's 19-member Cabinet
snippet: ISLAMABAD (AP)  The 19-member Cabinet of Pakistans newly elected Prime Minister Shahbaz Sharif was sworn into office on Monday and held its first meeting. The prime minister appointed several top government posts and promised to tackle the country's unrelenting economic crisis.
body:
Pakistani President Asif Ali Zardari administered the oath of office to the ministers at the presidential office in the capital of Islamabad, with Sharif in attendance. Sharif was elected as prime minister by the parliament on Sunday, a month after parliamentary elections and after his Pakistan Muslim League-N party formed a coalition with several allies.

Sharif held the same position from April 2022 to August 2023, when he replaced archrival Imran Khan, a former cricket star turned Islamist politician who was ousted in a no-confidence vote in the National Assembly.

Sharif's new government faces daunting challenges, including an unprecedented economic crisis, regular power cuts, near-daily militant attacks and a challenging relationship with neighboring Taliban-run Afghanistan.

In televised remarks, Sharif vowed to improve the country's economy and contain rising inflation and halt price hikes during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, when Muslims fast from dawn to dusk. Ramadan for most Muslim countries started on Monday.

Sharif appointed lawmaker Ishaq Dar as foreign minister and re-appointed Khawaja Mohammad Asif as defense minister. Mohsin Naqvi, who served as caretaker chief minister in the eastern Punjab province, was appointed interior minister while Attaullah Tarar was named information minister.

The post of finance minister went to Muhammad Aurangzeb. The minister for climate change is yet to be selected from among the remaining ministers.

Zardari was appointed president on Saturday by the newly elected parliament. His office is mostly a ceremonial role and he is Sharif's main ally. However, no one from his Pakistan Peoples Party has been appointed to the Cabinet. Zardari's son, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari, was foreign minister during Sharif's previous stint as premier.

On Sunday, police detained dozens of Khan's supporters while protesting alleged rigging in last months parliamentary elections, which the ousted politicians party claimed was aimed at blocking it from getting a majority. Election officials have denied the charge.

title: Top former US generals say failures of Biden administration in planning drove chaotic fall of Kabul
snippet:
WASHINGTON (AP)  The top two U.S. generals who oversaw the evacuation of Afghanistan as it fell to the Taliban in August 2021 blamed the Biden administration for the chaotic departure, telling lawmakers Tuesday that it inadequately planned for the evacuation and did not order it in time.

The rare testimony by former Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Mark Milley and U.S. Central Command retired Gen. Frank McKenzie publicly exposed for the first time the strain and differences the military leaders had with the Biden administration in the final days of the war. Two of those key differences included that the military had advised that the U.S. keep at least 2,500 service members in Afghanistan to maintain stability and a concern that the State Department was not moving fast enough to get an evacuation started.
body:
The remarks also contrasted with an internal White House review of the administrations decisions which found that President Joe Bidens decisions had been severely constrained by previous withdrawal agreements negotiated by former President Donald Trump and blamed the military, saying top commanders said they had enough resources to handle the evacuation.

Thirteen U.S. service members were killed by a suicide bomber at the Kabul airport's Abbey Gate in the final days of the war, as the Taliban took over Afghanistan.

Thousands of panicked Afghans and U.S. citizens desperately tried to get on U.S. military flights that were airlifting people out. In the end the military was able to rescue more than 130,000 civilians before the final U.S. military aircraft departed.

That chaos was the end result of the State Department failing to call for an evacuation of U.S. personnel until it was too late, Milley and McKenzie told the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

On 14 August the non-combatant evacuation operation decision was made by the Department of State and the U.S. military alerted, marshalled, mobilized and rapidly deployed faster than any military in the world could ever do, Milley said.

But the State Department's decision came too late, Milley said.

The fundamental mistake, the fundamental flaw was the timing of the State Department, Milley said. That was too slow and too late."

In a lengthy statement late Tuesday, the National Security Council took issue with the generals' remarks, saying that Biden's hard decision was the right thing to do and part of his commitment to get the U.S. out of America's longest war.

The president was not going to send another generation of troops to fight and die in a conflict that had no end in sight, the NSC said. We have also demonstrated that we do not need a permanent troop presence on the ground in harms way to remain vigilant against terrorism threats.

The statement said the president and first lady still mourn for those lost at Abbey Gate and are enormously proud of the men and women of our military, our diplomats and the intel community who conducted that withdrawal, the NSC said.

In the hearing, which was prompted by a lengthy investigation by the House Foreign Affairs Committee into the decisions surrounding the evacuation of Kabul, McKenzie spoke at length about his discomfort in how little seemed to be ready for an evacuation, even raising those concerns with Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin.

Evacuation orders must come from the State Department, but in the weeks and months before Kabul fell to the Taliban, the Pentagon was still pressing the State Department for evacuation plans, McKenzie said.

We had forces in the region as early as 9 July, but we could do nothing" without State ordering the evacuation, McKenzie said, calling States timing the fatal flaw that created what happened in August.

I believe the events of mid and late August 2021 were the direct result of delaying the initiation of the (evacuation) for several months, in fact until we were in extremis and the Taliban had overrun the country," McKenzie said.

Milley was the nation's top-ranking military officer at the time, and had urged President Joe Biden to keep a residual force of 2,500 forces there to give Afghanistan's special forces enough back-up to keep the Taliban at bay and allow the U.S. military to hold on to Bagram Air Base, which could have provided the military additional options to respond to Taliban attacks.

Biden did not approve the larger residual force, opting to keep a smaller force of 650 that would be limited to securing the U.S. embassy. That smaller force was not adequate to keeping Bagram, which was quickly taken over by the Taliban.

The Taliban have controlled Afghanistan since the U.S. departure, resulting in many dramatic changes for the population, including the near-total loss of rights for women and girls.

The White House found last year that the chaotic withdrawal occurred because President Joe Biden was constrained by previous agreements made by President Donald Trump to withdraw forces.

That 2023 internal review further appeared to shift any blame in the Aug. 26, 2021, suicide bombing at Hamid Karzai International Airport, saying it was the U.S. military that made one possibly key decision.

To manage the potential threat of a terrorist attack, the President repeatedly asked whether the military required additional support to carry out their mission at HKIA, the 2023 report said, adding, Senior military officials confirmed that they had sufficient resources and authorities to mitigate threats.

___

AP White House Correspondent Zeke Miller contributed to this report.

title: Uzbekistan seeks to invest in Afghan cement, power projects
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Uzbekistan is seeking to invest in cement and electricity production projects in Afghanistan, privately-owned Uzbek news website Daryo.uz reported on 12 March.
body:
"During a meeting with the Taliban's Prime Minister Mullah Hassan Akhund, Uzbek Foreign Minister Bakhtiyor Saidov said that Uzbekistan was planning to invest in the construction of a cement plant, coal production and 200 megawatt electricity generation from coal," the report said.

The Uzbek official had arrived in Kabul for talks with the Taliban administration the same day.

Saidov also told the Taliban prime minister that Uzbekistan "wants to share with the Taliban its experience in implementing economic and agricultural projects".

Speaking about the contruction of the Trans-Afghan railway, the Uzbek foreign minister said that a professional Uzbek delegation would arrive in Afghanistan soon "to review the technical work of this project".

For his part, Mullah Hassan Akhund said that his government was "ready to cooperate in implementing Uzbekistan's projects in Afghanistan".

Saidov also said, in a separate report posted on his Telegram channel on 12 March, that he had held talks with several oficials of Afghanistan’s interim government, including Acting Prime Minister Mullah Hassan Akhund, Acting Deputy Prime Minister Mawlawi Abdul Salam Hanafi, Acting Deputy Prime Minister Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, Acting Foreign Minister Mawlawi Amir Khan Muttaqi, Acting Interior Minister Mawlawi Sirajuddin Haqqani and Acting Minister of Trade and Industry Nooruddin Azizi. 

"We covered the broad agenda of cooperation in many areas. Paid a particular attention to boosting economic ties, creating the most favourable conditions for business communities to have better engagements with each other. We have rich and shared history, common traditions and future. There are many avenues we can jointly utilise," the Uzbek foreign minister said in English.

Another privately-owned news website Gazeta.uz said the following day that this was Saidov’s first visit to Afghanistan as foreign minister. "He was accompanied by other representatives of the Uzbek government and the private sector," it noted.

Source: Daryo.uz website, Tashkent, in Uzbek 1655 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Afghan TV discusses Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Afghan political commentators have condemned the IS-claimed attack in the Russian capital, calling for regional coordination against the "common enemy".
body:
The 22 March assault, which claimed the lives of over 130 people at a concert hall on the outskirts of Moscow, came a day after another IS-claimed bombing killed over 20 people in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar. Condemning the Moscow attack, the Taliban have called on the region to coordinate efforts against IS.

Speaking to Afghan Shamshad TV's Tawda Bahsona (Heated Discussions) talk show on 24 March, a Kabul-based analyst, Habibullah Janebdar reiterated the Taliban stance on the region's coordination, criticising regional countries for failing to recognise the ruling group and engaging in "proper" interaction with it.

"If there was coordination, such incidents would not have happened," he told Shamshad. "Neighbouring countries should learn a good lesson from such incidents and engage in full interaction with Afghanistan if they really want to work for peace for their citizens."

Janebdar lauded the Taliban fight against IS over the past three years of their return to power, saying that the group is preventing the threat to regional countries for free. 

Asked what assistance Russia should provide to the Taliban in the fight against IS, Janebdar put recognition of the ruling group as the first step that Moscow should take followed by encouraging Russian investments in the country, saying that internal shortcomings of the Taliban should be set aside.

When asked about Russia's recent hosting of anti-Taliban figures' conference, he advised Moscow to "learn a lesson from its past" in Afghanistan, saying: "Those pursuing good relations with Afghanistan make a gain, and those pursuing the policy of expansionism towards Afghanistan, be that the then policy of the Great Britain or tsarist Russia, have made a loss".

Another analyst from Moscow, Yahya Chaosh, accused France and the US of being behind the Moscow assault, which according to him was carried out by Tajik nationals, saying that Paris is "practically at war with Russia".

According to him, France has established close ties with Tajikistan through "fugitive" anti-Taliban former Afghan government officials, who he alleged have allied with IS's Khorasan branch to fight the Taliban.

Asked what are the objectives behind the attacks in Kandahar and Moscow, Chaosh described IS as a "common enemy created by Western intelligence to gain common interests in Afghanistan, Russia and other countries which oppose the policies of the United States of America".

Asked how regional countries would be able to fend off the IS threat, Chaosh stressed the need for intelligence cooperation between regional countries, including Afghanistan, saying he believed that "after his re-election, Russian President Vladimir Putin is determined to have very close relations with Afghanistan".

Another commentator, the US-based university lecturer Samsor Safi said: "I would like to condemn in the strongest terms the terrorist attacks in Kandahar and Moscow." He alleged that Tajikistan and Pakistan were involved in orchestrating both the Kandahar and Moscow attacks, suggesting that these assaults were conducted under the "direction of the West". He warned that the recent growing ties between Pakistan and Tajikistan could pose a "major threat" to the region.

"These two are going against the normal tide in the region, and this normal tide is the fact that the world has now become bipolar with Russia, China and India being in the East block… whilst Tajikistan and Pakistan are acting in contrary, which clearly shows that they are guided by the other side." 

He also called on regional countries to cooperate with the Taliban in eliminating the "common problem", saying: "The first thing Russia should do is to recognise the Afghan government, with China and Central Asia countries following suit."

According to him, regional countries should hould refrain from blaming the Taliban's internal policies and focus on regional cooperation against the "major threat" of IS.

Source: Shamshad TV, Kabul, in Pashto, 24 Mar 24

title: Afghanistan says mutual consent key to Central Asian water use
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Taliban government's acting minister of trade and industry, Hajji Nooruddin Azizi, has said that his country will cooperate with Turkmenistan and other Central Asian countries on the basis of the principles of mutual consent in transboundary water use, the pro-government Turkmen news website Orient.tm reported on 4 March.
body:
The Afghan minister made the remarks while addressing a Turkmen-Afghan business forum in the Turkmen capital of Ashgabat earlier in the day.

"In using transboundary water resources and building water facilities to improve the welfare of the Afghan people, Kabul will certainly be guided by the principles of mutual agreement, transparency and equality with neighbouring countries," Azizi said, as quoted by the website.

He specifically mentioned Turkmenistan, which he said has had friendly and good-neighbourly relations with Afghanistan for many years. He said that Turkmenistan had made a "genuine" contribution to Afghanistan's "social and economic" reconstruction.

In a separate report on 5 March, the pro-government Turkmen news website Infoabad.com said that Turkmenistan was in favour of cooperation in the use of transboundary water in accordance with international law.

"Our country advocates that water cooperation with neighbouring countries should be carried out in accordance with international law, on the basis of the principles of mutual respect, equality and transparency, in the spirit of traditional good-neighbourliness and brotherhood," the report said.

In March 2022, the Taliban government launched its controversial Qosh-Tepa Canal project. It will use water from the Amu Darya River that forms part of the border between Afghanistan and the Central Asian countries of Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. There are concerns that the project may exacerbate the acute water shortage across Central Asia.

Source: Orient.tm website, Ashgabat, in Russian and Turkmen 2050 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Several killed, wounded in blast in southern Afghan city of Kandahar
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Several people are feared dead in an explosion outside a bank in the southern city of Kandahar this morning (21 March), Afghan news outlets are reporting.
body:
The private Hasht-e Sobh online reported, citing sources, that 19 people had died and 20 others had been wounded.

The report said that the blast occurred at around 0900 local time (0430 gmt ) at the Shaheedan intersection in the provincial capital. It quoted sources "suggesting that the explosion took place amidst a gathering of Taliban fighters who had assembled to collect their salaries".

The private Khaama Press reported that "dozens" had been killed and injured.

However, the private Tolo News TV, quoting Asadullah Jamshid - a  spokesman for Kandahar Security Command - reported a much lower casualty figure, stating that only three people had died and 12 others had been wounded in the "suicide bombing".

Kandahar's Mirwais Hospital has been placed under heightened security measures, and the Taliban security forces have reportedly cut off mobile communication in the area.

No group has yet claimed responsibility for the blast.

Source: Hasht-e Sobh, Kabul, in Dari 0655 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Explosion reported at Taliban army base in east Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Local sources in Afghanistan’s eastern province of Logar have reported an explosion inside Talilban's 4th Brigade of Mansouri Army Corps 203 based in the province, the private Hasht-e Sobh website reported on 3 March.
body:
Sources have also confirmed that they heard an explosion in the base on the evening of 3 March, the website said.

Some other sources say the base was hit by a drone strike, it added.

However, the office of the Taliban’s governor for the province in a statement has rejected any drone attacks on the base.

Tajuden Soroush (@TajudenSoroush), a correspondent for the UK-based Afghanistan International TV, also reported the explosion in a post on X on 3 March, citing Hamasa Media. The Taliban are yet to comment on the report.

Source: Hasht-e Sobh, Kabul, 3 Mar 24

title: Pakistan security forces kill 10 militants in separate northwest operations
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistani security forces killed ten militants in two separate intelligence-based operations in the country's restive Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, widely-read daily The Express Tribune cited the military as saying on 9 March.
body:
The operations were conducted in the North Waziristan district bordering Afghanistan, said the military's media wing, the Inter-Services Public Relations.

"Interim Afghan Government is expected to fulfil its obligations and deny the use of Afghan soil by terrorists for perpetuating acts of terrorism against Pakistan," said the statement.

"Security forces of Pakistan are determined and remain committed to secure its borders and wipe-out the menace of terrorism from the country," it added.

Pakistan has consistently urged the interim Afghan government to boost border management measures on their side of the border, the ISPR said.

See: Briefing: Afghan Taliban yet to congratulate new Pakistan PM

Source: The Express Tribune website, Karachi, in English 0400 GMT 10 Mar 24

title: Indian daily says Moscow attack shows IS group on 'path to revival'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Influential Indian English-language daily The Hindu has said the Moscow concert attack indicated the Islamic State group is on a "path to revival", adding the group poses threat to the Eurasian region.
body:
“The group, which once controlled territories across Syria and Iraq, has now transformed itself into a traditional terrorist outfit that hides in chaos and strikes on the public. The back-to-back attacks pose a serious security challenge to the Eurasian region, especially for Russia,” the paper said in an editorial on 26 March.

Recent attacks including the latest one at the Crocus City Hall that killed 137 people on 22 March point towards the "terror capabilities" of the jihadist group, it said.

The jihadist group’s Afghanistan-focused Khorasan Province branch (ISKP or ISIS-K), established in Afghanistan’s Nangarhar province in 2015, rose to prominence after the Taliban’s return to power in 2021, the editorial noted.

Since then, ISK has targeted Afghanistan’s Shia minority and sought to build a network of cells with youths from Central Asia and Afghanistan’s Tajik and Uzbek minorities. 

“These networks are now gaining strength,” it said.

The group has been using anti-Russian and anti-Iranian propaganda to recruit members from Central Asia, Afghanistan and Pakistan.

It said Russian President Vladimir Putin will have to “plug the security loopholes”, adding countries should address the geopolitical conditions that help the IS regroup. 

“As long as the Taliban continues its Pashtun-only rule over a diverse, radicalised Afghanistan, and instability, wars and lawlessness prevail in parts of West Asia, groups such as the IS would continue to find avenues to grow and strike,” it said.

Source: The Hindu website, Chennai, in English 0911 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Taliban ministry says at least 60 dead in heavy snowfall in Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Taliban's Ministry of State for Natural Disaster Management said that at least 60 people had died due to heavy snowfall and cold weather in Afghanistan over the past 23 days, the private Tolo News TV reported on 13 March.
body:
Citing the ministry's spokesman Janan Saiq, the news channel added that 34 people had also been injured and more than 1,600 houses had been destroyed in the same period. 

"Our ministry, in collaboration with international organisations, has provided food, non-food, and cash assistance to 22,415 families across the country, and the process of assisting needy families is still ongoing," he said.

The Ministry of Public Works added that snowfall and storms had also blocked the crucial Salang Pass, which connects the northern Afghan provinces to Kabul, and several routes in Bamiyan, Ghor, Sar-e Pol, Nuristan, and Farah provinces.

Afghan news outlets had reported earlier this month that the provinces of Badakhshan, Balkh, Daikundi, Faryab, Ghor, Helmand, Kabul, Kandahar, Kapisa, Khost, Laghman, Nangarhar, Paktia, Paktika, Parwan, Samangan, Sar-e Pol, Takhar, Uruzgan and Zabul had been impacted by heavy snowfall and adverse weather.

Source: Tolo News TV, Kabul, in Dari 1330 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Pakistani official warns of terrorism threat from Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A senior Pakistani official has called on Islamabad to take bold and decisive action to combat terrorism threats emanating from Afghanistan, private Channel One (1TV) reported on 7 March.
body:
The Information Minister of Pakistan's Baluchistan Province, Jan Achakzai, claimed that three terrorists, who had recently entered the country from Afghanistan, have been arrested by Pakistani forces.

"Three terrorists who entered Pakistan from Afghanistan have been arrested with explosives, weapons, and hand grenades from Rawalpindi. The pleas for cooperation from the Afghan Taliban to control terrorism across the border, and all other efforts have fallen on deaf ears," the channel quoted Jan Achakzai.

The Pakistani officials also said that Islamabad agrees with the US's counterterrorism measures to prevent any recognition of the Afghan Taliban government.

Achakzai also said that families of the Taliban members residing in Pakistan must be repatriated to Afghanistan, and their properties should be confiscated.

However, some military analysts interviewed in the report said that greater regional and international efforts were needed to tackle terrorism in the region.

Speaking to the channel via a video feed, military analyst Sadiq Shinwari said: "The Islamic State [IS] group and other terrorist organisations have been and are a threat to the stability of Afghanistan and will remain a threat in the future as well."

"Eliminating these terrorist groups is the fundamental duty and responsibility of the Taliban's detective and intelligence bodies. However, there is an urgent need for regional and transregional coordination and consensus to contain and prevent the expansion of this group [Islamic State]," he added.

The caretaker Taliban administration has not commented on the report but has frequently expressed its commitment that Kabul will not allow anyone to use Afghanistan's territory against others.

Source: Afghanistan Channel One (1TV), Kabul, in Dari 1300 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of National Afghanistan TV news in Dari 1530 gmt 23 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on state-owned National Afghanistan TV on 23 March at 15:30 GMT

A. News headlines.
body:
B. Home news:

1. 0136 Prime Minister Mullah Mohammad Hassan Akhund has planted a tree on the premises of the Arg, the presidential palace, on the arrival of the New Year. Video shows the tree-planting ceremony.

2. 0218 The Taliban’s Foreign Ministry has condemned the “terrorist attack” in Moscow, calling it a blatant violation of all human standards. Video shows the building of the Foreign Ministry, gunmen purportedly firing at civilians. (Covered from X)

3. 0301 Acting Foreign Minister Amir Khan Muttaqi met with Mawlawi Sardar Ahmad Shakeb, the Taliban’s ambassador to Pakistan, today. Shakeb briefed the prime minister about his recent meetings with Pakistani authorities. The meeting also discussed recent developments in relations between the two countries. Video shows a picture of the meeting. (See combined MR of 3 and 4)

4. 0341 Sardar Ahmad Shakeb, the Taliban’s acting ambassador in Islamabad, had met with Asif Durrani, Pakistan’s special envoy to Afghanistan. The meeting discussed ways of addressing recent tensions in relations between the two countries, as well as the expansion of economic relations. A Taliban spokesman said the meeting was requested by Durrani. Video shows a picture of the meeting. Video shows a picture of the meeting, a Taliban spokesman and some commentators speaking.

5. 0618 The Interior Ministry says 23,000 operations were carried out against drug smugglers, closed 1,000 narcotics processing firms and arrested 10,000 people on drug-related charges last year. Abdul Matin Qani, a spokesman for the ministry, told RTA in an interview that police have had remarkable achievements in counter-narcotics efforts, and curbing crimes in the country.  Video shows Qani speaking. (Most parts previously covered, to be included in the Security Roundup)

6. 0845 Mullah Khairullah Khairkhwah, the Taliban’s acting minister of information and culture, says the caretaker administration works to ensure a safe environment for Afghan and foreign tourists across the country. Khairkhwah was speaking at the opening ceremony of the Tourism and Hotel Management Institute in Kabul.  Video shows Khairkhwah and some other officials addressing the opening ceremony.

7. 1204 Officials at the Interior Ministry say they have reclaimed 555 jeribs of state-owned land (one jerib equals 2,000 square metres) from usurpers and allocated it for use as a cemetery in Kabul. Video shows a spokesman for the ministry.

8. 1245 March 23 marks World Meteorological Day. The United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) has urged the people across Afghanistan to turn off their lights for at least one hour on Saturday night as a dedication to the Earth. Officials at the National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) say they have installed filters in apartments and industrial parks to minimise air pollution. Video shows a NEPA official and some people speaking, the text of a UNAMA statement.

9. 1537 Security officials have started installing security cameras in Pol-e Khomri, the capital of northern Baghlan Province. Video shows a security camera. (To be included in Security Roundup)

10. 1549 Passport Department officials in northeastern Kapisa Province say they have collected over 78 million afghanis in revenues from passport distribution in the past year. Video shows some employees of the province.

11. 1603 Two private banks have distributed food among needy families in Kapisa Province. Video shows some people and food packages.

12.  1614 Information and culture officials have held an Iftar - a fast-breaking evening meal - for dozens of young people and students in eastern Logar Province.

13. 1632 Heavy rainfall and flash floods have killed three people, destroyed several houses, and damaged thousands of jeribs of agricultural land in northern Fariyab Province. Officials say they have taken measures to support those affected. Video shows a spokesman for the provincial governor and some people speaking, flood hit areas.

14. 1855 Legal mine excavation has led to more job opportunities for thousands of people in northern Takhar Province. The Provincial Mines and Petroleum Department has issued gold panning licenses to dozens of people in some districts of the province. Locals welcome the move and say it can attract investment by more Afghan and foreign companies. Video shows some people panning gold, provincial officials and some people speaking.

15. 2127 Sweet pastry sellers and shop owners say sales have increased during Ramadan. They called on the government to help further expand their businesses. Video shows some workers of the sweets bakery speaking.

Source: National Afghanistan TV, Kabul, in Dari 1530 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Programme Summary of National Afghanistan TV news in Dari 1630 gmt 11 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on state-owned National Afghanistan TV on 11 March at 16:30 GMT

A. News headlines
body:
B. Home news

1. 0054 Taliban Prime Minister Mullah Mohammad Hassan Akhund has, in a message on the arrival of the month of Ramadan, called on human rights organisations to take action to end the violence in Gaza. The Taliban’s deputy spokesperson, Hamdullah Fitrat, says Mullah Hassan Akhund has also called for Palestinians. Video shows a picture of the Taliban prime minister, Fitrat speaking and pictures of some foreign dignitaries with parts of their Ramadan messages. (See combined MR of 1 and 2)

2. 0339 Mullah Mohammad Hassan Akhund has called on Afghan traders and citizens to help earthquake-hit people, returning Afghan migrants, and poor people during the month of Ramadan. Video shows a picture of Akhund, a Taliban spokesman and some religious scholars speaking.

3. 0611 Deputy Prime Minister Mawalwi Abdul Salam Hanafi has chaired a meeting of the commission for administrative affairs. The meeting discussed a proposed mechanism for amendments to the government budget. Video shows pictures of the meeting.

4. 0633 Mawlawi Abdul Salam Hanafi has chaired a meeting of the 12 committees set up to assess the problems of Afghan migrants. The meeting discussed the activities of separate committees, the number of returning Afghan migrants from various countries, and the need for shelters and aid for the migrants. Video shows pictures of the meeting.

5. 0729 Mawlawi Abdul Salam Hanafi has received Sheikh Mohammad Qasem Khaled, the governor of Nimruz Province. The meeting discussed the security, social, and economic situation in the province. Video shows pictures of the meeting.

6. 0813 Some Kabul residents complain about the high prices of basic commodities. In his message on the arrival of Ramadan, the Taliban’s prime minister has called on officials to control prices across the country. Video shows grocery stores, some people and officials speaking.

7. 1059 Diplomats at the Taliban-run consulate in Karachi say they have facilitated the release of over 4,000 Afghans from Pakistani prisons over the past two years. The Taliban’s consul general in Karachi says 150 more Afghan migrants are in jail in Pakistan’s Sindh state and that efforts are underway to release them. Video shows the consul general speaking, passenger buses.

8. 1302 Officials have donated food to 200 people with disabilities and families of martyrs in northern Panjshir Province. Video shows the aid distribution event.

9. 1316 A general knowledge competition about the life and personality of Prophet Muhammad has been held in northern Parwan Province. Video shows the participants of the seminar.

10. 1331 At least 150 young people have completed a three-month computer training course in Nili, the capital of central Daikundi Province. Video shows a gathering of the participants.

11. 1339 A power supply transformer has been installed in the capital of northern Sar-e Pol Province. Video shows the new transformer.

12. 1400 Officials at the Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development say 416 development projects worth 527 million afghanis have been completed and inaugurated in three districts of Kabul Province. Video shows the deputy minister of rural rehabilitation and development and the governor of Kabul cutting ribbon and speaking at the opening event.

13. 1644 Officials of the National Examination Authority (NEXA) say they have conducted dozens of exams over the past year. Speaking to RTA in an interview, Fazalhaq Hashemi, a NEXA spokesman, said they are working to modernise the exam questions bank. Video shows Hashemi speaking.

14. 1903 Officials in western Herat Province say 177 semi-development and cash-for-work projects have been completed in the province’s Zenda Jan and Kohsan districts. The projects include the construction of reinforcement walls and road gravelling. Video shows workers on construction sites, some officials and people speaking.

15. 2116 The provincial institute of higher education in Ghor has held an academic conference on the significance of the month of Ramadan. Video shows some provincial officials and lecturers speaking at the event.

2305 End of bulletin

Source: National Afghanistan TV, Kabul, in Dari 1630 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Samaa News TV show on recent militant attack, political tensions
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Nadeem Malik Live" hosted by anchor Nadeem Malik, a senior journalist and analyst, on moderate Samaa News TV in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 26 March 2024. The programme invites politicians and analysts to express their opinions on important issues.

Anchor Nadeem Malik said terrorism should be condemned no matter where it occurs in the world and noted incidents of terrorism have been taking place in Pakistan on a daily basis since the 9/11 attacks and thousands of civilians and military personnel have lost their lives due to this. He noted Chinese nationals were targeted in a militant attack on 26 March. He demanded this incident should be "strongly condemned" and elements behind the same should be traced.
body:
Malik said "political chaos" has been continuing in the country and the courts have been hearing back-to-back cases. He remarked neither the cases come to a conclusion, nor does the unrest and uncertainty in the country come to an end.

Malik spoke with Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Tariq Fazal Chaudhry and asked him who wants to damage Pakistan-China relations by attacking Chinese nationals. Chaudhry said the attack on Chinese nationals in Pakistan was very unfortunate. He noted China has significantly contributed to the development of Pakistan and is currently supporting Pakistan in construction of the Dasu dam. He remarked Chinese engineers had faced similar terror attacks in the area earlier as well but China's commitment to support Pakistan's development remains unwavering. He claimed there is evidence of Indian involvement in such acts in Pakistan and noted "anti-Pakistan elements" do not want to see stability in the country.

Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) politician Shehryar Khan Afridi said China is Pakistan's "time-tested friend" and has stood by the country in every situation. He was of the view that there should be zero tolerance on issues of national security. He termed India and Israel "the biggest permanent enemies of Pakistan" and said the country's enemies are working to exploit its "fault lines". He emphasised Pakistan needs to "build unity" and "put its own house in order". He insisted Pakistan should focus on improving relations with its neighbours and questioned why it is hostile towards the Taliban which was earlier in its favour.

Afridi complained political will and political leadership are nowhere to be seen at the moment when there is a need for Pakistan to engage with the world. He was of the view that there is a need to make a joint strategy by rising above party politics so that such incidents can be stopped.

Chaudhry said the government intends to engage all stakeholders but the opposition should also draw a line between fighting with political rivals and fighting against Pakistan. He emphasised Pakistan needs unity and consensus to resolve national issues and urged Afridi that his party [PTI] should show "the same sentiments" in the parliament and other relevant forums.

Afridi claimed he heard prisoners being tortured when he was in jail. However, he refused to talk about the torture that he faced. He argued security agencies are not able to focus on defending Pakistan's interests because they are involved in actions against political workers. 

Chaudhry "condemned" physical torture of prisoners. Talking about concerns expressed by the PTI regarding threats to Imran Khan's (PTI founder) life, he said it is the government's responsibility to ensure his security.

Speaking about a drugs case that was filed against PML-N politician Rana Sanaullah under the PTI government, Afridi said he would urge the chief justice of the Supreme Court, Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif and Chief of Army Staff Asim Munir to investigate who implicated Sanaullah in the case.

Source: Samaa TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1500 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Pakistan paper notes 'significant security risk' over militants from Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An editorial in English-language Pakistani newspaper Daily Times has highlighted the "significant security risk" posed by militants from Afghanistan, saying it has "long been a hotbed for terrorist activities".
body:
Daily Times is a moderate newspaper, which is generally critical of jihadist groups.

"Pakistan continues to make a case for across-the-border attacks from Afghanistan, asking the international community to take action and force the Taliban to cut off their ties with the militant organisations spreading havoc in all parts of the country," the paper said on 10 March. 

The editorial referred to the recent military operation where ten militants from Afghanistan were killed.

It lauded the security forces' efforts in protecting the borders and maintaining national security.

"But it can still not be overlooked how Afghanistan has long been a hotbed for terrorist activities, with various extremist groups finding safe havens within its borders," it said. 

"The close proximity of Afghanistan to neighbouring countries poses a significant security risk, as terrorists attempt to infiltrate and carry out attacks in these regions," it added.

"Terrorist organizations continue to exploit porous borders, seeking to establish sleeper cells and launch attacks within target countries," it further said.

Highlighting some of the challenges, the paper said that "the vast and often rugged terrain, coupled with the porosity of borders, makes it difficult to monitor and intercept infiltrators."

"Moreover, the presence of local populations and the complexities of cross-border relations further complicate the efforts," it added. 

In order to overcome these challenges, the editorial said that Pakistan needed "the support of the entire fraternity so that a deliberations table can be set up; those calling the shots in our western neighbour can be brought on board and we can collectively make efforts for a peaceful region."

See also: Afghan Taliban urge new Pakistani PM to 'take good steps' to improve ties

Source: Daily Times website, Lahore, in English 0700 GMT 11 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's PTV show on growing cases of militancy
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Riasat" (The State), hosted by anchor Shahzad Raza on state-owned PTV News in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 28 March 2024. The programme provides analysis and views of experts and politicians on important news of the day.

Anchor Shahzad Raza commented the forces which are working against the interests of Pakistan are based abroad and their facilitators are active inside the country. He said Pakistani security forces and intelligence agencies have remained vigilant and have "foiled numerous attempts" of militant attacks. Questioning how the "enemy" sitting abroad is able to carry out such actions, he claimed there are elements in Pakistan who "act as tools in the hands of the enemies".
body:
Raza asked defence analyst Ijaz Malik who has been facilitating the country's enemies. Malik said it is not a new phenomenon that some people become "agents of the enemy states or non-state actors" for personal or group interests. He added "fifth-generation warfare" has many dimensions and those involved in it never get to know the real objectives. He further said those elements are "brainwashed by their handlers" who use issues which are "sellable", for example, religion can be used to motivate any person.

Commenting on the recent attacks targeting Chinese nationals and the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC, mega development project) projects, Malik said it should be seen who are the likely beneficiaries of these attacks. He noted if the Chinese are targeted, it would put a question mark on continuity of the projects they were working on and would also have an impact on the relations between the two countries. He questioned how foreign investors would come to Pakistan if such attacks continue.

Raza asked Munawar Hasan, an expert on international affairs, whether people involved in militancy can be convinced through dialogue that they are following the wrong path. Hasan said, "In the past, we tried holding dialogue, yet these elements have existed and have been attacking Pakistan's vital and strategic interests". He emphasised Pakistan needs a "two-pronged strategy", which means diplomacy should continue with Afghanistan and "kinetic force should be used to maintain deterrence" within Pakistani borders. He noted the Pakistani armed forces are a conventional force, while "terrorists engage in guerrilla warfare". He expressed the view that "fifth-generation warfare" is being carried out by those who do not want connectivity in the region and are "enemies of the CPEC".

Defence analyst Waqar Khan said when the Taliban government took over [in Afghanistan], there was confidence that there would be stability in Afghanistan as the Afghans would be in the government after the withdrawal of the Unites States (US), but unfortunately like all other Afghan governments in the last 40 years, the Taliban government also believes that it can "draw some concessions by using terrorism as a tool of policy". He noted the previous Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) government tried to give them some concessions but the Taliban had a "greater design". He mentioned in a recent video clip of a Taliban leader, he can be seen talking about "international jihad" and "expansion of war", which reflects "greater designs" of the Taliban. He claimed "India has also jumped in" after which attacks on Pakistan from Afghanistan have increased. He was of the view that terrorism cannot be used as a "policy tool" for very long.

Malik was of the view that militants have not been eliminated completely because the environment of the "nurseries in which they are nurtured" has not changed. He insisted unless an alternate source of livelihood, social uplift and sense of well-being is provided, these people would remain vulnerable to "any kind of recruitment". He recalled special economic zones and large-scale development was promised but has not been delivered, so the position of Afghanistan has remained unchanged.

Hasan said Pakistan will have to rely on its own resources in its fight against militancy and should seek cooperation from alternative centres of power at the regional level. He noted the Taliban's decision-making has been weak as they are still in the "guerrilla warfare mode". He claimed investments from China and Turkey have given the Taliban confidence and they have started thinking that they can pressurise Pakistan, but they cannot do so.

Hasan criticised the US policy on Afghanistan and said due to "contradictory" international policies, "American influence has been eroding all around the world" and an "anti-US sentiment" has been rising. He argued Pakistan had supported the US in its war against terror, so it should be supporting Pakistan at the time when it is facing threats from militants. He remarked if the US does not cooperate, Pakistan would "obviously look for alternative options".

Source: PTV News, Islamabad, in Urdu 1500 GMT 28 Mar 24

title: Taliban claim surge in media outlets, tourism in Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Afghan Taliban de facto government's Ministry of Information and Culture has announced that around 300 media outlets are currently registered with the ministry and functioning, the Taliban-controlled state-run National Afghanistan (RTA) TV reported on 24 March.
body:
Talking to the channel, Qari Habib Ghofran, a spokesman for the ministry, said that 25 new outlets have started functioning and 20 media rights groups obtained licenses in the past year alone.

"A total of 25 audio, visual and print media outlets have obtained licenses for operations from the Ministry of Information and Culture. They include three television channels, 17 radio stations and five websites," Ghofran said.

The spokesman also said that there had been an uptick in tourism and an influx of foreign tourists in Afghanistan in recent years despite the world's propaganda against the Taliban administration.

Ghofran further said that over 5,000 foreign tourists visited historical sites in the country last year.

Source: National Afghanistan TV, Kabul, in Dari 0000 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Iran alleges rise in synthetic drugs trafficking from Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran has voiced concern over the reported increase in synthetic drug trafficking from Afghanistan despite the Afghan Taliban's claims that trafficking of illicit drugs to Iran has reduced by 90 per cent, private Channel One (1TV) reported on 6 March.
body:
Iskandar Momeni, the secretary-general of Iran's Drug Control Headquarters, said that there has been no significant decline in drug trafficking from Afghanistan into Iran, the report said.

"Taliban officials, who visited Iran, said during talks [with Iranian officials] that poppy cultivation and opium production had decreased. They said that narcotics are in the warehouses, and once they run out, drug trafficking into Iran may be reduced by 90 per cent. However, Iran is witnessing an increase in production of industrial drugs, in particular methamphetamine and crystal, in the country," citing Iranian media outlets channel quoted Momeni as saying.

Some political and military commentators interviewed in the report said that Afghanistan is no longer the origin of opium production and that Iran's claims of an increase in poppy production in Afghanistan are baseless.

"The main origin and source of opium production in Afghanistan, which is poppy cultivation, has been destroyed. I do not think 90 per cent of drugs are trafficked into Iran because large-scale drug trafficking from Afghanistan has ceased," Mohammad Seyal, another commentator, told the channel.

"The Iranian people and government's claim about drug trafficking in Afghanistan is wrong. We have seen that over the past two years and a half, the Islamic Emirate [the Taliban administration] has been carrying out a strong fight against the production and cultivation of narcotics in Afghanistan. There could be a possibility that Afghanistan's drugs were seized in Iran. I want to say that, in the past, most of the narcotics were transferred to Pakistan and then to other countries. May be, it was stored there and transferred to Iran via Pakistan," military analyst Kamran Aman said.

In the meantime, the Interior Ministry of the Taliban administration has said that they have cleared nearly 200,000 acres of land for poppy cultivation in several provinces, the channel added.

The Taliban administration has regularly rejected reports on the increase in poppy cultivation in Afghanistan, urging the international community to help support Afghanistan in eradicating the drugs, the TV report added.

Source: Afghanistan Channel One (1TV), Kabul, in Dari 1300 GMT 6 Mar 24

title: TV talk show discusses Pakistan's plan to resume Afghans' deportation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Afghan commentators appearing on the private Ariana News TV's Tahawol (Change) debate programme on 20 March discussed Pakistan's policy towards Afghanistan and the former's decision to resume the deportation of Afghan migrants lacking proper documents.
body:
"We will deport all the migrants, including Afghans, who do not have legal and migration documents. Nobody can stay in Pakistan without valid documents. We also seek to accelerate the process further," the channel showed Pakistani Minister of Interior Affairs Syed Mohsin Raza Naqvi saying, with superimposed translation into Dari.

Meanwhile, Taliban de facto authorities have said that they want Afghan refugees to return to the country voluntarily.

"We want the refugees to return to Afghanistan. We encourage them to voluntarily come to Afghanistan so that they are not coerced to do so… The migrants must return, and efforts should be made that they are no longer used as a pressure tool by countries," the channel showed Taliban Spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid saying. 

When asked why Pakistan has decided to resume the deportation of Afghan refugees, political commentator Bashir Hatif said: "There is no doubt that Pakistan wants to put continuous pressure on Afghanistan as it is fully aware of the current situation, including the humanitarian and economic crisis, in Afghanistan. Given that, Pakistan is trying to find different pressure tools against Afghanistan."

"There is no doubt that the commencement of the process of the migrants' expulsion can create challenges and problems for Afghanistan. But the question is why Pakistan resorts to such measures. We all know that Pakistan has some long-pending demands. It has also made new demands over the past two and a half years [since the Taliban came to power in Afghanistan in August 2021]," Hatif said further.

About Pakistan’s demands from Afghanistan, he said: "One of the main demands is that Afghanistan should always follow Pakistan in its foreign policy. I want to say, in other words, that Pakistan has been and is trying to manage Afghanistan's foreign relations."

Hatif added that Pakistan has been marginalised on the issue of Afghanistan. 

"Qatar has taken the position of Pakistan [regarding Afghanistan]. Qatar has been playing an active role in mediating between Afghanistan and the international community. Afghanistan, the US and all countries are now paying more attention to Qatar than Pakistan," he told the programme. 

Joining the programme online, Switzerland-based political commentator Rahmat Hassan said that Pakistan is seeking to turn Afghanistan into its "fifth province."

Hassan said: "Pakistan has a long history of differences with the people and the nation of Afghanistan. Since Pakistan was separated from the undivided India [in 1947], its relations with Afghanistan have been sour, and the recent airstrikes [in eastern Afghanistan] are not something new. Over the past 50 years, it has carried out bombardments on Afghanistan. What does Pakistan want from the people of Afghanistan? Pakistan's main and strategic goal is to turn Afghanistan into its fifth province."

When asked why Pakistan has always voiced concern about security threats emanating from Afghanistan, Hassan said: "Neither Pakistan nor Iran want Afghanistan to have a powerful centralised government and a powerful nation that can stand on their own feet. They have always wanted Afghanistan to be in peril and be a servant as well as a puppet."

Commenting on the deportation of Afghan refugees, US-based political pundit Zaman Stanikzai, who joined the debate online, said: "If the refugees return to Afghanistan from Pakistan, Pakistanis will not have any tool to pressure Afghanistan or the Afghan government."

Stanikzai said that the Taliban administration should spare no effort to gain the full support of Afghan nationals to get rid of Pakistan's continuous pressure.

"The Taliban need to win people's trust and support. They should also demonstrate flexibility in their policy towards women [in Afghanistan]. As far as the nation supports the Taliban, they should not be worried about anything," concluded Stanikzai. 

Source: Ariana News TV, Kabul, in Dari and Pashto 1400 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Afghan Herat customs office ensuring goods flow during Ramadan - TV
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of Afghanistan's customs office at Islam Qala in the western province of Herat has said that his department is ensuring the flow of goods from Iran during Ramadan, the state-run National Afghanistan (RTA) TV reported on 14 March.
body:
The customs office is maintaining normal working hours during Ramadan to ensure the smooth flow of essential goods into the country and to prevent any shortages of commodities during the holy month, the report said. 

Mawlawi Mohammad Hamed Ahmad, the head of the customs office in Herat, emphasised his department's commitment to serve traders and visitors efficiently even beyond normal working hours.

"We work 16 hours [daily] at the Islam Qala border customs office. Starting from the 1st of Hamal [21 March 2024] - Nowruz - we will extend working hours to 24 hours… We do not postpone [administrative] work for traders or their representatives, and other visitors, even when official working hours are over," Ahmad told the channel.

As reported by the state broadcaster, traders and investors in Herat have expressed satisfaction with the services provided by the customs office.

Speaking to the channel, Abdul Mana Bashardost, a trader, praised its facilities and the dedication of the department's employees to serving traders without stopping work before finishing the day's tasks.

The report also highlighted a significant increase in customs revenues in Herat since the Taliban's return to power.

Source: National Afghanistan TV, Kabul, in Dari 1630 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of National Afghanistan TV news in Dari 1630 gmt 2 Mar 24
snippet:
Summary of programme broadcast on state-owned National Afghanistan TV on 2 March at 16:30 GMT

B. Home news:

1. 0145 Deputy Prime Minister Mawlawi Abdul Kabir has met with Alain Deletroz, the director general of the Geneva Call, and Alexander Munafo, the head of the organisation’s global engagement. title: Pro-ISKP outlet celebrates IS attack in Moscow, warns of more to come
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A high-profile pro-Islamic State group (IS) media outlet has commented on the Moscow concert hall attack, describing it as retaliation for losses suffered by IS due to Russian military activity in Syria.
body:
It also emphasised that civilian citizens of "belligerent" countries are legitimate targets for jihadist violence.

The al-Azaim media group made the comments in a 30-page Pashto-language statement titled "Moscow Attack: Mourning and Fear of Militias", which was published on 25 March via pro-IS accounts on Telegram and RocketChat.

Other than the Syria angle, the statement did not offer new or original information about the attack or its perpetrators. 

But it did warn that ISKP attacks will not be limited to Afghanistan and will target all countries supporting the Afghan Taliban, singling out China, Iran, and Russia for further attacks.

The Taliban is a staunch enemy of ISKP and is generally the primary target of al-Azaim's rhetoric. 

The media group operates as an unofficial mouthpiece for IS's Khorasan Province branch (ISKP), which operates in Afghanistan and parts of north-western Pakistan.

Justifying attacks on civilians

In its statement, al-Azaim expressed jubilation over the loss of civilian lives in the assault on the concert hall in Moscow on 22 March. The attack, claimed to have been carried out by IS militants, resulted in the deaths of approximately 140 people and left over 180 wounded. 

Al-Azaim endorsed the targeting of Russian civilians, justifying it as retaliation for the deaths of IS members and their families in Russian military operations in Syria. 

This appeared to echo IS's official line on 23 March, when a statement by the group indicated that the attack was revenge against Russia, without saying over which issue.

The latest al-Azaim statement also argued that Russian citizens' tax contributions facilitated their military's actions against IS in Syria, suggesting that these citizens thus tacitly supported such operations.

It is probable that al-Azaim's justification for civilian killings is meant to convey the message to IS supporters that killing the citizens of any country participating in the war against IS anywhere is warranted.

A central theme in the statement was challenging the Taliban's alleged suggestions that ISKP receives covert support from Pakistan and Tajikistan.

It countered that if ISKP had alliances with Pakistan or Tajikistan, it would not target those countries. And yet, it continued, the group has carried out major recent attacks in Pakistan, citing a July 2023 suicide bombing in Bajaur and an IED attack in the same region in January.

Al-Azaim also highlighted the 2022 ISKP missile attack on Tajikistan's border forces from Afghan soil as contradictory to the Taliban's claims.

Moreover, the statement rejected the assertion from Taliban supporters that ISKP serves US interests. It cited the death of US soldiers in an ISKP suicide attack at Kabul Airport in August 2021, along with the pivotal role of US forces in dismantling ISKP's territorial grip in Kunar and Nangarhar provinces, as evidence refuting these claims.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Pashto 1200 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Azerbaijan ambassador says Baku, Kabul enjoy friendly relations
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Azerbaijan's ambassador in Kabul, Ilham Mohammadov, has announced that Baku has opened its embassy in Kabul, indicating that the two countries share amicable relations, the private Tolo News TV channel reported on 22 March.
body:
He made the remark in a meeting with the Taliban government's deputy prime minister for administrative affairs, Abdul Salam Hanafi, in Kabul. 

Mohammadov stated that Baku and Kabul support each other's independence and pursue policies of non-interference in their respective affairs.

The Taliban government's chief spokesman, Zabihullah Mujahid, gave the following brief about the meeting: "At the meeting, they discussed bilateral relations between the two countries. The Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan [Afghan Taliban de facto government] has expressed readiness to expand diplomatic and economic relations with Azerbaijan."

Political commentators said that the Taliban government needs to improve and expand its ties with the world.

"Any country that opens its embassy or plays a role in Afghanistan benefits the people of Afghanistan and the Islamic Emirate," said Salim Paigir, a political commentator.

Over the past month, delegations from various countries have visited Afghanistan and held talks with representatives of the Taliban government. Some commentators interviewed by the channel discussed the significance of the Taliban administration's diplomatic meetings.

"Regional countries fear an attack from Afghanistan; therefore, they share their concern with the Islamic Emirate. I think that regional countries want to see an inclusive government in Afghanistan. Therefore, they are encouraging the Islamic Emirate to take steps in this regard," opined Mohammad Sangar Amirzada, an expert on international affairs.

"The Islamic Emirate should open schools for Afghan women and girls; this is what the Afghan people want to see. The world is also eager to see this. Once it meets this demand, the world will engage with the Islamic Emirate," said Sayed Farhad Akbari, another commentator.

The Taliban government had previously announced that it would send its diplomatic personnel to Azerbaijan in the coming days.

Source: Tolo News TV, Kabul, in Dari 1330 GMT 22 Mar 24

title: Programme summary of National Afghanistan TV news in Dari 1630 gmt 10 Mar 24

B. Home news:

title: Taliban on 'alert' following Pakistani airstrikes in Afghanistan - TV
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Following Pakistani airstrikes in Afghanistan's southeastern border provinces of Paktika and Khost and the retaliatory attacks by the Taliban on Pakistani border posts, the Taliban caretaker administration has announced that the Taliban defence and security forces are on an alert "to defend the country against invaders", the state-run Taliban-controlled National Afghanistan (RTA) TV reported on 19 March.
body:
Speaking to the state broadcaster, Hamdullah Fitrat, the Taliban government's deputy spokesman, warned Pakistan of consequences if the air strikes continued. 

"The Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan [Taliban government] is ready to defend its territory against any aggression. Our defence and security forces have targeted Pakistani army's posts and bases since yesterday," the channel showed Fitrat as saying. 

The Taliban spokesperson's remarks were also echoed by commentators interviewed by the channel, who criticised Pakistan for allegedly destabilising Afghanistan.

"Pakistan has either attacked Afghanistan in some way, or it has paved the way for other invaders to pose threats to the security and the internal unity [of Afghans]," Mohammad Idris Zazai, a political affairs analyst, told the channel.

"If Pakistan violates Afghanistan's air space, it is the responsibility of the current government of Afghanistan to give a stronger reply to the Pakistanis and defend Afghanistan's sovereignty based on the national interests of Afghanistan," Zalmay Afghanyar, another political analyst, told the channel.

Five women and three children were killed in Pakistan's air strikes in Afghanistan's Khost and Paktika provinces, the channel said.

Source: National Afghanistan TV, Kabul, in Dari 1630 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Taliban say 1,700 mineral deposit sites identified in Afghanistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Afghan Taliban de facto government's Ministry of Mines and Petroleum has announced that 1,700 small and large-scale mineral deposit sites have been surveyed and identified across Afghanistan over the past year, the Taliban-controlled state-run National Afghanistan TV channel reported on 15 March.
body:
Homayun Afghan, a spokesman for the ministry, told the channel that engineers deployed by the ministry have surveyed and identified 1,600 small and big mineral deposits across the country, adding that mining and extraction of major copper, gold, marble, lead, cement, oil and gas deposits have been contracted to firms from China, Iran, Qatar, and Britain.

"During our latest exploration conducted across various regions of Afghanistan, close to 1,700 mineral deposits have been surveyed and identified. These are not final figures, though. More mineral deposits have been found in different parts of Afghanistan," he told the channel.

Mr Afghan added that the ministry has signed contracts with Afghan firms to extract 200 smaller nephrite, chromite, chalk, marble and fluoride mines, with the total cost of the contracts amounting to eight billion afghanis (around 112 million dollars).

"Nearly 200 mineral deposits have been discovered, identified, surveyed and contracted out. They have deposits of mineral resources like nephrite, chromite, fluoride, marble, and chalk spread across various provinces. These agreements have been signed with domestic companies," he elaborated.

The spokesman underscored a notable achievement in revenue generation, saying that over 17 billion Afghanis (238 million dollars) had been earned in revenue from mining activities over the past year.

Source: National Afghanistan TV, Kabul, in Dari 1630 GMT 15 Mar 24

title: TV talk show analysts call for Afghans' unity against Pakistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The recent air strikes by Pakistan in southeast Afghanistan continue to elicit reactions among Afghan commentators who have called on the Taliban to strengthen domestic unity against the neighbouring country.
body:
Speaking on the private Shamshad TV's Tawda Bahsona (Heated Discussions) talk show on 19 March, Kamran Aman, a Kabul-based commentator and former colonel, described the strikes in Khost and Paktika provinces as a "blatant and shameless aggression by the Pakistani army".

"The Afghan nation should give a decisive response to it," he said.

Aman called on clerics to issue a "fatwa [islamic verdict] of jihad against the enemy", saying that "it is obligatory on the entire nation to defend their land and dignity."

"Aggression should be responded with aggression," the commentator further said.

When asked against whom jihad is obligatory, Aman said: "Against any country which encroaches into Afghan territory and kills Afghans - even if it is one Afghan."

He lauded the Taliban's retaliatory ground attacks but called on the group to set up a national committee to strengthen unity and prepare plans to tackle future attacks by the neighbouring country.

"Yesterday, they did what they could – Well done. I wish I had been there at that time as well. We are awaiting the order of the honourable defence minister to say - Afghans, come out for the war," he said, answering a query about his thoughts on the Taliban's retaliation.

In reply to a question about the consequences for Pakistan, if it repeats attacks in the future, the former colonel said: "It would have a very heavy price for the Pakistani nation – a price they would end up paying for the actions of a few of their government authorities."

Commenting on the military capability of the two countries, Aman lauded the "high morale" of Taliban forces, saying that Pakistani forces have "rockets but lack faith and morale".

Another Kabul-based commentator, former Taliban ambassador to Pakistan Mawlawi Abdul Salam Zaeef, also called for unity among Afghans but suggested diplomatic efforts to resolve the issue with Pakistan.

"We should never get into a fight with Pakistan," he said. "There must be a reciprocal reaction to an action, but not more than that. Moreover, efforts should be stepped up for national unity," he added.

Zaeef warned Islamabad to "realise that Afghanistan is not a geography which would submit to others' orders", adding: "The use of force is a futile attempt here. There must be mutual respect instead."

He blamed the current economic crisis in Pakistan on its "despotic army", saying that it has political and security issues with all its neighbours, including Afghanistan, India, Iran and China.

The former Taliban diplomat further said that by attacking Afghanistan, the "despotic" Pakistani army "wants to divert Pakistani people's attention from its failures, incompetence and political instability in Pakistan".

When asked about the international community's "silence" on the Afghan-Pakistan tensions, Zaeef accused other countries of trying to "use" the deterioration of relations between the neighbouring countries as a tool to put pressure on the ruling Taliban, but advised the group to contemplate about its priorities, including engagement with the world, education and "nation building".

Asked whether Pakistan would change its policy towards Afghanistan, he said that Islamabad's approach towards Kabul will "never change as long as Pakistan's military is its policy-maker."

A commentator from Germany, Torialay Zazai, also urged the Taliban to strengthen internal unity and "encourage national mobilisation against Pakistan."

He called on the Taliban leadership to "retaliate to one bullet with 10", adding that "now the situation is not for dialogue". Zazai accused Pakistan of "trying to show to the world that there is no stability in the region", saying that Islamabad "wants to extract money from the international community" on the Afghan issue.

"If the world wants to eliminate terrorists in the world, they should partition and isolate Pakistan. This will free the world of terrorism," he further said.

Another Kabul-based commentator, Shahzada Massoud, also called on the Taliban to strengthen national unity.

"The most urgent thing the Islamic Emirate [Taliban administration] needs to do at the current juncture is to convene a traditional Loya Jirga [traditional grand assembly of elders] and decide on all issues, including engagement with the international community," the commentator said.

According to him, the ruling group should do some of its "homework", including lifting their ban on women's education, which he believed was crucial for their international recognition. Describing Pakistan's air strikes as a "blatant violation of Afghanistan's national sovereignty", Massoud said: "This was not their first attack, neither would it be the last. Pakistan has often shelled Kunar, Paktia, Paktika."

"Pakistan is weak at the moment, although we wish it was not so. Its economy is stagnating, and political stability is worsening. In other words, what remains of Pakistan now is just its skeleton," he said, answering a question about the consequences for Pakistan.

Source: Shamshad TV, Kabul, in Pashto 1740 GMT 19 Mar 24
