"The Embassy is monitoring reports that extremists have imminent plans to target large gatherings in Moscow, to include concerts, and U.S. citizens should be advised to avoid large gatherings over the next 48 hours," the US Embassy says in the statement.

The statement contains no other details on the possible terror acts.

Source: LETA website, Riga, in English 0830 gmt 8 Mar 24

title: Colombia makes largest cocaine seizure in nation's Caribbean area so far in 2024
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Colombia's Navy carried out the largest seizure of cocaine in the Colombian Caribbean so far in 2024 - over 3.3 tonnes valued at 113m US dollars - according to a 26 March posting on the official X account of Admiral Francisco Cubides Granados, the commander of the Colombian Navy.

title: Colombia court convicts former presidential candidate Hernandez for corruption
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A court in Colombia convicted former presidential candidate Rodolfo Hernandez for corruption, state news network RTVC reported on a post in social media platform X on 14 March.
body:
Hernandez, who narrowly lost the presidency in 2022 to the current head of state Gustavo Petro, was found guilty of irregularities committed when he was mayor of the north-eastern Colombian city of Bucaramanga.

The post by RTVC said that "irregularities were found in a consultancy contract subscribed with the Bucaramanga Municipal Sanitation Company" when Hernandez was mayor of that city, a position he held between 2016 and 2019.

In 2022, Hernandez, then a relatively unknown provincial politician, jumped to national prominence when he launched an independent presidential bid strongly based on social media, in which he promised to fight against corruption. 

The self-described "Colombian King of TikTok", trading on his image as an outsider who said he would defy traditional political elites, became the campaign's biggest surprise, and in the first round of the presidential election, held in May 2022, was the runner-up, obtaining around 28% of the vote. 

Since no candidate obtained more than 50% of the vote during this first round, Petro and Hernandez went on to a runoff election held on 19 June 2022, in which Petro prevailed, becoming the country's first-ever head of state.

The media report by RTVC said that the judge in the Hernandez case would announce his sentence on 13 June.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Spanish 0000 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Uyghur militant group in Syria announces senior appointments, urges unity
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Uyghur militant group, Turkistan Islamic Party (TIP), has issued a statement announcing two senior appointments in its Syria branch, and calling for unity.

title: BBCM Iran Watchlist for 25 March
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Iranian broadcast, press and social media sources

(As Iran marks Nowruz, New Year, holidays, newspapers are not being published. Most newspapers are expected to resume publication on 2 April.)
body:
Officials condemn Israeli 'siege' of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza

Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Nasser Kanani yesterday condemned a week of an Israeli "siege" of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza, saying that Israel was adding "another shameful page to its disastrous history and dark list of crimes".

International-facing English-language Press TV highlighted reports that Israeli troops were "raping Palestinian women before killing them" at the hospital.

See: Briefing: Anger online after Palestinian said Israel forces raped Gaza women

Kanani repeated these claims in his statement, calling on the international community to take "effective and decisive steps" to set up an international investigative group to "reveal the volume of the war crimes" of Israel at the hospital.

Israel says that it has killed more than 170 gunmen at the hospital in an extensive raid, while Kanani stressed that 170 "patients, medical staff and displaced Palestinians" were killed in Israel's "horrific crimes".

Yesterday, Iran's Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian discussed the Gaza war with his Omani counterpart Badr al-Busaidi, condemning Israel's "barbaric and inhumane actions" at Al-Shifa Hospital.

Somalia releases 33 Iranian fishermen and sailors detained last year

Iranian broadcast media reported this morning that Somalia had released 33 Iranian fishermen and sailors detained for illegal fishing in last summer.

Ali Gholampour, Iran's ambassador to Kenya and Somalia, said yesterday that the release of the fishermen could pave the way for restoring ties between Mogadishu and Tehran.

Somalia cut diplomatic ties with Iran in 2016 after accusing Tehran of trying to destabilise the Horn of Africa nation.

Iranians online criticise 'merciful dealing' call for cleric in land-grabbing scandal

Anti-establishment Iranians online have criticised a call by the conservative Hamshahri newspaper to "treat with religious mercy" the case of senior cleric Hojjat ol-Eslam Kazem Seddiqi who has recently been at the centre of an illegal land seizure scandal.

See: Briefing: Allegations of land grabbing by senior cleric stir controversy in Iran

Users wondered why the "merciful approach" was not exercised in regard with ordinary citizens and critics of the establishment.

"Religious mercy-based dealing for insiders, decisive dealing with outsiders," one user said sarcastically in a post on X (formerly Twitter).

Some asked why protesters were executed for petty crimes such as "setting fire to dustbins" during the 2022 nationwide protests rather than being granted such "merciful treatment". Charges against Mohsen Shekari, who was the first protester executed in relation to the 2022 unrest, included blocking a street and setting fire to a dustbin alongside wounding a security force officer.

They circulated photos of the protesters executed or killed, as well as other cases of police crackdown and political prisoners, under the hashtag "merciful dealing".

See also

Briefing: Rouhani, Zarif reveal new details on Iran's 2020 attack on US base

Source: BBC Monitoring 25 Mar 24

title: Mali, Burkina Faso condemn attack on Russian concert hall
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Mali and Burkina Faso have condemned an attack on a packed concert venue on the outskirts of Russia's capital Moscow that left at least 60 people dead on 22 March and wounded more than 100 others.
body:
Malian military leader Colonel Assimi Goita said on X (formerly Twitter) that he learned with "extreme sorrow of the cowardly and barbaric terrorist attack against the Russian people".

"During this painful time, I want to express my sympathy to President Vladimir Putin and his wounded people," he added.

Malian government spokesman Colonel Abdoulaye Maiga said in a statement that the West African nation was determined "to pursue with the Russian Federation the fight against terrorism". 

Burkina Faso's government said in a statement that it condemned the "despicable and inhumane" attack on the Crocus City Hall in Krasnogorsk  and expressed solidarity with the Russian people in the fight against "terror and blind violence".

The Islamic State (IS) group claimed responsibility for the attack.

Mali and Burkina Faso have pivoted towards Russia since 2020 amid tense relations between the Sahel nations and the West.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in French on 22 Mar 24

title: Ukraine says two Russian warships hit in Sevastopol
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Ukrainian military has struck two Russian warships and the Black Sea Fleet's communications centre in Sevastopol, the Ukrainian army's Strategic Communications Department has reported.
body:
In a Telegram post on 24 March, it said: "The defence forces of Ukraine successfully hit the Yamal and Azov large landing ships, the communications centre and also several infrastructure facilities of the Black Sea Fleet of the Russian Federation in temporarily occupied Sevastopol."  

Earlier, the Ukrayinska Pravda website quoted the OSINTtechnical account on X (formerly Twitter) as saying that "at least three" Ukrainian Storm Shadow cruise missiles hit the fleet's communications centre on the evening of 23 March. The strike on the facility was also reported by the pro-Ukrainian Telegram channel Krymsky Veter (Crimean Wind).

Ukrainian Air Force commander Mykola Oleshchuk posted on Telegram later the same day: "The sky and the sea are of the same colour! I thank pilots and sailors for their successful combat work! Crimea is OURS!"

Media earlier reported multiple explosions in Sevastopol.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Ukrainian 0820 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Highlights from Maldives' Dhivehi-language press, websites 20 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items published in Maldives' Dhivehi-language press and online media outlets on 20 March 2024.

Sun.mv
body:
Minister says foreign currency rate stabilising

Minister of Economic Development Mohamed Saeed on 19 March, in a post on X (formerly Twitter), noted that the Maldives' exchange rate has become more stable, and that the rufiyaa should appreciate even further in the near future. The minister highlighted that it was the efforts of President Dr Mohamed Muizzu that allowed the country to recover from the challenging situation it had been in, in November 2023. Former president Mohamed Nasheed had also noted that the US dollar situation in the country was improving, suggesting that it may be because the government has halted printing money to finance its expenditure. He said as a result, inflation is also decreasing. The previous government had suspending several articles of the Fiscal Responsibility Act and printed money as a measure to manage the economic decline due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and the parliament had approved the government printing 4.4bn rufiyaa ($285.3m) per year. Although the official exchange rate of the Maldives is 15.42 rufiyaa to a US dollar, US dollars are not available on the market at this rate, with the black-market exchange rate now between 17 and 17.40 rufiyaa per US dollar. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[This is a prominent Dhivehi-language news website that generally carries objective reporting. It is owned by the Sun Media Group, the largest private media house in the Maldives.]

Avas

Lawmaker proposes changes to number of parliament members

The Democrats Member of Parliament for Medhu Henveiru constituency, Ali Azim, on 19 March submitted a constitutional amendment to parliament to change the number of lawmakers in parliament. The amendment proposes that the change come into effect after the next term of parliament and beginning with the 21st parliament (the current 19th parliament's term will expire in 2024, with elections for the 20th parliament scheduled for 21 April). The amendment proposes one lawmaker for constituencies with between 6,000 and 12,000 people, two lawmakers for constituencies with 12,000 to 18,000 people, three lawmakers for 18,000 to 24,000 people, four for those between 24,000 and 36,000 people, and five for constituencies with more than 36,000 people. It also proposes to allocate one of 10 constituencies a political party contests in for women. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website run by "Mundoo" Adam Haleem and owned by former lawmaker Abdullah Sinan. The website is generally critical of the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party and Jumhooree Party.]

Mihaaru

Police salaries increased by 35%

Superintendent of Police Ahmed Shifan on 19 March announced a 35% increase in salaries for all police personnel from March. Shifan said the change will see a special allowance for police officers based on their category of work in addition to their basic salaries. He said while allowances had earlier been paid under various names, there will be only four types of payments from March- namely basic salary, position allowance, allowance depending on category of work, and risk allowance. He noted that the focus in the revised pay structure is to make a significant change to the pay for police personnel who work on the streets providing direct service to people. [Online, Approximate Words: 320]

[Mihaaru is a Dhivehi-language daily that generally carries objective reporting and does not appear to favour any political party. The newspaper widely covers political developments, radicalisation, and counter-terrorism-related developments in the Maldives.]

Raajje.mv

Government reports decline in import, export revenue for Feb

The Maldives Customs Service (MCS) on 19 March reported decline in both import and export revenue in February 2024. It said the CIF cost of imports in 2024 had been 4% higher than in February 2023, but that revenue to the government from imports had shown a 30% decline. The Maldives' top import markets in February were Oman, India, United Arab Emirates, China, and Singapore. The government recorded royalty receipts of 1.02m rufiyaa ($66.147) in February. [Online, Approximate Words: 160]

[This is the Dhivehi-language website of widely watched, privately-run television news channel Raajje TV that supports the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website provides detailed coverage of government actions and statements and sometimes criticises Chinese involvement in the Maldives.]

Vaguthu

Minister notes need to improve education quality

Minister of Education Dr Ismail Shafeeu on 19 March said although there are successes attained in the Maldives' education system, it has still not achieved the target of students passing at least five subjects at the ordinary level examinations [O levels, main examination for students at completion of class 10]. In response to a question in parliament by Member of Parliament for Ungoofaaru constituency, Mohamed Waheed, the minister noted that the Maldives' education system is based on an international curriculum and is one of the few countries in the Asian region that provides a universal education based on it. He highlighted that the ministry's target is for 65% of students taking the O'level examinations to pass five subjects, expressed the ministry's concern over this target not being reached and said national-level efforts are needed to improve student's education standards. The minister also highlighted that given the traditional school infrastructure of schools across the country, it was challenging to provide skills training and STEM labs. [Online, Approximate Words: 260]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website that was founded by a youth group that favours the ruling Progressive Party of Maldives and People's National Congress and criticises politicians from the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website generally backs China and strongly criticises India.]

Channel News Maldives

High court orders public service media case to be reviewed

The High Court of Maldives on 19 March annulled a previous ruling ordering Public Service Media (PSM) to pay 78m rufiyaa ($5.1m) to the Business Image Group (BIG) company and for the case to be reviewed again. The Civil Court in 2016 had ordered the payment be made in relation to transactions made by the Maldives National Broadcasting Corporation (MNBC) in 2010 during former president Nasheed's administration. The high court, in its ruling, said while the ruling was issued against MNBC, given that MNBC's assets and debt have now been transferred to the PSM, and given that the interests of PSM are now involved in the case, PSM should be a party to case proceedings. With the Civil Court ruling PSM had paid 30m rufiyaa ($1.9m) of the 70m rufiyaa to BIG. The case was appealed at the high court in 2021, after the appeal period expired. [Online, Approximate Words: 150]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website formerly known as Voice of Free Press run by prominent journalist Ismail Rasheed. It carried original reporting, editorial and commentaries primarily on domestic political and socio-economic issues and does not favour Indian or Chinese involvement in the country.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Dhivehi 20 Mar 24

title: Haiti Prime Minister Ariel Henry 'landed in Puerto Rico'-report
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An airplane allegedly carrying the Prime Minister of Haiti, Ariel Henry, whose whereabouts in the last few days had become a matter of intense speculation, "landed" in the US Caribbean territory of Puerto Rico, leading Puerto Rican daily El Nuevo Dia reported on a social media post published on 5 March.
body:
The daily cited Sheila Anglero, spokesperson for the government of Puerto Rico, as confirming the news.

It added that Henry's plane had landed at the Luis Munoz Marin international airport in the territory's capital, San Juan, after it was allegedly "denied permission" to land in Haiti and in the Dominican Republic, the country that shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti.

Henry had been in previous days in Kenya, negotiating with authorities there some details related to a proposed multinational police force that would be deployed in the Caribbean country, when a surge of civil unrest spread throughout the Haitian capital, Port au Prince.

Powerful armed gangs have demanded Henry's resignation.

According to El Nuevo Dia, Henry's airplane had taken off earlier on 5 March from Teterboro airport, near New York City. The daily did not confirm the source for this information.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Spanish 2141 gmt 5 Mar 24

title: Somaliland says no base for Ethiopia without recognition
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Somaliland will not give Ethiopia access to the Gulf of Aden to build a naval base if does not recognise the self-declared republic as an independent state, its foreign minister has said.
body:
On 1 January, Somaliland signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Ethiopia to give the landlocked country a naval base on the Gulf of Aden in exchange for recognition.

The agreement was condemned by Somalia as an act of “aggression”. Mogadishu has since waged an international campaign against Ethiopia and recalled its ambassador from Addis Ababa. 

“Three items in the MoU are currently in the public domain. Number one, we will not give a naval base to Ethiopia if it does not recognise us right away,” said Somaliland’s foreign minister Essa Kayd in a video his ministry posted on X (formerly Twitter) on 15 March.

Kayd’s comments followed reports that Ethiopia was considering abandoning its plan to recognise the self-proclaimed republic as an independent country due to international pressure.

See: Explainer: Ethiopia-Somalia row further fragments Horn of Africa

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Somali 15 Mar 24

title: Sudan's RSF seizes another town in central Gezira state
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) said on 4 March that it had taken full control of Almadina Arab town in central Gezira state.
body:
In a statement on X [formerly Twitter], the group said its fighters were advancing towards El Manaqil town in the state which is controlled by rival Sudan's military.

Almadina Arab is located west of the state's capital, Wad Madani, which RSF captured in December 2023 following days of heavy clashes.

Meanwhile, several Sudanese groups have accused the group of killing two doctors and abducting others during a raid on a hospital in the town.

Sudanese organisation that is active in Sudan and several African countries- said in a statement the targeting of health workers by RSF is "unacceptable".

The army has been mobilising troops to recapture Wad Madani from the RSF amid heavy fighting in Gezira state.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Arabic 4 Mar 24

title: Iran renews claim to gas field disputed with Kuwait
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's Vice-President for Legal Affairs Mohammad Dehqan has reiterated that his country would not retreat from its "rights" in the Arash offshore gas field in the Gulf.
body:
Dehqan said on his account in Virasty - an Iranian version of X (formerly Twitter) - on 25 March: "The Islamic Republic of Iran will not retreat from its unalienable right over the jointly-owned Arash gas field. Although we believe that the issue must be settled through talks with Kuwait, we will not allow that country, or any other country, to produce [gas] unilaterally, in breach of international law and disregarding our country's interests."

Kuwait continues to reject Iranian claims. It says the field, which Arab countries call Durrah, belongs only to Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

Dehqan warned on 8 March that Iran would start production in the disputed field if Kuwait did the same.

The Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, which leads the country's oil sector, said in October 2023 that the field would become operational by 2029, without waiting for a maritime border demarcation with Iran.

Source: Iranian social media platform Virasty in Persian 1743 gmt 25 Mar 24

title: India, Ukraine discuss war; pledge to strengthen ties
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Visiting Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba and his Indian counterpart S Jaishankar have discussed a range of issues, including the ongoing war against Russia, during their talks in Delhi on 29 March.
body:
"An open and wide-ranging conversation with Ukraine FM @DmytroKuleba this afternoon. Our discussions focused on the ongoing conflict and its wider ramifications. Exchanged views on various initiatives in that context," Jaishankar said in a post on X.

The Indian minister said they also discussed global and regional issues "of interest to both" countries and the two sides pledged to strengthen bilateral cooperation.

They also co-chaired a review meeting of the India-Ukraine Inter-Governmental Commission.

“Our immediate goal is to get trade back to earlier levels,” Jaishankar said in another post on X.

For his part, Kuleba said he held "sincere and comprehensive" talks with Jaishankar on bilateral relations, regional issues and global security.  “We paid specific attention to the Peace Formula and next steps on the path of its implementation,” he wrote on X.

He also said both sides "agreed to restore the level of cooperation between our countries that existed prior to the full-scale war launched by Russia, as well as identify new promising projects to take our relations to the next level".

Ahead of today's talks, Kuleba told reporters in Delhi on 28 March that Ukraine hopes to see India’s participation in an upcoming peace summit in Switzerland as it would convince other countries, especially in the Global South, to join efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the war.

India, a long-term ally of Moscow, has not openly criticised Russia’s invasion of Ukraine though it has repeatedly called for dialogue to end the conflict.

See also: Briefing: Media highlight Indian PM's phone call with Russia, Ukraine leaders

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in English 1101 GMT 29 Mar 24

title: Two killed, dozens injured in north-central Kenya 'bandit' attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two people have been killed and four others injured in the latest wave of violence in Kenya’s restive Samburu County, The Standard newspaper reported on X (formerly Twitter) on 25 March.
body:
Clashes between cattle rustlers – often referred to as bandits – and security forces have persisted despite a year of sustained operations by more than 4,500 multi-agency officers in six counties in the north-central regions.

“Bandits shot two people dead and injured four at Porro in Samburu County. Twelve security personnel were admitted at Samburu referral hospital after they were involved in a road accident on the way to respond to the attack,” the report that included a 58-second video clip added.

Two victims who appeared in the video said they sustained gunshot wounds during the attack that took place at dawn on 24 March while they were heading to church.

At least 2,000 families have fled from parts of the North Rift in the past three months due to the violence.

See Briefing: Nineteen schools 'forced to close' amid insecurity in northern Kenya

Source: The Standard website, Nairobi, in English 25 Mar 24

title: Iran passive defence chief reports 200 cyber-attacks before elections
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The head of Iran's Passive Defence Organisation (PDO), Gholamreza Jalali, has said that in the month before the 1 March elections some 200 cyber-attacks were launched against the country's communications infrastructure.
body:
On 5 March, the Islamic Revolution Guards Corps (IRGC) affiliated Tasnim News Agency cited Jalali as saying this on TV the previous day.

He was responding to a question regarding the cyber-security of the polls in which all identity verifications were conducted by the electoral administration online.

"The recent elections saw the passionate and enthusiastic participation of the public at a time when all kinds of media war and an adverse climate were being created by the enemy. This was to dissuade the public from coming to the ballot boxes. We must not forget, on the other hand, that the enemy mustered all his will to disrupt the electoral process. Of course, the objective of the defence officials was to hold a very calm set of elections with a high degree of security", he noted.

On 20 February, the dissident hacking group Edalat-e Ali shared a post on X (formerly Twitter) in which it said that it had published a number of seized documents on its Telegram Channel. It added that it had uncovered more than three million documents seized from the Tehran judiciary. The group underlined communications between "other corrupt organs of the state such as the Intelligence Ministry, IRGC intelligence and the National Security Council with the judiciary".

Jalali noted that the 200 alleged cyber-attacks were mostly small scale but there were "four or five big attacks". 

He added that "some of these attacks were controlled and eliminated" but he did not specifically say which cyber attacks proved successful.

Jalali also stressed that in the past six months some 100 DDoS attacks had been launched against the nation's communications infrastructure, which had been countered by the Communications Ministry.

See also: Briefing: Iran judiciary denies being hacked by cybergroup

Source: Tasnim news agency website, Tehran, in Persian 0558 GMT 5 Mar 24

title: Afghan Taliban official leads religious delegation to Uzbekistan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Afghan Taliban de facto government's acting minister of hajj and religious affairs, Sheikh Noor Mohammad Saqeb, has embarked on an official visit to Uzbekistan on the invitation of Sheikh Nuridin Haliknazarov, the head of the Religious Administration of Muslims of Uzbekistan.
body:
As announced in a statement on X (formerly Twitter) by the Ministry of Hajj and Religious Affairs on 16 March, the visit aims to bolster bilateral relations and cooperation and ensure coordination between the two countries in educational and religious areas.

Saqeb, leading a 10-member "high-ranking delegation" of religious scholars, will visit Tashkent, Samarkand, where the Afghan Taliban officials will meet officials from various Uzbek religious institutions, the statement added.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Persian 0853 GMT 16 Mar 24

title: Erdogan celebrates Mitsotakis's birthday in phone call amid Turkey-Greece thaw
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan celebrated Greek Prime Minister Kriyakos Mitsotakis's birthday in a phone call on 4 March, the Turkish Presidency said in a post on X (formerly Twitter) on 4 March.
body:
The call comes amid continued rapprochement in Turkey-Greece ties in recent months, after deep strains in previous years over disagreements regarding maritime territories, energy exploration efforts and migration.

President Erdogan visited Athens in December 2023, hailing a "new era" in relations.

Turkish pundits subsequently speculated that Mitsotakis will visit Turkey on Erdogan's invitation in spring.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Turkish 1205 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Chad opposition figure flees abroad after Yaya Dillo's killing
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Abakar Hakimi, the advisor of the late leader of the Socialist Party Without Borders (PSF), Yaya Dillo, left the country in fear of being targeted by the National State Security Agency (ANSE), pro-opposition news website Tchad One reported on 6 March.

title: Embassy denies Iran links to journalist stabbing in London
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's Charge d'Affaires to the UK, Seyyed Mehdi Hosseini Matin, has denied "any link" to Tehran in the attack on the anchor of the London-based channel Iran International TV.
body:
He was reacting, in a 30 March post in English on X,  to The Telegraph's report of the assault on Pouria Zeraati, who was stabbed outside his home in London by unknown attackers on 29 March.

The journalist was taken to hospital and London's Metropolitan Police is investigating the matter. 

Matin said it was "quite strange and questionable" that three hours after the incident, The Telegraph had "without evidence" and prior to "any official Met reports", "explicitly accused Iran" of having a hand in the attack.

The Iranian official further suggested that The Telegraph could be "informed in advance by the plotters/perpetrators", and referred to Zeraati as "the so-called journalist".

Matin attached a photo of the Telegraph article saying that his post followed the investigation led by counter-terror police, and he highlighted the timing of the attack indicated in the article.

 

Tehran designated Iran International TV as a "terrorist" organisation in 2022 amid nationwide protests in Iran. The network suspended operations in London in February 2023 for a few months due to threats against its journalists, after the UK revealed an Iranian plot to kill Iranian journalists on British soil.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Persian 0528 GMT 30 Mar 24

title: Bangladesh media highlights 22 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection and assessment of key developments in Bangladesh, as reported in frontline Bangladeshi press and online media outlets as of 08:00 GMT on 22 March 2024.

PM Hasina congratulates President Putin on election victory
body:
Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin on his reelection.

Hasina conveyed her "sincere congratulations" to Putin for being reelected the president of Russia, frontline Bengali newspaper Kaler Kantho reported, citing the press wing of the Prime Minister's Office.

The report said that Putin bagged a "record" 87.33% of the votes cast and has been reelected for another "six-year term" as Russian president.

Putin's reelection will further strengthen "his already tight grip on power", noted a report by prominent English-language business daily, The Business Standard.

It added that his return to power "should send a message to the West that its leaders will have to reckon with an emboldened Russia, whether in war or in peace, for many more years to come."

The prime minister's congratulatory message received widespread and largely factual coverage in frontline Bengali and English-language newspapers and online news outlets.

PM Hasina seeks India's help to get electricity from Bhutan

Prime Minister Hasina has sought India's support to import electricity from Bhutan via Indian territory.

The prime minister's speech writer, Md Nazrul Islam, said that Hasina sought "India's support" to import electricity from Bhutan, well-known Bengali newspaper Samakal reported.

Islam made these remarks when briefing journalists after a meeting between Prime Minister Hasina and Indian high commissioner Pranay Verma, at the Prime Minister's official residence Ganabhaban on 21 March, the news report noted. 

Bangladesh and Bhutan are likely to sign an agreement on the import of electricity during the upcoming visit of the Bhutanese King Jigme Khesar Namgyal to Dhaka on 25 March, Islam disclosed.

Citing unnamed officials, the report said that discussions between Bangladesh and Bhutan on the import of electricity are at the "final stage".

Hasina has urged India to withdraw the "anti-dumping measures" for import of jute and jute products from Bangladesh, the news report noted.

She has also sought India's cooperation in modernising the railway workshop in Saidpur (in Nilphamari District), the report said.

Islam cited Verma as saying during the meeting that India is "committed" to taking forward negotiations for a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) between the two countries, English-language newspaper The Messenger Online reported.

The high commissioner also said that Bangladesh "could set up a defence factory here with an Indian joint venture," the news report noted.

Verma said that in 2023, a total of four projects were implemented in Bangladesh under an Indian line of credit, with two more projects "in the pipeline for implementation", the report added.

The development received widespread and largely factual coverage in frontline Bengali and English-language newspapers and online news outlets.

Myanmar 'warship' reportedly spotted in Naf River

A "large" Myanmar warship was on the morning of 21 March reportedly spotted in the Naf River, according to an exclusive report by reputed English-language newspaper Dhaka Tribune.

The Naf River marks the border of southeastern Bangladesh and northwestern Myanmar.

The "large warship" was seen on the Myanmar side of the river, three kilometres east of the Shapuree island in Teknaf sub-district of Cox's Bazar, the news report cited local people as saying.

They said that "such vessels are not usually seen in the Naf River", the news report noted.

"A big ship was seen in the waters of the Naf River. However, it is not known what kind of ship it is," Battalion commander of the Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) in Teknaf, Lieutenant Colonel Mohiuddin Ahmed, was quoted as saying.

Meanwhile, "no sound" of gunshots across the border has been heard in "the past few days", according to chairperson of the Hnila Union Parishad (local council), Rashed Mahmud Ali, the report said.

Negotiations on with pirates who hijacked Bangladesh ship

Negotiations are reportedly ongoing with Somali pirates who hijacked the Bangladeshi-flagged cargo vessel, "MV Abdullah", along with its 23 sailors, on 12 March.

"According to sources [unnamed], the negotiations on the release of the ship and crew between the owners of the hijacked ship and the Somali Pirates have been going on since Wednesday [20 March] through a third party," English-language newspaper Daily Observer reported.

Sources related to the maritime trade have expressed hope that "the hijack drama will end very soon", the news report said.

However, Kabir Steel Re-Rolling Mills (KSRM) Group, the owners of MV Abdullah, have "refuted" reports on negotiations with the pirates, the report noted.

"We have been continuing contact with the sailors and the pirates," KSRM Group media spokesperson, Mijanul Islam, was quoted as saying.

"Our sailors were safe and in good health," he added.

In a related development, the European Union Naval Force (EUNAVFOR) "has deployed a warship under its anti-piracy mission Operation Atalanta near the hijacked Bangladeshi-flagged vessel", according to a report by prominent English-language news website bdnews24.com.

A video posted on EUNAVFOR's official X (formerly Twitter) handle shows its warship "positioned close to MV Abdullah" and a helicopter "hovering around the hijacked cargo ship", the news report noted.

Earlier, EUNAVFOR had proposed to launch an operation to rescue the hijacked ship but the Bangladesh side "did not agree", according to a report by popular Bengali newspaper Prothom Alo.

KSRM Group spokesperson Islam told the newspaper that their "first priority" is to safely bring back the sailors.

President of the Bangladesh Merchant Marine Officers' Association, Captain Anam Chowdhury, said that so far, the government and owners of the ship have "not given their consent for launching a military operation" to rescue the ship, the news report noted.

Chowdhury said that in the current situation, there is "no alternative but to find a peaceful solution" to free the hostage ship, the report added.

The developments received widespread and largely factual coverage in frontline Bengali and English-language newspapers and online news outlets.

News report says US, Canada likely to take in over 600 Rohingyas

The United States (US) and Canada are likely to take in another group of over 600 Rohingyas for resettlement, according to a report by Kaler Kantho.

Citing unnamed sources, the news report said that the US is likely to take in 503 Rohingyas, while Canada will take in 117 Rohingyas for resettlement.

Rohingyas, who "do not have any relatives" or are "helpless" have been selected by these two countries for resettlement, the sources were cited as saying.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has asked the Ministry of Home Affairs to issue "security clearance for 117 Rohingyas", the report noted.

During the past two years, the US and Canada have "provided shelter to 86 Rohingyas", the report said.

In April 2022, Canada took in 24 Rohingyas, including family members of the assassinated Rohingya leader, Muhib Ullah, while the US took in 62 Rohingyas in December, the news report added.

Source: BBC Monitoring in Bengali 22 Mar 24

title: BBCM Iran Watchlist 26 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Iranian broadcast, press and social media sources

TEHRAN TIMES
body:
Iran, E3 to hold nuclear talks in Geneva today

Iran and the three European signatories to the 2015 Iran nuclear deal (JCPOA) - France, Germany and the UK (collectively, the E3) - will hold a meeting today in Geneva on the deputy foreign ministerial level.

The meeting comes amid warnings by the E3 that they will activate the so-called snapback mechanism of the JCPOA to reinstate UN sanctions on Iran if Tehran fails to show progress in nuclear talks with the US.

US-Iran nuclear talks have been stalled since the 12-day Iran-Israel war in June. Talk about the snapback mechanism has intensified ahead of the October deadline when the UN Security Council Resolution 2231, passed in 2015 to endorse the JCPOA, expires.

The state radio channel (VIRI) said that Deputy Foreign Minister Majid Takht-Ravanchi will lead the Iranian delegation today. VIRI noted the 22 August phone call between Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi and his E3 counterparts, in which Araqchi rejected the E3's "legal and moral authority" to activate the snapback.

China and Russia, other signatories of the JCPOA, oppose the activation of the mechanism. President Massoud Pezeshkian also spoke by phone with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin yesterday, assuring him that Iran has never sought to build nuclear weapons.

Iran rejects Trump's post on Tehran's nuclear programme

Foreign Ministry Spokesman Esmail Baqai yesterday criticised Trump for reposting an old interview by a former Iranian MP, accusing the US president of distorting facts to justify US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

Baqai said Trump was ignoring his own intelligence chief's assessments, referring to Tulsi Gabbard's testimony in March that Iran was not building a nuclear weapon, and instead relying on personal remarks by a former Iranian lawmaker.

Baqai's remarks came in response to Trump sharing a clip without a comment, originally posted by influencer Mario Nawfal, of Ali Motahhari, former deputy parliament speaker, saying in 2022 that Iran had initially aimed to develop a nuclear weapon but failed to complete the project or conduct a test.

Motahhari, who left the parliament in 2020, dismissed Trump's post, saying that he was not an official at the time of the interview and adding that the US president "seemed to lack evidence and so resorts to the personal comment of an ordinary individual".

Foreign minister in Saudi Arabia for Gaza ministerial

Foreign Minister Araqchi yesterday addressed an emergency meeting of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) about the Israel-Gaza war, urging Muslim countries to take concrete steps to halt "genocide" in Gaza.

On the sidelines of the Jeddah ministerial, Araqchi met his Egyptian, Saudi, Iraqi, Pakistani, Turkish and Algerian counterparts as well.

Separately, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Baqai yesterday condemned a deadly Israeli strike on Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis.

Parliament speaker backs president after leader's endorsement

Conservative Parliament Speaker Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf this morning called on hardline factions to stop talking about President Massoud Pezeshkian's alleged "incompetence", saying that they were "playing into the enemy's hands".

Qalibaf's remarks come after Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei publicly backed the "hardworking" president on 24 August amid mounting criticism from hardliners against him and his reformist backers.

Some reformist newspapers complained that the attacks against Pezeshkian continued even after Khamenei's backing, accusing the hardliners of trying to "destroy the government".

Pro-reform daily Sazandegi named Saeed Jalili, Pezeshkian's hardline opponent in the 2024 election, Peyman Jebeli, the head of the state broadcaster, and several hardline MPs as members of the "distortion movement".

At the same time, Qalibaf in his speech rebuked a recent controversial statement by the major reformist group, Reform Front, while Judiciary Chief Gholamhossein Mohseni Ejei yesterday strongly condemned it.

While reformist daily Hammihan criticised the judiciary's "political statement", ultraconservative daily Keyhan welcomed Ejei's remarks, warning that "failing to deal with its statement-writing servants will give the enemy a foothold".

The leader of the Reform Front, Azar Mansouri, yesterday defended the group's statement calling for direct talks with the US and suspending uranium enrichment, saying that the proposal was rooted in national responsibility.

Outcry after comedian mocks Persian epic poet Ferdowsi

Comedian Zeynab Mousavi has faced a wave of criticism after posting a video parodying verses from Ferdowsi's epic poem, the Shahnameh, with coarse and sexually explicit language.

The clip, widely shared on X and Instagram, was condemned across the political spectrum as an affront to a cornerstone of Persian literature and culture. Many users described it as an "insult", saying the Shahnameh is a national symbol that should not be subjected to crude mockery.

Mousavi's Instagram account was taken offline amid the uproar, though it is unclear whether she removed it herself or whether it was deactivated following user complaints.

This morning, Iran's judiciary announced that a case had been opened in Tehran's prosecutor's office for the controversial comedian, after pro-establishment media outlets also weighed in yesterday to report the story and criticise Mousavi.

The controversy has reignited debate online under various hashtags such as #Ferdowsi and #Shahnameh.

Some users argued that comedians should be free to joke about any subject, while others accused Mousavi's defenders of hypocrisy for supporting satire of Ferdowsi while opposing jokes on other topics.

title: Guatemala authorities announce 'historic' cocaine seizures in Pacific waters
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Guatemala's Navy carried out three separate interceptions in recent days of vessels transporting cocaine in Pacific waters, confiscating a total of 2.3 tonnes of the drug and capturing 11 individuals, the official Guatemalan government newspaper Diario de Centro America said in a report posted on X on 13 March.
body:
The most recent interception took place on 11 March, in international waters 400 nautical miles from the coasts of Guatemala's Escuintla department, and the navy apprehended three suspected Mexican nationals in the seized vessel, which sank, the report said.

It quoted Carlos Mota, chief of Guatemala's Pacific Naval Command, as hailing this operation as a "milestone for the [Guatemalan] maritime forces, as it is the first time that a [drugs-carrying] launch has been found and intercepted at this distance in open sea, in international waters".

Earlier on 11 March, another cocaine-carrying vessel had been intercepted 145 nautical miles from the Guatemalan Pacific coast, with three people on board whose nationalities were not given.

On 9 March, 245 nautical miles from the coast, another launch with cocaine on board was seized and three Mexicans and two Ecuadoreans were detained, Diario de Centro America reported. The official daily described these seizures by the Guatemalan navy as "historic".

The report cited Carlos Antonio Medina, chief of Guatemala's National Defence Staff, as saying that the maritime anti-drugs operations had involved the "support of intelligence agencies of allied nations such as Colombia, Mexico and United States, as well as air assistance and use of radars to locate these launches".

On 28 February, the official Guatemalan daily added, authorities had made the Central American nation's "biggest seizure on land of drugs", confiscating over 1.7 tonnes of cocaine found in a truck in Coatepeque, in the Quetzaltenango department.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Spanish 2001 gmt 13 Mar 24

title: Iranian officials 'strongly' condemn Moscow attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian has "strongly condemned the 22 March, "terrorist attack" on a concert hall in the Russian capital, Moscow, which killed at least 93 people and wounded dozens more.
body:
In a post on X (formerly Twitter), on 22 March, Amir-Abdollahian said that "a joint and effective fight against terrorism requires serious action by the international community" without any discrimination.

He expressed condolences to his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, the families of the victims and the government and people of Russia.

Iran's Parliament Speaker Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf also condemned the attack in a letter to the Russian State Duma Speaker Vyacheslav Volodin.

"The eradication of all forms of terrorism requires the collective effort of the international community and the cooperation of all countries to seriously fight terrorism as an effective strategy for securing world peace", Tasnim news agency quoted Qalibaf as saying on 23 March.

Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Nasser Kanani also expressed condolences to the government and people of Russia, "especially the families of the victims". Kanani said that "the Islamic Republic of Iran stands with Russia in this tragic incident", according to a statement published on the foreign ministry's website.

Iran's ambassador to Russia, Kazem Jalali, condemned the attack in a post in Persian and Russian on X. He said Iran "stands with the people and government of Russia and sympathises with them".

The Islamic State group (IS) has claimed responsibility for the attack .

Source: Tasnim news agency website, Tehran, in Persian 0557 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Islamic Resistance in Iraq claims drone attack on Israel's Haifa Port
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Islamic Resistance in Iraq (IRI) has claimed it conducted a drone attack on a chemical materials station in Israel's Haifa Port.
body:
The announcement came in a statement the group posted on Telegram on 3 March, and it was followed by a video showing the launch of several drones.

“In continuation of our approach to resisting the occupation, in support of our people in Gaza, and in response to the massacres committed by the [Israeli] usurping entity against Palestinian civilians, including children, women and the elderly, the mujahideen of the Islamic Resistance in Iraq launched a drone attack on the chemical materials station in Haifa Port in our occupied territories on the evening of Friday, 1 March 2024,” the statement said.

The statement added that the IRI “confirms that it will continue to destroy enemy strongholds”.

Later in the day, the group released a video purportedly showing the launch of drones used in the attack. A label displayed in the video suggested the operation took place on 1 March.

A reporter for the Israeli Walla news site posted IRI's claim on X (formerly Twitter) alongside text saying: "There was no such attack."

IRI has claimed dozens of attacks on US forces in Iraq and Syria, as well as attacks on Israel, since the outbreak of the Gaza-Israel war in October.

IRI is an umbrella group comprising pro-Iran militias active in Iraq and Syria that seemed to have intensified their anti-US activities following the outbreak of the Gaza war.

See also: Name in the News: Iran-backed Islamic Resistance in Iraq militia

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1305 GMT 4 Mar 24

title: Iran, EU diplomats discuss Gaza, nuclear programme in Qatar
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran's deputy foreign minister and chief nuclear negotiator, Ali Baqeri Kani, has discussed the Israel-Gaza war and Iran's nuclear programme with senior EU diplomat Enrique Mora in Qatar.
body:
Baqeri said in a post on X (formerly Twitter) on 8 March that at this meeting, he discussed the necessity for "ending genocide and saving innocent lives" in Gaza, as well as lifting sanctions against Iran, which is how Iranian officials describe talks about Iran's nuclear programme.

The international talks between Iran and world powers to revive the 2015 nuclear deal - Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) - have been stalled since September 2022.

In a post on X on the same day, Mora said that the two sides also discussed Iran-Russia military cooperation, which was neither mentioned in Baqeri's tweet nor in the report published by Iran's official IRNA news agency.

Russia has regularly used Iranian-made drones in its war against Ukraine. Tehran has confirmed that it supplied a "limited number" of drones to Russia "months before" the war but denies they are being used against Ukraine.

Baqeri said in a separate post on X that he had also met Qatar's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Mohammed al-Khulaifi in Doha to thank his government for its efforts to stop the "genocide" in Gaza and to reiterate the need for stopping the "killing of women and children".

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Persian 1131 GMT 8 Mar 24

title: BBCM Armenia Watchlist 31 Jul 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Armenian broadcast, press and social media sources

Armenia rules out any 'corridor' compromising its sovereignty
body:
Yerevan has once again ruled out any transport arrangement that would compromise Armenia's territorial integrity or sovereignty.

"Armenia has never discussed and will not discuss the kinds of options of transport links that would be incompatible with its own territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction," Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan's spokesperson Nazeli Baghdasaryan said on Facebook. She made the comments in response to what she described as "confusion" in the media about the matter.

"It is evident that there is some confusion in the Armenian media about Armenia's position regarding the unblocking of regional transport links, and the media outlets see some contradictions in the statements of Armenian officials. To some extent, this is understandable, because the topic has numerous nuances, which sometimes get more complicated with the use of certain wordings, such as renting out, lease, building lease, outsourcing. Certainly, each of the wordings can have different meanings depending on what specifically it pertains to.

"In order to make the issue easier for the esteemed representatives of the press, I would like to once again underscore that the Republic of Armenia has never discussed, is not discussing and will not discuss the kinds of options of transport links passing through its own territory that would be incompatible with the territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction of the Republic of Armenia.

"And furthermore, as part of its territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction, the Republic of Armenia is not only discussing various formulas of utilising regional transport routes, but is also eager to reach an agreement around any of the formulas," Baghdasaryan said.

"Armenia's territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction cannot be outsourced. The business management of a railway, pipeline [or] power transmission lines can be [outsourced]. Incidentally, the maintenance and management of roads in Armenia has always been outsourced to private companies. Who manages [the roads] and with what quality is another matter. But this has nothing to do with the topic discussed," Baghdasaryan added.

Armenia to temporarily shelter 'endangered' Palestinian cultural heritage

Armenia will temporarily house elements of "endangered Palestinian cultural heritage" at the Matenadaran Institute of Ancient Manuscripts in Yerevan as part of an agreement between Armenia and the Palestinians, News.am reported.

It was quoting a statement made by Armenian Deputy Foreign Minister Vahan Kostanyan at the high-level UN conference on the peaceful resolution of the Palestinian issue, co-chaired by France and Saudi Arabia, in New York. In his speech, Kostanyan reaffirmed Armenia's commitment to the two-state solution, stating that "lasting peace and stability are only possible through the existence of two neighbouring independent states".

Kostanyan also welcomed France's intention to recognise "Palestine" and the UK's intention to follow suit, noting Armenia's pride in having hosted a meeting between the French and Palestinian foreign ministers during the Yerevan Dialogue diplomatic conference earlier in 2025.

Despite limited resources, he said, Armenia has made consistent efforts to support the Palestinian people - including sending humanitarian aid to Gaza and backing the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA).

Kostanyan emphasised the importance of protecting Christian communities and heritage in both states, noting that Armenia is particularly concerned about preserving holy sites in the "Holy Land".

"Armenia hopes that the historic status quo governing the holy sites in Jerusalem will be fully upheld," he said, calling it "a cornerstone of interfaith solidarity and peaceful coexistence".

Red Cross to stop visiting Armenian detainees in Baku

The families of Armenians held in Baku have been informed by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) that it will no longer be able to visit the detainees, Azatutyun.am, the Armenian service of Radio Liberty, has reported.

This news has caused serious concern among the detainees' relatives, as the ICRC was the only independent international organisation able to access the detained Armenians, monitor their conditions and health, provide necessary clothing and hygiene supplies, and facilitate video calls with family members, the report said.

One relative told Azatutyun that the ICRC was "the last hope" for the families and the detainees. "The only means was the Red Cross, which connected families and brought some light to these people's lives. And now this has been cut off too," the person said.

Zara Amatuni, the head of Communication for the ICRC delegation in Armenia, told Azatutyun that the last visit to the Armenians took place in June, and there have been no visits in July. According to Amatuni, the ICRC's Baku office will soon suspend operation at the request of the Azerbaijani authorities.

"Naturally, this situation is causing disruptions to our normal work process," she said.

Official data from Azerbaijan indicate that 23 Armenians are currently held in Baku prisons. Their only contact with relatives now is through phone calls arranged by the Azerbaijani authorities.

The pro-opposition Joghovurd daily cited the families of the detainees said that Azerbaijan has now fully prohibited visits to both civilian and military and political Armenian captives. Previously, limited contact was allowed once a month via video calls, but even that has been cut off, the report said.

The daily added that Baku is unwilling to make concessions, while the peace agreement with Baku promised by Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan appears increasingly uncertain.

Pundit says no unified stance in Iran on 'Zangazur corridor'

Expert on international relations Grigor Balasanyan has told News.am reformist and conservative forces in Iran no longer have a unified position on the issue of the potential so-called Zangazur corridor which is to link mainland Azerbaijan to its Naxcivan exclave via southern Armenia along the Iranian border.

Iran has long opposed the Zangazur corridor project which it says it fears would cut off its access to Armenia.

The expert noted that serious events are unfolding in Iran, where the political elite is currently divided into two factions. The reformists, led by President Massoud Pezeshkian, are no longer strongly opposed to the opening of the corridor.

"In fact, Pezeshkian recently gave an interview in which he made a controversial statement, saying that issues related to restoring routes along Iran's north-western border are trivial and not worth worrying about. In other words, the Iranian president considers the opening of the 'Zangazur corridor' an insignificant matter," Balasanyan said, noting that an opposite stance is held by the team of Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, who sharply criticise Pezeshkian, warning of destructive consequences for Iran from the corridor's opening.

The expert also said that Pezeshkian's visit to Azerbaijan's Karabakh in July for a summit of the Economic Cooperation Organisation was also symbolic following the 12-day Iran-Israel war. "Knowing well that Iranian territory is constantly shelled from Azerbaijan, choosing to attend the meeting implies agreement with everything happening against your [Pezeshkian's] state," the expert said.

Armenian president visits border checkpoint, communities near Iran

As part of his visit to Armenia's southern Syunik Province, Armenia's ceremonial President Vahagn Khachaturyan has toured the Meghri customs checkpoint at the border with Iran, where he was briefed by Deputy Head of the State Revenue Committee Karen Tamazyan on current operations and plans for a new facility at the checkpoint to boost transport links. The new facility will be ready in 2026, Tamazyan said.

Khachaturyan referred to the government's Crossroads of Peace initiative, expressing concern that the planned facility may not be adequate to support the project's full implementation or to ensure reliable transport connectivity along the Middle Corridor.

The president also visited the communities of Chakaten and Nerkin Hand, where he conversed with residents, discussed local issues and inquired about ongoing and planned government programmes in border areas. Khachaturyan visited a tunnel under construction as part of the North-South Road Corridor Project, where he observed the progress of ongoing construction work.

Also, Khachaturyan visited a military unit, reviewed living conditions and awarded several soldiers for their exemplary service.

Armenia-China defence relations

Armenian Armed Forces General Staff Chief Edvard Asryan has attended an event at the Chinese embassy marking the 98th anniversary of China's People's Liberation Army, Armenpress has reported.

Speaking at the event, Asryan stated that defence cooperation between two countries, including between the defence ministries, has developed successfully in recent years. He noted that China is currently one of Armenia's key international partners, and further development of bilateral cooperation is among the priorities of Armenia's foreign policy.

"Armenia-China relations are based on mutual respect, a high level of political dialogue and mutual understanding. Armenia is actively participating in the Belt and Road initiative proposed by the Chinese president, which aligns with Armenia's Crossroads of Peace project," Asryan said.

He said the Armenian government places strong emphasis on developing cooperation with China in the defence sector.

In this context, he highlighted that in 2023 and 2024, Armenian Defence Minister Suren Papikyan took part in the 10th and 11th Xiangshan international security forums held in Beijing to have productive meetings that helped further strengthen and expand bilateral cooperation.

Asryan added that annual bilateral cooperation programmes include delegation exchanges and expert-level working meetings across key areas of mutual interest. He said Armenia-China relations are currently at a high level, and further development is planned in several key areas.

In the field of military science, close relations have been established between the Academy of Military Sciences of the Chinese People's Liberation Army and Armenia's Vazgen Sargsyan Military University of the Ministry of Defence and National Defence Research University.

Chinese ambassador to Armenia Li Songwei said that China's global projects, such as the Belt and Road Initiative, aim to support development, and that countries like Armenia have shown interest and support.

Praising the steady development of relations between Armenia and China over the past 33 years, the diplomat said both nations respect each other's sovereignty and support one another on key national issues.

He confirmed that China will support Armenia's bid to join the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation during its chairmanship this year. Li added that Beijing is ready to deepen practical cooperation and strengthen peace and stability in the region.

In July, Armenia announced it seeks to join the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) as part of its strategy to pursue a balanced foreign policy. Prime Minister Pashinyan dismissed speculations that its possible SCO membership contradicts Armenia's position on the Moscow-led military alliance CSTO, noting that several countries are members of both organisations.

Premier's falling approval rating reportedly sparks search for new political challenges

Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan's approval rating has dropped to 13%, but Armenia's traditional opposition forces have failed to gain ground, Past daily has said. The newspaper argued that Pashinyan is now looking for a "dangerous opponent" among other forces that are capable of gaining the trust of Armenian society which is disappointed both with the ruling "velvet" government and former authorities.

Among those Pashinyan reportedly viewed as potential threats were the Armenian Apostolic Church and influential philanthropists, Past said. It said that Pashinyan deliberately provoked conflict with the Church in an effort to weaken it and reshape it to make it fit his "velvet revolution" narrative.

The arrest of influential businessman Samvel Karapetyan and his announcement to form a new political party marked a critical turning point, signaling a potential new challenge to Prime Minister Pashinyan's power, the daily said. It said that Karapetyan approaches politics as business and suggests that this approach manifests in his "in our own way" statement declared by Karapetyan's team, which has greatly unsettled the authorities. The daily concluded that unlike "insulting and imprisoning" clergymen, the new political force led by Karapetyan may prove far harder for Pashinyan to suppress.

title: Zimbabwe reacts to US sanctions against president
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Zimbabwean government spokesperson Nick Mangwana has described a US decision to end a two-decade-old sanctions regime against the southern African country as "massive", but condemned curbs on 11 people, including President Emmerson Mnangagwa.
body:
On 4 March, the US terminated a sanctions programme Washington imposed on Zimbabwe in 2003 over alleged human rights abuses, replacing it with an order blocking US-based assets belonging to Mnangagwa, the first lady and several other officials.

The order also barred the targeted Zimbabwean officials from unofficial travel to the US, with Biden citing corruption and human rights abuses.

US Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo said the sanctions "are not intended to target the people of Zimbabwe".

Mangwana tweeted in response that the termination of the sanctions regime "was massive. A great vindication of [Mnangagwa's] foreign policy", but that "as long our president is under sanctions, Zimbabwe remains under illegal sanctions".

The state-controlled Herald newspaper said the "piecemeal adjustments" to the sanctions signalled "the success of the country's engagement and re-engagement drive under President Mnangagwa".

Source: X (formerly Twitter) 4 Mar 24

title: Turkey, Somalia sign energy deal - minister
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Turkish Energy Minister Alparslan Bayraktar on 7 March said Turkey and Somalia have signed a deal on improving coordination on energy exploration and drilling in the latter's exclusive economic zone.
body:
"With this deal, we will undertake joint activities to bring Somalia's resources to the Somali people. We aim to strengthen Turkey's presence in the Horn of Africa with new collaborations in the field of energy," Bayraktar said in a post on X (formerly Twitter).

The deal included a memorandum of understanding on increasing cooperation on oil and natural gas fields in the "land and open sea blocks of Somalia", he added.

A Somali delegation led by Petroleum and Mineral Resources Minister Abdirizak Mohamed recently visited Ankara for talks on the issue.

Turkey and Somalia have close ties, with Mogadishu hosting Turkey's largest overseas military base.

Somalia's parliament in February ratified a defence and economic cooperation deal with Ankara.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Turkish 0950 GMT 7 Mar 24

title: Somalia arrests 16 suspects over deadly Mogadishu hotel attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Somali National Intelligence Security Agency (Nisa) has arrested 16 people, including security officers, in connection with a deadly 14 March attack on a hotel in the capital Mogadishu, the state-owned broadcaster Radio Mogadishu reported on 23 March.

title: Pakistan president, PM congratulate Putin on re-election
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's President Asif Ali Zardari on 19 March congratulated his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin on his victory in the presidential elections.
body:
In a post on X (formerly Twitter), the president expressed hope that Pakistan and Russia’s ties would grow further under his leadership.

"My heartiest felicitations to the president of the Russian Federation H.E Vladimir Putin on his victory in presidential elections. I am confident that relations between Pakistan and Russia will grow further under your dynamic leadership," Zardari posted.

Earlier, on 18 March, Pakistan's Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif also congratulated the Russian leader on his victory, saying he looked forward to working with him.

"I congratulate H.E. Vladimir Putin, President of the Russian Federation on his re-election and look forward to working with him to further strengthen Pakistan-Russia relations," Shehbaz wrote on X.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in English 0336 GMT 19 Mar 24

title: Yemen's Houthis claim attacks on US vessels in Red Sea, Gulf of Aden
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi movement said on 9 March that it had "successfully" attacked a ship and a number of US destroyers in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.
body:
Houthi-controlled Saba news agency published a copy of the statement issued by the rebel group's military spokesman, Yahya al-Sarea, in which he said that its naval forces had targeted the US ship Propel Fortune in the Gulf of Aden with a number of naval missiles.

He said that the second operation had targeted a number of US destroyers in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden with 37 drones.

The US military's Central Command (Centcom) said on X (formerly Twitter) on the same day that its Navy and coalition ships and aircraft had shot down 15 drones fired by the rebels towards the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden.

It said that on the previous day, Centcom had carried out a self-defence strike against two anti-ship ballistic missiles fired by the Houthis into the Gulf of Aden at the Singapore-flagged, owned and operated Propel Fortune.

Source: Saba news agency website, Sanaa, in Arabic 0734 GMT 9 Mar 24

title: Pakistan media highlights 6 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection and assessment of key developments in Pakistan, as reported in frontline Pakistani press and online media outlets, as of 09:00 GMT on 6 March 2024.

PM Sharif announces relief package for rain-hit area

title: BBCM Iran Watchlist 9 Aug 25
snippet:
Stories being covered today by BBC Monitoring from Iranian broadcast, press and social media sources

photo
body:
JOMLEH DAILY

Iran welcomes Armenia-Azerbaijan deal, warns against foreign presence

The Iranian Foreign Ministry has "welcomed the finalisation of the text of the peace agreement" between Azerbaijan and Armenia, describing the deal as "an important step in achieving lasting peace in the region".

In a statement issued this morning, the Foreign Ministry said Iran was ready to cooperate with Baku and Yerevan to "safeguard peace, stability, and economic development of the region through bilateral and regional cooperation".

The statement however expressed Iran's concern regarding the negative consequences of "any external intervention", particularly "in close proximity to shared borders which could disrupt the security and sustainable stability of the region".

As part of the deal, the US will help build a major transit corridor, previously referred to as Zangazur and now named "the Trump Route for International Peace and Prosperity", to connect Azerbaijan and its autonomous Nakhchivan (Naxcivan) exclave - separated by Armenian territory.

Iran has long opposed Azerbaijan's plans to open the Zangazur corridor, via southern Armenia, repeatedly warning against any attempt to shift geopolitical borders in the Caucasus. Tehran is worried that the establishment of the corridor will sever its land border with Armenia.

Iranian state TV and radio reported on the deal this morning, highlighting Russia's warnings against US control over the corridor. Several Iranian newspapers this morning also reacted to the signing of the agreement.

Prominent hardline Keyhan daily said "Baku's policy of becoming a regional energy hub is in complete conflict with the interests of Iran and Russia". The article was headlined: "Armenia gives green light to US for 100-year lease of Zangazur Corridor".

State broadcaster's Jaam-e Jam labelled the development "Trump's chaos in the Caucasus", while the conservative Farhikhtegan described the deal as Armenia's "surrender to Washington's plan to destroy" the country.

The conservative Siasat-e Rouz daily said that the plan "can be considered a new American-Zionist conspiracy against the geopolitics of the Caucasus and Iran's regional and global position".

Initial online reaction to 'Trump Route'

Some hardline pro-establishment users on X accused President Massoud Pezeshkian of having overlooked the importance of the development and maintained that remaining silent about the so-called Zangazur corridor was "tantamount to treason". They argued that neglecting it now would "harm Iran's national interests for centuries to come".

Hardliner and conspiracy theorist Ali Akbar Raefipour argued that the US was poking "Iran's sensitivity" to its borders through the project.

Meanwhile, foreign-based Iranian analyst Hossein Aghaie stressed Iran "couldn't do a damn thing" to prevent the plans for the corridor.

A pro-Trump anti-establishment user welcomed the event as a "historic moment", as Trump was at the centre of it.

Press highlights pro-Hezbollah protest, rejects disarmament plan

Several Iranian newspapers this morning reacted to the Lebanese government's approval of a US proposal that would see the disarmament of the Iran-backed group, Hezbollah.

Hardline Javan daily, affiliated with the Islamic Revolution Guard Corps (IRGC), described the approval as "Kill shot at "Lebanon's 40-year unity" and said "the Lebanese government approved the Hezbollah disarmament plan by vote and without consensus".

The ultraconservative Keyhan daily quoted Ali Akbar Velayati, a senior adviser to the supreme leader, as saying that "disarming Lebanon's Hezbollah and Iraq's Popular Mobilisation Forces is an American-Zionist plan" against the "Islamic resistance".

Jaam-e Jam called it a "pipe dream of disarmament" and conservative Qods said "the disarmament of the Resistance" - a term used to describe Iran's allies and proxies - was a "dangerous fantasy".

The reformist Hammihan and the moderate Sazandegi newspapers were among several outlets that highlighted protests by Hezbollah supporters against the move.

Tehran condemns Israel's plan military occupation of Gaza

Iranian Foreign Ministry Spokesman Esmail Baqai yesterday "strongly condemned" Israel's "complete military occupation" and its "forcing" Gazans out of the Gaza Strip. Baqai called the decision "a plan to complete the genocide of the Palestinian nation".

He said it is "each and every government's legal and ethical responsibility to put an end to genocidein the occupied Palestine".

Keyhan daily highlighted on its front page Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi's call for an emergency meeting of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) to address what he described as a "systematic destruction" of Gaza's civilian population and Israel's alleged plans to permanently occupy the territory.

On 7 August, the Israeli cabinet approved a plan to "take over" Gaza City and give Palestinians a deadline of 7 October to evacuate the city and move to the south, Israeli media reported.

Iran condemns US 'interventionist' policies against Venezuela

Iran's Foreign Ministry yesterday condemned the US for what it described as its "interventionist behaviours" and positions against Venezuela and said that Iran will stand in solidarity with the people of Venezuela.

"Iran stands in solidarity with the people and government of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and condemns US unlawful interventions in Venezuela's domestic affairs," said a statement posted to the Foreign Ministry's X account in English and Spanish yesterday.

The US has doubled the reward for information leading to the arrest of Venezuelan President Nicols Maduro to $50m, accusing him of being "one of the largest narco-traffickers in the world".

US Attorney General Pam Bondi said Maduro was directly linked to drug smuggling operations.

title: Pakistan minister urges need to 'reassess' social media laws
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's Interior Minister Mohsin Naqvi has called for "better laws" to regulate online free speech, amid disruption of social media platform X entering its fifth week, prominent daily Dawn reported on its website.
body:
"We need to make better laws," he said in response to a question on whether his ministry was behind shutting down the platform, formerly known as Twitter.

"Expression is fine, but making false allegations against people is wrong - it’s happening and needs to be fixed," he told reporters, adding that campaigns were being run on social media against the judiciary and armed forces, which needs to be checked.

"We must reassess our own laws and look into what is being misused," he added.

The minister also cited US as an example saying "even in a country like the US, the ban has been imposed on TikTok after such (negative criticism) things. We also need to review our laws to regulate social media."

Several areas of Pakistan have seen disruption in access to X since 17 Feb, when former Rawalpindi commissioner Liaquat Chattha accused the chief election commissioner and the chief justice of Pakistan of rigging the  8 February general elections.

See also: Briefing: Pakistani media highlight rigging claims, delays in election results

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0500 GMT 20 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's newly-appointed PM, army chief discuss security issues
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's newly-appointed Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif met Chief of Army Staff General Asim Munir at the Prime Minister’s House in Islamabad on 6 March.
body:
Munir congratulated Sharif on the assumption of office and expressed his best wishes, Sharif's party Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) said in a post on X. The post added that the two also discussed professional and security issues at the meeting.

Sharif on 4 March took oath to officially become the 24th prime minister of the country, nearly a month after the 8 February general elections. 

The PML-N party and the Pakistan People's Party (PPP) agreed to form a coalition government as they failed to secure a clear majority in the elections.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in English 0800 GMT 6 Mar 24

title: Houthi official says group open to 'military cooperation' with Russia, China
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

A prominent official in Yemen's Houthi movement has suggested the possibility of military cooperation between the group and other countries including Russia and China.
body:
In a post published on his X (formerly Twitter) account on 14 March, Mohammed Ali al-Houthi, a prominent member of the Houthi Supreme Political Council, expressed the group's willingness to "cooperate with Russia, China as well as any Arab or Muslim nation, to exchange expertise with the Yemeni armed forces, considering the enemy is the same [common] one".

"The Yemeni army has a distinctive military maritime expertise built on practical effectiveness rather than drills or studies of the enemy from afar based on the theories of experts influenced by US propaganda," he added.

The Houthis, who oppose the internationally-recognised Aden-based government, refer to their own forces as the "Yemeni armed forces".

The statement comes on the same day Houthi leader Abdulmalek al-Houthi announced the group was ‘widening’ its maritime actions by targeting ships "linked to Israel" transiting via the Indian Ocean towards the Cape of Good Hope, on the southern tip of Africa.

See: Merchant ship reported damaged by missile in Red Sea

See also: Briefing: Houthi chief says group now targeting ‘Israeli’ ships in Indian Ocean

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Arabic 0239 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Afghan Taliban ministry condemns Israel's West Bank settlement plan
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Afghanistan's Taliban-run Ministry of Foreign Affairs has condemned Israel's approval for the construction of over 3,400 new homes in the West Bank, according to a statement it issued on its website and X (formerly Twitter) on 8 March.

title: Two women arrested in Iran after dancing in public
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Two women have been arrested in Iran after dancing in public in the Tajrish area of the capital, Tehran, the Tasnim News Agency, close to the Islamic Revolution Guards Corps (IRGC), reported on its X (formerly Twitter) account on 8 March.

title: Qatar says will support aid to Gaza through maritime corridor
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The spokesman for Qatar’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Majed al-Ansari, said on 12 March that Doha would support and finance the entry of aid into Gaza through the maritime corridor being set up by the US and others.
body:
“However, this does not in any way mean that this form of aid delivery will substitute land corridors which we still call for the necessity to unconditionally open,” Ansari said in his weekly media update.
