He stressed that Qatar would continue its aid flights to Gaza, the last of which arrived on 12 March in Egypt’s Arish International Airport carrying food and shelter supplies.

Ansari said this was the 85th aid flight sent from Qatar, and that it delivered 2,506 tonnes of aid.

He also noted that Qatar was working to reach a ceasefire in Gaza before Eid al-Fitr despite what he described as a “very complicated” situation on the ground and deteriorating humanitarian conditions in the strip.

"We are not near to a Gaza ceasefire deal but remain hopeful," he added.

See also: Briefing: Pan-Arab media highlight Biden’s plan to build pier in Gaza

Pan-Arab outlet reports concerns over sea port for Gaza aid delivery

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Arabic 1342 GMT 12 Mar 24

title: Qatar mediates return of children between Russia, Ukraine
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Qatar announced on 21 March “the success of its continued mediation efforts” to swap children between Russia and Ukraine.
body:
Minister of state for international cooperation, Lolwah al-Khater, said that the Qatari embassy in Moscow “is hosting the children and facilitating their safe travel to Ukraine”, adding that Qatari representatives “are facilitating the safe transfer of the children from Ukraine to Russia via Belarus”, Qatar’s foreign ministry said in a statement.

Meanwhile, Russian state news agency TASS reported yesterday that Russia has handed over five children to Ukraine, quoting Russian Presidential Commissioner for Children's Rights Maria Lvova-Belova as saying that “one of the children is returning to relatives in Russia”.

“In total, 64 children have already returned to Ukraine, 6 have reunited with relatives in Russia," she added.

See also: Russia says six children returned to Ukraine

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Arabic 1813 GMT 21 Mar 24

title: Haiti's national penitentiary, in downtown Port-au-Prince, reported 'on fire'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Haiti's National Penitentiary, the Caribbean country's largest prison located in the downtown area of Port-au-Prince, was "on fire" on 14 March, several Haitian news outlets reported on X.
body:
Gazette Haiti and Radio RFM 104.9 posted the same photograph of black smoke billowing from the prison facility, which is situated not far from the central Champs de Mars government area.

The reports said the origin of the fire was unknown but noted that the prison had been largely empty for the last 13 days after armed criminal gangs had assaulted it and freed several thousand inmates.

"The biggest prison in the country is going up in smoke," Radio Tele Metronome said in its posting.

Although the prison complex had been empty of inmates since the violent offensive by the gangs in the capital in early March, the blaze at the facility indicated that Haitian security forces' presence in, and control of, the downtown Port-au-Prince area remained extremely tenuous.

Haitian political leaders are trying to form a transitional presidential council to instal a new government and lead the violence-torn country to elections, after the announced resignation this week of Prime Minister Ariel Henry.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in French 1422 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Iran 'invites' Sudanese army chief to visit Tehran
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Iran has extended an invitation for Sudan’s de facto leader and army chief Abdel Fattah al-Burhan to visit Tehran, the privately-owned Barq news website reported on 30 March.
body:
“Reliable sources have confirmed that the president of the Transitional Sovereign Council has received an official invitation from the Iranian government to visit Tehran,” the website said on its X account.

There has been no official confirmation of the invitation.

Khartoum and Tehran restored diplomatic ties in October 2023 after seven years of hiatus. 

Reports have emerged since then of Iran supplying military equipment to Sudan’s army to support in the fight against the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF).

Sudan's army has denied receiving military aid from Iran during the current conflict with the RSF.

Foreign Minister Ali al-Sadiq visited Tehran in early February for the first time since the two nations restored ties.

See: Briefing: Sudan denies receiving military support from Iran

See also: Briefing: Iranian drones reportedly instrumental in recent Sudan army advances

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Arabic on 30 Mar 24

title: At least five Chinese engineers killed in northwest Pakistan attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

At least six people including five Chinese nationals have been killed in a suicide attack on their vehicle in northwest Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province's Shangla district, private television channel Geo News has reported a police official as saying.
body:
The Chinese nationals were engineers headed to the Dasu camp in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa's Kohistan district from Islamabad, the official added.

Condemning the attack, Pakistani President Asif Ali Zardari said that "forces hostile to Pakistan will never succeed in harming Pak-China friendship," in a post on X (formerly Twitter).

Privatisation Minister Abdul Aleem Khan termed the attack "very sad and condemnable" in a post on X.

"The enemy is targeting Pak-China friendship and CPEC under a well-thought-out conspiracy, but the nation will thwart all the nefarious conspiracies along with the Pakistan Army," the post said.

See also: Briefing: Pakistan militant attack puts focus on Chinese investments

Source: Geo News TV website, Karachi, in English 1100 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: (Corr) Governor of Russia's Belgorod reports third aerial attack on region
snippet:
(Removing paragraphs no 6 and no 7 from the original report headlined "Governor of Russia's Belgorod reports third aerial attack on region in a day" as they contain a reference to a now deleted post on X (formerly Twitter) which appeared to have falsely claimed that the footage of burning cars in the post was from Belgorod. Reports on social media suggest that that footage was not from Russia.)

By BBC Monitoring
body:
Vyacheslav Gladkov, governor of Russia's Belgorod Region, has reported a third aerial attack on the city of Belgorod in one day.

Gladkov said in a Telegram post that air defences had shot down 11 "aerial targets on the approaches to the city", in the latest incident on 14 March,

He said that a construction depot and one other business had been hit with two people injured at the former location.

In an earlier post on the same day Gladkov said a car had been hit in a rocket attack killing the driver.

Rossiya 24 news channel's report from Belgorod, at 1442 gmt on 14 March, featured video footage of a lorry and cars damaged by shrapnel. The correspondent said that the situation in the region remained "alarming".

Three pro-Ukraine paramilitary units that claimed to have fought their way into Russian territory earlier in the week have called on civilians in Belgorod and Kursk regions to evacuate.

The Freedom of Russia Legion (FRL), Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK), and Siberian Battalion issued a joint statementon 13 March saying they were "forced to fire at military positions" in Belgorod and Kursk because Russian forces had fired on Ukraine from there.

"To avoid casualties among the civilian population we are calling on everyone to immediately leave towns," the groups said.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 1434 gmt 14 Mar 24

title: Indian PM Modi condemns Moscow concert hall attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi on 23 March condemned the "heinous terrorist attack" at a concert hall in Moscow, which killed 60 and injured more than 100 others.
body:
"We strongly condemn the heinous terrorist attack in Moscow. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of the victims. India stands in solidarity with the government and the people of the Russian Federation in this hour of grief," Modi posted on X.

Meanwhile, Russian Embassy in India said in a post on X, "As a sign of mourning and grief for the victims of the terrorist attack in Moscow, the Russian Embassy in India flies the national flag at half-mast. We express our sincere condolences to the families of those deceased and wish a speedy recovery to all those injured."

The embassy account also reposted Modi's post condemning the attack.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in English 0203 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: Pakistan president, interior minister to forgo salaries amid economic challenges
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Pakistan's newly-appointed President Asif Ali Zardari and Interior Minister Mohsin Naqvi have decided to forgo their monthly salaries amid the country's economic challenges, Dawn newspaper reported on 13 March.

title: Houthi spokesman reiterates rebel pledge to continue operations against Israel
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The spokesman for Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi movement has reiterated that the rebels will continue operations in support of Palestinians until Israel halts its military campaign in Gaza and aid is delivered to the enclave.
body:
In a post on X (formerly Twitter) on 14 March, Mohammed Abdulsalam said that Yemen's position - referring to the stance of the Houthi movement - was "firm and will continue, by God's grace, on the side of Gaza". He added that the rebels would not abandon their position, which they considered a "religious, humanitarian and moral responsibility".

Houthi leader Abdulmalik al-Houthi

delivered a speech on 10 March to mark the start of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan, during which he said that the group would continue its operations in the Red Sea. 

The Iran-backed group announced in the early hours of 12 March as Ramadan began that its forces had hit an “American ship” named Pinocchio in the Red Sea with naval missiles.

See: Briefing: Houthis claim attack on "US ship" Pinocchio

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Arabic 0028 GMT 14 Mar 24

title: Police officer, infant die in clashes with 'terrorists' in south-east Iran
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

An Iranian police officer and an infant have died during a shooting in the Khash County in the south-eastern Sistan-Baluchestan Province between the local police and "terrorists", the official IRNA news agency reported on 26 March.
body:
IRNA reported that Lt Mohammad Zakhireh, a member of the ranger unit of the Khash police, was shot on the evening of 25 March, in clashes with members of a "hostile and terrorist group" on the Khash-Iranshahr road.

The report said that the officer succumbed to his injuries before reaching the local hospital, due to heavy bleeding and severity of the injuries.

A later IRNA report on the same day said that the "terrorists" also shot at a civilian vehicle, killing an infant and injuring two other passengers.

The foreign-based Baluch human rights collective Haalvsh had said in a 25 March post on X (formerly Twitter) that the civilian vehicle came under fire from the police forces who "randomly" opened fire after being attacked by a group of militants.

Neither IRNA nor Haalvsh identified the militant group involved in the clashes.

Situated on the borders with Afghanistan and Pakistan, the marginalised and impoverished province of Sistan-Baluchestan is home to some Sunni militants, and is also an entry point for smuggled goods, drugs and arms.

The Sunni militant group Jaish al-Adl, which is active in the province and has launched repeated attacks on security forces in the region, has not claimed responsibility for the attack.

Source: Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) website, Tehran, in Persian 0909 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: DR Congo denies signing military pact with Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

DR Congo's government has denied that it has signed a military agreement with Russia amid diplomatic tensions between the central African nation and neighbouring Rwanda.
body:
The ministry of communication said in a statement it posted on X (formerly Twitter) on 8 March that "until today, there has been no signed agreement on military cooperation between Russia and DR Congo".

It came after Congolese media reported that Russia had signed an agreement on military cooperation with DR Congo that would entail joint military exercises and training of the central African nation's forces.

The ministry said that there were currently no talks underway on such a deal.

It comes as DR Congo grapples with a rebellion in its east it says is backed by Rwanda, an accusation which has raised tensions between the two countries but which Kigali has denied.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in French on 8 Mar 24

title: Ukraine asks for more air defence after recent attacks
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba has called for more air defence systems, specifically the US-made Patriot system, after Russian bombardments that left destruction and wounded in Kyiv on 25 March.
body:
Shortly after two missiles were intercepted over Kyiv, he said on X, formerly Twitter: "There are no atrocities Russian bastards would not commit, including an attempt of a ballistic strike at the heart of a multimillion city".

His post contained a video of what appears to be schoolchildren running for cover as explosions sound out and air sirens blast in the background.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in English 0946 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Somali spy agency identifies Mogadishu market attackers
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The Somali National Intelligence Security Agency (Nisa) has identified six men who were allegedly behind bomb attacks in Mogadishu's main market on 6 February after it released footage from CCTV cameras, the state-owned broadcaster Somali National TV (SNTV) has reported.

title: Blocked Venezuela oppositon contender says Maduro government 'removed its mask'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado said on 26 March President Nicolas Maduro's government had "removed its mask" by blocking candidates of the main opposition coalition, the MUD (Democratic Unity Roundtable), from registering candidates for a 28 July presidential election, and she added the international community "no longer has any excuses" for ignoring this, Venezuelan pro-opposition VPItv reported in postings on X.
body:
Machado, whose own presidential candidacy ratified in opposition primaries in October 2023 remained disqualified by Venezuela's pro-Maduro electoral and judicial authorities, denounced that the replacement candidate announced on 22 March by her campaign, 80-year-old academic Corina Yoris,  had been "impeded" from registering with the National Electoral Commission (CNE) by a 25 March deadline.

"The [Maduro] regime with its accomplices removed its mask to close this electoral path. The real opposition is united. The international community no longer has any excuses, this is too grotesque," Machado added, quoted by VPItv which published video excerpts of her statements made in Caracas.

The opposition leader noted that "the regime chose its candidates", referring to the fact that left-wing President Maduro had been registered as the official presidential candidate of the ruling Chavist movement, and that a group of other candidates, many of them seen as moderate members of the opposition or linked to the government, had also been allowed to register by electoral authorities. 

"Every day they invent a new conspiracy, Venezuelans know who I am," Machado added, cited by VPItv, recalling a recent wave of arrests by the Maduro authorities targeting key members of her presidential campaign team.

In her comments, Machado indicated that she and her chosen replacement candidate, Yoris, would continue to campaign for MUD participation in the upcoming elections, through what she called "citizen participation".

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Spanish 1551 GMT 26 Mar 24

title: Kenya to lead Haiti mission once new government in place
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

President William Ruto has reiterated that Kenya will take leadership of the UN Security Support Mission in Haiti once a presidential council is set up in the Caribbean nation.
body:
In a post on his X (formerly Twitter) account, President Ruto said he held talks with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken over the developments in Haiti and underscored Kenya's commitment to the mission.

"He informed me that a new Presidential Council will be formed shortly to manage the situation in Haiti. I assured Secretary Blinken that Kenya will take leadership of the UN Security Support Mission in Haiti to restore peace and security in Haiti as soon as the Presidential Council is in place under an agreed process," Ruto said.

This comes after Kenya on 12 March said it would delay the deployment of 1,000 police officers to the Caribbean nation following the resignation of Haiti's Prime Minister Ariel Henry.

Kenyan media and the public have questioned the ability of the East African nation's police force to tackle gang violence in Haiti, citing internal security crises, including "banditry" in Kenya's north-western regions.

See Briefing: Analysts urge caution as Kenya delays police mission to Haiti

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in English 13 Mar 24

title: Iran denies blast in refinery caused by cyber attack
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

The spokesman of Iran's National Cyberspace Centre (NCC) denied that a cyber attack had targeted the Aftab oil refinery in the southern province of Hormozgan, resulting in a blast in the facility.
body:
The NCC spokesman Hossein Dalirian, in his account on X (formerly Twitter), on 8 March, rejected "rumours" that the refinery had been hit by a cyber attack.

The spokesman called on the media to avoid spreading "misinformation".

On 7 March, Iran's media reported a blast in a furnace of the refinery which left a worker dead and three others injured.

The governor of Bandar Abbas, the capital of Hormozgan, said that the explosion happened during welding operations on the furnace.

According to IRNA news agency, Aftab refinery is the largest private exporter of oil products in the country.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Persian 1226 GMT 8 Mar 24

title: Turkey detains 40 IS suspects in nationwide raids - interior minister
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Turkish Interior Minister Ali Yerlikaya has said 40 individuals suspected of affiliation with the Islamic State (IS) group have been detained in recent raids across Turkey, days after the group claimed a deadly attack in Russia's capital, Moscow.
body:
Yerlikaya said in a post on X (formerly Twitter) on 24 March that the raids took place in eight different provinces.

"[Overall] we conducted 1,316 operations against the terrorist organisation Deash [Arabic acronym for IS] between 1 June 2023 and 23 March 2024," he added.

He said Turkey detained 2,733 suspects in these raids, arresting 692 of them.

IS's presence in Turkey was widely discussed in January after it claimed responsibility for a fatal church attack in Istanbul.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Turkish 1120 GMT 24 Mar 24

title: Highlights from India's Marathi-language press, websites 13 Mar 24
snippet:
The following is a BBCM selection of major news items from select Indian Marathi-language press and online media outlets 13 March 2024.

Sakal
body:
Survey says political party to emerge as majority in elections

According to a survey conducted by daily Sakal, Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is expected to be the leading party in western state Maharashtra in the forthcoming Lok Sabha (lower house of parliament) elections with it being the choice of 33.6% respondents. However, it reportedly also says that impact of Maha Vikas Aghadi [MVA, coalition mainly comprising Uddhav Balasaheb Thackeray party, Nationalist Congress Party (NCP)-Sharadchandra Pawar faction and Congress party] along with Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) might be more than that of BJP-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA). The survey conducted in all 48 seats of the state, also reportedly concludes that the BJP will face a "challenge" to gain votes because of "limited" strength of its partners in Mahayuti (grand coalition) Shiv Sena (Chief Minister Eknath Shinde faction) and NCP (Ajit Pawar faction). [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 500] 

Editorial on implementation of citizen amendment law

"In short, this decision is not likely to have much impact besides polarisation of Hindu votes. In the event, these non-Muslims without citizenship gain citizenship, they cannot vote in the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections. That is because voters lists have been published. But undoubtedly, the decision is part of BJP's Hindutva [ideology of Hindu nationalism] agenda. Whether or not people approve of the journey in this direction has to be decided by Indian voters in these elections [Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) passed by parliament in 2019 grants citizenship to non-Muslim refugees- Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, Buddhists, Parsis and Christians- entering India by 31 December 2014 from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh. Protests had followed in different parts of the country, including national capital New Delhi, the passage of law.]." [Page: 6, Approximate Words: 600]

[Sakal is the largest-circulation Marathi-language daily run by the family of Sharad Pawar, chief of the Maharashtra-based Nationalist Congress Party (NCP). The paper expectedly backs the NCP and often criticises its opposition parties.]

Lokmat

Politician assures share in development to tribal groups

Congress party former Chief Rahul Gandhi, whose Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra (tour for integrating India and justice) entered Maharashtra on 12 March said in Nandurbar (western district) that real owner of this country are tribal communities only but the BJP is trying to deprive them of their rights by referring to them as forest dwellers. Gandhi said that Congress party after coming to power will ensure them their right and their share in development of the country in proportion of their population. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

Tussle in coalition partners over seats in parliament

NCP (Ajit Pawar faction) Maharashtra spokesperson, Anand Paranjape, on 12 March advised Chief Minister Eknath Shinde to check Shiv Sena former Member of Legislative Assembly (MLA), Vijay Shivtare, warning that otherwise, there could be a different result in Kalyan Lok Sabha seat (constituency of chief minister's son, Shrikant Shinde). Shivtare had recently announced his candidature from Baramati area seat. The NCP has already announced that it will contest this seat presently represented by NCP-Sharadchandra Pawar party working President Supriya Sule. [Page: 2, Approximate Words: 120]

[Lokmat is a popular Marathi-language daily edited by Vijay Darda, a Congress party member. The paper is mostly critical of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) government especially on its handling of Kashmir, terrorism and economic issues.]

Saamana

Ex-chief minister claims party seeks to change constitution

Former Chief Minister and Chief of Uddhav Balasaheb Thackeray party, Uddhav Thackeray, while speaking at in Yavatmal (western district) on 12 March, said that the BJP seeks to change the constitution and seize all authority. He added that for it, the party wants to win more than 400 seats in the lower house of the parliament [out of a total of 543 seats]. Thackeray claimed that in case party captures all powers, there will be no elections in the future and the BJP will also take over courts. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 550]

Reply sought on plea challenging affirmative action

Bombay High Court on 12 March sought reply from the Maharashtra government over the petition challenging affirmative action law to grant 10% reservation in jobs and education to Maratha community passed in the state legislature on 20 February. The government had sought three weeks to submit its reply but court granted it two weeks while directing it to submit the report of backward class commission, on which affirmative action is based. Petitioners have objected to the report and appointment of its members. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 300]

[Saamana is the mouthpiece of the Maharashtra-based political party Shiv Sena. This nationalist and right-leaning daily supports the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) government on national security, terrorism and Kashmir issues. However, it is very critical of the government on economy and unemployment issues.]

Pudhari

Politician proposes discussion with party over seat sharing

VBA Chief Prakash Ambedkar has written to Congress party President, Mallikarjun Kharge, proposing separate discussion with party over seat sharing for Lok Sabha elections. The letter dated 10 March was posted on X (formerly Twitter) on 12 March, which has reportedly revealed differences in MVA constituents, Uddhav Balasaheb Thackeray party and Congress party, over seat sharing. Ambedkar has expressed the expectation that soon a date will be set for discussion. [Page: II, Approximate Words: 250]

Candidates from state not announced by party

Congress party on 12 March announced its second list of candidates for the Lok Sabha elections but no candidate was announced for seats in Maharashtra as seat sharing in MVA is not finalised yet. The first list was declared on 8 March. BJP has also not yet announced any candidate from state. [Page: 2, Approximate Words: 120]

[Pudhari is the second-largest Marathi-language daily that is nationalist and right-of-centre. The daily backs the Indian government on issues such as national security, terrorism and Kashmir.]

Maharashtra Times

News report notes pressure of coalition partners on party

Federal Home Minister, Amit Shah, was in Maharashtra last week but seat sharing for Lok Sabha is not yet finalised in Mahayuti. Shiv Sena and NCP are reportedly insisting on honourable share in seats. The new formula is reportedly of 31 seats for BJP, 13 for Shiv Sena and four for NCP but the issue has not been solved yet. Chief Minister Eknath Shinde, Deputy Chief Ministers Devendra Fadnavis and Ajit Pawar will visit New Delhi (national capital) to hold discussions with the BJP leadership in a day or two. Shiv Sena is reportedly insisting on 13 seats despite advice from Shah that it should ask for seats that it is likely to win. [Online, Approximate Words: 180]

[Maharashtra Times is a Marathi-language daily from the influential Times of India media group. The daily is observed to be critical of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government on its handling of the economic issues and alleged suppression of dissent. However, it backs the government on national security issues.]

Loksatta

Politician resigns from party

Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) politician, Vasant More, has resigned from primary membership of the party and all posts reportedly due to "factionalism". There are reportedly discussions about More's proximity to NCP-Sharadchandra Pawar and he had also met party chief Sharad Pawar recently. However, More said that for now, he will not join any party. [Page: 4, Approximate Words: 100]

[Loksatta is the third largest-circulation Marathi-language daily, which is run by the Indian Express Group that owns respected English-language daily The Indian Express. The daily generally carries objective reporting on local Maharashtra and regional issues.]

Tarun Bharat

Editorial views risk in citizenship law implementation

"BJP has taken a great risk [by announcing implementation of CAA] when hardly a few days are left for announcement of elections. The BJP has decided to implement this law urgently to draw all Hindu votes towards it, realising that it will not get Muslim votes anyway. It is bound to have far-reaching consequences. However, it will liberate these citizens living in neighbouring nations from persecution by the governments there." [Online, Approximate Words: 700]

[Tarun Bharat is a Marathi-language daily that is largely supportive of right-wing political entities, including the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Marathi 0000 GMT 13 Mar 24

title: Pakistan's Samaa TV show on new prime minister, media censorship
snippet:
The following is a summary of the talk show "Mere Sawal" (My Questions), hosted by anchor Muneeb Farooq on moderate Samaa News TV in Urdu at 15:00 GMT on 3 March 2024. The programme invites politicians and analysts to express their opinions on important issues.

Anchor Muneeb Farooq announced Shehbaz Sharif (president of the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz, PML-N) was elected as the prime minister on 3 March and he delivered a speech after his election. He noted the opposition commented that in his speech, Sharif only spoke about problems and the new government does not have a solution to those problems. He said none of the governments which came into power in the recent years had a solution. He further noted in his speech, Sharif "took ownership" of measures taken against those involved in the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged members of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, PTI). He added Sharif spoke about the need for a "charter of reconciliation".
body:
Farooq spoke with PML-N politician Ataullah Tarar and asked him why the speech of the opposition's candidate for prime ministership, Omar Ayub Khan, was not shown on PTV (state-owned broadcaster) but Sharif's speech was broadcast live. Tarar said Sharif delivered a "balanced speech" and did not talk about political revenge or chaos, instead he spoke about national harmony and reconciliation. He added he spoke about the economy, foreign policy and every section of the society, including labourers, farmers and women.

Tarar noted live coverage of Omar Khan's speech was interrupted but claimed it was not in the knowledge of the prime minister or anyone else. He said when pointed out, the deputy speaker took notice immediately and the transmission was resumed. He was of the view that the speech should have been "transmitted live end to end" and said he would ask the speaker and deputy speaker of the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament) to ensure that speeches of the opposition members are covered live.

Farooq played a clip of a statement by Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam (JUI) chief Maulana Fazl-ur-Rehman in which he claimed the elections were stolen and the [military] establishment is responsible for the theft. He added this is why the JUI will sit in the opposition this time. Farooq asked Tarar how he would respond to Rehman's allegations. Tarar insisted the election results should be accepted by all. He questioned if the establishment was involved in rigging, then why did Ali Amin Gandapur (PTI politician allegedly involved in the 9 May attacks) win the election and why several prominent PML-N politicians lost the polls. He said complaints about election results should be taken to election tribunals.

Tarar said he is against the blocking of social media platform X (formerly Twitter) or any other platform but emphasised that all political parties should agree upon a "code of conduct" regarding social media. He remarked 9 May was a "dangerous plan" and noted Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif said any prisoner being kept in jail without evidence of involvement in the 9 May incidents should be released.

Senior journalist Mazhar Abbas said he has been demanding that PTV should be a free and independent channel. He noted PTV was to be a national TV channel, but it has been turned into a state-controlled channel. He claimed there is an "undeclared censorship" in place at the moment and digital media is being controlled. He was of the view that freeing the media would be a challenge for Sharif's new government.

Speaking about the allegations of election rigging, Abbas said a "high-powered commission" should be formed and all parties should agree that they would accept the findings of the commission. He was of the view that the 9 May cases have been used for political advantage.

Farooq asked analyst Mansoor Ali Khan whether a commission could be formed. Khan claimed the PML-N would never want to form a commission because it has gotten into power and Shehbaz Sharif has been elected as the prime minister. He further claimed there is no need for a commission to investigate as journalists saw that the results were changed. He said Omar Khan's speech was censored because a person holding former prime minister Imran Khan's picture stood on his side and PTV did not want to show that picture. He remarked this is the state of censorship that the country is currently facing.

Source: Samaa TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1500 GMT 3 Mar 24

title: Ukraine raps Pope's 'white flag' remark about talks with Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Commenting on Pope Francis urging Ukraine to have the "courage of the white flag" and to start peace talks with Russia "before things get worse", Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba has called on the Vatican to pick a side in the battle between good an evil and avoid repeating past mistakes.
body:
Kuleba said in English on X, formerly Twitter, on 10 March, "The strongest is the one who, in the battle between good and evil, stands on the side of good rather than attempting to put them on the same footing and call it 'negotiations'. At the same time, when it comes to the white flag, we know this Vatican's strategy from the first half of the twentieth century. I urge you to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past and to support Ukraine and its people in their just struggle for their lives. Our flag is a yellow and blue one. This is the flag by which we live, die, and prevail. We shall never raise any other flags. We thank His Holiness Pope Francis for his constant prayers for peace, and we continue to hope that after two years of devastating war in the heart of Europe, the Pontiff will find an opportunity to pay an Apostolic visit to Ukraine to support over a million Ukrainian Catholics, over five million Greek-Catholics, all Christians, and all Ukrainians."

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in Ukrainian 1331 gmt 10 Mar 24

title: Ukraine minister asks EU's Borrell for more air defence systems
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba has urged the EU to provide more air defence systems to Ukraine during a phone call with the bloc's foreign policy chief Josep Borrell.
body:
"I spoke with @JosepBorrellF and briefed him on Russian ballistic missile strikes on the Ukrainian capital and other cities. I appreciate HRVP's expression of support and concern regarding the number of Russian missiles fired at Ukraine. I stressed the importance of delivering more Patriot and other air defence systems capable of intercepting ballistic missiles to Ukraine," Kuleba posted in English on X (formerly Twitter) on 25 March.

"I also emphasised that Ukraine is currently the only country in the world that is being attacked by ballistic missiles almost daily. Therefore, Patriots must be stationed here and now to save human lives, rather than remaining in places where the missile threat is zero. We discussed what the EU can do to help Ukraine get more Patriots and other air defence systems ASAP. I appreciate HRVP Borrell's and the EU's support," he wrote.

Source: X (formerly Twitter) in English 1747 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: Passenger buses from Ukraine 'being stopped at Polish border'
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Passenger buses travelling from Ukraine into Poland are being stopped by Polish police, with passengers "detained without explanation", the Interfax-Ukraine news agency has reported.
body:
"There is unpleasant news from the blocked Polish border. Protesters and police are stopping buses going to and from Poland. Passengers are being held without any explanation," said an X (formerlly Twitter) post from Oleksandr Kubrakov, minister for communities and territories development and infrastructure of Ukraine.

"We emphasise that these actions are unacceptable in relation to Ukrainian citizens. During the war in Ukraine, the passengers on such buses are women with young children, socially vulnerable categories, military personnel returning or going to training, and people in transit. An attempt to make them hostages to a protest seems inappropriate for the civilised world," he added.

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1403 gmt 11 Mar 24

snippet: MOSCOW (AP)  Islamic State group claims responsibility for Moscow attack in statement posted on affiliated channels on social media.

title: IS publishes images of deadly attack on 'Christian' village in Mozambique
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has published a set of photos showing an attack on a village in northern Mozambique that it said killed six people described as Christians on 6 March.
body:
The jihadist group published the batch of eight images on 18 March via its accounts on Telegram on behalf of its so-called Mozambique Province branch.

IS claimed responsibility for the attack on 15 March, claiming that militants killed six people and burned down a school and homes in the village of Pulo in Cabo Delgado province's Metuge district.

The images showed militants beheading two captives, at least three other corpses, a fire set in a "Christian" school and a burning home.

Domestic media reported on 7 March that militants had killed one person and abducted nine students from a secondary school and women from the village.

The militants released the captives hours after the raid, domestic media later reported.

 IS has significantly stepped up its attacks in Cabo Delgado province since the start of this year, focusing its violence on Christian communities.

The violence has recently centred in the province's Macomia and Chiure districts, while attacks have been rare in Metuge.

See more: IS claims killing six Christians, burning school in north Mozambique

Analysis: Islamic State violence surges in northern Mozambique

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1700 GMT 18 Mar 24

title: IS releases rare 'daily life' images of militants in Mozambique
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has released rare images depicting the "daily life" of its militants in Mozambique, in a clear effort to project strength, especially following the group's recent "feats" in the country.
body:
IS published the set of 25 photos in the name of its so-called Mozambique Province branch on 10 March via its channels on Telegram .

The images show militants engaged in a wide range of activities, including performing group prayers, watching videos, feasting together, attending lectures, and preparing and setting off for battle.

They were published a day before the start of Ramadan, which most Muslims marked on 11 March.

Such "daily life" images used to be a staple of IS propaganda in the jihadist group's heyday, and used for recruitment when it controlled large swathes of territory in Syria, Iraq and elsewhere. They became scarce over the years.

The last time the group published such images was in July 2022, depicting the "daily life" of militants in Syria.

The latest Mozambique images suggest that militants in that country now enjoy relative strength and security in areas where they operate.

They compliment the group's recent surge in the north of the country, where it has been claiming a significant number of attacks this year mostly against Christian communities, as well as reaching out to Muslims in the region.

See: Analysis: Islamic State violence surges in northern Mozambique

The images

The latest images show militants in what appears to be a dense forest area. The images' captions do not specify the location where the images were taken, but it is likely to be in the northern Cabo Delgado province, where IS is most active.

Some of the images show about a dozen men performing prayers together. Other images show militants reading the Quran.

One image shows a militant on watch duty, while other photos show dozens of militants "preparing" for battle.

A couple of other photos show militants watching what appears to be a recent video by IS's Afghanistan-focused Khorasan Province branch (ISKP).

Other photos shows militants slaughtering a goat, cooking the meat and eating together.

One set of images depicts a group of masked, armed men listening to what appears to be battle instructions by other men who are standing.

A final couple of photos show dozens of men "heading to fight crusaders".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1703 gmt 10 Mar 24

title: IS claims suicide attack during Nigeria army operation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has claimed that multiple soldiers were "killed and injured" during a suicide bombing, in response to an army assault on militant camps in Alagarno forest in Nigeria's north-eastern Borno state.
body:
IS made the claim a statement it issued on 3 March on behalf of IS's West Africa Province branch (ISWAP), via the group's official Telegram channels.

The statement said that militants clashed with soldiers who "sought to advance upon mujahidin positions" in the vicinity of Alagarno forest on 28 February.

It added that during this incident IS staged a suicide attack, perpetrated by an individual identified as Haroun al-Ansari "killing and injuring a number of" soldiers, and "damaging several vehicles".

ISWAP in the past has frequently staged suicide attacks using SVBIEDs (suicide vehicle-borne improvised explosive devises) in response to army crackdowns against militant camps. Most ISWAP suicide attackers have been identified with the nom de guerre "al-Ansari", which suggests that the individual was a local of the country or region.

See: Briefing: IS uses suicide bombers to repel army offensive in Nigeria (May 2023)

A statement by the army regarding a military operation in the Alagarno region on the same day provided a rather different account of events. It said that despite the use of an SVBIED, militants "fell under the overwhelming superior fire power of the troops, forcing them to abandon their stronghold, armaments and equipment in disarray".

The army statement reported the capture of large amounts of equipment, including an armoured vehicle. Reporting indicated that three IS militants were killed in the operation. No mention was made of possible military casualties.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1849 gmt 3 Mar 24

title: IS releases photos of attacks on al-Qaeda fighters in Mali, Burkina Faso
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has published two sets of photos that showed recent operations in Mali and Burkina Faso, including the execution of a senior al-Qaeda commander.
body:
The jihadist group issued the separate batches of photos on 18 March via its channels on Telegram on behalf of its so-called Sahel Province branch.

IS said a set of 14 images showed an ambush on al-Qaeda militants in Mali's Gao region that resulted in the death of 16 fighters and the capture and subsequent execution of four others.

IS had detailed the attack in the Ansongo area in the latest edition of its weekly newspaper al-Naba, published on 15 March, claiming that a senior al-Qaeda official, Ilyas (also spelled Iliassou, aka Amadou Moussa), was executed in the aftermath.

The images showed IS militants engaged in a gunfight, six corpses, the killing of four captured fighters and looted weapons.

Domestic media reported that an al-Qaeda commander was killed in clashes near the village of Intillit on 9 March.

The same day, IS published another set of four images that it said showed an attack on al-Qaeda fighters in north-eastern Burkina Faso.

The group also detailed the attack in the Dori area in the last edition of al-Naba, claiming two fighters were killed and another captured.

The images showed two corpses, a blindfolded captive and looted weapons.

The rival jihadist groups, which have been at war with each other in the region since 2020, regularly claim to have mounted attacks against each other.

See more: IS claims killing senior al-Qaeda commander in Mali

IS claims attacks on army and militant rivals in Mali, Burkina Faso

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1100 GMT 18 Mar 24

Summary of programme broadcast on privately-owned Somali Radio Simba on 7 March at 10:00 GMT

title: Uzbekistan urges citizens not to visit crowded places in Russia
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Uzbekistan's external labour migration agency has called on the country's citizens in Russia not to visit crowded places after the recent terrorist attack on a concert hall in Moscow, the privately-owned news website Gazeta.uz reported on 27 March.
body:
"In particular, Uzbek citizens should carry documents confirming their identity and their right to stay or work in the country, they should not visit crowded places without a reason, nor communicate with strangers or suspicious people, nor keep prohibited photo, audio and video material on their phones and other devices. When planning a trip, they are recommended to arrive at the railway station or airport earlier than planned," the report said, citing the agency.

The agency's press secretary Ortikkhuja Norov said that there were more than 1m Uzbek migrants in Russia.

He also denied reports that Uzbek and other Central Asian migrants in Russia were facing problems after the recent terrorist attack in Moscow.

"Most of the allegations about migrants being denied individual business licences and being expelled from the country are untrue, especially as far as Uzbek citizens are concerned. As for the videos that have emerged about individual business licences not being issued, we have spoken to the staff of a migration centre in Russia and they said that such rumours are not true," Norov said, as quoted by the website.

He admitted that document checks and raids may have taken place amid the current heightened security measures, but said they had been carried out "before".

Norov also said there was no need for Uzbek migrants to rush home at the moment.

"There is no need to return home as soon as possible. We can see the developments, Russia's official position is not against migrant workers either. I think that migrants can continue their work," Norov added.

On 22 March, a group of Tajik gunmen attacked Crocus City Hall as a concert was about to begin, shooting people indiscriminately. Islamic State has claimed responsibility. The latest figures put the death toll at 140, with hundreds injured.  

Source: Gazeta.uz website, Tashkent, in Russian 0800 GMT 27 Mar 24

title: IS claims killing six Syrian soldiers in Homs desert
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has claimed the killing of six Syrian soldier in two attacks in Syria’s Homs province.
body:
The group published two brief claims on 25 March via its channels on Telegram. 

The first claim stated that IS had captured and shot dead two soldiers in desert areas near the town of Palmyra on 24 March.

The second statement detailed an attack to the west of the town of Sukhna in which IS claimed to have taken prisoner four soldiers before interrogating and shooting them dead. The 'urgent' styling of this statement indicates that this attack likely occurred on the same day as its publication.

Earlier in March, IS claimed a similar attack in which it captured and shot dead three army personnel near Sukhna.

There has been a significant uptick in IS attack claims in Syria since the beginning of 2024, especially in Deir al-Zour, Raqqa, and Homs. IS has claimed an average of over 30 attacks per month so far in 2024, roughly three times the monthly number in 2023.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1430 GMT 25 Mar 24

title: IS claims killing six Christians, burning school in north Mozambique
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has belatedly claimed to have killed six people described as Christians and destroyed a school and homes in northern Mozambique on 6 March.
body:
The jihadist group published the claim on 15 March on behalf of its so-called Mozambique Province branch via its channels on Telegram.

The statement said IS militants attacked the village of Pulo in Cabo Delgado province's Metuge district, killing six "Christians".

It added that the militants burned down 29 homes and a Christian school in the village.

Domestic media reported on 7 March that militants had killed one person and abducted nine students from a secondary school and women from the village.

The militants released the captives hours after the raid, domestic media later reported.

IS has significantly stepped up its attacks in Cabo Delgado province since the start of this year, focusing its violence on Christian communities.

See more: Analysis: Islamic State violence surges in northern Mozambique

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1730 GMT 15 Mar 24

Islamic State group (IS) has claimed that it executed nine Christians in an attack on a village in north-east Democratic Republic of Congo (DR Congo).

title: 4 Men Showing Signs of Beating Charged With Terrorism After Moscow Attack
snippet:
The four accused of carrying out an assault at a concert hall near Moscow are migrant laborers from Tajikistan. They face a maximum sentence of life in prison.

The four men suspected of carrying out a bloody attack on a concert hall near Moscow, killing at least 137 people, were arraigned in a district court late Sunday and charged with committing a terrorist act.
body:
The four, who were from Tajikistan but worked as migrant laborers in Russia, were remanded in custody until May 22, according to state and independent media outlets reporting from the proceedings, at Basmanny District Court. They face a maximum sentence of life in prison.

The press service of the court only announced that the first two defendants, Dalerjon B. Mirzoyev and Saidakrami M. Rachalbalizoda, pleaded guilty to the charges. It did not specify any plea from the other two, Mediazona, an independent news outlet, reported.

The men looked severely battered and injured as each of them was brought into the courtroom separately. Videos of them being tortured and beaten while under interrogation circulated widely on Russian social media.

Muhammadsobir Z. Fayzov, a 19-year-old barber and the youngest of the men charged, was rolled into the courtroom from a hospital emergency room on a tall, orange wheelchair, attended by a doctor, the reports said. He sat propped up in the wheelchair inside the glass cage for defendants, wearing a catheter and an open hospital gown with his chest partially exposed. Often speaking in Tajik through a translator, he answered questions about his biography quietly and stammered, according to Mediazona.

Mr. Rachabalizoda, 30, had a large bandage hanging off the right side of his head where interrogators had sliced off a part of his ear and forced it into his mouth, the reports said, with the cutting captured in a video that spread online.

The judge allowed the press to witness only parts of the hearings, citing concerns that sensitive details about the investigation might be revealed or the lives of court workers put at risk. It is not an unusual ruling in Russia.

Russias Federal Security Services announced on Saturday that 11 people had been detained, including the four charged men, who were arrested after the car they were fleeing in was intercepted by the authorities 230 miles southwest of Moscow.

In the attack, on Friday night, four gunmen opened fire inside the hall just as a rock concert by the group Piknik was due to start. They also set off explosive devices that ignited the building and eventually caused its roof to collapse. Aside from the dead, there were 182 injured, and more than 100 remain hospitalized, according to the regional health ministry.

President Vladimir V. Putin used the fact that the highway where the men were detained leads to Ukraine to suggest that the attack was somehow linked to Ukraines war effort. But the United States has said repeatedly that the attack was the work of an extremist jihadi organization, the Islamic State, which claimed responsibility.

The first charged, Mr. Mirzoyev, who had a black eye and cuts and bruises all over his face, leaned for support against the glass wall of the court cage as the charge against him was read. Mr. Mirzoyev, 32, has four children and had a temporary residence permit in the southern Siberian city of Novosibirsk, but it had expired, the reports said.

Mr. Rachabalizoda, married with a child, said he was legally registered in Russia but did not remember where.

The fourth man charged, Shamsidin Fariduni, 25, married with an 8-month-old baby, worked in a factory producing parquet in the Russian city of Podolsk, just southwest of Moscow. He had also worked as a handyman in Krasnogorsk, the Moscow suburb where the attack took place at Crocus City Hall, at a concert venue within a sprawling shopping complex just outside the Moscow city limits.

The Islamic State has been able to recruit hundreds of adherents among migrant laborers from Central Asia in Russia who are often angry about the discrimination they frequently face.

Alina Lobzina, Paul Sonne and Milana Mazaeva contributed reporting.

title: Deadly Moscow Attack Shatters Putins Security Promise to Russians
snippet:
The tragedy outside Moscow is a blow to a leader riding an aura of confidence only days after a stage-managed election victory.

Less than a week ago, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia claimed a fifth term with his highest-ever share of the vote, using a stage-managed election to show the nation and the world that he was firmly in control.
body:
Just days later came a searing counterpoint: His vaunted security apparatus failed to prevent Russias deadliest terrorist attack in 20 years.

The assault on Friday, which killed at least 133 people at a concert hall in suburban Moscow, was a blow to Mr. Putins aura as a leader for whom national security is paramount. That is especially true after two years of a war in Ukraine that he describes as key to Russias survival  and which he cast as his top priority after the election last Sunday.

The election demonstrated a seemingly confident victory, Aleksandr Kynev, a Russian political scientist, said in a phone interview from Moscow. And suddenly, against the backdrop of a confident victory, theres this demonstrative humiliation.

Mr. Putin seemed blindsided by the assault. It took him more than 19 hours to address the nation about the attack, the deadliest in Russia since the 2004 school siege in Beslan, in the countrys south, which claimed 334 lives. When he did, the Russian leader said nothing about the mounting evidence that a branch of the Islamic State committed the attack.

Instead, Mr. Putin hinted that Ukraine was behind the tragedy and said the assailants had acted just like the Nazis, who once carried out massacres in the occupied territories  evoking his frequent, false description of present-day Ukraine as being run by neo-Nazis.

Our common duty now  our comrades at the front, all citizens of the country  is to be together in one formation, Mr. Putin said at the end of a five-minute speech, trying to conflate the fight against terrorism with his invasion of Ukraine.

The question is how much of the Russian public will buy into his argument. They might ask whether Mr. Putin, with the invasion and his conflict with the West, truly has the countrys security interests at heart  or whether he is woefully forsaking them, as many of his opponents say he is.

The fact that Mr. Putin apparently ignored a warning from the United States about a potential terrorist attack is likely to deepen the skepticism. Instead of acting on the warnings and tightening security, he dismissed them as provocative statements.

All this resembles outright blackmail and an intention to intimidate and destabilize our society, Mr. Putin said on Tuesday in a speech to the F.S.B., Russias domestic intelligence agency, referring to the Western warnings. After the attack on Friday, some of his exiled critics have cited his response as evidence of the presidents detachment from Russias true security concerns.

Rather than keeping society safe from actual, violent terrorists, those critics say, Mr. Putin has directed his sprawling security services to pursue dissidents, journalists and anyone deemed a threat to the Kremlins definition of traditional values.

A case in point: Just hours before the attack, state media reported that the Russian authorities had added the L.G.B.T. movement to an official list of terrorists and extremists; Russia had already outlawed the gay rights movement last year. Terrorism was also among the many charges prosecutors leveled against Aleksei A. Navalny, the imprisoned opposition leader who died last month.

In a country in which counterterrorism special forces chase after online commenters, Ruslan Leviev, an exiled Russian military analyst, wrote in a social media post on Saturday, terrorists will always feel free.

Even as the Islamic State repeatedly claimed responsibility for the attack and Ukraine denied any involvement, the Kremlins messengers pushed into overdrive to try to persuade the Russian public that this was merely a ruse.

Olga Skabeyeva, a state television host, wrote on Telegram that Ukrainian military intelligence had found assailants who would look like ISIS. But this is no ISIS. Margarita Simonyan, the editor of the state-run RT television network, wrote that reports of Islamic State responsibility amounted to a basic sleight of hand by the American news media.

On a prime-time television talk show on the state-run Channel 1, Russias best-known ultraconservative ideologue, Aleksandr Dugin, declared that Ukraines leadership and their puppet masters in the Western intelligence services had surely organized the attack.

It was an effort to undermine trust in the president, Mr. Dugin said, and it showed regular Russians that they had no choice but to unite behind Mr. Putins war against Ukraine.

Mr. Dugins daughter was killed in a car bombing near Moscow in 2022 that U.S. officials said was indeed authorized by parts of the Ukrainian government, but without American involvement.

U.S. officials have said there is no evidence of Ukrainian involvement in the concert hall attack, and Ukrainian officials ridiculed the Russian accusations. Andriy Yusov, a representative of Ukraines military intelligence agency, said Mr. Putins claim that the attackers had fled toward Ukraine and intended to cross into it, with the help of the Ukrainian authorities, made no sense.

In recent months, Mr. Putin has appeared more confident than at any other point since he launched his full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Russian forces have retaken the initiative on the front line, while Ukraine is struggling amid flagging Western support and a shortage of troops.

Inside Russia, the election  and its predetermined outcome  underscored Mr. Putins dominance over the nations politics.

Mr. Kynev, the political scientist, said he believed many Russians were now in shock, because restoring order has always been Vladimir Putins calling card.

Mr. Putins early years in power were marked by terrorist attacks, culminating in the Beslan school siege in 2004; he used those violent episodes to justify his rollback of political freedoms. Before Friday, the most recent mass-casualty terrorist attack in the capital region was a suicide bombing at an airport in Moscow in 2011 that killed 37 people.

Still, given the Kremlins efficacy in cracking down on dissent and the news media, Mr. Kynev predicted that the political consequences of the concert hall attack would be limited, as long as the violence was not repeated.

To be honest, he said, our society has gotten used to keeping quiet about inconvenient topics.

Constant Mheut contributed reporting.

title: IS claims killing 30 soldiers in Niger ambush
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has claimed the killing of "at least 30" soldiers in an ambush in Niger's western Tillaberi region on 20 March. The attack had prompted the government to declare three days of mourning.
body:
IS issued the claim on 23 March on behalf of its Sahel Province branch, and through its Telegram channels.

A slightly more detailed report on the attack was issued via the same channels by IS's "news agency" Amaq. A screen caption indicated that the photo shown in the statement (above) was not related to the latest attack.

The Amaq statement claimed that "at least 30" Niger soldiers had been killed in an ambush targeting a military patrol on 20 March near the village of Teguey in Niger. Other soldiers were wounded, while the remainder fled, IS claimed.

The statement added that militants burnt eight military vehicles and seized an additional vehicle, along with weapons and ammunition.

Amaq boasted that Niger's government had declared three days mourning due to its "major losses".

A statement by Niger's Defence Minister said that troops were ambushed by around 100 jihadists, armed with bombs and bomb-rigged vehicles, between the villages of Teguey and Bankilare, during a counter-insurgency operation. He confirmed that around 30 troops were killed in the incident.

The IS statement said that the ambush was staged with "various weapons", making no mention of the possible use of booby-trapped vehicles or explosive devices.

Since Niger's July 2023 military coup, IS has claimed a number of major attacks in the west of the country.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2055 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: IS central media issues statement for Russia attack with no 'branch' affiliation
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group's central media has finally issued a statement on the subject of the attack on a concert hall near Moscow on 22 March, for which the group's news outlet Amaq had earlier clamed responsibility.
body:
In the latest statement from IS's central media outlet, issued on 23 March, the group did not attribute the attack to any of its global branches.

In the place where IS typically refers to the name of the responsible branch, it simply had the word "Russia", with no "wilayah" (branch) affiliation. (BBCM has highlighted this section in the image above.)

This is not uncommon. IS publishes such non-branch claims in countries where it does not regularly carry out attacks. This was the case with the Iran attacks in January 2024, where IS did not indicate the involvement of a regional branch and simply had the word "Iran" in the claim.

IS typically operates in Russia under the banner of its low-profile Caucuses Province branch. Many analysts and authorities have speculated that the Russia attack was orchestrated by IS's Afghanistan-focused Khorasan Province branch (ISKP or ISIS-K). The group has not linked the attack to either branch.

This could be deliberate, to avoid having any of its regional branches come under scrutiny and fire, or it could be because the attack was carried out by IS operatives not linked to these branches. 

The latest statement did not offer a lot of new information nor indicated the fate of the four attackers. 

But it did deliver a message of threat to Russia "and its allies".

It said, "and let Crusader Russia and its allies know that the mujahidin do not forget their revenge".

This is possibly a reference to Russia's involvement in military operations against IS in Syria, particularly in the central Homs province. It may also be a reference to past and recent Russian crackdowns on IS operatives in Russia and its republics. 

For earlier IS statements about the attack, see here and here.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1429 GMT 23 Mar 24

title: IS claims killing 13 Christians in DR Congo
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has claimed killing 13 "Christians" and abducting two others in an attack in DR Congo's eastern North Kivu province.
body:
IS issued the claim on 23 March via its Telegram channels, in the name of its "Central Africa Province" branch (ISCAP). The "urgent" styling of the claim indicates that the attack likely occurred on the same day.

The statement said that militants attacked a "Christian" village identified as "Sayu" in Beni district. Militants "beheaded" 13 Christians and abducted two others, as well as burning six motorcycles, the statement added.

The attack has not been observed to receive media coverage.

Beni district has tended to be at the epicentre of IS activity in DR Congo, which has seen increasing numbers of attacks directed against Christians.

See: Analysis: Surge in IS attacks on DR Congo Christians

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1702 gmt 23 Mar 24

title: IS claims killing nine soldiers in Quirimba Island, Mozambique
snippet:
By BBC Monitoring

Islamic State group (IS) has belatedly claimed responsibility for an attack in the Quirimba Island in northern Mozambique, saying nine soldiers were killed in the IS raid of 3 March.
body:
Quirimba Island in the Quirimbas Archipelago is an area where IS had not been known to operate before. While the group's supporters and some local news outlets earlier said that the jihadist group had captured some or parts of the island on 3 March, IS itself made no such claim in its first comment on the subject.

IS issued the claim on 7 March through its weekly newspaper al-Naba (issue 433), via the messaging app Telegram. 

It said that on 3 March, Mozambican armed forces tried to advance on IS positions in Quirimba Island, prompting clashes between the two sides that allegedly led to the killing of two soldiers.

Another two soldiers died drowning as they "fled to their boats" to escape the militants, according to al-Naba.

The remaining five, the IS mouthpiece continued, were captured and later shot dead by the jihadists.

The publication featured a picture to illustrate the execution-style killing of the five soldiers, four of whom were dressed in military fatigues, all sat on a beach. 

Local media outlets said that "at least" eight soldiers were killed by militants in Quirimba "since the occupation of the island on 2 March".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2350 GMT 7 Mar 24
